The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p:
THe ≈øonne of God ≈øpake the≈øe words at the houre of his death vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, as if he would ≈øay. O my eternal, iu≈øt, & holy father, the fir≈øt thing that I reque≈øt of thee on this cro≈ø≈øe is that thou woulde≈øt forgiue all the≈øe, which take my life from me, ≈øeeing they know not how highly they offend thy goodnes & clemencie. O great God of I≈øraell, I giue thee many thanks, for that thou ha≈øt endued me with the vertue of prudence, by the which I haue learned to doe my ≈øelfe good by the enemies which per≈øecute me, and forgiue them the iniuries which they haue done vnto me. For the better vnder≈øtaÃÑ ding of that which Chri≈øt ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and of that which Dauid vttered in this P≈øalme, it is to bee vnder≈øtood, that among≈øt all the Cardinall vertues, the fir≈øt and chiefe≈øt is, Prudence, becau≈øe that without her, iu≈øtice endeth in cruelty, temperancie in weakene≈ø≈øe, ≈øloth and idlene≈ø≈øe; fortitude in tyranny, might and power in pride, boldne≈ø≈øe in folly and madne≈ø≈øe, and knowledge and skill in malice. is broken, ruleth and gouerneth that which is pre≈øent, prouideth for that which is to come, redre≈ø≈øeth that which is ami≈ø≈øe, and mainteineth that which is well done. E≈øchines the great orator ≈øayth, I haue known many Grecians of my time which were eloquent in that which they ≈øpake, ≈øubtile in that they inuented, bold in that which they tooke in hand, wary in their doings, clo≈øe and di≈ø≈øembled in that they went about to haue, and al≈øo mode≈øt in their behauior, which notwith≈øtanding for want of a little wi≈øedome and prudence lo≈øt all in one houre. Socrates ≈øaid oft vnto his ≈øchollers, that they were not tied and bound wholly vnto the letter of that which he taught them: for I am your mai≈øter ≈øaid he, to tell you only what you are to doe, but prudence mu≈øt afterward teach you when you are to doe it, and how you are to doe it, and whether you are to doe it or not; and if you are to doe it, then why are you to doe it. Cicero to Atticus ≈øayth, Thou art not to call him wi≈øe which hath ≈øeene much, read much, and knoweth much, but him onely who knoweth how to v≈øe it well, and apply it in time and place: for there is nothing more preiudicial to a Commonwealth then to be gouerned by one which hath great knowledge and ≈ømall wi≈øedome. red heared, low of ≈øtature, ≈øtrong in forces, and aboue all very con≈øiderate and wi≈øe in his words. It is much to bee noted that the holy ≈øcripture doth not commend Dauid, for that he ≈øhewed wi≈ødome in his behauiour and countenance or in gouernment, but only in ≈øpeaking, becau≈øe there is no one thing whereby a man is knowne to bee endued with the vertue of prudence and wi≈ødome more than by the words he vttereth with his mouth. Seneca ≈øayth, That all the things of this life haue a place of remaining, & a being, in which they are maintained, and time in which they are made, a qualitie and condition vnto which they incline, and an end where they re≈øt: which wee ≈øay by rea≈øon of ≈øpeaking, in the which al≈øo is required a conuenient time for that which we are to vtter, and order in knowing how to ≈øpeake. Vae mihi quia tacui, ≈øaid the Prophet Ieremy, as if hee would ≈øay, Woe be to me, woe bee to me O mighty God of I≈øraell, for all the ≈øins which I haue known, and all the naughtine≈ø≈øe which I haue concealed and di≈ø≈øembled, the which if I had reuealed would haue been amended, and the which if I had di≈øcouered ≈øhould haue ben puni≈øhed. To come then to our purpo≈øe, all this long di≈øcour≈øe which we haue made is to proue,
that the ≈øonne of God was very patient in holding his peace, and very di≈øcreet in ≈øpeaking: for he neuer ≈øpake vnle≈ø≈øe therby hee thought hee ≈øhould doe good, nor did neuer hold his peace, vnles he thought that ≈øcaÃÑdale ≈øhould ri≈øe of his ≈øpeech, B ‚Ä¢ de ≈øayth vpon the≈øe words, d ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ ine verba vitae habes, That the ≈øon of God was ≈øo di≈øcreet and wary in his words, that he neuer opened his mouth vnle≈ø≈øe it were to preach, nor neuer held his peace vnle≈ø≈øe it were to pray. Chri≈øts owne enemies reported openly of him, Qu√≤d nunqu√†m homo ≈øic loquutus e≈øt, that no man euer ≈øpake as hee ≈øpake: for he neuer murmured again≈øt any man, he neuer accu≈øed any man, nor iniuried any for iniury done vnto him. S. Barnard ≈øayth; O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, redeemer of my ≈øoule, the Prophet ≈øaith very well of thee, Ignitum eloquium tuum, con≈øidering that all thy holy words moued vs to pitty, ≈øtirred vs to charity, inuited vs to goodnes, trode downe wickedne≈ø≈øe, prouoked teares, conuerted Commonwealths, lightened our con≈øciences, and made our hearts meeke and gentle. They pre≈øented Chri≈øt before foure ≈øeats of iudgement the day of his holy pa≈øsion, that is before Pilate, before Herod, before the high prie≈øts hou≈øes, the Pontife Caiphas, and the tree of the cro≈ø≈øe before his father, before whom he ≈øpake onely, and in the pre≈øence of the others was for the mo≈øt part alwaies ≈øilent, and that for certaine not without a high mi≈øtery and hidden ≈øecret. The mi≈øtery then of this ≈øecret is, that he wold not an≈øwer, in the fir≈øt two Tribunals when they accu≈øed him of wickedne≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandale: but vpon the cro≈ø≈øe where he was an aduocate, he began pre≈øently to ≈øpeake and plead for vs, ≈øaying. Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them, in ≈øo much that for to excu≈øe my offences, he omitteth to an≈øwere for him≈øelfe. What meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? Thou doe≈øt not an≈øwer wheÃÑ thou art ≈øpoken vnto in that that toucheth thy ≈øelfe, and in that that concerneth mee doe≈øt thou an≈øwere not ≈øpoken vnto? Doe≈øt thou make interce≈øsion for my fault, & doe≈øt thou not remember thy owne life? Who but thou did euer excu≈øe tho≈øe which accu≈øed him, and defend them which condemne
him? An≈øelmus in his meditations ≈øayth, O quam ignitum e≈øt eloquium tuum, My ≈øweet Ie≈øus ≈øeeing that on the cro≈ø≈øe thou didde≈øt excu≈øe mee which was in the fault, and returned≈øt no an≈øwere for thy ≈øelf being without fault, the which thou did≈øt being enflamed with loue, and very full of griefe: Now that thou doe≈øt intreat, now that thou doe≈øt craue, why doe≈øt thou not entreat thy good father that hee would mitigate thy griefes, as well as forgiue ≈øinners? Ha≈øt thou no pittie of thy owne holy members which are loo≈øed one from another, and ha≈øt thou it towards thy enemies which are not as yet conuerted vnto thee? Seeing thou art a≈øwell bound to defend the innocent, as make interce≈øsion for the wicked, why ha≈øt thou no pittie vpon thy owne innocent fle≈øh, a≈øwell as of my enormious crimes? Vbertinus ≈øayth, O quam vehementer e≈øt ignitum eloquium tuum, My good Lord, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt excu≈øe him who is culpable, entreate≈øt without entreaty, forgiue≈øt without ≈øatisfaction, heape≈øt vp for tho≈øe which will not repay thee, and al≈øo die≈øt for tho≈øe which haue put thee to death: Seeing the law of Mo≈øes commandeth that the malefactor ≈øhould pay a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, foot for foot, eie for eie, and life for life, why doe≈øt thou O mighty redeemer giue thy hands vnto tho≈øe which bind theÃÑ, thy feet vnto tho≈øe which pierce them with nailes, thy eies vnto tho≈øe which make thee blind, and thy life vnto tho≈øe which take thy life from thee? If thou wilt not reuenge thy iniuries, why doe≈øt thou not let iu≈øtice doe iu≈øtice vpon thy enemies? S. Barnard ≈øayth in a ≈øermon, from the time that our Sauiour was taken in the garden, vntill hee was crucified on the cro≈ø≈øe, the works which he did were many, but the words which he ≈øpake were very few; whereby hee gaue vs to vnder≈øtand, that in time of great vexations and per≈øecutions, it is fitter for vs to helpe our ≈øelues with patience than with eloquence. In this fir≈øt praier which the ≈øonne made vnto the father, it is to be noted who the father is, what that is that he asketh, of whom he asketh, when he asketh, from whence he asketh, how hee asketh, and for whome hee asketh; for by ≈øo
much the more one bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is greater than another, by how much the inconueniences are greater which it draweth after it. He who asketh is the ≈øonne, he of whom he asketh is the father, that which he asketh is pardon, the place froÃÑ whence hee asketh is the cro≈ø≈øe, the time is when hee dieth, tho≈øe for whom are his enemies, the maner how is with many teares; in ≈øo much that a praier offered vvith all the≈øe circum≈øtances, ought of great rea≈øon to be heard. This praier of Pater igno≈øce illis, Father pardon them, is a very high praier, ≈øeeing that he vvhich made it vvas the ≈øonne of God, vvho ≈øaith, Si quid petieritis patrem in nomine meo dabit vobis, And if this bee ≈øo, how is it po≈øsible, that the father ≈øhould not graunt all that which the ≈øonne reque≈øteth, ≈øeeing hee promi≈øeth to giue all things that ≈øhall be demanded in his name? If this be a great praier by rea≈øon of him which maketh it, it is al≈øo a very great & high praier by rea≈øon of him vnto whom it is made, which is, Pater mi≈øericordiaruÃÑ & deus totus con≈øolationis, The father of mercies and the God of all comfort: the vvhich eternall father created vs vvith his power, guideth and gouerneth vs vvith his vvi≈øedome, ≈øu≈øtaineth and vpholdeth vs with his e≈ø≈øence, and forgiueth vs with his elemency, how is it po≈øsible that a ≈øonne vvhich hath ≈øuch a father, or a father vvhich hath ≈øuch a ≈øonne ≈øhould not grant his demand? This praier of Pater igno≈øce illis, was al≈øo very great becau≈øe of the place vvhere it was made, which was in the mount of Caluarie, and on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, vvhere the vvrath of the eternall father was appea≈øed, his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øonne put to death, the vvicked deuil ouercome, the old ≈øinne forgiuen, and all the world there redeemed. S. Ambro≈øe vpon S. Luke ≈øayth, how much the Iewes di≈øhonoured the holy temple, ≈øo much Chri≈øt honored the Mount of Caluary; for they made a den of theeues of the hou≈øe of praier, and the ≈øonne of God made a hou≈øe of praier, of a den of theeues. O good Ie≈øus what is there now that thou doe≈øt not make cleane, what doe≈øt thou not renue, what doe≈øt thou not ≈øanctifie, what doe≈øt thou not make holy, ≈øeeing thou wente≈øt to the Mount of Caluary to pray for
≈øinners, which before was infamous, by rea≈øon of execution done there vpon malefactors? The ≈øonne of God praying on the infamous and ≈øtinking place of the Mount of Caluary, giueth all men licen≈øe to pray vnto God, where they will, and how they will, and for whome ≈øo euer they will, becau≈øe the perfection of praier, doth not con≈øi≈øt of the place where wee pray, but of the ≈ømall or great deuotion with the which wee pray: According vnto that which the Samaritane woman ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt. That many Iews would not pray but within the temple; and it may bee to take away this error wee doe read that the ≈øon of God did not pray there, but preach only; which our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour did becau≈øe no man ≈øhould excu≈øe him≈øelfe from praier & deuotion, ≈øaying that the temple was ≈øhut vp. Vbertinus ≈øaith, that the ≈øonne of God is not a≈øhamed to pray, Pater igno≈øce illis, on the dunghill of the Mount of Caluary; and art thou a≈øhamed to pray alone in thy hou≈øe? O what a high charge and office the office of meditation and praieris, con≈øidering that Chri≈øt his being naked on the cro≈ø≈øe with his handes bound and tied, his feet peirced with nailes, his head crowned with thornes, his mouth ≈øea≈øoned with vineger, did not hinder him to pray, Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them: and ≈øeeing hee pardoned and forgaue with his heart, and praied with his tongue.

div.head: CHAP. II. How the ≈øonne of God ≈øaid vnto his father, that tho≈øe which crucifie him, be not his enemies but his friends.
div.p:
QVid ≈øunt plagae istae in medio manuum tuarum, his plagatus ≈øum in dom ‚Ä¢ eorum qui me diligebant, ≈øaid God by the Prophet Zachary in the thirteenth chapter, as if he would ≈øay, Who hath giuen thee the≈øe cruell wounds in the midde≈øt of thy hands; the Prophet an≈øwered and ≈øaid, Lord, they wounded mee thus, in the hou≈øe of tho≈øe which loued mee much. The≈øe words were not ≈øpoken
voluntarily, nor of euery man, ≈øeeing they cannot be applied, neither to the nature of mankind nor of angell, becau≈øe men are not wont to receiue ≈øtripes and words in their friends hou≈øes, but in their enemies. The Prophet toucheth a new thing, and a high my≈øtery, in ≈øaying that he was whipped and wounded in the hou≈øe of his well-willers, and therefore it is needfull for vs to lift vp our vnder≈øtanding, to di≈øcouer and reach vnto this high ≈øecret, becau≈øe that high my≈øteries are fit only for heroicall and high per≈øons. This demand and this an≈øwere, pa≈ø≈øed on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, betwixt the eternall father which asked, and his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øonne which an≈øwered: who [not being content to entreat only for his enemies, ≈øaying: Pater, Father forgiue them] would al≈øo haue excu≈øed them, and take all blame from them, in ≈øaying, Ne≈øciunt quid faciunt, They know not what they doe: the father ≈øaid vnto him, Quid ≈øunt plagae i≈øtae? ≈øo ≈øaid the father vnto his ≈øon, which is as much as to ≈øay, O my ≈øon if thou doe≈øt ≈øay, that none of the≈øe Iewes, are guiltie and culpable of thy death and pa≈øsion, I pray thee tell me, who made the≈øe cruell wounds in the mid≈øt of thy tender hands? The ≈øon an≈øwered his father, His plagatus ≈øum, in domo eorum qui me diligebant, which is as much as to ≈øay; O holy and eternall father, I receiued the≈øe wounds which thou ≈øee≈øt in my tender hands, in the hou≈øe of tho≈øe which were my friends: and if I be ioifull in receiuing them, why art not thou glad in forgiuing them? Thou knowe≈øt well O my father, that nothing can be called an iniury in this world, but only that which is done again≈øt our proper will. If I die by thy commandement, and to obey thy will, and becau≈øe ≈øo it is needfull for the world, why ≈øhould I call them enemies which execute thy commandements? Giue me leaue O my father, giue me leaue ≈øeeing I mu≈øt die, to ≈øell my death deerely, giue me leaue, ≈øeeing I lo≈øe my life to employ it well, which I ≈øhall thinke well be≈øtowed, if thou pardon tho≈øe which take my life from mee, and haue pitie on tho≈øe which offend thee: for what doth it auaile, that I die for ≈øinners, if thou wilt not forgiue them their ≈øinnes? Thou knowe≈øt O
my good father, that by pardoning and ≈øuffering, the redemption of the vvorld mu≈øt bee vvrought. If thou ≈øhoulde≈øt not be ≈øatisfied vvith the death vvhich I ≈øuffer, and with the life vvhich I offer thee; in giuing mee another life, I vvould offer it vnto thee, & giuing me another death, I vvould accept it, to the end O my good father, that thou ≈øhould≈øt be wholly appea≈øed, and all mankind pardoned. O euerla≈øting goodne≈ø≈øe, O infinite charitie, O in≈øpeakable clemency ≈øhowne in this an≈øwere, calling that a hou≈øe of friends vvhich was a fortre≈ø≈øe of enemies, and going about to excu≈øe tho≈øe vvhich he ≈øhould accu≈øe, and in purpo≈øing to appea≈øe him, vvhome hee ≈øhould haue ≈øtirred vp to vvrath and indignation. Fulgencius vpon this place ≈øayth, Notwith≈øtanding all the enemies and per≈øecutors vvhich the ≈øonne of God had in this vvorld, yet he neuer v≈øed this vvord Enemie: vvhich is euident by this demand of his fathers, vvho asking him vvhere hee had ben ≈øo euilly handled and wounded, ≈øought out a new deui≈øe becau≈øe he vvould auoid this vvord of enemy, and lay the fault vpon his friend rather than confe≈ø≈øe that he had any enemies, becau≈øe God vvas vvont to haue many familiar friends in the hou≈øe of the ≈øynagogue, vvhich vvere holy men: our ble≈ø≈øed ≈øauiour vvould not account of the iniuries vvhich the Iewes did pre≈øently vnto him, nor of the vvounds vvhich they gaue him, but re≈øpected rather the ≈øeruices vvhich the old Patriarkes had done vnto him. It is greatly to be noted and weighed, that in the an≈øwere vvhich the ≈øonne gaue vnto the father, he did not ≈øay that he had been vvounded in the hou≈øe of tho≈øe vvhich then loued him, but in the hou≈øe of tho≈øe vvhich vvere vvont to loue him, for hee ≈øayth, In domo eorum qui me diligebant, and not qui me diligunt, & yet notwith≈øtanding all this, he doth not only, not call them enemies, but telleth his father that they did vnto him the vvorks of friends. What meaneth this O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, vvhat meaneth this? If tho≈øe of the hou≈øe of I≈øraell vvere thine, in times pa≈øt, I pray thee didde≈øt not thou vnto them more good turns than they did ≈øeruices vnto thee? If thou doe≈øt reckon of the ≈øeruices
which the fathers did vnto the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a thou≈øand years agoe, why doe≈øt thou not make account of the vvounds, vvhich their children gaue thee not longer than one houre agone? O good Ie≈øus, O redeemer of my ≈øoule vvhat humane iudgement, yea vvhat angels vnder≈øtanding is able to conceaue or reach vnto this, vvhy thou ≈øhoulde≈øt rather re≈øpect old ≈øeruices, vvhich ordinarily other men forget, than thy owne iniuries vvhich run fre≈øhly from thy blood like ≈øtreames? Seeing we haue already told you vvho praied, vvhich vvas the ≈øon; and vnto whome he praied, vvhich vvas the father; and vvhere hee praied, to vvit vpon the cro≈ø≈øe: it is time now to tell you vvhat praier he made, and for whom he praied, for ≈øeeing the ≈øonne of God betooke him≈øelfe to praier in ≈øuch a narrow extremitie, it is to be thought, that hee entreated ≈øome great and vveighty matter. Vbertinus ≈øayth, That vvhen the diuine vvord vvas nailed vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, as it vvere almo≈øt dead, hauing his fle≈øh pierced vvith nailes, & his bowels burning vvith the loue of charitie, forgetting his owne ≈øelfe, and hauing his enemies in remembrance, lifting vp his holy eies vnto heauen, ≈øaid, Pater igno≈øce illis, qui ne≈øciunt quid faciunt, vvhich is as much as to ≈øay, O my eternall and ble≈ø≈øed father, in recompence of my comming into the vvorld, preaching thy name, appea≈øing thy vvrath, reconciling thee vnto the vvorld, I de≈øire of thee this one thing for a ≈øpiritual guerdon, and reward of all my trauailes, that is, that thou vvoulde≈øt pardon the≈øe ≈øinfull Iewes, father I am very vvell plea≈øed, that thou vvoulde≈øt not yeeld vnto my naturall de≈øire of life, vvhen I praied vnto thee in the garden, if it vvould now plea≈øe thee to heare mee in praying for them: for I thinke it a farre greater benefit that they liue in their ≈øoules, than a hurt vnto me to die in body. Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them, for I die becau≈øe they ≈øinned, and if I die it is becau≈øe they may liue: and in ≈øo difficult a matter as this, it is far greater rea≈øon that thou haue more regard vnto my new death, than vnto their old fault. Father forgiue them, ≈øeeing the death vvhich preuailed on the wood, I haue here crucified
with mee vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, the vvhich being ≈øo it is far greater rea≈øon, that thou e≈øteeme more of the charitie vvith the vvhich I die for them, than of their malice vvith the vvhich they put me to death. Father forgiue them, for if thou vvilt puni≈øh the≈øe Iewes with all rigour of iu≈øtice, it will bee but a ≈ømall puni≈øhment to condemne them for euer to hell: but if thou doe≈øt otherwi≈øe, as there was neuer any wickedne≈ø≈øe done like vnto this, ≈øo likewi≈øe thou ≈øhalt neuer be≈øtow thy accu≈øtomed mercy like as in forgiuing the≈øe their offences. Father forgiue them, for if my death be ≈øufficient to redeeme all tho≈øe which ≈øhall hereafter be borne, or be already borne, it is not rea≈øon that the≈øe vnhappy Iewes ≈øhould vvant the benefit of it, and ≈øo much the more becau≈øe that if my blood be ≈øhed by thy holy will and con≈øent it would be rea≈øon that it ≈øhould bee well emploied by thee. Forgiue them O my father forgiue them, for ≈øeeing the partie iniuried (which am I) do pardon the iniury, why wilt not thou O my father pardon that which concerneth thy iu≈øtice? What hath iu≈øtice to doe there, where there is no complaint of one again≈øt another? Father forgiue them, ≈øeeing the time is now come whereof the Prophet ≈øpeaketh, Tempus mi≈øerendi deus tempus mi≈øerendi, Time of forgiuing good Lord, a time of forgiuing: it is neither iu≈øt nor rea≈øonable that rigor ≈øhould take place there, where mercie by thee hath ben publickely proclaimed. If it be true as true it is, that, mi≈øericordia & veritas obuiuerunt ≈øibi, and al≈øo that iu≈øticia & pax o≈øculatae ≈øunt, Why wilt thou execute iu≈øtice vpon this people, ≈øeeing the Prophet ≈øayth, that peace and iu≈øtice haue embraced one the other. Father forgiue them, ≈øeeing I aske it in the end of my life, and intreat thee at the houre of my death, thou mu≈øt thinke my father that it behooueth me very much, that they be pardoned, becau≈øe that by my example none ≈øhould pre≈øume to call him≈øelfe my ≈øeruant, in my church, if he doe not reconcile him≈øelfe fir≈øt vnto his brother. Father forgiue theÃÑ, for ≈øeeing the old law endeth when I ≈øhal ≈øay, Con≈øummatum e≈øt, All is fini≈øhed; and the new law beginneth when I ≈øhall
≈øay, Commendo ≈øpiritum meum, I commend my ≈øpirit, it would not be rea≈øonable that vnder the law of Grace, we ≈øhould coÃÑ ≈øent that any thing ≈øhould be vnfitting or vn≈øit, nor that vnder the law of Loue, wee ≈øhould permit ranckor and malice. Father forgiue them; for if in the wilderne≈ø≈øe of Aaron, wheÃÑ thou wa≈øt angry vvith all the Iewes, thou didde≈øt forgiue them, and reconcile them vnto thee for no other cau≈øe but only becau≈øe Mo≈øes and Aaron did offer a little incen≈øe vnto thee: why wilt thou not forgiue them now, ≈øeeing I doe now offer for them, not incen≈øe, but my ≈øelfe crucified? Father forgiue them, for ≈øeeing they bee thy creatures by creation, thy clients by law, my children by redemption, my brethren by bloud, my acquaintance by education, my followers in doctrine, and ≈øo neare of kindred vnto my di≈øciples; why ≈øhould I con≈øent to their lo≈ø≈øe and condemnation? Father forgiue them, ≈øeeing I came not into the vvorld to procure thee enemies, but to giue thee new friends, and to take thy old griefes and ≈øorrowes from thee: for otherwi≈øe if by my death, this people ≈øhould remaine in thy di≈øgrace and hatred, it would ≈øeeme that my death, would rather moue thee to indignation, than appea≈øe thy wrath. If my death make not an attonement betwixt you, who is able to doe it? O my good father when thou didde≈øt command me to come downe from heauen, and al≈øo to die vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, didde≈øt not thou promi≈øe and agree, that thy anger and my life, and my life and thy anger ≈øhould haue an end at the ≈øame houre? Father forgiue them, and fulfill thy agreement, giue that which thou ha≈øt promi≈øed, and ≈øeeing in thy pre≈øence my life is deerer vnto thee than thy anger, I am glad and willing to die, if by that meanes thy ire may bee appea≈øed. O ble≈ø≈øed praier, O holy wi≈øh and reque≈øt, neuer heard of before! O happie petition, which thou made≈øt ≈øweet Ie≈øus in thy la≈øt houre, wherein thou didde≈øt ≈øhew by deeds all that thou hadde≈øt preached with words, ≈øeeing thou didde≈øt entreat for tho≈øe which put thee to death, & aske pardon for tho≈øe which crucified thee. Let all the praiers bee brought forth, that euer were made
in the world, and we ≈øhall ea≈øily perceiue, that there was neuer any equall vnto this praier of Chri≈øts: for there was neuer any which had that intent which hee had, nor asked that which hee asked, nor compa≈ø≈øed that which hee compa≈ø≈øed. What did the great Patriarch Iacob reque≈øt of Laban his father in law, but only his faire daughter Rachel for his ≈øpou≈øe? What did the women of I≈øraell demaund of the women of Aegypt ≈øaue only their ≈øiluer and gold? What did Anna Helcans wife and Samuels mother, reque≈øt of God in the temple, ≈øauing only that it would plea≈øe him to giue her a ≈øon? What did the Iew maid called Axa aske of her father Calaph but only the pa≈øture which held water, becau≈øe the other which hee had giuen her was drie? What did the mother of the Zebedees require of Chri≈øt, but onely that hee would make them the greate≈øt lords of his kingdome? Which of all the≈øe doe aske any thing of God for their enemies, or yet for their friendes? Euery man did aske for that which was fitte≈øt for his owne turn, euery man ≈øought for that which was good for him≈øelfe, no man entreated for his neighbour, no man remembred his enemie, no man made interce≈øsion for another, no man loaded him≈øelfe with other mens faults. Only the ≈øon of God made man, praieth for his enemies in the la≈øt ≈øupper, ≈øaying; Pater, keepe tho≈øe which beleeue in me: and praieth al≈øo vpon the cro≈ø≈øe for his enemies, ≈øaying: Pater igno≈øce illis, ≈øo that like a mercifull lord he defendeth the good, and pardoneth the wicked.

div.head: CHAP. III. How the ≈øon of God put him≈øelf a mediator betwixt God and mankind, and what torment he receiued thereby.
div.p:
QVae≈øiui de eis virum qui interpeneret ≈øepem, & ≈øtaret oppo≈øitus contra me: the≈øe are the words of the great God of I≈øraell, ≈øpoken to the Prophet Ezechiell being in the captiuitie of Babilon, not far from the
riuer Cobar in the two and twentith chapter of his prophe≈øie. And it is as if he would ≈øay, Ezechiell I haue beene many a day angrie with Ieru≈øalem, and I ≈øeeke out a holy and a vertuous man, which ≈øhould put him≈øelfe like a hedge betwixt mee and the people of I≈øraell, becau≈øe their offences might not come vnto mee, nor my puni≈øhment reach vnto them. Wee may inferre of the complaint which our Lord maketh in this place, what great ≈øcar≈øitie there was in the ≈øynagogue, of good men, ≈øeeing he found not one among them all which was worthie to appea≈øe the wrath of the Lord, and to helpe and ≈øuccour the people. The merites of good men are of great force and power before God, for to pardon the euill in their faith, which is ea≈øily ≈øeene in all the cities of Sodome which he did pardon for ten good mens ≈øake, and all the twelue tribes of I≈ørael which he pardoned for one alone: but ala≈ø≈øe neither in the ≈øynagogue was there found that one, neither in Sodome tho≈øe ten. To ≈øay the truth it was no maruaile that hee was not to be found in all the ≈øynagogue, with tho≈øe conditions, which God required in him: for he ought to haue ben a man in di≈øcretion and not a child, and the Lord him≈øelfe was to make choice of him and no other, and he was to be an Hebrew and not a Gentile, & he was to put him≈øelfe a mediator betwixt God and the people, and it was required that he ≈øhould be partiall on neither ≈øide. And our Lord was not content onely with this, but that mediator ought al≈øo to haue de≈øert and merit in him, to appea≈øe Gods indignation, and not ≈øinne to ≈øtirre him to wrath. S. Gregory vpon Ezechiell ≈øayth, I doubt whether a man endued with the≈øe conditions, and ≈øhining with the≈øe vertues, might bee found among≈øt the Angelicall Hierarchies, how much le≈ø≈øe among humane creatures, becau≈øe ≈øuch a one ≈øhould bee more than man, yea he ≈øhould be equall with God. Abraham, I≈øaac, Iacob, and Dauid, and all the letanie of the old and new te≈øtament, were not equall with God, nor any thing more then men, ≈øeeing they were borne in ≈øinne, and attained vnto no diuine ≈øecret without it were reuealed vnto them. The ≈øonne of God only was
equall vnto God, and the diuine vvord only vvas more than man, becau≈øe in him, and in no other, tho≈øe coÃÑditions of a holy man were found which God ≈øought for, and the vertues which ≈øhould paci≈øie God his wrath and anger. The fir≈øt condition which God required, was, that this mediator ≈øhould be a man in wi≈ødome, and not a child, which may better bee verified in Chri≈øt than in any other, ≈øeeing that from the fir≈øt in≈øtant that he tooke humane fle≈øh vpon him he ≈øaw the deuine e≈ø≈øence, and knew as much as hee dooth now in glorie, vvhich is not ≈øo in other men, ≈øeeing they are long a bringing vp, and vvaxe old very timely. The ≈øonne of God vvas al≈øo an Hebrue of the tribe of Iuda a vvhich vvas the mo≈øt honourable ≈øtocke of all the tribes, and hee vvas of Nazareth vvhich vvas a holy land: and he vvas al≈øo the mo≈øt honourable of all his kindred. Thirdly, the ≈øonne of God vvas be≈øt beloued of his father becau≈øe of him, and of no other, he ≈øaid in his bapti≈øme. Hic est filius meus dilectus, as if hee vvould ≈øay, This is only my lawful child, in him only am I vvel plea≈øed, this only is my heire, him onely I doe tender and loue, in him I delight, and take great contentment. Fourthly, the ≈øon of God vvas a very thicke mud vvall, a clo≈øe hedge, vvhich put him≈øelfe betwixt God and the people, vvhen he ≈øuffered him≈øelfe to bee crucified vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, vpon the vvhich as ≈øtrong battelments they di≈øcharged all the ≈øinnes vvhich vvere in the vvorld, and all the wrath vvhich God had. O glorious hedge, O happie vvall, O ≈øtrong vvounds, ≈øuch vva≈øt thou O redeemer of my ≈øoule, ≈øeeing thou didde≈øt permit, and con≈øent to put thy ≈øelfe a mediator betwixt God & man, to the end they ≈øhould vnlode and put vpon thee all the ≈øins of the vvorld, and all the vengeance vvhich God vvas to take for them. S. Gregory vpon Ezechiell ≈øayth, The ≈øonne of God only vvas the man he ≈øought for, this vvas the vvall he required, this vvas the mediator he asked for, this is the pacifier of the old quarrell, and of Gods vvrath, this is the reformer of new grace, and this is the ouerthrower of the old ≈øinne. S. Ierome vpon this place ≈øayth. The man vvhich God ≈øought
by Ezechiel, who el≈øe was hee, but the ≈øon of the liuing God, and our redeemer? Who like vnto an vnexpugnable wall, did put him≈øelfe boldly betwixt God and vs, ≈øaying, Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them. By which words, he did not like, that our ≈øinnes ≈øhould come into the ≈øight of God, neither ≈øuffered he Gods wrath and vengeance to de≈øcend vpon vs. Origen vpon S. Marke ≈øayth, That wheÃÑ the two chiefe captaines of the ≈øynagogue, Mo≈øes and Aaron, perceiued that the Lord began to poure his wrath and anger vpon the people, they went immediatly vnto the tabernacle, the one to pray, and the other to doe ≈øacrifice to be a mean betwixt God and them; becau≈øe that otherwi≈øe, God would haue poured out his anger vpon them, & the Synagogue haue receiued great hurt and detriment. That which happened vnto tho≈øe two holy men in the de≈øart happened vnto Chri≈øt on the mount of Caluarie, who ≈øeeing the elements to be troubled, and the dead to ri≈øe againe, to reuenge his death and puni≈øh that nation, he made him≈øelfe a mediator and a ≈øtikeler betwixt God and them, and praied, Paterigno≈øce illis, as if hee would ≈øay, Pardon them my father, pardon them; for if thou wilt not pardon them, it will bee a greater griefe vnto me to ≈øee them lo≈øt, then my pa≈øsion which cau≈øeth mee to die. What would become of the Iewes then, if Chri≈øt had not ≈øaid vnto his father, father forgiue them, and what ≈øhould betide vs now if he ≈øhould not ≈øay. Pater parce illis, Spare them father. S. Barnard ≈øaith in a ≈øermon, That this word of Igno≈øce illis, Forgiue them, is of ≈øuch a deepe con≈øideration, that it ≈øhould neuer be out of a ≈øinners mouth, nor blotted out of his memory: becau≈øe that the ≈øonne of God did ≈øhew his mercy more vnto vs in two things theÃÑ in al the re≈øt: that is, in the pardon which he got vs of his father, and in the bloud which he ≈øhed for vs on the cro≈ø≈øe. An≈øelmus rea≈øoning with Chri≈øt ≈øayth, What doe≈øt thou crie for, what doe≈øt thou aske, what doe≈øt thou intreat for, what wilt thou, what ≈øeeke≈øt thou, what ≈øaie≈øt thou to thy father O good Ie≈øus, what ≈øaie≈øt thou? I intreat O my father, that thou woulde≈øt forgiue them, becau≈øe they know
not what they do, and that thou woulde≈øt load my fle≈øh with thy anger; and I intreat that there remaine nothing vnteconciled vnto thee, becau≈øe that my redemption would ≈øeem vnperfect and in≈øufficient, if there ≈øhould remaine in any a fault to bee redeemed, and in thy ≈øelfe any anger to puni≈øh vs. O what an enflamed charity, what a wonderfull example, what incredible patience, what entire loue thou didde≈øt ≈øhew vs O ≈øweet Ie≈øus in this ≈øpeech of, Father forgiue them, the which thou didde≈øt vtter not for an ea≈øe to thy griefe, but in fauour of thy per≈øecutors! O what infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, what vn≈øpeakable clemencie, what ≈øtrange charitie doth ≈øhine this day in thee O my Ie≈øus and ≈øauiour, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt loo≈øe tho≈øe which bind thee, pleade≈øt for tho≈øe which diffame thee, entreate≈øt for tho≈øe which accu≈øe thee, excu≈øe≈øt tho≈øe which blame thee, and pardone≈øt al≈øo tho≈øe which will kill thee! What meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? doe≈øt thou pray for them at the very in≈øtant which they bla≈øpheme thee, mocke thee, and laugh thee to ≈øcorne? They haue pierced thee with a ≈øpeare, and yet doe≈øt thou giue them an acquittance and a relea≈øe of the blow? What mortall man can prai≈øe him≈øelfe or bo≈øt to haue done that which thou ha≈øt done, that is to craue pardon for murderers before they haue confe≈ø≈øed their fault, and ≈øeeke to relea≈øe them before they haue repented? They will not returne into the citie before thou ha≈øt yeelded vp the gho≈øt, and wilt not thou die before thou ha≈øt fir≈øt pardoned them? Who euer ≈øaw or heard any thing like vnto this; to wit, that pardon ≈øhould proceed fir≈øt out of his ble≈ø≈øed bowels, before the blood ≈øhould end to i≈ø≈øue out of his tender vaines? Doe≈øt thou not remember to aske a ≈øepulchre for thy body, and doe≈øt thou remember to aske forgiuene≈ø≈øe and mercie for tho≈øe which crucified thee? O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules glorie, who but thou could haue the breath going out of his body, and Igno≈øce illis Pardon them in his mouth? To defend thy ≈øelfe coulde≈øt not thou open thy mouth, and to excu≈øe thy enemies could≈øt not thou keepe it ≈øhut? S. Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øayth, The ≈øonne of God onely
was he, who on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, in≈øpeaking the≈øe words, Father forgiue them, coupled, ioined, and handfa≈øted together, pittie and cruelty, the offence and mercie, anger and patience, hatred and loue, killing and pardoning. With as great rea≈øon (≈øayth Hilarius) we can now ≈øay, Vbi ≈øunt irae tuae antiquae, as the Prophet Dauid ≈øaid, Vbi ≈øunt mi≈øericordiae tuae antiquae, ≈øeeing we bee certaine that from the houre that the ≈øon of God died vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe, we may cal him, Pater mi≈øericordiaruÃÑ, as the Synagogue called him, Deus vltionuÃÑ, The God of reuenge. No man ought to di≈øtru≈øt Chri≈øts goodne≈ø≈øe and mercie, although he haue ben neuer ≈øo great a ≈øinner, ≈øo as he liue and die a Chri≈øtian: for ≈øeeing he pardoned tho≈øe which would not bee pardoned, hee will much rather pardon tho≈øe which aske for pardon. S. Barnard as if hee were in a maze ≈øayth thus vnto Chri≈øt; O good ≈øauiour, O my ≈øoules delight, if thou wilt pardon thy death, why doe≈øt thou pardon it before thou bee dead? they tooke thy life from thee, to the end that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt forget ≈øuch a greeuous iniury done vnto thee, and make no reckoning to be reuenged. It is a tollerable thing to forgiue the iniury done vnto thy ≈øelf; but why doe≈øt thou forgiue the iniury done vnto thy ≈øorrowfull mother and thy ble≈ø≈øed father, not calling the parties offended vnto it? Thy mouth is now ready to receiue vineger, thy per≈øon to be mocked, thy ≈øide to bee pierced, thy bodie to bee buried, and yet doe≈øt thou make interce≈øsion for that wicked people? Doe≈øt thou entreat for tho≈øe which crucifie thee, and doe≈øt thou not remember tho≈øe which weepe by thee? Now that thou ha≈øt pitie on the offences of the ≈øynagogue, why ha≈øt thou not al≈øo compa≈øsion of the tears of thy ble≈ø≈øed mother? S. Cyprian vpon the pa≈øsion of our Lord ≈øayth: All things end with thee, and all for≈øake thee O ≈øweer Ie≈øus vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øauing only thy patience, with the which thou did de≈øt ≈øuffer thy torments, and thy charitie with the which thou didde≈øt forgiue thy enemies, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt pray for tho≈øe which crucifie thee, entreat for tho≈øe which bla≈øpheme thee, hold thy peace again≈øt tho≈øe which ≈øpit on thee, excu≈øe
tho≈øe which accu≈øe thee, and pardon tho≈øe which pardon not thee. O my redeemer, what a pitifull heart ha≈øt thou, that con≈øidering how the Iewes them≈øelues gaue thee licence to take reuengement on them: ≈øaying, Sanguis eius ≈øuper nos, His bloud vpon vs, yet thou didde≈øt not only not v≈øe this libertie giuen thee, but for≈øooke≈øt it, & there pardoned thy iniury. O how contrary the≈øe two ≈øpeeches are, Sanguis eius ≈øit ≈øuper nos, Let his bloud fall vpon vs, and Igno≈øce illis, Pardon them: ≈øeeing that by the fir≈øt the Iewes craue puni≈øhment of God, and in the la≈øt Chri≈øt asketh pardon of his father for them: in ≈øo much that the bloud of Chri≈øt which they asked to bee again≈øt them, the ≈øon of God asketh that it may be for them! What ha≈øt thou to do O good ≈øauiour, what ha≈øt thou to do with the Iews (≈øayth Vbertinus) and hangmen and torturers? They goe about to condemne thee, and thou to ≈øaue them; they to accu≈øe thee, and thou to excu≈øe them; they to carry thee to Pilate to bee condemned, and thou to thy father that they may be pardoned; they to ≈øay, crucifige, crucifige, crucifie him, crucifie him, and thou to ≈øay, Igno≈øce, igno≈øce, Pardon them, Pardon them. At what time the ≈øon of God hanging vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, praied on one ≈øide vnto his father, and on the other ≈øide the Hebrews praied Pilate; there was a great conflict betwixt Gods iu≈øtice and mercie: for iu≈øtice willed the praier of Sanguis eius, Let his bloud fall vpon vs, to be heard, and contrary mercy forbad it, and would haue Pater igno≈øce illis, but in the end mercie had the vpper hand, and reuengement had no part therein. Who≈øe heart ≈øaith Bonauenture would not bleed, and who would not loue thee O good Ie≈øus, to ≈øee thee ≈øay to thy father, my father forgiue them, and not my father examine them, and to ≈øee that thou doe≈øt forgiue theÃÑ without asking, yeelde≈øt vnto them without entreaty, and pardone≈øt them without amendment? It is ≈øuch a high my≈øterie ≈øayth S. Augu≈øtine, and a hidden Sacrament, to ≈øee the ≈øonne of God relea≈øe iniurie with mercie and clemencie, and not puni≈øh their crime with reuenge, and that the praier of Igno≈øce illis, Forgiue them, preuailed again≈øt that of
Sanguis eius, His bloud light vpon vs; that although it may well be rehear≈øed, yet it cannot bee well comprehended and vnder≈øtood.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of many high qualities and conditions which the praier of, Father forgiue them, had in it: and how it is meet for vs to follow it in our praiers.
div.p:
CVm clamore valido & lachrimis efferens preces & ≈øupplicatienes, exauditus e≈øt pro ≈øua reuerent ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , ≈øayth the Apo≈øtle in his Epi≈øtle to the Hebrewes, chap. 5. as if hee would ≈øay: When the ≈øonne of God was crucified: vpon the tree of the cro≈ø≈øe, hee made many reque≈øts vnto his father, & with many ≈øupplications entreated him, praying vnto him with a loud voice, and pouring down many tears before him. This praier was well heard of the eternall father, and very acceptable vnto his diuine clemencie, partly becau≈øe hee who praied was a per≈øon worthy of great reuerence, and partly becau≈øe the praier which he made was founded vpon great pitie and mercie. It appeareth well that he which praied was of an excellent and perfect condition, and hee very mighty vnto whom he praied, and that which hee praied of great merit, and the manner which hee ob≈øerued in praier a perfect platforme of praier, ≈øeeing that the Apo≈øtle in this place laieth down ≈øuch high conditions of this praier which Chri≈øt made vpon the cro≈ø≈øe. Whereof although much be ≈øpoken, yet there remaineth much more not ≈øpoken of. Fir≈øt then he ≈øaith that Chri≈øt praied once on the cro≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe he ≈øaith, Cum clamore, with a crie; and with a high and loud voice, becau≈øe he ≈øaith, valido, ≈øtrong; and that with tears Cum lachrimis; and that hee praied and offered his praier at the ≈øame time vnto his father; and that the quality of the praier was
to entreat and be≈øeech, preces & ≈øupplicationes; and that his praier was heard of his father at that very in≈øtant when hee made it, becau≈øe hee ≈øayth, & exanditus e≈øt pro ≈øua reuerentia. The condition and qualitie of the praier which the ≈øonne of God made vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, which the Apo≈øtle toucheth here, is very great and worthy to bee marked and ob≈øerued with great heed, and followed with great diligence: for if we faile in any one of the≈øe conditions, we are ≈øaid rather to crie out then to pray. Theophilus vpon the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, That when the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith that the ≈øonne of God praied with a loud voice vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, hee meaneth that hee offered and directed his praier with all his heart, and with all his will vnto God only, and vnto no other. For to ≈øay the truth, hee is ≈øaid to pray aloud, who≈øe mind is not di≈øtracted and drawne into many thoughts. When the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith that Chri≈øt praied aloud on the cro≈ø≈øe and with a ≈øtrong voice, he letteth vs vnder≈øtand with what a feruent de≈øire and great deuotion, he praied: for there is nothing reque≈øted aloud and by crying out, which is not either through abundance of loue, or ouermuch griefe. Both together forced Chri≈øt to crie out vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, that is, the great loue he bare vnto his friends, and the ouermuch paine he ≈øuffered in his members. When the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, That the ≈øonne of God offered vp praiers and ≈øupplications vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, hee declareth, as Theophilactus ≈øayth, That the praier igno≈øce illis was extended vnto the good and vnto the bad: in ≈øo much that for his enemies he offered praiers for the pardon of their ≈øinnes, and for his friends hee offered vp oblations for to confirme them in his grace. As the ≈øonne of God was Lord ouer all men and died for all men, ≈øo vpon the cro≈ø≈øe he praied for all men. For if the wicked had need of him to help them to ri≈øe, the good al≈øo had need of his helpe to keep them from falling. An≈øelmus in his meditations ≈øayth, That when the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, that the ≈øonne of God was not content to pray only with deuotion, but al≈øo offered vp that praier vnto his owne father, it is to let vs vnder≈øtand, that for the ≈øauing of all the world hee
offered vp his paines and ≈øorrowes for a recompence, his life for a ≈øatisfaction, his per≈øon for a reward, his bloud for a price, and his ≈øoule for a ≈øacrifice. It is al≈øo to bee weighed, that the ≈øonne of God made not this holy praier of Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them, ≈øitting but vpright, not being at libertie but bound, not in a low voice but aloud, not laughing but weeping, & that which is mo≈øt to be maruelled at; the words that he praied with, were very few, but the tears he bathed them with, were very many. O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øouls plea≈øure, who could be worthy to ≈øtand at the foot of thy cro≈ø≈øe, to ≈øee how thy bloud ran from the thornes, and thy tears flow from thy eies, in ≈øo much that at the ≈øame hour and moment, thou didde≈øt water the earth with tears, and pierce the heauens with ≈øighes! O what a ≈øacred word was that, O what a holy praier was Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them, ≈øeeing that it was made by the ≈øonne of God vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe accompanied with ≈øighes, wa≈øhed with the bloud of Chri≈øt, and offered vp with the tears of the redeemer! Although the ≈øonne of God reque≈øted the greate≈øt matter of his father and of the greate≈øt weight that euer was demaunded of him, that is to wit, Pardon of his precious death, yet the tears which hee ≈øhed were ≈øo many, and the loue ≈øo great with the which he asked it, that if he had asked a greater matter of him, his father would neuer haue denied it him. S. Ba≈øill ≈øayth, O what great hurt ≈øinnes bring vnto vs, con≈øidering that for to lighten vs of them, and obtaine pardon for them, it was needfull for Chri≈øt to pray vnto his father for theÃÑ, and offer oblation, and crie out, and ≈øuffer his bloud to bee ≈øhed, and tears to poure downe from his eies, ≈øo that thou O good Ie≈øus didde≈øt buy my great offences by the weight of thy bloud & tears. Our Lord when he praied for his enemies vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, taught vs what forme and fa≈øhion wee ought to keepe when wee pray, that is, to ≈øhed bloud from our members, and fall tears froÃÑ our eies. The ≈øon of God wept when he praied for his enemies, and art not thou a≈øhamed to laugh and talke, when thou praie≈øt for the remi≈øsion of thy ≈øinnes? Yea
and if thou can≈øt not weep in thy praiers, yet tel me why thou doe≈øt talke ouermuch? Barnard ≈øayth, That it is more then a ie≈øt, rather then a praier, if at one time thou woulde≈øt pray and talke: for if thou bee not attentiue vnto that that thou praie≈øt, neither will our Lord be vnto that that thou demande≈øt. Defecerunt prae la ‚Ä¢ hrimis oculi mei, ≈øayth Ieremie in his Lamentations; as if he ≈øhould ≈øay. I had ≈øuch great compa≈øston to ≈øee all the Iewes led captiue vnto Babilonia, that my eies with very weeping lo≈øt their ≈øight. And indeed there is no greater token that a man is in true charity, then to ≈øee him haue compa≈øsion of other mens hurts; and therevpon it happeneth that good men weepe ≈øooner for the wicked then for them≈øelues; the which happened al≈øo vnto Chri≈øt vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, who wept fir≈øt for his enemies, before they wept for their owne ≈øinnes. It is a very proper thing vnto the cho≈øen people of God to weepe a like for other mens harmes, and for their owne; becau≈øe it is the propertie of true Chri≈øtian charitie, to take as great griefe to ≈øee his brother lo≈øt, as plea≈øure to ≈øee him≈øelfe ≈øaued. One of the greate≈øt priuiledges that good men haue is, that euen as they merit in taking comfort and ioy of the good that is done to good men, ≈øo they are greeued at the hurt which falleth vnto euill men, in ≈øo much that the good man and the iu≈øt reapeth profit & commodity of euery mans conuer≈øation. Who doubteth but that the lamentation which Chri≈øt made vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, was far greater then that which Ieremie made on the Mount Sion? But now it is to be vnder≈øtood that Ieremy wept for one people onely, and the ≈øonne of God for all the vniuer≈øall world. Ieremy wept only tears from his eies, but the ≈øon of God wept tears from his eies and ≈øhed bloud from his vains. Further Ieremie complained that by weeping he had lo≈øt his ≈øight onely, but our ≈øweet ≈øauior did not only loo≈øe his ≈øight with weeping vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, but al≈øo his very life. O good Ie≈øus, my ≈øoules delight, what patience is ≈øufficient, or by vvhat iu≈øtice is it rea≈øon that I ≈øhould commit the offence, and thou ≈øhed the teares? Art thou not content vvith Ier ‚Ä¢ my to make fountains
of tears of thy eies, but al≈øo to make ≈øtreames of bloud of thy vains? With all tho≈øe ≈øighes which proceed from thy heart, with ≈øo many griefes which thy members endure, with ≈øo many teares which run from thy eies, and with ≈øo much bloud which floweth from thy vains, who would not graunt thy reque≈øt, and who would not haue compa≈øsion of that which thou ≈øuffere≈øt? O who can be able to≈øay with Ieremy, Defecerunt prae lachrimis oculi mei, Becau≈øe that the greate≈øt hap which could light vnto mee were, that in amending my faults I could recouer my ≈øoule, and in weeping many teares lo≈øe my ≈øight.

div.head: CHAP. V. Why the father an≈øwered not his ≈øonne when hee praied for his enemies.
div.p:
VOs cogita≈øtis malum de me, ≈øed deus vertit illud in bonum: ego pa≈øcam vos & paruulos vestros. When the great Patriark Iacob died in Aegypt, and that all his childreÃÑ remained vnder the power and will of their brother Io≈øeph, and being afeard lea≈øt hee ≈øhould call to mind how they had ≈øold him vnto the muleters of Aegypt, the good Io≈øeph ≈øpake the≈øe words vnto them. You my brethreÃÑ did think that you had done me great hurt, but you did me great good: for your ≈øelling of me was the occa≈øioÃÑ that I came vnto pro≈øperity, and to rule and gouerne all Aegypt, in ≈øo much that the great goodne≈ø≈øe of our Lord turned your gall into honny, and your poi≈øon into triacle. Feare not, nor yet haue no ≈øu≈øpition, that I will reuenge for that iniurie, or that I will take ≈øatisfaction for that reproch and ≈øhame; but I haue rather a will to looke vnto your wants, & giue nurriture vnto your children. It is not nece≈ø≈øary to expound this glorious figure, vnto tho≈øe which are curious in the ≈øcriptures, ≈øeeing al this was fulfilled literally in our good Ie≈øus. Yet notwith≈øtanding, we will ≈øay
≈øomething touching this figure, becau≈øe all meÃÑ may perceiue how well the truth an≈øwereth vnto the figure, the ≈øence vnto the letter, the proofe vnto the prophecie, and that which was prophecied vnto that which after happened. What did it mean that Io≈øeph was enuied of his owne proper brothers, but that the ≈øon of God was hated of al the Iews? Who was ≈øold vnto the I≈ømalites like Io≈øeph, but the ble≈ø≈øed Ie≈øus, who was al≈øo bought with money? Who like vnto Io≈øeph was ca≈øt into pri≈øon, becau≈øe hee would not commit adultery with his mi≈øtris, but only the ≈øonne of God, which was condemned vnto death becau≈øe he would not con≈øent to ≈øinne with the Synagogue? who like vnto Io≈øeph did pardon the man≈ølaughter coÃÑ mitted by his brothers, but only the ≈øon of God, who was not coÃÑtent only to pardoÃÑ his enemies, but al≈øo praied vnto his father for theÃÑ? The pardon which Chri≈øt gaue his enemies, was of greater value theÃÑ that which Io≈øeph gaue vnto his brothers, becau≈øe without compari≈øon, it is a greater mi≈øchiefe to take ones life froÃÑ one, theÃÑ to ≈øell his per≈øon. O how rightly may the ≈øon of God ≈øay vnto the Iews which killed him, Vos cogitastis de me malum, ≈øed deus vertit illad in bonum. You thought todo me hurt, but God doth turne it to my good, con≈øidering that they thought at one time to put him to death vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe, and take all power from him vpon earth! but hee maugre theirmalice ro≈øe the third day, and like vnto another Io≈øeph had al power giuen vnto him vpon earth, and in heauen. You O yee Iews Cogita≈øtis de me malum, When you bereaued me of my life, but my ble≈ø≈øed father did turne it to my good, when at the ≈øame time my life ended, the Synagogue was buried, and the Church tooke her beginning. With iu≈øt occa≈øion, and with no le≈ø≈øe rea≈øon good men may ≈øay vnto the euill, the iu≈øt vnto the vniu≈øt, tho≈øe that are per≈øecuted vnto the per≈øecutors, Vos cogita≈øtis de me malum, You thinke to hurt mee, but God turneth it vnto my good: for when they thinke to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe & tread them down, they exalt and life them vp, and thinking to diffame and di≈øcredite them, they giue them credite and honour: for the Tyrant Herod did
much more good to the innocent children, when hee cau≈øed their throats to bee cut, then if hee had cau≈øed them to haue ben kept and brought vp. There was neuer done in the world (≈øaith S. Augustine in his Confe≈øsions) nor neuer ≈øhal be done a wickeder part then the killing of Chri≈øt: and yet there was neuer ≈øo great good done, nor neuer ≈øhalbee as hath been gathered by the death of Chri≈øt, that is, the redemption of all the vniuer≈øall world; in ≈øo much that God neuer permitteth any euill to be done, whereof he doth not draw ≈øome profite. Cyprian in his booke of Martyrs ≈øayth. If the diuell do tempt thee, if the fle≈øh di≈øquiet thee, if the world hate thee, Iacta cogitatum tutum in dominum, Ca≈øt thy thought vpon God: for although Tyrants, and naughty men thinke to doe thee hurt, yet haue a ≈øure confidence and hope, Qu√≤d deus vertet illud in bonum, That God will turne it to good: ≈øeeing that the euill Chri≈øtian goeth out of tribulation moued and ≈øtirred vp, but not amended; and the good and vertuous man cha≈øti≈øed, bettered, and amended. The excommunicated Iewes, Cogitabant de Chri≈øto malum, wheÃÑ at the foot of the cro≈ø≈øe they ≈øaid, Vah qui de≈øtruis templum dei, Thou which doe≈øt de≈øtroy the Temple of God: but the ≈øon of God turned that into good, when hee ≈øaid, Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them, in ≈øo much that the ha≈øt which they v≈øed in ≈øpeaking ill and cur≈øing of him, and reuiling him, our good Ie≈øus v≈øed in ble≈øsing and praying for them. It is here now to bee weighed how it can be true, that the ≈øonne of God was heard of his father as S. Paule ≈øayth, Pro ≈øua reuerentia. Seeing that God an≈øwered him no one word at all? For the better vnder≈øtanding of this point, it is to bee pre≈øuppo≈øed, that in ≈øome reque≈øts which were made vnto the ≈øonne of God, if he would not yeeld vnto that which was demanded, he an≈øwered them pre≈øently by word, but when it plea≈øed him to condi≈øcend vnto their petition, he performed it with deed without any word ≈øpeaking, we haue example of both the≈øe in the Zebedeans his cou≈øins, vnto whom he an≈øwered, Ne≈øcitis quid petatis, You know not what you aske: & when the great Iohn Bapti≈øt ≈øent to know of
Chri≈øt, Es tu qui venturus e≈øt? He an≈øwered no one word vnto the Emba≈øsie more, then that he began immeadiately before the Emba≈ø≈øadors to work ≈øuch great miracles, that they knew by them that he was the Me≈øsias promi≈øed vnto the Iewes. When the collectors of the tributes of Capernaum ≈øaid vnto Ie≈øus that hee was to pay his Didrachma, which was the tribute due vnto the king, he an≈øwered them no word at all, but ≈øent S. Peter vnto the ≈øea, and of that which the di≈øciple fi≈øhed the mai≈øter pared his tribute. To applie this vnto our purpo≈øe, wee ≈øay that what magnificency Chri≈øt v≈øed vnto Iohus de≈øciples, and vnto the rent-gatherers of Capernaum, the ≈øelfe≈øame v≈øed the father towards his proper ≈øon on the cro≈ø≈øe, not an≈øwering him by word vnto Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgine them; but by deed forgiuing the wicked their offences, if they would at any time be ≈øorry and repent them of their ≈øinnes, and by confirming the good in grace. Beda vpon Luke ≈øayth, That the praier which the ≈øonne of God made was not mad in vaine, con≈øidering that by the merit of that praier, and by him who praied it, all our praiers both are, and haue been heard: and for this cau≈øe the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, Qu√≤d offerebat oblationes & preces, Becau≈øe hee praied for all men, and in the name of all men; and ≈øo he wept for all, and in the name of all. O good Ie≈øus, O glory of my ≈øoule, what doe I want if I doe not want thee, and what haue I not, ≈øaith Barnard, if I haue thee? I haue and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe thee O my good Ie≈øus, ≈øeeing that I am partaker of thy praiers, I haue part in thy teares, I haue thy gifts in pledge, I am the ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of thy ≈øorrowes, and heire apparant vnto thy ≈øweatings. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth as the Apo≈øtle doth: Exauditus e≈øt pro≈øua reuerentia, Chri≈øt was heard vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing that by the merites of, Father forgiue them, the Centurion immeadiately there ≈øaid, Vere hic erat filius dei, Truly this was the ≈øonne of God, and the good theefe al≈øo ≈øaid, Domine memento mei, Lord remember me In who≈øe power ≈øaith Fulgentius ‚Ä¢ , but onely in the vertue and power of the praier of Paterigno≈øce illis, within a ≈øhort ≈øpace after that Chri≈øt had ≈øo praied, did ≈øome
≈øtrike their brea≈øts, and ≈øome ≈øay, This man was iu≈øt? By the merite of this holy praier, the Apo≈øtles conuerted three thou≈øand men in one day, and fiue thou≈øand another day: by rea≈øon that the ≈øonne of God had gotten pardon for the excommunicated ≈øynagogue, glorious S. steuen was baptized, holy Paul conuerted, and the good Matthew called to be an Apo≈øtle. O what a difference there is betwixt the praier which Chri≈øt made in the garden, & that which he made vpon the cro≈ø≈øe: in the one hee≈øwet blood, and in the other he ≈øhed teares; in the one he praied that the bitter challice might pa≈ø≈øe, and in the other pardon for the ≈øynagogue: and that which Ie≈øus praied for him≈øelfe was denied him, & that which hee praied for others was graunted him: In ≈øo much that his ble≈ø≈øed father had more pitie on the ≈øinnes of that people, than on the fle≈øh of his owne ≈øonne. O great goodnest O infinit charity? The Sonne of God is in the garden alone, hee is pro≈øtrate on the ground giuing vp his gho≈øt, and yet ready for a new combat, his blood i≈ø≈øueth from all the pores of his body, he praieth thri≈øe for him≈øelfe, and thou wilt not heare him, and when he praieth for his enemies doe≈øt thou heare him at the fir≈øt word? Why do≈øt thou not graunt him his reque≈øt, ≈øeeing that when hee praied vpon the cro≈ø≈øe for his enemies, he called thee nothing but Father; but when he praied in the garden alone for him≈øelfe, he called thee, My Father, which is a ≈øweet word, and a word of a gentle and courteous ≈øonne. What would become of vs (≈øaith S. Ierome) if Chri≈øt ≈øhould not in his glory aboue, repeat that word vnto his father, Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them? Chri≈øt ≈øaid once only, Father forgiue mine enemies, and he repeateth it a thou≈øand thou≈øand times in heanen for his Chri≈øtians: for euen as wee neuer cea≈øe from ≈øinning, ≈øo the ≈øonne of God neuer cea≈øeth to pray for vs. Saint Steuen did not ≈øee Chri≈øt ≈øitting by his father, but on foote; and the rea≈øon was, becau≈øe that at that in≈øtant when S. Steuen fell downe on his knees to pray for his enemies, Chri≈øt ro≈øe immediatly al≈øo to pray and make interce≈øsion for them: ≈øo that that praier which Saint
Steuen made here vpon earth, our ≈øweet Ie≈øus pre≈øented pre≈øently vnto his father in heauen. It is deeply here to be weyed, that Chri≈øt did not ≈øay, Lord forgiue them, but, Father forgiue them; becau≈øe this word Lord is a fearefull word, but this word Father is a word of ioy: and therefore when one man calleth another Father, it ≈øeemeth that hee doth bind him to an≈øwere him friendly, and not to deny him any thing that he demandeth. Wee ≈øhall find often in holy ≈øcripture, that when God was angry with the Hebrewes, hee ≈øaid alwaies, Ego Dominus qui loquor vobis, I am the Lord which ≈øpeake vnto you: but when he would as it were flatter them and make much of them, he alwaies ≈øaid vnto them, Ego ero illis in patrem, I will be a father vnto them: that is, that hee would deale with them like a pitifull father, and not like a rigorous Lord. In ≈øo much that this word Pater Father, breedeth loue, and this word Lord bringeth feare. Alwaies when the ≈øonne of God made any great praier or asked any great fauour at his fathers hands, hee began his petition with Father, O iu≈øt father, O holy father, making reckoning that by calling him father, nothing ≈øhould be denied him which was his ≈øonne. If Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhould haue begun his praier with Lord, as he began it with Father, it would haue ≈øeemed that he had called vpon Gods iu≈øtice & power, & not vpon his wil & mercy: & therfore in ≈øaying, Father, he intreated him that hee would not iudge as a Lord of iu≈øtice, but like a father of mercy. O depth of all goodnes! O bowels full of charity! what els did≈øt thou meane when thou beganne≈øt thy petition with Father, but that thou woulde≈øt giue him to thy enemies for a father who is thine owne proper father? what goodnes in all the world can be equall vnto thine, or what like charity can be found, ≈øeeing thou art the plaintife & the party offended, yet thou gaue≈øt him vnto thy enemies for a mercifull father, whom thou ≈øhould≈øt haue giuen for a rigorous iudge? Then let vs conclude, that when the ≈øonne ≈øaid vnto his father, Pater igno≈øce illis, that at one time he praied vnto him that hee would forgiue them their ≈øinnes, & that at the ≈øame time hee would vouch≈øafe to take them for his children.

div.head: CHAP. VI. How Chri≈øt praied for his enemies on the cro≈ø≈øe more heartilie then hee did in the garden for him≈øelfe, ≈øeeing the one praier was made with condition, and the other not.
div.p:
SVpra dor≈øum meum fabricauerunt peccatores, & prolongauerunt iniquitatem ≈øuam. The≈øe are the wordes of King Dauid in the 128 P≈øalme, ≈øpoken in the name and per≈øon of the ≈øonne of God: and they are as if he ≈øhould ≈øay. I know not O mother the Synagogue, what I haue done again≈øt thee, nor wherin I haue offended thee, & yet thou ha≈øt gain≈øaid mee from my childhood, thou ha≈øt per≈øecuted mee from my manhood, thou ha≈øt defamed mee, euer ≈øince I began to preach vnto thee, and in the ≈øweete≈øt time of al my life, thou ha≈øt crucified mee. But this is nothing O mother Synagogue, this is nothing in compari≈øon of that, that thou didde≈øt lay all thy ≈øinnes vpon my ≈øhoulders, which neuer had lo≈øt their innocency, nor neuer done vnto thee any iniury. Supra dor≈øum meum, And ≈øinners haue built vpon my backe, ≈øeeing that Adam hath ca≈øt his di≈øobedience vpon me, Eue her gluttony, Cain her ≈øonne his murder, king Dauid his adultery, the Tyrant Roboam his Idolatrie, and all the Synagogue her malice. Is it not true that ≈øinners haue built vpon my backe, ≈øeeing that I mu≈øt be puni≈øhed and pay for all the offences that the ≈øinfull Iewes committed? The Iewes would willingly haue loaden Chri≈øt on both his ≈øhoulders, that is they would haue ca≈øt vpon him both the paine and the offence: but good Ie≈øus tooke vpon him the puni≈øhment like a redeemer, but charged not him≈øelfe with the guilt of ≈øinne like an offender. S. Augustine vpon S. Iohn ≈øaith, That the ≈øonne of God doth not complaine, that they burdened both his ≈øhoulders, but
only one, ≈øeeing he ≈øaith, Supra dor≈øum Vpon my backe, although his enemies would haue ouercharged and wearied them both, by killing his humanitie, and darkening his diuinitie, by blotting his fame and credite and hindering his doctrine; but our mighty redeemer ≈øuffered them onely to lay the puni≈øhment on him, and take his life from him. Ba≈øil ≈øayth, That ≈øinners build vpon one ≈øhoulder only, when they haue no other goodne≈ø≈øe in them, but the bare name of Chri≈øtians only: and iu≈øt men build vpon both his ≈øhoulders when they are at one time both Chri≈øtians and vertuous men. Thou mu≈øt know (brother) that in the law of Chri≈øt it is not ≈øufficieÃÑt that a man be called a Chri≈øtian, vnle≈ø≈øe he be al≈øo ≈øuch a one indeed. Sinners build vpon one of Chri≈øts ≈øhoulders onely, when they ≈øerue God in wi≈øh and de≈øire onely, and ≈øerue the world with all their might and power, which is a mean rather to condemne them then to ≈øaue them: for in the Church of God there are many condemned by good wi≈øhes & de≈øires, but not one by good workes. Chri≈øt complaineth, that cur≈øed Heretikes doe build vpon one ≈øhoulder, when they confe≈ø≈øe only his humanitie, & take away his diuinity; which is great wickedne≈ø≈øe & fal≈øhood: for he is as true a God as he is a man and as true man as he is true God. Chri≈øts complaint of the Synagogue doeth not end here, but hee ≈øaith further, Et prolong auerunt iniquitatem ≈øuam: as if he would ≈øay, Thou was not content, O ingrateful Synagogue, to impute thy offence vnto mee, and lay all the puni≈øhment due for it vpon my backe, but thou ha≈øt al≈øo prolonged thy naughtine≈ø≈øe and per≈øeuered in thine infidelity, heaping ≈øinne vpon ≈øinne, malice vpon malice, enuie vpon enuie, and idolatry vnto idolatry. When did the for≈øaken Iewes prolong their iniquitie, but when at the foot of the cro≈ø≈øe, they were nothing forrie to haue crucified Chri≈øt, but were grieued to ≈øee him ri≈øe againe? S. Barnard ≈øayth, that Chri≈øt had great rea≈øon to ≈øay that the Iewes had prolonged their iniquitie, becau≈øe that at the time of his pa≈øsion, for the better reuengement vnto their malicious hearts, and the more to torment Chri≈øts ble≈ø≈øed
members, they would haue been glad that day had been longer, and that Chri≈øts life had continued a longer time. The hatred which tho≈øe wicked Iewes bate vnto Chri≈øt was ≈øo great, that ≈øometimes they de≈øired nothing more then to ≈øee him yeeld vp the gho≈øt, and ≈øometime they were neuer ≈øatisfied and full in doing him iniury, in≈øomuch that if they did crucifie him with their haÃÑds, they did al≈øo crucifie him much more with their hearts. Wee ≈øhould haue great compa≈øsion vpon the Iewi≈øh nation which doe prolong their iniquity vntill the end of the world: for as the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, the Synagogue ≈øhall neuer be all lightened vntill all the Gentiles bee conuerted. It may be ≈øaid not only of the Hebrewes, but al≈øo of many Chri≈øtians, that Prolong auerunt iniquitatem ≈øuam, who in ≈øtead of amending them≈øelues, goe on euery day empairing them≈øelues, ≈øo that they are like vnto tho≈øe which are ≈øick of the drop≈øie, who the more they drinke the more they thir≈øt; ≈øo they the more they ≈øinne the greater lu≈øt they haue to ≈øinne. And as Chri≈øt with great rea≈øon ≈øaid, that the Hebrewes did prolong their iniquitie again≈øt him, with the like rea≈øon may they ≈øay of Chri≈øt, that towards them he prolonged his mercy, ≈øeeing he was as ha≈øtie in procuring their pardon, as they were in cau≈øing his pa≈øsion. What ≈øhold become of me O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, what ≈øhould become of me ≈øaith An≈øelmus, if as euery day I adde naughtine≈ø≈øe to naughtine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo prolong my iniquitie, thou didde≈øt not adde goodnes vnto goodne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo prolong mee thy mi≈øericordiam? O ≈øweet Ie≈øus and my ≈øoules delight, of whom may it ≈øo truly be ≈øaid as of thee, that thou ha≈øt prolonged thy mercy, ≈øeeing that thou wa≈øt vpon the cro≈ø≈øe as it were gaping for death, and yet pardoning thy enemies? And although I doe euery day prolong my iniquity, and thou euery moment prolong thy mercy, notwith≈øtanding thy mercy exceedeth my iniquitie: for otherwi≈øe my ≈øorrowfull ≈øoule ≈øhould long agoe haue knowne what thy rigorous iu≈øtice had beene. Cyprian ≈øaith vpon the pa≈øsion of our Lord, that hee hath much more prolonged his mercy, ≈øeeing hee ≈øaid not in his praier, Father forgiue them if
thou wilt, but ab≈øolutely that hee would forgiue them; and that not by the rigour of iu≈øtice due vnto them, but by the ≈øole mercy of him which made the petition. Behold then O my ≈øoule, behold that with greater deuotion & affection the ≈øonne of God praied for thee vpon the cro≈ø≈øe than hee did for him≈øelfe in the garden, ≈øeeing that he ≈øaid there, Father if thou wilt, let that chalice pa≈ø≈øe; but on the cro≈ø≈øe he ≈øaid not If thou wilt, but Father forgiue them. In ≈øo much that it ≈øeemeth that hee left the care of his pa≈øsion vnto the will of his father, but the pardon of his enemies hee de≈øired pre≈øently to be giuen. What meaneth this O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? It ≈øeemeth that thou doe≈øt put it in con≈øultation whether thou ≈øhalt die or not, ≈øaying vnto him Father if thou wilt; and doe≈øt thou not giue thy father leaue to thinke whether he ≈øhall pardon that wicked people or not, but that he ≈øhould there pre≈øently forgiue them? The ≈øonne of God ≈øaith vnto his father (as Gregory reports) Father forgiue them, and not If thou wilt, becau≈øe we ≈øhould vnder≈øtand that when wee forgiue and be reconciled vnto our enemies, we ≈øhould doe it ≈øo ≈øincerely and heartily, and with ≈øuch good wil that we ≈øhould neuer turne our face from them, nor neuer deny them our communication. I will not (≈øaith Hugo) call that a Chri≈øtian forgiuing, when we forgiue our enemy vnder condition neuer to ≈øpeake vnto him, nor goe by his gate, nor dwell where hee hath to doe: for our redeemer excepted no condition in the pardon of his pa≈øsion. It is al≈øo deepely to bee weighed, that the ≈øonne of God did not ≈øay vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, Father forgiue him, but Father forgiue them: That is, he asked forgiuene≈ø≈øe not for one in particular, but for all the whole world in generall. Whereof it is inferred that ≈øeeing hee praied for all, that there was ≈øinne in all. When Chri≈øt ≈øaid Pardon them and not pardon him, he gaue cau≈øe of great hope vnto all ≈øinners, that they ≈øhould bee pardoned by him, ≈øeeing hee forgot not to redeeme any, nor to pardon any man, nor leaue out any man not ≈øpoken for of his father, but made all men partakers of his pa≈øsion. As the ≈øonne of God ≈øaid vnto his father, Pardon
them, ≈øo if he had ≈øaid Pardon him, he would haue put all the church in an vpro ‚Ä¢ e and hurliburly, and al the world in a confu≈øion and doubt in knowing who were condemned, and who pardoned. Rabanus vpon S. Matthew ≈øayth, That when the Maker hanged vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, if hee had ≈øaid Pardon him, as he ≈øaid Pardon them, then we ≈øhould not haue known whether hee had pardoned Iudas which ≈øold him, or Herod which ≈øcorned him, or Pilat which condemned him, or S. Peter which denied him, or Caiphas which bla≈øphemed him. And he ≈øaith further, that the cau≈øe why Chri≈øt ≈øaid vnto his father, Pardon them, and not pardon him, was becau≈øe our good Lord is ≈øo liberall in giuing and ≈øo noble in pardoning, that he cannot forgiue any one ≈øinne alone, if there remaine any other hidden offence in the ≈øinner. Factious and enuious men are wont to pardon ≈øome of their enemies, & not other ≈øome: but the ≈øonne of God for a certainty dooth not ≈øo, but he would forgiue all men tog ‚Ä¢ ther, and redeeme all men togither. S. Iohn ≈øaid not of Chri≈øt, behold him who taketh away the ≈øinne of the world; but ≈øaid behold him who taketh away the ≈øinnes of the world. He ≈øaid not vnto Mary Magdalen, thy ≈øinne is relea≈øed, but thy ≈øinnes are forgiuen thee: In ≈øo much that in matter of ≈øinnes God cannot but either wholly winck at them, or wholly pardon them. For as S. Ierome ≈øayth, No man euer heard the ≈øonne of God ≈øay, I pardon thee ≈øuch a ≈øinne or this ≈øinne or that ≈øinne, but hee alwaies ≈øaid I pardon thee all thy ≈øinnes, and therevpon praying vpon the cro≈ø≈øe vnto his father, hee did not ≈øay Pardon him, but ≈øaid Father pardon them. For it ≈øeemed vnto him, that the value of the bloud which hee ≈øhed, was of ≈øuch price, that tho≈øe for whome hee died were but few, although hee died for tho≈øe which were ab≈øent, as well as for tho≈øe which were pre≈øent, for the quicke and for the dead, for tho≈øe which were already pa≈øt and for tho≈øe which were to come, for the iu≈øt and for the ≈øinners; & that one drop of his bloud which he ≈øhould ≈øhed, would bee ≈øufficient to redeeme a thou≈øand of worlds: and if this were ≈øo, what rea≈øon had hee to be≈øtow it vpon one
alone, ≈øeeing there did abound for all the world? The ≈øonne of God debated not the matter, nor plaied not the huck≈øter with his father in contending, how much bloud ≈øhall I giue thee for their pardon; becau≈øe he would let vs vnder≈øtand in this, that he paied very well, yea and repaied for al the ≈øinnes which were forgiuen. For to conclude, all the ≈øinnes in the world might haue ben numbred, but the price of the bloud of Chri≈øt could not bee valued. O good Ie≈øus! O my ≈øoules hope, if in fauour of great ≈øinners thou didde≈øt ≈øay, Father forgiue them, why doe≈øt thou not ≈øay in my behalfe who am a great ≈øinner, Pater igno≈øce illi, Forgiue him? If the Iewes haue beene vngratefull towards thee for the miracles which thou didde≈øt among≈øt them, haue not I been much more ingratefull for the benefites receiued of thee? If thou didde≈øt pray for the I≈øraelites which did kill thee once, why doe≈øt thou not pray for me which kill thee euery day? Doe not I put thee to death euery day and euery houre, ≈øeeing I doe crucifie thee as oft as I ≈øinne again≈øt thee? Seeing the ≈øinnes which are ≈øeuerally in other meÃÑ, are together in me, why do≈øt thou not ≈øay, Father forgiue him, as thou did≈øt ≈øay, Father forgiue theÃÑ? Say then O my good Ie≈øus, ≈øay vnto thy Father, Father pardoÃÑ this ≈øinner, ≈øeeing that by how much the more my ≈øins & offences are greater then other mens, by ≈øo much the more thy mercy will ≈øhine by forgiuing me.

div.head: CHAP. VII. How God is more mercifull now then hee was in time pa≈øt: and why Chri≈øt did not ≈øay that he did pardon his enemies, when he asked pardon for them of his father.
div.p:
POnam contra te omnes abommationes tuas, & non parcet oculus meus ≈øuper te. The≈øe are the woordes of the great God of I≈øraell, ≈øpoken with much anger and verie great furie to the people of
I≈ørael, by the mouth and preaching of the holy Prophet Ezechiel chapter. 7. as if he would ≈øay: I am ≈øo angry with thee O Synagogue, and haue pardoned thee ≈øo often, that I am now determined to lay open all thy wickednes, and not forgiue thee any one of them: becau≈øe that as mercy doth follow thy amendment, ≈øo iu≈øtice & rigor may follow thy hardne≈ø≈øe of heart. Before the ≈øonne of God came into the world to take mans fle≈øh vpon him, God was much more accu≈øtomed to v≈øe his iu≈øtice then his mercie; ≈øeeing that in all the ≈øtory of the old Law, tho≈øe which hee cha≈øti≈øed were very many in number, and tho≈øe whome hee forgaue very few. And that we may proue it to haue ben ≈øo from the beginning of the world, how did he puni≈øh Adam, and Eue his wife for no other cau≈øe but for eating the apple which was forbidden them? Did hee not condemne the wicked Cain to wander throughout all the world, and haue a ≈øhaking in his head, for the murder which hee v≈øed again≈øt his brother? Who is ignorant how God did drowne many in the vniuer≈øall floud for the ≈øinne of the fle≈øh, and ≈øunke tho≈øe of Sodome for the ≈øinne again≈øt nature, and let the ground open and ≈øwallow vp Dathan and Abiron for the rancor of enuie? And did not God command Moy≈øes and Io≈øua, to take out of the campe and ≈øtone to death the Iew for hiding a barrell of gold at the ≈øacke of Ierricho, and another I≈øraelitie for gathering ≈øtickes vpon the Sabboth day? Hieremie neuer endeth to bewaile the captiuitiy of Babilon, whereof hee ≈øayth, Destruxit & non pepercit hee de≈øtroied and ≈øpared not. But God commaunded that all that kingdome ≈øhould bee made de≈øolate and de≈øtroied, not pardoning nor forgiuing any one. When the Lord commanded king Saule to go & take Amelech his kingdome, hee adui≈øed him and in≈øtructed him, that from the king him≈øelfe which ≈øate in his throne vnto the bea≈øt which fed in the meadow hee ≈øhould not pardon any one, but ≈øley and kill them euery one. In the ninth chapter of Ezechiell, God ≈øaid the≈øe wordes vnto
the ≈øtriking Angel, Senem, & iuuenem, & virginem, & paruulum interfice, & ≈øanctuario me ‚Ä¢ incipe, &c. as if he would ≈øay, Go throughout all the city of Ieru≈øalem, & put to the ≈øword all the old men, and all the young men, all the virgins, and all the children, and becau≈øe no man ≈øhall thinke that any place may ≈øaue him, thou ≈øhalt begin this my puni≈øhment with the Prie≈øts of the Temple. Cadent √† latere tuo mille, & decem millia √† dextris tuis, ≈øayth the P≈øalmi≈øt, as if he would ≈øay: Thou doe≈øt ≈øo ≈øeuerely reuenge thy iniuries O great God of Saboth, and ≈øo puni≈øh our offences, that as oft as I looke vpon thee I ≈øee both thy armes armed, and both thy hands couered with bloud, in≈øomuch that if a thou≈øand men are fallen at thy left hand, there are other ten thou≈øand ≈ølairie at thy right hand. When the eternall God had ≈øeene that they had put to death his welbeloued ≈øonne, being accu≈øtomed to puni≈øh pre≈øently and not to pardon, he darkened the light of the ≈øunne, made the earth to quake, rent the vaile of the Temple, and opened the ≈øepulchres of the dead, becau≈øe tho≈øe which were dead ≈øhould ri≈øe againe and take reuengemeÃÑt of tho≈øe which were aliue. WheÃÑ the ≈øon of God perceiued that al this was done for his ≈øake, & that his father would de≈øtroy all the word for to reuenge his death, hee lifted vp his eies vnto heauen, and with a ≈øorrowfull voice ≈øaid, Father forgiue them, becau≈øe they know not what they doe: as if he would ≈øay; O my eternall and holy father, I be≈øeech and pray thee that thou woulde≈øt forgiue this vnhappy people, ≈øeeing thou ≈øhoulde≈øt make more account of the bloud which I ≈øhed for theÃÑ, than of the offence which they haue committed again≈øt thee. It is now now time for a thou≈øand to fall on thy left ≈øide, and ten thou≈øand on thy right: for ≈øeeing that I ≈øtand betwixt them and thee, it is not rea≈øon that they ≈øhould fall but ri≈øe, nor that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt puni≈øh but pardon them. O what a happie time! O what a happy age the Catholike church liueth in, in the which hee which is iniuried is reconciled and made our friend, the iudge become our aduocate and ≈øpoke≈øman for vs, our accu≈øer turned
