to bee our defender, and hee who was woont to feare vs with iu≈øtice, doth now flatter vs and entice vs to him with mercy. How ≈øhal Dauid be able to ≈øay now, Cadent √† latere eius mille, A thou≈øand ≈øhall fall on his ≈øide, ≈øeeing the ≈øonne of God hath ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, Father forgiue them? In the law of grace, and vnder the yoke of Chri≈øt it is not time to goe a≈øtray but aright, not to ca≈øt away our ≈øelues but to ≈øaue our ≈øelues, not a time of iu≈øtice but of mercie, not to puni≈øh but to pardon, neither is it time to fall but to ri≈øe. It is much to be noted, that the ≈øonne of God did neuer command any man to fall and throw downe him≈øelfe, but rather bad all men ri≈øe vp, as it appeareth in the ninteenth of S. Matthew, where hee ≈øayth, Ri≈øe vp and take thy bed, and in another place Ari≈øe maid, and hee ≈øaid vnto him whom hee rai≈øed from death in Naim, adole≈øcens tibi dico ≈øurge, and likewi≈øe hee ≈øaid in the garden to his Di≈øciples, Ri≈øe let vs goe. It is the propertie and office of the diuell, to coun≈øell and procure men to fall: for ≈øo he coun≈øelled Chri≈øt in the de≈øart, when he ≈øaid, I will giue thee all the≈øe things, Si cadens adoraueris me, as if hee would ≈øay; I will make thee Lord ouer all the world, if thou wilt but fall downe on the ground. O my ≈øweet Ie≈øus I wil liue with thee, who commandeth me to ri≈øe, and not with the diuell who coun≈øelleth mee to fall: for hee is de≈øirous to haue me fall, and thou and no other art able to helpe mee vp again. Why ≈øhould I liue with the diuell who deceiueth me a thou≈øand waies, or with the world which putteth mee in a thou≈øand daÃÑgers, or with the fle≈øh which asketh of me a thou≈øand plea≈øures? O redeemer of my ≈øoule, O ≈øweet delight of my life, I will liue and die with thee, and no other, for if I bee ≈øick thou do≈øt heale me, if I be ≈øorrowful thou do≈øt coÃÑfort me, if I be falling thou do≈øt help me, if I be falne thou do≈øt helpe me vp, & if I haue ≈øinned thou do≈øt pardon me. He is the di≈øciple of the diuell, who goeth about to throw down his brother, & he is the ≈øonne of Chri≈øt who doth helpe to lift vp his neighbor: for we are not able in this life to do any maÃÑ a greater fauor, then to keepe his credit & honor, & to help him to ≈øaue
his ≈øoule. When the giuer of life ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, Father forgiue them, by tho≈øe ≈øpeeches he ment to obtain two things of his father: That is, that hee would neither puni≈øh their bodies like vnto murderers, nor condemne their ≈øoules like vnto traitors. O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe! O clemency neuer heard of before! O redeemer of my ≈øoule, doe≈øt thou di≈ø≈øemble with the trecherous, pardon murderers, excu≈øe traitors, vndertake≈øt for the credite of the infamous, & turne≈øt vnto ≈øinners? It is litle when I ≈øay thou doe≈øt turn vnto ≈øinners, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt not only turn vnto them but al≈øo die for them. What is the rea≈øon O good Ie≈øus, what is the rea≈øon that thou doe≈øt pray vnto thy father that he would forgiue them, and doe≈øt not ≈øay I doe forgiue them. When thou ≈øaie≈øt, Father pardon them, why doe≈øt thou not ≈øay al≈øo, I pardon them? Art thou the partie iniuried, art thou the partie ≈øhamed and di≈øgraced, art thou the partie agreeued, and doe≈øt giue the libertie of pardoning them vnto another? It is a high my≈øterie, and a hidden Sacrament, to thinke that the ≈øonne of God would not ≈øay I pardon them, but entreat his father to pardon them, making greater reckoning of the iniurie which they had done vnto his father, then of the death which they procured vnto him≈øelfe. The rea≈øon why the ≈øonne of God would not ≈øay, I pardon them, although hee were the partie offended, was to tell vs plainly, That hee did not e≈øteeme tho≈øe which put him to death his enemies, rather his deer brothers & great good doers vnto the world, hauing more regard vnto the good vvhich they had done in cau≈øing the world to be redeemed, then vnto the hurt which they did in cau≈øing him≈øelfe to bee murdered. When good Ie≈øus ≈øaid, Father forgiue theÃÑ, it is no more theÃÑ to ≈øay, thou art he my good father who mu≈øt forgiue theÃÑ, becau≈øe they haue brokeÃÑ thy law, di≈øcredited thy doctrine, violated thy temple, & put to death thy ≈øon. If thou do≈øt ≈øay that I ≈øhould forgiue theÃÑ, I ≈øay I haue no cau≈øe to forgiue: for I take my death as wel reuenged, & my life as well be≈øtowed, ≈øeeing that by the merit thereof all the world may liue, & heauen made open vnto
all men. S. Augustine ≈øayth, That if the ≈øonne of God had holden the Iewes for his enemies, as they accounted of him, it was in his power to for≈øake them, and goe preach vnto others; but becau≈øe hee e≈øteemed of them as of his kindred in bloud, neighbours by nature, brothers by law, di≈øciples in doctrine, it was not needful for him to ≈øay on the cro≈ø≈øe I forgiue theÃÑ, ≈øeeing he was not angry towards theÃÑ, nor moued at al with theÃÑ. They bare rancor and hatred vnto Chri≈øt, but nor Chri≈øt vnto theÃÑ; & therfore notwith≈øtanding all the reproches they v≈øed towards him, & al the iniurious ≈øpeeches they gaue him, he neuer left off preaching vnto theÃÑ, nor neuer cea≈øed to work miracles among≈øt them. With what face could they ≈øay that Chri≈øt was their enemy, ≈øeeing hee rai≈øed their dead, ca≈øt out diuels froÃÑ them, in≈øtructed their childreÃÑ, cured their friends of di≈øea≈øes, & al≈øo forgaue theÃÑ their ≈øins? Seeing the ≈øon of God had done the works of a friend among them, & that of a true friend, why ≈øhould he ≈øay vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe, I do al≈øo forgiue theÃÑ, ≈øeeing he did not hold any one of theÃÑ for his enemy? If ≈øweet Ie≈øus was angry with theÃÑ, if he mi≈øliked theÃÑ, it was not for the iniuries which they did vnto him, but for the offences they coÃÑmitted again≈øt his father; & therfore he coÃÑmitted the pardoÃÑ vnto him which was mo≈øt iniuried, prote≈øting that him≈øelf was not offended with theÃÑ. O ≈øweet Ie≈øus how can≈øt thou ≈øay that thou wa≈øt not offended nor iniured by theÃÑ, being as thou wa≈øt iniuried & crucified by their hands? and although thou do not coÃÑplaine vpon theÃÑ, nor reuenge thee on them, nor yet accu≈øe theÃÑ; yet O my redeemer why do≈øt thou excu≈øe them? Barnard ≈øaith, That the ≈øon of God was repleni≈øhed with ≈øuch great charity, and ≈øuch in≈øpeakable pity towards tho≈øe which crucified him, that he could not obtaine leaue of him≈øelfe to impute any fault vnto them, ≈øeeing he had charged him≈øelfe with the pain due for it. Cyprian ≈øaith, That ≈øeeing Chri≈øt was the true mediator, pacifier, & ≈øtikler betwixt his father & the world, it would haue beene euilly thought of to ≈øay, that any one of them were his enemies: and therevpon it is that ≈øeeing hee had no enemie there among≈øt them, hee had no
nece≈øsitie to ≈øay on the cro≈ø≈øe, I pardon them. If the ≈øonne of God (≈øaith S. Chry≈øostome) hanging vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould haue ≈øaid, I al≈øo pardon them, it would haue beene thought that hee receiued greater griefe for the torment which hee him≈øelfe ≈øuffered, than of the iniuries which were done vnto his father; which for a certentie was not ≈øo: for if it were po≈ø≈øible, Chri≈øt would more willingly returne againe into the world to die, than endure to ≈øee one iniury done vnto his father. Who dare now, O good Ie≈øus (≈øaith S. Barnard) who dare aske a reuenge of the iniuries done vnto him, ≈øeeing thou didde≈øt make ≈øuch ≈ømall account of tho≈øe which were done vnto thy ≈øelfe? Doe≈øt not thou recken of the cruell thornes which pierced thy holy head, and ≈øhall I make account of an angry word which my brother ≈øpeaketh again≈øt me? How ≈øhall I dare to ≈øay, that I haue enemies, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt handle tho≈øe which nailed thee vnto the cro≈ø≈øe like brothers? It ought to be a ≈øtrange ≈øpeech in the mouth of a Chri≈øtian to ≈øay, This is my enemy; for in making thy brother thy enemie, thou doe≈øt loo≈øe Chri≈øt, and cau≈øe≈øt him to be no more thy friend. It is much to be noted, that Chri≈øt entreated not his father to pardon them after they were dead, but asked that he would pardon them quickly, yea & that very quickly, becau≈øe he would let vs vnder≈øtand, that the value of his precious blood was of ≈øuch great price, that at that in≈øtant that it began to be ≈øhedde, at the ≈øame time it began to doe good. The redeemer of the world would not leaue vs out of the fauor of his father, nor an enemy vnto any; in token wherof hee came into the world, ≈øaying, Et in terra pax hominibus, Peace vnto men vpon earth: and went out of the world, ≈øaying, Pater igno≈øce illis, Father forgiue them. The ≈øon of God (≈øaith Ca≈øsiodorus vpon the P≈øalms) is not like vnto the children of this world, who leaue vnto their children a little wealth with much ≈øtrife, ≈øeeing that by that ≈øpeech of, Father forgiue them, hee redeemed vs with his blood, baptized vs with his teares, annointed vs with his ≈øweat, in≈øtructed vs with his doctrine, loo≈øed vs from the deuill, and reconciled
vs vnto his father. O how much are wee bound vnto thee, ≈øweet Ie≈øus, for praying vnto thy father that he would forgiue his enemies before and not after thy death, that is, before the teares of thy eies were dried vp, and whil≈øt the wounds of thy body were yet fre≈øh. What would haue become of mankind if Chri≈øt at his death had bin angry with vs? When he ≈øaid in his la≈øt Sermon, Pacem meam do vobis, I giue you my peace, What el≈øe meant he, but that he left vs reconciled vnto his father, and vnited vnto him≈øelfe? How could the eternall father (≈øaith An≈øelmus) deny his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øonne the pardon which hee demaunded, ≈øeeing he asked it with ≈øuch milde wordes, with ≈øuch ≈øorrowfull teares, with ≈øuch fre≈øh wounds, with ≈øuch louing bowels, with ≈øuch continual ≈øighes, and with ≈øuch great and pa≈øsing griefe? Wee may then conclude, that when Chri≈øt praied his father to pardon quickely and without delay, he teacheth vs, that before we die and go out of this life, it is conuenient for vs to pardon all iniuries; for otherwi≈øe tho≈øe in the other world ≈øhall haue great occa≈øion to weepe, which would not in this world ≈øpeedily forgiue.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. How our Lord reckoneth with the Synagogue: and of fiue cruelties which the Iewes v≈øed in the death of Chri≈øt.
div.p:
SIt Dominus iudex inter te & inter me, ≈øaid the mo≈øt renowmed king Dauid vnto his Lord and king, king Saul, Reg. chap. 24. as if hee would ≈øay, I will haue no other iudge betwixt me and thee, O great king of I≈ørael, but onely the mighty God of heauen, vnto whom it is well known how faithfully I doe ≈øerue thee, and how cruelly thou doe≈øt handle me. Origen ≈øaith, that king Dauid ought to haue great
priuitie with God, ≈øeeing h ‚Ä¢ e cho≈øe him for the iudge of all the words he ≈øpake, of all the thoughts he conceiued, of all the workes which he did, of all the enmities he ≈øuffered, yea and of all the friend≈øhips he followed. Dauid could not iu≈øtifie his cau≈øe better, than to referre the iu≈øtice of it vnto the hands of God, who is ≈øo iu≈øt in his per≈øon, ≈øo vpright in his iudgement, that neither praiers bow him, neither threatnings feare him, nor gifts mooue him, nor words deceiue him. When good king Dauid cited Saul to appeare before the iudgement of God, Dauid could haue cut off his head if hee would, as hee did the gard of his garment: but yet hee would not doe it, becau≈øe hee did ≈øet more by Gods fauour than by Sauls euill will. Saul was a capitall enemie vnto king Dauid: hee cau≈øed him to flee his countrey, for≈øake his kindred, depriued him of his riches, bani≈øhed him his court, ≈øeparated him from his wife, and proclaimed him to be his publike enemie. And yet notwith≈øtanding all this, Dauid (if hee had li≈øted) could haue beene reuenged of Saul, as e≈øpecially when hee ≈øtole the bottle from vnder his beds head, and cut away a piece of his garment: yet the pitifull king Dauid would not onely not do it, but ≈øhewed him≈øelfe angry with tho≈øe which dur≈øt coun≈øell him vnto it. The fir≈øt wrong which they did vnto Chri≈øt was, that they crucified him through malice, not finding any fault in him at al: which appeareth plainly by that that they did let goe Barrabas the man≈ølaier, and condemned the ≈øonne of God; iudging him to bee an hone≈øter man who killed tho≈øe which liued, theÃÑ that great Prophet which rai≈øed vp tho≈øe which were dead. The ≈øecond iniury was, that if they had put the ≈øonne of God to death in ≈øome mean village, it would not haue ben ≈øo great an infamy and reproch vnto him: but the excommunicated Iewes the better to reuenge them≈øelues vpon Chri≈øt and to put him to the greater ≈øhame, put him to death in the great city of Ieru≈øalem, where he was very well known by his preaching, & allied vnto many honorable Per≈øons by con≈øanguinity. The third was, that although they could haue put him to death ≈øecretly in his chaÃÑ ber, or in ≈øome darke night, yet they neuer ment once to do it; but they brought him forth at one of the clocke, they condemned him at three, they crucified him at ≈øix, & they murdered him at nine. It was not for want of diligeÃÑce, but through abundance of malice that they cho≈øe that houre, becau≈øe theÃÑ the ≈øunne ≈øheweth his beames mo≈øt brighte≈øt, & mo≈øt people pa≈ø≈øe through the ≈øtreets. Chri≈øo≈øtome vpon S. Matthew ≈øayth, That the Iews would not put Chri≈øt to death in the morning becau≈øe all men were not vp, nor in the night becau≈øe all were

It was an old plague of the Synagogues to embrue & fle≈øh theÃÑ≈øelues in the bloud of the prophets & holy men, as of E≈øaias whoÃÑ they ≈øawed in peeces; Ieremy whoÃÑ they drowned in a wel; Micheas whom they buffeted to death, Zachary whom they ≈øtoned to death, & Ezechiel whom they impri≈øoned: and becau≈øe the cur≈øe of their predece≈ø≈øors ≈øhould reach vnto tho≈øe which were theÃÑ aliue, they be thought theÃÑ≈øelues to take Chri≈øts life froÃÑ him, & blemi≈øh his good name & credite. Dama≈øceÃÑ ≈øaith, that wheÃÑ the Iews crucified Chri≈øt, they cho≈øe a bright & a fair day without cloud & darknes, becau≈øe Chri≈øt ≈øhould be ≈øeen of al meÃÑ, & not vnknown of any, becau≈øe their purpo≈øe & intent was a≈øwel to di≈øcredit him as to kill him. For wheÃÑ the EuaÃÑgeli≈øt ≈øaith, that wheÃÑ Chri≈øt gaue vp the gho≈øt, the ≈øun was dar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed, it is an vnfallible argumeÃÑt that it was a bright & a clear day; but the ≈øun waxed darke vpon the ≈øudden, becau≈øe he would with his ≈øhadow haue couered him whoÃÑ the Iewes had put to open ≈øhame. S. Ciprian ≈øaith, That when the Iews put Chri≈øt to death, they were not coÃÑtent only to make choice of a bright day & cleare, but al≈øo they would haue a long day (as coÃÑmonly the daies are the 25 of March) becau≈øe they might haue time in one day to accu≈øe him, giue iudgement on him, & crucifie him. It is to be weighed, that the Iews neuer gaue Chri≈øt the prehemineÃÑce or highe≈øt room but only vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe and gibbet, where they crucified him betwixt two theeues, & they put him in the mid≈øt as if he had ben the greate≈øt theef among theÃÑ al, & the mo≈øt notorious offender. Prophet was, ≈øeeing that in compari≈øon of him the theeues were of a better life. Put the ca≈øe, ≈øaith S. If the ≈øonne of God drew ≈øinners vnto him & receiued them, truly it was not for that he would helpe them or further them in ≈øinne, but to draw theÃÑ to good life, in ≈øo much that by his ble≈ø≈øed company they were not peruerted but much more conuerted. The fifth wrong was, that although they might haue put him to another kind of death, which was not ≈øo ≈øcandalous to heare of, nor ≈øo cruell to bee endured as the death of the cro≈ø≈øe, yet they would put him to no other death but that, becau≈øe hee ≈øhould end his life with great cruelty & ≈ømart. They & not the ≈øonne of God were breakers of the law, they were Traitors vnto the king, they cau≈øed ≈øedition among the people, yea they ≈øtole away the ≈øacrifices: in ≈øo much that again≈øt all order of iu≈øtice, tho≈øe tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors murdered him which was holy, the Traitors put to death him who was loiall, the guiltie crucified the innocent, and the theeues crucified their iudge. Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øayth, That as the hatred which they bare vnto Chri≈øt did pa≈ø≈øe al other hatred in the world, and as the enuie they bare Chri≈øt was far greater then any other which could ≈øinke into

As touching the fir≈øt, they entreat Pilat to put Chri≈øt to death, and Pilat ≈øaid, that he found no cau≈øe in him why hee ≈øhould die: but in fine, his re≈øi≈øtance preuailed not ≈øo much as their importunity. The Iews did not reque≈øt of Pilat that he would whip Chri≈øt or bani≈øh him, or obiect any reprochfull crime again≈øt him, but that he would immediatly put him to death, & that becau≈øe the holy doctrine which he preached, and the euill life which they led were imcompatible the one with the other. And as for the ≈øecond, the for≈øakeÃÑ Iews were not content to demand of Pilat that Chri≈øt ≈øhould be put to death, and with that death which they them≈øelues de≈øired, but that they ≈øhould immediately crucifie him on a cro≈ø≈øe, which kind of puni≈øhment was neuer giuen but vnto very naughty & wicked per≈øons, and for very heinous and enormious ≈øaults. And although Pilate ≈øhould haue been determined to put him to death, either by cutting his throat, or ca≈øting him into a well, or by hanging him, which are ea≈øier deaths to ≈øuffer, and le≈ø≈øe infamous to endure, yet the doggi≈øh Iews would not leaue it vnto Pilates arbitrement and free will, for feare lea≈øt he wold haue beene too pitifull in the maner of his death. FRons meretricis facta e≈øt tibi, & noluisti erube≈øcere, tamen reuertere ad me & dic pater meus es tu. And they are as if he ≈øhould ≈øay; O wicked and infortunate people of the Iews, which art come vnto that boldne≈ø≈øe of ≈øinning, that like vnto a publick whore, thou ha≈øt no ≈øhame in doing naught. aske thee forgiuene≈ø≈øe of all my ≈øinnes, and ≈øeeing I doe turne vnto thee as vnto my Lord, and confe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe before thee to bee a great ≈øinner, I be≈øeech thee mo≈øt humbly, that thou would≈øt not ca≈øt me from before thy face, & that thou woulde≈øt not take thy holy ≈øpirit from me: for if thy holy grace for≈øake me, my ≈øoule is turned vnto that that ≈øhe was before, that is vnto a ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe and lewd woman. It is much to be noted here, that God doth not coÃÑplaine of the Iews that they were enuious, angry, or gluttennous, but that they were bold and without ≈øhame; which wanteth not a high my≈øtery, becau≈øe there is no greater ≈øigne in all the world that a mans con≈øcience is very corrupt, then when to ≈øin he hath no ≈øhame at al. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, with very great rea≈øon and for iu≈øt occa≈øion God called the ≈øynagogue a ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe and di≈ø≈øolute ≈øtrumpet, ≈øeeing that in the death of his ≈øonne ≈øhee ≈øhewed not onely her malice, but al≈øo her impudency, in killing him in the open day, not being ≈øorrowfull for it at all. Chri≈øt knew very well that which his father had promi≈øed vnto the Iewes, that is, that if they would call him Father, hee would forgiue them as his children. By rea≈øon whereof Chri≈øt our God began his praier with Father forgiue them, giuing thereby to vnder≈øtand, that ≈øeeing hee called him Father, hee ≈øhould bee heard like a ≈øonne. If it ≈øeeme vnto you my louing brethreÃÑ (≈øaith S. The fir≈øt thing wherin he ≈øhewed his mercy towards theÃÑ, was in the petitioÃÑ which he made vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe for them, that is, pardoÃÑ & remi≈øsion of their ≈øins being his enemies; preferring them before his ble≈ø≈øed mother, which brought him into the world, & his welbeloued di≈øciple which followed him, & before Mary Magdalen whom he ≈øo much loued. Barnard ≈øaith, that it was in maner of a coÃÑtention whether were greater the ≈øighs of the faithful, the tears which i≈ø≈øued out of his mothers eies, or the bloud which gu≈øhed out of Chri≈øt vains, or the bla≈øphemies which the wicked Iewes vttered with their mouth: but yet our holy & meek Ie≈øus did fir≈øt pardoÃÑ the iniuries, before he was mindful of the tears. O good Ie≈øus, O redeemer of my ≈øoule (≈øaith An≈øelmus, as thou do≈øt ≈øay, Father forgiue theÃÑ, why do≈øt thou not ≈øay, dry the eies of my ≈øorrowfull mother, ≈øtanch the bloud of my tender vains, & heal the wouÃÑds of my geÃÑtle fle≈øh, & haue pity & coÃÑpa≈øsion of the≈øe faithfull women which here weep for my ≈øake? as thou did≈øt ≈øay in thy la≈øt ≈øupper (≈øaith Ciprian) MandatuÃÑ nouuÃÑ do vobis, I giue you a new coÃÑ mandemeÃÑt, ≈øo mai≈øt thou now ≈øay vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe, I giue you a new exaÃÑple, ≈øeeing that neuer any before thee hath taught vs ≈øo perfect a maner how to loue, nor ≈øo liuely an exaÃÑple how to pardon, & it was a ≈øtrange & a new kind of goodnes which Ie≈øus v≈øed in asking pardon fir≈øt for tho≈øe which crucified him, rather then for tho≈øe which followed him, & for his mother which accompanied him: for without compari≈øon the griefe which he had to ≈øee the ≈øouls of his enemies peri≈øh, was farre

Let no man theÃÑ wonder, nor maruel that our good Ie≈øus did remeÃÑber him≈øelf fir≈øt of the people which murdered him before his mother which bare him, becau≈øe he came not into the world to drie meÃÑs eies froÃÑ weeping, but to ≈øaue≈øoules from peri≈øhing. SecoÃÑdly, the ≈øon of God ≈øhewed his mercy in asking pardon for his enemies with kind & ≈øweet words: that is, not by calling him God, or Lord, or creator, but only father, which is a word an≈øwerable vnto mercy & pity, & contrariwi≈øe this word God, or Lord, doth alwaies ≈øignifie iu≈øtice. WheÃÑ Chri≈øt ≈øaid, Father forgiue them, hee would haue ≈øaid, Lord forgiue them, or my God forgiue them, it would haue ≈øeemed that he would haue had the pardon according vnto the rigor of iu≈øtice: the which if he had required or his father granted, there is no doubt at al, but before the ≈øon of God ≈øhould haue yeelded vp his gho≈øt, the ground would haue opened & ≈øwallowed theÃÑ vp. WheÃÑ the ≈øon of God would ask any great thing of his father, he began his praier alwaies with Father; as wheÃÑ he ≈øaid, I confe≈ø≈øe vnto thee O father, & wheÃÑ he ≈øaid Father into thy hands I coÃÑmend my ≈øpirit. What meaneth this O redecmer of my ≈øoule, what meaneth this? Is thy pity ≈øo great towards vs, and thy mercy ≈øo abundant, that thou doe≈øt pray for thy enemies with the ≈øame wordes, as thou doe≈øt pray for thy own affairs? S. Chry≈øo≈øt. vpon S. Mathew noteth, That the excoÃÑmunicated Iews did alwaies change their ≈øtile & maner of ≈øpeech wheÃÑ they ≈øpake vnto Chri≈øt: for once they ≈øaid, Benedictus qui venit in nomine domini, & anone after they ≈øaid, Vah qui de≈øtruis teÃÑpluÃÑ: but as for the ≈øon of God, as his mind was ≈øincere & clear inwardly, ≈øo his words were holy outwardly: were not think you his words holy, & his thoughts pure & cleare, wheÃÑ he ≈øaid vnto his Father, Father forgiue them, ≈øeeing hee praied with his tongue, & pardoned with his heart? S. Barnard crieth out, O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, O redeemer of my ≈øoule, what coulde≈øt thou haue ≈øaid, or what ≈øhoulde≈øt thou haue done more for thy enemies, thaÃÑ pardon them with all thy heart, & make interce≈øsion for theÃÑ with ≈øuch ≈øweet & louing words? Thirdly
Chri≈øt ≈øhewed his goodnes & mercie, in asking pardon in the pre≈øence of ≈øuch as were there, that is, in the pre≈øence of his ≈øorrowful mother, of his welbeloued di≈øciple, his deer friend Mary Magdalen, his cou≈øins and kindred, ≈øhewing that as all men were by him redeemed, ≈øo al≈øo all ≈øhould be by him pardoned. Vbertinus to this purpo≈øe ≈øaith, O good Ie≈øus in the death which thou did≈øt ≈øuffer, and in the pardon which thou didde≈øt giue to thy enemies, thou didde≈øt not only helpe thy ≈øelfe there with thy tongue, but al≈øo with thy heart, ≈øeeing thou did≈øt entreat thy father with thy tongue that he would haue pity on them, and didde≈øt al≈øo be≈øeech thy mother with thy heart that ≈øhe would forgiue them. Rabanus vpon S. Matthew ≈øaith, That it was not without a high my≈øtery & hidden ≈øacrament, that the ≈øon of God when he died would haue his mother & his kindred there; & the rea≈øon was, becau≈øe they ≈øhould all be witne≈ø≈øes of his pardon, as they were of his pa≈ø≈øion: for our holy Lord had a greater de≈øire that his bloud ≈øhould benefite his enemies, than that his kindred ≈øhould entreat at his death for him. Wherfore O good Ie≈øus (≈øaith An≈øelmus) wherfore did≈øt thou bring thy mother & all thy family to the foot of the cro≈ø≈øe, but only becau≈øe as thou did≈øt ≈øuffer in thy fle≈øh, ≈øo they ≈øhould al≈øo fuffer in their hearts; & as thou did≈øt forgiue theÃÑ thy death, they ≈øhould al≈øo forgiue theÃÑ their iniuries & wrongs done by theÃÑ? Bonauenture ≈øaith, that as the ≈øon of God ≈øaid father forgiue theÃÑ opeÃÑly, ≈øo he ≈øaid mother forgine theÃÑ in≈øecret, in ≈øo much that as the hangmeÃÑ did martirize the ≈øonne, ≈øo the ≈øon martirized the mother, leauing her bound to weep his death, but not licen≈øed to reueÃÑge it. O my Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules health, I be≈øeech thee, that as thou did≈øt get pardon of thy father and mother for thy enemies, ≈øo thou would≈øt get me pardon for my ≈øinnes, ≈øaying, Father forgiue, mother forgiue him, ≈øeeing I am hateful vnto thy father by rea≈øon of the ≈øins which I commit again≈øt him, & vngratefull vnto thy mother for the benefites which I haue receiued of her. O happy & holy day in which thou did≈øt die, ≈øeeing that on that day the Father forgaue his iniury, the ≈øon pardoned his death, the mother pardoned her martyrdome, Saint
Iohn pardoned his reproch and perill, Mary Magdalen her angui≈øh and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and the good theefe was pardoned of his ≈øinne. How was it po≈øsible that the Father ≈øhould not forgiue the world of their ≈øinnes, ≈øeeing that on one day in one houre, and at one time they ≈øaid, Father forgiue them; the ≈øon by letting his bloud ≈øtreame from his vaines, the mother by ≈øuffering her tears flow from her eies, and the ≈øadde familie by piercing the heauen with their ≈øighes? Becau≈øe (≈øaith Ciprian) the office of the ≈øon of God was, to put together that which was broken, and reconcile tho≈øe which di≈øagreed, hee would not depart out of this world, before hee had made an attonement betwixt his friendes and his foes, be≈øeeching his father to forgiue theÃÑ, & coÃÑmanding his mother not to accu≈øe theÃÑ. The ≈øorrowful mother had great rea≈øon to challenge the Iews for the life which they took froÃÑ her ≈øon, and al≈øo the father for the wrongful death which they put him to: & therefore our mo≈øt merciful redeemer, be≈øought of his father that he wold not coÃÑdemn theÃÑ into euerla≈øting damnatioÃÑ, & obtained with his mother that ≈øhe ≈øhold not challeÃÑge hisdeath before any iu≈øtice. But what iu≈øtice could ≈øhe ask of tho≈øe malefactors, ≈øeeing they had been already pardoned of her ≈øonne? An≈øelmus ≈øaith, That wheÃÑ Ie≈øus gaue vp the gho≈øt vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, he left no death for his mother to reueÃÑge, nor iniury to forgiue, but only a bitter pa≈øsion to weep and bewaile, which ≈øhold be great inough to rend her bowels in ≈øunder, & dry vp the tears of hir eies. The 4. goodnes which Chri≈øt ≈øhewed the Iews, was in that he gaue pardoÃÑ to his enemies which did not demaÃÑd it, & yeelded that vnto his crucifiers which they wold not haue. For how is it po≈øsible for tho≈øe men to ≈øeek for pardon, which will not acknowledge them≈øelues culpable? And how ≈øhould they acknowledge theÃÑ≈øelues culpable which ca≈øt al the fault vpoÃÑ him which de≈øerued it not? The Iews were ≈øo fle≈øhed in the bloud of Chri≈øt, & ≈øo far out of their wits, that they did not not only procure & ask pardoÃÑ for their offeÃÑce, but rather hindered it & put it froÃÑ theÃÑ when it was offered theÃÑ, taking delight in the hurt which they did vnto Chri≈øt, & griefe
that they were not able to do him more. When they led the innocent lambe to be crucified, for very ioy they ≈øaid, O thou which doe≈øt de≈øtroy the Temple of God. And when Pilat would haue deferred his crucifying, with great enuy they ≈øaid, If thou let this man goe, thou art not a friend vnto Cae≈øar: in ≈øo much that if they did ≈øhew them≈øelues grieued and ≈øorrie, it was not for that they thought them≈øelues culpable of any crime, but becau≈øe they had deferred and prolonged Chri≈øts life ≈øo long time. The wickedne≈ø≈øe of the Iewes was not content in not hauing pardon of God for their offences, but they demaunded openly vengeance for them, when they ≈øaid vnto Pilat, Let his blood fall vpon vs and vpon our children; and therefore by the≈øe dreadfull words they de≈øire to be puni≈øhed of God, and at no time pardoned at his hands. O wicked Synagogue, O impious ≈øaying. Let his blood be vpon vs. Tell me, I pray thee, why doe≈øt thou de≈øire that the blood of Chri≈øt which hee ≈øhed for to redeeme thee, be ‚Ä¢ urned to condemne thee? The ≈øonne of God appealeth from the≈øe words which they ≈øpeake, and he will not ≈øtand vnto that agreement which the Iewes made with Pilat; hee will not agree that his blood ≈øhould be ≈øhed again≈øt them, but for them: and therefore as they ≈øaid, Let his blood fall vpon vs; ≈øo contrariwi≈øe he ≈øaid, Father forgiue them. O wicked Synagogue, O vnfortunate Iewi≈øh nation (≈øaith Remigius) who hath led you vnto ≈øuch great folly and madne≈ø≈øe, that you ≈øhould more e≈øteeme of the blood of kine (which your prie≈øts ≈øhed in the Temple) than of the blood which Chri≈øt ≈øhed in the mount of Caluarie? Saint Ierome ≈øaith, On the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe the Prophecie of Simeon was fulfilled, who ≈øaid, that Chri≈øts comming into the world was to ≈øome mens good and to others hurt, ≈øeeing that wee doe pray that the blood which hee ≈øheddeth ≈øhould be in the remi≈øsion of our ≈øinnes, and the Iewes doe intreat that it turne vnto their condemnation, and vpon their children. It is much to be noted, that wee ≈øee it often times fall out, that one enemy hurteth not another, and that a good Chri≈øtian doth pardon another
of his offence when hee repenteth, wee ≈øee it al≈øo by experience; likewi≈øe we ≈øee it fulfilled that a perfit man doth loue his enemy: but yet wee neuer ≈øaw that euer any but Chri≈øt pardoned him which would not be pardoned. And how would they be pardoned who pardoned Barrabas and condemned the ≈øonne of God? What contrition of their ≈øinnes haue they, who de≈øired of Pilat that the cur≈øe of God ≈øhould light vpon them and vpon their children? O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe! O vn≈øpeakable charity! did they ≈øay pardy with king Dauid, Tibi ≈øoli peccaui, To thee alone haue I ≈øinned: or with the thiefe, Domine memento mei, Lord remember me; to the end that he ≈øhould ≈øay, God be mercifull vnto you, Mi≈øereatur ve≈øtri? What wit is able to conceiue, or what heart able to acknowledge ≈øuch great mercy, when thou ≈øaid≈øt, Forgiue them, in ≈øtead of their ≈øanguis eius, His blood light vpon vs? O my good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules health, who is hee who dare ≈øay, that hee hath enemies now, ≈øeeing that thou doe≈øt make cleane the vncleane, ≈øette≈øt tho≈øe at libertie which will not be free, loo≈øe≈øt tho≈øe which wil be bound, vnburdene≈øt tho≈øe which will bee burdened, and aboue all giue≈øt pardon vnto tho≈øe which will not be pardoned? If thou doe≈øt pardon that people which would not be pardoned, wilt thou not with a better will pardon him who hath repented him of his ≈øinnes, and whome it grieueth with all his heart to haue offended thee? Saint Augustine vpon S. Iohn ≈øaith, Will not he who meant to meete them who came to apprehend him in the garden of Geth≈øemani, come out to receiue and embrace tho≈øe who goe to ≈øerue him? div.head: CHAP. X. How it is meet for vs to conforme our wills vnto Chri≈øts will, to the end that we may know how to loue him and ≈øerue him.
div.p:
COr tuum numquid e≈øt rectum cum corde meo, ≈øicut cor meum est rectum cum corde tuo? Wee reade in the fourth booke of the Kings that a certaine king of I≈ørael called Iehu going from Samaria to kill the children of Achab and the prie≈øtes of Baal, met on the way with Ionadab, vnto whome he ≈øpake the≈øe words: Tell me, I pray thee, Ionadab, is thy heart and mind ≈øo faithfull and vpright with mine, as my heart is with thine? Ionadab an≈øwered him vnto the≈øe words, Know thou, O king Iehu, that my heart is conformable vnto thine. Iehu replied and ≈øaid, Seeing it is true that thy heart is agreeing vnto mine, giue me thy hand, and come to me into this charriot, where we will talke and communicate of things profitable for vs both. This is a wonderfull figure & worthy of great attention and con≈øideration, ≈øeeing that our Lord doeth teach vs by it, the great good turnes which hee doth vnto vs, and that which in recompence thereof wee are to doe vnto him againe. Who is that king Iehu who taketh his iourney from Iudea vnto Samaria to kill and to take vengeance vpon the wicked men which were there, but onely the ≈øonne of God, who came downe from heauen aboue to de≈øtroy our ≈øinnes? A≈ø≈øure mee (≈øaith Saint Augu≈øtine) that there be no ≈øinners in the world, and I will a≈ø≈øure thee that there be no naughty men in the world; for as in heauen there is no ≈øinne remitted, nor any wicked man there ≈øuffered, and as contrariwi≈øe there is nothing but ≈øinne and wickedne≈ø≈øe in hell, ≈øo al≈øo there is nothing but naughty and wicked men. Wee are much more bound vnto our Chri≈øt, than Samaria
vnto their king Iehu, becau≈øe that that king did only rid Samaria of naughty men, but the ≈øonne of God made cleane & purged all the earth from ≈øinne. Who are the children of Achab who≈øe heads king Iehu cut off, and who are the prie≈øts of Baal which the al≈øo ≈ølew, but Idolatry which hee tooke away from the Gentiles, and the Mo≈øaicall law which hee tooke from the Iewes? What is the charriot which the ≈øon of God went vp into to accompli≈øh ≈øuch high and ≈øtrange things, but onely the cro≈ø≈øe vpon the which our holy Lord attained ≈øuch and ≈øo many great victories? It is to be noted that the king Iehu did not aske Ionadab whether their apparell were alike or neat of one fa≈øhion, but if they loued one another alike; to let vs vnder≈øtand, that without compari≈øon our Lord doeth much more regard the loue which wee beare him, than the ≈øeruices which wee doe him. Saint Ba≈øil vpon the Prophet which ≈øaith, Bonorum meorum non eges, Thou wante≈øt not of my goods, ≈øaith, I ≈øee wel, my God, I ≈øee well, that how much the more need I haue of thee, the le≈ø≈øe thou ha≈øt of me; and if thou ha≈øt need of mee, it is not in re≈øpect of the goods of fortune, but the loue of my mind. Note al≈øo that the king of I≈ørael and no other tooke Ionadab by the hand to lift him vp into the charriot; whereby we are to vnder≈øtand, that onely the ≈øonne of God & no other Saint of heauen, is able to giue vs grace to loue him, & giue vs ≈øtrength to follow him. Who is able to follow thee, or hath power to imitate thee, O redeemer of the vvorld, if thou doe not fir≈øt ≈øtretch out thy hand vnto him? who is able to lift him≈øelfe vp vnto the charriot where thou doe≈øt triumph, or vnto the cro≈ø≈øe whither thou goe≈øt to die, if thou doe not take vs by the arme to lift vs vp, and if thou doe not hold vs by the hand lea≈øt wee fall? How had it beene po≈øsible for Mary Magdalen to haue for≈øaken her prophane life, or Matthew his renting of cu≈øtome, or Paul his per≈øecution, or the thiefe his a≈ø≈øailing of men by the high vvay, if the ≈øonne of God had not taken them by the hand, and lifted them vp vnto the cro≈ø≈øe with him? When in the holy ≈øcripture by the feet are vnder≈øtood good purpo≈øes
and de≈øires, and by the hands good works, what meaneth he by giuing Ionadab his handes and not his feet for to mount into the chariot, but that our good Lord doth rather take hold of the good works which wee doe, then of the good purpo≈øes which wee haue? Gregory in his Regi≈øter ≈øaith; If thou wilt get vp vpon the chariot of the cro≈ø≈øe with thy captaine Ionadab, thou mu≈øt not get vp with thy tongue, which are good words, nor with thy feet, which are good wi≈øhes and purpo≈øes, but with thy hand which are good deeds, becau≈øe S. Iohn dooth not ≈øay, Veeba ‚Ä¢ ecoruÃÑ, Their words, nor De≈øideria coruÃÑ, Their de≈øires, but Opera corum ≈øequuntur illes, Their works follow theÃÑ, It is al≈øo to be noted, that the king of I≈øraell would not ≈øuffer the captaine Ionudab to goe vp into the chariot to him, vntill hee had certified and a≈ø≈øured him that hee was his true friend, in ≈øo much that they vnited their hearts before they ioined their hands. After the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ itation of the≈øe two friends, we mu≈øt haue amity and loue with Chri≈øt, if we wil haue him to helpe vs vp into the chariot: and the amity and friend≈øhip which wee ought to haue with him, is to loue him as hee loueth vs: for Chri≈øt our Lord will fir≈øt bee loued of vs, then ≈øerued by vs. S. Ba≈øil ≈øaith, That if any maÃÑ did labor in the church of God, and take pains, and forgetteth to loue, wee may well ≈øay of ≈øuch a one, that he ≈øhall not only not bee accepted, but that God will thinke him al≈øo importunate and trouble≈øome, becau≈øe God will not be ≈øerued by men of great≈øtrength, & ≈øuch as are forcible, but of ≈øuch as are free of heart. And further the king of I≈ørael was not content to ask Ionadabs heart, but that hee ≈øhould giue it him vpright, ≈øincere and entire; which Chri≈øt al≈øo demandeth of vs, becau≈øe the ≈øon of God will neuer take him for his friend, who hath his heart crooked, ≈øini≈øter, and not vpright. And who hath his heart vpright and ≈øincere, but the ≈øeruant of our Lord, and hee which hath no other thing in this world, nor ≈øeeketh after any thing but onely Ie≈øus Chri≈øt? Who is hee who hath his heart crooked and awry, but hee who is without life, who hath care neither of Chri≈øt, neither of him≈øelfe, but goeth euery houre more
and more ≈øinking, and as it were drowned in the world? Dauid knew this very wel, when he ≈øaid, Cor mundum crea in me deus, & ≈øpiritum rectum innoua in vi≈øceribus meis, as if he would ≈øay; O great God of I≈ørael, O great Lord of the hou≈øe of Iacob, I be≈øeech thee that thou woulde≈øt create a new heart in mee, and fauor me with the gift of a new ≈øpirit which may be both right and true: for the heart which I brought from the womb of my mother, is ≈øuch a one, as I dare not offer it vnto thee, nor he dareth not appear in thy pre≈øence, becau≈øe it is vnclean with ≈øinne, and loaden with thoughts and care. O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules hope, what better praier can I make vnto thee, or what iu≈øter petition can I make vnto thee, then that thou woulde≈øt create a new heart in mee. That is, that you woulde≈øt giue mee a cleane heart, with the which I may prai≈øe thee, and a new ≈øpirit with the which I may loue thee. Giue me O good Lord, giue me a new ≈øpirit, becau≈øe mine is old & vnplea≈øant vnto thee, giue me a cleane and a cha≈øt heart, becau≈øe mine is foule and ≈øtinking before thy face: for if thou do not, no praier of mine can bee acceptable vnto thee, nor no worke that I doe can bee meritorious vnto thee. Ca≈øsiodorus noteth, That king Dauid was not content that hee was noble in bloud, a Prophet by office, a king in degree, and in ≈øurname and calling of a roiall tribe, but he asketh of God aboue all things, that hee would giue him a cleane heart, and poure the holy gho≈øt into him; to let vs vnder≈øtand that it doth little auaile vs to bee gratefull vnto the world, if withall wee bee hatefull vnto God. Then wee are hatefull vnto God and out of his ≈øauour, vvhen our hearts bee vncleane and loaden with many ≈øpirits, and then wee haue many ≈øpirits, when vvee plea≈øe others better then wee plea≈øe God. Which the Prophet liketh not, but praieth vnto God that it would plea≈øe him to giue him a cleane heart to beleeue in him, and an vpright to ≈øerue him. Why vvoulde≈øt thou O my ≈øoule haue more then one heart, ≈øeeing thou art to loue but one Chri≈øt onely? And vvhy al≈øo vvoulde≈øt thou haue more then one holy ≈øpirit, con≈øidering that it is the Deuill vvhich poureth
many ≈øpirits into one body, and our God for all bodies hath but one onely ≈øpirit? S. div.p:
DOmine memento mei dum veneris in regnum tuum, ≈øaid the good theefe which vvas crucified on the right hand of Chri≈øt, and ≈øpeaking vnto Chri≈øt him≈øelfe: and it is as if hee had ≈øaid; O maker of all things and redeemer of all mankind, I be≈øeech thee, that ‚Ä¢ s thou vvoulde≈øt take mee for a companion vnto thee vpon this tree, ≈øo al≈øo thou vvoulde≈øt vouch≈øafe to remeber me aboue in thy kingdome. If vve marke curiou≈øly this ≈øpeech, vve ≈øhall find, that there vvas neuer praier made vvith like circum≈øtances as this vvas. For he vvho made it vvas a theefe, the place vvhere he made it vvas on the cro≈ø≈øe, he vnto vvhom he made it a man crucified, that vvhich hee asketh is a kingdome, and the

I haue of a long time commended vnto my memory, and ≈øingularly well liked of that ≈øpeech of Boetius which ≈øaith, Qu√≤d nihil ex omniparte beatum, as if he would ≈øay; There is nothing ≈øo perfect in this life, which doth neither want, nor abound in ≈øomewhat, in≈øomuch that either we haue need of ≈øci≈ø≈øers to clip off that which is ≈øuperfluous, or a needle and a thimble to ad that which wanteth. Seneca in his booke of Clemency ≈øaith; It is an hundred and twelue years agoe ≈øince I was borne in Cordua a town in Spaine, and it is three≈øcore and eight years agoe ≈øince I came to dwell in the court of Rome, and yet in all this time I neuer ≈øaw any thing ≈øo perfect, which was euen when it came to bee mea≈øured, or of iu≈øt waight in the ballance when it came to be pei≈øed, or ≈øatisfied the eie when it came to bee ≈øeene, or contented mens minds when it came to be enioied. And it is ea≈øily perceiued that there is nothing, Ex omni parte beatum, becau≈øe there hath neuer been any Prince in the world ≈øo famous and renowned, no Philo≈øopher ≈øo wi≈øe, no captaine ≈øo valorous, no per≈øonage ≈øo worthy who wanted not ≈øomewhat worthy of commendation, and in whom there was not found ≈øomwhat worthy of reprehen≈øion. Who doubteth that there is nothing euery way perfect, ≈øeeing there is no maÃÑ aliue who hath not wept, who hath not erred, who hath not ≈øinned, who hath not ≈øighed, and who hath not ben per≈øecuted? How can wee ≈øay that there is any man happy on earth, ≈øeeing he doth a thou≈øand things whereof hee hath cau≈øe to repent, & ≈øcar≈øe one thing worthy of prai≈øe? Only our Lord and no other is, ex omni parte beatuis, in all re≈øpects happy ≈øeeing that of him and of no other, the Prophet ≈øaith, lustus es domine & rectum iudicium tuum, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay; Our Lord is very iu≈øt in him≈øelfe, and vpright in all which hee dooth. It had beene but a ≈ømall honour vnto God to ≈øay that hee was iu≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe it had beene al≈øo ≈øaid that hee did iu≈øtice; and it is a ≈ømall matter to ≈øay that hee did iu≈øtice, vnle≈ø≈øe wee ≈øay al≈øo that hee is very
iu≈øt, becau≈øe there are many which are iu≈øt, and yet doe no iu≈øtice; and very many which doe iu≈øtice, and yet are not iu≈øt. S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaith, That it is ≈øo high and heroical a vertue to hit aright in all things, and not to be able to mi≈ø≈øe in any, that God re≈øerued this point onely vnto him≈øelfe, and participated it with none but vnto his ≈øonne and vnto his mother. Irenaeus vpon the P≈øalmes ≈øayth. That it is a ≈ømall matter to ≈øay of our Lord that he is iu≈øt, ≈øeeing hee is iu≈øtice it ≈øelfe, and to ≈øay that he is vpright, ≈øeeing that he is righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe, and to ≈øay that hee is holy, ≈øeeing that he is holine≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe: becau≈øe there is no other righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe but that which hee hath, no holine≈ø≈øe but that which hee giueth, nor iu≈øtice but that which he doth. Who is ≈øo blind who ≈øeeth not plainely that our Lord is iu≈øt and his iudgement right, ≈øeeing there is no other goodne≈ø≈øe but that which is him≈øelfe, nor other iu≈øtice but that which hee dooth in his owne hou≈øe? Who is ≈øo iu≈øt as thou (≈øayth Hierome) in that which thou doe≈øt, and ≈øo vpright in that which he iudgeth as thou art, O great God of I≈øraell; ≈øeeing that in thy iudgements and ≈øentences neither ignorance deceiueth thee, nor entreaty boweth thee, nor rewards corrupt thee, nor threatnings feare thee? To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, ≈øeeing that thou art iu≈øt O good Lord, and that thy iudgement is rightfull, how fell it out that thou didde≈øt ≈øend Iudas from the cro≈ø≈øe into hel, and tooke≈øt the theefe from thence with thee to Paradi≈øe? Theefe for theefe, naught for naught, ≈øinner for ≈øinner, vngratefull for vngratefull, and both alike: it ≈øeemeth vnto mans iudgement that he ≈øhould as well haue be≈øtowed his kingdome vpon Iudas which followed him three years, as vpoÃÑ the theefe which accompanied him three houres. When our Lord tooke from Cain the right of his fir≈øt birth or inheritance and gaue it vnto Abel, tooke it from I≈ømaell and gaue it vnto I≈øaac, tooke it from E≈øau and gaue it to Iacob, from Ruben and gaue it to Iudah, from Saul and gaue it to Dauid, the rea≈øon was for that hee found in tho≈øe great demerite, whereby they lo≈øt it; and in the others great merit with the which they de≈øerued
it. If Chri≈øt ≈øhould take a kingdome from a naughty man and be≈øtow it vpon a good man, it would bee but iu≈øt: but yet it would ≈øcome a hard point to take it from one theefe & giue it to another, becau≈øe that that is very ill be≈øtowed which is giuen vnto one which is vnworthy of it. Was not the one as great a theefe as the other, ≈øeeing that when the one went robbing by the high way, the other being with Chri≈øt ≈øtole away the almes? But wee an≈øwere vnto this and ≈øay, that neither in this nor in any other God is to be called in que≈øtion, nor yet holy Ie≈øus to bee reprehended, con≈øidering that iu≈øtly he ≈øent the Traitor Iudas into hell, and iu≈øtly likewi≈øe he carried the theefe with him to Paradi≈øe; becau≈øe the one did de≈øerue it becau≈øe hee was a confe≈ø≈øor, and the other lo≈øt it becau≈øe hee was a Traitor. Let vs not bee proud or ≈øtout (≈øayth Cyrillus) for any thing that God dooth, nor bee moued at any thing that God prouideth: for we iudge a man only by the apparrell which he weareth, but he iudgeth him not but by the merites which he doth. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, That before the high Tribunall ≈øeat of Chri≈øt, they doe iniury vnto no man, they deny no man iu≈øtice, they are moued with no man, neither do they any thing there without rea≈øon, becau≈øe there the rod of iu≈øtice is neuer bowed, nor the mea≈øure of mercy euer fal≈øified. For the wi≈øe man ≈øaith, Thou ha≈øt done all thinges good Lord by weight and mea≈øure, ≈øpeaking of Gods gouernment, as if he would ≈øay; O great God of I≈ørael, O mighty God of the hou≈øe of Iacob, how iu≈øt thou art in thy deeds, and how rightful in thy iu≈øtice, becau≈øe that thou do≈øt make al things euen by the line & plummet which thou do≈øt, and doe≈øt heape vp all things which thou doe≈øt giue, becau≈øe they ≈øhall bee of full weight. When dooth our Lord (≈øaith Saint Ambro≈øe) not doe all things by mea≈øure and weight, but when he mea≈øureth our merits with his rod of iu≈øtice, & with the poi≈øe of his great mercy giue vs that which we de≈øerue? Gregory vpon Ezechiel ≈øayth, That when our Lord doth pardon ≈øome & not other≈øome, cha≈øti≈øe the≈øe & not tho≈øe, exalt
this man and pull downe that man, he doth all this in weight and mea≈øure, and not by hap without iu≈øtice; and if at any time his worke breed any admiration in vs, it is not becau≈øe God hath erred in doing it, but becau≈øe wee are not able with our vnder≈øtanding to attaine vnto it. Abraham would willingly that God would haue giuen him pre≈øently the land of promi≈øe which hee had promi≈øed him, but hee gaue it him not vntill three hundred yeares after, expecting vntill the Cananeans ≈øhould fully be vnworthy of it, and the Iewes de≈øerue ‚Ä¢ t. After that king Saule fell from the fauour of God, & good king Dauid was cho≈øen king of I≈øraell, yet there pa≈ø≈øed fortie years before they tooke the crowne from the one, and placed the other in the throne of the king: all which time God looked that Saul would grow wor≈øe and wor≈øe, & that the good king Dauid ≈øhould become better and better. I maruell at nothing that thou doe≈øt O my Lord (≈øaith An≈øelmus:) for although it be hidden from me, yet it wanteth not rea≈øon with thee. If our Lord bee determined to accept of the ≈øacrifice which Abel offered him, and mocke at that which his brother Cain offered, if his will bee to conuert Nabugodono≈øer, and ≈øuffer king Pharao to per≈øi≈øt in his ob≈øtinacy, and if hee let Iudas ca≈øt away him≈øelfe, and yet ≈øaue the theefe, what are we to aske him an account of this: yea and although he wold giue it vs, who is able to vnder≈øtand it? Wee read in the Prophet Daniell, that when God tooke away the kingdome from king Balta≈øer, that fir≈øt hee reckoned and compared his demerites with the merites of the Chaldeans, by mea≈øuring tho≈øe of the one, and weighing tho≈øe of the other; and in the end hee found by iu≈øtice, that the Chaldeans de≈øerued to raigne, and Balta≈øer worthie to lo≈øe his life and e≈øtate. Seeing there is alwaies (≈øayth Chri≈øo≈øtome) in the hou≈øe of God weight and mea≈øure, Quia omnia feci≈øti in pondere & men≈øura, how is it po≈øsible that it ≈øhould be euilly gouerned? div.head: CHAP. II. How Iudas I≈øcarioth was a great theefe; and of the thefts which he committed; and how he fel from the apo≈øtle≈øhip.
div.p:
FVrerat, & locules habebat, & non erat ei cura de egenis; ≈øaith S. Iohn, chap. 12, ≈øpeaking of wicked Iudas. In the holy Colledge of Chri≈øt there was a Di≈øciple called Iudas I≈øcarioth, who was a wicked theefe; he carried the pur≈øe, & he had litle pur≈øes within it, and hee made no reckoning of the poore which were in nece≈øsity. Vnder a few briefe wordes, the Scripture accu≈øeth Iudas of very enormious and greeuous faultes, con≈øidering that it calleth him an open theefe, and ≈øaith, that he had little pur≈øes where he kept that which hee had ≈øtolne, and that he had no compa≈øsion or pity vpon any. It is a carele≈øne≈ø≈øe for a man to be naught alone, to bee naught in the company of naughty men is weakene≈ø≈øe, but to be naught in the company of good men is malice and wickedne≈ø≈øe; becau≈øe it is better rea≈øon that one follow many,
then that many follow one. The vnhappy Iudas had no occa≈øion, nor any rea≈øon to giue him≈øelfe as hee did to ≈øinne, nor yet to dare to ≈øteale as hee did: for if we well con≈øider all circum≈øtances, we ≈øhall find, that in the hou≈øe where hee remained there was pouertie; in the company he went with, there was patience; in the mother which hee ≈øerued there was humilitie; and in the mai≈øter which hee had there raigned charitie. O how well the Apo≈øtle ≈øaid, Qui ≈øe exi≈øtimat ≈øtare, videat ‚Ä¢ ne cadat, He that thinketh to ≈øtand, let him take heed lea≈øt he fall, ≈øeeing that poore Iudas got ≈øuch great wickedne≈ø≈øe in the hou≈øe of holine≈ø≈øe. How ≈øhould it bee po≈øsible for him to bee good in the company of the deuill, which was naught in the company of Chri≈øt? If the infamous Iudas was a theefe and a Traitor, couetous and ambitious, liuing in the company of ≈øo many good, what doe≈øt thou then hope for brother (≈øayth Cyprian) vvhich art compa≈ø≈øed on euery ≈øide with ≈øo many naughty men? The fir≈øt thing that the Scripture accu≈øeth Iudas of, was, that hee was a murmurer and a detractor: ≈øaying, Vt quid perditio haec, &c. as if hee would ≈øay, If it bee ≈øo that Chri≈øt my mai≈øter hath made profe≈øsion of a vertuous man, and preacheth pouerty vnto all the world, and al≈øo reprehendeth ≈øharpely all ≈øuch as ≈øpend any thing wa≈øtfully; it would bee better for him (becau≈øe he might conforme his life vnto his doctrine, to command this ointment to bee ≈øold for a great deale of money, and diuide it afterward among the poore and needy. Here Iudas doth murmure notoriou≈øly, ≈øeeing hee murmureth at the ointment which was ≈øhed, and how euilly it was be≈øtowed, and at Mary Magdalen which ≈øhed it, and hee murmureth at Chri≈øt vpon whome it was ca≈øt. When excommunicated Iudas ≈øaid, Ad quid perditio haec, hee iniuried the other Apo≈øtles, which would not murmure as hee did, hee ≈øcandalized
Simon the leaper, in hearing ≈øuch thinges ≈øpoken of his mai≈øter, hee iniuried Mary Magdalen in finding fault with her for ≈øpending of the ointment, and hee rebuked Chri≈øt, and noted him to be a curious and a daintie man in ≈øuffering it to be ≈øpent vpon him≈øelfe. An≈øelmus talking vnto Iudas ≈øayth, Tell mee I pray thee Iudas, if the ≈øhedding of the ointment vpon thy mai≈øter was a good worke, why doe≈øt thou not like of it as the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles doe? Iohn there al≈øo to haue hindered it, and coun≈øelled him, who was more familiar with him than thou wa≈øt? O wicked Iudas what iu≈øtice is it to ≈øell thy mai≈øter for money, and yet to hold it for an euill thing to annoint him with ointments? Doe≈øt thou make a con≈øcience of it, that they ≈øhould annoint Chri≈øt his tender fle≈øh, and doe≈øt thou make it no ≈øcruple at all to ≈øteale away the almes? O ble≈ø≈øed Magdalen, O happy woman! Ierome in an epi≈øtle) which ≈øay with Iudas, Vt quid perditio haec, What needeth this lo≈ø≈øe, condemning & finding fault at all that which is not done according vnto their will and plea≈øure, in ≈øo much that the murmurer thinketh nothing well done vnle≈ø≈øe it be done as hee will. Becau≈øe the ≈øonne of God dooth repre≈øent all holy and vertuous men (≈øaith Origen,) what other thing is ment, when hee ≈øuffered Magdalen to annoint him and refre≈øh his body, but that he would bee well plea≈øed, that we ≈øhould ≈øerue all holy and good men, and well content that we ≈øhould v≈øe all courte≈øie towards them? Put the ca≈øe (≈øaith S. Chri≈øo≈øtome) That there were a fault in that vnction, yet without compari≈øon Iudas did far more ≈øinne in murmuring at it, then Mary Magdalen in doing it, or Chri≈øt in con≈øenting vnto it. The ≈øecond accu≈øation in ≈øcripture again≈øt this traitor Iudas was, that he was a notonous theefe; which was a vice by God in the old law ≈øtraightly forbidden, and with greeuous puni≈øhments cha≈øti≈øed. As if he would ≈øay: The office which Iudas I≈øcarioth had in Chri≈øts hou≈øe was to receiue and take charge ouer all the alms which denout per≈øons did ≈øend vnto Chri≈øt, and to be≈øtow them, and deuide them to Chri≈øts v≈øe and his Apo≈øtles. S. Iohns woords are to be noted, wheÃÑ he ≈øaith, That Iudas caried tho≈øe things which were ≈øent them: wherein he noteth the great perfection of Chri≈øt, and of his Colledge, con≈øidering that he asked nothing from dore to dore, but did eat only of the alms which were ≈øent them vnto their hou≈øe. The ≈øon of God (≈øaith Dama≈øceu) nor tho≈øe of his holy colledge, were not of tho≈øe poor which were trouble≈øome and importunate, becau≈øe he bu≈øied
him≈øelfe more in preaching than in begging: for if they had no almes ≈øent vnto them, they did eate the eares of the come and the hearbs of the fields. We do not read in the cour≈øe of the whole Go≈øpell, that Chri≈øt commanded or commended any other matter vnto Iudas his di≈øciple, but the gathering of the almes and the charge of tho≈øe temporall matters; in ≈øo much that were it much or little which they did ≈øend vnto Chri≈øt, Iudas did both receiue it and deuide it, and withall ≈øteale the be≈øt part of it. Chry≈øo≈øtome ≈øaith thus, If wee marke it well, our Lord commended his holy ≈øoule vnto his Father, his ble≈ø≈øed mother vnto Saint Iohn, his holy Church vnto Saint Peter, his glorious body to Nicodemus, and his poore ≈øub≈øtance and wealth vnto Iudas; in ≈øo much that hee committed the goods of this life vnto the wickede≈øt man that was theÃÑ aliue. It is not to be thought that it is a good ≈øign if our Lord giue any great aboundance of temporall wealth in this world, ≈øeeing that naughty Iudas ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ charioth had more wealth lone than Chri≈øts whole company and colledge all togither. It is much to be noted, that ≈øeeing Chri≈øt had neither hou≈øe, nor vineyard, nor land, not other rent, but onely the almes which they gaue him in the commonwealth: & al≈øo it is to be thought religiou≈øly, that that which Iudas ≈øtole from Chri≈øt could not bee much, nor that which hee detained from the almes which was giuen him. If it be ≈øo then, that Chri≈øt had but little, and that that which Iudas ≈øtole was not much, why doth the ≈øcripture with open mouth call him a theefe? wicked
‚Ä¢ udas was a thiefe and that a great thiefe, becau≈øe that that which he ≈øtole was a holy thing, and a holy almes, and in a holy hou≈øe, and did belong vnto a holy per≈øon; and therfore according vnto the law of God, that cannot be a ≈ømall theft which is done in a holy and ≈øacred place. Saint Augu≈øt. ≈øaith, that as the two mites which the poore old woman offered in the Temple were more acceptable vnto God than all the trea≈øures of the people, ≈øo our Lord is more offended with a little which is taken out of the Temple, than with a great deale ≈øtollen in the world. Benauenture ≈øaith, that Iudas
did not condemne him≈øelfe for the great quantitie which he ≈øtole, but becau≈øe it was a holy place from whence hee ≈øtole it, and therevpon it is, my religious brother, that thou maie≈øt offend more in taking a ≈ømall thing out of thy mona≈øtery, then a ≈øecular man in taking a greater out of the market. Why ≈øhould any man meruell, that the Scripture calleth vnhappie Iudas a theefe, ≈øeeing hee ≈øtole away the life and goods from the king of glory? Iudas ≈øold Chri≈øts life for many, he put Chri≈øts fame and credit to pledge with the wicked, and hee put Chri≈øts wealth into his pur≈øes: in ≈øo much that if Chri≈øt more had had, more this theefe would haue robbed. O good Ie≈øus, O redeemer of my ≈øoule, if I were Iudas, or Iudas were as I am, I would neuer haue pledged thy honour and credit, nor haue ≈øold thy life: that which I would haue ≈øtolne ≈øhould haue beene the humilitie the which thou didde≈øt liue with, the patience which thou didde≈øt ≈øpeake with, and the charitie which thou did≈øt forgiue with, and the zeale which thou didde≈øt preach with. O what a happy theefe ≈øhould I be if I could rob all the≈øe vertues from thee, ≈øeeing that in ≈øtead of the≈øe thefts heauen gates would be open vnto me. The third accu≈øation is, that wicked Iudas Habebat loculos, that is, had a pur≈øe with litle pur≈øes in it to hide the pence which he had ≈øtolne. Rich couetous men are wont to put their double duckats in one pur≈øe, the ≈øingle in another, ≈øhillings in another, and their ≈ømall money in another, becau≈øe they may find them quickly, and count them ea≈øily. Wherein ≈øaith Seneca doth the felicity of couetous men con≈øi≈øt, but in ≈øeeing euery houre their pur≈øe, counting their money, alwaies hoording vp ≈øomewhat, and in ≈øtudieng how they may le≈ø≈øen their ordinary charges? Aymon noteth, That the Scripture ≈øayth not, that Iudas had pur≈øes, but little pur≈øes, whereby is gathered Chri≈øts and his colledges great pouertie, ≈øeeing that all which that theefe ≈øtole was but ≈ømall ba≈øe money which might well bee contained in ≈ømall pur≈øes. Saint Cyprian noteth, That there was ≈øo little money in Chri≈øts family, that there was not enough to ≈øtuffe a
little pur≈øe, much le≈ø≈øe many pur≈øes: and when the Scripture ≈øayth, that Iudas had many pur≈øes, it was becau≈øe hee had one common pur≈øe to ≈øpend of, and another ≈øecretly to ≈øteale with. O happy time, O golden age of the primitiue Church in the which there was but one pur≈øe among them all: but now ala≈ø≈øe that not among worldlings, but al≈øo among them which profe≈ø≈øe a mona≈øticall life, there is ≈øcar≈øe any one which hath not with Iudas his ≈ømall pur≈øes to keepe his own money in. And hee ≈øaith further, tell me traiterous Monke, tell mee thou Monke which ha≈øt propertie in thinges, what difference is betwixt thee which ≈øteale≈øt the reuenues of thy Mona≈øtery, and the Traitor Iudas which ≈øtole the almes from Chri≈øt? An≈øelmus ≈øayth, That as all perfect men are more bound vnto ≈øtraight v≈øes, than all other worldlings, I dare affirme that hee hath ≈øecret pur≈øes hidden with Iudas, which in his cell fo≈øtereth di≈øordinate and ≈øuperfluous appetites. Saint Ba≈øil in his Rule ≈øayth, As it is a greater perfection in a religious per≈øon to want his owne will, than to want any kind of money, yet wee may ≈øay of ≈øuch a one that it is more daungerous for him to bee mutinous again≈øt his ≈øuperiour, then to haue his pur≈øe full of money. Now thou art to vnder≈øtand my religious brother, that Iudas did not ≈øo much damne him≈øelfe for the money which he carried, as he did becau≈øe he did what he lu≈øted. It is an euill thing to beare the pur≈øe, but it is farre wor≈øe to bee wedded vnto a mans owne will: it is a bad thing to carry pur≈øes with money, but far wor≈øe to fulfill a mans owne appetites, becau≈øe there is no ≈øin which burneth ≈øo much in hell as the ≈øin of a mans owne proper will.

div.head: CHAP. III. Here are reckoned many other great offences which Iudas committed, and diuers trea≈øons which he did again≈øt Chri≈øt.
div.p:
IV≈øtificationes tuas cu≈øtodiam, non mederelinquas v≈øquequaque, ≈øaid the Prophet Dauid in his 118 P≈øalme; as if hee would ≈øay, O great God of I≈ørael, O great God of the hou≈øe of Iacob, I be≈øeech thee with all humility, that ≈øeeing I bind my ≈øelfe to keepe thy commaundements all the daies of my life, that thou woulde≈øt not for≈øake me vntill my death. This is a high praier which the Prophet maketh, con≈øidering that hee doeth capitulate and agree with God, and God with him, that he will ≈øerue our Lord, & that our Lord will haue charge ouer him. It is much to bee noted with Ca≈øsiodorus vpon the P≈øalmes, that the Prophet doth not only ≈øay, Doe not for≈øake mee, but he addeth al≈øo V≈øquequaque, that is, that hee would not for≈øake him all his life, and al≈øo that he would giue him his helping hand in all that hee ≈øhall goe about. O good Ie≈øus, O the loue of my ≈øoule, I be≈øeech thee, that if thou doe ≈øuffer me to fall into any ≈øin, yet that thou woulde≈øt not for≈øake me, V≈øquequaque, Alwaies or continually, and let me commit all ≈øinne, for if thou doe not hold mee with thy mercifull hand, where ≈øhall I ≈øtop but in the pains of hel? Our Lord hath held many with his hands, as Cain, Heli, Saule, and Mana≈ø≈øes; but hee did not hold them V≈øquequaque, that is ≈øtill, and all in all vntill the end; con≈øidering that the one ≈ølew his brother, the other lo≈øt his Prie≈øthood, the other was depriued of his kingdome, and the other died a Pagan. Hee did al≈øo for≈øake Dauid in his adultery, S. Peter when hee denied him, Paul when hee per≈øecuted him;
but he did not for≈øake them, V≈øquequaque, that is, vntil death; for of great ≈øinners they became very holy and cho≈øen men. O what a ≈øingular fauour, ≈øayth S. Ba≈øil vpon the P≈øalmes, our Lord doth vnto tho≈øe whome he doth not vtterly for≈øake, as he neuer doth his be≈øt friends; the which although they bee euilly handled, and ≈øuffer much, yet hee doth it rather to exerci≈øe them, then to for≈øake them. The vnhappy and vnfortunate Iudas cannot ≈øay truly vnto our Lord, leaue me not for euer, becau≈øe his ≈øinnes were ≈øo great and his offences ≈øo grieuous, that he was for≈øaken of Gods hands vtterly, & he made him≈øelfe wholly vnworthy of Gods mercy and clemency. Was not the traitor Iudas vtterly for≈øaken thinke you, ≈øeeing that he ≈øold our Lord & ma≈øter vpon the Wedne≈øday, & vpon the Friday after he hanged him≈øelfe vpon a tree? Doe not for≈øake mee O good Ie≈øus, doe not for≈øake me V≈øquequaque, for euer: but if thou wilt for≈øake me for a time, and withdraw thy helping hand from mee, forget mee no longer then thou didde≈øt forget S. Peter, which was vntill hee wept; and doe not forget mee as thou didde≈øt Iudas, vntill hee hanged him≈øelfe. The ≈øcripture accu≈øeth Iudas that he had noregard vnto the needy and poore, but that he was more careful to ≈øteal ≈øomewhat from the almes which was giuen vnto Chri≈øt, then to bee pitifull vpon the poore and nece≈øsities which were among the people. Su≈øpirabam, ligatus ≈øum non cathenis ferreis, ≈øed me a praua voluntate, ≈øaith Saint Augu≈øtine in the eighth of his Confe≈øsions, as if he would ≈øay; O how many times did I pierce the heauens with ≈øighes, and watered the fields with my teares, ≈øeeing my ≈øelfe taken and bound in yrons, and yet not with fetters and cheines, but with my own proper wicked vvill: and that vvhich I cannot ≈øpeake vvithout vveping is, that I yeelded my owne will vnto the enemie, and with my vvill he doth that vvhich is not my will. Who euer vttered ≈øuch pitifull vvords vntill this day? O vvith vvhat great rea≈øon this holy man ≈øpeaketh this, and vvith vvhat greatrea≈øon hee vveepeth for giuing our vvill vnto the deuill, ≈øeeing hee maketh of our vvill that vvhich vve vvill not: for if vve giue
the enemy once an entrance into our ≈øoule, he rebelleth pre≈øently with the chiefe≈øt force hee hath, Iudas gaue principally his will vnto the deuill, and hee in lieu of his will, taught him to murmure, and hauing taught him to murmure hee v≈øed him to ≈øteale, and hauing v≈øed to ≈øteale he began to haue pur≈øes, and that being done hee came to ≈øell Chri≈øt for couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe. What would the Prophet ≈øay when hee ≈øaith, aby≈ø≈øus abi≈ø≈øum inuocat, One depth calleth another, but that the qualitie of one ≈øinne is to call another vnto him. Augu≈øt. vpon the P≈øalmes ≈øaith; King Dauid ≈øaith very well that one ≈øinne enti≈øeth another, con≈øidering that of idlene≈ø≈øe commeth looking, of looking de≈øiring, of de≈øiring con≈øenting, of con≈øenting doing, of doing per≈øeuering, of per≈øeuering damning him≈øelfe, in ≈øo much that wee goe from ≈øinne vnto ≈øin in po≈øt ha≈øt, vntill we be benighted in hell. Iucundus home qui mi≈øeretur, & commodat, &c. ≈øaith Dauid in his hundred & eleuenth P≈øalme, as if hee would ≈øay. O how happy is that man who is pitiful with the weake, a giuer of almes vnto the poore, and mode≈øt in that which hee ≈øpeaketh: for although God ≈øuffer ≈øuch a one to be tempted, yet hee ≈øuffereth him not to bee ouercome. S. Ierome vpon the≈øe words ≈øaith, If thou marke it well, there is no man called plea≈øant and faire in Scripture, but hee which v≈øeth pitie, and giueth almes, and hee who mea ‚Ä¢ reth his words before hee vtterthem; for ≈øuch a one is in fauour with God, and e≈øteemed among men. Who hath ben mercifull vnto his brother in this world, vnto whom God hath not beene the like in the other? who hath imparted his goods vnto the poor, vnto whom God hath not imparted his glory? who hath brideled his tongue, who hath not benregarded & re≈øpected for it? What greater reward would he haue which v≈øeth mercy, or he which giueth alms of his ≈øub≈øtance or he who hurteth no man with his tongue, then that oth and promi≈øe which the Prophet ≈øpeaketh of, Qu√≤d in aternum non commouebitur, that although he be neuer ≈øo much vexed and beaten with temptations, yet our Lord will not ≈øuffer him to be ouerthrown. S. Barnard ≈øaith vpon Qui habitat, O good Ie≈øus,
O the glory of my ≈øoul, if my hart be a≈ø≈øured by thee that he ≈øhal not bee moued for euer, what doe I weigh it if pride beate me, if anger moue mee, if enuy mole≈øt me, yea and the fle≈øh di≈øquiet me? when our Lord asketh of vs that we would be merciful, & alms giuers, & fair ≈øpoken, it is a very ≈ømal matter that he asketh of vs, con≈øidering that which he doth promi≈øe for it: for for to be a≈ø≈øured, that neither in aduer≈øity which may come vnto him, nor pro≈øperity which hee may happen vnto, Qu√≤d in aeternuÃÑ, that his heart ≈øhall neuer bee moued, is ≈øuch a great matter that it can neither bee bought with the weight of tears, nor de≈øerued by heroicall deeds. The contrary vnto all this was found in wicked Iudas: for in ≈øteed of pitty he was cruel, coÃÑ≈øidering how he had no regard vpon the poor, & in ≈øtead of almes-giuing he ≈øtole the almes from Chri≈øt, & in≈øtead of brideling his tongue he ≈øold his God & Lord vnto the Synagogue; and how could Iudas the theefe haue pity on the poor which begged among the people, ≈øeeing he ≈øtole the alms which they gaue vnto Chri≈øt? If it be a ≈øin to ≈øteale from a rich man, yea that which hee aboundeth with; ≈øhall it not be a ≈øin & a wicked ≈øacriledge to ≈øteale from the poor that which they haue nece≈øsity of? wheÃÑ tho≈øe of Chri≈øts holy colledge did eat the ears of corne for pure hunger, they would rather haue earen bread and meat if they had had money to buy it. If Iudas did ≈øee Chri≈øt deuide the apo≈øtles alms to the needy poor, he ≈øhould nor only not haue takeÃÑ it as a reprochfull thing & di≈øhone≈øt, but rather he ≈øhould haue ben thankfull and glad for it, becau≈øe there is no worke of mercy which is not in this world commeÃÑded, and in the other rewarded. It is a certaine thing that the eues wi≈øh not well vnto the poore, becau≈øe a theefe will neuer come to him whom he thinketh will aske ≈øomething of him, but vnto tho≈øe from whome they imagine they can ≈øteale ≈øomewhat away. Fulgentius ≈øaith in a ≈øermon; If ≈øorrowfull Iudas had beene loiall vnto his mai≈øter, mercifull vnto the poore, friendly with the Apo≈øtles, di≈øciplinable in his manners, and not de≈øirous of other mens goods, our Lord would neuer haue left him to haue gone
out of his colledge, nor hee euer haue committed trea≈øon. Who made thee O Iudas ≈øtumble and fall into ≈øuch enormious and greeuous ≈øins, but thy ≈ømall or rather no pity? When the ≈øcripture accu≈øeth the traitor Iudas that he had no care of the needy, it is a matter both to make vs afeard, and al≈øo to wonder at; becau≈øe that in the ≈øight of our Lord, the almes which we doe vnto the poore are much more accepted, than the ≈øacrifice and incen≈øe which we offer him. Iudas is al≈øo accu≈øed of that which hee did in the parlar where hee ≈øupped, when Chri≈øt ≈øaid. Ecce manus tradentis me, as if hee would ≈øay; O my di≈øciples, O my only ≈øons and companions, truly I open and di≈øcouer one thing vnto you: that is, that one of you which are here with me, hath ≈øold me by trea≈øon, and which is wor≈øt of all, hee doth eat with mee at my table and at my owne di≈øh. Chri≈øt complaineth that Iudas ≈øold him vnto the Synagogue, and that hee ≈øate at his table with him, and that he did eat with one hand only, and that he was a≈øhamed neither of the one nor of the other: and there is none of this ≈øpoken without a great my≈øterie. Confundimini & crube≈øcite ≈øuper viis ve≈øtris √¥ domus I≈ørael, ≈øaid God by Ezechiel, chap. 6, as if hee would ≈øay: O hou≈øe of I≈ørael, O ye people of Iuda, bee now a≈øhamed of the filthy works which you doe, and of the wicked ≈øteps yee walke in. For I am much more offended to ≈øee how little you e≈øteeme of me, then of the offences which you commit again≈øt me. A man which is of a noble and ≈øtour courage, and of a ≈øhamefa≈øt countenance, although hee haue beene offended and wounded by another, yet he doth not ≈øo much feele the iniury which is done, as he greeueth to ≈øee his enemy walke before his hou≈øe; becau≈øe the brabble proceeded of anger, but the going about his hou≈øe commeth from malice. Gregory vpon Ezechiel ≈øaith thus, Our Lord had great rea≈øon to complain of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael, & of the kingdome of Iuda, and that not ≈øo much for the wickedne≈ø≈øe they committed, as for the ≈ømall ≈øhame they had in committing it; becau≈øe that hee wil either late or neuer amend, which is not a≈øhamed at all to haue offeÃÑded. It is to be noted that the Prophet
≈øaith, Erube≈øcite de vijs ve≈øtris, that is, that we ≈øhould bee a≈øhamed to walke our waies, becau≈øe to walke vnto the fle≈øh and the world there are many waies, which are all of vanity: but to walke vnto heauen there is but one way, which is of charity. What are our waies but onely our di≈øordinate and naughty de≈øires? Whither doe our de≈øires lead vs, but vnto vices, and from vices vnto ≈øins, and from ≈øins vnto hell? Then be a≈øhamed to ≈øinne or to haue ≈øinned: for as S. Ambro≈øe ≈øaith, The fir≈øt ≈øtep to repentance is to bee a≈øhamed of the ≈øinne committed. What ≈øaith the ≈øon of God, when hee ≈øaith, Behold the hand of him which betraieth me: what el≈øe doth he ≈øay thaÃÑ, behold the Traitor, behold wicked Iudas, who is not coÃÑtent to haue ≈øold me vnto the ≈øynagogue, but al≈øo ≈øitteth & eateth at my table without any ≈øhame at all. The ≈øon of God could not haue ≈øpoken a word of greater iniury to Iudas than to call him Traitour: for after a man hath committed trea≈øon again≈øt another, there is neuer after any hope to be had of him, nor tru≈øt to bee put in him. Iudas was a Traitor in ≈øelling Chri≈øt vnto tho≈øe vnto whome hee did ≈øell him: that is, vnto his mortall enemies, who bought him not becau≈øe hee ≈øhould ≈øerue them, but becau≈øe they would bee reuenged on him. Iudas was a traitor, for ≈øelling Chri≈øt for ≈øo ba≈øe and vile a price, becau≈øe a lu≈øtie and an able young man, as Chri≈øt was, was more worth if it had beene but to make a ≈ølaue of. Iudas was a Traitor in ≈øelling him vnto them, becau≈øe in doing of it he ≈øhewed great malice, and exceeding auarice, ≈øeeing hee agreed with his enemies for him at the fir≈øt word, & hee neuer replied nor hucked one word vpon the ≈øale. Iudas was al≈øo a traitor, becau≈øe he went of his own voluntary wil to ≈øel Chri≈øt, not being asked nor induced vnto it by any, wherein he ≈øhewed his infamous condition & wicked trea≈øon. For by ≈øo much the more ≈øins are offen≈øiue, by how much the occa≈øions were le≈ø≈øe which cau≈øed vs to commit them. Iudas was al≈øo a Traitor in ≈øitting with Chri≈øt at his table, as though he had offended him in nothing: vvherein he ≈øhewed his ≈ømall con≈øcience and great impudency; for hauing as hee had the money in
his pur≈øe, for the which he ≈øold Chri≈øt, it was not rea≈øon hee ≈øhould haue eaten with him in his di≈øh. Remigius exclaimeth in an epi≈øtle: O vnto how many may Chri≈øt ≈øay now adaies, behold the hand of him which betraieth mee is at the table with me, all which like vnto Iudas either by v≈øury, or by ≈øymony dare ≈øell Chri≈øt, and after eat with him at the ≈øame me≈ø≈øe, prophaning and wa≈øting church-goods, as though they had co≈øt Chri≈øt nothing! S. Augu≈øt. vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, That there ≈øupped but one Traitor in the parlar with Chri≈øt, but now adaies in the table of his church there dineth & ≈øuppeth an infinit number of Traitors: and that which cannot be ≈øpoken without tears is, that neuer ≈øeruing nor benefiting the catholike church at all, they eat and take away the fruit which Chri≈øt got vs with his precious bloud. Tell mee my brother, tell mee I pray thee, what difference is there betwixt thee which ≈øelleth Chri≈øt for ≈øinnes, and Iudas which ≈øold him for money? Is it not thinke≈øt thou a greater ≈øinne to ≈øell Chri≈øt for other ≈øinnes, then for Iudas to ≈øell him for thirty peeces of money? The difference which I find betwixt thee who art a ≈øinner, and wicked Iudas who was a Traitor is, that hee ≈øold Chri≈øt but once, and thou ≈øelle≈øt him euery day and houre: and in ≈øo greeuous an offence there can be nothing more iu≈øt, that ≈øeeing thy trea≈øon is greater than his, that thy condemnation al≈øo ≈øhould be greater than his. It is al≈øo to be weighed that Chri≈øt doth not ≈øay that Iudas did eat with him with both hands, but with one only; for hee ≈øaith: Ecce manum tradentis me; Behold the hand of him who betraieth me, which hee ≈øpake not without a ≈øecret my≈øterie. S. Ierome ≈øayth thus, He who could haue ≈øeene Iudas in the parlar, ≈øhould haue ≈øeene how his heart was giuen to the deuill, his body vnto the world, his word vnto the Synagogue, his left hand vpon his pur≈øe, and with his right hand hee did eat with Chri≈øt. Vbertinus ≈øayth, That he doth eat with the Traitor Iudas at the table with one hand, who liueth in a mona≈øtery, not with a purpo≈øe to follow Chri≈øt, but with an intention to flee the perils of the world, and coker him≈øelfe with
the goods of the mona≈øtery. Bonauenture ≈øayth, That then the religious man eateth with one handwith Iudas at Chri≈øts table, when he liueth in the mona≈øtery by nece≈øsitie, and not voluntarily, in≈øomuch that his body is in his cell, & his heart in the market place. Thus then you haue had recited vnto you the heinous offences, which the Traitor Iudas committed, and how iu≈øtly our Lord condemned him: ≈øo that now there remaineth onely to tell you of the perfections which were in the good theefe which died with Chri≈øt, and how iu≈øtly Chri≈øt tooke him to heauen with him.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of the great vertues which the good theefe had which died with Chri≈øt, and how he beleeued: and of that which the Prophet Ieremy ≈øpeaketh to this purpo≈øe.
div.p:
TOnde capillum tuum & proijce, & ≈øume indirectum planctum, quiae perijt fides & ablata e≈øt de ore eorum, ≈øaid God vnto the Prophet Ieremy in the 7. chap, as if hee would ≈øay. O Ieremy my friend and Prophet, poule the haire of thy head, and then ca≈øt it vnder thy feet, and weepe and bewaile the Synagogue, becau≈øe now there is no truth in her mouth, and the faith of her Commonwealth is vtterly lo≈øt. Men did neuer poule their heads in holy ≈øcripture, nor rent their garments, nor ≈øhed many tears, but for very great di≈øa≈øters, or pitifull accidents; as for the death of Iobs childreÃÑ, & with all the lo≈ø≈øe of all his goods; for what cau≈øe holy Iob ≈øhaued his hair, rent his garmeÃÑts, & cried out with loud cries. O high iudgements of God, O in≈øcrutable ≈øecrets of Gods diuine prouideÃÑce! vvhich of the Saints de≈øerue to vnder≈øtand them, or vvhich of the Seraphins is able to attaine vnto theÃÑ? We ≈øee daily that ≈øome ≈øteale in their childhood, ≈øome in their youth, ≈øome at mans e≈øtate, ≈øome in their old age, ‚Ä¢ nd ≈øome euen vnto the gallowes: but yet to ≈øteale vpon the gallowes, of whom do we read it, but of this holy theefe? There was neuer any famous theefe, that euer did ≈øo famous a robbery before he came to the gallowes, as this good theefe did euen vpon the gallowes, con≈øidering that before all their faces he ≈øtole away the kingdome of heaueÃÑ. O that this was a happy theft which the theefe ≈øtole vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, con≈øidering that hee ≈øtole the ≈øonne from his father, their Lord from the Angels, and their creator from the Iewes, and their redeemer from the Chri≈øtians. Who euer ≈øaw any thing like vnto this, who euer heard any thing like vnto this, or who euer read any thing like vnto this? When other men ask pardon of the people, ≈øay their beliefe, re≈øtore things taken away, as all other theeues doe, at that time thou doe≈øt go about to ≈øteale anew. O my ≈øoule, O my heart if you will ≈øteale and rob with this theefe, ≈øuffer your ≈øelues to be taken, then to be bound, then to bee di≈ømembred and crucified: for as in the world when wee are at liberty money is ≈øtolne, ≈øo vpon the cro≈ø≈øe when we lo≈øe our liberty, the heauens are ≈øtoln. Adams was but a ≈ømall theft, ≈øeeing of all Paradi≈øe hee ≈øtole but one apple. But this good theefe was not content with the apples of Paradi≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe he ≈øtole all Paradi≈øe. It was a vaine and a light theft which faire Rachel committed again≈øt her father Laban, and this of the theefe was an honorable theft, becau≈øe hee did not aba≈øe him≈øelfe to ≈øteale idols made of wood, but
