The theft which king Dauid coÃÑ mitted was a bold theft, when hee ≈øtole the bottle of water and the ≈øpeare from king Sauls boul≈øter: but the good theeues theft was more ≈øolemne, who ≈øtole not a launce from a boul≈øter, nor a bottle of water, but he ≈øtole Chri≈øts body drie and without bloud, and his ≈øide which was pierced with a launce. Moi≈øes ≈øpies were craftie and ≈øubtile theeues, vvhich ≈øtole avvay the bunch of grapes of the land of promi≈øe: but the good theefe vvas farre more ≈øubtiler, ≈øeeing hee ≈øtole from tho≈øe vvho had ≈øtolne, not a bunch of grapes vvhich hanged, but Chri≈øt crucified. Let al the theeues that are, come forth (≈øaith Cyprian) and bee compared vvith this theefe, and they ≈øhall find for a truth, that he is the greate≈øt of all, and the mo≈øt famous of them all: ≈øeeing that if other doe ≈øteale they lo≈øe their life, but this in ≈øtealing recouered life.

div.head: CHAP. VI. How the good theefe had nothing remaining on the cro≈ø≈øe, but his heart and his tongue: and that by the≈øe two hee gained glory: and there are curious points vttered touching the heart.
div.p:
OMni cu≈øtodia custodi cor tuum, quia ex ip≈øo vitaprocedit, ≈øaid Salomon the vvi≈øe, ≈øpeaking vvith his ≈øon Roboam, in the fourth chap. of his Prouerbes; as if he vvould ≈øay, I coun≈øell thee my ≈øon Roboam, as a thing that doth very much import thee, that thou keep thy heart vvith all care & vvatching, becau≈øe from him proceedeth al the good of thy life. It doth behooue vs very much that vvee beleeue this that the vvi≈øe man ≈øaith, and al≈øo keepe it, ≈øeeing he vvriteth it vvith ≈øuch high vvordes, and per≈øuadeth it vvith ≈øuch
deepe rea≈øons. I confe≈ø≈øe for my owne part, that among≈øt all the things which I haue read, or haue heard wi≈øe men ≈øpeake of, there is none that hath taken ≈øuch deep root in my memory, nor hath ≈øatisfied my iudgemeÃÑt like vnto this couÃÑ≈øel of the wi≈øe man. For the better commending of which ≈øpeech I wi≈øh I had Homers vnder≈øtanding, Platoes wit, Diogenes phra≈øe, E≈øchines art of Oratory, & Ciceroes tongue. After this ≈øaying, & in compari≈øon of it, there is nothing more to bee thought, nothing more to be ≈øought, nothing more to be ≈øaid, nor nothing more to be commended: for vnder this ≈øpeech is comprehended, al the goodnes that hath ben written vntil this day, & all that which is nece≈ø≈øary for thy ≈øaluation. This is a high doctrin, a wonderful ≈øaying, worthy to be heard, and true to be beleeued, iu≈øt to be taught, & wholly to be ob≈øerued. S. Ierome ≈øaith thus of it: wheÃÑ the wi≈øe man ≈øaith, Omni cu≈øtodia, Keep thy hart with al watching, it is to ≈øay plainly, keep, keep, watch, watch, be adui≈øed, be adui≈øed, ≈øhut ≈øhut the gates & entrance of thy heart: for it is he in whom our Lord de≈øireth to delight in, and that is he vvhom the deuill al≈øo would willingly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe. S. Augu≈øtine in a ≈øermon ≈øaith, The wi≈øe man ≈øaith not without cau≈øe, keepe thy heart with a carefull watch, con≈øidering that God and the deuill, and the diuell and God ≈øtriue not who ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the eies wee doe ≈øee with, or the tongue which we ≈øpeak with, but only which of theÃÑ both ≈øhall hou≈øe & ≈øhut him≈øelf as in a ca≈øtle in our harts which we bear: in≈øomuch that in the guard & keeping of the hart con≈øi≈øteth our ≈øaluation or perditioÃÑ. Origen ≈øaith, That wheÃÑ the wi≈øe man ≈øaith, Omni cu≈øtodia cor tuuÃÑ cu≈øtodi, he doth forwarne vs & adui≈øe vs, that we put diligeÃÑt watch & ward ouer our fugitiue hart, becau≈øe the fle≈øh may not defile him, the world mooue him, the deuill deceiue him, the enemy ≈øteale him & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him. What els doth he ≈øay wheÃÑ he biddeth thee watch & ward thy hart, but only that ≈øo much intere≈øt wee haue in Chri≈øt, how much hee him≈øelfe hath in our hearts. If God hath little in thee, thou ha≈øt litle in God: if thou ha≈øt much in God, god hath much in thee: & ≈øeeing thou woulde≈øt haue nothing of God but thy ≈øaluation, &
God would haue nothing of thee but thy heart, thou oughte≈øt highly to keepe it, and tru≈øt it and commit it to none but vnto him. S. Gregory in his Morals ≈øaith, The coun≈øell of the wi≈øe man is very deepe, and his adui≈øe very diuine, when hee ≈øaith, Keepe thy heart with all watching, and the rea≈øon is, that becau≈øe all that which God giueth vs, and al that which wee offer vnto him is worth nothing if it bee not kept in the heart, and proceed from the heart: and therefore it is a very whole≈øome thing that our hearts bee alwaies full of good de≈øires, and very far from vaine thoughts. Tell mee I pray thee, why the wi≈øe man was not content to ≈øay, that wee ought to keepe the heart, but he added that we ≈øhould keep him with all watching and guarding, and put him in very great ≈øafetie? What other thing is it to keepe it with al guard, but only that wee ≈øhould not giue place for any vanity or folly to enter in? Seneca ≈øaith in an Epi≈øtle, Wee ≈øee that the eies are defended with the eie lids, the mouth with the lips, the ears with a cotton, the bands with gloues, the corne in the garner, and mony in che≈øts: but no man is able to take away vaine de≈øires from the ambitious & mutinous heart, nor cut off his light cogitations. Tel me I pray thee what trea≈øure is there in mans heart, becau≈øe he ≈øhold be gorged with ≈øo many guards? O my brother if thou didde≈øt know what a great trea≈øure that is which God hath left in keeping in the heart of the iu≈øt man, I a≈ø≈øure thee, and ≈øweare vnto thee, that thou would≈øt keep thy heart with a ≈øtrong guard, & would≈øt not con≈øent that any but God ≈øhold enter into it. is it not thinke≈øt thou great rea≈øon that thy hart be wel guarded, ≈øeeing God wil not haue it for any other but for him≈øelfe? In the he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t of man there is the rea≈øonable power, with the which hee gouerneth him≈øelfe, the ira≈øcible power with the which he defendeth him≈øelf, & coÃÑcupi≈øcible with the which hee prouideth for things nece≈ø≈øary; and in the keeping of the≈øe three powers, the ≈øaluation of the ≈øoul con≈øi≈øteth, & the re≈øt & quietnes of the life. The diuell trauelleth much like vnto another Ioab, to giue vs three fierce wounds in the≈øe three noble powers, becau≈øe our ≈øorrowful heart ≈øhould
faint & be di≈ømaied, & not know how to gouerne him≈øelfe in pro≈øperity, nor help him≈øelf in aduer≈øity. S. Barnard vpoÃÑ Qui habitat ≈øaith, O what guards & double guards, O what watches & double watches meÃÑ ≈øhould put to their poor heart, that is, Liberality again≈øt the world which doth compa≈ø≈øe vs with riches, Cha≈øtity again≈øt the fle≈øh, which doth enuiron vs with plea≈øures, Charity again≈øt the diuel who doth vex vs with malice. If we had as great a care in guarding our harts, as the diuel hath in fighting with it, he ≈øhold neuer bring vs into ≈øuch great di≈øquietnes, nor could neuer put vs in ≈øuch danger and perill. If thou wilt hear me tel thee the order of thy perditioÃÑ, thou ≈øhalt perceiue clearly, that it ri≈øeth for want of putting a guard ouer thy hart: in≈øomuch, that at the ≈øame in≈øtant in which we withdraw the guard froÃÑ our hart, pre≈øently our coÃÑ≈øcieÃÑce runneth to perdition. TheÃÑ the order of our di≈øorder is, that the ≈øight breedeth thought, thought breedeth delight, delight breedeth coÃÑ≈øent, coÃÑ≈øent breedeth work, the work breedeth cu≈øtome, cu≈øtome breedeth ob≈øtinatioÃÑ, ob≈øtinatioÃÑ breedeth de≈øperatioÃÑ, & de≈øperatioÃÑ damnatioÃÑ. Would it not be iu≈øt to keep a hart manacled & fettered, which bringeth forth ≈øuch children & nephews? who holdeth you O my ≈øoul loaden with ≈øcrupulo≈øities, who holdeth you O my body tormeÃÑted with trauails, but only the towers of wind which my heart breedeth, & a thou≈øand daÃÑgers into which he ca≈øteth him≈øelf? It is very coÃÑuenieÃÑt ≈øaith An≈øelmus, that we keepe our heart in work, becau≈øe that which we ≈øhal do may be good, & keep our tongue very well, becau≈øe that which we ≈øhal ≈øpeak may be iu≈øt, & keep wel our thought, becau≈øe that which we ≈øhall think may be clean and pure, becau≈øe our hearts ≈øhalbe ≈øuch as our works are. Audi popule ≈øtulte, audiqui non babes cor, ≈øaid God by the Prophet Ieremy in the 5. chap: as if he would ≈øay, Heare my fooli≈øh & cur≈øed people, heare mee people without heart, which art come to ≈øuch perdition, that thou wante≈øt rea≈øon, and ha≈øt no heart. God could not haue ie≈øted at the people of I≈ørael, nor giuen theÃÑ a greater ≈øcoffe than call them fooles without a heart. For ≈øeeing that the life of the body is the heart, as it is, and the life
of the heart the ≈øoule, and God the life of the ≈øoule, & that the life of God is God him≈øelfe; what other thing is it to be without a heart, than to be naught and vvithout a ≈øoule? Origen vpon
‚Ä¢ eremy ≈øaith, That God ≈øpeaketh not of the heart of fle≈øh which is in the brea≈øt, for this heart no Iew vvanted; but God ≈øpeaketh of holy & ≈øpiritual hearts, with the which vvee ≈øerue our Lord, and ≈øaue our ≈øoules: & in this ≈øence if any one want a heart, hee wanteth al≈øo rea≈øon. And if this be true as true it is, that the heart is nothing el≈øe but rea≈øon, vvhat lo≈øeth he who lo≈øeth his heart, and vvhat hath hee vvho hath not his heart? And therefore there are not any put into the hou≈øe of innocents, or into Bedlem, becau≈øe they wanted a heart to liue with; but becau≈øe they want rea≈øon to gouerne them≈øelues with: & for this cau≈øe is not he a verier foole who liueth not according to rea≈øon, thaÃÑ he who hath his heart mole≈øted and troubled. Plato ≈øaith in his Timaeo; If a man doth lo≈øe his eies, or feet, or hands, or his wealth, we may ≈øay of ≈øuch a one, that if he lo≈øe, he lo≈øeth ≈øomewhat; but hee who lo≈øeth his heart & rea≈øon lo≈øeth all: for in the wombe of our mother the fir≈øt thing which is engendred is the heart, and the la≈øt thing which dieth is the ≈øame heart. Becau≈øe wee haue great need of patience in the trauails which we do endure, and con≈øtancy in the good works which we do take in haÃÑd, God doth vs a principall fauour in making vs a ≈øtout heart, & it is al≈øo a great puni≈øhmeÃÑt of him to make vs of a faint hart. An≈øelmus in his meditations ≈øaith, O good Ie≈øus, O the glory of my ≈øoule, ≈øtop I pray thee, ≈øtop my ears, that I heare not, make my eies blind that I ≈øee not, cut off my hands that I ≈øteale not, with coÃÑdition that thou would≈øt leaue me a wil to ≈øerue thee, and a heart to loue thee. How is it po≈øsible that I ≈øhold loue thee, & ≈øerue thee with al my hart, if thou O ≈øweet Ie≈øus doe≈øt let my heart lo≈øe it ≈øelf? ≈øeeing thou art the God in whom I beleeue, the Lord whome I ≈øerue, and life with which I liue, and the heart vvhich I mo≈øt loue, vvhat other thing is it for me to be vvithout a heart, than to bee depriued of thee O my good Ie≈øus? Vae duplici corde, & labijs ≈øcelestis, &c,
≈øaid the wi≈øe man, as if he would ≈øay; Woe bee vnto that man which hath two hearts to think ill with, two tongues to murmure much with, and two hands to ≈øteale more with, and goeth two waies to lo≈øe him≈øelfe. No man hath two hearts, but hee who is malicious, no man hath two tongues but hee who cannot rule his tongue, no man hath two handes but the couetous man, no man goeth two waies but the ambitious man, who for to haue more, and preuaile more, leaueth no way not gone, nor any e≈øtate not ≈øhot at or ≈øhakeÃÑ. It is ≈øure a new thing & not heard of before, that the wi≈øe maÃÑ dare ≈øay, that ≈øome maÃÑ hath two tongues to murmure much with, & ≈øome two hearts to think much with, & in this ca≈øe we dare well ≈øay that it is as mon≈øtrous a thing to haue two harts, as to want one. Remigius vpoÃÑ the≈øe words ≈øaith, In things which do hinder the one the other, to vndo them is to win theÃÑ, to ≈øeperate theÃÑ is to flie from theÃÑ, & to cut theÃÑ a≈øunder is to ≈øow theÃÑ, & to dimini≈øh theÃÑ is to encrea≈øe them, and to wa≈øt them is to better theÃÑ. the example of all this may bee giuen in trees which haue many boughes, and in a vine which hath many branches, who≈øe ≈øuperfluitie if we doe cut off, wee make them grow, and the pruning of the vine maketh it fructifie. The Prophet Ieremy accu≈øeth I≈ørael, becau≈øe he hath no heart at all; and Salomon reprehendeth the malicious man, becau≈øe hee hath two hearts: what meane ≈øhall we keep then to complie with the one, and ≈øatisfie the other? Hugo de arra anima, an≈øwereth and ≈øaith, Seeing our loue ought to be but one, and he on whom we ought to be≈øtow our loue ≈øhould bee but one, in like manner the heart with whom we ≈øhould engage our loue, ≈øhould bee but one, becau≈øe that cannot be called true loue which is ≈øcattered into many hearts. If we ≈øhould be permitted by the law of Chri≈øt to haue many loues, wee ≈øhould al≈øo bee ≈øuffered to haue many hearts: but ≈øeeing it is not permitted to haue more than one loue, why would we haue more than one heart? He in an Order of religion is ≈øaid to haue many hearts, who remaineth with his body in the mona≈øtery, and with his will & mind wandereth in the world, and ≈øo hee liueth with paine by
rea≈øon of the one, and ca≈øts out ≈øighes by rea≈øon of the other. The di≈ø≈øembling hypocrite hath al≈øo two hearts, who with the one de≈øireth to bee in low degree, and with the other laboureth to be exalted; with the one he ≈øpeaketh fair, & with the other he bireth ≈øecretly; with the one he proclaimeth coÃÑ ≈øcience, & with the other he maintaineth malice; & which is wor≈øt of all, with the one he doth forward concord, and with the other he ≈øtirreth vp war. Woe therfore be vnto him who hath two hearts: for if hee had but one, either hee would bee wholly good or wholly bad; but hauing two hearts, he cannot in religion do that which he ought, nor in the world doe that which hee would. Hee hath al≈øo two hearts, who hath good words and naughty vvorks, he vvhich crieth the ≈øpirit, & is al fle≈øh, he vvho liueth wickedly & hopeth vvell, he vvho is rigorous vvith other men, and mild vnto him≈øelfe, ≈øtrait vnto his brothers, & liberall vnto him≈øelfe. Hath not he think you two harts, vvho promi≈øeth much & performeth litle, he vvho ≈øweareth that he loueth, and yet in the end loueth not, but deceiueth? To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, all that vvhich I haue ≈øpoken, is to let you know hovv vvi≈øely and vvarily the good theefe kept his heart, and hovv highly he did imploy it, ≈øeeing he denied it the diuel, & offered it vnto Chri≈øt. The good theefe gaue Chri≈øt al that he could, all that he vvas vvorth, all his povver, all that hee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, & al≈øo al his might & vvill, at vvhat time he acknovvledged him≈øelfe a ≈øinner vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, and Ie≈øus Chri≈øt to be his redeemer. div.head: CHAP. VII. How the naughty theefe lo≈øt him≈øelfe only for want of faith: and of two chalices which the ≈øcripture maketh mention of, of which both the theeues dranke of.

COn≈øurge con≈øurge Hieru≈øalem, quiae bibi≈øti calicem irae dei v≈øque ad faeces, ≈øaid the Prophet E≈øay ≈øpeaking with I≈ørael, as if he would ≈øay. Ri≈øe vp O Ieru≈øalem, ri≈øe vp O Synagogue, ≈øeeing that of meere drunkene≈ø≈øe, thou art fallen vpon the earth, con≈øidering that thou ha≈øt dronke the cup of the anger of God, vnto the very bottome and dregs. The ≈øonne of God the night before his pa≈ø≈øion, being at his praiers in the garden of Geth≈øemani, when all the torments which he was afterwards to ≈øuffer, came vnto his mind, and the torment of the death which hee was to endure, ≈øaid vnto his eternall father, Pater ≈øivis, tran≈øeat a me talix i≈øte, as if he would ≈øay. My eternal and holy father, I ask thee as thy ≈øon, and be≈øeech thee as thou art my father, that thou woulde≈øt con≈øent, that all tho≈øe of my church may al≈øo drink of this cup of bitternes. The doubt now is, that ≈øeeing the cup that I≈ørael ta≈øted of, was froÃÑ as good a God as the cup that Chri≈øt drank of, why the cup that Chri≈øt drank of was approued & liked, & the cup that Ieru≈øaleÃÑ drank of mi≈øliked & di≈øallowed? The one was a cup, & the other a cup: the one was of bitternes, and the other was of ire: the one fell to the ≈øynagogue, & the other to the church: the one was of God, & the other was of God, & ≈øeeing it is ≈øo, why do they threateÃÑ I≈ørael, for that which hee drunk, and prai≈øe Chri≈øt for that which he ≈øupped vp? The better to vnder≈øtand this point, we mu≈øt vnder≈øtaÃÑd that there are two kind of cups or chalices in the holy ≈øcripture. To wit, the one which is called the chalice of bitterne≈ø≈øe, & the other which is called the chalice of ire, and
the difference betwixt theÃÑ is, that by drinking the one, we appear betimes in the morning in Paradi≈øe, & by drinking the other we go down at night vnto hel. What is the cup of bitterne≈ø≈øe ful of, but with hunger, cold, thir≈øt, per≈øecution, & temptation; all which things our Lord giueth to drinke, vnto all tho≈øe which hee hath cho≈øen to ≈øerue him, and vnto all tho≈øe whom he hath prede≈øtinated vnto ≈øaluation. S. Gregory in his Morals ≈øaith. That it is a ≈øign that he is prede≈øtinated to be ≈øaued, vnto whom God giueth his cup of bitternes to drink; in ≈øo much that we cannot e≈øcape grieuous hels, vnle≈ø≈øe it be by the co≈øt of great trauails. It is to be noted, that Chri≈øt ≈øaid not vnto his father, that he wold not drink of the cup, neither yet did he offer him≈øelf to drink vp al, but he praied him only by ≈øpeciall grace, that others might help him to drink it: for if he ≈øhould alone haue dronken the cup of bitternes, he alone ≈øhould haue entred into Paradi≈øe. O giuer of all goodnes, O di≈øtributer of al fauors, what had≈øt thou that thou did≈øt not coÃÑmunicate vnto vs, or what did≈øt thou po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe that thou did≈øt not deuide among≈øt vs? Thou ha≈øt giueÃÑ vs thy body to eat, thou ha≈øt giuen vs thy bloud to drink, thou ha≈øt giueÃÑ vs thy law to keep, thou ha≈øt giueÃÑ vs thy hart to loue, thou ha≈øt giueÃÑ vs thy cup to ta≈øt, & thou ha≈øt giueÃÑ vs thy glory to enioy. An≈øelmus ≈øaith, That in the vain pallaces of the world, tho≈øe are thought to be mo≈øt familiar, which are mo≈øt of all made much of by their Lord: but in the company & hou≈øe of God, tho≈øe are be≈øt beloued which are wor≈øt handled; in≈øomuch that we wil ≈øay him to be his familiare≈øt friend, whom we ≈øhall ≈øee to drinke oftene≈øt of his bitter cup. O high my≈øtery, O diuine Sacrament! when the ≈øonne of God did weepe teares from his eies in the garden, and did ≈øweat bloud from his body, hee did not aske that his cho≈øen flocke might bee cockered and made much of, but only that he wold let theÃÑ ≈øup ≈øome ≈øup of his bitter cup. What el≈øe was S. Peters cro≈ø≈øe, S. Andrews cro≈ø≈øe, likewi≈øe Bartolomewes knife. S. Laurence grediron. S. Steuens ≈øtones, but certain pledges which they receiued of Chri≈øt, & certain bitter ≈øups which they dranke of his chalice? Hilarius vpon S. Matthew
≈øaith, That how many more ≈øups a man hath ≈øupped in this life of Chri≈øts cup, ≈øo many ≈øteps the higher ≈øhall hee bee in heauen in glory: for what cau≈øe we ought to entreat and aske earne≈øtly, that if we cannot drink al his cup, yet that he would let vs at the lea≈øt ra≈øt of him with his elect. S. Ierome ≈øayth al≈øo, That although the cup which Chri≈øt left his elect, bee ≈øomewhat bitter in drinking, yet after that it is drunke, it is ≈øauerous and profitable, becau≈øe the trauels of this world doe not giue vs ≈øo great griefe and paine when wee ≈øuffer them, as they bring vs delight after we haue ≈øuffered them. It is al≈øo to bee noted that hee ≈øayth, Tran≈øeat a me calix i≈øte, that is, He would not haue his bitter cup turne backe againe, but goe on forward: wherby he giueth vs to vnder≈øtand, that the merit of his pa≈øsion, and the bloud of our redemption, ≈øhould not be be≈øtowed vpon them which euery day goe wor≈øe and wor≈øe vntill the end, but onely vpon them vvhich euery day grow better and better. This word of Tran≈øeat, Let this cup pa≈ø≈øe, is a high word, and worthy to bee marked, in the which and by the vvhich our good Ie≈øus doth admoni≈øh and warne vs, that tho≈øe ≈øhall not drinke of his cup of bitterne≈ø≈øe, & enter vvith him into glory, which hauing been good, turn in the end to be naught; but only tho≈øe vvho being naught, proue to be good: nor tho≈øe vvho vvhen they ≈øhould go forward from vertue to vertue, turne backward and per≈øeuere in vices, becau≈øe that among the ≈øeruants of our Lord he vvho doth not profit doth di≈øprofit. There is no rich maÃÑ in this world which doth ≈øet ≈øo much by his wealth, as Chri≈øt doth by his chalice of bitterne≈ø≈øe: and therfore ≈øeeing that he commandeth that his cup ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe further, & that tho≈øe ≈øhould drink of him vvhich doe go forward, the ≈øeruant of our Lord ought to take pains to make him≈øelfe better, and to go forward, not in ambitioÃÑ which doth teÃÑpt him, but in deuotioÃÑ which he doth want. O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules coÃÑfort, Let this cup go, not froÃÑ me, but to me, becau≈øe we may ta≈øt of thy pains & trauels, feel thy griefes, weep for thy tormeÃÑr, enioy thy loue, & wa≈øh away my wickednes; in≈øomuch that wheÃÑ thy cup doth pa≈ø≈øe froÃÑ thee, it
may light vpon me. Let euery maÃÑ make his proui≈øion of wines of Illana, of Candie, of Dania, yet I for my comfort and deuotion, doe aske of God that all the daies of my life I may de≈øerue to drinke of that bitter cup one drop. There is another cup which is called the cup of the wrath and ire of God, of the which when I begin to ≈øpeake, my bowels open, my heart is troubled, and my ≈øoule is ≈øorrowfull, my fle≈øh trembleth, and my eies al≈øo weepe. How is it po≈øsible that my hart ≈øhould di≈øpo≈øe, my penne write, my inke marke, and my paper ≈øuffer mee to write, how happy they are who e≈øcape the drinking of this cup; and how vnhappy they are which drinke of it? With this cup of ire God did threaten Ieru≈øalem, of this the Synagogue dranke, with this wicked Babilon was drunk, yea and this was the cau≈øe why all Iudea was lo≈øt. S. Augu≈øtine in an Homilie ≈øaith, He drinketh of the cur≈øed cup of ire, who through his ≈øin falleth from the e≈øtate of grace, which is an euill aboue all the euils of this life, becau≈øe a ≈øoule without grace is farre more deader than a body without a ≈øoule. When doe≈øt thou thinke that God doth ≈øuffer vs to drinke of the cup of his ire, but when hee forgetteth to hold vs vp with his hand through our demerite? When ≈øhall wee ≈øee whether we haue dronke of the cup of his wrath, but vvhen God is carele≈ø≈øe in keeping vs from falling, and vvee ≈ølothfull in amending our ≈øelues? S. Ambro≈øe vpon the P≈øalmes ≈øayth, O vvhat a difference there is betwixt the vvrath of God, & the vvrath of man, for they puni≈øh vvhen they are angry, but God forbeareth to puni≈øh vvhen hee is angry, in ≈øo much that God is more di≈øplea≈øed vvhen hee di≈ø≈øembleth a fault than vvhen he doth pre≈øently puni≈øh. S. Barnard ≈øayth, That there is no greater temptation than not to bee tempted, nor greater tribulation thaÃÑ not to be afflicted, nor greater puni≈øhment than not to be puni≈øhed, nor yet a ≈øharper ≈øcourge than not to be ≈øcourged. For as there is ≈ømall hope of the ≈øick mans life vvhome the Phi≈øition doth di≈øtru≈øt and de≈øpaire of, euen ≈øo in like manner there is great occa≈øion to ≈øu≈øpect the ≈øaluation of that man vvhom our Lord doth not puni≈øh in this life.
It is al≈øo to be noted, that E≈øay doth not only threaten Ieru≈øalem, becau≈øe ≈øhe dronk of the cup of the ire of God, but becau≈øe ≈øhe drunke al≈øo the dregs and lees, vntill ≈øhee left none, in ≈øo much that if there had ben more, more ≈øhe would haue drunk. We call that properly the dregs of the wine, that part of the wine which corrupteth and marreth, and that which goeth to the bottome, and that which rotteth and ≈øtinketh, and that whereof we receiue no profite. What are the dregs which ≈øinke vnto the bottome, but onely wicked ≈øinne which beareth vs into hell? The dregs of ≈øinne cau≈øe vs to rot, and with dregs of ≈øinne we ≈øinke, and by the dregs of ≈øinne we are damned, and by the dregs of ≈øin we are hated of God. I will vi≈øite Ieru≈øalem and tho≈øe men which are fa≈øtened in their dregs, ≈øaith God by the Prophet Sophonias in the fir≈øt chapter, as if hee would ≈øay, I will vi≈øite all the dwellers of Ieru≈øalem, and I will make no reckoning of other ≈øinnes and offences, but of ≈øuch as I ≈øhall find entangled, and tumbling in the dregs and lees. Who are tho≈øe which ≈øticke in the mire & are bedurted with the dregs, but tho≈øe which ≈øtand ob≈øtinately in their ≈øinnes and wickedne≈ø≈øe? God complaineth not of tho≈øe which are defiled in the dregs, but on tho≈øe which are fa≈øtened and fixed in them: for our Lord is not ≈øo much ≈øcandalized to ≈øee vs fall into ≈øinnes, as to ≈øee vs wallow and delight in their dregs and grounds. O that wicked is the heart which is fa≈øtened, and ≈øtandeth firme in the dregs of ≈øinne, becau≈øe promi≈øes cannot allure and enti≈øe him, nor threatnings feare him, nor entreatie conuert him, nor puni≈øhment amend him, nor coun≈øell profite him! How badly our Lord liketh of them which are firme in the lees and dregs, he ≈øheweth plainly, ≈øeeing he threatneth ≈øuch as ≈øtand fa≈øt in them, and tho≈øe which drink of the cup vnto the dregs; wherof we may inferre that wee doe not ≈øo much condemne our ≈øelues for ≈øinning, as becau≈øe we will not goe out of ≈øinne. To drinke of the cup vnto the dregs is, as if as there are but ≈øeuen capitall ≈øins they were feuen thou≈øand, to haue a will to offend in them all before we died. To drinke vnto the dregs is, that if by deed we commit
ten ≈øinnes euery day, in thought we commit an hundred euery houre. To drinke the cup vnto the dregs is, that if wee omit to commit any ≈øinne, it is not becau≈øe wee would not, but becau≈øe we could not or dur≈øt not. To drinke of the cup vnto the dregs is, that not being content to ≈øinne, we commend and prai≈øe our ≈øelues for doing it, as if we had done our Lord ≈øome notable ≈øeruice. To drinke the cup vnto the dregs is, that when wee haue committed all kind of ≈øinnes, yet wee cannot endure to be called ≈øinners. To drinke the cup vnto the dregs is, to be ≈øo gracele≈ø≈øe and ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe in ≈øinning, that we enti≈øe and importunately vrge others to do the like. To drinke the cup vnto the dregs, is to hate our neighbour with our heart, iuiurie him with words, and hurt him in deeds. Loe thus then haue I told you what is the cup of bitternes which the elect and cho≈øen drinke of, and which is the cup of wrath and ire which the wicked drinke of: in ≈øo much that if wee would know who ≈øhall bee ≈øaued, or who damned, wee are onely to mark what cup he dranke of. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, we mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe that the≈øe two theeues drank of both the≈øe cups, which are ≈øo dreadfull and wonderfull; and ≈øuch as the cup was, of which ech of them dranke, ≈øuch was the reward or puni≈øhment which on the cro≈ø≈øe ech of theÃÑ receiued and carried away. WheÃÑ the naughty theefe ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt, ≈øaue thy ≈øelfe and vs, he dranke of the cup of wrath, and when the good theefe ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt, Lord remember me, he dranke of the cup of bitterne≈ø≈øe, in≈øomuch that the one drank of the pure wine, ≈øeeing he went into heauen, and the other dranke of the ≈øtinking dregs, ≈øeeing he went into hel. What meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? Seeing they were both coÃÑpanions, both the eues, both hanged, both ≈øaw Chri≈øt, and both were neere vnto Chri≈øt, why doe they giue to the one to drinke of the cup of glory, and vnto the other the cup of ire? S. Augu≈øtine an≈øwereth vnto this & ≈øayth. Why God doth giue light vnto one, and not vnto another, why he draweth this man and not that man, I pray thee good brother goe not about to ≈øeeke out the rea≈øon, if thou wilt not bee deceiued:
for all this dependeth of Gods high iudgements, the which although they be ≈øecret, yet notwith≈øtanding they be not vniu≈øt. Origen vpon Mark ≈øaith; As there are many things in the heart which are not of the heart, and as there are many in war ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ which take no pay in the warre, ≈øo the naughty theefe was vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, not hauing the fruit of the cro≈ø≈øe: for in ≈øtead of asking Chri≈øt that he would pardon him, be asked that he would deliuer him and vnbind him. If thou bee Chri≈øt, ≈øaith the naughty theefe, ≈øaue thy ≈øelfe and vs, as if he would ≈øay, If thou bee the Chri≈øt which the Iewes hope for, deliuer thy ≈øelfe from death, and quite vs from paine. Cyprian vpon the pa≈øsion of our Lord ≈øayth; O that, that is a wicked word and a dete≈øtable praier which thou O naughty theefe doe≈øt vtter with thy mouth, when thou doe≈øt per≈øuade the ≈øon of God to come downe from the cro≈ø≈øe: for if he do ≈øuffer & die, it is for nothing that toucheth him, but for that which toucheth thee and is mo≈øt expedient for me. Why do≈øt thou aske him that hee would ≈øaue thee and al≈øo him≈øelfe, ≈øeeing that he ≈øuffereth of his owne accord, & dieth for thy naughtine≈ø≈øe? The beginning of this naughty theeues perdition was, when he ≈øaid, if thou be the ≈øonne of God, and not, thou art the ≈øon of God: in which words it ≈øeemed that hee doubted whether hee were the ≈øonne of God or not; and ≈øo hee doubted in his faith, and made a ≈øcruple, whether he were the redeemer of the world or not, and ≈øo hee fell into infidelitie, which is the highe≈øt wickedne≈ø≈øe of all other. Cyrillus vpon S. Iohn ≈øaith, That the good theefe ≈øaid not, If thou be Chri≈øt, neither did S. Peter ≈øay, I beleeue if thou bee Chri≈øt; but the one ≈øaid faithfully, Lord remember me, and the other likewi≈øe ≈øaid, I beleeue, becau≈øe thou art the ≈øonne of God, in≈øomuch that no man can be lightened or pardoned which maketh any doubt at all in the faith of Chri≈øt. The Apo≈øtle ≈øaith in his canonicall Epi≈øtle, if any man want wi≈øedome, let him aske it of God, not doubting in faith: as if he would ≈øay, If any man haue need of any great matter, let him take heed that he do not aske it with a faith that is luke warme: for if our Lord do
not grant vs that which we aske him, it is rather becau≈øe wee know not how to ask him, than becau≈øe hee hath not a de≈øire to giue it. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, If he who asketh be not a Pagan, and that which he asketh bee not vniu≈øt, and hee who asketh be holy, and the place where he asketh be al≈øo ≈øacred, and he for whoÃÑ he asketh be needy, why ≈øhould he doubt to obtaine it, con≈øidering that of him≈øelfe hee is ≈øo mercifull? O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules plea≈øure, giue me thy grace that I may ≈øay vvith the blind man in Ieremie, O ≈øonne of Dauid haue mercy vpon mee: and keepe mee from ≈øaying vvith the naughty theefe, if thou be Chri≈øt ≈øaue thy ≈øelf and me too; ≈øeeing that like a true Chri≈øtian I confe≈ø≈øe thy mighty power, and call for thy great mercy. Chri≈øto≈øtome ≈øaith, The naughty thee≈øe thought, that as Pilate had condemned him for a robber by the high way, ≈øo he had executed iu≈øtice vpon Chri≈øt for ≈øtirring the people to ≈øedition, and that Chri≈øt did no le≈ø≈øe e≈øteeme of his life, than hee did abhorre death: vvherein certainly he vvas much deceiued; for he did not ≈øo earne≈øtly de≈øire to liue as Chri≈øt did de≈øire to die. The Iews per≈øuaded Chri≈øt that hee ≈øhould come downe from the cro≈ø≈øe, and this naughty theefe did al≈øo per≈øuade him that hee vvould ≈ølie from the cro≈ø≈øe, that vvhich the ≈øonne of God did not loue to hear of, nor would not do: for if he had for≈øaken the cro≈ø≈øe all the vvorld ≈øhould haue beene crucified. S. Barnard ≈øayth, I doe not de≈øire thee my good Ie≈øus, that thou come down froÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe, nor that thou ≈ølie from the cro≈ø≈øe, but that thou vvoulde≈øt put me there with thee, becau≈øe it would be more rea≈øonable that they ≈øhould giue ≈øentence vpon me for thee, than that they ≈øhould giue ≈øentence vpon thee for me. It may bee gathered of all that which wee haue ≈øpoken, what great courage we haue need of to begin any good worke, and a far greater to fini≈øh it: for our enemies are ready alwaies about to deceiue vs, the fle≈øh to mooue vs, men to hinder vs, and the world to trouble vs.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the great charity which the good theefe had towards the naughty theefe in correcting him of euill doing, and in adui≈øing him of the good which he lo≈øt.
div.p:
COmmendat deus omnem charitatem ≈øuam in nobis, ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle writing vnto the Romanes in the fift chap. as if he would ≈øay. The God and Lord which I preach vnto you O Romanes, dooth commend nothing more vnto you than charity, in louing your neighbours with all your heart: the which loue you mu≈øt ≈øhew them, not ≈øo much becau≈øe they loue you, as becau≈øe they ≈øerue God. Holy Paule did preach and teach vs many things, whereof ≈øome were to make vs afeard, ≈øome to giue vs coun≈øell, ≈øome to teach vs, ≈øome to comfort vs, as this matter which we now handle, the which being wel looked into, and read with attention, we ≈øhal find that hee giueth vs as much as hee hath, and loueth vs as much as he ought. For the better vnder≈øtaÃÑding of this ≈øpeech, we mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe that the loue of God, charity, and grace, go alwaies coupled together, in ≈øo much that no man can haue heauenly loue without heauenly charity, & no man can haue heauenly charity, but he mu≈øt haue heaueÃÑly grace, & he who hath heauenly grace, cannot faile but goe to glory. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, That Loue, and Charitie, and Grace, are only one gift, and the greate≈øt which came from heaueÃÑ; & is called Grace, becau≈øe it is giuen without any price, and it is called Charity becau≈øe it is high, and it is called Loue becau≈øe it doth ioine and vnite vs with God: in ≈øo much that when he recommendeth his Charity vnto vs, he tru≈øteth his Loue with vs. WheÃÑ our Lord doth commend vs his Loue, as a thing left to keepe
with vs, if we marke it well, what el≈øe is it but a token, whereby we ≈øhould marke with what Loue he loueth vs, and with what Charity he entreateth vs? O happy pledge, O luckie tru≈øt, when our Lord credited vs with his eternall Loue, his infinite Grace, and vn≈øpeakable Charity! the which vertues he gaue vs becau≈øe we ≈øhould not liue ingratefully with them, and that in our death we ≈øhould buy heauen with theÃÑ. When our Lord doth giue vs charge to keepe his Charity, what el≈øe is that but to doe vs the fauour to giue it vs? If he would not haue giuen it vs, hee knew well where to keepe it, without gi
‚Ä¢ ing it vs to pledge: but hee ≈øaith that hee dooth commend it vnto vs to keepe, and not giue it vs; becau≈øe wee ≈øhould bee very carefull in keeping it, and fearefull to lo≈øe it, becau≈øe we cannot be ≈øaued without it. Bede vpon the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, One friend can giue to another his iewels of ≈øiluer and gold, but he cannot giue him the loue which hee hath in his heart; for although he can ≈øhew it, yet hee cannot pa≈ø≈øe it vnto him: but the ≈øonne of God did not onely ≈øhew vs his loue, but did al≈øo giue it vs. He did ≈øhew vs his great loue, when hee tooke mans fle≈øh vpon him, and he doth giue vs his ≈øweet loue when he doth impart his grace among≈øt vs, in≈øomuch that with the fir≈øt loue hee deliuered vs from being ≈ølaues, and with the ≈øecond loue, he receiued vs to be his ≈øonnes. In figure of all this, the altar of the Synagogue was all hollow, but the altar of the church is ma≈øsie and ≈øound, by rea≈øon of the feruent loue which God beareth vs, and great charitie and mercy which hee doth vs. It is much to bee noted, that God doth not commend vnto vs, Faith, Hope, Patience, and Cha≈øtitie, but only Charitie: in which words hee giueth vs to vnder≈øtand, that if we doe ≈øet much by that which our Lord giueth vs, we ought to e≈øteeme much more of the loue with the which hee doth giue it vs. I≈øidorus ≈øayth, That all the courte≈øies which our Lord doth promi≈øe vs, and all the per≈øua≈øions vvhich hee v≈øeth vnto vs, are to no other end, but becau≈øe vve ≈øhould bee thankfull vnto him, and becau≈øe vve ≈øhould be mercifull vnto our neighbours. What vvanteth hee vvhich vvanteth not
Charity; and what hath he who hath no Charity? The mercifull and pitifull man hath God alwaies at his hand, that he fall not from his faith, that hee lo≈øe not his hope, that he defile not his cha≈øtity, nor de≈øpi≈øe humility: for in the high tribunall ≈øeat of God, no man need to feare that they will deale cruelly with him, if hee hath had any charity in this world. Wherein doe≈øt thou thinke (≈øaith S. Ierome) that all Chri≈øtian charity doth con≈øi≈øt, and al the health of thy ≈øoule, but only in ≈øeruing of Chri≈øt with all our heart, and in labouring to profit and benefit our neighbour? What greater good can I doe vnto my brother, than put him in the right way if hee be out, and correct him if hee bee naught? Bede ≈øayth vpon this matter, That true and cha≈øt loue, may bee deuided betwixt God and our neighbour, ≈øo as our neighbor be not prowd and naught: for if he be ≈øo, we are to wi≈øh his ≈øaluation, and flie his conuer≈øation. Wee haue ≈øpoken all this, to declare the great charity which this good theefe had, and al≈øo v≈øed towards the naughty theefe, ≈øeeing that vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, hee taught him that which was conuenient for him, & reprehended him in that which he ≈øpake. Neque tu times deum, qui in eadem damnatione es? ≈øaid the good theefe vnto the bad: as if he would ≈øay, O my friend and companion, I wonder much at thee, that hauing beene of ≈øuch a naughty life and conuer≈øation, and being vpon the very point to die, I ≈øay I maruel that thou dare≈øt to crucifie this holy Prophet more with thy tongue, than the hang men doe, with their nailes; becau≈øe the nailes doe open his vains, but thy euill tongue doth rend his entralls. The good theefe v≈øed but few wordes, but they contained many my≈øteries, and therefore it is needfull that they be read with attention, and written with grauity. It is to bee noted, that although our Lord God be pre≈øent in all things with his power, yet hee is much more in mans heart, and tongue by grace; becau≈øe tho≈øe are the two parts with the which we doe mo≈øt of all plea≈øe or offend God with. S. Aug. ≈øaith, That the eies doe loth oft to ≈øee, the ears to hear, the hands are loth to work, & the feet to go, yea & the body to ≈øinne; but the heart is neuer
weary of thinking, nor the tongue with ≈øpeaking. Cor mundum crea in me deus, & pone cu≈øtodiam ori meo, ≈øaid the Prophet Dauid: as if he would ≈øay, I be≈øeech thee O good Lord, that thou woulde≈øt renue this heart within me, & put a watch vnto this mytongue, becau≈øe that al the other parts of my body can but trouble & offend me, but the heart & tongue can trouble me & damne me. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øaith, That it is a certein token, that we are in Gods fauor, when he doth giue vs grace to keep our hearts clean, & our tongues brideled, becau≈øe the foundation of all Chri≈øtian goodnes is to beleeue our Lord God with all our hearts, & prai≈øe him with our tongue. Ego dabo eis cer nouuÃÑ, ≈øaid God vnto I≈ørael, & I will open thy mouth ≈øaid God vnto Ezechiel; as if he would ≈øay, I will lighten thy heart O I≈ørael, to the end that thou mai≈øt beleeue in me, and I will open thy mouth O Ezechiel, to the end that thou mai≈øt preach my name: for thou ha≈øt obtained no ≈ømall gift, if thou come to know me, & learn wel to ≈øet forth my name. To come theÃÑ vnto our purpo≈øe, the grace of a new heart which God gaue vnto I≈ørael, and the gift of prai≈øing his name, which he gaue Ezechiel, Chri≈øt al≈øo gaue vnto the good theef which was neer vnto him, ≈øeeing he touched his heart, with the which he beleeued in him, & opened his mouth with the which he preached his name. Vbertinus ≈øaith, That this good theefe was an excellent preacher in the church of God, who in a ≈øort ≈øeemed to goe before the Apo≈øtles in faithfully beleeuing, and preaching Chri≈øts might and power. What greater maruell would≈øt thou haue the bloud of Chri≈øt worke (≈øaith Rabanus) thaÃÑ to make preachers of theeues & robbers? the pulpit in the which hee preached was the cro≈ø≈øe, the preacher was the the ‚Ä¢ f, the holy one of whoÃÑ he preached was Chri≈øt, the church where he preached was Caluary, the audience before whom he preached were the Iews, the Theame vpoÃÑ which he preached, was Neque tu deum times, Neither doe≈øt thou fear God: and that which there hee preached, was the ≈øetting forth of Chri≈øt, and the reprehending of that which his fellow ≈øpake. The office of a preacher is (≈øaith Saint Gregory) Secreta re≈øerarae, vitia extirpare, & virtutes in≈øerere. The duty of a
preacher is, to open the ≈øecrets of the ≈øcripture, extirpate vice out of the Commonwealth, and teach how our ≈øoules are to be ≈øaued. What greater ≈øecret can there bee than to confe≈ø≈øe and preach a man crucified to bee God? Who reprehended vices like vnto this theefe, ≈øeeing that hee confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe to be a ≈øinner, and accu≈øed the other theefe to bee a bla≈øphemer: who did teach the way to heauen better thaÃÑ this theef, ≈øeeing hee was almo≈øt the fir≈øt that went thither? The good theefe deuided his ≈øermon into foure parts: the fir≈øt was when hee rebuked the other theefe, when hee ≈øaid, Neque tu deum times: the ≈øecond when hee accu≈øed him≈øelfe to bee naught, ≈øaying, Nos quidem iu≈øt√® patimur: The third when he excu≈øed Chri≈øt: ≈øaying, Hic autem quid mali fecit? The fourth when hee craued pardon for his ≈øinnes, Domine memento mei, Lord remember mee. Seeing then that the preacher is but a new preacher, & the pulpit new, and the thing that he preacheth new, it is rea≈øon that wee ≈øhould heare that which hee preacheth with attention, and do that which he coun≈øelleth with great deuotion. Auferetur zelus meus ate & quie≈øcam, ne ira≈øcar amplius, ≈øaid God by Ezechiel chap. 16: as if he would ≈øay. O thou Synagogue which art hardened, ≈øeeing that thou wilt not beleeue that which I tel thee, nor doe that which I command thee, I am determined not to chide thee nor puni≈øh thee for any fault that thou ≈øhall commit, but as being incorrigible, I am determined to for≈øake thee. O ≈øorrowful ≈øpeech, O dreadfull word: when our Lord ≈øaith that he will adui≈øe vs no more what we haue doe, nor correct vs of that which wee doe: for if he take his mercifull hand from vs, what ≈øhall wee dare to take in hand? Tell me I pray thee what can we doe, or what doe we know of our ≈øelues, if wee bee not guided by the hand of God, in that which wee take in hand, and aduerti≈øed in that which wee doe ami≈ø≈øe? S. Gregory ≈øaith vpon Ezechiel. When our Lord ≈øaith by Ezechiel that he will be no more angry with vs, it is a ≈øigne that hee is very angry with vs, becau≈øe it is a propertie of our Lord neuer to bee ≈øo angry as when hee is not angry to ≈øee vs offend. Barnard ≈øaith, O good
Ie≈øus the light of my ≈øoule, I be≈øeech thee that thou take not thy zeale from mee, nor withdraw thy puni≈øhing hand from me; but as I commit a fault, ≈øo let thy puni≈øhment bee ready: for by this means I ≈øhall ≈øooner amend, & liue al≈øo more warily. When the father of a company doth not puni≈øh a peruer≈øe ≈øeruant, it is a ≈øigne that he will put him out of the hou≈øe; and when they let a ≈øick man eat all things that he lu≈øteth, it is a ≈øign that he wil die: & ≈øo wheÃÑ God doth let vs go with the bridle loo≈øe in our own hand after what vices we lu≈øt, it is a token that wee goe altogether out of the way. O how indurate that man ought to be in ≈øin, and how he ought to be mired in wickednes, of whom God ≈øayth, Auferetur zelus meusate! For when God ≈øaith that hee will not loue vs any more with realou≈øie, what doth hee mean el≈øe, but that he will be carele≈ø≈øe and forgetfull of vs, and for≈øake to puni≈øh vs? The holy ≈øcripture maketh mention of two kinds of zeale; the one is holy and glorious, and it is that which God hath towards vs; & the other is common, and is that zeale which wee beare towards our neighbours: and if the one be nece≈ø≈øary, the other is more nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe the true zeale and loue of our neighbour con≈øi≈øteth not ≈øo much in helping him to maintaine him≈øelfe, as in directing him to ≈øane his ≈øoule. S. Augu≈øtine in a Sermon ≈øayth, What doth it auaile thee O my friend, that thou help thy neighbour in time of nece≈øsitie with thy money, if thou con≈øent vnto him and hee with thee to wallow in vices? O how far a greater good turne thou ≈øhoulde≈øt doe him in le≈ø≈øening his faults, than by augmenting his wealth, becau≈øe there is no greater riches vnder the heauen, than to haue a cleane con≈øcience! The good theefe had a great zeale that the other ≈øhould bee ≈øaued, ≈øeeing hee did rebuke him for being a bla≈øphemer, and per≈øuaded him to be a Chri≈øtian: in≈øomuch that for a recompence for helping him to ≈øteale, hee would al≈øo helpe him to die well. Chry≈øi≈øtome vpon this matter ≈øayth, The≈øe two theeues had kept companie a long time together, and deuided equally their prey betwixt them, becau≈øe that as there was no difference betwixt them in the
fault, ≈øo they would haue equall ≈øhares in the deui≈øion. Now the good theefe would haue continued his old v≈øe, and as he had ≈øtolne heauen there vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øo he would haue deuided part of it vnto his companion, if the Lord of the theft, which was Chri≈øt, would haue con≈øented vnto it, or if the wretched theefe had de≈øerued it. O how great and vn≈øpeakable a charity was this of the good theeues! for con≈øidering that him≈øelfe was a Chri≈øtian, hee would haue made the other one al≈øo, and ≈øeeing him≈øelfe the heire of heauen, he would haue taken the other thither with him, and ≈øeeing him≈øelfe pardoned, hee would haue gotten pardon for the other, but that hee would neither beleeue in Chri≈øt, nor with good will giue eare vnto his companion. It is much to be noted (≈øayth Chri≈øo≈øtome) that the good theefe ≈øaid fir≈øt vnto the bad, Neither thou doe≈øt feare God, before hee ≈øaid, Lord remember me. For as I ≈øuppo≈øe, it helped much to ≈øaue the good theefe, that Chri≈øt ≈øaw with what great charity hee laboured that his coÃÑpanion ≈øhould not ca≈øt away him≈øelf. WheÃÑ he ≈øaid fir≈øt in fauor of the other, Neither thou doe≈øt feare God, before hee ≈øpake in the behoofe of him≈øelfe, Lord remember me; is it not mo≈øt manife≈øt and clear, that he de≈øired as much that his companion ≈øhould bee conuerted, as him≈øelfe ≈øaued? Remigius ≈øayth, That among all the ≈øeruices which wee can doe vnto our Lord, there is none ≈øo great, as to help our neighbor to ≈øaue him≈øelfe, and contrariwi≈øe, there is none that doth more offend him, than to helpe our neighbour to damn him≈øelfe; becau≈øe it ≈øeemeth that wee make ≈ømall account of the ≈øhedding of his bloud, if we helpe him not to be≈øtow it well. Then we be≈øtow his glorious bloud well, when we cau≈øe it to benefit our brothers: for otherwi≈øe we may ≈øay, that it was wel ≈øhed by Chri≈øt, but euilly be≈øtowed by vs. What greater ≈øacrifice can I doe vnto our Lord, than draw my neighbor from ≈øinne, who hath been redeemed by his precious bloud? TheÃÑ I draw my brother out of ≈øinne, when I correct him with my tongue, and help him in his worke. For as touching the offending of our Lord, it is conuenient not only to adui≈øe & coun≈øell
him, but if we can al≈øo puni≈øh and cha≈øti≈øe him. Cyprian in his booke of Martyrs ≈øayth, Who dare now adaies like vnto Phinees thru≈øt through with a poynyard a bold Iew and a ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe Gentile? Who like vnto holy Samuel will weepe for the di≈øobedience of Saule? Who like vnto holy Iob will ri≈øe earely in the morning to offer ≈øacrifices of peace for the ≈øinnes of his ≈øonnes? Who like vnto the High prie≈øt Aaron will threaten Pharaoh within his own pallace, becau≈øe hee ≈øhould leaue off the ≈øeruice of his God in the Synagogue? Who will lo≈øe the light of his eies like vnto the good Prophet Ieremy in weeping and taking pity vpon tho≈øe who carried away tho≈øe of Babilonia captiues? Now the zeale of holy men is lo≈øt, now the feruency of good men is at an end, now the puni≈øhment of naughty men is forgotten; for becau≈øe that in matter of correction, a friend will rather venter his con≈øcience with his friend, then ≈øuffer him to lo≈øe his credite. Certainly it is no credite, but a di≈øcredit, no charity but cruelty to ≈øuffer his neighbour to damne him≈øelfe for want of correcting him: for oftentimes naughty men would amend them≈øelues of their errors, if their friends which they haue, would aduerti≈øe them of them. Seeing wee cannot auoid it, but ≈øtumble at euery foot, nor giue ouer ≈øinning more or le≈ø≈øe, why haue wee friends and companions, but becau≈øe they ≈øhould keepe vs vp with one hand from falling, and lift vs vp with the other, if they ≈øee vs downe? S. Barnard in an Epi≈øtle ≈øaith, Let no man leaue off the correcting of his neighbour and friend, becau≈øe he thinketh that by ≈øo doing, he doth di≈øplea≈øe him: for after he hath con≈øidered of the matter, hee ≈øhall perceiue that hee hath done a good worke; becau≈øe that oftentimes the coun≈øell which they giue vs, is more worth thaÃÑ the money which they lend vs.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Why the good theefe did not chide with the naughty theefe, becau≈øe hee did not loue Chri≈øt, as hee did chide with him becau≈øe hee did not feare God: there are many notable things brought touching the feare of our Lord.
div.p:
ECcle≈øia quidem magis quotidi√® aedificabatur, ambulans in timore domini, & con≈øolatione ≈øpiritus ≈øancti, ≈øaith S. Luke in the ninth chap. of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles; as if he would ≈øay, After that S. Steuen was ≈øtoned to death, and the Apo≈øtle Saint Paul was conuerted, by ≈øo much the more the church of God encrea≈øed in building, by how much the more ≈øhee was founded vpon the feare of our Lord, and the church did receiue no comfort but ≈øuch as the holy gho≈øt did ≈øend her. Bede vpon this place ≈øayth, That the ≈øcripture doth adui≈øe vs with a high ≈øtile, how much it doth import vs that we feare our Lord and keepe his commandements, becau≈øe the primitiue church neuer began to encrea≈øe and flouri≈øh, vntill that Commonwealths began to feare the Lord, and ≈øeeke for the con≈øolation of the holy Gho≈øt. S. Augustine vpon the words of our Lord ≈øayth, That in the triumphant church loue without feare worketh; but in the militant church, loue and feare goe together: and a ≈øigne of this is that the greater loue I beare my friend, the greater feare I haue to di≈øplea≈øe him. Cyrillus vpon S. Iohn ≈øaith, Although the ≈øon of God ≈øaid, Ignem veni mittere in terram, which was as much as to ≈øay, that he builded his church vpon loue, yet he tooke not his feare from her: becau≈øe that ≈øeeing that there is both mercy and iu≈øtice in God, wee are bound a≈øwell to feare his rightfull iu≈øtice, as we are to loue his mercy. When God gaue Moi≈øes the old law, hee gaue it him with great thunders and terrible lightnings, and with al mixed it with many threats, &
ordained it with many puni≈øhmeÃÑts: becau≈øe the Iews ≈øhould determine with them≈øelues to keepe it, and not in any wi≈øe to breake it. King Pharaoh commanded all the midwiues of the kingdome of Egypt to ≈ølay al the male children of the Iews at the time of their birth: and becau≈øe they would not doe it for fear of the Lord, the Lord gaue them great riches in their hou≈øes. S. Becau≈øe that if an euil maÃÑ might enioy the world, he would little care if heauen vvere taken from him. A vaine vvordly man engraued in a medall of gold the wordes of the
P≈øalme, Caelum caeli domino, terram autem dedit filijs hominum, The heauen of heauen vnto our Lord, he gaue the earth vnto the ≈øons of men: and hee wrote for a po≈øie, take thou Lord heauen for thee, vpon condition that thou vvould≈øt leaue the earth vnto mee. An≈øelmus ≈øaith, O what a great fauour God doth vnto that maÃÑ whoÃÑ God doth not exclude froÃÑ his loue, & doth not leaue him without fear for the maÃÑ which hath both loue and feare in him, although he want other perfections, neither ought to fear, lea≈øt he ≈øhould be damned, nor di≈øtru≈øt at all to be ≈øaued. We haue ≈øpoken all this in the coÃÑmendation of the good theef, & of his piety & charity, who did not rebuke the other theefe his coÃÑpamon, for that hee was prowd or enuious, but only becau≈øe he did not feare God, ≈øaying Neque tu times deum, Neither doe≈øt thou fear God: Giuing vs to vnder≈øtand by this, that he went down right into hell, for no other cau≈øe, but becau≈øe he made ≈ømal reckoning of Chri≈øt. The wil which wee haue to ≈øerue our Lord, is rather, ba≈ølard will, than a
lawfull will; for to tell the troth, my brother, wee haue more skill in ≈øinning than in louing. The good theefe would not ≈øo plainely teach the euill theefe the art of loue, as hee did the duty of feare, partly becau≈øe the time was too ≈øhort to learne ≈øo high a matter, as then being in great torment, and neer vnto death, and partly becau≈øe the quality of mans mind is ea≈øily induced to feare, and very ≈ølowly to loue. O vnto how many may wee ≈øay now adaies that which the good theefe ≈øaid vnto the other, that is, neither thou doe≈øt feare God; letting them to vnder≈øtand by the≈øe words, that they neither feare God, nor loue God, nor ≈øerue God, nor yet remember whether there bee a God, con≈øidering they let no ≈øinne vndone, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee becau≈øe they dare not, or becau≈øe they cannot. What friend is there in this world, which giueth his brother ≈øuch brotherly correction? What friend dare tell his friend, take heed brother, for thou art prowd, or ill-tongued, or a babbler, badly beloued, and euery man marketh thy doings? S. Barnard vpon tho≈øe words of Ieremy, Omnes amici eius ≈øpreuerunt eum, &c, ≈øayth, Woe be vnto me O my good Ie≈øus, woe be vnto me, becau≈øe that all the holy mai≈øters which brought me vp, are now dead, all my faithful friends, which were wont to giue me coun≈øell are now gone; and if I haue any left, they rather couer my faults than correct them. What

Iohn Herod, and S. Paul S. Did I not hate tho≈øe which did hate thee, and they are become my enemies? Who made a Sermon of greater weight than this theefe did, con≈øidering that in the pre≈øence of all men, and again≈øt them all he accu≈øed him≈øelfe and excu≈øed Chri≈øt? Hic autem quid malifecit? That which thou doe≈øt, thou doe≈øt very well O my good Ie≈øus, becau≈øe no man can giue abetter te≈øtimony of thy charitie and clemency, thaÃÑ rich Zachaeus whome thou didde≈øt vi≈øite, and the Publicane Matthew whom thou didde≈øt receiue, and the infamous Samaritane whom thou didde≈øt conuert, and the adulterous woman whom thou didde≈øt defend, and the good theefe whom thou did de≈øt pardon. The good theefe did not only excu≈øe Chri≈øt, and intreat for him, but did al≈øo accu≈øe him≈øelfe, ≈øaying, Nos quidem in≈øt√® patimur: as if hee would ≈øay, Thou and I, I and thou, my companion, if we ≈øuffer any thing, wee ≈øuffer it worthily, becau≈øe they haue giuen vs our torment according to our offence. There are very few which make a more glorious confe≈øsion than this, becau≈øe it is ≈øo much again≈øt our nature to ≈øuffer a reproch, that we will rather ≈øuffer torment than confe≈ø≈øe our fault. Our fir≈øt father being asked by God, why he had tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed his commandement, did ca≈øt the blame vpon the wom ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ who had deceiued him and ≈øhe being asked why ≈øhe did deceiue him,
made an≈øwere that the ≈øerpent was importunate with her, and did per≈øuade her; and ≈øo in ≈øtead of confe≈øsing, they began to excu≈øe them≈øelues. S. Augu≈øtine vpon the Apo≈øtles words ≈øayth, Woe be vnto me, woe bee vnto me: for I doe inherite ≈øinne from my father, an excu≈øe from my mother, lying from the diuel, folly of the world, to make much of my ≈øelfe of the fle≈øh, and pride of my ≈øelfe; in≈øomuch that I am not content to be m ‚Ä¢ ght, but I would al≈øo bee counted good. Seneca writing vnto his friend ≈øayth thus, Our nowes from hence are the≈øe, the wals of Rome are ruined, the Temples not vi≈øited, the Prie≈øts fled, the trea≈øure robbed, old men are dead, young men are wicked and mad, & vices are lords of all. O my good friend Eucilius, if the≈øe ≈øeeme great faults, there are other greater than the≈øe in Rome: and they are, that no man dooth confe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe culpable of any of the≈øe things; but the Dictator laieth the blame vpon the Con≈øull, the Con≈øull vpon the Cen≈øor, the Cen≈øor vpon the Prae ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r, the Praetor vpon the Aedile, and the Aedile vpon the Quae≈øtor; in≈øomuch that becau≈øe no man doth confe≈ø≈øe his fault, wee neuer hope to haue an ameÃÑd meÃÑt of it. O my ≈øoule (≈øaith An≈øelmus) O my heart, why doe≈øt thou confe≈ø≈øe vs, but becau≈øe thou ≈øhoulde≈øt amend vs. Woe be vnto me, woe be vntome, there is no ≈øin that Peommit, for the which I haue not an excu≈øe; that is, the deuill deceiued me, my friend entreated me, I was weak and feeble, the world drew mee on, I tooke not heed, in≈øomuch that I am more faulty in my excu≈øe, than in committing the offence. Iu≈øtus prior e≈øt accu≈øator ≈øut, ≈øaid the wi≈øe man in his Prouerbes, The greate≈øt token that a man is iu≈øt and hone≈øt is, that hee knoweth not how to accu≈øe another of any thing that he ≈øeeth, nor excu≈øe him≈øelfe of any thing that he doth. WheÃÑ the Angel rebuked the children of I≈ørael in Galgalos, they did pre≈øently break down their Idols, cloth them≈øelues with fackclothes: by rea≈øon whereof when the Lord ≈øaw that they began to confe≈ø≈øe their fault, and not excu≈øe it, hee did not only pardon them, but did al≈øo comfort them. When Achab the murderer was rebuked by the Prophet Helias for ≈øtoning Naboth to death, becau≈øe hee denied him his Vineyard, hee wept immediately and fa≈øted, & repented him of that which he had done, and therfore he was ab≈øolued of his fault before the Prophet went out of the thre≈øhold of his dore. Who euer hath confe≈ø≈øed with his heart, which hath not ben pardoned at Gods hands? Why doe≈øt thou thinke that the theefe obtained pardon ≈øo quickly at Gods hands, but becau≈øe hee excu≈øed Chri≈øt, in≈øtructed his fellow, and accu≈øed him≈øelf? This was a glorious confe≈øsion, and a fault worthy of pardon, ≈øeeing that on the Mount of Caluary, and not in the Temple, vpon the tree & not in place of confe≈øsion, publickly & not ≈øecretly, aloud and not in muttering wi≈øe, hee confe≈ø≈øed the ≈øonne of God to be our redeemer, and him≈øelfe a ≈øinner. Truly that ≈øeemeth to bee an exceeding great loue which thou did≈øt beare vnto Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing thou didde≈øt forget thy ≈øelfe, and remember him, excu≈øe his innocency, & proclaime thine own offences. It would not hurt vs at all, to confe≈ø≈øe that which thou didde≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, ≈øaying, Nos quidem iust√® patimur, Wee doe iu≈øtly ≈øuffer. For if our faults were put in a ballance on one ≈øide, and our puni≈øhment on the other, without compari≈øon our Lord doth di≈ø≈øemble much more than hee doth puni≈øh. div.head: CHAP. X. How the ≈øon of God was more gratefull vnto the good theefe, which bare him company on the cro≈ø≈øe, than Pharoahs cupbearer was to Io≈øeph who accompanied him in pri≈øon.
div.p:
MEmen to mei, cum bene tibi fuerit, vt ≈øuggeras Pharaoni vt educas me de i≈øto carcere, quia huc innocens mi≈ø≈øus ≈øum. The≈øe are the words of holy Io≈øeph, ≈øpeaking vnto Phareahs chiefe cupbearer: as if he would ≈øay, For a reward of interpreting thy dream, & for letting thee vnder≈øtand, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt vpon the morrow returne again to the pallace, and v≈øe thy old office of the cupbearer, I be≈øeech thee that thou woulde≈øt bee mindfull of me, and entreat the king that hee would let mee out of this dungeon, where I haue beene two yeares without cau≈øe or de≈øert at all. There were in pri≈øon at one time with
‚Ä¢ o≈øeph Pharoahs baker and cupbearer, who hauing dreamed each of them ≈øundry dreames, and not knowing what they meaned, Io≈øeph did interprete them vnto them, telling them that after three daies they would hang the baker, and return the cup bearer vnto the pallace: al which came to pa≈ø≈øe as Io≈øeph had told them. After that cha≈øt Io≈øeph had ben two years in pri≈øon becau≈øe he would not ≈øinne with his ma≈øters wife, he entreated the kings cupbearer very earne≈øtly that he would ≈øpeake vnto the king for him: but hee was ≈øo vngratefull, that he neuer thought of him any more, of whome hee had receiued ≈øuch good newes. God doth not well like of ≈øuch per≈øons which are not thankfull for the benefites be≈øtowed vpon theÃÑ. Which is ea≈øily perceiued: for although Pharaohs cupbearer had forgotten to doe that which good Io≈øeph reque≈øted him to doe, yet the ≈øcripture dooth not forget to accu≈øe him for a
thankle≈ø≈øe and an vngratefull man. Rich Laban was vngratefull vnto his ≈øonne in law Iacob, who although he had ≈øerued him forty yeares continually for his ≈øhepheard, yet hee paied him very vnthankfully for all that ≈øeruice: for ouer and be≈øides, that he gaue him one daughter for another at the time of his mariage, he deceiued him al≈øo in parting of his goods. Saule was al≈øo vngratefull vnto his good ≈øonne in law Dauid, who hauing ≈ølaine in his ≈øeruice that great Phili≈øtian, and oftentimes deliuered all the people of I≈ørael from the enemies, yet Saule lanched a dart at him at dinner time, where Dauid had ended his life, if hee had not defended him≈øelfe ≈øpeedily from him. The yong Prince Amon was vngratefull vnto the good king Dauid, who hauing ≈øent to comfort him for the death of his father, the young youth cut off a peece of king Dauids Emba≈ø≈øadours coats, and ≈øhaued halfe their beards, ≈øaying: that they went not to comfort him, but to bee a ≈øpie ouer him. King Demetrius was vngrateful vnto the good captaine Ionathas, who after he had ≈øent to ≈øuccour king Demetrius being in great di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and to leuie the ≈øiege being be≈øieged, yet good Ionathas had no greater aduer≈øary afterward than the king Demetrius. Cognouit bes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øorem ≈øuum, & a≈øinus prae≈øepe domini ≈øuit I≈ørael autem non cognouit me, ≈øaid God by the Prophet I≈øay in the fir≈øt chapter: as if hee would ≈øay, What meaneth this, people of I≈ørael, what meaneth this? The oxe knoweth the labouring man which doth yoke him, and the a≈ø≈øe knoweth him which giueth him meat, in the ≈øtable, and thou I≈ørael doe≈øt neither know me for thy Lord and ma≈øter, neither remember thy ≈øelfe of the good turns which I haue made vnto thee. I≈øidorus vpoÃÑ the≈øe words ≈øaith, That God compareth a thank le≈ø≈øe and an vngratefull man as it were in an anger, vnto an oxe which is a heauy bea≈øt, and vnto
to an a≈ø≈øe which is a fooli≈øh bea≈øt: becau≈øe that to ≈øay the troth no man omitteth to bee thankfull for the benefites receaued, vnle≈ø≈øe he be a waiward and ≈øluggi≈øh man in conuer≈øation, or a foole in condition. Is not thinke you an vngrateful man a foole, and a very foole, ≈øeeing hee maketh him≈øelfe vnworthy of an other benefite, by not being thankfull for that which hee hath receaued? There is no vice in the world which hath not his ≈øeat rather in one kingdome than in another, as pride among the Babilonians, enuy among the Iewes, anger among the Thebanes, couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe among the Thirians, gluttony among the Sidonians, and the magicall art among the Egyptians. But there is no man which will receaue ingratitude in his hou≈øe, no man willingly giue him a ≈øeat to ≈øit in. For although I bee vngrateful to thee, yet I would not haue thee bee vngratefull vnto mee. Seneca in his booke of Anger ≈øayth, That it is not onely a griefe, but al≈øo a perillous thing to haue to doe with an vngratefull man: for when hee purpo≈øeth not to pay that which hee oweth, hee hateth him whome hee ought not; and by that meanes for hauing beene his friend, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ turneth to bee thy enemy. Cicero in his Bookes De Legibus reporteth, that Bi≈øias the Grecian, O≈øiges the Lacedemonian, Bracaras the Thebane, and Scipio the Romane counted it a le≈ø≈øer hurt to be bani≈øhed into ≈øtrange countries, than to liue in their owne countries with tho≈øe which were vngratefull for their ≈øeruiuices. Plautus ≈øaith very well in a Comedy, That it is the property of a ba≈øe mind, & of an impudent man to giue euery man leaue to ≈øerue him, & be vngrateful vnto all men for their ≈øeruice: and therevpon it is, that he which ≈øerueth an vngratefull man ≈øerueth no body, & he which doth any thing for an vngrateful maÃÑ, doth for no man. E≈øchines the Philo≈øopher ≈øaith, that although the cities of Thebes & Athens be ful of naughty men, yet there are not ≈øo many of any ≈øort, as of vngrateful men: & the rea≈øon of this great mi≈øchiefe is, becau≈øe we take tho≈øe to bee our friends which are not expedient for vs to take, and giue our gifts vnto tho≈øe which know not how to
bee thankfull for them. Whereof thinke≈øt thou doth it proceed, that no men be thankful for that which thou doe≈øt be≈øtow vpon them, nor acknowledge the fauors thou doe≈øt theÃÑ, but becau≈øe thou doe≈øt admit tho≈øe to be thy familiars, which ought not to bee taken for thy neighbours? If thou doe≈øt any good (≈øayth Ciprian) vnto tho≈øe which de≈øerue it, I a≈ø≈øure thee that he will be gratefull for it: but if thou giue vnto him who is ≈øtrait vnto him≈øelfe, how woulde≈øt thou haue him liberall vnto thee? To come then vnto the purpo≈øe, although King Pharaohs cup-bearer was vngrateful vnto holy Io≈øeph, yet certainly Chri≈øt was not ≈øo vnto the good theefe, ≈øeeing that vpon the cro≈ø≈øe he did more for him than he de≈øerued, and al≈øo gaue him more there than he asked. And therefore ≈øeeing we haue told you what the theefe demanded of Chri≈øt, it is coÃÑ uenient now that wee tell you what Chri≈øt gaue the theefe, and thereby wee ≈øhall plainly perceiue, that our Lord is more liberall in giuing, than we are in asking. Amen dico tibi hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øo, ≈øaid Chri≈øt vnto the theefe: as if hee would ≈øay, O thou theefe, my friend and companion, doe≈øt thou thinke that I haue forgotten the ≈øeruice that thou ha≈øt done me in honouring me & keeping me company vntill this my la≈øt houre? I promi≈øe thee as I am God, and ≈øweare vnto thee as I am man, that this day thou ≈øhalt bee with me in Paradi≈øe. O this was a glorious an≈øwere, and a happy legacy, which the diuine wi≈øedome gaue vnto this good theefe, becau≈øe that in old time God recoÃÑpenced all the ≈øeruices done vnto him by increa≈øing their wealth, or prolonging their daies, or deliuering them from warre, or ≈øauing them from plague. O happy ≈øpeech, This day thou ≈øhalt bee with mee in Paradi≈øe, becau≈øe that all which God gaue from the beginning of the world, was as it were from the tiles of our hou≈øe downewards: but that which he giueth now is from the heauens vpward, that is, ≈øuch a gift as no tongue is able to expre≈ø≈øe; Do tibi partem vnam extra fratres tuos, ≈øaid Iacob vnto his ≈øonne Io≈øeph when hee was at the point of death: as if hee would ≈øay, For the troubles which thou ha≈øt endured with
