this my≈øtery was, that when the children of I≈ørael ≈øaw the ≈øea before them, which they could not pa≈ø≈øe ouer, and the Egyptians behind them, who came with intent to ≈øley them, they began to complaine of Moi≈øes, and in his prefence crie out aloud, why he had brought them out of Egypt, where they had their ≈øepulchres, and lead them into the de≈øarts where they ≈øhould bee eaten vp of wild bea≈øts. Moy≈øes ≈øeeing him≈øelfe in ≈øuch a narrow ≈øtrait, ≈øpake not one word vnto our Lord, but began to weepe, and with his heart only to pray vnto God and commend him≈øelf vnto him: which praier was of ≈øuch great force & efficacy, that it ≈øeemed to moue God greatly to condi≈øcend vnto that which hee had asked him. Good Moi≈øes did pray, & yet did not crie; he wept and yet ≈øpake not; he ≈øighed and made no noi≈øe; hee de≈øired and entreated not; and hee hoped, and yet hee did not importunately vrge. This was a high kind of importuning, by not importuning; and a high kind of asking in not asking: for to obtaine that which wee de≈øire at Gods hands, ≈øighing is better than crying out, & more is gotten by offering vnto him tears, than by ≈øpeaking many words. S. Gregory in his Morals ≈øayth, That God did not beare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt Moi≈øes, in ≈øaying that he did importune him, in not importuning him; and that he a≈øtonied him by crying, he not crying at all: becau≈øe there is no higher kind of asking than by praying, nor any ≈øweeter manner of ≈øpeaking with God, than by weeping. Barnard ≈øayth, How is hee not bu≈øie who is bu≈øie with his heart, and what doth not he obtaine who asketh with tears? S. Augu≈øtine vpon the Apo≈øtles words ≈øaith, That our Lord doth oftentimes heare the heart when hee praieth, although the tongue doe not ≈øpeake outwardly: but hee neuer heareth the tongue which ≈øpeaketh outwardly, if the heart doe not pray inwardly: becau≈øe our Lord is neerer vnto the heart with the which we loue him, than vnto the tongue with the which we ≈øpeak vnto him. Our Lord had great rea≈øon to ≈øay vnto M ‚Ä¢ i≈øes, Quid clamas ad me, What doe≈øt thou cry vnto me for? Becau≈øe
he had more re≈øpect vnto the tears which Moi≈øes wept, than vnto the cries which the people made; and ≈øo he regarded more that which Moi≈øes de≈øired with ≈øilence, than that which the people demanded with a noi≈øe. What meaneth this O great God of I≈ørael, what meaneth this? Doe≈øt thou not an≈øwere one word to the people which call vpon thee, & doe≈øt thou an≈øwere Moi≈øes which doth not ≈øpeake one word vnto thee? Doe≈øt thou hold thy peace when the Iewes and torturers ≈øpeake vnto thee at the foot of the cro≈ø≈øe, and doe≈øt thou an≈øwere the theefe for ≈øpeaking once vnto thee? There is no ≈øuch great difference betwixt torturers and theeues, and theeues and torturers, that the one ≈øhould be heard, and the other repul≈øed: for if torturers and hangmen take their liues from ≈øuch as are hanged, ≈øo doe great theeues al≈øo take away mens riches and apparell by the high way. The wicked Iewes did not de≈øerue an an≈øwere at Chri≈øts hands, ≈øeeing they ≈øaid, come downe from the cro≈ø≈øe; becau≈øe no man ≈øhould bee ≈øo bold as to bid him come downe, but goe vp: becau≈øe ≈øuch as are to goe into hell, goe downe, and tho≈øe which are to go to heauen goe vpward. The hangmen did not de≈øerue to be an≈øwered of Chri≈øt, which ≈øaid Thou who do≈øt de≈øtroy the teÃÑ ple of God, becau≈øe he came not into the world to take away the ≈øtones of Salamons Temple, but to win ≈øoules vnto his father which is in heauen. For it auailed Chri≈øt very little to that which he pretended, whether the temple ≈øtood or were fallen downe. Neither did the naughty theefe de≈øerue an an≈øwere who ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt, Saue thy ≈øelfe and vs, becau≈øe there was no man able by any force to put Chri≈øt vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe he had gone vp of his own wil, & that not to fly from it, but to redeem the world vpon it. Why ≈øhould the ≈øon of God an≈øwere ≈øo naughty a theefe, ≈øeeing he demanded nothing, but to haue his life ≈øaued, not making any mention at all of his ≈øoule? When the naughty theefe ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt, ≈øaue thy ≈øelf & ≈øaue me too, what els did he preteÃÑd or demaÃÑd, but that by ≈øome miracle, or by ≈øome words of enchantment
he ≈øhould deliuer them from the cro≈ø≈øes, and put them in ≈øafety? Irenaeus in a ≈øermon ≈øayth thus, According vnto the great loue, that Chri≈øt died with, & according vnto the great quantity of bloud which i≈ø≈øued out of his body, it had been but a ≈ømall enterpri≈øe for Chri≈øt to haue loo≈øed the theefe, & haue ≈øent him to keepe his Ea≈øter in his owne hou≈øe, becau≈øe hee came not into the world to ≈øet theeues at liberty, but to ≈øaue ≈øinners. Cyprian ≈øayth, That if as that naughty theefe did ask Chri≈øt that hee would pull out tho≈øe nailes, and ≈ølacken tho≈øe cords, and deliuer him from tho≈øe torturers, and a≈ø≈øwage his torments, he would haue asked ≈øomewhat touching his ≈øoule, or that he would haue had mercy ≈øhewed vpon him, our gratious Lord would not haue refu≈øed to an≈øwere him to that which hee ≈øaid, nor haue denied him that which hee demanded. O what a theefe hee is (≈øayth Haymo) and a theeues fellow, who can aske nothing of Chri≈øt, but honour to get him credite, power to defend him≈øelf, and might to offend others, riches to enioy, liberty to command, and health to liue onely in this world! Such as dare to aske the≈øe things of our Lord, be either Chri≈øtians without ≈øouls, or theeues without ≈øhame, of whom I doe now prophecy, that if they bee not hanged like theeues, they ≈øhall bee condemned like ≈øinners. Let vs take example by this dreadfulll example, that wee doe not aske with the naughty theefe, that our Lord would take vs from the cro≈ø≈øe, but that hee would keepe vs on the cro≈ø≈øe; nor let vs not aske of him that hee would giue vs a long life, but that he would amend our con≈øciences. For look how willing our Lord is, to giue vs things nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øaue vs, ≈øo is hee vnwilling to giue vs that which wee doe aske of him to cocker vs.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the≈øe words Domine memento mei, Lord remember me, which the good theefe ≈øpake vnto Chri≈øt: the which words are deuoutly and deepely expounded.
div.p:
QVia patiens est dominus, indulgentiam fu≈øis lachrimis po≈øtulemus ab eo, ≈øaid the holy woman Iudith ≈øpeaking to the inhabitants of Bethulia in the eight chapter of her booke: as if ≈øhe would ≈øay, It ≈øeemeth be≈øt vnto me O ye citizens of Bethulia that we kneele down vpon our knees, our hands ioined together, and our eies full of teares, and craue pardon of our Lord for our ≈øinnes, and that it would plea≈øe him to deliuer vs from our enemies. Holofernes the Tyrant had ≈øo narrowly be≈øieged the city of Bethulia, that within fiue daies they would haue deliuered them≈øelues vnto the enemie, if the ≈øiege had not been rai≈øed, or ≈øome new ≈øuccor come vnto theÃÑ. There was in the ≈øame citie a widdow named Iudith, who was beautifull in her countenance, cha≈øt in her body, rich in e≈øtate, and of great fame and credite among the people. This holy Iudith perceiuing that the captains of the city were di≈ømaied on one ≈øide, and the neighbors di≈øpaired on the other, ≈øaid vnto them as followeth: Who are you which dare tempt the great God of I≈ørael, and will giue your ≈øelues to be ≈ølaues, if he do not deliuer you from the A≈ø≈øyrians within fiue daies? Wil you pre≈øcribe fiue daies to the infinit mercy of the Lord, who hath neither beginning nor ending? Doe you not know that ≈øuch a promi≈øe and vow made again≈øt our Lord, doth rather ≈øtirre him to indignation, than appea≈øe his anger? Care not then to load your ≈øelues with armes, but with larmes: care
you not to make proui≈øion of victuals, but to weepe for your ≈øinnes: becau≈øe you ≈øhould be more afraid of your ≈øins, than of your enemies. The warre which you endure, and the hunger which you ≈øuffer, the God of heauen, and not Holofernes maketh again≈øt you, and with no other weapons but with your owne offences: and you mu≈øt learne, that the enemies who be≈øiege you, are rather executioners of Gods diuine iu≈øtice, than enemies of your Commonwealth. All the time that our forefathers were at peace with our Lord, they did well; and when they neglected their duty vnto him, it went not well with them: and as it fared then with them, ≈øo doth it now with vs; in ≈øo much that all our paines and trauels come from the hands of God, either to puni≈øh vs, or for to make vs merit. Tell me (≈øaith Dauid) what are wee able to doe, what are we able to performe, or what doe wee know if we bee not guided by the hand of God? If theÃÑ our ablene≈ø≈øe mu≈øt come from God to doe any thing, and our ≈øtrength from him to be able to performe any thing, and our knowledge from him if we will gue≈ø≈øe aright at any thing, in who≈øe hands ≈øhould wee put our hope, but in the hands of his diuine mercy? Let it bee ≈øo then, that there bee a proclamation made throughout all Bethulia, that the old men fa≈øt, the yong meÃÑ giue them≈øelues di≈øcipline, the Prie≈øts pray, and all weepe together, that it would plea≈øe God to keepe and deliuer not the wals from enemies, but our hearts from ≈øinnes. All the citizens were very much amazed at that that holy Iudith coun≈øelled them, and all accepted her coun≈øell, by rea≈øon wherof, within fiue daies Holofernes was beheaded, he and his defeated, the city vnburdened, and the countrey pacified. To returne then fitly vnto our purpo≈øe, agreeablie vnto this adui≈øe our theefe behaued him≈øelfe on the cro≈ø≈øe with Chri≈øt: for fir≈øt, he de≈øired our redeemer of the world to forgiue him his ≈øinnes, before hee asked him that it would plea≈øe him to take him with him vnto the kingdome of heauen. This theef did not ≈øay vnto Chri≈øt, When thou comme≈øt into thy kingdome, Lord remember me, for ≈øo hee might haue ≈øeemed to aske for heauen before
he had asked for the remi≈øsion of ≈øinnes; but he ≈øaid Domine memento mei, Lord remember me when thou ≈øhalt come into thy kingdome. In which words hee fir≈øt made his confe≈øsion, and then formed his petition. What doth it auaile thee to ask of Chri≈øt, if hee bee angry with thee: fir≈øt make Chri≈øt thy friend, then aske fauour at his hands. For it is the manner and condition of our Lord, that fir≈øt thou giue thy ≈øelfe vnto him, and then for him to giue him≈øelfe vnto thee. Vbertinus ≈øayth, That it is greatly to bee noted, that the good theefe did not ≈øay vnto Chri≈øt, take me from this cro≈ø≈øe, help to vnloo≈øe me, giue me life, re≈øtore my credite; but hee ≈øaid, Lord remember me, ≈øeeing that thou knowe≈øt better what to giue me, than I. to aske of thee. S. Ambro≈øe vpon S. Luke ≈øayth, That this theefe was very happy and glorious, ≈øeeing hee taught the church how to pray, as he had taught the Synagogue how to ≈øteale, con≈øidering he ≈øaid nothing in his petition, but Lord remember mee: the which praier although it were ≈øhort, yet it was full of my≈øtery, becau≈øe that we need not to be very importunate with God to win his fauour, but remember him of our bu≈øines with Domine memento mei. What ≈øaie≈øt thou good theefe, what ≈øaie≈øt thou? Domine memento mei dum veneris in regnum tuum: as if he would ≈øay, O holy Prophet, O Ie≈øus of Galily, by the bloud which thou ≈øhedde≈øt, I be≈øeech thee, & by the loue with the which thou didde≈øt ≈øhed it, I pray thee, that thou woulde≈øt be mindfull of me, when thou ≈øhalt come into thy owne proper kingdome. If wee will reckon the fiue words, they are the≈øe: Domine the fir≈øt, memento the ≈øecond, mei the third, dum veneris the fourth, in regnum tuum the fift. Now it is to be noted, who ≈øpake the≈øe words, that is a theefe, vnto whom he ≈øpake them, which was Chri≈øt, where he ≈øpake them, which was vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and when hee ≈øpake them, and it was when hee was ready to die: in≈øomuch that if they be ea≈øie to be counted, they are hard to be vnder≈øtood. Hee dooth begin his praier like a curious Orator with this word Domine, Lord, wherein it ≈øeemeth that hee dooth confe≈ø≈øe in Chri≈øt, his Deity and diuinity, his e≈ø≈øence and power, his authority
and rule, his iu≈øtice and liberality. Origen ≈øayth, If the good theefe ≈øhould beleeue that Chri≈øt was a mighty and great king, yet would he aske him no le≈ø≈øe than a whole kingdome? This word Lord is a high beginning of a petition: for if he who asketh do not beleeue that all things are vnder his mighty hand, he could not thinke that he ≈øhould obtaine any thing. O glorious theefe (≈øayth An≈øelmus) and happy martyr, what doe≈øt thou ≈øee in this Lord which is crucified, what do≈øt thou ≈øee in him on the cro≈ø≈øe, why thou ≈øhoulde≈øt commend thy ≈øelfe vnto him? Who euer ≈øaw or heard the like, that one which was bound ≈øhould commend him≈øelfe vnto another, which was al≈øo bound; and one which was crucified vnto another in the ≈øame ca≈øe? Doe≈øt thou aske that tho≈øe confederacies and friend≈øhips which end in death, ≈øhould begin with Chri≈øt and thee in death? Seeing hee who ≈øhould be a Lord, ≈øhould bee at liberty and in freedome, why doe≈øt thou call him Lord, which is fa≈øtened to the cro≈ø≈øe, and crucified like thy ≈øelfe? Seeing that he who ≈øhould be a Lord, ought to bee mighty and rich, why doe≈øt thou call him Lord, who was poor in his life time, and naked in his death? But this Prophet whoÃÑ I call vpon, and vnto whome I commend and commit my ≈øelfe, is a mighty Lord, and a king of great power, ≈øeeing the ≈øon lo≈øt his light for compa≈øsion, the ≈øtones broke with griefe, the vaile rent in ≈øunder for a my≈øtery, the graues opened with feare, and the Centurion confe≈ø≈øed him to be Chri≈øt. O great God of I≈ørael, O great Lord of the hou≈øe of Iacob ‚Ä¢ , for this cau≈øe thy name is admirable, and wor≈øhipped in all the circuit of the earth, becau≈øe thy power and dominion is doubled and redoubled, more than any mans in the world. Ca≈øsiodorus noteth vpon this matter, That the holy ≈øcripture doth neuer call any twi≈øe Lord, Lord, but Chri≈øt alone; becau≈øe he alone, and none with him, is Lord of heauen and earth, of life and death, body and ≈øoule, and of peace and warre. Wee cannot call Hector the Troian, Anchi≈øes the Grecian, Alexander the Macedonian, and Cae≈øar the Romane, Lord, more than once, becau≈øe they were kings onely of their owne kingdomes: but
vnto the ≈øonne of God, wee ≈øay twi≈øe Domine domine no≈øter, Lord our Lord, becau≈øe his ≈øiegnory is ≈øo great, that no man is able to limit it, nor ≈øet any bonds vnto it. Euery other Prince hath his kingdome limited and ≈øet with bonds, either to the top of a ≈øteeple or couering of a hou≈øe; and if it bee not ≈øo, let him ≈øend a po≈øt from thence vpward, and hee ≈øhall perceiue that his kingdome reacheth no higher: which cannot be ≈øaid to be true of the ≈øonne of Gods Empire, ≈øeeing it goeth from one end of the world vntill the other, and reacheth vp vnto the highe≈øt heauen. Con≈øidering that Dauid calleth Chri≈øt, Lord Lord twi≈øe, why doth he call him only once Lord. The my≈øtery of this my≈øtery is, that Dauid called him Lord, Lord twi≈øe, becau≈øe hee ≈øhould keepe his body from his enemies, and cary his ≈øoule vnto tho≈øe which are ble≈ø≈øed: but the good theefe did call him but once Lord, becau≈øe his intention was not that Chri≈øt ≈øhould keepe his life, but only that hee would vouch≈øafe to ≈øaue his ≈øoule. Why doe≈øt thou thinke (≈øayth S. Ba≈øil vpon the P≈øalme) that Dauid ≈øaid vnto our Lord, Lord calling him twife Lord, but becau≈øe he was Lord of the truth, and of the figure, of the church and of the ≈øynagogue, of the Prophets and of the Apo≈øtles, and of the old Te≈øtament and of the new? The good theefe would not call Chri≈øt Lord twi≈øe, becau≈øe hee would let vs vnder≈øtand, that the figure is fulfilled, and the truth come; that the church is come and the ≈øynagogue ended; that the Prophets are dead, and the Apo≈øtles ≈øucceeded in their place; that the old law is buried, and the Go≈øpel proclaimed. Why, think you, doth the good theef call Chri≈øt Lord but once, but becau≈øe we haue but one Lord to beleeue, & one redeemer to wor≈øhip? To ≈øay once Chri≈øt remember me, was to ≈øay, that hee would haue him and no other for a ma≈øter to ≈øerue, for God in whoÃÑ he would beleeue, for his Lord whom hee would obey, for a friend whome hee would tru≈øt vnto, & for an aduocate in who≈øe hands he would put him≈øelfe into. The ≈øecond word which the theefe ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt was RemeÃÑber me: as if he would ≈øay, Seeing that I doe confe≈ø≈øe thee here before all men to bee my Lord, and
vpon this cro≈ø≈øe acknowledge thee to be my redeemer, haue mee in remembrance, my good Lord, ≈øeeing I haue remeÃÑbred thee, and turned vnto thee. Remember me O ≈øweet Ie≈øus: ≈øeeing thou ha≈øt created me, remember me; ≈øeeing thou ha≈øt redeemed mee, remember mee; and ≈øeeing thou ha≈øt lightened me, remember mee; and ≈øeeing thou ha≈øt cho≈øen me, remember me: for it would auaile me very little, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt giue me light to know thee, if withall thou ≈øhoulde≈øt not giue me grace to ≈øerue thee. RemeÃÑber me O good Ie≈øus, becau≈øe I am hard by thy ≈øide, remember me becau≈øe I beleeue in thee, remember me becau≈øe I tru≈øt in thee, remember me becau≈øe I hope in none but in thee; and ≈øeeing I haue offered my ≈øelfe for to be thy perpetuall ≈øeruant, remember I be≈øeech thee to accept me for thine. Remember mee becau≈øe thou ha≈øt rai≈øed me from the du≈øt, remember me becau≈øe thou ha≈øt made me a Chri≈øtian, remember me to make mee good, and remember mee to giue mee heauen, and aboue all things I be≈øeech thee that ≈øeeing thou ha≈øt giuen thy life for me, remember me that I lo≈øe not my ≈øoule. O good Ie≈øus giuer of life, with my tongue I be≈øeech thee, and with my heart I aske it of thee, that ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt ≈øhed thy precious bloud vpon the cro≈ø≈øe for me, remember me that it be not euilly be≈øtowed on mee: and when ≈øhall thy bloud be euilly be≈øtowed on mee, but when it is not by thee accepted for me? Seeing thou ha≈øt ≈øweat oft for me, ≈øuffered mo≈øt grieuous pains for me, endured in≈øpeakable per≈øecutions for mee, and ha≈øt di≈ø≈øembled my abominable offences; what doe≈øt thou gaine O good Ie≈øus, what doe≈øt thou gaine, if I lo≈øe my ≈øoule, and thou the fruit of thy precious bloud? Remember me O Lord, ≈øeeing that in pardoning my fault, and by ≈øauing my ≈øoul, thou ≈øhalt make a Chri≈øtian, people heauen the more, enrich thy church, ≈øpread abroad thy fame, and exalt thy mercy. Remember the ≈øabboth day, ≈øaid God in the law, remember the daies pa≈øt ≈øaid Moy≈øes vnto God, remember becau≈øe my life is a wind ≈øaid holy Iob, remeÃÑ ber how I haue walked before thee≈øaid king Ezechias when he was ≈øick, and remember me ≈øaid good Io≈øeph when he was
in pri≈øon, and remember mee when thou comme≈øt into thy kingdome, I ≈øay vnto thee here now crucified vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe. What ≈øhould I ≈øay, O the light of my life? What doe≈øt thou aske me that I haue not giuen thee, and what doe I po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe that is not thine? I haue already giuen my money to the iailor, my coats to the hang man, I haue ≈øalne out with my companion who iniuried thee, I haue made the be≈øt an≈øwere that I could for thy honour, and therefore I can do nothing more, but ≈øay, Lord remember me, Domine memento mei: and ≈øeeing I offer thee the confe≈øsion of Mi≈øerere, & that vpoÃÑ my knees, and my eies wa≈øhed with tears, why ≈øhoulde≈øt thou ≈øhut the gates of thy mercy again≈øt me, my confe≈øsion being thus iu≈øt, being condemned for a naughty per≈øon as thou art, my members di≈øiointed the one from the other like thine, crucified vpon the cro≈ø≈øe like thy ≈øelfe, I beleeue faithfully in thee, and commend my ≈øelfe wholly vnto thee ≈øaying, Lord remember mee, Lord-remember mee: and I be≈øeech thee haue pitie on me, ≈øeeing that in ≈øuffering I am like vnto thee. I dy for being a theefe, and thou for the ≈øame cau≈øe; they put mee to death on the Mount of Caluary, and on the Mount of Caluary they kill thee, at high noone daies they execute mee, and at the ≈øame houre they execute thee, thou art as neere the end of thy life, as I am neere to death; and therfore Lord remember me: thus as wee depart both together out of this world ≈øo al≈øo we may both together goe into heauen. What rea≈øon doth permit it, or what iu≈øtice doth ≈øuffer, O my good Lord, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt take me for thy companion, to ≈øuffer on the cro≈ø≈øe with thee; and when thou doe≈øt go into heauen, to leaue mee here behind thee? Seeing thou wilt depart out of this world to death, and that through ≈øuch a narrow pa≈ø≈øage and long way, whom can≈øt thou take with thee better than the theefe, which was thy fellow vpon the tree? It is nece≈ø≈øary that thy poore mother liue, thou ha≈øt left thy Iohn thy cou≈øin to his owne cu≈øtodie, Peter thy Di≈øciple hath denied thee, Iudas thy ≈øteward hath ≈øold thee, all the Iewes haue beene vngratefull vnto thee; and therfore ≈øeeing
that thou doe≈øt ≈øee no body neere thee, who doth confe≈ø≈øe and acknowledge thee but my ≈øelfe alone, who am here alone with thee, Lord remember mee, and either giue mee ≈øomewhat in thy Te≈øtament, or take mee with thee to Paradi≈øe. O holy Nazarean and ble≈ø≈øed Prophet, ≈øeeing that thou didde≈øt heare Ionas out of the Whales belly, Daniel out of the lake of Babilonia, Io≈øeph out of the dungeon of Egypt, Ieremy out of the darke well, and didde≈øt heare Dauid when he ≈øaid, Tibi ≈øoli peccaui, I haue ≈øinned vnto thee only, why doe≈øt thou not heare-mee, when I crie Lord remember mee, Domine memento mei? Behold O my good Lord, behold O my good companion, now my eies doe breake, now my la≈øt houre is come, now my ≈øight faileth mee, and my ≈øpeech is troubled, and my ≈øoule is pulled out of my body, and therefore in this narrow pa≈øsing and doubtfull way, vnto whome ≈øhould I ≈øay better than vnto thee, Lord remember me, yea and all the whole P≈øalme of Mi≈øerere? Io≈øue was a theefe, ≈øeeing he ≈øtole grapes fron Chanaan, Dauid was a theefe, ≈øeeing hee ≈øtole the bottle of water from Saul, Rachael was a theefe, ≈øeeing ≈øhe ≈øtole the idols from her father, Ionathas was a theefe, ≈øeeing hee ≈øtole hony from the hiue, Io≈øaba was a theefe, ≈øeeing he ≈øtole the infant Ionas, and yet thou didde≈øt not command any one of all the≈øe to bee hanged, nor ≈øend them from thy hou≈øeuf this be ≈øo, and if thou didde≈øt forgiue tho≈øe which ≈øtole thy goods, wilt thou not forgiue mee poore theefe, who turne for thy honours ≈øake, and keepe thee company in this place? Seeing that of old time, thou art accu≈øtomed to forgiue very famous theeues, and di≈ø≈øemble very notorious thefts, why doe≈øt thou not forgiue me among them, and ab≈øolue me of my ≈øinnes? If thou wilt haue tears for the thefts which I haue done, thou ≈øee≈øt that they run downe my cheekes; if thou doe≈øt content thy ≈øelfe to ≈øee bloud, thou ≈øee≈øt that there is no drop left in mee, if thou wilt haue mee whip my ≈øelfe, I am already bowelled, if thou wilt haue mee repent, I ≈øay vnto thee Soli peccaui, if thou wilt haue mee make entire ≈øatisfaction, how can≈øt thou haue me to do it, not
hauing halfe an houre to liue? Lord Ie≈øus remember mee, and bee my ≈øurety vnto thy father in the other world, and put mee with thy cho≈øen flocke, write mee in thy booke, and place mee in thy glory, ≈øeeing that the faith of which thou art, doth flouri≈øh onely in thy mother, and remaineth in my heart. Remember mee O good Ie≈øus, and if thou wilt depart out of this ≈øorrowfull life into the other before mee, I be≈øeech thee, leaue mee the ≈øtep of thy foor to tread in, and a path-way to follow thee: for if I acknowledge thee for my God, and receaue thee for my God, and beleeue in thee for my God, being as thou art di≈ømembred and crucified, ≈øhall not I ≈øerue thee, and prai≈øe thee farre better when I ≈øhall ≈øee thee glorified? Dare≈øt thou tru≈øt me with thy cro≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe I ≈øhould wor≈øhip it, and with thy body becau≈øe I ≈øhould accompany thee, and with thy mother to comfort her, and with thy honour to defend it, and with thy church to augment it, and with thy faith to maintaine it, and wilt thou not put thy glory into my hands, that I may alwaies prai≈øe thee in it? When they condemned thee to bee crucified, and brought mee to bee executed, I heard thee ≈øay there before Pilate, That thy kingdome was not of this world: and then ≈øeeing thou art a king, and ha≈øt a kingdome, remember mee and take me with thee, and I will tell thy father what thou ha≈øt ≈øuffered to ≈øerue him, and all the fauours which thou ha≈øt done for me. Now that the good theefe hath made his praier vnto God, and recommended him≈øelfe vnto him, it is rea≈øon now that the naughty theefe haue licen≈øe to ≈øpeake, which is my naughty and peruer≈øe heart; becau≈øe the theefe which hanged on the left hand of God, did bla≈øpheme Chri≈øt but once, but thou, my ≈øoule, doe≈øt bla≈øpheme him euery day. Remember mee O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, and haue mercy on mee, O my ≈øoules glory, to the end that the ≈øhedding of thy pretious bloud, be not euilly be≈øtowed in mee: for at the time when thou didde≈øt ≈øhed it, thou didde≈øt not feeele ≈øo grieuou≈øly the vvant of it in thy bodie, as thou didde≈øt feele the
vngratefulne≈ø≈øe of the whole world. And when is thy precious bloud vnthankfully ≈øhed for mee, but when I yeeld vnto that which my Sen≈øuality dem ‚Ä¢ ndeth of mee, and not vnto that which thy Go≈øpell coun≈øelleth mee? What is all that worth which I would, if thou wilt not? If thou goe≈øt to ≈øeeke out theeues, and if thou doe≈øt hunt after ≈øinners; why doe≈øt thou ≈øeeke for any more than for mee; becau≈øe there is no theefe who hath committed greater robberies than I, nor any ≈øinners who hath done more greeuous ≈øins than I? O patient and benigue Lord, if the wickedne≈ø≈øe of my heart, and the offences which I haue committed, in ≈øecret were knowne notoriou≈øly vnto the iudges of the world, as they are knowne vnto thee, I ≈øhould many yeares agoe haue beene hanged, and in the other world condemned. I will not ≈øay with the Prophet Dauid, Where be thy old mercies, ≈øeeing that I ≈øee them enter euery day into my gates, becau≈øe I doe not make more ha≈øt to ≈øinne, than thou to pardon mee. The pardon which thou didde≈øt giue vnto the good theefe, doth giue vs al≈øo great hope to obtaine pardon at thy hands: for he being come to the gibbet, condemned for his offence, went away ≈øanctified with thy Grace. If thou do giue theeues and robbers kingdomes, what wilt thou do and giue vnto theÃÑ whom thou doe≈øt loue; and are cho≈øen of thy father? If thou didde≈øt giue the kingdome of heauen to a rouer and a thee≈øe for ≈øpeaking one onely word vnto thee, and ≈øeruing thee one halfe houre, what wilt thou giue vnto him O good Ie≈øus who loueth thee with all his hart, & prai≈øeth thee with his tongue, and emploieth all his might and power in thy ≈øeruice.

div.head: CHAP. XII. How our Lord heard the theeues praier vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and how Chri≈øt an≈øwered him ≈øeuen words for fiue which hee ≈øpake vnto Chri≈øt.
div.p:
DOminus exaudiuit vocempueri de loco in quo e≈øt, Gene≈øis 21. ≈øaid the Angel vnto I≈ømael his mother: as if he would ≈øay, Take no care O Agar, take no care: for although thou ha≈øt lo≈øt thy way, and art bani≈øhed in this de≈øart, feare no peril, becau≈øe our Lord hath heard the praier of the youth thy ≈øonne, becau≈øe he hath praied where he hath praied. The Patriarch Abraham had a ba≈øtard child by Agar his maid and ≈ølaue, both which were throwne out of dores after that hee had a lawfull child borne vnto him, and the≈øe two went vp a mountaine alone in great di≈øpaire, & our Lord ≈øent vnto them an Angel to comfort them, and to giue them drinke. Origen ≈øayth, That if wee looke well into the ≈øcripture, we ≈øhall neither read, that the mother did pray vnto the Lord, neither is it made mention that the ≈øonne did commend him≈øelfe vnto God: but that Gods great mercy is ≈øo great, that by ≈øeeing the youth I≈ømael weepe, and the ≈øorrowfull mother lament and cry, our Lord was moued to comfort them by word, and al≈øo releiue them in deed. Plato in his Timao ≈øayth, That it doth ≈ømally benefit the grieued and comfortle≈ø≈øe to vi≈øit them ≈øeldome, and ≈øpeake much vnto them, and giue theÃÑ no comfort at all, vnle≈ø≈øe that comfort be wrapped in ≈øome remedie and reliefe. Seneca ≈øayth, That if a friend doe vi≈øite his friend, and find him heauy and ≈øad, and ≈øo leaue him, if hee find him poore and ≈øo leaue him, if hee find him weeping, and leaue him weeping, wee will ≈øay of ≈øuch a one, that hee goeth rather to ie≈øt, than to vi≈øite and comfort: becau≈øe a comfortle≈ø≈øe heart, is much better appea≈øed with that
which we giue him with our hands, than with that which we ≈øpeake vnto him with our tongue. S. Ambro≈øe in his Exameron ≈øayth, That to the end a worke of mercy may bee perfect & more acceptable vnto our Lord, it ought neither to bee asked of any, nor craued, but voluntarily & liberally be be≈øtowed, becau≈øe there is nothing more deare in this world, than that which is bought with entreaty. O that hee buieth very deerely, who buieth by the change and price of his ≈øhame; becau≈øe that ≈øhamefa≈øt men and of liberall hearts, doe without compari≈øon grieue more when they vncouer & ≈øhew their face, than when they vntie their pur≈øe. Cicero to Atticus ≈øayth, That there is nothing wherein a Gentlemanlike man taketh more delight than in giuing, and greater griefe than in asking; becau≈øe that in giuing, he maketh him≈øelf Lord of him vnto whome hee giueth, and in taking hee maketh him≈øelfe a ≈ølaue to him of whoÃÑ he receiueth. Hilarius ≈øaith, That to deale with God, there need no words but teares, nor many entreaties but many ≈øighes: for wheÃÑ we pray vnto our Lord, he hath greater regard vnto the heart which de≈øireth, than vnto all that which the tongue ≈øpeaketh. Agar the ≈ølaue, and I≈ømael her ≈øonne, ≈øpake no word vnto God, nor yet made any petition vnto him, but ech of them being ≈øet downe vnder a ≈øeuerall oke, the ≈øonne did neuer fill him≈øelfe with weeping, and the mother neuer cea≈ø≈øed from ≈øighing, the which holy teares were not vnpaied, nor ≈øighes vnaccepted. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, if our Lord did heare I≈ømaels teares, which was in the de≈øart, will he not al≈øo hear the memento mei, which the theefe ≈øpake vnto him in the Mount of Caluary? Let no man maruell that we compare the theefe with I≈ømael, and I≈ømael with the theefe: for as the one was brought vp in the mountaines a hunting, ≈øo the other went by the high waies a robbing, & as I≈ømael had one very vertuous brother, ≈øo al≈øo this theefe had a bla≈øphemer to his companion. I≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ael was yong, for hee was not aboue three yeares of age, the theefe was al≈øo yong, for he had not been as yet three houres a Chri≈øtian, becau≈øe that before our Lord, the yeares when we are borne,
are not reckoned, but the time from whence we are baptized. After Chri≈øts re≈øurrection, hee called his di≈øciples children and yonglings, not re≈øpecting that ≈øome of them were old, and had gray haires, but that they had not ben long baptized, that is, when hee wa≈øhed their feet in the parlar, and ordained them Prie≈øts after his ≈øupper. If I≈ømael did weepe at the foot of the oake in the de≈øart, ≈øo did the good theefe weepe al≈øo vpon the cro≈ø≈øe on Caluary: and that which is more excellent is, that if hee gaue the one water whereof hee ≈øhould drinke, he gaue the other his bloud, wherewith he ≈øhould bee ≈øaued. As Abraham had one lawfull child, which was I≈øaac, and another a ba≈øtard which was I≈ømael, ≈øo God the father had or lawfull child, which was Chri≈øt, and the other a ba≈øtard, which was the theefe; and of the≈øe two, the one was borne in the church, and the other in the Synagogue. The ble≈øsing which fell vnto I≈ømael, was that he ≈øhould be again≈øt all men and all men again≈øt him: the which ble≈øsing al≈øo the good theefe had, who being vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and all purpo≈øing to kill and crucifie Chri≈øt, hee again≈øt all [though all again≈øt him] defended him and excu≈øed him. I≈ømael was a father of many barbarous people, and the good theefe was an example of many great ≈øinners, but not that they ≈øhould liue wickedly as hee had done, but that they ≈øhould turne vnto our Lord as hee did. Agar the mother could not ≈øee I≈ømael her ≈øonne die, neither could the ≈øonne of God ≈øee his companion the theefe bee condemned: and therefore as the teares of the one were gratefull vnto him, euen ≈øo the words of the other vvere plea≈øing vnto him; to wit, when hee ≈øaid on the cro≈ø≈øe, Lord remember me, and O good Ie≈øus haue mercy vpon mee. With great rea≈øon, and for good occa≈øion the ≈øon of God did giue care vnto all that the good theefe would ≈øpeake vnto him, and vnto all that which hee did reque≈øt of him, becau≈øe hee v≈øed ≈øuch mea≈øure and di≈øcretion in his petition, that hee asked nothing which ≈øhould bee for his comfort, but for his ≈øaluation. If hee vvould haue asked any thing for his comfort, he vvould
haue asked that the cudgels which winded his cords ≈øhould haue been ≈ølackened, or that they would haue pulled out the nailes, or healed his wounds, or that they would pull him downe from the cro≈ø≈øe, or that they would giue him longer life: but he asked none of all this, but only that Chri≈øt would haue his ≈øoule in remembrance, not mentioning his per≈øon at all. Our Lord could not denie him ≈øo rea≈øonable a petition, nor delay him, but he an≈øwered him immediately: for euen as he ≈øaid, Domine memento moi, Chri≈øt ≈øaid pre≈øently vnto him, Hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øo, This day thou ≈øhalt be with me in Paradi≈øe. The naughty theefe did not de≈øerue to haue an an≈øwere at Chri≈øts hands neither ≈øoon nor late, partly becau≈øe it was the ≈øonne of Gods cu≈øtome, not to an≈øwer tho≈øe which did iniury him, nor e≈øteeme of tho≈øe which bare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt him, and partly to adui≈øe vs, that it is a point of great di≈øcretion, not to ≈øet by iniurious words. Vbertinus ≈øaith, Why ≈øhould Chri≈øt heare what the naughty theefe would aske him, or make account of it, ≈øeeing that he knew very wel that if he would haue beene loo≈øed, it was to ≈øteale againe, and in ≈øtealing againe, they would hang him againe? In that that Chri≈øt would not an≈øwere vnto the naughty theefe, nor yeeld vnto his petition, hee v≈øed a new kind of clemency toward him; to wit, that he hindered him froÃÑ ≈øinning any more, and froÃÑ augmenting his damnation: for if Chri≈øt ≈øhould haue taken him from the cro≈ø≈øe, and hee haue returned againe into the world, by how much the more he would haue augmeÃÑted his ≈øinne, by ≈øo much the more he ≈øhould haue encrea≈øed his puni≈øhment. S. Augu≈øtine vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, That our Lord ≈øhewed his mercy and pity toward both the theeues; vnto the good one in giuing him glory, to the naughty one in denying him life: for if he had liued longer, he would haue ≈øinned more, and according to the mea≈øure of his offences, his torments ≈øhould haue beene giuen him. S. Gregory ≈øaith, That if our Lord doe for vs that which wee aske, wee ought to reioice; and if he deny vs that which wee aske him, wee mu≈øt not complaine: for if our Lord would haue giuen the ≈øonnes
of Zebedet the kingdome which they required, and vnto the naughty theefe the life which hee craued, it had beene vnto their great confu≈øion and al≈øo damnation. And becau≈øe that in the≈øe words, Hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øo, there are contained ≈øeuen words, as we haue noted heretofore; it ≈øhall not bee ami≈ø≈øe, if that vpon euery word we ≈øpeake one word, becau≈øe the curious Reader may ≈øee how wi≈øely the theefe dealt, and how profoundly Chri≈øt did an≈øwer him. The fir≈øt word which Chri≈øt ≈øpake vnto the theefe was Amen, that is, I ≈øweare to thee in truth: which word Amen was in the old Te≈øtament very famous, and much ≈øet by, and in the mouth of the ≈øonne of God much v≈øed, in≈øomuch that the Synagogue did profit her≈øelfe with that word to confirme that which ≈øhe ≈øware, & Chri≈øt v≈øed the ≈øame word to ≈øweare that which he ≈øpake. In monte Hebal ≈øtabunt, Ruben, Gad, A≈øser, Zabulon, Dan & Nepthalim, ad maledice ‚Ä¢ dum populum, & re≈øpondebit omnts pepulus, Amen, ≈øaid the Lord vnto Moi≈øes in the 28 chapter of Gene≈øis: as if hee would ≈øay, It is my will and plea≈øure O Moy≈øes that ≈øixe Princes of I≈ørael, that is, Ruben and Gad, and A≈ø≈øer and Zabulon, and Dan and Nepthalim; goe vp vnto the highe≈øt of the hill Hebal, and from thence they ≈øhall begin aloud to cur≈øe all the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors of my law, and in the end of euery cur≈øe, all the people ≈øhall an≈øwere, Amen. When the ≈øix princes were come to the top of the hill Hebal, they began to cur≈øe tho≈øe which brake the law in this manner. Accur≈øed be that man which dare make ≈øtrange Gods to wor≈øhip and giue honour vnto them, although they be of gold and ≈øiluer, & let all the people ≈øay Amen. Cur≈øed bee the ≈øonne or daughter which will not honour his father and his mother, and let all men ≈øay Amen. Cur≈øed bee that man which ie≈øting at a blind man, ≈øhall put his foot before him to make him fall, and ≈øhall ≈øet him out of the way to make him erre, and let all the people ≈øay Amen. Cur≈øed be the man which will take money to kill his neighbour by trea≈øon and craft, and let all ≈øay Amen. Cur≈øed bee the iudge, who either through hatred or gaine which hee may pretend, giueth a wrong iudgement again≈øt a
widdow, and oppre≈ø≈øe the orphane, and not ea≈øe a ≈øtranger, and let all the people ≈øay Amen. You may then ≈øee that this word Amen was a word of feare and of great rigour, ≈øeeing that it was v≈øed to confirme their cur≈øes, which they did ca≈øt vpon the people, and not the ble≈øsings which they gaue them. It is to bee noted, that God commanded Moy≈øes the ≈øame day to goe vp vnto the top of the hill Gari≈øim with ≈øix Princes with him, to ble≈ø≈øe all tho≈øe which would keepe his commandements: but hee did not command them in the end of their ble≈øsing to ≈øay Amen, as hee did in the end of his cur≈øe. The ≈øynagogue was not worthy of this priuiledge, becau≈øe God kept it for his church, which is ≈øeene by the promi≈øe which Chri≈øt made vnto the good theefe, wheÃÑ he ≈øaid, Amen I ≈øay vnto thee this day thou ≈øhalt be with me in Paradi≈øe, in ≈øo much that Chri≈øt began to ble≈ø≈øe the cho≈øen of his church, with the ≈øame word that the ≈øynagogue ended her cur≈øe again≈øt the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors of the law. This word Amen (≈øayth Vbertinus) which did ≈øerue in the ≈øynagogue for a cur≈øe, doth ≈øerue now in the vniuer≈øall Church for a ble≈øsing: the which word the ≈øonne of God had alwaies in his mouth, when hee promi≈øed any great matter, or ≈øpake any high ≈øecret. Chri≈øt did ≈øo well like this word Amen, truly, that his Euangeli≈øts and Chroniclers doe affirme, that hee v≈øed it fifty and fiue times, and S. Paul in his Epi≈øtles eighteen times, and it is v≈øed in the Apocalips al≈øo fiue times, and in the canonicall Epi≈øtle three times. S. Augu≈øt, vpon S. Iohn ≈øaith, That the ≈øonne of God was not content to ≈øay once Amen, but he did ofteÃÑtimes double the word, ≈øaying Amen, Amen, truly, truly; giuing vs thereby to vnder≈øtand, that he did not only ≈øpeake the truth in that which he ≈øpake, but al≈øo that he was the truth it ≈øelfe. There is no Angell nor man (≈øaith Remigius) which can ≈øay Amen, Amen: for although they ≈øpeake the truth in all that they ≈øpeake, yet it doth not follow that they be the truth it ≈øelfe, becau≈øe God did not impart this high priuiledge vnto any, but his onely ≈øonne, who by ≈øpeciall grace ≈øaid, Ego ≈øum via & veritas & vita, I am the way and the truth and life.
Chri≈øt did not ≈øay, I know which way the way goeth, but ≈øaid I am the way: for in troth he who is not guided by Chri≈øt ≈øhal mi≈ø≈øe the way to heauen. Nor Chri≈øt ≈øaid not, I giue life, but ≈øaid I am the life, becau≈øe that in the hou≈øe of God, they call it not to liue, vnle≈ø≈øe they liue well, neither doe they ≈øay that man to liue, which is not a good man; nor Chir≈øt did not ≈øay, I ≈øpeake the truth in that which I ≈øay, but ≈øaid I am the very truth: for euen as the deuill is a bottome without bottome, from whence all lies doe proceed, ≈øo the ≈øonne of God is a fountaine from whence all truths doe ≈øpring. Benedictio & honor & gloria, & pote≈øtas in ≈øecula ≈øeculorum, & quatuor animalia dicebant Amen, Apocalips 5. ≈øaid the Angels in prai≈øe of our Lord: as if they would ≈øay, Let honour, glory, power and ble≈øsing, be giuen vnto our God, and vnto the lambe his ≈øon, for euer and euer, and the foure bea≈øts an≈øwered Amen. Al≈øo S. Iohn ≈øaid in the 7. chapter, That he ≈øaw a company of Saints before God, which were ≈øo many in number, that they could not bee numbred, and ≈øo many Angels al≈øo that they could not be numbred, clothed with ≈øtoles & palmes in their hands and pro≈øtrate vpon the ground, which ≈øaid no other thing in the prai≈øe of God but Amen, Amen, Amen. O what great my≈øteries and deepe ≈øecrets are contained vnder this holy word Amen, ≈øeeing we find it in the old Te≈øtament, and that Chri≈øt v≈øed it, and the Angels in heauen prai≈øe Chri≈øt with it, and the church al≈øo doth euery vvhere profite her ≈øelfe vvith it! Doth ≈øhee not profite her ≈øelfe vvith it, ≈øeeing that in the end of euery praier, ≈øhee doth confirme it with Amen? Vnto World without end, we an≈øwere Amen, vnto Who liueth and raigneth, vve an≈øwer Amen: vvith this holy vvord the ≈øonne of God began to pardon, and vvith the ≈øame vvord the church endeth her praier. Rupert vpon the Apocalips ≈øaith, That this vvord AmeÃÑ, is neither Greek, nor Latine, nor Chaldey, but Hebrew: and although this word might haue beene turned as other vvordes vvere, yet the church did not thinke it conuenient, but as Chri≈øt ≈øaid Amen, ≈øo doth the church ≈øay likewi≈øe Amen. Why did the
≈øon of God (≈øaith Chri≈øo≈øt.) begin the pardoÃÑ, which he gaue the good theefe, with this word Amen dico tibi, but only to a≈ø≈øure him, that he would fulfill all which he promi≈øed him? Seeing that it is a cu≈øtome fir≈øt to promi≈øe that which wee will giue or do, and then to ≈øweare and affirme it, why did the ≈øonne of God do the contrary, & ≈øwear before he promi≈øed the theefe Paradi≈øe? For when Chri≈øt ≈øaid vnto the theefe, Amen dico tibi, it was as much as to ≈øay, I ≈øweare in truth: and why would God ≈øwear that which he promi≈øed, and would not be beleeued at his word? Cyprian vpon the Pa≈øsion ≈øaith, That becau≈øe that which Chri≈øt promi≈øed was ≈øuch a great matter, to wit Paradi≈øe, and he vnto whom he promi≈øed ≈øuch a grieuous ≈øinner, who was a theefe, & he who promi≈øed, of ≈øuch ≈ømall credite, who was a man crucified, and the place where he promi≈øed ≈øo infamous which was the cro≈ø≈øe, and the people before whom he promi≈øed ≈øo vile, who were the Iewes, the ≈øonne of God would ≈øwear fir≈øt before he promi≈øed. If Chri≈øt did ≈øwear it was not becau≈øe there was any want in his word, but becau≈øe the ≈øynagogue ≈øhould the better beleeue him. Augu≈øt. vpon S. Iohn ≈øaith, That if the ≈øon of God would not haue ≈øworn the performance of ≈øo great a gift, it would haue ≈øeemed vnto the Iewes, that he had promi≈øed it him in a mockage; & ≈øo much the rather, becau≈øe that vntil that very in≈øtaÃÑt, in which Chri≈øt ≈øaid on the cro≈ø≈øe, Hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øe, he neuer gaue it vnto Saint, nor promi≈øed it in ≈øcripture. If Chri≈øt had not ≈øworn that which he promi≈øed, who would not haue thought that he had ie≈øted in promi≈øing credit & honor vnto him who had lo≈øt his credit, to promi≈øe life vnto him who was dead, liberty vnto him who was bound, riches vnto him who was poore, and glory vnto him who was infamous? Becau≈øe the Iewes ob≈øtinacy was ≈øo great, and the good theeues faith but yong and weake, good Ie≈øus would ≈øweare before hee promi≈øed that which he meant to promi≈øe; & becau≈øe al men might be certain, that he who at the point of death, confirmed any thing by oth, ought neuer to deceiue.

div.head: CHAP XIII. How the ≈øonne of God neuer v≈øed this word Paradi≈øe, vntill he promi≈øed it vnto the good theefe: and of many learned expo≈øitions of this ≈øaying, Hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øo, This day thou ≈øhalt be with mee in Paradi≈øe.
div.p:
NOn fru≈øtra dixi ≈øemini Iacob, quaerite me, quia ego ≈øum dominus loquens iu≈øtitias, & annunciansrecte, ≈øaid God by E≈øay, chap. 48, as if hee would ≈øay, I ≈øaid not in vain vnto old honourable Iacob, that he ≈øhould ≈øpeak with me alone & beleeue in no other, becau≈øe I am the Lord who can ≈øay nothing but that which is iu≈øt, nor demand nothing but that which is holy. As God is iu≈øt (≈øaith Ierome) hee ≈øayth nothing but that which is iu≈øt, and as he is holy, he ≈øpeaketh nothing but holy things; becau≈øe other men be≈øides him, neither tell vs aright what wee haue to doe, nor adui≈øe vs in time of that which we are to auoid. All out friends and coun≈øellors, when they doe aduerti≈øe vs of any thing, doe ≈øeeme rather to goe by gue≈ø≈øe, than bee ≈øure of that which they ≈øay: and by that means they giue vs coun≈øell after we haue receiued hurt, and teach vs the way after that wee haue gone a≈øtray. God ≈øayth very well, that Iacob heard him not in vaine, neither did I≈ørael that in vaine which he commanded him, ≈øeeing that he gaue him the right of the fir≈øt birth, due to E≈øau, and made him ≈øonne in law vnto Laban, and gaue him Lia and Rachel for his wiues, and made him father of twelue children, and Prince ouer twelue tribes. O how true it is (≈øaith Origen) when our
Lord ≈øaith that hee ≈øpeaketh nothing but that which is iu≈øt, and teacheth nothing but that which is right, ≈øeeing hee maketh tho≈øe iu≈øt who deale with him, and maketh tho≈øe holy who doe conuer≈øe with him. And if he ≈øay that the ob≈øtinate men and naughty be his, yet he will not ≈øay, that hee is one of their number. What can the children of vanity tell vs but vain things, and what can the children of lies tell vs but lies? Who is loiall and faithfull vnto him whome hee hareth, or whom commodity draweth awry? It is our Lord onely who giueth vs our ≈øight to ≈øee with, and teacheth vs which way we ≈øhould goe, and taketh away the ≈øtones lea≈øt wee ≈øtumble at them, and giueth vs coun≈øell in all that wee haue to doe. Our Lord ≈øaith very well, that hee is the Lord who ≈øpeaketh iu≈øtice and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe: for there hath been no man ≈øaued vntill this day, whom he hath not coun≈øelled, nor no man lo≈øt whome hee hath not deceiued. King Roboam who was nephew vnto Dauid, and ≈øonne vnto Salomon, of twelue kingdomes which hee inherited from his predece≈ø≈øors, lo≈øt ten of them, for no other rea≈øon, but becau≈øe hee beleeved not our Lord in that which hee coun≈øelled him, and by following other young mens humors, which plea≈øed his fancy. Ieroboam and A≈ø≈øa, and Iozias, and Achab, and Benedab, and Mana≈ø≈øes, which were famous kings of I≈ørael, what could they do to get credit, what could they doe again≈øt their enemies, or wherein could they helpe their friends, or how could they deale in their owne affaires, becau≈øe they beleeued not in God, nor followed his coun≈øels? And therefore ≈øeeing hee ≈øayth, I am the Lord who ≈øpeaketh iu≈øtice, whom ≈øhould we giue ear vnto but vnto him, who≈øe doing ≈øhould wee credite but his, and e≈øpecially, ≈øeeing that be alone & no other, ≈øeeth that which is pre≈øent, and knoweth all that is pa≈øt, vnder≈øtandeth that which is doubtfull, teacheth vnto that that is ≈øecret, knoweth things to come, and withall mo≈øt of all others de≈øireth that which is good for vs? Why ≈øhould I beleeue in man, and not in God, ≈øeeing that of that which is pa≈øt, he knoweth nothing but that which hee hath heard; of that which hee≈øeeth not,
he knoweth nothing but that which hath beene told him; of ≈øecret things he knoweth no more thaÃÑ hath been reuealed vnto him; of things which are pre≈øent, hee knoweth no more than that which he ≈øeeth, and of things to come he knoweth no more than what hee can gue≈ø≈øe at. S. Barnard in an Epi≈øtle ≈øayth, That it is not without cau≈øe that God ≈øaid by E≈øay, I am the Lord which ≈øpeaketh iu≈øtice and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe that the coun≈øels which meÃÑ giue vs, are but coniectures and no certainties, but the coun≈øels which God giueth vs cannot faile but be as he hath ordained. God ≈øaid vnto Iacob, non fru≈øtr√† dixi, quaerite me, that is, That he had not giuen him that coun≈øell in vaine, neither did it repent Iacob at any time to haue followed it: but few men can ≈øay this, nor few coun≈øels can bee prai≈øed in this ≈øort: for oftentimes it were better giue a coun≈øellor his fee, not to follow his coun≈øell, than to follow it. He giueth me coun≈øell in vain, who maketh me more pa≈øsionate than already I am, and maketh me enter into more ≈øutes than I haue already begun, becau≈øe it is the dutie of a good friend to put him in his vvay vvho is out of it, lift him vp who is downe, comfort him vvho is afflicted, and quiet his mind vvho is mooued vvith pa≈øsions. Vpon tho≈øe vvordes of the P≈øalme, Audiam quid loquetur in me dominus deus, Ba≈øil the great ≈øaith, O how vvillingly I vvill heare all that thou vvilt ≈øay vnto me O good Ie≈øus, becau≈øe thou art eloquent in ≈øpeaking, vvi≈øe in coun≈øelling, pittifull in pardoning, iu≈øt in ≈øuccouring, mighty in commanding, bountifull in giuing, and true in accompli≈øhing all that thou doe≈øt promi≈øe. What did euer good man aske of thee, but thou ha≈øt commanded it to bee giuen him, and what ha≈øt thou commanded but hee hath obtained? What can a man giue but that which hee hath, and what can a man ≈øay, but that which he knoweth? Seneca vnto this purpo≈øe ≈øayth, That if we find a man eloquent in ≈øpeaking, vve ≈øhal find him weake in vvit, to put that in execution vvhich he ≈øpeaketh; in≈øomuch that if it be a plea≈øure to hear him, it is daugerous to beleeue him. If vvee find a man that is iu≈øt in releeuing him vvho is oppre≈ø≈øed, vve ≈øhall find him very
hard in forgiuing his owne enemy; in≈øomuch that if he be iu≈øt in other mens iniuries, he is very vindicatiue of his owne. It is the property of a man, that if he haue much temporall goods at his commandement, he hath no vvill to ≈øpend them vvith any; ≈øo that if by the reque≈øt of friends, or importunitie of neighbours, he do part vvith any thing, he doth vveep before he doth leaue it. It is the property of man, although not of a wi≈øe man, to de≈øire to be heard, although he cannot ≈øpeak, to be feared although he haue no authority, and wel beloued although he cannot loue, and be beleeued although he ≈øpeak not true, and he vvill bee ≈øerued although hee haue no need. What tongue can ≈øpeake it, and vvhat heart can ≈øuffer and endure to talke vvith a foole, to loue an vngratefull man, to aske and craue of a niggard, deale vvith a liar, and ≈øerue a proud man? Hee vvho forgetteth God, and dealeth vvith man, cumbereth him≈øelfe vvith all the≈øe inconueniences, and bindeth him≈øelfe vnto all the≈øe obligations, and the rather becau≈øe there is no man vvho tru≈øteth long another man, but in the end is paied for it. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, the good theefe was mo≈øt happy in vvor≈øhipping Chri≈øt alone, and beleeuing in him onely: for reward vvhereof Chri≈øt ≈øaid vnto him alone and no other, This day thou ≈øhalt be with me in Paradi≈øe. It is a great pitty to ≈øee how many Leuites and Prie≈øts, Lawyers and ancients, neighbours, and acquaintance of Chri≈øt vvere about the cro≈ø≈øe, looking how he ≈øuffered, & vvatching how he died; vnto none of all vvhich he ≈øaid, Hedie me cum eris in Paradi≈øo, as he did vnto the good theefe; in ≈øo much that they heard the words, but vvanted the promi≈øe. Seeing our good Ie≈øus (≈øaith Chry≈øo≈øtome) vvas determined to giue the good theefe glory, vvhy did hee not giue it him, and hold his peace? And ≈øeeing hee did not ≈øend him vvord by a third per≈øon, vvhy did he not tell it him in ≈øecret, and in his eare? And ≈øeeing he vvould not tell him in ≈øecret, but publikely, why did he not defer the reward? And yet if he would not defer the reward, vvhy did he not ≈øend him to heauen alone, but vvould take him to Paradi≈øe vvith him≈øelfe? All
the≈øe are ≈øuch high my≈øteries and ≈øuch deepe ≈øecrets, that there is no wit able to vnder≈øtand them, nor tongue able to ≈øet them forth, nor hand able to write them, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary for vs to craue for the grace of our Lord to direct vs in it, and the holy Gho≈øt to lighten vs. When Chri≈øt ≈øaid vnto the theefe, This day thou ≈øhalt bee with mee in Paradi≈øe, it is as if hee had ≈øaid: O thou theefe my friend and fellow, ≈øeeing that I know with whome I ≈øpeake, it is al≈øo rea≈øon, that thou doe know who ≈øpeaketh: and therefore I let thee vnder≈øtand, that I am the creator of heauen, I am the redeemer of the world, I am the Prophet which is de≈øired, I am the Me≈øsias promi≈øed, I am the giuer of the Go≈øpell, and I am al≈øo the Lord of Paradi≈øe. Let all men beare witne≈ø≈øe with me, & therefore I ≈øpeake it openly, that I bequeath my eternall Paradi≈øe vnto this theefe by this Will and Te≈øtament, becau≈øe that all ≈øuch which ≈øhall ≈øucceed me in my church, may know how well I recompence tho≈øe which ≈øerue me, and how well I deale with tho≈øe which follow mee. An≈øelmus crieth out and ≈øaith, O glorious theefe, O happy theef, how fortunate and lucky wa≈øt thou, ≈øeeing thou didde≈øt nothing but that which did content our good Ie≈øus, nor ≈øaide≈øt nothing but that which well liked him! Thy feet with the which thou didde≈øt follow him were happy, the eies with the which thou did≈øt ≈øuffer with him was happy, the tongue with the which thou didde≈øt confe≈ø≈øe him was happy, & the heart with the which thou didde≈øt beleeue in him was happy. S. Chri≈øo≈øt. noteth, That God did ≈øend Moi≈øes as an Emba≈ø≈øador to Pharaoh, Nathan the Prophet vnto Dauid, the great Prophet E≈øaias vnto Mana≈ø≈øes, his holy Prophet Ieremy vnto King Ozias, the Prophet Daniel vnto Baltha≈øar, and the Satiricall Prophet Helias vnto king Achab. The ≈øonne of God ≈øent a greater imba≈øie and greater Emba≈ø≈øadours vnto the theefe, than God the father did vnto the Kings, ≈øeeing that vnto the theefe which was crucified on the cro≈ø≈øe with him, he ≈øent no other emba≈ø≈øador than him≈øelfe, & ≈øo by this
meanes, the emba≈øie and the Emba≈ø≈øador, were all one thing. Was it not think you the ≈øelfe≈øame thing, ≈øeeing that it was Chri≈øt which ≈øent the me≈ø≈øage, & the ≈øelfe≈øame Chri≈øt which carried it? Origen in an Homilie ≈øayth thus, The greate≈øt me≈ø≈øage that euer came from heauen into the world was that of the incarnation, and the next vnto it was that which Chri≈øt did vnto the good theefe, in≈øomuch that by the comming of the ≈øonne of God the gate of glory was opened, and in the promi≈øe made vnto the good theefe the po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of it was taken. The emba≈øie which Iohn Bapti≈øt brought vs, was that the kingdome of heaueÃÑ was at hand, but the good theef ≈øaith not that he is neer vnto heauen, but that he is within heauen, S. Iohns was a great emba≈øie, when he ≈øaid, Behold the lambe of God which taketh away the ≈øinnes of the world: but that of the theeues was better wheÃÑ he ≈øaid, Behold him here who hath already redeemed the world. The emba≈øie that Samuel brought vnto Dauid was good, wheÃÑ as of a ≈øhepheard he annointed him king but the emba≈øie which Chri≈øt did vnto the good theef was farre better, becau≈øe that there pa≈ø≈øed almo≈øt fourty years betwixt the time that the kingdome was promi≈øed vnto Dauid, and the time that it was deliuered vnto him, but the theef had his kingdome promi≈øed him at two of the clock in the afternoone, and was giuen him pre≈øently toward night. The reward for bringing thee news of ≈øuch a great emba≈øie as that of Chri≈øts was, that is, the promi≈øe of glory, he would let no man haue but he would win it him≈øelf; in≈øomuch he who promi≈øed glory & gaue glory, was the glory it ≈øelf. O good Ie≈øus, redeemer of my ≈øoule, & do≈øt thou well ≈øee that in promi≈øing glory & Paradi≈øe that thou doe≈øt promi≈øe nothing but thy ≈øelf? what meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? Do≈øt thou tru≈øt malefactors, coÃÑmeÃÑd thy ≈øelf vntorouers, offer thy≈øelf vnto ≈øinners, coÃÑmit thy ≈øelf vnto theeues? If thou thinke≈øt thy ≈øelfe ouercharged with this theefe, giue him the Prouince of Achaia, giue him part of A≈ø≈øyria, giue him the kingdome of Pale≈øtine, giue him the monarchy of A≈øia: for in giuing him as thou doe≈øt giue him thy ≈øelfe, if thou were
not God as thou art, it would ≈øeeme that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt preiudice many. Is there any other Paradi≈øe but to enioy thee, is there any other glory than to ≈øee thy face, is there any greater contentment than to be in thy company, is there any goodne≈ø≈øe but that which commeth from thy hands? This day thou ≈øhalt bee with me in Paradi≈øe, where thou ≈øhalt ≈øee me face to face, enioy my e≈ø≈øence, dwell with my per≈øon, haue the fruition of my glory, thy death ≈øhall die, and thy life ≈øhall ri≈øe againe. This day thou ≈øhalt bee with mee in Paradi≈øe, where thou ≈øhalt be alwaies mine, and I will be thine, where thou ≈øhalt ≈øerue mee, and where I will loue thee without end, where thou ≈øhalt leaue ≈øinning, and I neuer cea≈øe to doe thee good. This day thou ≈øhalt bee with mee in Paradi≈øe, where thou ≈øhalt ≈øee ioy without ≈øorrow, health withour griefe, life vvithout death, light vvithout darkene≈ø≈øe, company vvithout ≈øu≈øpition, plenty vvithout want, and glory without end. This day thou ≈øhalt bee with mee in Paradi≈øe, where youth doth neuer waxe old, old age doth neuer appeare, beauty neuer fadeth, health neuer decaieth, ioy neuer waxeth le≈ø≈øe, griefe is neuer felt, no vvailing euer heard, no≈øorrow euer≈øeene, and death feareth nor. This day thou ≈øhalt bee with mee in Paradi≈øe, where thou ≈øhalt go from the goulfe to the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ auen, from the battaile to the triumph, from the ≈øtreame to the ≈øpring, from darkene≈ø≈øe vnto light, from vva ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to vvealth, from a dreame vnto the truth, from faith to hope, from cold loue to perfect and ≈øeruent Charitie. This day thou ≈øhalt bee vvith mee in Paradi≈øe, vvhere thou ≈øhalt not know how to vveepe but laugh, not complain but bee ‚Ä¢ oifull, nor aske but g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, not bla≈øpheme but ble≈ø≈øe, not ≈øigh but ≈øing, not hate but loue, not mi≈ølike but prai≈øe, not die but liue. This day thou ≈øhalt bee ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th mee in Paradi≈øe, vvhere thy handes ≈øhall touch that which they de≈øiced, thy eies ≈øee that th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ they looked for, thy eares heare that which they loued and thy heart po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe that
which hee groned for. This day thou ≈øhalt bee vvith mee in Parach≈øe, vvhere thou ≈øhalt nor feare the deceits of the Diuell, the cockering of the fle≈øh, the vanitie of the world, the ambu≈øhes of thy enemies, the ≈øuddaine pa≈øsions vvhich fall out euery day, the nece≈øsity of euery hour, nor yet the anxiety and griefe of mind. This day thou ≈øhalt bee vvith mee in Paradi≈øe; vvhere there is no night which is darke, nor day which decrea≈øeth; no rough Winter, nor trouble≈øome Summer, no cold to freeze thee, no heat to di≈øtemper thee, no famine to weaken thee, no thir≈øt to make thee drie, no death to make thee afraid, nor life which ≈øhall haue any end. O my ≈øoule, O my heart, wilt thou not tell mee vvhat thou doe≈øt thinke vpon, or what thou doe≈øt contemplate on, ≈øeeing thou heare≈øt not this which is ≈øpoken: doe≈øt thou not marke vvho ≈øpeaketh it, nor vnto vvhom hee ≈øpeaketh it, nor doe≈øt thou regard vvhere it is ≈øpoken? Hee vvho ≈øpeaketh is the ≈øonne of God, hee vvith vvhom hee ≈øpeaketh is a theefe, that which he ≈øayth is that he promi≈øeth Paradi≈øe, the place vvhere hee ≈øpeaketh is the Mount of Caluary, the houre vvhen hee ≈øpeaketh is at the point of death, and tho≈øe before whome hee ≈øpeaketh is the vvhole Synagogue. Is it po≈øsible that an imba≈øie accompanied vvith the≈øe many circum≈øtances, ≈øhould not bee new and heard? For in Scripture there is nothing nece≈ø≈øary, that is not full „Äà‚óä„Äâ my≈øtery. Certainly this was a very new thing, ≈øeeing that Chri≈øt neuer had this word Paradi≈øe in his mouth not from the time of his incarnation, vntill the la≈øt houre that hee departed out of this world, and then hauing no other there but the theefe which bare him company at that time he promi≈øed him Paradi≈øe. O my ≈øoule, if thou wilt haue part in Paradi≈øe, behold vvhat a one the ≈øonne of God is vvho giueth it, and behold vvhat hee doth vnto the theefe vnto vvhom hee gaue it; and as thou didde≈øt ≈øee vvhat they doe, ≈øo doe thou force thy ≈øelfe to doe the like. O my ≈øoule, O my heart,
doe≈øt thou not ≈øee that our Lord who giueth Paradi≈øe is vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and that the theefe vnto whom heauen „Äà‚óä„Äâ giuen, is al≈øo vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, & therefore that the crucified doth nor giue the reward of Paradi≈øe but vnto another crucified. Saint Barnard vpon the Pa≈øsion ≈øayth, for mine owne part I thinke not my ≈øelfe deceiued, but I know that the naked giueth not his kingdome but vnto another naked, he who≈øe ioints are vnloo≈øed, vnto another who≈øe ioints are al≈øo loo≈øed one from an other, hee that is couered with bloud, vnto another couered with bloud al≈øo, and the crucified vnto another crucified. Thou that ≈øitte≈øt ≈øporting thy ≈øelfe what doe≈øt thou aske of him who ≈øuffereth on the cro≈ø≈øe? Thou that art clothed and reclothed, what doe≈øt thou craue of him who is bowelled vpon the cro≈ø≈øe? Thou that art faire and fat, what doe≈øt thou aske of him who is on the cro≈ø≈øe, one member rent from one another? Thou that art at freedome and liberty, what doe≈øt thou aske of him who is nailed and fa≈øtened vpon the cro≈ø≈øe? If thou wilt heare (≈øayth An≈øelmus) O my ≈øoule, Hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øo, Lift vp thy affections from the earth, let thy heart bee free from all pa≈øsions, let thy fle≈øh keepe watch and vvard ouer her inclinations, crucifie thy liberty on the cro≈ø≈øe, let bloud thy fancie of all pre≈øumptions, and bury thy affections that they may not appeare. If thou wilt a≈øcend as high as heauen, it is nece≈ø≈øary, that with the theefe thou take the cro≈ø≈øe for thy ladder to ≈øteale it: for otherwi≈øe although thou bee a companion with him in ≈øinning, yet for all that thou ≈øhalt not ≈øo be in raigning.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. Why the ≈øonne of God did not ≈øay vpon the cro≈øse vnto all men, Amen dico vobis, as hee did ≈øay vnto the theefe Amen dico tibi: aad how he was the fir≈øt martyr which died with Chri≈øt, and the fir≈øt Saint which he canonized.
div.p:
LOquetur ad eos in ira ≈øua, & in furore ≈øuo conturbabit eos, ≈øaid king Dauid in the ≈øecond P≈øalme: as if hee would ≈øay, when the great God of I≈øraell ≈øhall bee angry and troubled, hee will ≈øpeake vnto the wicked men with anger, and when hee ≈øhall trouble their iudgements, it ≈øhall bee with great anger. Our Lord doth threaten the wicked whome hee meaneth to puni≈øh, with two grieuous ≈øcourges, that is, that hee will ≈øpeake in anger to feare them, and trouble their iudgement that they ≈øhall not bee able to gue≈ø≈øe at any thing aright. If our Lord ≈øpeake vnto vs with anger, it may bee borne with, but if he trouble our iudgement, it is a thing much to be lamented: for in this wicked world, if he doe not lighten our ≈øteps to ≈øee where wee goe, wee ≈øhall fall downe vpon our face. Barnard crieth out and ≈øaith: What ≈øhall become of thee, O my ≈øoule, if he who ≈øhould lead me put mee out of the way, if hee who ≈øhould ≈øuccour me for≈øake mee, if hee who ≈øhould pardon me accu≈øe me, and he who ≈øhould quit mee condemne me, and he who ≈øhould giue mee ≈øight make mee blind? Saint Augu≈øtine De verbis Apostoli ≈øayth, When it is ≈øaid in Scripture, that God ≈øpeaketh vnto vs with anger, it is meant that he doth not ≈øpeake with mercy, and when it is ≈øaid that hee doth trouble vs with fury, it is to ≈øay that hee doth not lighten vs with his diuine grace, becau≈øe there cannot happen vnto vs greater hurt in this world, than for God to withdraw his hand from doing vs good. There is no anger in God, as there is in
man, with the which hee doth trouble him≈øelfe, nor furie to moue him withall; and when wee ≈øay that he is angry, it is becau≈øe he v≈øeth that puni≈øhment which in others is done with anger, and if we ≈øay that he is in fury, it is becau≈øe hee v≈øeth rigorous puni≈øhment towards vs, or el≈øe becau≈øe hee doth not puni≈øh at all in this world: for wherin can our Lord ≈øhew greater anger, than by not v≈øing his accu≈øtomed clemency? Our Lords wrath is appea≈øed when hee puni≈øheth pre≈øently after the offence committed, and he is very angry when hee deferreth the puni≈øhment vnto hell. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, That in the hou≈øe of God, not to puni≈øh is to puni≈øh, to di≈ø≈øemble is to bee angry with, not to ≈øpeake is to chide, to pardon is to threaten, to ≈øuffer is to let it putrifie, & to defer is to reuenge the more. Is there, thinke you, any greater puni≈øhment, than not to bee puni≈øhed in this world? When doth our Lord ≈øpeake vnto vs with anger, but when wee fall from his grace into ≈øinne by our fault? God ≈øpake with anger vnto our fir≈øt father, when hee ≈øaid vnto him thou ≈øhalt eat thy bread in the ≈øweat of thy face, as if hee would ≈øay, Becau≈øe thou ha≈øt fallen from my grace, and eaten of the apple which I did forbid thee to eat of, for a perpetuall puni≈øhment, thou ≈øhalt eat and drinke alwaies with care in thy mind, ≈øweat on thy face, and trauaile of thy body, in≈øomuch that at the be≈øt mor≈øell thou ≈øhalt giue ouer eating, and fall to ≈øighing. God ≈øpake al≈øo with anger vnto the murderer Cain, when hee ≈øaid vnto him, behold the bloud of thy brother Abel doth crie from the earth vnto mee: as if he would ≈øay Becau≈øe thou ha≈øt flaine thy brother Abel through malice and enuy, I cannot but doe iu≈øtice vpon thee, becau≈øe his bloud crieth aloud for it of me; and thy puni≈øhmeÃÑt ≈øhall be, that thou ≈øhalt wander to and fro all the daies of thy life, and thy head ≈øhal neuer cea≈øe ≈øhaking. God ≈øpake with anger vnto the great king Nabugodono≈øer wheÃÑ he ≈øaid, Eijciam te ab hominibus, as if he would ≈øay, Becau≈øe thou ha≈øt robbed my teÃÑples of their trea≈øures, and led away my people of the Iews captiue, thou ≈øhalt be throwne out froÃÑ the conuer≈øation of men, & ≈øhalt liue with bea≈øts on the mountaines, thou ≈øhalt eat hay like oxen, and bee clothed like wild ≈øauages with haire, vntill thou
doe≈øt acknowledge mee for to bee thy Lord, and thy ≈øelfe to bee a ≈øinner. God ≈øpake with anger vnto the great Prie≈øt Heli, when hee ≈øaid, Ego praecidam brachium tuum, &c, as if hee would ≈øay, Becau≈øe thou didde≈øt not puni≈øh thy children when they ≈øtole away the ≈øacrifices, and behaued them≈øelues di≈øhone≈øtly vvith women in the Tabernacle, I will take thy Prie≈øthood from thee, I will kill thy ≈øteward, and will make that no old man come into thy hou≈øe, in ≈øo much that thou ≈øhalt haue no children in thy ≈øtocke to inherite after thee, nor ancient men to coun≈øell thee. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, God v≈øed this kind of ≈øpeech vnto the Synagogue, but now ≈øpeaketh otherwi≈øe vnto the church, as is ea≈øily ≈øeene in the death of Chri≈øt, when hee ≈øaid vnto the theefe, Hodie mecum eris in Paradi≈øe. Wee doe not read that Chri≈øt did euer v≈øe this woord of anger ≈øo oft as hee hath done the woord of mercy, the which hee hath v≈øed often, as Per vi≈øcera mi≈øericordiae dei nostra, ≈øaid holy Zachary in his ≈øong: as if he would ≈øay, The ≈øonne of God came downe from the highe≈øt of heauen into the earth, moued thereunto by the bowels of his mercy. The holy Prophet dooth in this open a high my≈øtery vnto vs, whereby hee giueth vs to vnder≈øtand, how entirely our Lord dooth loue vs, ≈øeeing that hee doth vi≈øite vs vvith the bowels of his mercy. There bee many vvhich haue this word Mercy in their mouth, but not in their hands, and tho≈øe bee ≈øuch as are faire in ≈øpeech, but cruell in deedes, and ≈øuch v≈øe ≈øweet ≈øpeech to take men, and flattery to kill them. Others there bee which haue mercy in their handes, and nor in their tongues, the which are rough in words, but mild and gentle in deeds, and tho≈øe offer blowes but ≈øtrike not, they feare but kill not. Only our ≈øweet Ie≈øus hath mercy & pity in his mouth, ≈øeeing hee dooth ≈øo much commend it vnto vs, and in his deedes ≈øeeing hee dooth v≈øe it ≈øo much, and al≈øo in his bowels becau≈øe hee dooth loue vs ≈øo much. S. Barnard ≈øayth vnto this purpo≈øe, Our Lord would not place mercy in the eies, lea≈øt they ≈øhould make him blind, hee would not place it in the eares, for feare they ≈øhould make him deaffe, hee would not
place it in the handes, for feare it ≈øhould bee lo≈øt, hee would not put it to keepe in the body for feare lea≈øt it ≈øhould grow old, neither yet in the tongue for feare hee ≈øhould be dumbe: But our good Ie≈øus put it to keepe in his heart to be≈øtow it vpon tho≈øe whom hee loueth, and keepeth it within his bowels, becau≈øe that all that which is loued with the heart is kept within the heart. O good Ie≈øus, O the life of my ≈øoule, I be≈øeech thee by the bowels of thy mercy, that thou woulde≈øt take pity on my ≈øinfull ≈øoule, and ≈øeeing I haue no other Lord in my bowels but thy ≈øelfe, on whom woulde≈øt thou better be≈øtow the mercy which thou ha≈øt within thine, than vpon mee! Thou didde≈øt ≈øpeake with the bowels of thy mercy, vnto the good theefe, when thou wa≈øt not content onely to ≈øay: Amen, Truly I ≈øay, but thou didde≈øt adde tibi to thee, letting vs vnder≈øtand, that thou didde≈øt ≈øpeake vnto him alone, and promi≈øe Paradi≈øe vnto him alone and vnto no other. Vbertinus ≈øayth, That if when Chri≈øt ≈øaid Amen dico, hee had not added tibi, his mother who brought forth his humanity, and the other theefe which had lo≈øt his liberty, might haue thought that hee had ≈øpoken vnto them, I ≈øay if hee had not turned him≈øelfe vnto the good theefe, and ≈øaid tibi. What meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this, doe≈øt thou ≈øpeake vnto the theefe, and forget thy mother? Doe≈øt thou not ≈øpeake vnto thy mother who bare thee nine months in her bowels, and doe≈øt thou ≈øpeake vnto the theefe who had knowne thee but three houres? Doe≈øt thou promi≈øe pre≈øently Paradi≈øe vnto the theefe which ≈øpake but three words, and doe≈øt thou make no reckoning of thy mother, who bought thee with her teares? Doe≈øt thou be≈øtow thy precious bloud, fir≈øt vpon a theefe which knew not how to do any thing el≈øe but ≈øhed bloud by the high waies, before thou doe≈øt be≈øtow it vpon thy mother? Would it not bee rea≈øon to pay thy mother now with the bloud that runneth from thy ≈øide, for the milke which thou didde≈øt ≈øucke of her brea≈øt? What more heroicall and diuine exchange could there bee made in the world betwixt the ≈øonne and the mother, the
mother and the ≈øonne than bloud for milke, and milke for bloud? If thou doe≈øt looke O good Ie≈øus that ≈øhee ≈øhould ≈øpeake vnto thee as the theefe did, doe≈øt thou not ≈øee that for wearines ≈øhe cannot helpe thee, for griefe ≈øhe cannot looke vpon thee, for feare ≈øhee cannot comfort thee, and for being a≈øtonied ≈øhee cannot ≈øpeake vnto thee? I be≈øeech thee Per vi≈øcera mi≈øericordia, that thou woulde≈øt ≈øay, Amen dico vobis, as thou doe≈øt ≈øay, Amen dico tibi: For by that means thou ≈øhoulde≈øt comfort thy mother, ≈øatisfie the theefe, vanqui≈øhe Hell, helpe the world, and withall I ≈øhould haue hope to be pardoned. If thou doe≈øt die for all and not for one, why doe≈øt thou not ≈øay, Verely I ≈øay vnto you, as thou doe≈øt ≈øay, Truly I ≈øay vnto thee? O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, and loue of my ≈øoule, ≈øeeing that vpon my knees, and my face bathed in teares, I ≈øay vnto thee, Tibi ≈øoli peccaui, I haue ≈øinned vnto thee alone, doe not I de≈øerue to heare from thy mouth the≈øe words, Amen dico tibi, Truly I ≈øay vnto thee? An≈øelmus ≈øayth, That it was too timely to giue Paradi≈øe vnto his mother, and the other theefe had not de≈øerued it, and the great Centurion was not yet become a Chri≈øtian, and the Iewes were hardened in their hearts, and therefore it was not without cau≈øe that he ≈øaid vnto the theef, Amen dico tibi, and not Amen dico vobis. It was a great word which God ≈øpake vnto the fir≈øt man, that is, dominamini pi≈øcibus maris, & volatilibus cali: but that which hee ≈øpake vnto the good theefe was farre greater, becau≈øe it is far better to be companions vnto the Angels in heauen, than kings ouer bea≈øts vpon earth. It was a great word that God ≈øpake vnto Noe, that is, I found thee iu≈øt in my ≈øight: but this which hee ≈øpake vnto the theefe was far greater, becau≈øe it is better to be iu≈øt & receiue the reward of being iu≈øt, thaÃÑ to be ≈øimply iu≈øt. That was a fauourable ≈øpeech which hee v≈øed vnto king Dauid, I haue found a man according vnto my heart: but this which he ≈øpake vnto the good theefe was farre more fauourable, becau≈øe that Dauid was but neere vnto his heart, but the theefe was in his heart. And it did appear ea≈øily, that Dauid was but neer Gods heart, ≈øeeing hee did ≈øinne afterward, and it doth well appeare
that hee had the theefe within his heart, ≈øeeing hee ≈øuffered him to ≈øinne nor ≈øteale no more. That was a fauorable ≈øpeech which God v≈øed vnto Abraham, that is, Num celare potero qua ge≈øturus ≈øum Abraham. But that which was v≈øed towards the theefe was more fauourable, becau≈øe the greate≈øt ≈øecret that God reuealed vnto Abraham was, that the ≈øon of God ≈øhould come into the world, but hee did not onely reueale, but al≈øo ≈øhew this vnto the good theef. Chri≈øt did tru≈øt the good theef better thaÃÑ he did tru≈øt Abraham, becau≈øe he was the fir≈øt ≈øinner who ≈øaw the redemption of the world with his eies, & he was hee vpon whome the bloud of Chri≈øt was fir≈øt be≈øtowed. The precious bloud of the ≈øonne of God was then otherwi≈øe ≈øhed towards the theefe, who was vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, than towards his mother who was by the cro≈ø≈øe; becau≈øe it dropped downe vpon the garment of his ≈øorrowfull mother, but it went to the ≈øoule of the theefe to ≈øaue him, & therevpon the holy theef went immediately to Paradi≈øe, but his ≈øorrowful mother ≈øtaied weeping on the Mount of Caluary. O holy bloud, O heauenly blame, why doe≈øt thou take ≈øuch pity on the theefe, & doe≈øt deferre to giue thy mother the kingdome of heauen which thou doe≈øt giue pre≈øently vnto the theefe? Doe≈øt thou defer it to her who brought forth Chri≈øt, & take pity on him who bare him coÃÑpany on the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt augmeÃÑt tears in her, & dimini≈øh offences in him? It was a word of great fauor which hee did v≈øe vnto Mary Magdalen, that Remi≈øsa tibi peccata multa, Many ≈øins are forgiuen thee: but yet that was greater which he did v≈øe to the good theefe, becau≈øe hee v≈øed greater liberty with him thaÃÑ with hir: for if he loued her & pardoned her, he loued the theef like a friend, pardoned him like a Chri≈øtian, & rewarded him lika a iu≈øt man. Barnard ≈øaith vnto this purpo≈øe, That it is a ≈øigne of great loue to pardon, but a greater ≈øign to giue & pardon; becau≈øe that pardon is ≈øometime giueÃÑ by force, but a gift neuer coÃÑmeth but of free wil. OrigeÃÑ vpoÃÑ Mathew crieth out, O deepe my≈øtery, O diuine ≈øacrameÃÑt! who euer heard or ≈øaw the like vnto this, that is, betwixt the ≈øunne ri≈øing & the ≈øunne ≈øetting, the theef was condemned by Pilat,
≈øhamed by the criers, iu≈øticied by the hangmen, confe≈ø≈øed by his owne mouth, by Chri≈øt pardoned and al≈øo brought vnto Paradi≈øe. What meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? Who is able to reach vnto the rea≈øon why Abel vvith his innocency, Nee with his iu≈øtice, Abraham with his faith, Dauid with his charity, Moy≈øes with his meekene≈ø≈øe, I ‚Ä¢ b vvith his patience, Tobias with his frankne≈ø≈øe, Lazarus with his pouerty ≈øhould ≈øo long de≈øire to ≈øee Chri≈øt, and the theefe pre≈øently enioy him!

S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, That Chri≈øt receiued in a new kind of martyrdome all the torments vvhich were giuen the theefe as a naughty man from the houre and moment that he defended Chri≈øt, and confe≈ø≈øed with Chri≈øt: in≈øomuch that if he began to ≈øuffer like a theefe and a rouer, hee ended and died like a glorious martyr. This happy theefe was a very glorious martyr, ≈øeeing he ≈øuffered neere Chri≈øt, and with Chri≈øt, & where Chri≈øt ≈øuffered, and in the ≈øame manner that Chri≈øt ≈øuffered, and which is mo≈øt of all, hee was the fir≈øt martyr after Chri≈øts pa≈øsion, and the fir≈øt Saint which the ≈øonne of God did canonize after his death. S. Stouen was the fir≈øt martyr after Chri≈øts a≈øcention, but from Chri≈øts death vntill he a≈øcended into heauen there was no other Mattyr in the vvorld but the theefe, who≈øe conuer≈øion Chri≈øt cau≈øed, who≈øe teares hee accepted, who≈øe martyrdome hee approued, who≈øe pa≈øsion hee canonized, and who≈øe ≈øoule hee glorified. S. Augustine ≈øayth, O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules delight, con≈øidering that thou doe≈øt ≈øaue him who accu≈øeth his owne faults, and him who excu≈øeth thy innocency, the maintainer of thy credit, the confe≈ø≈øor of thy e≈ø≈øence, the companion of thy per≈øon, wilt thou not ≈øaue al≈øo this ≈øinfull ≈øoule of mine? For ≈øo great a battaile as thou ha≈øt won this day, for ≈øo great a victory as thou ha≈øt obtained, and al≈øo for ≈øo much bloud as hath i≈ø≈øued from thee, it is a ≈ømall prize to carry away with thee but one theef only, becau≈øe that by ≈øo much the greater the triumph is, by how many more pri≈øoners the triumpher is followed with all. And if it will not plea≈øe thee to take mee thither with thee, tarry thou here
with me O good Ie≈øus, for I de≈øire no other glory of thee in this mi≈øerable world, but that thou woulde≈øt let mee haue alwaies a good con≈øcience.
