cup endeth with our life, and our life with the la≈øt cup. This grape out of the which this precious wine came out of, was fir≈øt formed in Nazareth, borne in Bethelem, brought vp in Pale≈øtine, the vintage made on the Mount of Caluary, pre≈ø≈øed vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, where all the bloud which ran from the ≈øonne of God, was turned into wine for to drinke of in his catholicke church. It is a common Prouerbe v≈øed by one friend vnto another, that he will giue him all that he asketh, yea al≈øo his bloud; which offer wee ≈øee made, but fulfilled of none. Why doe≈øt thou offer thy friend that thou wilt ≈øhed thy bloud for him, if hee require it at thy hands, and afterwards if he aske thee any thing, thou turne≈øt thy face from him? The ≈øonne of God is none of the≈øe certainly, who ≈øaying and doing, gaue vs his body to eat, and his bloud to drinke, with the which we were redeemed, and by the which all the elect are ≈øaued. O good Ie≈øus, with what wine doe≈øt thou make the ≈øoule of thy be≈øt beloued drunke, but with the wine of thy precious bloud? Vidi mulierem ebriam, &c, I ≈øaw a woman drunke with the bloud of the ≈øaints, ≈øayth S. Iohn in his Apocalips chap. 17, as if he would ≈øay, Being in bani≈øhment in the I≈øle of Pathmos, among other vi≈øions which I ≈øaw there, I ≈øaw a woman which was drunk, but not with the wine, which was made of grapes, but with bloud which i≈ø≈øued out of vains. We ≈øee men drunke with wine euery day: for with this kind of drunkenne≈ø≈øe the good Patriarch Noe was drunke, & the couetous Nabal, Cornelius, and the prowd captain Holofernes. We ≈øee men drunke with anger al≈øo euery day, and with this kind of drunkenne≈ø≈øe king Iehu was drunke when hee ≈ølew in one day ≈øeuenty of king Achabs children, and when the captaine Ioab ≈ølew the captaine Abner. Wee ≈øee many drunke with enuy euery day, as Io≈øephs brethren when they ≈øold him for enuy, & the wicked Phara≈øies which put Chri≈øt to death for enuy. We ≈øee many drunke with loue, as Hemor was with Dia ‚Ä¢ Iacobs daughter, & Iacob with Rachel Labans daughter, and good king Dauid with his neighbour Ber≈øabe, and young Amon with Tamar his ≈øi≈øter. See then how ≈øome are drunke
with wine, ≈øome with vaine loue, ≈øome with anger, ≈øome with enuy, ≈øome vvith the wine of wicked Ambition, the vvhich are ≈øo farre out of their vvits and ≈øences, that for to better their honour a little, they care little to lo≈øe their credite, and al≈øo to damne their ≈øoules. Wee haue read of no drunkards, we haue ≈øeene no drunkards, nor yet heard of any drunkards, which haue made them≈øelues ≈øuch onely vvith pure bloud: for although barbarous men loue to ≈øhed bloud, yet they loue not to drinke it. The catholicke church hath no ‚Ä¢ ewell comparable vnto this, nor no greater riches in her holy ≈øhop than the bloud of the Saint of all Saints, and with the which ≈øhee healeth vs, vvhen vvee are ≈øicke, ≈øhee vpholdeth vs vvhen vvee fall, maketh vs cleane when wee finne, and iu≈øtifieth vs vvhen vvee die. The Apo≈øtles vvere drunke vvith this kind of drunkenne≈ø≈øe, when they ≈øaid, Wee mu≈øt rather obey God than man, and S. Peter was drunke in this ≈øort, when hee ≈øaid, Let vs make three Tabernacles in this place, and S. Paul when hee ≈øaid, I am not ready onely to be bound, but al≈øo to die, and S. Laurence when he ≈øaid, it is broiled inough, turne it now and eat of it. The more pure wine S. Steuen had drunke of, the more impatiently hee would haue felt the ≈øtones vvhich hee vvas ≈øtoned vvith, and S. Laurence the coales, and S. Bartholomew his ≈øword: but after they had entred into this holy ≈øeller, and drunke of this holy bloud, he ≈øuffered the ≈øtones as if they had been ro≈øes, and the coals as if they had been lillies. And therefore the bride had great rea≈øon to commend, and not to bee angry with her loue, for bringing her into this diuine ≈øeller, where ≈øhee ≈ølept without being awaked, and vvatched and yet ≈øate not vp all night, and entred into it without infamy, and liued with change, and did eat without paying for the ≈øhot. O good Ie≈øus, O the glory of my ≈øoule, wilt thou not let me goe into this holy tauerne, to drinke there if I lu≈øt one drop? Giue me leaue O good Ie≈øus, giue me leaue, becau≈øe I may know thy grace, and ta≈øt of thy precious bloud: for of all other drinkes in the world, the more I drinke of them, the greater thir≈øt I feele of all the drops
of bloud which thou ha≈øt ≈øhed mo≈øt freely, wilt thou not giue mee one to a≈ø≈øuage the thir≈øt of this ≈øinfull ≈øoule? It is al≈øo to bee noted, that the bride doth not only boa≈øt that her bridegroome did bring her to the tauerne to drinke, but did al≈øo teach her there the order which ≈øhe ≈øhold keep in louing, in ≈øo much that of a plain maid, he taught her to be a curious louer. This that the bride ≈øaid, Ordinauit in me charitatem, is worthy of great heed, ≈øeeing that by that the Scripture will let vs vnder≈øtand, that there is no loue firme and ≈øtable, if there be not an order in the maner of louing. If there be (≈øaith Ouid) an order in fi≈øhing, in fouling, fighting, ≈øhall there not be al≈øo in louing? And he ≈øaith further that all which fi≈øh loue not, nor all which hunt loue not, nor al which fight loue not: but al which loue, fi≈øh, hunt, and fight, becau≈øe he fi≈øheth well who fi≈øheth for others good wil, & he hunteth well who hunteth after others bowels, & fighteth wel who fighteth for anothers hart. S. Barnard ≈øaith, Take heed O my ≈øoule, take heed, that that do not happeÃÑ vnto thee, that happeneth in vain worldly loue, where often tho≈øe which loue chide, & tho≈øe di≈øagree which loue wel, not ≈øo much for any trea≈øoÃÑ which the one hath done to the other, as for want of order in louing. He who is not wi≈øe in his loue, is not my friend but my enemy, hee doth not loue me but diffame me. Origen vpon the≈øe words ≈øaith, That wheÃÑ there is no order in loue, al endeth in di≈øorder: for loue endeth in hatred, well-willing in dete≈øting, ≈øeruing in offending, prai≈øing into diffaming, ≈øpeaking into not hearing, care into forgetfulnes, diligeÃÑce into ≈ølouth, ofteÃÑ vi≈øiting into long ab≈øence, and ≈øighing into coÃÑplaining. S. Augu≈øt ≈øaith, O how well the bride ≈øaith, he hath ≈øet charity in me in good order, becau≈øe that by how much the more ferueÃÑt the zeale is, & the ≈øpirit vehemeÃÑt, and the loue ≈øodain, by ≈øo much the more it is coÃÑuenient, that he who loueth be wi≈øe, becau≈øe that the zeale may be printed in him, & the ≈øpirit moderated in him, & charity ≈øet in order. An≈øelmus ≈øaith al≈øo. O how well my good Ie≈øus hath ≈øet charity in good order in me, when he giueth me his holy grace to loue our Lord only for him≈øelf, & in him≈øelf, & by him≈øelf, &
giueth me al≈øo grace to loue my neighbor only for God, and in God, and becau≈øe he is the hou≈øe of God. Cyprian vpon the Creed ≈øayth, He cannot bee ≈øaid with truth, that Ordinauit in me charitatem, vvho loueth God not becau≈øe hee is good, but becau≈øe he ≈øhould giue him Paradi≈øe, and hee who for≈øaketh ≈øinne not becau≈øe it is naught, but for feare of hell, and if he loue his neighbour it is not becau≈øe hee is a Chri≈øtian, but becau≈øe hee is his friend, in ≈øo much that ≈øuch a one would neither loue God, nor his neighbor, but in hope to get ≈øome profite by it. This kind of loue the Deuill had in the beginning, vvho when he ≈øhould haue loued God in God, and for God, loued him≈øelfe in him≈øelfe, and for him≈øelfe; in≈øomuch that when he went about to climbe aboue him≈øelfe, he fell lower than him≈øelfe. Then God doth ordaine all things in charitie (≈øayth Remigius) when he ≈øetteth mee in the right way, and doth lighten me, and when my loue beginneth in him, continueth in him, and endeth in him: becau≈øe that cannot be called true loue, which is not grounded in God for God and by God. Irenaeus in an Homily ≈øaith, I will ≈øay theÃÑ with the bride that he hath ordained charity in me, when hee hath ≈øet ≈øuch order to my eies, that they ≈øee no vaine thing, and when hee ≈øtoppeth my ears that they heare no prophane things, & bridle my tongue that he ≈øpeak no ≈øuperfluous things, & ≈øhut vp my heart that hee de≈øire no forbidden thing. S. Gregory vpon Iob ≈øayth, That ≈øeeing there is nothing bad but that which our Lord hath forbiddeÃÑ, we dare ≈øay boldly, that no maÃÑ ought to de≈øire that which is not lawfull for him to get. S. Ierome to Pri≈øcilla ≈øaith, O vvith vvhat great truth, he may ≈øay with the bride, Ordinauit in me charitatem, vvho holdeth him≈øelfe for a ≈øinner, and others for iu≈øt, and hee who acknowledgeth a fault in him≈øelfe, and preacheth innocency in others! for otherwi≈øe it ≈øhould bee no Chri≈øtian charity, neither is it permitted in the law of God to loue goodne≈ø≈øe in my neighbour, and retaine naughtine≈ø≈øe in my ≈øelfe. To come at the la≈øt vnto our purpo≈øe, vvho in this life hath or ≈øhall enter ≈øo farre into the ≈øhop and ≈øtorehou≈øe of our Lord, as the mother of our Lord,
and that without ≈øpot? No man went ≈øo farre into the ≈øelle ‚Ä¢ of our Lord, nor no man drunke off ≈øo many wines as ≈øhe did, becau≈øe ≈øhee left no cup vnta≈øted of, neither was there any grace of the holy gho≈øt, vvhich ≈øhee was not repleni≈øhed with. Saint Ierom ‚Ä¢
≈øaith, That grace was giuen vnto all other Virgines, by weight and mea≈øure, but vnto the mother of God, it vvas not giuen by weight and mea≈øure, but heaped vp. The Angels in heauen, neither yet the holy men departed did not reach vnto ≈øo many ≈øecrets of God, as the mother of God did: becau≈øe it is to bee beleeued, that hee who did tru≈øt and credite her, would hide nothing from her. O mother of my redeemer, tell mee what coulde≈øt thou not doe, what had≈øt thou not, or what did≈øt thou not know when thou hadde≈øt my God in thy wombe? O Virgin ble≈ø≈øed and beloued of the Lord, thou mai≈øt well ≈øay, Dilectus meus mihi, & ego illi, ≈øeeing that if he hath placed thee in his eternall ≈øtorehou≈øe, thou didde≈øt put him in thy virgins wombe, where thou didde≈øt teach him to know what it was to bee a man, and hee taught thee what it was to bee the mother of God. As Iobs ≈øonnes went ≈øporting them≈øelues from hou≈øe to hou≈øe, ≈øo the mother of God and the ≈øonne of God went from ≈øeller to ≈øeller recreating them≈øelues, and the mother told the ≈øonne what hee ≈øhould haue in this world, and the ≈øon told the mother how they ≈øhold re≈øt in heaueÃÑ: the which ≈øpeeches the holy Orders of heaueÃÑ were not worthy to hear. O (≈øaith S. Barnard) how coÃÑtent the ≈øonne of God was of the wine≈øeller, vvhere his mother kept him: for vvithout compari≈øon he tooke more plea≈øure in the cha≈øt cogitations vvhich hee ≈øaw in his mothers wombe than in the milke which hee ≈øucked at her brea≈øts. An≈øelmus al≈øo ≈øaith, O what a thing it had been to ≈øee in that virgins wombe, the ≈øonnes life vvithin the mothers life, and the ≈øonnes body within the mothers body; and which is mo≈øt of all, though their bodies were ≈øeperated the one from the other at the time of his birth, yet their hearts vvere neuer ≈øeperated at all.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the fir≈øt and ≈øecond word which holie Simeon ≈øpake vnto our Lady: and how many fall from the law of Chri≈øt, without his fault.
div.p:
ECce hic po≈øitus est in ruinam, & re≈øurrectionem multorum in I≈ørael, Luke the ≈øecond chapter. The great Chronicler S. Luke ≈øaith, That the fir≈øt time that the mother of our Lord went abroad, the mother and Io≈øeph her and were in a maze, and wondered at that that Simeon ≈øaid of the child, and of that which the holy woman Anna Phanuel prophecied of him before them all. S. Cyprian vpon this place ≈øaith. If the great wonders which Simeon ≈øpake of Ie≈øus the child, did make the mother ioifull, ≈øo likewi≈øe they put the Angels in a wonder and maruell, becau≈øe they ≈øaid of him, that he ≈øhould be the light of the Gentiles, the glory of the Iewes, and the redeemer of all Nations. And Simeon not contented with that which he had ≈øaid, although he were very ioifull of that which he had ≈øeene, ≈øaid further that hee de≈øired not to liue any longer in this world but die pre≈øently, ≈øeeing that he had already ≈øeene with his eies that which his hart had ≈øo long time wi≈øhed for. It is a natural condition of the hart which hath long wi≈øhed for any thing, if at any time he hath that before his eies which he bought with many ≈øighes rather to de≈øire to die, than to be ≈øeperated from the ≈øame. Origen vpon Luke ≈øaith, That all the prai≈øes which Simeon ≈øpake of the ≈øonne of God, moued the mother to further loue: for if he ≈øaid that her ≈øonne was the light, ≈øhe knew that ≈øhee fir≈øt of all receiued light; if hee ≈øaid that her ≈øonne was honour, ≈øhe knew that hee had fir≈øt of all honoured her; in≈øomuch that the Virgin did already po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe all that which
was promi≈øed vnto others. S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth in a Sermon. That Simeon did very well ≈øay, that the child Ie≈øus was the light of the Gentiles, con≈øidering that he brought them vnto this holy faith; and that he was the glory of the Iews, ≈øeeing that there neuer came any one out of their ≈øtocke like vnto him, which is ea≈øily ≈øeene in that that for their further honour and fame, he made of a Synagogue a church, of a figure the truth, of Prophets Apo≈øtles, and of ≈øacrifices Sacraments. It is here to bee noted, that Simeon did not ≈øay ≈øimply, Thou ≈øhalt be the glory of the people of I≈ørael, but he added more and ≈øaid, thou ≈øhalt bee the glory of thy people of I≈ørael: the which he ≈øaid for the wicked and peruer≈øe of the Synagogue who although they were in the people of the Iewes, yet they were not of the people of I≈ørael. Abel, Seth, Noe, Sem, Abraham, Iacob, Io≈øeph, and Dauid, and all the Prophets were of the people of God, of all whome the ≈øonne of God was the honour and glory, ≈øeeing they beleeued in him, before that he came into the world, and were ≈øaued in the faith in which they liued. Cain and Cham, I≈ømael and E≈øau, Roboam and Athalia, Ie≈øabel, Annas & Cayphas did all dwel among the people of God, but they were not of the elect number of the people of God, becau≈øe that no man can bee called a neighbour of the children of God, but hee who beleeueth ≈øtedfa≈øtly in God. Let me (≈øaith Chry≈øostome) be of the number of the people of God, becau≈øe I may bee lightened with thy light, and glorified with thy glory, ≈øeeing that no man can be lightened but whome thou doe≈øt lighten, nor glorified, but whom thou doe≈øt glorifie. O how many there bee at this day in the church that be not of the church, and how many in religion, which bee not of the religion! Becau≈øe that our perfection and ≈øaluation doth not con≈øi≈øt in the names wee beare, nor in the places we haue, but in the good or euil liues which we lead. What doth it auaile me to bee called a Chri≈øtian, if I lead the life of a Pagan, or what doth it helpe me to be called a religious man if I liue like a worldling? As the ≈øonne of God came into the world not to the honour of tho≈øe which
were in the people, but of tho≈øe which were of the people, ≈øo thou my brother ≈øhoulde≈øt bee of the number of the religious, and not in the number: for otherwi≈øe thou ≈øhalt be as Saul was among the Prophets, and as Sathan vvas among≈øt the children of God. Origen ≈øayth, That when Simeon did deuide Chri≈øts gifts, he gaue light vnto the church: ≈øaying, Lumen ad reuelationem gentium, A light to the reuelation of the Gentiles: and he gaue the Iewes honour and glory, ≈øaying, Ad gloriam plebis tuae I≈ørael, which honour and glory they de≈øerued to lo≈øe when they went about by all the means they could to di≈øhonour the ≈øonne of God vpon the cro≈ø≈øe. The ≈øon of God gaue great honour and glory vnto the Synagogue, if the Iews could haue known it; and that is, in that he vouch≈øafed to di≈øcend of them, and bee borne among≈øt them, and in that hee would conuer≈øe among them, & preach among them, and do ≈øo many miracles to theÃÑ: but becau≈øe they knew him not, nor were not gratefull vnto him for it, all that glory and fame is turned into their di≈øhonor and infamy. The light which happened vnto the Gentiles, of which our holy mother the church is di≈øcended, was neuer taken from them, as the honour was taken from the ≈øorrowfull Iewes: for ≈øince that the holy Gho≈øt was ≈øent vpoÃÑ the holy Apo≈øtles, we neuer ≈øaw the church of God erre nor go a≈øtray. O what in≈øpeakable ioy the mother of God receaued at that time, wheÃÑ ≈øhe ≈øaw her precious ≈øon pre≈øented vnto the teÃÑple, offered to holy Simeon, prai≈øed of Anna the Prophete≈ø≈øe, & the v≈øuall offering offered vp for him! His mother reioiced much to haue him in her armes, to looke on him with her eies, to giue him ≈øuck with her brea≈øts, to offer ≈øacrifices for him, and to hear tho≈øe maruellous things which the old men ≈øpake of him. The Virgin then being very ioifull to heare Simeon, and much more of that which ≈øhee ≈øaw in her ≈øon, the good old Simeon turned him≈øelfe vnto our Lady, and did behold her ≈øaying, Ecce hic po≈øitus e≈øt in ruinam, as if hee would ≈øay, I haue often told thee, my daughter, that this my Lord and thy ≈øonne ≈øhould be the light of the Gentiles, and the glory of the Iewes: but now I tell thee al≈øo, that he ≈øhall be a ≈øtumbling blocke for many to fall by,
and a helpe for many to ri≈øe by againe, and hee ≈øhall bee as it were the white in a butt, which very many ≈øhall ≈øhoot at, but few at all hit. Dauid in his P≈øalme ≈øpake of Chri≈øt, that which vvas not vnlike vnto that that Simeon ≈øpake of Chri≈øt; that is, Cadent in retitulo eius omnes peceatores, as if hee would ≈øay, All the ≈øinners of the vvorld ≈øhal fall into his nets, my ≈øelfe excepted who am ≈øaued by ≈øpecial priuiledge. And it is much to bee noted, that the Prophet doth not ≈øay, that there is not any one con≈øtrained to fall into the net, but they will fall into it of their owne voluntary vvill, and entangle them≈øelues; and ≈øo vve may ≈øay that there is no fault of the mai≈øters net, if he making and arming his net to take fi≈øh, yet men will fall, into it. Neither did Simeon ≈øay, when he ≈øpake of Chri≈øt, that hee ≈øhould be the fall of many; but hee ≈øaid, Po≈øitus e≈øt in ruinam, Becau≈øe there is very great difference if I make you fall, although you vvould not fall, or to fall or ≈øtumble on me without my making you fall. Remigius vpon S. Luke ≈øaith, That notwith≈øtanding that Dauid doth ≈øay that all ≈øinners ≈øhal fall into his net, and that Simeon doth ≈øay that hee is put a ≈øtumbling blocke, I ≈øay that notwith≈øtanding all this, wee ≈øhould beare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt the ≈øonne of God, if wee ≈øhould ≈øay that hee hath beene the cau≈øe that any man hath fallen from the faith: for it cannot be ≈øpoken of the ≈øelfe ≈øame per≈øon, that he is come to redeeme vs, and that hee is the cau≈øe of our damnation. If I make a bridge ouer the which all men may goe ouer a ≈øtrong and a dangerous riuer, what fault am I in, if you ca≈øt your ≈øelfe downe from it into the riuer, ≈øeeing that I made it to the end that you might goe ouer ≈øafely, and you would needes throw your ≈øelues headlong into the vvater? When the ≈øunne doth ca≈øt his morning beames ouer all the world, what fault is he in, if through his heat and brightne≈ø≈øe the durt be hardened, and waxe made ≈øoft? If there be a ≈øtone put to pa≈ø≈øe ouer a quagmire or durtie place, and you fall and beray your ≈øelfe, what fault is the ≈øtone in, ≈øeeing that you could not ≈øtand vpon it? The ≈øonne of God was nothing el≈øe in this world, but a bridge for vs to pa≈ø≈øe ouer, and a
≈øunne with the which wee ≈øhould haue lightened our ≈øelues, and a ≈øtone vpon which we ≈øhould tread on, and a ≈øword vvith the which we ≈øhould haue defended our ≈øelues: and ≈øhall hee then be in any fault, if wee turne that into poy≈øon, which hee gaue vs for triacle? Ca≈øsiodorus vpon the P≈øalme ≈øaith, That all the ≈øinners of the earth ≈øhall fall into his net without any fault at al in the ≈øon of God: for ≈øeeing he came into the world, preached vnto the world, amended the world, taught the world, and redeemed the world, what fault is there in him, if a man damne him≈øelfe, con≈øidering that hee will not keepe the law which is giuen him by God? Chri≈øts holy law is not an occa≈øion for vs to fall, nor ≈øu≈øpicious to be beleeued in, nor ob≈øcure to bee vnder≈øtood, nor hard to bee kept, in ≈øo much that the danger is not in that which he commandeth vs, but in that that we doe di≈øobey his commandement. Then when old Simeon doth ≈øay of Ie≈øus the child, that hee is put for a ≈øtumbling blocke vnto many, he wil not ≈øay that the ≈øonne of God ≈øhould be a cau≈øe that many ≈øhould be ca≈øt away in his church, but that many would fal from his holy law, and e≈øpecially more perfideous Iewes than of others, who when they ≈øhould haue been blowers abroad of his holy doctrine, were hangmen of his holy life. Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, That all Gentiles haue fallen into his net vvhich know him not, all Iewes by not receauing him, all Tyrants by per≈øecuting his Martyrs, all Heretikes by fal≈øifieng ≈øcriptures, and all naughty men fall daily by bla≈øpheming his name. Of the ≈øame flowr that the Bee gathereth honny, the ≈øpider maketh poy≈øon: rattes bane to poy≈øon vvith, and triacle to help men vvith, is made of the ≈øame thing: the ro≈øe which ≈ømelleth ≈øweet, & the adder which biteth deadly, is often bred in the ≈øame bu≈øh, & of the ≈øame wood men do oft cut timber to couer a church, & to make a gibbet. Good iudgements by the≈øe examples may ea≈øily perceiue that which I haue ≈øaid to bee true vvithout further triall. What fault may bee imputed vnto the ≈øonne of God if of the ≈øame holy law the Iew gather poi≈øon, and the Chri≈øtian honny; the infidell gathereth
gall, and the faithfull man honny, the naughty man adders, the good man ro≈øes, the iu≈øt man findeth a church to ≈øaue him in, and the tyrant maketh a gallowes to damne him≈øelfe on. It is al≈øo to bee noted, that ≈øinners will fall not into a net, but they will fall into reticulo a ≈ømall net: for if we wil wel looke vnto it, Chri≈øt hath put before vs more rea≈øons to ≈øaue our ≈øelues, than the Deuill hath ≈øet occa≈øions before vs to damne vs. They are but ≈ømall nets which the deuill doth ≈øet before vs to fall into, but they are very great and large nets, which God putteth to catch vs; but yet alas if there fall tenne into Chri≈øts net, there fall tenne thou≈øand into the deuils ≈ømall net. Cyrillus vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, That according vnto the prophecy of Simeon and of Daniell, the ≈øonne of God came for the fall of the Babilonians, Egyptians, Chaldeans, Per≈øians and Medes, Greekes and tho≈øe of Pale≈øtine, becau≈øe the law of the Go≈øpell hath been preached and receiued in tho≈øe places. Chry≈øostom ≈øaith, That the ≈øon of God came to take fle≈øh for the fall of the Temple of Salomon, the city of Ieru≈øalem, the ≈øacrifices of Iuda, the ceremonies of I≈øraell, and of the old Mo≈øaicall law, and of the pride of all the Synagogue, which was all ended and gaue vp the gho≈øt with this word, Con≈øummatum e≈øt. The ≈øonne of God came into the world for the ouerthrow of all ≈øinnes: for if hee was, as hee vvas, the truth it ≈øelfe, hee was a great enemy of lies, and becau≈øe he highly loued charitie he hated cruelty, and becau≈øe hee highly commended humilitie, hee per≈øecuted enuy, vvhich vvas the cau≈øe that no man did euer reprehend vice more ≈øharplier than hee, nor no man did euer extoll vertue like vnto him. The ≈øonne of God came into the vvorld, to the vtter ruine of the famous city of Hieru≈øalem, ≈øeeing there vvas not one tower in the citie vvhich vvas not throwne downe, no vvall which was not broken, no hou≈øe vvhich vvas not barnt, no Temple vvhich vvas not beaten to the ground, no trea≈øurie vvhich vvas not robbed, nor orchard vvhich vvas not ≈øpoiled, no Virgine vvhich was not violated, no woman which was not forced, no man
which was not either ≈ølaine or taken captiue. The ≈øonne of God came into the world for the ouerthrow of the Synagogue, ≈øeeing he left them no kingdome whither to goe vnto, no citie where to dwel, no king to rule them, no Patriarke to honour, no Prophet to giue them coun≈øell, no army to defend them, no captain to fight for them. The ≈øoune of God came into the world in ruinam the ouerthrow of the Phari≈øies and Sadduces, coÃÑ≈øidering that he took away their hypocri≈øie from theÃÑ by which they preuailed, their authority by which they commanded, their doctrine with which they deceaued, their couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe with the which they robbed, and their Symony with the which they made them≈øelues rich.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of the third word which old Simeon ≈øpake vnto the Virgine in the Temple: and of three authorities touching this purpo≈øe.
div.p:
IN re≈øurrectionem multorum in I≈ørael, & in ≈øignum cui contradicetur, ≈øaid holy Simeon vnto the ble≈ø≈øed Virgine, that day when ≈øhe pre≈øented the child Ie≈øus in the Temple: as if hee would ≈øay, I haue told thee my daughter Mary, how this thy ≈øon and my Lord ≈øhall bee a ≈øtumbling blocke to many, and an occa≈øion that many which are fallen ≈øhall ri≈øe againe, and many which goe a≈øtray conuerted, and he ≈øhal be a marke and a ≈øigne which ≈øhall bee ≈øpoken again≈øt by many. Origen ≈øaith, That it doth wel appear, that holy Simeon ≈øpake by the mouth of the holy Gho≈øt, when hee ≈øaid that the ≈øon of God was come into the world, not only for all naughty & wicked men to ≈øtumble at, but al≈øo becau≈øe that al goodne≈ø≈øe
and good men ≈øhould bee rai≈øed vp by him, becau≈øe it is the dutie of a good Phi≈øitian not only to purge the humor which offendeth, but al≈øo to ≈øtrengthen it. What fruit ≈øhould we receiue by his comming into the world, if he ≈øhould only throw downe the wicked, and not rai≈øe vp the good? WheÃÑ our Lord ≈øaith by Ieremy, Con≈øolabor me de inimicis meis, he would vvith a farre better will forgiue vs, rather thaÃÑ puni≈øh vs: but becau≈øe all that is in God, is God him≈øelfe, hee cannot doe le≈ø≈øe than v≈øe his iu≈øtice, giuing notwith≈øtanding alwaies place vnto his mercy. When he ≈øayth, Woe bee vnto mee, vvoe be vnto me, I mu≈øt reuenge mee of my enemies, what can bee ≈øpoken with a more tender heart, or vvhat iu≈øtice can bee done vvith greater mercy, ≈øeeing that hee fir≈øt weepeth for the ≈øinner before he puni≈øh the ≈øinne, and fir≈øt ≈øhed many tears, before he ≈øhew di≈øcipline vpoÃÑ the malefactors? In the iudgemeÃÑt ≈øeat of vvorldly iudges, they puni≈øh ≈øinnes without iu≈øtice, & then mocke at the ≈øinners: but in the hou≈øe of God they fir≈øt vveepe for the ≈øinners, and then they puni≈øh the ≈øinne, becau≈øe there is nothing more ≈øtrange to God than reuenge, nor nothing more gratefull vnto him than mercy. Perditio tua ex te I≈ørael, ex me autem ≈øaluatio, ≈øaid God by the Prophet o≈øee: as if hee vvould ≈øay, O vvhat paines I take with thee, O I≈ørael! for if thou lo≈øe thy way, I put thee into it againe, if thou ≈øtumble I hold thee vp, if thou ≈øee not I direct thee, if thou fall I lift thee vp, if thou defile thy ≈øelfe I make thee cleane, if thou bee blind I giue thee light, if thou doubt I coun≈øell thee. This ≈øpeech of the Prophet is vvorthy to bee noted and al≈øo vvept, and to bee bewailed vvith many teares, ≈øeeing that hee telleth vs and admoni≈øheth vs by it, how little vvee are able to doe of our ≈øelues, how little wee are worth, how little wee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, how little vvee know, ≈øeeing that it is in our owne power to fall, but vvee are not able to ri≈øe vvithout the helpe of God. Thou ≈øaie≈øt very vvell O great Simeon, that the ≈øoune of God is come In re≈øurrectionem multorum:
for after wee are fallen and defiled, if hee doe not giue vs his hand, who is able to lift vs from the ground? What had become of the people of I≈øraell when they were captiue in Egypt, if our Lord had not deliuered them from thence vvith his mighty hand? What would haue become of good King Dauid when he ≈ølue innocent Vrias, and committed adultery with his wife Ber≈øabee, if God had not giuen him coun≈øell by the mouth of the Prophet Nathan, and lightened his heart? What had become of king Ezechias when our Lord coÃÑdemned him to death, and that vnto a ≈øuddain death, if our Lord had not vi≈øited him by the hands of the Prophet E≈øay, and accepted his tears? What had become of the Apo≈øtle Saint Peter, when hee denied Chri≈øt three times, if our Lord when he was tied to a pillar had not looked vpon him, and prouoked him to teares? What had become of S. Paul when hee went to the city of Dama≈øco to apprehend all ≈øuch which called vpon the name of Chri≈øt, if our Lord had not ≈øpoken vnto him by the way, and of Saul would not haue made him Paul, and of a per≈øecutor of Chri≈øt had not made him a preacher of the Go≈øpell? What would become of thee and me, and of all the ≈øinners of the world, if good Ie≈øus ≈øhould not giue vs light, becau≈øe wee ≈øhould not ≈øtumble, and giue vs his hand to ri≈øe againe? S. Barnard to this purpo≈øe ≈øaith, It may be ≈øaid better of me than of any, O my good Ie≈øus, That thy perdition is of thy ≈øelfe I≈ørael, and thy ≈øaluation of mee. For if I hit aright in any thing, it is onely through thy grace, and if I erre it is through my owne malice: and therefore my owne ≈øinne is able to make me fall, but to ri≈øe againe I haue need of thy mercy. An≈øelmus in his Meditations ≈øaith, What greater weakene≈ø≈øe of maine can there bee, or what greater mi≈øhap, than that if I defile my ≈øelfe, I cannot make my ≈øelfe clean againe, if I be ≈øicke I cannot make my ≈øelfe whole againe, if I ray my ≈øelfe I cannot wa≈øh my ≈øelfe againe, yea and if I ≈øinne I cannot repent of my ≈øelfe; if our Lord doe not fir≈øt giue mee his light, as hee did the good theefe on the cro≈ø≈øe, and if hee doe not fir≈øt looke vpon mee, as hee did looke vpon S. Peter,
from the piller. Heale mee good Lord, and I ≈øhall bee made whole, Saue me and I ≈øhall be ≈øaued, ≈øaith king Dauid, as if he would ≈øay, No man is able to heale mee O my good Lord, if thou doe it not, nor no man is able to ≈øaue me, if thou do≈øt not ≈øaue me, O my redeemer, becau≈øe no maÃÑ knoweth my wound but thou, nor my felicity con≈øi≈øteth in none but in thee. Ca≈øsiodorus vpon the P≈øalme ≈øaith, That we ≈øhould note how that the Prophet doth fir≈øt aske of our Lord that he would make him whole before hee ≈øaue him: for if our Lord doe not fir≈øt wa≈øh the fault from vs, it is in vaine to thinke that hee ≈øhould giue vs his glory. S. Ba≈øil vpon this place, Sana me domine ≈øayth, That if thou doe not goe vvith me, nor I with thee, the more I goe about to heale my ≈øelfe, the ≈øicker I grow, when I think to goe forward I turne backward, vvhen I imagine that I goe ≈øtreight, then I find my ≈øelfe mo≈øt out of the way, when I labour to goe mo≈øt cleane and neat, I find my ≈øelfe then mo≈øt of all vncleane: and that vvhich is the wor≈øt of all is, that I know not vvherein I doe be≈øt, nor cannot gue≈ø≈øe vvhen I doe ami≈ø≈øe. An≈øelmus vpon the ≈øame place, Heale mee good Lord, and I ≈øhall bee vvhole, ≈øaith: Who but thou O my ≈øweet Ie≈øus, can cure mee, and giue mee any temedy, to ≈øuch hidden wounds, and ≈øuch manife≈øt offences, to faults of ≈øuch quality as mine are, to ≈øuch carele≈ø≈øe care, ≈øuch vncleane thoughts, ≈øuch wicked crimes, ≈øuch damnable bowels, and ≈øuch incon≈øiderate ≈øpeeches? Heale mee good Lord, and I ≈øhall bee made vvhole: for it auaileth me very little, to v≈øe helpe and not bee made vvhole, to fight and kill my ≈øelfe, to ≈øwimme & drowne my ≈øelfe, „Äà‚óä„Äâ to ≈øtudie and not profit, to take a iourney and neuer come to the end, to aske and neuer haue any thing giuen mee, to ≈øerue and neuer de≈øerue any thing. Heale me good Lord, & I ≈øhall be made vvhole of the pride which ouerthroweth mee, of the enuy vvhich rotteth in me, of the anger vvhich vva≈øteth mee, of the gluttony vvhich di≈øquieteth me, of ≈øloth vvhich dulleth me, of couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe vvhich maketh me cruell, and of all ≈øen≈øuality vvhich neuer leaueth me. Heale me Lord, & I ≈øhall bee free, from the world vvhich
deceiueth me, from the deuill which tempteth me, from the fle≈øh which pampereth mee, from my enemies which per≈øecute me, from my friends which importune me, from my euill thoughts which torment me, and from malicious men vvhich diffame me. Heale me good Lord, and I ≈øhall bee healed, not of a ≈øcab but of a ≈øin, not of blindnes but of filthines, not of the members of my body, but of my thoughts, not of my body but wickednes, not of ≈øwollen feet, but of di≈øordinate appetites. Heale me Lord, and I ≈øhall be healed, of my vnruly de≈øires, of the wantonne≈ø≈øe of my eies, of my ouermuch ≈øpeaking, of the coldnes of my workes, of the ≈øtealth of my hands, of the malice of my thoughts, and of the worme of my couetou≈ønes. O good Ie≈øus, my only tru≈øt, heale my ≈øoule, becau≈øe I haue offended thee in thought, I haue offeÃÑded thee in delight, I haue offended thee in omi≈øsion. I haue offended thee in con≈øent, & I haue offended thee in deed, & therefore vnto thee my fault I confe≈ø≈øe, and therfore good Ie≈øus take pity vpon me. Sprinckle me with i≈øope, & I ≈øhal be made clean, Lauabis me & ≈øuper niueÃÑ dealbabor ≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt, as if hee would ≈øay, When it ≈øhal plea≈øe thee, & wheÃÑ thy ≈øon ≈øhal come into the world, thou ≈øhalt ≈øprinckle me with holy I≈øope, & wa≈øh me with thy precious haÃÑd, by which ≈øprinckling and wa≈øhing I ≈øhall not only bee clean and without fault, but I ≈øhal remain whiter than all the ≈ønow of the highe≈øt mountains. Who is he (≈øaith Aymon) who coÃÑmandeth vs to wa≈øh our ≈øelues, but only the eternal father, & who is he who wa≈øheth vs, but only his precious ≈øon, & with what doth he wa≈øh vs, but with his holy bloud, and who bee tho≈øe which he doth wa≈øh, but ≈øuch as are of his holy church? O glorious I≈øope, and happy wa≈øhing place, in the which the Angels if they had licen≈øe to come down, and the heauenly powers if they dur≈øt, would wa≈øh them≈øelues in? There were many riuers in Samaria, but Naaman was healed in none but in the riuer of Iordan: there were many ce≈øterns & pooles in Ieru≈øalem, but the di≈øea≈øed were helped only in the Probatica. There were many fountaines in Pale≈øtine, but Dauid could neuer ≈ølackeÃÑ his thir≈øt, but in the fountain of Bethelem.
Wee will inferre of all this, that there hath been very much bloud ≈øhed in the world, but none could euer make vs cleane, but only the bloud of Chri≈øt. All water wa≈øheth not, euery fi≈øh poole maketh not cleane, euery fountaine filleth not, neither doth all bloud make whole: a bea≈øts bloud hurteth, mans bloud defileth, but the bloud of Chri≈øt doth make whole, doth wa≈øh, doth fill, and content. If wee looke curiou≈øly into the Scripture, and e≈øpecially into the Apocalips, thou ≈øhalt find it to bee true, that S. Iohn did not ≈øee any Saint of heauen wa≈øh him≈øelfe in the water which did run in the riuer, but onely in the bloud which did run from the lambe. O of what great vertue this holy bloud is of, ≈øeeing that for to wa≈øh vs and bath vs in it we need no great quantity, but a very ≈ømal deale! which is ea≈øily ≈øeene in that the Prophet doth not ask, that he would make him a pole of bloud to wa≈øh him in, but that it would plea≈øe him to ≈øprinckle him with a little I≈øope dipped in it. A very little is ≈øufficient, O my good Ie≈øus, and it ≈øufficeth to be ≈øprinckled with it, and not wa≈øhed, ≈øeeing that one drop of thy precious bloud, ≈øufficeth to fil thy glory with many, and to people thy church with many good men. It is much to be noted, that he v≈øeth this word Sprinckle me with I≈øope, and I ≈øhall be made cleane: for by ca≈øting water with I≈øope, one drop falleth here, and another there, this man is wet with it, and that man is drie: euen ≈øo it falleth out in the be≈øtowing of Chri≈øts holy bloud: for although it were ≈øhed for all the world, yet notwith≈øtanding it was not emploied vpon all men. The bloud of the ≈øonne of God is ≈øprinkled with I≈øope, ≈øeeing that the Chri≈øtian is ≈øaued with it, and the Pagan condemned, the in≈øt is made cleane, & the naughty man continueth vncleane, the vertuous man is bedewed with it, and the vicious man remaineth dry, and that which is more to be lamented, ≈øome doe there wa≈øh away their offences, & ≈øome haue not one drop of it. The Prie≈øt in the Leuiticall law did clen≈øe ≈øuch as were infected with a lepro≈øie if they came vnto him, and if they brought tho≈øe things which the law pre≈øcribed, and if they were ≈øprinckled ≈øeuen times with the
bloud of the bird: but if they refu≈øed to doe any of the≈øe things, the Prie≈øt was in no fault, and their vncleanne≈ø≈øe vvas imputed vnto them≈øelues. The High prie≈øt the ≈øonne of God, did die for all men, and ≈øhed his bloud for all men: but if thou Infidell or Heretike, wilt not enter into the Catholicke church, if thou ≈øinner or naughty man wilt at the time, when it is de≈øtributed turne thy face from it, what fault is in Chri≈øt if his precious bloud worke no vertue in thee? O how happy that ≈øoule is, vpon whom there falleth one drop not of the bloud which the prie≈øt ≈øprinckled, but this precious bloud which the ≈øon of God ≈øheddeth! for being wa≈øhed in ≈øo deep a pool≈øhe wil go beyond the ≈ønow in whitenes, & exceed the ≈øon in clearnes. It is time now for vs to come vnto our fir≈øt purpo≈øe, & apply all this vnto that which holy Simeon ≈øpake of Chri≈øt. When Simeon ≈øayth of Chri≈øt, that he is put to helpe vp many, and when the Prophet ≈øaith O I≈øraell thy perdition commeth of thy ≈øelfe, and thy ≈øaluation of mee, and when Dauid ≈øaith, Heale me Lord and I ≈øhal be made whole, and on the other ≈øide Sprinckle me Lord with I≈øope, and I ≈øhal bee made cleane, hee letteth vs vnder≈øtand plainly, that if wee bee not made cleane by the mighty hand of the ≈øon of God, no man el≈øe hath the power to doe it. Wherefore ≈øayth Irenaeus did the redeemer of the world come into the world, but becau≈øe wickedne≈ø≈øe and wicked men ≈øhould fall downe, and becau≈øe vertue and vertuous men ≈øhould ri≈øe? By his comming into the world, idolatry fell downe, and the true faith was ≈øet vp; Hypocri≈øie was beaten downe, and truth lifted vp; tyranny fel downe, and iu≈øtice lifted vp; malice fell downe, and innocency lifted vp; reuengement fell downe, and mercy lifted vp. If thou do≈øt come into the world (≈øaith Vbertinus) becau≈øe that all naughtine≈ø≈øe and naughty men ≈øhould fall, who in all the world is ≈øo wicked as my ≈øelfe, or who fallen ≈øo low? What greater fal than to be fallen from thy grace? Come theÃÑ ≈øweet Ie≈øus, come to the lifting vp of my vertues, and come to the fall of my vices: for if thou doe not make my vices fir≈øt to fal, my vertues can neuer ri≈øe. Note (≈øaith Remigius) that Simeon
fir≈øt ≈øaid of Chri≈øt, that hee was come in ruinam, before hee ≈øaid that he was in re≈øurrectionem, becau≈øe it is impo≈øsible that humility ≈øhould ri≈øe in mee before that my pride bee ouerthrowne, neither can patience ri≈øe in me, if my anger fir≈øt fall not, neither my ab≈øtinence ri≈øe in me, before my gluttony fall, and therefore I mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈øuffer my ≈øelfe to die, and theÃÑ I ≈øhall ri≈øe againe with Chri≈øt, Chry≈øostome ≈øaith, That in the hou≈øe of God, there is neuer no ri≈øing of vertues, if there be not fir≈øt in her a fall of vices: wherof it followeth, that if thou wilt haue whole≈øome vertues to grow in thee, thou mu≈øt fir≈øt of nece≈øsity pull all ≈øuperfluous pa≈øsions out of thee. S. Barnard ≈øayth, That the ≈øonne of God came into the world for the fall & ri≈øing of many, ≈øeeing that pride fell with his humility, couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe with his pouerty, anger with his patience, the fle≈øh with his cha≈øtity, gluttony with his ab≈øtinence, and al≈øo ignorance fell with his doctrine. Chry≈øo≈øt. ≈øaith, That the ≈øonne of God came into the world, in ruinam & re≈øurrectioneÃÑ, wheÃÑ the prowd maÃÑ becoÃÑmeth humble, the couetous maÃÑ pitiful, the furious man meeke, the carnall man cha≈øt, the gluttonous ab≈øtinent, and the cold man deuout, in ≈øo much that there is in the ≈øame man a fall of vices, and a ri≈øing of vertues.

div.head: CHAP. V. How Salomon did inherite the kingdome of his father Dauids plea≈øures: and how Chri≈øt did inherite the kingdome of trauails.
div.p:
IN tuam ip≈øius animam doloris gladius pertran≈øibit, Luke 2. The≈øe be the wordes which Simeon v≈øed to the holy Virgin, as if hee would ≈øay, I haue told thee Mary what ≈øhal happen vnto this thy ≈øonne: I will tell thee now what ≈øhall fall vnto thy ≈øelfe, that is, that the ≈øame ≈øword ≈øhall end his life, and pierce thy ≈øoule. What thing more ≈øtrange, or what
more grieuous newes can be told a holy and vertuous womaÃÑ, than to tell her from God that her ≈øonnes ≈øword ≈øhal part her heart in two? Abraham tooke a knife for his ≈øonne I≈øaac, but hee killed him not. Balaam met with an Angell which had a knife, but he ≈øtroke him not: Io≈øue ≈øaw another Angell with a drawne ≈øword, but he did not ≈øet vpon him, and Salamon tooke a knife to cut a child in two, but in the end he did not part him in two. What meaneth this mother of God, what meaneth this? Abrahams knife did not hurt his ≈øonne, and thy ≈øonnes ≈øword woundeth thy hart. Balaam did not hurt his A≈ø≈øe with his ≈øword, and doth not thy ≈øonnes ≈øword fauour thy heart? Io≈øue his ≈øword doth offer and threaten but hurteth not, and doth thy ≈øonnes ≈øword wound but not threaten? Had Salamons knife pitie on the ≈øtrumpets child, and had not thy ≈øons knife pitie on his owne mother? Hee placed a Cherubin before Paradi≈øe, and a firie ≈øword to keepe the way of the tree, ≈øaith the holy Scripture in the fourth chapter of Gene≈øis. After that our fir≈øt Parents had tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed the commaundement of God, our Lord put there pre≈øently a firie ≈øword to keepe Paradi≈øe, becau≈øe no man ≈øhould enter in, to eat of the tree which was forbidden. S. Augu≈øtine vpon this place ≈øaith, That there was neither ≈øword nor knife in the hou≈øe of God, before that man knew what ≈øinne was, but at the ≈øame houre that he fell from grace to ≈øinne, our Lord put both ≈øword and gibbet in his hou≈øe. Before that man ≈øinned, there was no dore to ≈øhut in the hou≈øe of god, nor Cherubin to watchit, nor ≈øword to defend it: but immediately after man ≈øinned, the gate was ≈øhut, and the key was lo≈øt. What is the ≈øword which we ≈øpeak of here, but onely the ≈øonne of God in whom wee beleeue? The ≈øonne of God is called a ≈øword in the Apocalips, and a ≈øword vvhich cutteth on both ≈øides, becau≈øe hee alone and no other puni≈øheth the bad and defendeth the good, killeth tho≈øe which are aliue, and rai≈øeth tho≈øe vvhich are dead. It vvas in the hands of the Cherubine to let vs enter in or not, into the terre≈øtriall Paradi≈øe: and it is in the
hands of the ≈øonne of God, vvhether wee ≈øhal enter into the cele≈øtiall Paradi≈øe or not. Wee haue a greater and a better watch in our Paradi≈øe, than Adam had in his, becau≈øe that the Cherubin did but ≈øtand at the gate, but the ≈øonne of God is the gate it ≈øelfe. When he ≈øaid I am the gate, what did hee mean el≈øe, but that he was the key with the which we ≈øhould open, he was the gate through the which we ≈øhould enter in, and he the guide which ≈øhould direct vs, and he the Paradi≈øe which we ≈øhould enioy. It is al≈øo to bee noted that the ≈øword with the which the Cherubin kept Paradi≈øe, was neither of ≈øiluer nor gold, nor yron, but was of pure fire, which is a new and an vnu≈øuall thing which no man would beleeue if it were not in Scripture. It is a thing often tried for yron to haue fire in it, and for yron to bee in fyre: but that a fyre ≈øhould bee called a ≈øword, is neuer read but of that ≈øword which kept Paradi≈øe. To apply theÃÑ the figure vnto the thing figured, al meÃÑ are as it vvere yron ouerca≈øt with ru≈øt, that is, fallen into original ≈øinne, or actuall great or ≈ømall, the ≈øword of the liuing God excepted, in vvhoÃÑ there was neuer found any ≈øin, nor the ru≈øt of any fault, but was alwaies like vnto a ≈øword of fire, made in the forge of the holy Gho≈øt. What was the ≈øword vvhich kept Paradi≈øe but onely Ie≈øus vvhich ≈øuffered on the cro≈ø≈øe? When thou didde≈øt ≈øay. O my ≈øweet Ie≈øus, I come to put fire on the earth, art not thou happily all fire, ≈øeeing that thou do≈øt come to put all the vvorld on fire? O how much better the ≈øword is vvhich the church hath, than that vvhich the ≈øynagogue v≈øed! Becau≈øe her ≈øword did let no man enter into Paradi≈øe, but ours doth open the gates vnto vs. What ≈øhall I ≈øay more, but that her ≈øword vvas of fire, vvhich did burn, & ours is but of Loue vvhich giueth comfort? O ≈øword of holy loue, my ≈øweet Ie≈øus, hovv happy I ≈øhould be if I vvere dead vvith thy knife, becau≈øe that that killing ≈øhould bee a ri≈øing from death, that bowelling of me a letting of bloud, my end a nevv beginning, and my dying a liuing. Our Lords mercy is ≈øuch, that he ≈øaith not, Ego mortifico, but he ≈øaith I doe giue life: nor
he ≈øaith not I will ≈øtrike, but hee ≈øaith I will make whole, in ≈øo much, that if he kill vs it is to rai≈øe vs to life againe and if he ‚Ä¢ wound vs it is to make vs whole againe. Then our Lord doth mortifie vs, when he killeth our inclinations in vs, and theÃÑ we are ≈øtroken with his hand, wheÃÑ we are puni≈øhed with his great mercy, and like a good ≈øurgeon hee neuer ≈øeareth the quicke fle≈øh, but the rotten member which infecteth the re≈øt. And becau≈øe Simeon ≈øaith, that the dolours and the ≈øword of her ≈øonne went through the mothers heart, it is expedient for vs to ≈øtay ≈øomewhat in declaring the greifes which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered, becau≈øe that thereby we ≈øhall know them, which he imparted vnto his mother. Cum e≈ø≈øet Dauid in ≈øpelumcaÃÑ Obdollam, conuenernat ad eum omnes qui erant in angu≈øtia, & oppre≈øsi aere alieno, ≈øaith the Scripture 1. Reg. 22. as if he would ≈øay, When king Dauid hid him≈øelfe in the den of Obdolla, there came vnto him all ≈øuch as were bani≈øhed by the order of iu≈øtice, or fled for debts; of all which ≈øorrowfull Dauid was the Prince and captaine, for of all the afflicted he was the mo≈øt afflicted. This is a high figure, and deepe my≈øtery, worthy of great con≈øideration, becau≈øe in it is figured very much by Dauid, and namely the great griefes which Chri≈øt endured. O that it were farre better for me poor ≈øinner which write this, that my ≈øoule did ta≈øt of them, than for my fingers to write them! Becau≈øe that the doctrine which the ≈øonne of God teacheth is of that quality, that although it bee very good to preach it, yet it is farre better to follow it. There were many figures of Chri≈øt in the old law, but none ≈øo liuely as Dauid was: in proof whereof, they did not call Chri≈øt the ≈øonne of Adam, nor the ≈øonne of Moy≈øes, but the ≈øonne of Dauid, partly becau≈øe hee was of his princely Tribe, partly becau≈øe he was not ≈øo liuely figured in any as in him. God ≈øaid vnto Dauid by ≈øpecial priuiledge, I haue found a maÃÑ according vnto my own hart, & the Father ≈øaid of Chri≈øt only, this is my welbeloued ≈øonne, in ≈øo much, that that loue which God bare in times pa≈øt vnto Dauid, was figured afterward in the loue which hee bare to his
deere beloued ≈øonne. Dauid was al≈øo a figure of the ≈øonne of God in that, that as Dauid was per≈øecuted by his mai≈øter the king of I≈ørael without cau≈øe, euen ≈øo Chri≈øt vvas per≈øecuted of the I≈øraelites, not hauing offended them at all: in≈øomuch that if Saul did per≈øecute Dauid of pure enuy, the Iewes did per≈øecute Chri≈øt of pure malice. Dauid was al≈øo a figure of Chri≈øt in the denne of Obdollam, where if Chri≈øt had been, Dauid had neuer beene the captaine and prince of all the afflicted, and bani≈øhed men, but the ≈øon of God had been their ringleader, as hauing endured more griefe and vexation than all they, becau≈øe he did exceed all heatheni≈øh gods in power, and all the Angels in merite, and all the Martyrs in ≈øuffering. King Dauid vvas badly handeled by his brothers defied and chalenged by Golias, bani≈øhed by Saul, skoffed at by Michol, ≈øtoned by Simei, per≈øecuted by Ab≈øalon, robbed by the Amalechites, vvarred by the Phili≈øtims, watched by the Ceilitas, and iniuried by the Ammonites. But notwith≈øtanding, that king Dauid ≈øuffered many griefes and troubles, yet they may bee numbred. But what ≈øhall we ≈øay of tho≈øe which good Ie≈øus endured, which were ≈øo many in number, that no man is able to reckon them, nor yet at all follow them? Being a verified matter that king Dauid had tenne kindes of people which did per≈øecute him, & that he had twelue tribes or kingdomes which did obey him, it is now to be knowne who was his ≈øon vvho inherited his kingdomes, and vvho was his ≈øonne who ≈øucceeded him in all vexations and griefes. Salomon ≈øonne vnto Ber≈øabee and Dauid, ≈øucceeded him in the inheritance of his twelue kingdomes, vvith vvhome his father left him no warres to maintaine, no enemies to re≈øi≈øt him, no ≈øucceeds to contend with him, no factions to pacifie, nor debts to pay. What did not the good old man leaue his ≈øonne, con≈øidering that he left him al his kingdomes in peace, and great trea≈øures laid vp for him? But vvhen forgetfull Salomon ≈øaw that his father, had left him great ≈øtore of vvealth and no vvarres, hee be≈øtowed all that in vices vvhich hee ≈øhould haue be≈øtowed
again≈øt his enemies. King Salomon inherited kingdomes and vices, vices and kingdomes, ≈øeeing hee had three≈øcore Queenes crowned to his wiues, and ≈øeueÃÑ hundred concubines. Salomon did inherite vices and all other daintine≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing he him≈øelfe doth commend him≈øelfe, that his eies coueted nothing which was denied him, nor his heart de≈øired nothing which he did not obtaine; in ≈øo much that he did not liue according vnto that which rea≈øon did pre≈øcribe him, but according vnto that the fle≈øh did lead him vnto. Hee vva≈øted his fathers trea≈øures, which hee did inherite, in building ≈øtately hou≈øes to dwell in, and ≈øtrong ca≈øtels to retire him≈øelfe vnto, large orchards to recreate him≈øelfe in, great pooles to fi≈øh in, cunning mu≈øitians to ≈øing to him, ≈øweet in≈øtruments to play vpon, and nimble young maids to daunce in his hall. King Salomon did inherite great peace and concord from his father Dauid, con≈øidering that in fifty years vvhich hee raigned, hee vvas neuer challenged by any king, hee neuer ≈øaw enemie in his kingdome, hee neuer placed army in field, there neuer vvent banner out of his pallace, neuer captaine had pay of him, no drum euer brake his ≈øleepe. Salomon did inherite great riches from his father, ≈øeeing that he couered the Temples with gold, he inherited great power, ≈øeeing that all the kings of the earth did ≈øerue him, he inherited great wi≈øedome, ≈øeeing he neuer erred in matter of iu≈øtice, hee inherited eÃÑxceeding great knowledge, ≈øeeing that men came to ≈øee him as a miracle. Salomon did inherite from his father more delights and dainties than kingdomes, ≈øeeing it is not read, that euer he was ≈øick, that euer he endured any nece≈øsitie, that any enmity did di≈øquiet him, that any per≈øecution did afflict him, that any grief did trouble him, that any king dur≈øt offend him, that any kingdome rebelled again≈øt him, or ≈øubiect di≈øobeied him. To conclude, wee ≈øay that Dauids ≈øucce≈ø≈øor in his kingdomes was his ≈øonne Salomon, vvhome by excellency they called the rich, the wi≈øe, and quiet, becau≈øe that in all his life time, he neuer put hand to ≈øword, nor neuer ≈øhed mans bloud. Now
that wee haue told you who ≈øucceeded Dauid in his delights and kingdomes, it is al≈øo needful that we proue vnto you who was his ≈øonne which ≈øucceeded him in his iniuries and greifes: for ≈øeeing wee haue reioiced with the pro≈øperous, it is rea≈øon that we ≈øuffer ≈øomewhat with the afflicted. Dauid was twi≈øe made a Prince, once in the city of Ebron, where hee was annointed king of the twelue Tribes, & ≈øecondly in the denne of Obdollam where hee was made chiefe of tho≈øe which were in tribulation: and from hence it groweth, that when the time came when hee ≈øhould deuide the≈øe two kingdomes betwixt his two ≈øonnes, he gaue Salomon his rich and flouri≈øhing kingdome, and Ie≈øus Chri≈øt his poore afflicted one. Our Lord will giue him his father Dauids ≈øeat, ≈øaid the Angel vnto the Virgine, as if he would ≈øay, Thou art to vnder≈øtand O high Virgine, that the pledge and dowrie which the eternall father will giue his eternall ≈øonne, ≈øhall bee the ≈øeat of his old father Dauid, the ≈øeat I ≈øay, not of iudgemeÃÑt, but to be iudged, nor the ≈øeat of commanding, but of obeying, not of weale but of woe, not of honour but of pouerty, not of plea≈øure but of paine. O how the Iudaical natioÃÑ was deceiued in thinking that Chri≈øts kingdome ≈øhould bee a temporall kingdome, and that hee ≈øhould deliuer them out of their captiuity! For ≈øeeing that he inherited but one ≈øeat of his father Dauid, how was it po≈øsible that he ≈øhould deliuer the ≈øynagogue by force of armes? If the Me≈øsias promi≈øed in the old law, ≈øhould bee Dauids ≈øonne, and rich and mighty, why did they not receaue king Salomon for their Me≈øsias, ≈øeeing that hee inherited from his father armes to deliuer them, power to defend them, trea≈øure to enrich them, and great wi≈ødome to gouerne them? How is it po≈øsible that the ≈øonne of God who inherited nothing of Dauid but a poore ≈øeat, ≈øhould make warre vnto any, and deliuer them from ≈øeruitude? The ≈øonne of God ≈øucceeded his father Dauid in the ≈øeat of obedience, which hee had with tho≈øe who obeied him, in the ≈øeat of charity which hee had with the di≈øea≈øed, in the ≈øeat of mercy which he had with the
afflicted, the ≈øeat of humilitie which he had with the prowd, and the ≈øeat of patience which hee had among the ouertrauelled. Chri≈øt did onely inherite the principality of the afflicted and comfortle≈ø≈øe, and was content withall with it, ≈øeeing that he was bani≈øhed by Herod, ≈øold by Iuda ‚Ä¢ , denied by Saint Peter, accu≈øed of the Iewes, and ≈øentence giuen on him by Pilate, and mocked of his ≈øeruants. If all the troubles & vexations of the world ≈øhould bee put on one heape, and tho≈øe which Chri≈øt alone ≈øuffered on another, all men would giue him the prime, and to none of the re≈øt, becau≈øe that of all other men bee they neuer ≈øo holy, there is no man that feeleth more than his owne griefe and paine; but the ≈øonne of God did feele his owne, and tho≈øe of his elect. When the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith that the ≈øonne of God, Factus e≈øt omnia nobis, is made all things for vs, what el≈øe doth hee ≈øay, but that hee doth ≈øuffer with him who ≈øuffereth, weepeth with him who weepeth, & dieth with him who dieth? Becau≈øe he is the father of vs al, he feeleth all our griefes, and becau≈øe we co≈øt him much he is grieued that wee ≈øuffer much; and therefore being a Prince and a captaine of the afflicted, he doth helpe vs to weep our greif ‚Ä¢ , and remedy the exce≈ø≈øe. For he ≈øaith in his Sermon, Ve
‚Ä¢ ite and m ‚Ä¢ omnes qui laboratis & ‚Ä¢ nerati e≈øtis, & ego reficiam vas: as if he would ≈øay, Come vnto me al you which are laden and I will vnlade you, and come vnto ‚Ä¢ ee all you which labour, and I will comfort you. O glorious captaine, and happy proclamation which Chri≈øt maketh throughout the world, ≈øeeing that hee bindeth him≈øelfe to vnload tho≈øe which are burdened, comfort tho≈øe wich are afflicted, turne to tho≈øe which are per≈øecuted, refre≈øh tho≈øe which are hungry, lift vp tho≈øe which are troden downe, and b ‚Ä¢ e a father of all which be father le≈ø≈øe. If ≈øuch as were in tribulation and nece≈øsity, and fled vnto king Dauid were ≈øad and ≈øorrowfull, ≈øad and ≈øorrowfull they returned again, if they were bani≈øhed, bani≈øhed they returned againe, if they were in debt, indebted they returned againe, and if they were di≈øcontent, di≈øcontented they
returned, in ≈øo much that good king Dauid could neither coÃÑ fort them, nor releeue them. He vvho is per≈øecuted with Ie≈øus cannot for a certaine ≈øay ≈øo, nor hee who is bani≈øhed vvith our bani≈øhed Lord, becau≈øe none coÃÑmeth vnto him comfortle≈ø≈øe who returneth not comforted, nor no man commeth vnto him indebted, who≈øe debt he paieth nor. O this, this is a happy calling, Come you vnto me al you which are laden, ≈øeeing that the ≈øon of God doth let vs vnder≈øtand thereby, that he hath a ≈øchoole for the ignorant, an exchange for the needy, an ho≈øpitall for the di≈øea≈øed, a tower for ≈øuch as are fled, a pantry for the hungry, and a ≈øafe conduct for the bani≈øhed. S. Barnard ≈øayth, The God of all creatures, and the Lord of the heauenly gouernements is the true Phi≈øitian of my griefes & ≈øorrowes, becau≈øe all other men haue power only to hear theÃÑ, but no skill to remedy them. Irenaeus ≈øayth, If I be a cold, he who wi≈øheth me vvel, can bring me to the fire, if I be hungry, giue mee a little bread, if I bee thir≈øty giue mee a cup of vvater, if I bee naked giue mee a ≈øhirt, but if my ≈øoule bee ≈øad and comfortle≈ø≈øe, vvhat comfort can he giue me, but only bid me haue patience? S. Augu≈øtine to the Hermites ≈øaith, Hee who will comfort the ≈øoule, ought to be in the ≈øoule, and he vvho will remedy the heart ≈øhould dwell in the heart, but becau≈øe no man hath his abiding there but onely the ≈øonne of the liuing God, of him and of no other our remedy and ea≈øe mu≈øt proceed. Cicero in an Epi≈øtle ≈øaith, O how hee is deceiued which ≈øaith and thinketh, that the griefes of the heart are lenified and ea≈øed by ≈øeeing faire meddowes, vvalking by fre≈øh riuers, eating dainty meats, hearing plea≈øant mu≈øicke? For all the≈øe things can but ≈øu≈øpend my griefes for an houre or two, but they cannot root them out, and much le≈ø≈øe remedy them. Tell mee I pray thee, how can the in≈øtruments vvhich found in my eares, remedy my griefes vvhich are inclo≈øed in my bowels? How can the plea≈øures and ioies which my eies receiue in beholding meddowes and forre≈øts, giue ea≈øe to my paines vvhich lie in my bones? What doth dainty faire
mitigate the anxiety of mind? What comfort can an a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ licted mind take, if they giue him no other remedy but bid him haue patience? What careth my ≈øorrowfull heart for my friends words, if when they are gone from mee, my ≈øorrowes remaine? Seeing that all the plea≈øures and ioies of the vvorld reach no further than vnto the fiue ≈øences, it is a certaine thing, that as plea≈øures are ≈øeated in tho≈øe ≈øences, ≈øo likewi≈øe griefes are rooted in the heart. Plato ≈øayth, That griefes and delights are great enemies, and that they dwell farre one from another, and therevpon it happeneth, that there is no delight and plea≈øure which ent ‚Ä¢ reth into the inward part of the heart, nor no griefe which commeth out further than the heart. Ca≈øsiodorus ≈øaith, That as we ≈øeeke for an expert Pilote to ≈øaile with, and a skilfull Phi≈øition to cure vs with, ≈øo for to comfort our griefes and heauine≈ø≈øe, we ≈øhould ≈øeeke out cunning men in them, becau≈øe that no man can take more pitty on another, than he who hath been wearied & iniuried by ≈øuffering. WheÃÑ the ≈øon of God came into the world, hee came not to learne to read, nor to write, nor to ≈øwim, nor to preach: for all this is but dro≈ø≈øe and mire in compari≈øon of that which hee knew before hee came into the world. That which hee came hither to learne by experience, was that which hee knew before onely by ≈øcience, that is, to accu≈øtome him≈øelfe to ≈øuffer corporall pa≈øsions and vexations, becau≈øe he might haue the more compa≈øsion vpon the afflicted. Chry≈øo≈øtome ≈øayth, That the ≈øonne of God came to trafficke in this vvorld like vnto a rich & wealthy merchant, that is, by carrying to heauen that which there wanted, & by bringing from thence that which wanted here: for there ther wanted meÃÑ, & therfore took ≈øome thither with him, & here there wanted merits, & therefore left ≈øtore behind him. The ≈øon of God came into the world, becau≈øe there wanted men in heauen, to enioy his glory, and becau≈øe we wanted grace to de≈øerue it, & ≈øo we gaue him humane fle≈øh to ≈øuffer with, and he gaue vs his holy grace wherby wee might merit. O holy and glorious exchange, ≈øeeing that he changed with vs, quietne≈ø≈øe for trauell, innocency for
infamy, ≈øpirit for fle≈øh, life for death, and glory for pain ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Now that „Äà‚óä„Äâ haue declared how the ≈øonne of God came into the world to learne vexations and troubles, the better to haue compa≈øsion on them in others, it is conuenient that wee declare now, how that the mother of God did inherite her ≈øons ≈øword of ≈øorrows, as hee did inherite his father Dauids ≈øeat of griefes and trauails.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the ≈øword of griefe which killed the ≈øonne of God, and went through his ble≈ø≈øed mother.
div.p:
ETtuam ip≈øius animam doloris gladius pertran≈øibit, ≈øaid Simeon to the Virgine in the ≈øecond chapter of S. Luke: as if he would ≈øay, The ≈øword of the pa≈øsion of this thy ≈øonne, ≈øhall bee ≈øo cruell, O high Virgine, that at one ≈øtroke it ≈øhal take his life from him, & pierce thy ≈øoule. The like prophecy was neuer heard of in times pa≈øt, nor read in any booke, nor any ≈øo ≈øorrowfull a prophecie euer ≈øpoken of, as this was which the Virgine newly deliuered heareth this day, which the good old Simeon vttereth vnto her: for what ≈øaith the prophecy, but that at one time, in the ≈øelfe≈øame day, in the ≈øame hour, and with the ≈øelfe≈øame ≈øword, they will doe iu≈øtice vpon the ≈øonnes fle≈øh, and vpon the mothers bowels? There are found ≈øwords commonly to cut off a theefes eare, to behead a murderer, to quarter a traitor, to cut a bla≈øphemous tongue, but a ≈øword that can pierce the ≈øoule, and mind, there is no other to bee found, but this ≈øword of Chri≈øts. The ≈øword which Cain killed his brother with, the ≈øword which Moy≈øes killed the Egyptian with, and the ≈øword which king Dauid ≈ølew the Phili≈øtime with, and Helias ≈øword with the which he ≈ølew the Idolaters, and Phi
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es ≈øword with the which he ≈ølew the Ammonites, did all
wound the body, but alas Simeons ≈øword bru≈øed the fle≈øh of the ≈øonne, and did not fauor the bowels of the mother. Vbertinus noteth, that Simeon doth not ≈øay, that a ≈øword of ≈øorrow ≈øhall ≈øtrike thee, but Pertran≈øibit, that is, that that ≈øword vvill not bee content onely to wound, but as it were with a mortall thru≈øt ≈øhall peirce thy ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoule, from one ≈øide vnto the other. And then that deadly ≈øword peirced her from one ≈øide vnto the other, when all the ≈øorrowes and griefes which the ≈øonnes fle≈øh endured did load the heart of the dolorous mother with griefe. The wordes of Auegratia plena which the Angel v≈øed, and tho≈øe which Simeon ≈øpake, doloris gladius pertran≈øibit went togither, and were of equall force: for euen as the Virgines ≈øoule was ≈øo full of grace, that ≈øhe could receiue no more, ≈øo her heart was ≈øo full of griefe, that ≈øhee could endure no more. There could not a greater griefe be ≈øpoken of than that which the mother was to ≈øuffer, which was vttered in ≈øaying that a ≈øword ≈øhould pierce her heart from one ≈øide vnto the other: and indeed as old Simeon had prophecied, ≈øo it came to pa≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe there was neuer Martyr which ≈øuffered more torment in the martyring of his body, than the ble≈ø≈øed Virgine ≈øuffered in ≈øeeing her ≈øon martyred. And this ≈øpeech tuam ip≈øius animam, is very much to bee noted: for although other holy men were grieued at the death of Chri≈øt, yet none ≈øo much as his holy mother: for in other men the griefe was as it were a blow, but in the Virgins heart a thru≈øt. div.head: ‚ùß Here beginneth the fourth word which the ≈øonne of God ≈øpake vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe when hee complained vpon his father, ≈øaying: Deus meus, deus meus, vt quid me dereliqui≈øti? That is to ≈øay, My God, my God, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me?
CHAP. I. How Chri≈øt in this ≈øpeech more than in all the re≈øt ≈øeemeth to change his ≈øtile of ≈øpeaking.
div.p:
HEloij beloij lamazabathani? Hoc e≈øt: deus, deus meus, quare me dereliqui≈øti? This is the fourth word which the redeemer of the vvorld ≈øpake on the altar of the Cro≈ø≈øe: vvhich ≈øpeech is no le≈ø≈øe dreadfull than pittifull, nor pittifull than dreadfull: and it is as if hee would ≈øay, My God, my God, My father, my father, what haue I done irreuerently again≈øt thee, that thou ≈øhould≈øt for≈øake me in ≈øo narrow a ≈øtrait as this is? There are offered vnto vs in this diuine ≈øpeech high my≈øteries and deepe ≈øecrets to entreat of, whereof wee can giue no rea≈øon if vvee bee not fauoured vvith Gods diuine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance:
whom with teares wee doe humbly be≈øeech, that it would plea≈øe him to lighten vs vvith his grace, and ≈øuccour vs vvith his helpe and aid. The rea≈øon is to bee knowne vvhy the ≈øonne of God did change his manner of ≈øpeaking rather in this ≈øpeech, than in all the others which hee v≈øed, as the Euangeli≈øts do record it, ≈øaying, Heloij, heloij, lamazabathani. Was it becau≈øe hee ≈øhould be vnder≈øtood of all men, ≈øeeing that hee vvas crucified for all men? It is al≈øo to bee knowne vvhy hee doth repeat this vvord God twi≈øe, ≈øaying My God, my God, as though God vvere deaffe in hearing him. It is al≈øo to bee vveighed vvhy hee called him God, and not Father, ≈øeeing hee vvho complained vvas the ≈øonne, and hee vnto whom hee complained was his Father. It is al≈øo to bee maruelled at, that ≈øeeing hee did not cal him father, but God, why he did adde this vvord My, ≈øaying, My God, my God, as though his Father were his God onely, and not the God of all others. It is al≈øo very much to be noted, why hee doth rather complaine that his Father had for≈øaken him, than put him to death: ≈øeeing that hee knew very well that Pilate was not of power to take away his life from him, if his eternall father had not giuen him licen≈øe to doe it? And although hee did complaine of his Father, vvhy did hee not ≈øay, My Father why doe≈øt thou for≈øake mee, but My God vvhy ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee, making account of that vvhich hee hath ≈øuffered, and not of that vvhich then hee did ≈øuffer? Although all the≈øe thinges are ea≈øily rehear≈øed, yet they are not ea≈øie to bee expounded: but becau≈øe they are diuine ≈øecrets, and done betwixt diuine per≈øons onely they pa≈ø≈øe mans capacity, yea the Angels vnder≈øtanding. To come then vnto the my≈øteries, it is fir≈øt to bee ≈øeene vvho complaineth, and vnto whome hee complaineth, vvhereof hee complaineth, and vvhere hee complaineth, and before whome hee complaineth, and vvith vvhat wordes hee complaineth. Hee vvho complaineth is Chri≈øt: hee vnto whome hee complaineth
is his Father: that whereof hee complaineth is becau≈øe hee had for≈øaken him: the place where, was on the cro≈ø≈øe: and hee complained before his mother with the≈øe words, My God, my God, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee. The≈øe are mo≈øt pittifull words to heare, and tender to prouoke vs to weepe: for if vve con≈øider how the ≈øonne of God ≈øpake them being nailed vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, his body naked, and his enemies round about him, and that vpon a dunghill, what heart is there that would not breake to thinke on it? Seeing wee know, beleeue, and confe≈ø≈øe, that Chri≈øt was true God, and that his father was al≈øo God, and both were but one God, how can it enter into mans vnder≈øtanding that one who is God ≈øhould complaine vpon him who is al≈øo God? If between one God and another there bee complaints, is it any great matter if men ≈øometimes fall at ods? Wee ≈øee it fall out daily, that the ≈øonne complaineth of the Father, and one friend vpon another, yea & one man vpon him≈øelfe, but that Chri≈øt who is God ≈øhould complaine vpon his father who is God, it is a thing neuer heard of before, nor humane weakene≈ø≈øe is not able to conceiue it. For ≈øeeing no man coÃÑplaineth on another but for ≈øome wrong done vnto him, what grieuance could the eternall Father haue done vnto his ≈øonne whom he loued ≈øo well? For ≈øeeing we know that Chri≈øt is the ≈øonne of God and his onely beloued ≈øonne, and with whome God hath left all his trea≈øures in keeping, how is it po≈øsible that God ≈øhould haue dealt hardly with him, ≈øeeing that he de≈øerued it not, neither his father de≈øired it? According vnto that which we haue ≈øaid our rea≈øon is good which way ≈øo euer wee doe wind our ≈øelues: for if wee ≈øay that the father did that vnto his ≈øonne, which hee ought not, wee can neither ≈øay it nor affirme it: then if we ≈øay that the ≈øonne complained vvithout occa≈øion, we dare not pre≈øume ≈øo to ≈øay, in ≈øo much that we mu≈øt deliuer the father of all fault, and allow the ≈øonnes complaint to bee good. To vnfold our ≈øelues of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, it is to bee noted that Chri≈øt ≈øaid by the Prophet, Abinfantia creuit mecum mi≈øeratio,
Becau≈øe he began to ≈øuffer from his childhood, and yet hee neuer complained vntill the time came that hee ≈øhould die. Leo vpon the Pa≈øsion of our Lord ≈øayth, That the noble mens children of this world crie our pre≈øently when they ≈øee any trouble come vpon them, and aske for ≈øuccour: but neuer any man ≈øaw our Lord open his mouth to complaine, vntill a quarter of an houre before they would pull his heart out of his body. S. Chri≈øo≈øtome vpon Luke crieth out & ≈øayth. What newes is this O redeemer of the vvorld, vvhat news is this? When they lay hands on thee, thou take≈øt it quietly, vvhen they bla≈øpheme thee thou make≈øt as though thou vvere deaffe, vvhen they vvhip thee thou doe≈øt hold thy tongue, whon they doe crucifie thee thou doe≈øt ≈øuffer, vvhen they kil thee thou doe≈øt di≈ø≈øemble: and yet doe≈øt thou open thy mind euen as thou art yeelding vp thy gho≈øt? Why doe≈øt thou complaine vpon thy father alone, hauing as thou ha≈øt ≈øo many enemies which haue offended thee, that is, Iudas who ≈øold thee, Peter which did denie thee, Pilate which g ‚Ä¢ ue ≈øentence on thee, Herod vvho ≈øcorned thee, and all the people vvhich put thee to death? Demo≈øthenes the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, That a man ought neuer begin that vvhich hee cannot bring to an end, nor ≈øay that vvhich he cannot proue, nor aske that which cannot be giuen him, nor loue that vvhich cannot be gotten, no ‚Ä¢ contend with him vvhome hee cannot reuenge, nor yet complaine of that which cannot bee remedied. Seneca in an Epi≈øtle ≈øayth, That no man ≈øhould ≈øay that hee complaineth, vnle≈ø≈øe he thinke that he ≈øhall haue remedy again≈øt his complaint: for otherwi≈øe he doth him≈øelfe hurt in complaining, & ≈øtirreth him vnto anger of vvhom he complaineth. Tell mee then O good Ie≈øus, what remedy h ‚Ä¢ ≈øt thou for thy coÃÑplaint, ≈øeeing that thou ha≈øt not halfe an houre to liue? Doe≈øt thou make thy reque≈øt vnto thy Father when thy ≈øoule is euen now departing from thy body? Who euer heard of, or euer ≈øaw the like, that the end of thy vexitions to bee the beginning of thy complaint: in thirty and three yeares that thou
didde≈øt conuer≈øe with vs, thou didde≈øt neuer braule with any, thou didde≈øt neuer iniury any man, nor neuer complaine of any man, and now being at the very point of death doe≈øt thou complaine only vpon thy Father? O what great my≈øtery and deep ≈øecret this thy complaint doth couer, ≈øeeing that in ≈øuch a time, and ≈øuch a narrow ≈øtrait, thou doe≈øt complaine, when all other are woont to pardon their iniuries and reconcile their enmities, and aske pardon for their offences? Pauper & in laboribus a iuuentute mea: exaltatus autem, & humiliatus & conturbatus: the≈øe wordes the Prophet Dauid ≈øayth in the per≈øon of Chri≈øt P≈øalme 88, as if hee would ≈øay, I haue been brought vp in trauails and pouerty from my childhood, and then I was lifted vp, and then made low, and afterward troubled and per≈øecuted. Thy fears haue made me afraid; and thy angers haue broken vpon me, and thy trauails haue compa≈ø≈øed me about, and they haue compa≈ø≈øed me about altogether as it were a vie, and ouer and aboue all this, thou ha≈øt ≈øet my friend farre from me, and ha≈øt ≈øeperated him who was my neighbour farre from me. If wee doe deepely looke into the complaints which the ≈øonne maketh in this place again≈øt his eternall Father, wee ≈øhall find that they are many in number, great in quality, and in re≈øpect incomparable, cruell in their kind, and vnworthy of him vnto whom they are ≈øent. Ba≈øil vpon the P≈øalme ≈øayth, That ≈øpeaking like a man, it ≈øeemeth in humane rea≈øon that the innocency of good Ie≈øus did not de≈øerue, neither could it be in the clemency of his good Father, that the diuine pittie ≈øhould load vpon weake humanity, ≈øo many torments together, and heape ≈øo many troubles & vexations. The fir≈øt complaint which the ≈øonne made again≈øt his Father is, Quod pauper & in laboribus ≈øum a iuuentute mea, to wit, That he brought him vp poorely from his childhood, he made him liue with hunger, and go like a bani≈øhed man from place to place. Cicero ≈øayth in an Epi≈øtle, When a young man doth ≈øuffer trauails, and endure pouerty, if he bee not a foole and an idiot, he beareth it with a great courage, by remembring
that his Father was poore in the ≈øame manner: but if his Father had been rich, and now hee him≈øelfe poore, this is ≈øuch a misfortune, that there is no patience able to endure it, nor heart which can di≈ø≈øemble it. What ≈øhould the ≈øonne of God thinke when hee remembreth what a rich Father hee had, and that hee did ≈øpend all his trea≈øure vpon other mens children, and ≈øuffer him to goe poorely, naked and a hungred, and ≈øcorned by all men? The Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaking of Gods riches ≈øayth, Deus qui dines es in omnibus, as if hee would ≈øay, Thou art the God only which doth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe great riches, and art the Lord which hath many lord≈øhips, becau≈øe thou ≈øhoulde≈øt want nothing thy ≈øelfe, and to impart much of the ouerplus vnto others. Gloria & diuitiae in domo eius, ≈øaith the Prophet, his hou≈øe is full of glory, and there is infinite wealth in his chamber. If God then haue glory for tho≈øe which are in heauen with him, and bee al≈øo a father who hath wealth for ≈øuch as are with him in this world, what was the cau≈øe why he did not impart ≈øome of this vnto his ≈øonne? Ambro≈øe vpon this word Pauper & in laboribus ≈øayth, That mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity came in pouerty of glory, ≈øeeing that his Father did not ≈øuffer his ≈øoule to impart ≈øomewhat of his glory vnto his body, and his per≈øon al≈øo liued in pouerty, ≈øeeing hee had nothing proper vnto him≈øelfe in this life, in ≈øo much that as the father was rich in all things, ≈øo the ≈øonne was poore of all things. Plato in his Timaeo ≈øayth, That although pouerty bee no euill thing in a good man, yet notwith≈øtanding mans nature doth much abhorre it, becau≈øe there can none but he be called very fortunate who is able to giue vnto others, neither is there any other very vnfortunate, but hee who mu≈øt of nece≈øsity aske of others. It is to bee thought that Chri≈øts humanity did feele his pouerty, and nece≈øsity which hee endured, a≈øwel becau≈øe his father had very much to be≈øtow vpon him, as for that hee mu≈øt oftentimes aske for that which hee had need of. S. Bonauenture ≈øayth in the life of Chri≈øt: Chri≈øt had much a doe to maintaine him≈øelfe and tho≈øe of his Colledge:
for ≈øometimes he asked that which he had need of, and they gaue it him not, and at other times he asked not, and yet they ≈øent him, in ≈øo much that there did ≈øtriue in his tender heart at one time the hunger which hee ≈øuffered, and the ≈øhame which he had to aske. Hunger did bid him to aske, and ≈øhame did bid him to forbeare: in ≈øo much that there pa≈ø≈øed very few daies in the which his ≈øtomacke was not very hungry, or his holy face couered with ≈øhame. Ginomius the Philo≈øopher being asked what pouerty was, an≈øwered. That pouerty of his owne nature was very euilly conditioned, becau≈øe it giueth no contentment vnto the per≈øon in whome it is, no ≈øauour at the table, no ta≈øt in the cup, no warmth in the gowne, nor any life in the pur≈øe. What contentment can a poore man haue, ≈øeeing they ≈øcorne him before his face? What ≈øauour hath he at his table, ≈øeeing that oftentimes it is time to haue dined before the fire be made in his hou≈øe? What ta≈øt can he haue in his cup, ≈øeeing that ≈øometime hee doth not ≈øend once a weeke vnto the tauern? What tru≈øt can a poor creature haue in his pur≈øe, ≈øeeing that his pur≈øe did co≈øt him more than that which is in it? Chri≈øt had great rea≈øon to ≈øay, that hee vvas brought vp poorely, and with great paine from his infancy, ≈øeeing that he was borne poore, liued poore, and died poore, in≈øomuch that as hee was the mo≈øt holie≈øt of all holy men, ≈øo was he the poore≈øt of all poore men. Exaltatus autem humiliatus & conturbatus, which is the ≈øecond complaint which the ≈øonne maketh of the Father. And it is as if he would ≈øay, Be≈øides that my Father hath brought me vp in pouerty, & great mi≈øery, he hath remembred to giue me honour, the better afterward to diffame me, and to exalt mee to throw mee afterwards downe, in ≈øo much that my fame hath beene ≈øpread abroad throughout all this kingdome, and my infamy hath flowne afterward throughout al the world. This is a very pittifull complaint, and a very deepe ≈øpeech, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary for vs to expound it well and read it vvith great heed. Seneca in his ≈øecond booke of Anger ≈øaith, Laetiores reliquit
fortuna, quos nunquam a≈øpexit qu√†m ques a≈øpexit, & postea de≈øeruit, as if he would ≈øay, It was better with them, and they were more merrier which fortune did neuer exalt, nor neuer thought on, than with tho≈øe whom fortune had once lifted vp to great honour, and afterward thrown down again. Boetius in his fir≈øt booke of Comfort ≈øayth, In falici≈øsimum genus infortunij est hominem fui≈ø≈øe faelicem. As if he would ≈øay, There is no torment in the world to bee compared vnto that, that when a man doth remember that hee hath beene happy in time pa≈øt, and that he is fallen from that e≈øtate; becau≈øe ≈øuch a mans heart doth bewaile his pre≈øent mi≈øery, and ≈øigh after the felicitie which he was wont to enioy. What griefe can he take for honour, who neuer knew what it was? Macrobius in his Saturnales ≈øayth, That if wee want any thing, all that we can doe is to de≈øire it; but if we doe once obtaine it, & then lo≈øe it, the heart is not content with de≈øiring it only, but doth al≈øo lament the lo≈ø≈øe of it, becau≈øe it is a farre greater griefe to lo≈øe that which once we haue enioied, than that which we neuer had, although we doe de≈øire it neuer ≈øo much. The ≈øon of God did complaine on his owne father, becau≈øe he had exalted him, and afterward throwne him downe, becau≈øe there was neuer ≈øonne more honored by his father than Chri≈øt, nor neuer ≈øonne ≈øo much aba≈øed as Chri≈øt was afterward on the Mount of Caluary. The better to vnder≈øtand this ≈øpeech, exaltatus & humiliatus, wee mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe, that God did neuer giue nor neuer will giue vnto any tho≈øe graces and preheminences, which hee gaue vnto his welbeloued ≈øonne, becau≈øe there is no creature worthy to receiue them, nor any Angell of that capacity, that he is able to haue them imparted vnto him. The ≈øonne was exalted by his Father, ≈øeeing hee gaue him his owne diuine e≈ø≈øence and power, and in that his fle≈øh ≈øhould be vnited vnto that diuine nature, and becau≈øe the holy Gho≈øt was the maker and framer of all that my≈øtery, and becau≈øe he ≈øhould take fle≈øh of a Virgine, and ≈øhe remained a Virgine.
