The ≈øonne was highly exalted by his father, con≈øidering that hee gaue him ≈øo much power vpon earth, as hee
had aboue in heauen. The ≈øonne of God was highly exalted by his father, con≈øidering that hee gaue him the mo≈øt excellent ≈øoule that euer was or ≈øhall bee created, and gaue him power to ca≈øt out diuels, and authoritie to rai≈øe the dead, and power ouer al the elemeÃÑts, & al≈øo gaue him licen≈øe to pardon ≈øinnes. The ≈øonne of God was greatly honoured, when hee gaue him, him≈øelfe for his father, a pure Virgine for his mother, holy Io≈øeph for his mai≈øter, the great Bapti≈øt for his emba≈ø≈øadour, the great Euangeli≈øt for his Secretary, holy Peter and Saint Paule for his Preachers. Chri≈øt was highly honoured by his Father, con≈øidering that he made Iohn baptize him in the riuer of Iordan, and cau≈øed the holy Gho≈øt to bee pre≈øent with him, and his glory to ≈øhine there vpon him, and openly acknowledge him to bee his welbeloued ≈øon. Behold then how the ≈øonne of God was exalted and honoured by his father: but ala≈ø≈øe as hee endeth his ≈øpeech with exaltatus, he ≈øayth pre≈øently that he was humiliatus & conturbatus, that he was throwne downe and troubled, ≈øo that according vnto this prophecy the end of his honour was the beginning of his infamy. Chri≈øt was abiected and aba≈øed by his father, becau≈øe that from his young tender infancy, his father began to hold a rigorous hand ouer him: for in the fir≈øt three and thirty years which he liued, he neuer gaue him licen≈øe to ≈øhew his power, nor employ his knowledge, nor ≈øet forth his learning, nor win credite and fame in the world. Chri≈øt was abiected and made low by his father, ≈øeeing that of God he made him a man, of eternall temporall, of one that was inui≈øible, vi≈øible, and of one that was immortall, mortall, of one who was ≈øtrong & mighty, weake, and of a free man a bond≈ø ‚Ä¢ aue, according to his humanitie. The ≈øonne of God was aba≈øed and abiected by his father, con≈øidering how he ≈øuffered the Phari≈øies to per≈øecute him by malice, the Prie≈øts by enuy, the Scribes by couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, the Gentiles through ignorance, and the Synagogue by ob≈øtinacy. Chri≈øt was brought low and aba≈øed by his father, ≈øeeing he gaue his enemies leaue to point at him as if hee had been an enchanter, diffame him as an Idolatour, accu≈øe him of
bla≈øphemy, rebuke him of ≈øedition, and condemne him for a Traitor.

div.head: CHAP. II. How Chri≈øt doth complaine vpon his father, becau≈øe he doth breake all his anger vpon his body.
div.p:
IN me tran≈øierunt irae tuae, & terrores tui conturbauerunt me, ≈øaith Dauid, as if he would ≈øay, Thou was not content O my Father, thou wa≈øt not content, to bring mee vp in ≈øuch great mi≈øery as thou did≈øt, thou wa≈øt not content to exalt mee and throw mee downe againe, but now anew thou doe≈øt breake all thy anger vpon me, and doe≈øt lay vpon my back all thy dreadfull feares. It is a new ≈øpeech and a grieuous complaint, to ≈øay that the father ≈øhould breake his anger vpon his ≈øonne, and that hee maketh his ≈øoule afeard. And therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary for vs to ≈øhew what anger is, and how it can be verified that there is anger in God. Po≈øsidonius the Philo≈øopher being asked what anger was, an≈øwered, In my opinion anger is nothing el≈øe but a ≈øhort and a ≈øuddaine folly. Ari≈øtotle defyning it ≈øaid, that anger was but a kindeling of the bloud, an alteration and mouing of the heart, a forgetting of wit & ≈øence, and a troubling of the iudgement. E≈øchines being demanded from whence anger proceeded, ≈øaid that it proceeded from the heat of the bloud, and of the abundance of choller, and a vapour of the gaule, and fiercene≈ø≈øe of the heart. Macrobius ≈øayth, That no man ≈øhould chide with one that chideth, nor with him who is chidden, vntill the cau≈øe be knowne on both ≈øides: for the cau≈øe is not in the anger which wee ≈øhew in chiding, but in the iu≈øtice or iniu≈øtice of the cau≈øe for which wee chide. Seneca in his fir≈øt booke of Anger ≈øayth, That the conditions of an angry man are, not to beleeue his friends, to bee
≈øodden in all his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, helpe him≈øelfe with his hands, not to re≈øpect dangers, ≈øpeake ≈øuddenly and maliciou≈øly, and bee angry for a ≈ømal occa≈øion, and admit no rea≈øon. Chilo the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, That if any man aske him what hee thinketh of anger, hee will an≈øwere that it is a thing ea≈øie to be written of, and ea≈øie to per≈øuade, and ≈øweet to bee coun≈øelled again≈øt, but very hard to bee bridled. Saint Ba≈øil vpon the P≈øalme, Neque in ira tua corripias me ≈øayth, That Anger is ≈øuch a dangetous thing, that if wee doe giue it entrance into our will, it doth afterward make our nill of our will. Then wee yeeld our will vnto anger, when wee begin to trouble our ≈øelues with ≈ømall matters, and then anger doth that which is not our wil, when in great matters we would not be angry: in ≈øo much that if wee doe not re≈øi≈øt anger in the beginning, we ≈øhall neuer or late ca≈øt it out of our hou≈øe. Wee haue ≈øpoken all this to the end that wee ≈øhould maruell the more how it ≈øhould be in God, and how he ≈øhould bee moued like a man, ≈øeeing that as there is no man able to take his eternall being from him, ≈øo there is no man able any way to trouble him. Who ≈øhould bee able to trouble him, ≈øeeing wee know that God is a ≈øpirit, and hath no heart in his brea≈øt, no bloud in his vaines, no vapour ri≈øing from his gaule, no gaule in his lights, no forgetfulne≈ø≈øe in his memory, no alteration in his iudgement? S. Ierome vpon the Prophet O ≈øee ≈øaith, That God is ≈øo wi≈øe that no man is able to deceiue him, ≈øo mighty that no man is able to re≈øi≈øt him, ≈øo con≈øtant that no man is able to mooue him, ≈øo inui≈øible that no man is able to touch them, ≈øo iu≈øt that no man is able to oppre≈ø≈øe him. Then if it bee ≈øo, that hee cannot bee deceiued, oppre≈ø≈øed, nor moued, how is it po≈øsible that any anger ≈øhould raigne in him, as it doth in a man? When the ≈øonne ≈øayth vnto the Father, In me tran≈øierunt iraetuae, hee ≈øayth plainly, that hee hath vnloaden his great anger vpon him, and hath ca≈øt all his griefes vpon his ≈øhoulders. For the better vnder≈øtanding of this complaint which Chri≈øt maketh, it is to bee
noted, that for the ≈øpace of many yeares God had enmities and hatred, and found him≈øelfe agrieued, moued, and di≈øquie ‚Ä¢ ed: for at the ≈øame houre that he created creatures, the Angels would haue been equall with him, man began to di≈øobey him, ≈øinne began to preuaile, and al≈øo to per≈øecute his friends. God had three notorious enemies in the world, which are man, the deuill, and ≈øinne: whereof man went about to lift vp him≈øelfe in Paradi≈øe, the diuell to take heauen from him, and ≈øinne to rule and gouern the whole world. O that the≈øe were vn≈øpeakeable griefes which the≈øe three enemies cau≈øed God to haue, and their di≈øobedience toward him exceeding great, heaping daily ≈øin vpon ≈øinne, wickedne≈ø≈øe vpoÃÑ wickedne≈ø≈øe, neuer going about to amend them≈øelues, nor God to be pacified. Our Lord did di≈ø≈øemble all kind of di≈øobedience, and all manner of ≈øinne, vntill his ≈øonne came into the world, vpon who≈øe humanity hee did ≈øo fully vnload and vnburden his anger and griefe, as though hee had been the only inuenter of ≈øinne. Gregory in his Morals ≈øayth, That the world is a ≈øtrong enemy, the deuill a ≈øtronger, and ≈øinne the Traitor the ≈øtronge≈øt of all: for if there were no ≈øinne in the world, God would not bee angry, nor man ≈øhould not bee condemned, nor the Deuill vvould not goe about ≈øo diligently, neither ≈øhould there bee any hell for the vvicked. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth thus, It dooth vvell appeare that the eternall Father did breake all his anger vpon his precious ≈øonne, and that hee did vnburden him≈øelfe and load all his vvrath vpon his humanitie, ≈øeeing that before his ≈øonne did take fle≈øh, hee did nothing but puni≈øh, and after that hee died did nothing but pardon. Haue you ≈øeene ≈øince God hath broken his anger vpon his ≈øonne, either the vvorld drowned vvith vvater, as in the floud, or burnt vvith fire, as in Sodome and Gomorra? Hath there beene ≈øeene ≈øince God brake his anger vpon his ≈øonne, ≈øuch captiuities as the people of the Iewes vvere in, or ≈øuch plagues as vvere in Aegypt,
or ≈øuch famine as were in Dauids time, or ≈øuch warres as were in the Machabees time? Chri≈øt had great rea≈øon to ≈øay vnto his father, In me tran≈øierunt irae tuae, ≈øeeing that hee broke all his anger, and di≈øcharged all his wrath vpon him. Eripuit me de inimicu meis forti≈øsimis, & ab his qui oderunt me, ≈øaith the Prophet Dauid ≈øpeaking vnder the per≈øon of Chri≈øt: That is, in recompence that my Father hath vnloaden vpon mee all his wrath and anger, he hath deliuered me from my mightie≈øt enemies, and hath put from my ≈øide ≈øuch of my enemies which did hate mee exceedingly. What doe≈øt thou ≈øay O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, what doe≈øt thou ≈øay? doe≈øt thou die by the hands of thy enemies, and yet doe≈øt ≈øay that thy father hath deliuered thee from them? My father hath not deliuered me from the deuill, ≈øeeing that he doth tempt me, nor from the Phari≈øies ≈øeeing that they haue accu≈øed mee, nor from the Scribes ≈øeeing that they haue diffamed mee, nor from the Gentiles ≈øeeing that they haue crucified me, but he hath deliuered me from ≈øinnes which are the ≈øtronge≈øt of all my enemies. Are they not the ≈øtronge≈øt of all, ≈øeeing they rule and mai≈øterall? Augu≈øtine vpon the Apo≈øtles words ≈øayth, Of three enemies which we haue, ≈øinne is the ≈øtronge≈øt of them al; becau≈øe many holy men, haue gone before vs in old times, vpon whom although the deuill and the world haue had no power, yet notwith≈øtanding ≈øin hath had a dwelling place in them, becau≈øe there did neuer man liue ≈øo cleane, who knew not what ≈øinne was. Ca≈øsiodorus ≈øayth, I for my part, thinke ≈øinne more mightier than any other enemy, becau≈øe the world and the diuell can but deceiue me, but wicked ≈øin can hurt me & damn me. For if there were no manner of ≈øin in the world, we ≈øhould need neither gallowes nor ≈øword. Chri≈øt onely may ≈øay, hee hath deliuered me from my enemies, becau≈øe he & no other was free from ≈øinne, becau≈øe all other creatures knew what ≈øinne was, and all knew what puni≈øhment for it was. O how happy a man he ≈øhould be, who could ≈øay with the Prophet, he hath deliuered me from my ≈øtronge≈øt enemies! for it is nothing
el≈øe to ≈øay that God hath deliuered him from his enemies, but that our Lord hath deliuered him from his ≈øinnes. The Prophet had great rea≈øon to call ≈øinne not only an enemy, but al≈øo his ≈øtronge≈øt enemy, ≈øeeing that without other helpe, he threw the Angell out of heauen, ca≈øt Adam out of Paradi≈øe, depriued Iudas of his Apo≈øtle≈øhip, and condemned all the world to death. Is not ≈øinne thinke you the mightie≈øt of all other enemies, ≈øeeing that hee is able and ≈øtrong inough to carry mee to hell? The power of my vi≈øible enemy reacheth no further than to take my life from mee, but ≈øinne the Traitour is an enemy ≈øo ≈øtrong, that hee is able to take my life from me, depriue me of grace, ca≈øt me out of glory, hurt my ≈øoule, and condemne mee vnto paine. Who had ≈øuch enemies as the ≈øonne of God had; that is, ≈øo wicked in their cogitations, ≈øo malicious in their ≈øpeech, and ≈øo cruell in their deedes? Were not the la≈øhes which opened Chri≈øts ≈øhoulders very cruell enemies, the nailes which broke his ≈øinewes, the thornes which tore his temples, and the ≈øpeare which opened his ≈øide, and the Synagogue which tooke his life from him? Yet Chri≈øt called none of all the≈øe his enemies, nor did not handle them like his enemies, but only ≈øins, which hee did not only call enemies, but mighty and ≈øtrong enemies, giuing vs therby to vnder≈øtand, that we ≈øhould hold none for our enemie but onely ≈øinne. When good king Dauid ≈øaid, Per≈øequar inimicos meos & comprehendam illos, Hee ≈øpake it not in re≈øpect of the enemies which per≈øecuted his per≈øon, but for ≈øinnes which did damnifie his ≈øoule. For ≈øeeing that good king Dauid did pardon Saul and Simei, and others his mortall enemies, how could hee coun≈øell vs that wee ≈øhould per≈øecute ours? When he ≈øaith I will per≈øecute my enemies vntill I de≈øtroy them, he ≈øpake of no other enemies but of his ≈øinnes, the which it is conuenient for vs to per≈øecute, and ca≈øt from vs. And it is not without a my≈øtery that hee ≈øayth Per≈øequar & comprehendam, Becau≈øe that as the enemy which is offended, if he be not taken, turneth againe and biddeth vs a
more fierce battaile than hee did before; euen ≈øo dooth the diuell and ≈øinne deale with vs, the which if we doe not driue away vtterly from vs, and root out from our hearts, they turn againe again≈øt vs like vnto mo≈øt mighty and ≈øtrong enemies. What doth it auaile the hunt≈øman if hee run after the Hare, if he take her not: what doth it is profite thee, if thou run after ≈øinne and dete≈øt ≈øinne, and ≈øpeake euill of it, if thou doe≈øt not ouertake ≈øinne; and what el≈øe is it to ouertake ≈øinne, but to ouercome and de≈øtroy ≈øinne vtterly? O how many there be which ≈øay, I wil per≈øecute my enemies, and how few there bee which ≈øay, and I haue taken them: for if they ca≈øt out ≈øinnes to day on one ≈øide of their hou≈øe, they turne againe to morrow, and knocke at the ring of the dore, and it is opened pre≈øently vnto them.

div.head: CHAP. III. How Chri≈øt complaineth of his Father, becau≈øe hee tooke all his friends from him in his pa≈øsion, and all others which he knew.
div.p:
ELonga≈øti ame amicum & proximum & notos meos a mi≈øeria, The≈øe are the words which the ≈øonne of God ≈øpake, continuing his former complaint, vttered by the Prophet Dauid, P≈øalm 87: as if he would ≈øay, Thou ≈øhoulde≈øt haue contented thy ≈øelfe O my Father, when thou did≈øt vnload al thy wrath vpoÃÑ my weake body, & not ≈øeperate anew my friends froÃÑ me, & hinder tho≈øe to come vnto me which were my known acquaintance. Chri≈øt coÃÑplaineth in this place of his Father, that he tooke his friends from him, ≈øeeing that he ≈øayth, thou ha≈øt remoued my friends from me, & he complaineth that he took his kin≈ømen from him, & that hee tooke his acquaintance from him, and at that in≈øtant when hee vvas in greate≈øt mi≈øery. This is a pittifull complaint
which the ≈øonne of God now maketh, becau≈øe there is no griefe to be compared vnto that, nor no hurt equall vnto the taking away of a mans tru≈øty and faithfull friend. Horace asketh what hee is able to doe, or what hee hath who hath no friends? To what purpo≈øe doth he liue which hath no friends? Mimus the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, That a man dieth as oft as he lo≈øeth any of his good friends: and ≈øayth further, that as the body is made of diuers members, ≈øo the heart of friends: and there vpon it is, that as the body cannot liue without it haue many members, ≈øo likewi≈øe the heart cannot liue vvithout friends. They killed Dauids greate≈øt enemy which was Saul, and his deere≈øt friend who was Ionathas in one day, and hee was ≈øo agreeued at the death of his friend, that by turns after hee had wept the death of his friend, hee wept his enemies death al≈øo. We doe not read that our redeemer did weep for the death of holy Io≈øeph his mai≈øter, nor for all the trauails which he eudured in this world; but he wept for the death of Lazarus his good friend, who≈øe death hee could not endure, but immediately did rai≈øe from death againe. If Plutarch the great Philo≈øopher doe not deceiue vs, Plato came from A≈øia vnto Cicilia, for no other cau≈øe but to ≈øee Phocion the Philo≈øopher, who was his deere friend. Cicero in his booke of Friend≈øhip ≈øayth, That the Philo≈øophers do coÃÑmend nothing more vnto vs, nor wi≈øe men did e≈øteeme of no riches more than of the conuer≈øation of their friends, becau≈øe that without friends it is not lawfull for vs to liue, nor yet very ≈øure to die. Ari≈øtorle being asked what friend≈øhip was, an≈øwered, That it was nothing el≈øe but one ≈øoule which ruled two hearts, and one heart which did dwell in two bodies. Diogenes ≈øayth, That ≈øeeing there is no greater paine than to deale with naughty men, nor no greater comfort than to conuer≈øe with good men; for my owne part I confe≈ø≈øe and ≈øay, that I had rather die vvith him whom I hold for my friend, than liue with him whome I e≈øteeme my enemie. E≈øchines the Philo≈øopher being demanded how one friend ≈øhould be towards another, an≈øwered: betwixt
true friends there is but one yea, and one nay, one liking & one mi≈øliking, one agreeing & one di≈øagreeing, one wil and one nill, one loue and one hatred. Experience doth teach vs, that how good ≈øoeuer the bread be yet it mouldeth, and wine becommeth vineger, and garments teare, and fle≈øh waxeth ≈øtale, and years pa≈ø≈øe away, but friend≈øhip alone is that which neuer wearieth, & good conuer≈øation is that that neuer doth loathe. Pliny in an Epi≈øtle ≈øayth, If thou wilt be honored, giue honour vnto others; If thou wilt bee ≈øuccoured ≈øuccour others; If thou wilt be loued loue others. For if thou wilt haue a friend, thou mu≈øt either make him or find him: and in that ca≈øe I ≈øay, that it is better for thee to make him by good turns, than buy him with money. Peter of Rauenna ≈øayth in a Sermon of the holy Gho≈øt: O what a ≈øweet thing it is to haue friends to loue, and to loue to bee loued againe: for the qualities of true friend≈øhip are, that it feareth no ≈øword, it dreadeth no arrow, it refu≈øeth no ≈øpear, nor e≈øteemeth not his life, but embraceth death with cheerefulne≈ø≈øe, rather than make any default in friend≈øhip. I≈øidorus ≈øayth, That the priuiledges of true friend≈øhip are, that it maketh pro≈øperous fortune more plea≈øant, and aduer≈øe more ea≈øie, maketh doubtful things certaine, and fiercene≈ø≈øe meeke, and maketh that light which is greeuous & heauy. Hermogenes ≈øayth, When thou art in pro≈øperity in this world, thou oughte≈øt to ≈øu≈øpect all friend≈øhip; for thou doe≈øt not know whether they loue that which thou ha≈øt, or thy ≈øelfe which doe≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe it: for true friend≈øhip is not knowne when thou ha≈øt much to giue, but when thou art in nece≈øsity to aske. Is there (≈øaith S. Ambro≈øe) any greater coÃÑ ≈øolation in this mi≈øerable vvorld, thaÃÑ to haue a faithful friend, with whom thou mai≈øt open thy brea≈øt, communicate thy ≈øecrets, di≈øcouer thy heart, impart thy plea≈øures, and giue part of thy griefes? If thou doe≈øt make a bed to lie in, and build chimnees to warme thee in, and garners for thy corne, vvhy doe≈øt thou not ≈øeeke bowels to hide the ≈øecrets of thy bowels? And thou mu≈øt know, that thou oughte≈øt nor to tru≈øt the
≈øecrets of thy heart, but vnto another who is thy heart. Saint Ierome vnto Ruffinus ≈øayth, WheÃÑ thou do≈øt enter into friend≈øhip with any faithfull friend (Ruffinus) learne better how to keepe him than thou didde≈øt keepe Ierome: for a good friend is not found euery where the is long a ≈øeeking for, and ≈øeldome gotten, he is hardly kept and ea≈øily lo≈øt, he is recouered very ≈ølowly, and the want of him felt very quickly. Chilo the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, I am halfe of my friend, and my friend is halfe of me, in ≈øo much that I mu≈øt ≈øeeke him in me, and my ≈øelfe in him, becau≈øe he is I, and I am hee. And hee ≈øaith further, that when my friend dieth in him whom I loued, halfe of my ≈øelfe died with him, and halfe of him remaineth aliue with mee, in ≈øo much that by my will I ≈øhould die, if it were not to keepe that part of him which remained in me aliue. This vertue of friend≈øhip could not bee better prai≈øed, than this Philo≈øopher hath done it, ≈øeeing hee doth confe≈ø≈øe, that halfe of him≈øelfe is in the graue with his friend, and that halfe of his friend was aliue in his ≈øoule, and that he de≈øired to liue for no other rea≈øon, but becau≈øe his friend ≈øhould not die in him. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, if all this be true, we ≈øhould haue great compa≈øsion vpon Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing his Father tooke his friends from him, ≈øeparated his kin from him, & left him no comfort by his acquaintance. It is much to be noted, that Chri≈øt doth complaine that his Father took but one friend froÃÑ him, & one kin≈øman, but many of his acquaintance; to note vnto vs, that of faithfull friends there is ≈øcar≈øe one to be found, and of vertuous kin≈ømen hardly one, but of acquaintance a great number. O that hee knoweth but meanly what friend≈øhip is, who putteth a friend, a kin≈øman, and his acquaintance vnder one reckoning, becau≈øe that I am to call him only my friend who loueth me, & him my kin≈ømaÃÑ who is a good Chri≈øtian, & all other my neighbours & coÃÑpanions my acquaintance. To ≈øpeak properly, Chri≈øt had but one friend only who was his Father, & no other friend like vnto him; & one only which was of his kindred, who was his mother, & none other like vnto her: but
he had great acquaintance among the Iews: & in that great conflict which he had in his pa≈øsion, his friend for≈øooke him, his kindred did not helpe him, and his acquaintaince ≈øhewed them≈øelues vngratefull. Thou didde≈øt remoue farre from me, my friend, ≈øeeing that thou O my Father, woulde≈øt not heare me when I praied vnto thee in the garden following the inclination of the fle≈øh: and thou didde≈øt remoue my kin from me, ≈øeeing that my mother could not help me on the Mount of Caluary; and thou didde≈øt remoue my acquaintance from me, ≈øeeing that there I was put to death by them. O in what great danger, and in what a narrow ≈øtrait the ≈øon of God vvas at the time of his pa≈øsion, ≈øeeing he complaineth that his Father did not heare him, his mother did not helpe him, and none of his friends would know him. Thou didde≈øt ≈øay very well O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, that Elonga≈øti a me amicum & proximum, ≈øeeing thy friend who was thy father, could comfort thee but would not; thy kin who was thy mother, would but could not helpe thee; and thy acquaintance who was Iudas, neither would nor could accompany thee, in ≈øo much that vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe thou didde≈øt abound in torment, and want friends. O that wee had a farre better friend of thee, than thou hadde≈øt of vs, ≈øeeing that Totum belli pondus ver≈øum e≈øt in Saul; When as to make an attonement betwixt vs and thy Father, he did lay all the danger of the warre vpon thy ≈øhoulders. Non e≈øt qui vtrumque po≈øsit arguere, & ponere manum ≈øuam in ambobus, ≈øayth Iob chapter 9. As if hee would ≈øay, The one is ≈øo ≈øtrong, and the other ≈øo ob≈øtinate, that there is no man able to ≈øatisfie theÃÑ, nor who dareth put his hand between theÃÑ. WheÃÑ that holy maÃÑ Iob ≈øaith, that he ≈øaw two men at a variance, which al the world could not make friends & ≈øet at agreement, & yet did not name theÃÑ, it is ≈ømall doubt but he vnder≈øtandeth ≈øome great ≈øecret & hiddeÃÑ my≈øtery. Of the≈øe two which holy Iob ≈øpeaketh of, who is the ≈øtrong & mightie one, but only our eternal God, & who the ob≈øtinate man, but he who is without coÃÑfort? Cyrillus ≈øaith, That God & man, &
man & God did haÃÑdle one another very hardly, becau≈øe man did nothing but ≈øin, & God did neuer cea≈øe to puni≈øh, & thervpoÃÑ it is, that in tho≈øe daies they called God, Deus vltionuÃÑ, deus vltionuÃÑ twi≈øe; becau≈øe he did neither pardon their bodies of puni≈øhment, nor their ≈øoules of the fault. Becau≈øe God was the highe≈øt and chiefe≈øt goodne≈ø≈øe that was, and man inclined vnto wickedne≈ø≈øe, God did command him to better and amend him≈øelfe: vnto which he an≈øwered that he would bee merry and take his plea≈øure; by rea≈øon whereof man went euery day wor≈øe and wor≈øe, and God more angry and incen≈øed euery day again≈øt him. Pope Leo ≈øayth, That God doth not weigh whether we be weake or ≈øtrong, in health or ≈øicke, rich or poore, ≈øimple or wi≈øe, but that which he de≈øireth, is that we ≈øhould be good, and he is angry if we be naught: and therupon it is, that hee neuer ca≈øteth any good man out of his pre≈øence, nor hee admitteth no naughty man into his hou≈øe. Gregory ≈øayth, That hee could not ≈øuffer one ≈øinne in him who was an Angell, and doe≈øt thou thinke he will ≈øuffer ≈øo many ≈øinnes in thee who art but a man? And hee ≈øayth further, that God would rather ≈øuffer, that an Angell ≈øhould take heauen from him, and man the world, than ≈øuffer one only ≈øinne either in the one or in the other; becau≈øe that to make a new heaueÃÑ he is of ≈øufficient power, but to like and approue a ≈øinne, neither is his power able to doe it, neither can it bee comprehended vnder his clemency. Seeing then that God is ≈øuch an enemie vnto ≈øinne, and ≈øeeing that man doth ≈øo much couet to ≈øinne, how can they bee but contrary the one vnto the other, and v≈øe one another like enemies? Holy Iob doth weepe and ≈øigh, ≈øaying, Non e≈øt qui po≈ø≈øit vtrumque arguere, that is, there was no man who dur≈øt be a mediator betwixt them, nor put him≈øelfe betweene them, to the end that man might giue ouer ≈øinning, & God withdraw his hand from puni≈øhing. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, When God and man, and man and God, were at ≈øtrife and variance, and the one alwaies aboue in heauen, and the other continually vpon the earth, there vvas no
meane to make them meet, nor no court to agree them in, becau≈øe there came none downe from heauen to vs, nor any fit per≈øon went hence from vs to heauen. The ≈øon of God came theÃÑ into the world, and put him≈øelf a mediator between them both, that is, betweene God and fle≈øh. O how much wee are bound to Chri≈øt for that which he did for vs, and much more for the manner with the which he did it! for the more to bind the one and the other, he tooke the diuinity of his Father with the which he might pardon vs, and tooke fle≈øh of man, with the which hee might ≈øuffer with vs. In ≈øo much that becau≈øe he tooke his kindred and alliance of both, hee was able to make them both friends. O how co≈øtly this friend≈øhip and kindred was to the ≈øon of God, and grieuous al≈øo, ≈øeeing that it did co≈øt him his bloud which was in him, & the life which hee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed ≈øo farre forth, that for to make mee friends with God, he became an enemy vnto him≈øelfe. It is certaine that when two enemies doe draw their vveapons to fight, if another venter in betwixt them, that both their blowes do light vpon him, in ≈øo much that hee vvho parreth them is hurt or ≈ølaine, and tho≈øe which were at debate proue afterward good friends. On the Mount of Caluary, and on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, as God and man, and man and God, had ≈øummoned the one the other to a place of defiance, ble≈ø≈øed Ie≈øus put him≈øelfe betwixt them both to cut off the ≈øtrife, becau≈øe hee knew that if hee had not taken away all anger at that place, they vvould haue remained perpetuall enemies. As man threw ≈øinnes at God, and God puni≈øhment vpon man, it fell out that the ≈øinne which man fought with, and the puni≈øhment with the which God did cha≈øti≈øe, fell all vpon the Mediatour who had not de≈øerued it. O good Ie≈øus and glory of my ≈øoule, vpon whome but vpon thee did thy Father lay his old anger, vpon whome but vpon thee did man lay his fault? Doe not then vexe thy ≈øelfe O holy Iob, and ≈øaie, Non est qui ponat manum ≈øuam in ambobus, ≈øeeing hee is already come from heauen, and
already borne in the world vvho hath put his hand betwixt God and man, yea and hath both his hands cut off by them? Haue not they both trow you cut off his hand, ≈øeeing his Father ordained that hee ≈øhould die, and man put the fault on him for which hee ≈øhould bee crucified? O diuine mediatour, O holy ≈øtickeler! which of the Angels could doe the like, or vvhat man could attempt that which thou ha≈øt done? That is willingly, and vpon good and long deliberation, thou didde≈øt offer thy ≈øelfe to lo≈øe thy life, to ≈øet God and man in concord and vnitie. The ≈øonne of God then doth complaine vpon his Father with iu≈øt cau≈øe, ≈øaying, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee? ≈øeeing that hee did load all his wrath vpon his backe, and man likewi≈øe lay all the burden of his ≈øinnes vpon his ≈øhoulders, vpon him in that place God did emptie all his wrath, and in that place mans ≈øinnes tooke their end. O that this is a glorious time, and a happie age which vvee of the Catholicke church liue in! for hauing Chri≈øt for our Mediatour, there can no ≈øinne goe vp to the Father, but it mu≈øt fir≈øt meet with Chri≈øt, nor any puni≈øhment come downe vpon man, but it mu≈øt al≈øo come by him. The ≈øonne of God being a meane betwixt his Father and vs, who doubteth but that hee will ≈øtop our ≈øinne in him≈øelfe, that it a≈øcend not to heauen, and al≈øo keepe backe the puni≈øhment of his Father, that it doe not de≈øcend into the world? As otherwi≈øe it would if Chri≈øt ≈øhould not make him≈øelfe a meane betwixt vs.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. How Chri≈øt complaineth on his Father, becau≈øe hee bathed his body with the bloud of his vaines, and drowned his heart in waters of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
CIrcumdederunt me ≈øicut aqua, tota die circuÃÑ dederunt me≈øimul, P≈øalme 88. The ≈øonne of God ≈øpake the≈øe words, continuing his complaint again≈øt his Father: and it is as if hee would ≈øay, What meaneth this O my Father, what meaneth this? Wa≈øt thou not content to breake thy anger vpon me, and remoue all my friends from me, but now anew thou wilt compa≈ø≈øe mee with a great floud of water, in the which my life is drowned? Chri≈øt doth ≈øet foorth at large all his trauails, and bewaileth the want of friends: for hee ≈øayth that the waters were great, and he ≈øaith twi≈øe that they be≈øieged him, and that they came all together vpon him, and that they came ≈øo ragingly, that they tooke away all his forces. Fir≈øt of all, we mu≈øt examine here of what kind of waters our Lord ≈øpeaketh in this place, whether they bee ≈øea waters, or of a riuer, or fountaine, or of a lake, becau≈øe that in all the≈øe a man may drowne him≈øelfe, and lo≈øe his life. We read onely of two puni≈øhments which God hath inflicted by waters, the one in the floud of Noe, in which almo≈øt all the world peri≈øhed, the other which he v≈øed again≈øt the people of Aegypt in the red ≈øea; the which two puni≈øhments were ≈øo famous, that our Lord hath not v≈øed the like vntill this day. The ≈øonne of God dooth not complaine of this kind of floud, nor wee doe not read that he euer was in danger by water: for being Lord of all the waters, how is it po≈øsible that he ≈øhould bee drowned in the waters? The ≈øonne of God complaineth of ≈øtronger flouds than the≈øe, of more raging ≈øeas, & more ≈øalter waters,
of who≈øe bitterne≈ø≈øe none ta≈øted ≈øo much of as hee did, nor no man went ≈øo neere the bottome of them as hee did. What waters were they then which compa≈ø≈øed the ≈øonne of God, but onely mo≈øt grieuous tribulations, which pa≈ø≈øed through his heart, and tormented his body? In Scripture by many waters is oftentimes vnder≈øtood many tribulations, as when hee ≈øaid el≈øewhere, Saluum ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e fac ‚Ä¢ domine, quia intrauerunt aquae animam meam, as if hee would ≈øay, Saue me O Lord becau≈øe I am drowned, helpe mee O my great God, becau≈øe the waters ouerflow me, becau≈øe the waters of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe enter in at my mouth, and drowne my dolorous heart. O in what great angui≈øh of mind hee was who ≈øpake the≈øe words! for to ≈øay that angui≈øh went to his heart, was nothing el≈øe but to bee grieued at the heart. The waters of tribulation, and the floud of vexation entred into no mans heart ≈øo deepely, as into our Sauiours: for ≈øeeing that we were the cau≈øe of them all, as he did loue vs from the heart, ≈øo hee did feele them from the heart. It is to bee noted, that hee doth not ≈øay that the water did wet him, or bemite him, or make him afraid, for all the≈øe things doe not kill, but onely put vs in feare. All the perill of water is, that a ≈øuddaine ≈øtreame doe not carry vs away, and that our life doth con≈øi≈øt in nothing but in the ≈øuddaine growing or decrea≈øing of the water. Seneca ≈øayth, That no man can be in greater danger in this life, than hee who ≈øeeth him≈øelfe compa≈ø≈øed with waters, becau≈øe that at the ≈øelf ≈øame time our ≈øoule and life goeth out where the waters goe in, and the waters goe out where our ≈øoules goe in. To what other thing could the ≈øon of God better compare his angui≈øh & di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, than vnto one compa≈ø≈øed about with waters? It is to bee noted that he ≈øayth, Circumdederunt me, Haue enuitoned mee, becau≈øe the water which raineth doth wet onely, the water throwne da≈øheth onely, and that which is dronke filleth, but that which compa≈ø≈øeth on euery ≈øide drowneth: and therfore Chri≈øt ≈øaith they haue iuclo≈øed me on euery ≈øide; & ≈øaith not they haue wet me, becau≈øe his ble≈ø≈øed heart was drowned in the ≈øea of ≈øorrow, and his ≈øacred body in the floud of tormeÃÑts.
The waters which compa≈ø≈øed him about, & the flouds which fell vpon him were ≈øo great, that my tongue is not able to rehear≈øe them, nor my heart to thinke them, nor my fingers to write them, nor my eies to bewaile them. O good Ie≈øus & my ≈øoules delight, how or when didde≈øt thou ≈øee thy ≈øelfe enuironed with waters, but when thou ≈øawe≈øt one member pulled froÃÑ another on the Mount of Caluary? O that it is an improper ≈øpeech to ≈øay that thou wa≈øt compa≈ø≈øed with water, ≈øeeing that thou mighte≈øt with greater rea≈øon haue ≈øaid, that thou didde≈øt ≈øee thy ≈øelfe drowned in bloud, becau≈øe that in that lamentable day of thy death thou didde≈øt want water, and flow in bloud. It is nor without a deepe my≈øtery and hidden ≈øecret, that Chri≈øt ≈øaith, that hee was compa≈ø≈øed about with water, although it were true that he was enuironed with bloud: and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe there is no man who is ≈øo greatly recreated by drinking a cup of cold water, nor taketh ≈øo great contentment in it, as good Ie≈øus did in ≈øhedding his bloud to redeeme the world with it. Chri≈øt ≈øayth then, they haue compa≈ø≈øed me about like vnto water, becau≈øe that if he did looke vpward, hee ≈øaw his Father who would not ≈øeeme to heare him, if downward he ≈øaw but his mother, who could doe nothing but weepe for him, if hee did looke on the left hand he ≈øaw but a thiefe, who would not beleeue in him, if on the other hand hee ≈øaw another thiefe who could not helpe him. He was compa≈ø≈øed on euery ≈øide: for if hee ≈øhould haue looked behind, he ≈øhould haue ≈øeene the hangmen watching him, and before him the Iewes a mocking him. Chri≈øt ≈øaith, they haue coÃÑpa≈ø≈øed me like vnto a water: vpon which words S. Barnard ≈øayth thus, O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules delight, what pitty did moue thee, what charity did force thee, being nailed vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, loaden with thornes, be≈øet about with ≈øpeares, yet thou ≈øaie≈øt that thou art compa≈ø≈øed with waters? Doe≈øt thou die vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and that with great thir≈øt, & coulde≈øt not get a cup of water to drinke, and yet doe≈øt thou ≈øay, that thou art coÃÑpa≈ø≈øed with water? What loue hath tran≈øported thee, or what goodne≈ø≈øe hath made thee pa≈øt thy
≈øence, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt thinke the bloud which i≈ø≈øueth from thee, ≈øhould bee water that runneth out of thee? What meaneth this O redeemer of my ≈øoule, what meaneth this? Doth thy hard nailes, cruell ≈øpeares, grieuous thornes, ≈øeeme to be fountains of ≈øweet waters? The loue which Chri≈øt bare vs in ≈øuffering was ≈øo infinite, that all things ≈øeemed ≈øweet and plea≈øant vnto him, becau≈øe it is a priuiledge of loue that nothing ≈øeemeth hard and painful vnto him which loueth, but that which he doth vnwillingly. The ≈øonne of God doth nothing vnwillingly in this world, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee when hee puni≈øheth our offences: for although he do many things daily being praied thereunto, yet hee doth nothing being forced. Chri≈øt doth complaine al≈øo that they compa≈ø≈øed him with many flouds of waters comming together: for hee ≈øayth, Circumde derunt me ≈øimul, which kind of per≈øecution is no le≈ø≈øe painfull than perillous, nor perillous than painefull. Plato to this purpo≈øe ≈øayth, That when griefes and vexations come by little and by little, they ≈øeeme to bee ≈øomewhat tollerable: but when they come by heapes, they are vntollerable; and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe man had no time to fore≈øee ≈øuch dangers, nor place to auoid them. Ba≈øil vpon the P≈øalme ≈øayth, That griefes and vexations came vpon that mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed humanity of Chri≈øt, like a very great water, and like many enemies which laid in ambu≈øh, the which Chri≈øt would not nor did not re≈øi≈øt, nor yet flie away from, but only be≈øeech his Father to giue him more ≈øtrength to endure and abide them. Bede ≈øayth in an Homily, O that this thy loue which thou didde≈øt ≈øhew in this ≈øpeech of Quare me dereliquisti was vn≈øpeakable, and thy charity incomparable! for if thou doe≈øt complaine to thy Father, it was not becau≈øe he ≈øhould take away ≈øome part of the torment which thou didde≈øt ≈øuffer, but becau≈øe hee would not giue thee longer life to ≈øuffer more. Vbertinus ≈øayth that Chri≈øt ≈øaid very truly, when he ≈øaid, that whole flouds of many waters had compa≈ø≈øed him round about, becau≈øe that in the compa≈ø≈øe of foure & twentie houres he was watched, apprehended, denied, accu≈øed, whipped, and
receiued ≈øentence, ≈øpoiled, crucified, and dead; in≈øomuch that if we compare the moments of times with his torments, wee ≈øhall ≈øee, that the torments which hee ≈øuffered vvere more than the moments and quantities of the time in which he ≈øuffered. S. Ambro≈øe vpon the P≈øalme ≈øayth, That no man could euer ≈øay the≈øe words of Circumdederunt me aquae tota die & ≈øimul, with ≈øo good rea≈øon as Chri≈øt; becau≈øe on that day which he ≈øuffered in, there pa≈ø≈øed no houre, nor moment, nor minute of time, in the which he was not either ≈øtrockeÃÑ, or whipped, or ≈øpit vpoÃÑ, or bla≈øphemed: in≈øomuch that tho≈øe mini≈øters of wickednes were ≈øo bu≈øie & ha≈øty in giuing him tormeÃÑt, that they them≈øelues had no time to re≈øt them in, nor Chri≈øt to breath in. Pope Leo vpon the Pa≈øsion of our Sauiour ≈øayth, That hee had great cau≈øe to ≈øay, that hee was compa≈ø≈øed with many waters, becau≈øe that all kind of people and all nations con≈øpired in one again≈øt that mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity, Iews, Gentiles, Prie≈øts, Phari≈øies, Di≈øciples, Pontifes, Kings, Captains, Souldiours, hangmen, yong, old, ≈øtranger, and all others. S. Augu≈øtine vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth this: What people were therein the world which were not at the death of Chri≈øt, or what tormeÃÑt was there inuented which he ≈øuffered not? In ≈øo tempe≈øtious a ≈øea, in ≈øo dangerous a floud, in ≈øuch ≈øudden waues, and in ≈øuch di≈øtre≈ø≈øes heaped one vpon another, who would not haue the ≈øonne ≈øay vnto the Father, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee, ≈øeeing hee did not ≈øpeake one word to comfort him, nor left him any one friend which did fauour him?

div.head: CHAP. V. How Chri≈øt complaineth of his Father, becau≈øe he did permit tho≈øe to crucifie him which were wont to bee his friends: and how he calleth them friends.
div.p:
QVae ≈øunt plagae istae in medie manuum tuarum? His plagatus ≈øum in domo eorum qui me diligebant, ≈øayth E≈øay, chap. 20. The≈øe words were ≈øpoken by all the Angels, vnto the Lord of all Angels, who was the ≈øonne of God, and it is as if he would ≈øay: O ≈øonne of God, O eternal wi≈øedome, being de≈øcended froÃÑ heaueÃÑ into this world aliue & whole, how doe≈øt thou come now from thence with ≈øuch a pittifull body, and ≈øo wounded in thy hands? If thou wilt know where, how, and by whome I haue receiued the≈øe wounds and ga≈øhes, know thou that I haue receiued them in the hou≈øe of ≈øuch as loued me, and they gaue them me who bare me good will. Looke how new and ≈øtrange this que≈øtion is, ≈øo maruellous is the an≈øwere; and how maruellous the an≈øwere, ≈øo ≈øtrange the que≈øtion: for it is a very ≈øtrange thing that God ≈øhould goe to heauen with wounds vpon him; and to ≈øay that his friends gaue them him, is al≈øo a very maruellous thing, becau≈øe it is the part of a friend to cure our wounds, and of an enemy to make them. What is this O good Ie≈øus, what is this? How can hee vvho loueth thee vvound thee, and hee who wi≈øheth thee well hurt thee, and hee who woundeth thee take pitie on thee, and hee vvho ≈øerueth thee offend thee? An≈øelmus handling this place ≈øayth, O eternall goodne≈ø≈øe of thee my God, and patience neuer before this time ≈øeene, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt call them openly thy friends which rent thy fle≈øh, vvre≈øt thy ≈øinewes, vnioint thy bones! To ≈øay O good Ie≈øus that thou vva≈øt vvounded in the hou≈øe of ≈øuch as loued thee, is a ≈øpeech vvhich ≈øheweth thy clemency, and giueth
me great confidence: for if thou doe call tho≈øe thy friends which doe wound thee and kill thee, what wilt thou doe by them which faithfully haue ≈øerued thee? Chri≈øt had one hou≈øe in Iury, which was Ieru≈øalem, and hee had a friend in heauen which was his Father, and he had another friend vpon the earth which was the Synagogue, and in that hou≈øe he was put to death, and hee was wounded by tho≈øe two friends: for the Synagogue did crucifie him, and his Father did determine that he ≈øhould be crucified. If the Gentiles which were not his friends & acquaintance ≈øhould haue put him to death, it would haue been tollerable: but to ≈øee that he was wounded & ≈ølain in the city where he had liued, & by his friends which he had made much of, & by the wil of his Father which begat him, did grieue him very much, although he did di≈ø≈øemble it. Barnard ≈øaith, The more I think vpoÃÑ thy works O good Ie≈øus, the more I wonder; ≈øeeing that man hauing done the deeds of an enemy towards thee, thou can≈øt not call him enemy but friend, coÃÑ≈øidering that thou ≈øai≈øt, I haue been wounded in the hou≈øe of ≈øuch as did loue me. By which words hee doth let vs vnder≈øtand, that he regardeth more the loue which hee beareth vnto the world, than the offences which the world doth vnto him. If as good Ie≈øus ≈øaid vnto the Angels, my friends haue thus wounded me, hee would haue ≈øaid vnto his Father that his enemies had done it, what ≈øhould then haue become of the poore Iewes, and what afterward of vs all? As when friends in ie≈øting doe hurt and ≈øcratch one another, ≈øo Chri≈øt would make the Angels and his Father beleeue, that his enemies had not wounded his ≈øacred hands, but that his friends had done it as it were in ≈øporting. O how truly we may ≈øay with the Prophet Dauid, Non e≈øt deus no≈øter ≈øicut dijeorum, Our God is not like vnto their gods, ≈øeeing that here vpon earth men take in earne≈øt the words which their friends ≈øpeak in ie≈øt to them, and if they ≈øcratched with a pin, or with ones naile, they make no le≈ø≈øe a matter of it, than if it were a thru≈øt with a lance. The which quality could not ≈øincke into Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing that before his father, he called his enemies his friends,
his whipping ≈øcratching, his deep wound a rai≈øing of the skin, and earne≈øt te≈øting. S. Augu≈øtine vpon the≈øe words, Amice ad quid veni≈øti, ≈øayth, this word Enemy, O good Ie≈øus, wil not enter into thy mind, becau≈øe thou art accu≈øtomed to call euery man friend: for ≈øeeing that thou didde≈øt call Iudas thy greate≈øt enemy thy friend, whome wilt thou call enemy? O≈øculantes ≈øe ad inuicem fleuerunt pariter Dauid & Ionathas; ≈øed Dauid fleuit amplius. 1. Reg. chap. 20. The≈øe holy words are rehear≈øed in ≈øcripture, talking of the friend≈øhip that was betwixt Dauid and Ionathas: and this is their meaning; As king Dauid was departing out of the kingdome, and going from Ionathas his faithfull friend, at the time of their departure they embraced one the other, and wept; and although Ionathas did weepe much, yet Dauid did weepe more. Mimus the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, That the loue which one friend beareth another, is neuer better knowne than when the one departeth from the other; for if the one want words, the other aboundeth in teares. Cicero in his booke of Friend≈øhip ≈øayth, That true friend≈øhip is knowne in going the one from the other, becau≈øe that in their embracing the one the other, they change their hearts, in ≈øo much that this mans heart goeth away with him, and his heart remaineth with this man. It ≈øeemeth that Dauid and Ionathas vvere great friends, ≈øeeing that they did embrace one another ≈øo heartily, and wept ≈øo tenderly. Dauid did much more e≈øteem of the friend≈øhip of Ionathas, than of the hatred of his father king Saul: the which was ea≈øily ≈øeene to bee ≈øo, con≈øidering that when Saul made a truce betweene them, Dauid pre≈øently departed out of the kingdome. Dauid vvith all his wi≈øedome and force dur≈øt neuer abide the per≈øecution of Saul his enemie, vvithout his friend Ionathas aid: vvhereby vvee may inferre, that there is no griefe in this life equall to the lo≈ø≈øe of a friend. Bee hee (≈øaith Seneca) poore or be hee rich, be hee great or be hee little, how is it po≈øsible for him to liue without a friend? Horace ≈øayth, That if a man be in pro≈øperous e≈øtate, he hath need of one to giue him coun≈øell, if in meane to comfort him: for I haue heard (≈øayth he)
my mai≈øter Menander ≈øay, that a fortunate man hath as great need of good coun≈øell to gouerne him≈øelfe by, as the needy man hath need of helpe to lift vp him≈øelfe by. If then the mighty haue need of good coun≈øell, and the poore of helpe and ≈øuccour, who can better giue vs good coun≈øell, or ≈øupplie our vvants than a friend? E≈øchines in an inuectiue again≈øt Demo≈øthenes ≈øayth, That an enemy can doe his enemy no greater vvrong, than take his good friend from him, becau≈øe hee taketh away the ≈øecret of his heart, the refuge of his trauails, the remedy of his nece≈øsities, and reliefe and cheri≈øhing of his per≈øecutions. Plutarch maketh mention, that when Denis the Tyrant did ≈øcoffe at Phocion the Philo≈øopher, for that he vvas poore, hee made an≈øwere thus, I confe≈ø≈øe vnto thee that I am poore, but yet Denis is poorer: for although hee abound in money yet hee vvanteth friends, and I haue friends inough but vvant money. That Philo≈øopher thought it a greater pouerty to want friends, than to want money: wherein hee had great rea≈øon, becau≈øe that in tribulation or ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, it doth ea≈øe a man better to ≈øee two or three friends at his beds head, than to haue his che≈øts & coffers full of gold and ≈øiluer. There are many (≈øayth Vbertinus) vvhich are poor of money, & not of friends, and others which are poore in friends and not in money, and there are ≈øome which are poore in the one and in the other, of which ≈øort Chri≈øt is the chiefe, ≈øeeing that on the cro≈ø≈øe, he had no man which vvould be≈øtow a cup of water vpon him, nor any one which would giue him one word of comfort. Chri≈øt complaineth of the Apo≈øtles becau≈øe they fled, complaineth of his parents becau≈øe they did hide them≈øelues, complained on his acquaintance becau≈øe they did not ≈øticke vnto him, becau≈øe that in all the conflict of his pa≈øsion hee had no friend which followed him, no kin≈øman which defended him, nor acquaintance which backed him. Chri≈øt had (≈øayth Rabanus) very honourable and vertuous friends, and valerous acquaintance; but vvhen they ≈øaw him weake in ≈øtrength, and poore in wealth, all of them left him in his troubles, becau≈øe they vvould not bee the partakers
of his daunger. Saint Barnard crieth out and ≈øayth, What meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, vvhat meaneth this? There vvanteth not one in Ieru≈øalem to defend Barrabas, and dooth there vvant one before Pilate to defend thee? Doth Barrabas by ≈øtealing find friends, and doe≈øt thou by preaching get enemies? Doth the murderer of the quicke find defenders, and doth the rai≈øer of the death find accu≈øers? Doe they condemne him who made an attonement betwixt God and man, and doe they ≈øet him at liberty who di≈øquieted all Ieru≈øalem? O vnhappy and wicked Ieru≈øalem, will there be alwaies ≈øome in thee to per≈øecute the good, and defend the wicked? Venerable Bede ≈øayth, That al tho≈øe which were Barrabas friends, were Chri≈øts enemies, and all tho≈øe which were Chri≈øts friends, were Barrabas enemies: for with the ≈øame note and voice that they cried, doe not let goe any but Barrabas, they ≈øaid of Chri≈øt, crucifie him. S. Augu≈øtine in an Homily ≈øaith, That becau≈øe the twife doubling of a word is the true token of loue or hatred, the Iewes did well ≈øhew the loue which they bare vnto Barrabas, in de≈øiring Pilute twi≈øe to let him loo≈øe, and the hatred which they bare to Chri≈øt in ≈øaying twi≈øe, Crucifie, crucifie him. For to ≈øay twife Non dimittas nobis ni≈øi ‚Ä¢ arrabam, what el≈øe was it then to aske with all their hearts that hee would grant that thiefe his life, and ≈øend him to his hou≈øe that fea≈øt of Ea≈øter? And to crie out twi≈øe aloud, crucifie, crucifie him, what el≈øe would they ≈øay to Pilate, but that they aske with their tongues, & entreat with their hearts that hee would put Ie≈øus of Nazareth vpon the gibbet, or put him to death vpon the cro≈ø≈øe? Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øaith, The Prince of the Synagogue, and the ruler of Capernaum, Centurio the captaine, Zacheus the rich, and Simeon the leaper, and Lazarus the knight, were not all the≈øe, trow you, Chri≈øts friends and acquaintance, and of the riche≈øt and honourable≈øt among the people? Chri≈øt did very much for euery one of the≈øe, wheÃÑ he was aliue, but there was none of the≈øe which did any thing for him wheÃÑ he died, although he went by their gates to be crucified, and with their eies they did ≈øee
him die. Chri≈øt then had great rea≈øon to ≈øay vnto his Father, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me, con≈øidering that him≈øelf had too many enemies, and Barrabas wanted no friends.

div.head: CHAP. VI. How Chri≈øt complaineth vnto his father, becau≈øe they made more account of Iepthes daughter in the Synagogue, than they doe at this day of his death in the church.
div.p:
FAc mihi quodcunque pollicitus es, conce≈ø≈øa tibi victoria & vltione de inimicis tuis. chap. 12 of the Iudges. The daughter of that famous captaine Iepthe ≈øpake the≈øe words vnto her father when her father returned from the war which the people of I≈ørael had again≈øt the king of the Ammonites: as though ≈øhe wold ≈øay, Do with me O my Father, doe with me what plea≈øeth thee. For ≈øeeing that thou doe≈øt come victorious from the warre, it is very iu≈øt and rea≈øonable that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt performe that which thou ha≈øt promi≈øed our Lord. Iepthe had promi≈øed and made a ≈øolemne vow, that if God would giue him the victory of that warre, that he would offer vnto him the fir≈øt liue thing of his hou≈øe which he ≈øhould meet withall; and although it were aliue vvhen hee ≈øhould meet it, yet he vvould not offer it but killed and dead. Iepthe then returning from the vvarre vvith a great victory, his ≈øorrowfull fate vvas, that hauing but one only daughter, ≈øhe vvent to meet him & receiue him comming home ≈øinging and playing on a Taber. Immediately as the ≈øorrowfull Father ≈øaw his vnfortunate daughter, his eies were full of vvater, and his heart brake in two, vvhen hee remembred the vow vvhich he had made in the vvarre, and that he could do no le≈ø≈øe than kill his daughter. The father then ≈øaid vnto his daughter, O my daughter and ≈øole inheritrize, how vnfortunate vvas thy de≈øtinie, and how vnlucky vvas my fortune,
in that I mu≈øt open my mouth, and make that promi≈øe to ≈øuch great preiudice to thy life, and hurt vnto my hou≈øe? His daughter an≈øwered him and ≈øaid, If thou ha≈øt opened thy mouth, my father, to make any vow vnto the great God of I≈ørael, let mee bee no hinderance for the performance of it: for I vvill like it well, onely becau≈øe I ≈øee thee victorious ouer thy enemies. And ≈øhe added further and ≈øaid, only I aske of thee my father, that thou woulde≈øt giue mee two months ≈øpace before thou doe≈øt ≈øacrifice mee in the Temple, to bewaile my Virginity in the≈øe ≈øorrowful mountains with others my companions. And when tho≈øe two months were pa≈øt, (the tender virgine bewailing and weeping the lo≈ø≈øe of her life and virginity vnbe≈øtowed) the Father performed his vow, and ≈øacrificed his daughter. Becau≈øe Iephthe that captaine had that famous victory, but yet with vufortunate lo≈ø≈øe of his onely daughter, all the young maids and virgines of the people of I≈øraell agreed a meeting to weepe and lament the death of Iephthes daughter foure daies in the yeare; and although the people of the Iewes did omit thinges of greater weight than that was, yet they did neuer forget to mourn and lameÃÑt tho≈øe daies. The holy ≈øcripture doth promi≈øe vs many great matters in this figure of Iephthe, worthy to be knowne, & hard to expound. Who is vnder≈øtood by the famous captaine Iephthe, but the ≈øonne of the liuing God, and redeemer of the world? He who ≈øaid, all power is giueÃÑ me in heauen and earth, is more valerous and mighty than Ieph the was, becau≈øe that Iephthes authority extended no further than the land of Iury, but the ≈øonne of Gods did reach ouer heauen & earth. The ≈øcripture maketh mention, that when Iephthe was a yong man, tho≈øe of his countrey put him from his fathers inheritance, & bani≈øhed him out of the land, and how that in progre≈ø≈øe of time hee deliuered them from their enemies, and vvas captaine ouer them all. That which the neighbours of Gilead did to Iephthe, the inhabitants of Ieru≈øalem did to Chri≈øt, whome they bani≈øhed out of the Synagogue, and depriued of his Fathers inheritance: and yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe hee deliuered them from
their ≈øinnes, and vvas the red ‚Ä¢ emer of them all. The truth doth very vvell an≈øwere to the figure in this place, and the ≈øence vnto the letter. For as they which did bani≈øh Iephthe out of all the kingdome, did afterward entreat him to bee their guide and captaine: ≈øo tho≈øe which ≈øaid to Pilate, crucifie, crucifie him, did afterward on the Mount of Caluary ≈øtrike their brea≈øts and ≈øay aloud, Ver√® hic filius deifuit, This man was truly the ≈øon of God. Who was vnder≈øtood in Iepthes daughter, a virgine faire and young, but only that fle≈øh and humanity of the Word? S. Ambro≈øe vpon tho≈øe words Specio≈øus ≈øorma, ≈øayth, Who is ≈øo beautifull, who is ≈øo pure, who ≈øo holy, as that mo≈øt ≈øacred fle≈øh vvas and is? The daughter of Iephthe was not knowne of any man, and Chri≈øts humanitie was al≈øo vnknowne of man, ≈øeeing that it was not conceiued by con≈øent of husband, but formed and framed by the vvebe of the holy gho≈øt. Iephthe did promi≈øe to offer in the Temple his only daughter for the victory which hee had obtained again≈øt his enemies, and Chri≈øt did promi≈øe to offer vpon the cro≈ø≈øe his owne fle≈øh for the victory and conque≈øt vvhich he had again≈øt ≈øinnes; ≈øo that Iephthe did offer only the daughter vvhich hee had begotten, and the ≈øonne of God did offer his owne proper body. Is it not thinke you a greater matter for a man to offer his owne fle≈øh, than that vvhich is born of his fle≈øh? Iephthe vvas very loath and grieued to offer his onely daughter, and it vvas a great corra≈øiue to the daughters heart, to ≈øee her ≈øelfe ≈øacrificed by her owne Father: but in the end ≈øhee vvas more ioyfull and glad of the victory vvhich her Father receaued again≈øt his enemies, than grieued that her owne life ≈øhould bee ≈øacrificed. O how vvell one my≈øtery doth an≈øwere vnto another! for vvhen the fle≈øh ≈øaid, Let this cup pa≈ø≈øe from mee, vvith the daughter of Iephthe hee vvas loath to die: but vvhen hee ≈øaid, Not as I vvill, but as thou vvilt, hee was glad to ≈øuffer: ≈øo that that ≈øacred fle≈øh vvas very vvilling to bee ≈øacrificed, becau≈øe that the diuine Word ≈øhould obtaine victory ouer ≈øinnes. Doe≈øt thou not
thinke my brother, that one my≈øtery doth very vvell an≈øwere another, and that one ≈øecret is very vvell compated vvith another, ≈øeeing that that virgine vvas ≈øacrificed for her fathers honour, and that diuine and ≈øacred fle≈øh al≈øo ≈øacrificed for the honour and glory of his father? Iepthe had a great reuenge ouer his enemies, but Chri≈øt a farre greater ouer ≈øinne: and yet it is to be noted, that by how much the greater tho≈øe two victories vvere, ≈øo much the more greater vvere the prices vvhich they vvere bought for, becau≈øe the one did co≈øt his daughters life, and the other his owne. What can be deerer than that vvhich doth co≈øt a mans life? Pellem pro pelle & cuncta dabit home pro anima≈øua, ≈øaith Iob chapter 2. The Scripture maketh mention in Iob, that as there appeared before the iudgement of God many vvicked men, the deuill made one among them: for good men doe neuer a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues to doe good, but Sathan is there al≈øo to doe them ≈øome hurt. Our Lord ≈øaid vnto Sathan, from vvhence doe≈øt thou come, and vvhither ha≈øt thou gone? To this Sathan an≈øwered, I haue gone about all the earth, and vvalked through it, to ≈øee whether I could happen vpon any more that vvere mine. Our Lord replied, ha≈øt thou ≈øeene my good ≈øeruant and tru≈øty friend Iob, vnto vvhome no man on the earth may bee compared? And doe≈øt thou not know Sathan that Iob is a holy man, ≈øincere in condition, vpright in his con≈øcience, fearfull in that vvhich the law commandeth, vvithout malice, & one vvho continueth till this day in his innocency? Thou ha≈øt ≈øtirred me vp again≈øt him, that I ≈øhould kil his ≈øonnes, de≈øtroy his ≈øheepe and deere, and that his oxen ≈øhould be ≈øtolne froÃÑ him, and all his vvealth taken from him, and that I ≈øhould depriue him of all his honour. Sathan an≈øwered vnto this and ≈øaid, Know Lord, that a man vvill giue all his vvealth & ≈øub≈øtance vvith condition to ≈øaue his life. Pellem pro pelle dabit hemo, that is, A man vvill giue al his ≈øheepe skins, & all the cowes hides in the vvorld to keepe his owne fle≈øh. If thou vvilt trie Lord vvho thy friend Iob is, lay thy hand vpon his owne per≈øon, and fill his bodie with a lepro≈øie, and then thou ≈øhalt ≈øee, that hee
will bee more grieued to ≈øee his body plagued, than to ≈øee his goods taken from him. This then was the rea≈øoning and dialogue which pa≈ø≈øed betwixt God & the diuell touching Iobs tentation: whereof we may inferre, how much more that is to be e≈øteemed which the ≈øonne of God offered, than Iephthes ≈øacrifice, becau≈øe the one offered his daughter, and the other his owne proper life. The victory which Iephthe had, was a co≈øtly victory vnto him, but Chri≈øts was more co≈øtly, becau≈øe that Iephthe did ouercome and liue, but the ≈øonne of God did ouercome and die, and there is no dearer victory in the world than that which is bought with the exchange of a mans proper life. Although Iephthe did loue his onely daughter well, yet Chri≈øt did loue his precious fle≈øh better, becau≈øe it was vnited vnto the diuine e≈ølence, and therefore the better hee did loue it, the more was his griefe in lo≈øing it. Ari≈øtotle ≈øayth, That wi≈øe men doe loue their liues better than others of the vulgar people, becau≈øe they ≈øee them≈øelues more nece≈ø≈øary vnto the Commonwealth, and euery common good is to be preferred before a particular. And according vnto this ≈øaying of the Philo≈øopher, as the ≈øonne of God was wi≈øer than all men, and better than all men, ≈øo without doubt by ≈øo much the more he loued his life, by how much it was mo≈øt profitable to all men. Sathan ≈øaid well Pellem pro pelle dabit homo, A man will giue one skin for another. For if a man would haue asked the captaine Iephthe which of the≈øe two thinges he would rather haue done, either haue ≈øacrificed his daughter, or his owne per≈øon, it is to bee thought that hee would rather haue ≈øacrificed his daughter twi≈øe, than his owne per≈øon once. Seneca in his booke of Clemency ≈øayth, That becau≈øe it is a naturall thing vnto vs to liue, and a dreadfull and fearefull thing to die, wee are much afraid of our owne death, and beare another mans ea≈øily. Theophilus ≈øaith, That it is much to be maruelled that Chri≈øt would die; but it is much more to bee wondered at, that hee would die with ≈øo good a will, becau≈øe that without augmenting his glory, yea rather dimini≈øhing it, hee offered him≈øelfe
willingly vnto them, to the end that they ≈øhould take his life from him. The figure ≈øayth further, that Iephthes daughter, went two months weeping and wailing her virginity on tho≈øe ≈øolitary mountains, with other virgines and maids which bare her company. What was the meaning that that pare virgine, bemoned and bewailed her virginity, but onely that ≈øhee was ≈øorry that ≈øhee had not been married, and had a husband, and that ≈øhe had no children to mourne for her death, or inherite her goods? It ≈øeemeth to bee a di≈øhone≈øt matter for a virgine to weepe, and bewaile her owne virginity, if there were no other hidden ≈øence vnder this letter, becau≈øe that in ≈øcripture the more ob≈øcure a ≈øaying is, the more fuller it is of my≈øtery. Wee haue already ≈øaid that Chri≈øts ≈øacred fle≈øh is figured by that tender virgine, and now wee ≈øay againe, that as Iephthes daughter bewailed her owne virginity, ≈øo did Chri≈øt likewi≈øe his: only it is to be noted, that there is a difference betwixt weeping and weeping, virginitie and virginity. The ≈øonne then doth complaine on his father ≈øaying, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me: which he vttered becau≈øe hee had not emploied his mo≈øt pure virginity and mo≈øt holy innocency as he de≈øired to doe: for as he was borne a virgine, a virgine hee died; and if hee came innocent into the world, with his innocency hee returned vnto heauen againe. Let no man thinke that Chri≈øt bewailed and wept his virginity, becau≈øe hee did inuiolably keepe his mo≈øt holy fle≈øh: for if his mother did not lo≈øe it in bringing him into the world, neither could hee lo≈øe it by liuing in the world. The cha≈øtity which the ≈øcripture ≈øpeaketh of, and the virginity which Chri≈øt bewaileth with Iephthes daughter, is not the corruptible virginity, but the incorruptible, not the virginity of the body, but of the ≈øoule, the which doth make our Lord great with holy ≈øpeeches and diuine in≈øpirations; and therefore if hee bee great with the≈øe diuine in≈øpirations, he bringeth forth afterward holy workes. S. Augustine vpon tho≈øe wordes, De≈øpon≈øauit te mihi in fide ≈øayth, Spirituall and holy men haue as great need to marry their foules with Chri≈øt, as worldlings haue to ≈øeeke husbands
for their daughters: and if I haue ≈øaid as great, now I ≈øay more need; becau≈øe a maid may bee ≈øaued without the company of a husband, but a ≈øoule cannot be ≈øaued vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øhe take Chri≈øt with her. S. Barnard ≈øayth, O how farre more higher is the ≈øpirituall matrimony, than the corporall! the one is betweene the wife and her husband, the other betwixt the ≈øoule and Chri≈øt; of the one come children, which ≈øometimes do breed griefe & anger, of the other there do proceed workes which doe alwaies good. If Iephthes daughter doe weepe her departing out of this world a virgine, euen ≈øo doth Chri≈øt weepe and lament his virginitie, becau≈øe hee hath left no greater a ≈øpirituall po≈øteritie after him: for he would willingly haue left all the hearts in the world great with child with good & vertuous de≈øires, and all ≈øoules deliuered of good workes. When God ≈øaid by the Prophet E≈øayas, Numquid ego qui alijs generationem tribue, ≈øterilis ere? That is, Shall I be barren my ≈øelfe and giue i≈ø≈øue vnto others? hee did not ≈øpeake this for any de≈øire which hee had to marry him≈øelfe with any woman, but for the great zeale which hee had to marry and couple him≈øelfe with our ≈øoules; becau≈øe that in all ages and all times the cha≈øtity of the body is a holy thing, and in all ages & all times the barrenne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øoule is naught and di≈øcommendable. What doe≈øt thou weepe for then O good Ie≈øus, what doe≈øt thou weepe? I weepe my virginity with the daughter of Iephthe, becau≈øe I haue ≈øcar≈øe found any in all the world who will marry with my diuine grace, nor who will be great with child with my diuine in≈øpirations: and that which I mi≈ølike mo≈øt of all is, that if I begin to dally and make loue with any ≈øinfull ≈øoule, ≈øhe turneth her backe towards mee, and is ready to flie from mee. I bewaile my virginitie, becau≈øe that in three and thirty yeares which I haue liued in the world, with al the ≈øermons which I haue preached, and with all the dead which I haue rai≈øed vnto life, and with all the diuels which I haue ca≈øt out, and all the ≈øinnes which I haue forgiuen, it ≈øeemeth vnto mee that I haue made ≈ømall gaine, and done little good in re≈øpect of the paines which I haue taken.
I bewaile my virginity, becau≈øe that being come in per≈øon into the world, hauing in≈øtructed all the people, ≈øhed my bloud, rent and torne my fle≈øh, lo≈øt my reputation, and be≈øtowed my life, yet I ≈øee now that there is ≈øcar≈øe any one found who would benefit him≈øelfe with my bloud, or who is thankful vnto me for my benefites be≈øtowed vpon him. I bewaile my virginity, becau≈øe I haue found none to be≈øtow my virginity on, none to giue my innocency vnto, none to impart my patience vnto, none vnto whome I may communicate my charity, nor any one with whom I may leaue my humility in keeping: but if I came rich and adorned with vertues in the world, ≈øo I mu≈øt return rich again with theÃÑ to heauen. The figure which wee haue ≈øpoken of, ≈øaith further, that all the maids of Sion did meet in Ieru≈øalem to mourn and weep the death of Iephthes daughter foure daies one after another, in the which they made great lamentations, ≈øo that no yeare did pa≈ø≈øe, in which this ≈øolemnity was not ob≈øerued. It is here to be noted, that although there haue beene in the ≈øynagogue many per≈øonages, noble in bloud, valerous in warre, di≈øcreet in the Commonwealth, learned in all ≈øciences, and cleane and vn≈øpotted in life, yet it is not read of any of theÃÑ, that after they were dead and buried, were mourned for at any other time. Al the kings, Dukes, Patriarks, and Prophets were buried by their friends and kin≈øfolkes, and forgotten of them, excepted onely the daughter of Iephthe, for who≈øe death all the virgines and maids did mourne and weepe euery yeare once by a ≈øpeciall priuiledge. Wee ≈øpeake all this becau≈øe that if the daughters of Sion thought it conuenient to thinke vpon and weepe for the death of that virgine once euery yeare, ≈øhould it not bee greater rea≈øon that wee ≈øhould weepe for the death of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt euery houre and euery moment of an houre? Tho≈øe virgines did weepe for the death of that young virgine for no other rea≈øon but becau≈øe ≈øhe was young, beautifull and vertuous, ≈øo that they were induced to make that ≈øolemne lamentation rather through compa≈øsion than rea≈øon. What other rea≈øon could there bee for that ≈øolemne yearely lamentation,
≈øeeing that the daughter of Iephthe died not for the Commonwealth, nor yet had in e≈øtimation for any rare vertue aboue the re≈øt? Iu≈øt occa≈øion and rea≈øon doth inuite vs to weep euery houre, and euery moment of an houre, for the death of Chri≈øt, con≈øidering that he died for the Commonwealth, and paied for our offence. For the ≈øon to ≈øay vnto his father, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me, is to ≈øay nothing el≈øe, but to complaine of vs becau≈øe wee remember not his precious death, as Iephthes daughter was wept for once a yeare. Although the ≈øinfull ≈øoule doth not remember the death of Chri≈øt, yet the holy church doth not forget nor omit to celebrate his death once at the end of euery year in the holy weeke. And in ≈øteed that the daughters of Sion did weepe for the death of that virgin foure times in the yeare, the church doth repre≈øent vnto vs the pa≈øsion written four times of the foure Euangeli≈øts.

div.head: CHAP. VII. How Chri≈øt complaineth vnto his father, becau≈øe they did open his wounds through malice, as they did ≈øtop vp I≈øaac his wels through enuy.
div.p:
HAbuit I≈øaac po≈øse≈øsion ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ onium, armentorum, & familiam plurimam: ob hoc inuidentes Pale≈øtini ob≈øtruxerunt omnes putees eius, implentes humo, Gene≈ø. 26. The Scripture hath the≈øe wordes telling vs of a great di≈øcoure≈øie which the king of Pale≈øtine did vnto I≈øaac the Patriarke: and it is as if hee would ≈øay, I≈øaac was a great and mighty man, and had many flockes of ≈øheepe, and many heards of kine, and many bond≈ølaues both man and woman; by rea≈øon of which pro≈øperity of his, the Pale≈øtines did greatly enuy him, and did ≈øtop vp his wels by ca≈øting much earth into euery one of them. O that the Apo≈øtle ≈øaid very true, when hee ≈øaid, all things happen
vnto them in figura, ≈øeeing that all things that were done in the Synagogue, were nothing el≈øe thaÃÑ a figure of that which ≈øhould happen in the Catholicke church. For if it were not ≈øo, there are many things in Scripture which vvould ≈øeeme but a ie≈øt to write of, and a ≈øuperfluous thing to read. If there ≈øhould not be ≈øome deep my≈øtery & ≈øome hiddeÃÑ ≈øecret in this figure, what were it vnto vs, or what profite ≈øhould wee receiue in knowing that I≈øaac had many ≈øheepe, kine, and ≈ølaues? What were it al≈øo vnto vs, if hee had many enemies, and that they did ≈øhut vp his wels, enuy his riches, haue an ere vnto his greatne≈ø≈øe, con≈øidering that it is an old cu≈øtome, that euery rich man is enuied? This figure doth lead vs vnto higher my≈øteries than the letter doth ≈øhew, and therefore it is needfull to haue a high ≈øpirit to declare it, and great attention in reading it. To come then vnto the purpo≈øe, I≈øaac in the Hebrue tongue doth ≈øignifie a man ful of laughter and ioy: the which ioifull name can agree only vnto the ≈øonne of God, and hee only in this world in a high degree can be called I≈øaac. When rhe ≈øonne of God was in heauen aboue, and before hee came downe into this world, no mortall man knew any cau≈øe to laugh, nor yet dur≈øt not laugh: for becau≈øe that they ≈øaw that God was angrywith all the world, al the world was in a dump and mourned. When God had ≈øaid vnto Noe the Patriarke, Paenitet me feci≈ø≈øe hominem, that is, I am ≈øorry and repent that euer I made man, how could any man dare to laugh and bee merry? How dur≈øt holy Iob laugh, ≈øeeing that hee ≈øaid with many teares, Vtinam de vtero tran≈ølatus e≈ø≈øem ad tumulum: I would to God I had been buried as ≈øoone as euer I was borne. His meaning was this, O great God of I≈ørael, why ha≈øt thou brought mee out of my mothers wombe, and now that thou ha≈øt brought me out, why doe≈øt thou not de≈øtroy me, & why did de≈øt thou not carry mee pre≈øently from my mothers bowels to my graue? How could the Prophet Helias laugh, ≈øeeing that running & flying away through the mountains from Queene Iezabel, Petiuit anima ≈øua, vt moreretur? His meaning was: Am I better than my predece≈ø≈øors, that I ≈øhould
liue rather than they? Die then my ≈øoule, die, for becau≈øe that my life is grieuous vnto me, and I would ≈øee it at an end. How ≈øhould the Prophet Ieremy laugh, ≈øeeing that hee ≈øaid with deepe ≈øighes, Quis dabit capiti meo lachrimas, & oculis meis fontes lachrimarum, vt plorem interfectos populi mei? His meaning was, Who can bring to pa≈ø≈øe with the great God of I≈ørael, that he would make a ≈øea of water of my head, & change my e ‚Ä¢ es into fountaines of teares, to ≈øigh by night, and weepe by day, for tho≈øe whom ≈øinne hath deceaued, and the ≈øword ≈ølaine? How could old honorable Tobias laugh when he ≈øaid, Quale mihi gaudium erit quia in tenebris ≈øedeo, & lumen caeli non video? In tho≈øe pittifull words hee meant to ≈øay this, What ioy can there be in my heart, or what laughter can there bee in my mouth, ≈øeeing that I find my ≈øelfe poore, and feele my ≈øelfe aged, blind, and cannot ≈øee the light of heauen? Origen vpon Exodus ≈øayth, That becau≈øe the old law was a ≈øhadow of the new, and that all tho≈øe which were of the Synagogue were ≈øad and terrified, therefore they did v≈øe ≈øo many kinds of in≈øtruments, & ≈øuch diuer≈øe ≈øorts of mu≈øicke, becau≈øe that by theÃÑ they might forget the ≈øorrow & ≈øadne≈ø≈øe which they were in. But when the fulne≈ø≈øe of time came, in the which God ≈øent his ≈øonne into the world, hee brought mirth with him, he brought plea≈øure with him, hee brought the ioies of heauen with him, where they doe nothing el≈øe but laugh and reioice, as we doe nothing el≈øe but mourne and weepe. Did not trow you our ioyfull I≈øaac come laughing into the world, ≈øeeing that when hee was borne, the Angels did ≈øing, Gloria in excel≈øis Deo, Glory bee to God on high? Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, That if the words which God ≈øpake, and the works which he did be weighed with grauity, they doe all giue vs ioy & comfort, and put vs in a great confidence of our ≈øaluation, and take away the di≈øtru≈øt of damnation, becau≈øe hee ≈øpake and did much more in the fauour of clemency than hee did in the rigour of iu≈øtice. And becau≈øe wee may not ≈øeeme to ≈øpeake at randome, it is rea≈øon that wee bring forth ≈øome few ≈øentences which hee vttered in the fauour of mercy and pittie.
Chri≈øt to the Hebrewes ≈øaid, If any man ≈øhal keepe my vvord hee ≈øhall not die for euer; that is, His ≈øoule ≈øhall neuer peri≈øh. Si quis ≈øermonem meum ≈øeruauerit, non morietur in aeternum: It is rea≈øon that wee marke who ≈øpake the≈øe words, vvhy hee ≈øpake them, and vnto whom hee ≈øpake them. Hee who ≈øpake them was our laughing I≈øaac, and the cau≈øe vvhy hee ≈øp ‚Ä¢ ke them vvas, becau≈øe he vvould make the vvorld re ‚Ä¢ oice vvith ≈øuch good news: & yet for a recompence for this good newes they rewarded him very badly, ≈øeeing that becau≈øe he ≈øaid in Pilates hou≈øe, that there vvas another world, & that his kingdome was not of this vvorld, they clothed him with purple in Herods hou≈øe as if he had been a foole. He ≈øpake the≈øe vvords vnto the cur≈øed Iewes when they called him a Samaritane, which vvas as much as to call him an Hererike; & when they ≈øaid that hee had a diuell, which was as much to ≈øay, that hee was a Nigromancer. Doe≈øt thou not think, my good brother, that our merry I≈øaac vvas full of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ughter, vvheÃÑ he an≈øwered ≈øo ≈øweetly vnto ≈øuch outragious bla≈øphemie? O ≈øweet an≈øwere, O heauenly ≈øpeech! vvho but thou did promi≈øe vs another life, after that this vvas ended? Doe≈øt thou not think that our I≈øaac is full of laughter, ≈øeeing that vvhen the Iewes doe goe about to ≈øtone him, hee putt ‚Ä¢ th him≈øelfe betwixt God and our faults, to the end that they may charge all the blowes vpon his backe? Did not hee laugh, trow you, vvhen as hee had ca≈øt the Diuell out of them, yet they called him a man po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed vvith a Deuill? When the ≈øonne of God ≈øaid that his yoke vvas ≈øweet, hee did let vs vnder≈øtand thereby plainly, that his holy lavv vva ‚Ä¢ a cheerefull lavv, a gracious lavv, and a loifull lavv: and ≈øo truly it is, becau≈øe all good men keepe it cheerefully, and all naughty men breake it vvith vveeping. Secondly the figure aboue named ≈øaith, that I≈øaac vvas very rich, and that hee had many flockes of ≈øheepe, and many heards of kine, and a great number of bond≈øl ‚Ä¢ ues both men and vvomen. To ≈øay the truth the ≈øonne of God had neither ≈øheepe, nor kine, nor bondmen; but hee f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d that vvhich was ≈øignified by them,
becau≈øe his comming into the world was not to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe ≈øheepe and kine, nor to be wealthy in them, but his comming was to redeeme our ≈øoules, and to bee a mediator for our ≈øins. div.head: CHAP. VIII. How the ≈øonne of God complaineth of his Father, becau≈øe they did load his body with ≈øtripes, and his heart with care and angui≈øh.
div.p:
IN flagella ego paratus ≈øum, & dolor meus in con≈øpectu meo ≈øemper, ≈øayth the Prophet Dauid ≈øpeaking in the name of the ≈øon of God, and it is as if hee would ≈øay, Doe by me O good Father, doe by me what thou thinke≈øt good: for I am ready to ≈øuffer all the ≈øtripes that thou wilt lay vpon mee, becau≈øe I can neuer forget nor put out of my mind the griefe which I haue conceiued in knowing that I mu≈øt ≈øuffer. Such dolefull words as the≈øe are, doe well ≈øeeme to proceed from a man which is in great angui≈øh, and from one who ≈øeeth him≈øelfe condemned to die, confe≈øsing and prote≈øting that he dieth for obedience ≈øake, and that he taketh his death with patience: doth not he die for obedience, who offereth him≈øelfe vnto death, and doth not hee take his death in patience, who knoweth not how to coÃÑplain? There are ≈øome per≈øons vvhich feele no labour and paine but of the mind, as great lords; and there are others which feele no paine but of the body, as labourers; and ≈øome which neither feele them in mind nor bodie as fooles; and ≈øome there be which feele them both in the mind and the body, as vertuous men doe. Seneca in his booke of Clemency ≈øayth, That the labour of the mind doth weary
