ETdolor meus in coÃÑ≈øpectu meo ≈øemper, ≈øaith Chri≈øt in the ≈øame P≈øalme: as if hee would ≈øay, Among all the dolours which I ≈øuffer, there is one of them of ≈øo euill a condition, that it neuer departeth out of my ≈øight. Although the complaint which Chri≈øt formeth in this place, doe containe but few words, yet it is full of many graue ≈øentences: for he complaineth not of many griefes but of one, hee ≈øayth not that it is another mans griefe but his owne, hee ≈øayth not that it is in an others mans ≈øight but in his owne, and
hee hath it not by fits, but cootinually. If the Prophets doe not ri≈øe againe to tell vs, and if the Angels doe not declare it vnto vs, how can wee be able to gue≈øte what griefe it is which la≈øted ≈øo long, and the complaint which hath no end. If the ≈øonne of God had been di≈øea≈øed of a drop≈øie, or gout, or pal≈øie, we could haue ≈øaid that as his infirmity was, ≈øuch had ben his griefe: but ≈øeeing that wee doe not read that hee was euer ≈øick who can gue≈øle what his griefe ≈øhould be? It cannot ea≈øily bee comectured what this griefe was, ≈øeeing hee calleth it but dolor, one griefe: wee know not whether it was the griefe of his agony, or of the pillar, or of the piercing of the ≈øpeare, or the yeelding vp of his gho≈øt, becau≈øe euery one of the≈øe griefes doe breed a feare in vs when vvee thinke of theÃÑ; how much more to ≈øuffer them? When Chri≈øt ≈øaith that my griefe is alwaies in my ≈øight, it is a thing to make vs both wonder & feare: for ≈øeeing that Chri≈øts griefes were ≈øo many in number, and ≈øo cruell in torment, what ≈øhould he meane to complaine vpon one, ≈øeeing that they were without number and count? Wee cannot deny but that Chri≈øt ≈øuffered many bitter torments: but there is one more principall than all the re≈øt, the which is ≈øuch a one, and ≈øo grieuous a one, that vntill this pre≈øent day it runneth bloud in thy pre≈øence, and cannot bee taken away while≈øt this life doth la≈øt. What griefe can be compared vnto this grief, ≈øeeing it hath his beginning in this world and doth not end in the other? This long griefe is the great vngratefulne≈ø≈øe which is in vs for our redemption & the ≈ømal c ‚Ä¢ re which we had that hee ‚Ä¢ as put vpon the cro≈øle for vs; in ≈øo much, that the griefe whereof he complaineth vnto his father, was cau≈øed neither by the thornes, nor nailes which pierced him, but by vngratefull and vnthankfull men who did not acknowledge him. S. Barnard ≈øpeaking of our dury to God ≈øayth, If thou wilt know what God hath made thee, looke vvhat he hath done for thee: for in thy mi≈øerable nature the vvorkes of his infinite benignity doe appeare. How much the ba≈øer thy God made him≈øelfe in humility, ≈øo much the greater he made thee in goodne≈ø≈øe, and how much the more viler
hee made him≈øelfe for mee, ≈øo much the more familiar and like hee made me vnto him. Take heed then man, that thou be not prowd, ≈øeeing that thou art made of dirt, and ≈øee that thou bee not vnthankfull and vngratefull vnto God, ≈øeeing that thou art ≈øo neer coupled vnto him, becau≈øe an vngratefull man was neuer plea≈øant nor acceptable vnto God. It is the part of a peruer≈øe mind, to ≈øeeke occa≈øions and ≈øhifts to excu≈øe him≈øelfe, & not to be gratefull for the benefites which he hath receiued: the which kind of trea≈øon and naughtine≈ø≈øe is proper only vnto ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe men, and to ≈øuch as haue dead hearts, and as it were without a ≈øoule. Who is he who cannot be thankfull for a benefite receiued, but he who neuer knew to doe good vnto others? All this is S. Barnards ≈øpeech. Ca≈ø≈øiodorus ≈øayth in an Epi≈øtle, That it is a hard matter to ≈øuffer, and not ea≈øie to di≈ø≈øemble, that a wi≈øe & di≈øcreet man ≈øhould gather no fruit of his trauaile, but that hee ≈øhould rather receiue hurt from whence hee hoped for remedy, in ≈øo much that he ≈øuffereth hurt without an offence giuen, puni≈øhment without a fault, griefe without cau≈øe, paine without ≈øin, per≈øecution without an enemy. Naughty mens manners would bee much wor≈øe than they are, if there were none to cha≈øti≈øe vice and reward vertue. Lactantius ≈øayth, That which Imaruell at in men is, that if they bee ≈øicke they commend them≈øelues pre≈øently vnto God, if they haue warres they run to God, if they want water they aske it of God, if they bee mole≈øted with a plague, they turne to God, if they goe by ≈øea, they offer them≈øelues vnto God; but that which cannot bee ≈øpoken without griefe is, that after God hath deliuered them out of tho≈øe dangers, no man thinketh more of God. Do not thinke it (≈øayth Seneca) to bee a ≈ømall misfortune vnto thee, if by chance thou ha≈øt lighted vpon an vngratefull friend, becau≈øe that as a benefite or good turne is woont to make of a foe a friend, ≈øo the ≈øame benefite is wont to make an enemy of him who was thy friend. For it is the property of an vngratefull man, that the more that he is bounden vnto any man for any benefite receiued of him, the more he hateth him of whom
he hath receiued it: and the wor≈øt of all is, that they would ≈øee him dead of whom they receiued it, and not be thankfull at all for it. Thou doe≈øt complaine, O my friend Lucilius, that thou ha≈øt fallen vpon more than an vngratefull man, and that of an old friend hee is become thy new enemy, and if thou woulde≈øt enter into the coÃÑ≈øideration of this lo≈ø≈øe, thou ≈øhoulde≈øt ab≈øtaine from euer doing any good turn vnto any: which I doe not coun≈øell thee to doe, nor yet that thou coun≈øell any man to doe it, becau≈øe it is better that men accu≈øe the other of vngratefulne≈ø≈øe, than thy ≈øelfe of couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and that the benefite bee lo≈øt in the other, rather than rot in thee. There is no vice more common among men, than for one man to be vngratefull vnto another, which doth proceed oftentimes, hereof, that men know not how to make choice of their friends, or for that they doe not be≈øtow their benefites well: and therefore oftentimes we haue greater rea≈øon to complaine vpon our ≈øelues, for not knowing how to giue, rather than of others, becau≈øe they bee vngratefull for the good turnes which they haue receiued of vs. Cicero in his third booke of laws ≈øayth, Clari≈øsimi viri Athenis pul≈øi carere ingrata ciuitate maluerunt, qu√†m manere in improba, as if hee would ≈øay, Many famous men in watres, and learned in ≈øciences, haue been bani≈øhed from Athens, not for any fault which they committed, but for malice conceiued again≈øt them; the which were rather willing and glad to liue in bani≈øhment than to dwell in an vngratefull citie. Valerius Maximus ≈øayth, That the mo≈øt notable≈øt man that the renowmed Lacedemonia did euer bring forth, was that great Philo≈øopher Lycurgus, becau≈øe among all tho≈øe which liued before his time, & tho≈øe which ≈øucceeded him, there was none equall vnto him in knowledge, nor none which went beyond him in life. The Oracle of Pithius Apollo, being asked in what reputation he did hold Lycurgus, made an≈øwere, I am very doubtfull vvhether I ≈øhould put him among the number of men, or place him among the companie of Gods. Notwith≈øtanding that the Oracle had giuen this high te≈øtimony of Lycurgus, and that
he was pure in his life, eloquent in learning, con≈øtant in paines, and very wi≈øe in his lawes, yet all the≈øe vertues and excellent gifts could not keepe him from proouing the vngratefulne≈ø≈øe of his thankle≈ø≈øe citizens. And therefore they did not onely iniury him in words, but al≈øo they did ≈øhew by cruell deeds the hatred which they bare him, and the hurt which they wi≈øhed him: for once they burned his hou≈øes, and another time they followed him with ≈øtones, and another time they da≈øhed out one of his eies, another time they expelled him from among the people, and in the end for a recompence and reward of gouerning that Commonwealth eight and thirtie years, they bani≈øhed him out of the country, and ≈øo hee died. Plautus ≈øayth, That there is no loue wor≈øe be≈øtowed than that which is be≈øtowed vpon an vngrateful man, becau≈øe that man loueth nothing at all who loueth an vngratefull man. I haue ≈øpoken all this again≈øt the vice of vngratitude, and v≈øed ≈øo many examples, becau≈øe euery man might perceiue what great rea≈øon God hath to complaine vpon vngratefull men: for ≈øeeing that the Philo≈øophers doe inueigh ≈øo bitterly again≈øt them, it would be but ≈ømall rea≈øon that they ≈øhould be defended by Chri≈øtians. S. Cyprian ≈øayth, Chri≈øt doth complaine of our ingratitude, becau≈øe that for ≈øo great & vn≈øpeakable a benefite as he did for vs in dying vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, hee did not bind vs to follow him in that kind of death, or that we ≈øhould die for him by the ≈øword, but that which good Ie≈øus did bind vs vnto is, that we ≈øhould haue his ble≈ø≈øed pa≈øsion in a remembrance, and loue him with all our heart. How ≈øhall any man (≈øayth Barnard) beleeue that thou wilt venter thy life for Chri≈øt, and for his faith, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt not remember his death in all thy life? If thou wilt (≈øayth Vbertinus) haue the death of Chri≈øt help thee in thy la≈øt houre, remember that death of his euery day; becau≈øe the ≈øonne of God doth alwaies take pittie vpon tho≈øe in their la≈øt houre, vvhich doe remember his pa≈øsion in their life time. Chri≈øt ≈øaith, And my griefe is alwaies before my eies, becau≈øe that among all the griefes which are, ingratitude is cau≈øe of
the greate≈øt of them, and among all the ≈øinnes and naughtine≈ø≈øe which are, this is the greate≈øt: for if there were no vngratefull men vnto God, there ≈øhould bee no ≈øinne at all in the world. Chri≈øt doth cal the ≈øinne of vngratefulne≈ø≈øe dolour and griefe, becau≈øe that hee is alwaies grieued with it: for the griefe which hee had of the thornes is pa≈øt, his whipping had an end, and the paine of the cro≈ø≈øe dured no longer than his life did la≈øt, but the griefe of ingratitude is renued in him daily. Chri≈øt doth al≈øo ≈øay, that the griefe which hee doth complaine of is his owne griefe, Dolor meus: by which louing ≈øpeech he doth let vs vnder≈øtand, that he is much more grieued to ≈øee vs ≈øinne, than it grieueth vs to be ≈øinners. Why doth Chri≈øt ≈øay in his complaint, my griefe, and not our griefe but onely becau≈øe that wee doe not feele ≈øo great paine and griefe when we are puni≈øhed by him, as good Ie≈øus feeleth to thinke that he mu≈øt puni≈øh vs. I would to God that it would plea≈øe his diuine clemency, that I were ≈øo ≈øory to commit an offence, as it doth grieue him to puni≈øh me: for then I thinke that I ≈øhould not know how to ≈øinne, nor God ≈øhould haue nothing to puni≈øh. He complaineth al≈øo that he doth not only ≈øuffer griefe, but he ≈øayth that that grief is alwaies in his ≈øight; and therefore becau≈øe wee doe neuer giue ouer ≈øinning, it is certaine, that his griefe of compa≈øsion wil neuer haue an end. Cea≈øe then my brother, and giue ouer ≈øinning, and then the paine which thou doe≈øt endure, will pre≈øently haue an end. When thou ≈øhalt heare vs ≈øay that God hath any griefe or paine, thou mu≈øt not thinke that it is a griefe or paine which hee ≈øuffereth, but onely a mo≈øt entire and louing compa≈øsion which he hath vpon vs. When the ≈øonne of God ≈øayth vpon the cro≈ø≈øe vnto his Father, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee, the chiefe≈øt complaint that hee formeth in that place is, becau≈øe hee cau≈øeth him to ≈øuffer ≈øo cruell a pa≈øsion for ≈øuch vngratefull people.

div.head: CHAP. IX. How the ≈øonne of God complaineth vpon the Synagogue, that hauing carried them vpon his backe, yet they be vngratefull vnto him.
div.p:
AVdite me domus Iacob, & re≈øiduum domus I≈ørael, qui portamini ab vtere meo, v≈øque ad ≈øenectam. God ≈øpake the≈øe words by the Prophet E≈øayas chap. 46, as if he would ≈øay, Hear me now, he are me all you of the hou≈øe of Iacob, and all you which haue e≈øcaped of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael, giue credite vnto my words, ≈øeeing that I am the God which carry you vpon my ≈øhoulders, from the houre of your birth vntill your death. Vnder the≈øe few words God doth touch very many great matters: for fir≈øt he beginneth to call them, then he biddeth them giue eare, then he ≈øaith that it is hee who calleth them, then he noteth who they bee whom hee calleth, then how vvell he loueth them, when hee ≈øayth, Qui portamini ab vtero ad≈øenectutem, But we mu≈øt note fir≈øt of all in this place, why the Lord doth ≈øeperate the hou≈øe of Iacob froÃÑ the hou≈øe of I≈ørael, and why hee doth call the hou≈øe of Iacob an entire hou≈øe, and the hou≈øe of I≈ørael a broken and di≈ø≈øolued hou≈øe: for he ≈øayth, heare mee all you of the hou≈øe of Iacob, all you of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael which haue e≈øcaped, and remaine. If Iacob and I≈øraell, and I≈ørael and Iacob bee all one thing, and all one hou≈øe, fauing that one man had two names, how vvas it po≈øsible for the one to ≈øtand, & the other to fal? In very truth in old time all the Synagogue had but one God, one people, one linage, one king, one law; but when they began to ≈øinne and play the Idolaters, our Lord did immediately deuide theÃÑ. By the one hou≈øe & by the other are vnder≈øtood the church
and the Synagogue, whereof the one, which was Iacobs, came wholly vnto the church, and I≈øraels fell vnto the Synagogue, but almo≈øt ouerthrowne, not becau≈øe ≈øhe de≈øerued it not, but becau≈øe all which was written might bee fulfilled. According vnto this Prophecy, the Angell ≈øaid vnto the virgine in his emba≈øie, He ≈øhall raigne in the hou≈øe of Iacob, & he ≈øaid not, he ≈øhall raigne in the hou≈øe of I≈ørael, becau≈øe the Synagogue did then draw towards an end, and the church vnto her beginning in the ≈øonne of God. God then calleth the hou≈øe of Iacob, which is the church, calleth tho≈øe which remained of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael, which is the Synagogue, becau≈øe Saint Peter was the re≈øidue of I≈ørael, and Saint Paul was the re≈øidue of I≈ørael, and all tho≈øe of his Colledge were the remnant of I≈ørael, the which the ≈øonne of God vvent throughout all the Iewi≈øh nation to gather together as it had been crummes of bread hurled abroad. Now that wee know what the hou≈øe of Iacob is, and tho≈øe who remained of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael, it is now rea≈øon al≈øo that wee know what hee will doe vvith them, and why he doth call them, and why he v≈øed a ≈øpeech vnto them, which was neuer hard of before, that is, that hee doth beare them vpon his ≈øhoulders from their mothers wombes. God will haue nothing el≈øe with them, but onely that they beleue in him and heare him, ≈øeeing he ≈øayth, Audite me Heare me: and withall hee doth put them in remembrance of the great benefites that hee doth for them, to wit, carry them vpon his ≈øhoulders, Portamini ab vtere; and therfore if we will haue Gods fauour, we mu≈øt beleeue the words which he doth ≈øpeake, and bee thankfull vnto him for all the benefites that hee ≈øhall be≈øtow vpon vs. Robertus vpon E≈øay ≈øayth, If wee will compare that which God requireth at our hands with that that hee doth giue vs, vvithout compari≈øon hee doth bind him≈øelfe vnto more than that which hee doth bind vs vnto: for hee doth bind vs to nothing, but to beleeue in him, and hee doth bind him≈øelfe to maintaine and gouerne vs, Ab vtero v≈øque ad ≈øenectam: that is, from the time that wee bee fir≈øt borne, vntill our dying
day our Lord doth bind him≈øelfe to bring vs vp like his children, and maintaine vs like his brothers, in ≈øo much that like a pittifull Father, and a mercifull Lord, hee giueth vs that which we haue need of, and coun≈øelleth vs that which we haue to doe. O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, and exceeding charity of thine, my good God, con≈øidering that by this ≈øpeech, Ab vtero portamini, thou doe≈øt bind thy ≈øelfe to giue vs food to liue vvith, and by Audite me, thou doe≈øt bind thy ≈øelfe to giue vs coun≈øell to ≈øaue our ≈øelues vvith! and therefore vvee haue of thee a Lord to helpe vs, and a Father to coun≈øell vs. Our Lord, vvhich did create vs, is a better Father vnto vs than man vvhich doth beget vs, ≈øeeing that hee ≈øayth, Qui portamini ab vtere: By vvhich fatherly ≈øpeech hee doth let vs vnder≈øtand, that hee doth not only prouide for our nece≈øsities, but doth al≈øo di≈ø≈øemble our iniquities. O that our Lord doth ≈øay very vvell, Qui portamini ab vtero, ≈øeeing that hee doth beare vs on his ≈øhoulders as oft as hee doth vvinke at our wickedne≈ø≈øe: for if hee ≈øhould puni≈øh vs for euery fault according vnto his iu≈øtice, wee ≈øhould by this time haue had no memory left of vs. If our Lord ≈øhould not beare vs vpon his ≈øhoulders, and di≈ø≈øemble vvith our faults, to prouoke vs to repentance, hee ≈øhould ≈øcar≈øe haue any at all to puni≈øh aboue two or three houres; and for the fir≈øt ≈øinne only, if it had plea≈øed him, he might haue condemned vs to hell. What temporall father doth ≈øo long ≈øuffer his owne children, as our Lord doth all vs. What father doth carry his child in his armes aboue an houre, as our Lord doth vs all our life time? Before wee bee borne, wee offend him in originall ≈øinne, & after we be borne we offend him al the re≈øt of our life with other grieuous ≈øinnes; yet notwith≈øtanding all this, hee doth bring vs vp like his children, and deale vvith vs like brothers. What vvoulde≈øt thou haue mee ≈øay more vnto thee, but that from our mothers wombe our wickedne≈ø≈øe doth ≈øtriue with his goodne≈ø≈øe, hee in forgiuing vs and wee in offending him: O great goodne≈ø≈øe and vn≈øpeakable clemency! what father or mother did euer the
like for their children, that thou my good Ie≈øus ha≈øt done for my ≈øinfull ≈øoule? There is no liuing creature this day in the world, that doth giue milke vnto his young ones aboue two yeares: but our eternall Father and Chri≈øt his precious ≈øonne, from our birth vntill our old age, doth giue vs the milke of his grace, the bread of his doctrine, the helpe and ≈øuccour of his church, the pardon of his clemency, and the reward of his glory. Dilexit me & tradidit ≈øemetip≈øum pro me, ≈øayth S. Paul ‚Ä¢
as if hee would ≈øay, Doe not maruell, you Galathians, that I did preach ≈øo vehemeÃÑtly vnto you, & that I did exalt Chri≈øts name with ≈øuch great feruency: for I tell you if you know it not, that be≈øides that hee loued mee very much, hee ≈øuffered him≈øelfe to be crucified for me. This is ≈øo ≈øtrange a thing, that S. Paul ≈øpeaketh of in this place, that vnle≈ø≈øe a man bee acquainted with the phra≈øe of Scripture, hee would take ≈øcandale at it: for when Paul ≈øaith that Chri≈øt died for him, not mentioning any other, he ≈øeemeth to exclude the redemption of all the world be≈øide. What meaneth this, O diuine Paul, what meaneth this? if the ≈øonne of God did giue him≈øelf for thee, why doe≈øt thou preach him to bee the redeemer of all mankind? Were thy ≈øinnes ≈øo grieuous and ≈øo enormious that they had need of all Chri≈øts bloud to redeeme them? If God ≈øhould ≈øend into the world a new redeemer for the taking away of euery ≈øinne, how were it po≈øsible that God could ≈øend ≈øo many, ≈øeeing that hee had no more ≈øonnes but Chri≈øt? Tell me I pray thee, how could ≈øo glorious a humanity, ≈øo profitable a life, ≈øuch ≈øound doctrine, ≈øuch a copious redemption, ≈øuch a dreadfull death bee emploied in thee alone, and not benefite any but thy ≈øelfe? If it bee ≈øo O Paule that Chri≈øt gaue him≈øelfe for thee, and not for me, what haue I more to doe with Chri≈øt than with a holy Prophet? If hee died for thee alone, is it not rea≈øonable that thou alone ≈øholde≈øt be thankfull for his death? God forbid that it ≈øhould be ≈øo, neither doth his mercy permit that the Apo≈øtle onely ≈øhould be redeemed, and all the world be≈øides depriued of the bloud of Chri≈øt: for his redemption was ≈øo copious, and
there was ≈øuch abundance of bloud ≈øhed for vs, that on Chri≈øts part redemption did abound, and there wanted on ours to be redeemed. Did not redemption, think you, abound on his part, ≈øeeing that one drop of his bloud was ≈øufficient for all redemption; and did there not want on our ≈øide, ≈øeeing that if there had ben an hundred thou≈øand worlds, he would haue redeemed euery one of them? When the good Apo≈øtle ≈øaid, Tradidit ≈øemetip≈øum pro me, hee ≈øpake it not to extenuate and dimini≈øh Chri≈øts pa≈øsion, nor ≈øtraiten his redemption, but to confe≈ø≈øe before all the world, that what≈øoeuer the ≈øonne of God had ≈øuffered vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, hee was as much and as ≈øtreitly bound to bee gratefull for it, as if hee had died for him alone. S. Augu≈øtine in his booke of Chri≈øtian doctrine ≈øayth. As our Lord did know euery mans offences in particular, ≈øo hee did redeem euerie of them particularly, in ≈øo much that euery man in particular is as greatly bound vnto him for his bloud; and as certaine a debtour vnto him for his death, as if hee ≈øhould haue redeemed him alone, and ≈øuffered for him only and no other. Theophil ≈øayth, Euen as in thy creation thou art as greatly bound vnto God as if he ≈øhould haue created thee and no other, ≈øo in thy redemption thou art ‚Ä¢ s greatly bound vnto him, as if he ≈øhould haue redeemed thee & no other: for at that time when he bought thee, he gaue as much for thee as for all men, and as much for all men, and no more, as for thee. S. Barnard ≈øaith. If the ≈øonne of God ≈øhould haue redeemed a thou≈øand thou≈øand of worlds, he would haue giuen no more bloud for them than hee did, and if hee ≈øhould haue redeemed no more but me alone, hee would haue ≈øhed no le≈ø≈øe bloud than he did: by rea≈øon whereof wee cannot de
‚Ä¢ nde his redemption betwixt vs, that thou mighte≈øt bee but meanly gratefull vnto him, and another le≈ø≈øe; but thou mu≈øt thinke that he died wholly for thee, and wholly for mee, and that euery maÃÑ is as great a debtour vnto him, as if he had died for him alone. An≈øelmus ≈øayth. Doe not thinke that Chri≈øt bought vs ingreat, and at the fir≈øt ≈øight, as flockes of ≈øheepe are bought, but hee bought euery man by him≈øelfe alone, ≈øatisfying
in particular for euery ≈øinne, ≈øo that as he found many in the world, ≈øo hee redeemed them all: but if hee had found but one ≈øinfull ≈øoule in the world, hee would haue be≈øtowed his precious bloud in redeeming her alone. I≈øidorus De≈øumme bono ≈øaith, Mark and note wel, good Chri≈øtian, that Chri≈øt did not le≈ø≈øe loue thee, than he loued me, neither did he buy thee with le≈ø≈øer trauel thaÃÑ he bought me, not giuing le≈ø≈øe bloud for one than for all. And thereupon being as it were carried away with great loue towards vs, he e≈øteemed not, nor did not look to the price which he gaue for vs, but vnto the loue with the which he bought vs. If our ble≈ø≈øed Lord would haue looked vnto the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe and ba≈øe value of that which he did buy, as hee did looke vpon the great loue with the which hee did buy vs, would hee, thinke you, haue be≈øtowed one drop of his bloud vpon vs? If humane nature ≈øhould be ioined and coupled with the nature of Angels, and that of them both there were made one nature, what could it doe, what were in it, what were it worth, that the ≈øonne of God ≈øhould ≈øhed ≈øo much as one drop of bloud for it? That it vvould plea≈øe Chri≈øt to die for vs, let vs thanke the great loue which he bare vnto vs, and not any de≈øert or merit of our owne. For if he ≈øhould haue expected at our hands that we ≈øhould fir≈øt haue de≈øerued it, he ≈øhould yet be to take fle≈øh vpon him, & to redeeme vs. Origen in his Periarchon ≈øayth, As the ≈øunne wheÃÑ he ri≈øeth, doth no le≈ø≈øe giue light vnto al thaÃÑ vnto one, & a≈øwell vnto one as vnto all: eueÃÑ ≈øo the ≈øon of God did not die more for all thaÃÑ for one, nor nole≈ø≈øe for one thaÃÑ for all. Barnard ≈øaith, O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, O in≈øpeakable charity! which of all creatures wold haue done ≈øo much for thee as thou ha≈øt done for me, that is, e≈øteem more of my ≈øoule, than of thy own life, of my honor thaÃÑ of thy fame, of my redeÃÑptioÃÑ thaÃÑ of thy pa≈øsion, & of my remedy & help than of thine own hurt. O with what great rea≈øon the Apo≈øtle did ≈øay, Tradidit ≈øemetip≈øum pro me, ca≈øting vpon him≈øelfe the whole price of the bloud of Chri≈øt, but not that which it was worth in value, but that great obligation vnto which it did bind him. The ≈øonne of God than
doth complaine to his Father, ≈øaying, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me, becau≈øe he did puni≈øh him and not the Synagogue, vvhome hee had brought vp and carried vpon his ≈øhoulders.

div.head: CHAP. X. How Chri≈øt complaineth vnto his Father vpon vs for our vngratefulne≈ø≈øe, con≈øidering that hee hath taken vpon him≈øelfe all our offences.
div.p:
QVidvltr√† debui facere vineae meae, quod non fec? Chri≈øt ≈øpake the≈øe words by the mouth of the Prophet E≈øayas, chap. 5. As if hee would ≈øay, What can any man doe more for his vineyard, or Lord for his Commonwealth, than I haue done for thee O Synagogue? The≈øe are tender words to feele, and pittiful to heare, ≈øeeing that on one ≈øide hee doth complaine of the Synagogue, and on the other he will reckon and debate the matter with her, and cono ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce her fir≈øt, that all the fault is in her and not in him, before hee doe puni≈øh her and giue her pennance. God doth debate the matter with the Iewes, as one good friend doth with another, going about to win them with the great benefires which he hath done for them, and the great ingratitude with the which they haue recompenced him. Our Lord might very well puni≈øh the Iewes without delay, and not contrary vnto the order of iu≈øtice; but yet he would fir≈øt put theÃÑ in mind of the great goodnes which they had receaued at his hands, and of their manifold ≈øinnes which hee had di≈ø≈øembled, to the end, that if they feele the ≈ømart of it, they might not iu≈øtly complaine on him. It is a cunning manner of reprehending a mans friend, to tell him of the good turnes which he hath done vnto him, and the dangers which hee hath deliuered him from, becau≈øe by this meanes hee doth not only reprehend him, but al≈øo confound him. Saint Ierome
to Martella ≈øayth, The ≈øumme of all the benefits which God can doe to vs are, to direct vs in the right way of goodne≈ø≈øe, and put from vs the way of ≈øinne and wickedne≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe wee are no le≈ø≈øe bound vnto him who dooth deliuer vs from perils and dangers, than vnto him who doth vs great good turnes. S. Gregory vpon the P≈øalmes ≈øayth, When the redeemer of the world did make our Lords praier, Pater ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ster, when hee did command vs to ≈øay, Da nobu hodie, giue vs this day, hee did al≈øo enioine vs to ≈øay, Sed libera nos, But deliuer vs from euill; by which words he did teach vs, that wee ≈øhould not onely craue helpe of him, but al≈øo be≈øeech him, that hee would deliuer vs from euill. What innumerable benefites God hath be≈øtowed on vs, E≈øay doth tell vs in this authoritie when he ≈øayth, Quid vltra debut facere vincae meae, and S. Paul when he ≈øaid, Tradit ≈øemetip≈øum pro me, where the one ≈øpeaketh of the great care which our Lord hath in gouerning and maintaining vs, and the other of the bitter paine hee tooke in redeeming vs. Our Lord ≈øayth very well, what ≈øhould I haue done more vnto my vineyard, ≈øeeing that he tooke humane fle≈øh for vs, wa≈øhed away our offences, endued vs with his grace, incorporated vs in his church, and made vs capable of glory? What ≈øhould he hauedone more, con≈øidering that he hath left vs his body to receiue, his merites to help our ≈øelues with, his Saints to imit-te, his Go≈øpel to keepe, and his Sacraments for a medicine? Quid vltra debus facere, con≈øidering how he made our bodies of nothing, created our ≈øoules to his owne likene≈ø≈øe, giuen vs Angels to guard vs, and be≈øtowed all the earth vpon vs? What ≈øhould he do more, ≈øeeing that hee hath commanded the ≈øunne to giue vs light, the earth to ≈øu≈øtaine vs, the fire to heat vs, the water to wa≈øh vs, & the aire to recreate vs? What ≈øhould he doe more for vs, ≈øeeing th ‚Ä¢ t ouer and aboue all other bea≈øts hee hath giuen vs iudgement to di≈øcerne good from bad, memory to rememberthings p ‚Ä¢ ≈øt, and a will to loue that which is holy and good? If the≈øe benefites doe ≈øeeme great vnto thee, yet I tell thee further, that he hath done more than this for thee, which thou ha≈øt forgotten,
of which our Lord wil call for an account, at the great day of his generall accounts. What are the≈øe new ≈øauours, or when doth hee vnto vs any other good turnes, but when hee turneth ≈øome dangerous hurt from vs? Griefe of mind, anxietie of heart, feares of life, ≈øuddaine pa≈øsions touching our credite and fame, with ≈øuch like as are woont to a≈ø≈øault vs euery minure of an houre, although we thinke not on them: ≈øo that if our Lord ≈øhould not keepe vs with his mighty hand, wee ≈øhould liue with paine, and die with perill. What are tho≈øe mi≈øchiefes which doe mo≈øt of all weary vs, and which are neuer from vs, but dreadfull death, vn≈øpeakable griefe, bitter teares, extreame ≈øorrow, and vntollerable feare? The≈øe fine dolours doe bait, and ouerthrow all mortal men, becau≈øe they are ≈øo common among great men, and ≈øo vniuer≈øal among the meaner ≈øort, that vntill this day we haue known none exempted from them, and wee haue heard of none who haue died and not tried them. If euery man will examine his owne per≈øon, he ≈øhall find it to bee true, that he knoweth all the≈øe mi≈øchiefes and euils, not by any ≈øcience which hee hath heard, but by experience within him≈øelfe, ≈øeeing that we ≈øee nothing el≈øe euery houre, but euery man to weepe and bewaile his infinite paines and griefes? And becau≈øe we may not ≈øeeme that we doe ≈øpeake at plea≈øure, we will ≈øpeake of euery word a little, to bring thee to remembrance, how euery one of the≈øe griefes is experimented in thy ≈øelfe. As concerning the fir≈øt, which is death, what mortall man was euer borne in this life, whom death in the end hath not made an end of, and put into his graue? With this condition we come into the world, and liue in the world, that in the end wee mu≈øt leaue the world, and that by rea≈øon of a common law which he hath giuen vs. The ≈øecond griefe are teares: and what mortall man did euer liue in this world with ≈øuch great ioy, but hath wept at ≈øome time or other, and that heartily? Horace ≈øayth, That weeping is ≈øo naturall a thing vnto all mortall men, that we be borne weeping, liue weeping, and die weeping. Demo≈øthenes ≈øayth. That a man hath need of a mai≈øter to learne all offices and
duties, vnle≈ø≈øe it be weeping; becau≈øe there is nothing wherof a man hath ≈øuch abundance and plenty, as of cares in his mind, complaints in his tongue, and teares in his eies. The third paine is ≈øorrow: for what mortall man did euer attaine vnto ≈øuch ≈øure and quiet ≈øtate of life, that hee ≈øhould neuer need to fetch at any time a deepe ≈øigh? O that it is well ≈øeene in the life of holy Iacob, that to mourne, ≈øigh, and weepe, are offices and duties ≈øo annexed vnto the mi≈øerable life of man, that we ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øee our ≈øelues dead, than free from them! The griefes which trouble our mindes are ≈øo many, and the anxieties which charge our bowels are ≈øo huge and ≈øtrong, that lamenting and vvailing is taken for a remedy, and ≈øighing for a comfort, and weeping for an ea≈øe; becau≈øe it happeneth often to afflicted minds, that the more teares they ≈øhed, the more ea≈øe their hearts receiue. The fourth paine, which is griefe: what man hath euer beene ≈øo ≈øtrong and healthy, who hath not beene throwne downe with ≈øome ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, or beaten vvith ≈øome great affliction? O that the Apo≈øtle ≈øaid very well, that vvee haue a trea≈øure in fickle ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øeeing that vvee are ≈øo weake in ≈øtrength, and feeble of health, that wee doe nothing but keepe our ≈øelues from the ≈øunne lea≈øt hee burne vs, and from cold lea≈øt it goe through vs, and from the aire lea≈øt it di≈øtemper vs, from the vvater lea≈øt it ≈øtop vs, and from meat lea≈øt vvee di≈øge≈øt it not. Auerroes ≈øayth, That becau≈øe the≈øe inferiour bodies are ≈øubiect vnto the ≈øuperiour influences of the heauens, they pa≈ø≈øe great perill, and are endangered by the ≈øtarres and planets: for the elements often changing in them≈øelues the bodies which are made of them, doe al≈øo the like. Of all the riches of this life, there is none equall or to bee compared vnto health, becau≈øe that all other paines and griefes either time doth cure, or di≈øcretion doth moderate. The fi≈øt paine, vvhich is feare: vvhat mortall man had his heart euer ≈øo at re≈øt, that no feare hath euer come vpon him, or in vvhome no ≈øuddaine pa≈øsion hath raigned? Xenophon ≈øaith, What plea≈øure or contentment can raigne in any mortall mans heart, ≈øeeing that wee ≈øuffer ≈øo many griefes without vs, and ≈øo many feares torment vs within vs. Loe then you ≈øee the≈øe fiue principal griefs prooued vnto you, although it was not needfull to prooue them, ≈øeeing wee ≈øee that all men doe die, all men weep, that all men are full of ≈øorrow, that all men complaine, and that all men liue in feare. If wee could happily meet with any man now adaies vvho would bind him≈øelfe to keepe vs from the≈øe griefes, and cure vs of the≈øe feares, vvhat vvould vvee denie him, or vvhat vvould vvee not giue him? Ver√® languores no≈øtros ip≈øe pertulit, & dolores no≈øtres ip≈øe portauit, ≈øayth E≈øayas, chapter, 54. As if hee would ≈øay, The Redeemer of the vvorld, and the heire of all eternities vvas he vvho tooke our infirmities vpon him≈øelfe, and did load and burthen him≈øelfe with all our griefes & ≈øorrows. In old time E≈øculapius the inuenter of Phi≈øick was much ≈øet by; the Greekes e≈øteemed of Hipocrates their fir≈øt Phi≈øitian; the Thebanes of Anthony Mu≈øa their fir≈øt ≈øurgeon; and the
Romanes of Archagnatus their fir≈øt Phi≈øitian, whome they adored for a time like an Idoll, and in the end ≈øtoned him in Campus Martius. The Greekes, the Romanes, the Thebans had neuer ≈øuch a Phi≈øitian as wee Chri≈øtians haue of Chri≈øt: for all other Phi≈øitions of the vvorld can but coun≈øell vs, but our great Phi≈øition hath ≈øcience to coun≈øell, experience to cure, and power to heale. S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, There was neuer any ≈øuch manner of curing in the world as Chri≈øt brought with him, becau≈øe that all other Phi≈øitions before his time, if they found any man ≈øicke, they left him ≈øicke, and if they found him in paine, they left him in paine: but holy Ie≈øus did neuer lay his band vpon any that was di≈øea≈øed, but hee left him whole. Hilarius ≈øayth, WheÃÑ the Go≈øpell ≈øaith of Chri≈øt, Totum hominem ≈øaluum fecit, bee ≈øpake it not ≈øo much for corporall infirmities, as hee did for ≈øpirituall di≈øea≈øes, the which are woont to proceed, not of corrupted humours, but of ≈øinnes vvhich had taken root. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, The ≈øonne of God did then heale me of all my griefes, when he tooke them vpon him≈øelfe: for ≈øeeing that they had ≈øuch po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of me, & ≈øo long time rooted and wxt old in me, how was it po≈øsible that any man ≈øhould take them from me, if hee had not ca≈øt them vpon him≈øelfe? Hee did ca≈øt my death vpon him≈øelfe, when he did die vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, hee did ca≈øt my ≈øorrow vpon him≈øelfe when he was in his agonie, he did ca≈øt my teares vpon him≈øelfe vvhen hee did vveepe for my ≈øinnes, hee did load my griefe vpon his owne backe when hee did ta≈øte vineger and gaule, and hee did take my feare vpon him≈øelfe, when he did feare death like a man. When a temporall Phi≈øitian commeth to vi≈øite a ≈øicke per≈øon, hee dooth comply with him by taking him by the pul≈øe, and by giuing him a regiment of life, and if hee find him to haue an ague hee leaueth him vvith it, in≈øomuch that they may better bee called coun≈øellours, ≈øeeing they doe giue coun≈øell onely, than Phi≈øitians, ≈øeeing they cure not. God forbid that any ≈øuch thing ≈øhould bee ≈øaid of our Phi≈øitian, ≈øeeing that from the time that he came down from
heauen to cure the world, he him≈øelfe became ≈øicke, & cured him who was ≈øick, and he who was ≈øicke did ri≈øe vp aliue, and the Phi≈øitian remained there dead; and the rea≈øon of that was, becau≈øe he changed the health which he brought with him, with the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe which the other had. O that this exchange was a glorious and happy exchange which thou didde≈øt make with me, good Ie≈øus, ≈øeeing that thou did≈øt change thy goodne≈ø≈øe for my naughtine≈ø≈øe, thy clemency for my iu≈øtice, thy health for my infirmity, thy innocency for my malice, and thy paine and puni≈øhment for my fault! And becau≈øe we haue made mention before of fiue notable paines & euils, with the which all mortall men are beaten and afflicted, it is rea≈øon that wee ≈øee in this place how the ≈øonne of God did bear our weakne≈ø≈øes, vnburdening vs of them, and burdening him≈øelfe with them. Ver√® languores no≈øtros ip≈øe pertulit, when he ≈øaid in the garden of Geth≈øemani, my ≈øoule is heauy vnto death: for with tho≈øe dolefull words, he loaded his ≈øoule w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h my heauine≈ø≈øe, and did vnload vpon me all his ioy. WheÃÑ did our ioy begin but in his greate≈øt ≈øorrow? So long as God did not know by experience what ≈øorrow was, we did neuer know what mirth was; and from that day that hee began to weepe, we began to laugh. Hee did truly take our infirmiries vpon him, when good Ie≈øus vpon his knees in the garden ≈øaid vnto his Father, Tran≈øeat a me calix i≈øte: for in that agonie hee did ca≈øt all my feare vpon him≈øelfe, to the end that I ≈øhould afterward be le≈ø≈øe timorous. Before that God tooke fle≈øh he was feared of all men, and did feare no man, and wicked man did feare all things, and was feared of no body: but ≈øince the time that Chri≈øt like a fearefull man ≈øaid, my ≈øoule is ≈øorrowfull and heauy, there is no rea≈øon that we ≈øhould fear any thing, for his feare was ≈øufficient to make all the world couragious S. Barnard vpon that ≈øaying, Cum ip≈øo ≈øum in tribulatione ≈øayth Seeing that thou doe≈øt bind thy ≈øelfe, O good Ie≈øus, by the≈øe words to be alwaies at hand with me, and to be by my ≈øide when I ≈øhall be afflicted and per≈øecuted, why, or for what cau≈øe, or whereof ≈øhould I bee afeard? There is no
cau≈øe to feare the fle≈øh, ≈øeeing that thou didde≈øt make thy ≈øelfe fle≈øh: there is no cau≈øe to feare the deuill, ≈øeeing that thou ha≈øt ouercome him: there is no cau≈øe to feare ≈øinne, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt brought it to an end: there is no cau≈øe to feare the world, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt ouercome it: there is no cau≈øe to feare man, ≈øeeing thou ha≈øt redeemed him; neither will I feare thee O my good Ie≈øus, but loue thee. Before that thou didde≈øt make thy ≈øelfe man, I was man who did feare; & now I am he who is feared: ≈øinne doth feare mee becau≈øe I admit him not: the fle≈øh feareth mee becau≈øe I cheri≈øh him not: the diuell feareth me becau≈øe I beleeue him not: and the world feareth me, becau≈øe I follow him not. He did then truly take our infirmities vpon him, when as vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe he did crie with a loud voice and many teares, and when hee praied and ≈øhed many teares, with the which hee did wa≈øh away our offences. He did then take our infirmities vpon him, when as in the la≈øt houre he did yeeld vp his gho≈øt, Inclinato capite, accepting the death which his Father did offer him, to transferre life into vs. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, From what time did we loo≈øe the ≈øhame of death, but ≈øince Chri≈øt did fear death? No man ought to maruell that the ≈øonne of God did feare death, but that which we ≈øhould maruell at is, that hee made his martyrs not feare death, and that they ≈øhould goe ≈øo freely to death, ≈øeeing that they goe more cheerefully to be martyred, than Princes doe goe to be crowned. The ≈øonne then doth complaine vnto his Father, ≈øaying, Why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me, becau≈øe that hauing takeÃÑ our infirmities, ≈øinnes, and ≈øorrowes vpon him≈øelfe, it is no rea≈øon that wee ≈øhould bee ≈øo vngratefull and vnthankfull vnto him.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Chri≈øt complaineth vnto his Father how badly enuy did v≈øe him: and how in Samaria they ≈øold an a≈ø≈øe head for four≈øcore pence, and they gaue but thirty for his.
div.p:
INuidebant ei fratres ≈øui, nec poterant ei quidquam pacific√® loqui. Gene≈øis, 37. chap. The Scripture declaring the great hatred which Iacobs eleuen ≈øons bare vnto their brother Io≈øeph, ≈øpeaketh the≈øe words: and the meaning is this, The elder brothers did hate the yong very much, becau≈øe his father did loue him be≈øt, and make mo≈øt of him; and their hatred and enuy grew to that depth, that they could not endure to ≈øee him, nor ≈øpeake one friendly word vnto him. Saint Paul thought that enuy was the root and foundation of the perdion of mankind, ≈øeeing hee ≈øayth, that Propter inuidiam mors intrauit in mundum: and therefore it ≈øhall be great rea≈øon that we declare what enuie is, and what hurt it doth, and who is Queene of enuy. Ari≈øtotle ≈øayth, That enuy is nothing el≈øe but a pa≈øsion of the mind, & a mortall angui≈øh to ≈øee another man in credite and honour, imagining that to be his di≈øcredit. Horace ≈øayth, The greate≈øt griefe that we haue with enuy is, that it is not in the eies, for ≈øo it would bee ≈øeene, nor in the hands, for it would bee felt, nor in the tongue, for it would bee heard, but his chaire and ≈øeat is in the ≈øecrete≈øt place of the heart and mind, where it abideth, complaining of euery man, and tormenting him who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth it. Menander ≈øaith, The mother of enuie is ≈øwelling pride, and cur≈øed ambition, and therefore they neuer goe a≈øunder, or very ≈øeldome, but where pride is there is enuy, and where enuy, there pride. S. Augustine ≈øayth, Take away enuy, and pre≈øently all that is mine, is thine, and all that is thine is mine. Origen ≈øayth, Enuy doth grow ≈øo fa≈øt vpon me by rea≈øon of the di≈øordinate loue which I beare vnto my owne per≈øon: for thereby I beare malice vnto my inferiors for feare lea≈øt they become my equals, and I enuy my equals lea≈øt they goe beyond mee, and I ≈øpight my ≈øuperiors becau≈øe they doe me no good. S. Ierome in a Sermon ≈øayth, That the difference betwixt a malicious man, and an enuious man is, that the malicious man doth loue nothing but that that is naught, and the enuious man doth hate nothing
but that which is good. S. Gregory in the fift booke of his Morals ≈øayth, The naughty man doth enuy none but ≈øuch as he ≈øeeth in higher e≈øtate than him≈øelfe, or whom hee ≈øeeth to bee of better life than him≈øelfe, or whome hee heareth better ≈øpoken off than him≈øelfe: whereof it in≈øueth, that how much the other doth grow & encrea≈øe in goodne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo much the enuious man doth vexe and torment him≈øelfe. I≈øidorus ≈øayth, Take heed of enuy, my brother, take heed; for it is nothing el≈øe but a certaine di≈øea≈øe which doth trouble thy ≈øences, burneth thy brea≈øt, gnaweth thy bowels, grindeth thy heart, wa≈øteth thy life, darkeneth thy memory, and condemneth thy ≈øoule. Seneca ≈øayth, That a man doth ≈øeldome enuy him whom he can ouercome, but him whom he cannot vanqui≈øh. And the ≈øelfe≈øame Seneca ≈øayth further, It is more expedient for vs to beware of the enuy of our friends, than of the hatred and di≈øplea≈øure of our enemies, becau≈øe the enemy carrieth his hatred in his tongue, and I take heed of him: but becau≈øe my friend hideth his enuy in his heart, it cannot be known, nor I cannot beware of him. Laertius ≈øaith, I would to God, that all enuious men had their eies ≈øcattered ouer all the world, that becau≈øe other mens goods and welfare is a torment vnto them, they might bee tormented with ≈øo many tortures, as they ≈øee other mens hap and felicity encrea≈øe. Diogenes ≈øayth, There hath no man liued in this world in fame and credite, but hee hath pre≈øently felt the worme of enuy; whereof it followeth, that the poor and mi≈øerable man doth only e≈øcape the enuious mans hands. Demosthenes in an Oration ≈øayth, What ≈øhall I doe wretched man as I am, or whether ≈øhall I goe? For if I de≈øire to liue in pouerty, mi≈øery doth weary me; and if I chu≈øe to be rich, enuie doth torment mee. To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, all this di≈øcour≈øe hath tended vnto no other end, but to admoni≈øh all men of hone≈øt life, and of a cleane con≈øcience; to beware of enny, becau≈øe the Deuill is ≈øuch a friend vnto this vice, that if hee ≈øee a man to bee very enuious, hee will tempt him with no other ≈øinne. Cicero ≈øayth, What hath cau≈øed all the vvarres
which we haue had with ≈øtraÃÑgers, & all the di≈ø≈øen≈øions which wee haue had among our ≈øelues, but aboundance of wealth, and the enuy which men haue borne vnto Rome? Although Chri≈øt vvas poore, yet hee vvas hated of the vvicked, accu≈øed of malice, and per≈øecuted vvith enuy. But his pouertie being ≈øo great as it was, and hiding his power as he did, wherof ≈øhould any man enuie him? They did not enuy Chri≈øt for the feature of his body, ≈øeeing there vvere other beautifull al≈øo, nor for his ≈øtocke and kindred, ≈øeeing there vvere others noble al≈øo; not for his eloquence, ≈øeeing there were others learned, nor for his vvealth, ≈øeeing there vvere others more vvealthy; but that vvhich they did mo≈øt of all enuy at vvas, his Catholicke doctrine vvhich hee did preach, and holy life which hee did lead, becau≈øe that none of the Prophets vvhich vvent before him, did preach of ≈øuch high points as hee did, nor yet any one of them did liue ≈øo ≈øincerely as hee did. Saint Augustine vpon tho≈øe words, Sciebat enim quod per inuidiam tradidi≈ø≈øent eum ≈øayth, The enuy conceiued again≈øt good life, is more dangerous than that vvhich is bred by rea≈øon of our vvealth: for if hee bee a naughtie man vvhich is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this vvealth, hee vvill endeuour him≈øelfe rather to encrea≈øe his ≈øub≈øtance, than amend his life. Let vs compare then the enuie vvhich Iacobs ≈øonnes bare vnto their brother Io≈øeph, vvith the enuie vvhich they did beare vnto Chri≈øt, and vvee ≈øhall ≈øee how vvell the figure dooth an≈øwere vnto the thing figured, and the ≈øpirit vnto the letter, ≈øeeing that the one vvas fold by enuie into Aegipt, and the other al≈øo through enuie crucified. Io≈øeph did mi≈ølike his brothers doings, and therefore they did enuie him; and Chri≈øt did not like the Iewes doings, and therefore they did hate him: and they did per≈øecute Io≈øeph becau≈øe hee did accu≈øe them before their father; and enuied Chri≈øt becau≈øe hee did reprehend them before the people. The Iewes malice towards Chri≈øt vvas greater than Io≈øephs brothers again≈øt him; for Io≈øeph
was onely ≈øold, but innocent Ie≈øus was not onely ≈øold, but al≈øo crucified. Io≈øephs brothers could not giue him one faire word, neither could the Iewes hear Chri≈øts doctrine with patience: and therefore if his diuine prouidence ≈øhould not haue kept him from their fury, they had taken Chri≈øts life long before away from him. Nolunt audire te, quiae nolunt audire me filij hominis, quia omnis I≈ørael e≈øt attrita fronte, & duro corde, ≈øaid God vnto the Prophet Ezechiel: as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, Bee not angry O Ezechiel, bee not angry, if thou perceiue that thou doe≈øt no good with thy ≈øpeech, and ha≈øt no credite among them: for ≈øeeing that they doe not beleeue me, it is not to bee maruelled though they doe not heare thee: for the hou≈øe of I≈ørael is growne now vnto that madne≈ø≈øe, that it hath neither con≈øcience in her ≈øoule, nor ≈øhame in her face. The≈øe are the words of the eternall Father, directed vnto his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øon, letting him vnder≈øtand by them what ≈ømall fruit hee ≈øhould reape by his doctrine, and what ≈ømal credite they would giue vnto his ≈øpeech; & the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe that all tho≈øe which were of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael were inwardly without a good ≈øpirit, and outwardly without ≈øhame. According vnto this ≈øpeech of the Prophet ≈øuch Prelates as gouern & preach, do toile & labor exceedingly, wheÃÑ the ≈øubiects which heare theÃÑ, are a people without any con≈øcience, & of le≈ø≈øe ≈øhame. For be≈øides that they do no good among theÃÑ, there is al≈øo great danger to liue among them. Ezechiel did very well couple ≈ømall con≈øcience with ≈ømall ≈øhame, and ≈ømall ≈øhame with a ≈ømall con≈øcience, becau≈øe that you ≈øhall neuer or very ≈øildome ≈øee a ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe man, but hee is without con≈øcience, nor a man without con≈øcience but is al≈øo ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe. Wickedne≈ø≈øe for wickedne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øinne for ≈øin, A Chri≈øtian can haue no greater ≈øinnes than to bee ob≈øtinate in heart, and without ≈øhame in his face, becau≈øe that hell is full of none but of ≈øuch as are of an ob≈øtinate heart and impudent countenance. The man which is of a tender and ≈øoft heart, and ≈øhamefa≈øt in his behauiour, is ea≈øily amended, and doth now and then ≈øinne by ≈øtealth; but he who is hard harted & ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe in condition,
doth late or neuer amend his ≈øinne, becau≈øe he careth not for being counted a ≈øinner. When Chri≈øt ≈øaid, Gaudete & exultate, quia nomina ve≈øtra ≈øcripta ≈øunt in caelis, he gaue vs heence to be glad of nothing, but only that we were good Chri≈øtians, and regi≈øtred in the booke of Saints; and likewi≈øe that wee ≈øhould be ≈øorry of nothing ≈øo much, as to be naughty Chri≈øtians, and blotted out of the booke of life: for he was borne in an euill houre, who doth not endeuour to amend his life, and doth not care at all to ≈øinne. We ≈øpeake all this to proue that the Iewes vvere of a ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe forehead and hard hearted, ≈øeeing that Pilate did know plainely, that they did accu≈øe Chri≈øt through enuy and malice, which hee gathered by the ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe ≈øpeeches which they v≈øed again≈øt Chri≈øt, and the fal≈øe proofes which they alledged again≈øt him. Facta e≈øt fames magna in Samaria, ita vt caput a≈øini vaenundaretur octoginta argenteis, 4 Reg. 6. The Scripture rehear≈øeth this, to ≈øhew the great mi≈øery and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe that Samaria was in, as if it would ≈øay, When Samaria vvas at warres with the Arabians, being be≈øieged and afflicted with famine, an a≈ø≈øe head vvas worth foure≈øcore rials, and a certaine mea≈øure of Pigeons dung fiue rials, ≈øo that they had no meat to eat but a≈ø≈øes, and nothing to dre≈ø≈øe it with but Pigeons dung. Although the fle≈øh of an a≈ø≈øe bee loth≈øome to eat, and Pigeons dung filthy to burne, yet notwith≈øtanding vvee vvill draw ≈øome my≈øtery of this figure, to aduance Chri≈øts honour by it, becau≈øe there is no word in holy Scripture which hath not ≈øome ≈øecret hidden vnder it. In this figure of the a≈ø≈øe is repre≈øented the great warre that Chri≈øt found in mans nature. What other thing was the warre vvhich Samaria had vvith the king of Arabia, but the di≈øplea≈øure & anger which God had again≈øt the Synagogue? What was the great dearth & famine which they endured, but the exceeding want which they had of good doctrine? What did it meane that an a≈ø≈øes head was ≈øold ≈øo deerly, but only that a good man was little worth, & a naughty man highly e≈øteemed? By the Pigeons dung wherewith they did dre≈ø≈øe the a≈ø≈øes head, is meant nothing el≈øe but the
Mo≈øaicall ceremonies with the which they did offer vp their ≈øacrifices. There fell nothing vnto the Synagogues lot but the dregs, and the wine vnto the church; to the Synagogue the barke, and vnto the church the fruit; the thorne vnto the Synagogue, and the ro≈øe vnto the church; the Pigeons dung to the Synagogue, and to vs the Pigeon. The warre betwixt God and mans nature, was farre more cruell, than that which was betwixt the city of Samaria and the king of Arabia, becau≈øe men did nothing but ≈øight with God with their ≈øinnes, and God did nothing vnto man but inflict puni≈øhment vpon him. If they aske the ≈øonne of God why hee came into this world, and took humane fle≈øh vpon him, he will an≈øwer them, that his comming was to relieue this famine, and appea≈øe this warre, in te≈øtimony whereof the Angels in heauen did ≈øing, when Chri≈øt was borne, Peace, Peace; ≈øeeing that I am a meane between you, there mu≈øt be no more anger left. WheÃÑ the ≈øonne of God came into the world, the warre cea≈øed, and when he began to preach, the famine began to cea≈øe, becau≈øe that this famine, which humane nature was afflicted with, was not cau≈øed for want of corporall food, but for want of vertuous meÃÑ. The want of victuals dured in Samaria but the ≈øpace of one yeare, but the want of vertuous men continued in the Synagogue from the time of the valerous Machabeans vntill the comming of Chri≈øt: for from that time vntill Chri≈øts comming, they had no Prophet to giue them light, no captaine to defend them, no Prie≈øt to teach them, nor any other famous man to reioice in. Who did euer find a greater dearth in the world than that which Chri≈øt found among the Iewes? Seeing that he found the princely ≈øcepter broken, the prie≈øthood at an end, the Temple robbed, the city peruerted, and her libertie lo≈øt? There was a great dearth in the Synagogue, con≈øidering that there was not in her one per≈øon of account. For he did not chu≈øe the twelue Apo≈øtles for his companions becau≈øe they were holy, but becau≈øe hee meant to make them holy. There was a great famine in Samaria, ≈øeeing the gouernour was Pilate, who was a Tyrant, the bi≈øhop was Cayphas,
who was a prophane per≈øon, the Phari≈øies were coun≈øellers, who were Hypocrites, the Preachers were Sadduces, who were Heretikes, and their gouernours were Romanes, who were Gentiles and Pagans. How was it po≈øsible that there ≈øhould bee any good in a Commonwealth, which was gouerned by ≈øuch naughty gouernours? As in the vnfortunate Samaria they had no kine nor calues left, ≈øo al≈øo the Synagogues Patriarkes and Prophets were at an end, and that which was wor≈øt of all was, that as Samaria was con≈øtrained to feed vpon a≈ø≈øes heads, ≈øo the Synagogue was forced to bee gouerned by naughty and wicked men. Wee doe not ≈øay much in ≈øaying that they were gouerned by wicked men: for wee might with good rea≈øon call them a≈ø≈øes, ≈øeeing they had no di≈øcretion to know that vvhich was good, nor wi≈øedome to e≈øchew that vvhich vvas naught. Doe≈øt thou not thinke that Pilate the iudge vvas a very a≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing hee confe≈ø≈øed before them all, that hee found no cau≈øe to put Chri≈øt to death, and yet Tradidit illum voluntati eorum? Thou doe≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, Pilate, that Chri≈øt was vvithout fault: and yet doe≈øt thou condemne him to die? Was not the High-prie≈øt Cayphas a very a≈ø≈øe, to ≈øay that Chri≈øt bla≈øphemed, becau≈øe hee ≈øaid that hee would come to iudge the vvorld? Art thou iudge of the vvorld which is not thine, and vvilt thou not let him iudge the vvorld vvho hath created it? Was not, thinke≈øt thou, King Herod a great a≈ø≈øe for clothing Chri≈øt in fooles apparrell, becau≈øe Chri≈øt vvould not giue him an an≈øwere, ≈øeeing that for that act hee ≈øhould rather haue accounted him wi≈øe than otherwi≈øe? Wherein could the ≈øonne of God haue better ≈øhowne his di≈øcretion and patience, than in not an≈øwering vnto any iniury, and in not mi≈øgouerning him≈øelfe in any word? Was not all the vvhole congregation and coun≈øell of the Iewes, a very a≈ø≈øe in thy opinion, in that they did crie for libertie for Barrabas, and procured that Chri≈øt ≈øhould die? The Synagogue did not buy Barrabas life ≈øo good cheape, as Samaria did the a≈ø≈øes head, becau≈øe the a≈ø≈øes head was bought for money, but Barrabas life
did co≈øt Chri≈øt his bloud. It was not worth ≈øo much, and yet they gaue more in Samaria for an a≈ø≈øes head, than they did for Chri≈øts bloud in Ieru≈øalem, ≈øeeing they gaue but thirty peeces of money for Chri≈øt, and foure≈øcore for the a≈ø≈øes head. To ≈øpeake morally then; men buy the a≈ø≈øes head deerely, when they chu≈øe for the gouernour of a Commonwealth, or Prelate, a ≈øimple and vndi≈øcreet man; becau≈øe that in all canonicall elections, the learned is to bee preferred before the ≈øimple, and the wi≈øe before the vndi≈øcreet. There mu≈øt needs be a great famine in that mona≈øtery, in which they chu≈øe for their head, ≈øuch a one as is light in behauiour, ba≈øe in linage, a foole in his iudgement, & an a≈ø≈øe in his con≈øcience. The Prophet did not ≈øay in vaine, Cum ≈øancto ≈øanctus eris, & cum peruer≈øo peruerteris; For a wi≈øe man can bring vp but wi≈øe men, a wicked man nothing but wicked men, and an a≈ø≈øe none but a≈ø≈øes. O thou who≈øoeuer thou art who doe≈øt hear or read this, doe not thinke that we call tho≈øe a≈ø≈øes who haue but ≈ømall or no learning, but tho≈øe which haue no con≈øcience, nor no bringing vp: for he is often fitter to gouern who hath great experience & di≈øcretion, than hee who is full of knowledge & folly. We do not call him an a≈ø≈øe who is ignorant in Logick, & Philo≈øophy, and Diuinity, becau≈øe that in Vniuer≈øities men learn rather to di≈øpute than gouerne, make Sillogi≈ømes, than rule ≈øubiects. When a Prelate is vnplea≈øant in his conuer≈øation, hard in charity, variable in his opinion, ≈ølacke in iu≈øtice, negligent in praier, the≈øe we call a≈ø≈øes, and vnworthy of ≈øuch a calling; for, for my owne part, I had rather my Prelate ≈øhould be experienced in gouernement, than skilfull in learning and knowledge.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Chri≈øt complaineth vnto his Father, that all other martyrs had their paines and troubles inflicted vpon them at diuers times, and he his all at once.
div.p:
EGre≈ø≈øus e≈øt frater eius, in cuius manu erat coccinum, quem appellauit Zaram, Gene≈øis 38 cha. As if he would ≈øay, Thamar brought foort ‚Ä¢ two children at one birth, and both aliue; of the which, the one they called afterward Zaram, which was the la≈øt of the two, and was borne with a ≈øcarlet thred tied at his finger: which for a certaine was a ≈øtrange thing to behold, and deepely to be con≈øidered of. If wee will curiou≈øly ≈øeeke out the meaning of this figure, we ≈øhall find that it containeth a deepe my≈øterie, pertaining directly vnto our purpo≈øe, becau≈øe it ≈øheweth how ≈øoone our redemption began in Chri≈øt. That two children haue been borne at one birth wee haue ≈øeene often, and that one ≈øhould be borne before the other we haue al≈øo heard: but that the one ≈øhould haue his finger tied and not the other, is a thing that hath neuer been ≈øeene nor hard of; and therefore by how much the thing is more rare, by ≈øo much it is the fuller of my≈øtery and ≈øecret. Deepely then expounding this ≈øigure, who were the two children born at one birth, but only the humane & diuine nature, which ≈øaued the world? The two children who≈øe names were Phares and Zaram did know no other mother but Thamar, and the diuine and humane nature did acknowledge no other father but God: for as it is an ea≈øie matter for a father to haue many childreÃÑ, ≈øo it is a hard & impo≈øsible thing for Chri≈øt to haue many fathers. Although tho≈øe two children were very naturall, and neere brothers the one to the other, and of one belly, yet they were neuer ≈øovnited together, as the diuine and humane nature was vnited in Chri≈øt, becau≈øe the≈øe two were neuer ≈øeperated in Chri≈øt in his life, nor ≈øeuered at his death vpon the cro≈ø≈øe. And as one of the≈øe two children was borne before the other, ≈øo the redeemer of the world was fir≈øt God before hee was man, and was fir≈øt born of his Father, according to his diuinity, than he was of his mother, according to his humanity. We know well that of the two brothers Phares and Zaram, the one was born after the other: but the diuine birth was ≈øo farre before the other,
that we find no beginning of it, becau≈øe it was Ab aeterno. Of the≈øe two brothers the fir≈øt of theÃÑ was borne in health, pure and cleane, and without any marke at all, to giue vs to vnder≈øtand, that Chri≈øts fir≈øt birth, which was his diuinity, did returne againe as whole, faire, and clean to heauen, as it came from heauen; becau≈øe it is the natural condition of the diuine e≈ø≈øence, that how much the ≈øtraiter his power is ioined vnto it, ≈øo much the ≈øtranger and further it is from all kind of ≈øuffering. What did it mean that the other brother was born with a coloured thred tied about his finger, but that Chri≈øt ≈øhould ≈øhed his bloud for the redemption of all the world? O good Ie≈øus, O redemption of my ≈øoule! thou doe≈øt ≈øee well, that to come out of thy mothers wombe with thy finger tied, is nothing el≈øe but to come into the world condemned to death. Zaram onely, who was the figure, and the ≈øonne of God, who was the thing figured, were tho≈øe who had their finger tied with a coloured thred, becau≈øe he and no other was to die for the world, and redeeme vs out of ≈øinne. What other meaning had the thred of ≈øcarlet, ≈øauing onely the ≈øhedding of his precious bloud? The difference betwixt thee, O my ≈øweet Ie≈øus, and other condemned per≈øons is this, that they are tied in a hempen cord, and thou in a thred of ≈øcarlet, and they about the necke, and thou about the finger, and they are lead to be hanged, and thou to be crucified. A thiefe is led away bound with a great tope, becau≈øe he is drawne to death by force, but the ≈øonne of God is tied with a ≈ømall fine thred, becau≈øe hee dieth not by force, but of his owne free will: for if it were not his good plea≈øure ≈øo to doe, neither the Angels, nor men, nor the diuels were able to put him to death. O high my≈øtery, O diuine Sacrament! who euer ≈øaw or heard, that before a child were borne, or knew what ≈øinne was, yet that he ≈øhould come out of his mothers wombe already condemned? What mercy can be compared vnto this, that before his mother ≈øhould giue him milke to ≈øucke, his owne father threatened him that he ≈øhould die crucified? Elegit ≈øu≈øpendium anima mea, & o≈ø≈øa mea mortem, & nequaquam vltra iam viuam, ≈øaith Iob chap. 7.
And he ≈øpake them when his children were dead, and his body plagued, and his goods lo≈øt, and him≈øelf vpon the dunghill; and it is as if hee would ≈øay: My paines and dolours doe ≈øo narrowly be≈øet mee about, and my griefe is come to that bitterne≈ø≈øe, that my ≈øoule hath cho≈øen to be hanged, and my life to come at an end, becau≈øe I am a weary to ≈øuffer any longer, and doe loath my life. Such pittifull complaines as the≈øe are, and ≈øuch tender vvordes, cannot proceed but from an afflicted and grieued heart, and from a man which de≈øireth death. Becau≈øe it is the property of one which is di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, to complaine vnto all tho≈øe which comfort him, & fill him≈øelfe with weeping with all tho≈øe which come to vi≈øite him. What el≈øe would holy Iob ≈øay, when he ≈øayth, Elegit ≈øu≈øpendium anima mea, & o≈ø≈øa mea mortem, but that his ≈øoule de≈øired to bee hanged, and his bones chu≈øe death, and his life to bee at an end? O holy man, thou ha≈øt nothing left thee but thy ≈øoule, and woulde≈øt thou haue it hanged, nothing left but thy bones, and doe≈øt thou de≈øire to haue them dead, thou ha≈øt nothing left but thy life, and vvoulde≈øt thou loo≈øe it? Thou mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, my good brother, that Iob did not ≈øpeake the≈øe dolefull vvordes in his owne name, but in Chri≈øts name, vnto vvhome this ≈øpeech dooth mo≈øt properly belong. Becau≈øe that from the beginning of the vvorld vntill this day, there vvas neuer ≈øoule ≈øo ≈øorrowfull as his, nor neuer body ≈øo martyred as his vvas. Saint Chri≈øo≈øtome vpon the≈øe vvords of the Apo≈øtle. Fidelis deus, qui non permittit nos tentari vltra id quod po≈ø≈øumus, ≈øayth thus: Our Lord is very faithfull and pittifull, becau≈øe hee tempteth no man aboue that vvhich hee is able to ≈øuffer, nor ≈øuffereth no man to haue greater paine than he is able to beare, the ≈øonne of God excepted onely, vpon vvhome the Father laid in the iudgement of men, torment and paine not able to bee indured, and withall innumerable temptations. What vvilt thou require more in this ca≈øe, but that God the Father laid martyrdome vpon Saints by ownces‚ñ™ but vpon his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øonne by great loads and burdens‚ñ™ Wha ‚Ä¢
great di≈øtre≈ø≈øe vvas his ≈øoule in, thinke you, and vvhat griefe did oppre≈ø≈øe his heart, vvhen hee ≈øighed for the gallowes, and his body de≈øired his graue? When did thy ≈øoule de≈øire to bee hanged, but vvhen thou didde≈øt crucifie thy ble≈ø≈øed humanity vpon the cro≈ø≈øe; & when did thy bones couet death but vvhen thou didde≈øt loo≈øe thy life for the elects ≈øake? When the Scripture ≈øayth Elegit, Hee did chu≈øe, it is ≈øignified that thou didde≈øt die willingly for vs: and when he ≈øaith Su≈øpendium, his death was ≈øignified, and withall his determination which he had to redeeme the world, and that our redemption ≈øhould be hanged vpon the tree. And vvhen he ≈øayth, O≈ø≈øa mea, the multitude of people is ≈øet forth which were at his death, as well the good as the bad, the quicke as the dead: the good, to ≈øee them≈øelues redeemed by him, and the bad to ≈øee them≈øelues reuenged of him. All humane pains are brought vnto three principall heads, that is, to the trouble and trauell of the body, to the griefe and ≈øorrow of the mind, and to the lo≈ø≈øe of life. The≈øe vexations are woont to happen at diuer≈øe times, and al≈øo be deuided and laid vpon diuer≈øe per≈øons, and hee who hath griefe of body feeleth no ≈øorrow of mind, and if hee haue angui≈øh of mind yet not ≈øo great that it ≈øhould take his life from him, becau≈øe our Lord is ≈øo pittiful that hee dooth not looke vnto the multitude of our offences, but vnto the vveakene≈ø≈øe of our forces. God was more pittifull vvith all mankind than vvith his owne only ≈øonne, con≈øidering that hee gaue other men their troubles and paines by peeces, and vnto his ≈øonne all at once. For hee gaue him ≈øorrow and griefe of mind, ≈øeeing hee ≈øayth, My ≈øoule hath cho≈øen to bee hanged: and hee gaue him the paines of the body, ≈øeeing hee ≈øayth, that his bones de≈øired death: and hee tooke away his life con≈øidering that hee ≈øayth, Iam non viuam. What vn≈øpeakable ≈øorrow, and what ≈øea of tempe≈øt ≈øhould to≈ø≈øe and vexe that ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoule vvhen hee ≈øaid, My ≈øoule hath cho≈øen to bee hanged, that is, that it vvould bee a comfort vnto him to bee crucified! What cruell griefe ≈øhould cru≈øh
his bones when hee ≈øaid, and my bones death, thinking it an ea≈øe to ≈øee his bones in their graue, rather than to ≈øuffer ≈øuch intollerable torment? What a ie≈øt did they make of his doctrine, and how little did they regard his per≈øon, ≈øeeing hee ≈øayth, I vvill liue no longer, that is, that hee vvould for≈øake vs, becau≈øe vvee are incorrigible, and becau≈øe vvee doe not de≈øerue his company, hee vvill not be≈øtow his grace among vs. This ≈øpeech may otherwi≈øe bee very vvell vnder≈øtood, becau≈øe the time vvhich hee did ≈øuffer and die in did take from him all that might mittigate his paine, and comfort his heart. No other Martyr could euer ≈øay, My ≈øoule hath cho≈øen hanging, becau≈øe there vvas none of them vvhich vvanted comfort in their ≈øorrows, and helpe in their pains; and aboue all, this vvas a great comfort to them to thinke for how good a mai≈øter they ≈øuffered, and vvhat a great reward they expected for their martyrdome. That vvhich did comfort Martyrs in their Martyrdome, did di≈øcomfort Chri≈øt in his pa≈øsion. For if hee did die, it vvas for a lo≈øt and peruer≈øe nation, and the reward hee looked for was perpetuall ingratitude; becau≈øe there was neuer ≈øo great a matter performed, as when Chri≈øt died becau≈øe vve ≈øhould liue, and yet there vvas neuer deed ≈øo vngratefully requited, as his death was by vs. Saint Barnard ≈øayth, O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules ioy, Art thou not content to loo≈øe thy life for my life, but that thy ≈øorrow and griefe ≈øhould continue al≈øo vntill they take thy ≈øoule from thee vpon the cro≈ø≈øe? If the ≈øonne of God had ≈øaid only, Tri≈øtis est anima mea, it had beene tollerable: but to ≈øay, V≈øque ad morteÃÑ, it is a thing not to be any way indured: For it was only he and no other, in whom the paine ended at the ≈øame time that his ≈øoule departed from him. Cyprian ≈øaith, That by this ≈øpeech, V≈øque ad mortem, the ≈øon of God dooth bind him≈øelfe to die ≈øorrowfully and comfortles, taking no ea≈øe at all in his pa≈øsion, becau≈øe there was no portion of the inferiour part, which griefe did not wholly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe,
nor any bone in all his bodie vvhich vvas not bru≈øed and broken with griefe and paine. Chri≈øt ≈øayth, Eleg it ≈øu≈øpendium anima mea, becau≈øe that as all the time that hee liued in this vvorld, hee kept the glory of his ≈øoule in ≈øu≈øpence, becau≈øe it ≈øhould not fall vpon his body; ≈øo at the time of his pa≈øsion hee did keepe his rea≈øon in ≈øu≈øpence, becau≈øe it ≈øhould not comfort his ≈øoule. For if Chri≈øt vvould haue giuen his glorious ≈øoule licen≈øe to impart ≈øome ≈ømall ≈øparkle of her glory vnto the body, hee had neuer been comfortle≈ø≈øe; and if hee would haue giuen licen≈øe vnto his rea≈øon to haue comforted him in his pa≈øsion, hee ≈øhould neuer haue felt his pa≈øsion ≈øo ≈øharpe and bitter. But becau≈øe our redemption ≈øhould bee more copious and aboundant, hee would admit no comfort nor con≈øolation at all. Ne fortitudo lapidum fortitudo mea, nee caro mea, ≈øayth holy Iob; As if hee vvould ≈øay, O great God, doe not puni≈øh mee ≈øo rigorou≈øly, nor ≈øhew thy ≈øelfe ≈øo cruell again≈øt mee, becau≈øe my heart is not ≈øo hard as a ≈øtone to feele no paine, nor my fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh as hard as copper, that no torments are able to hurt it. Hee who ≈øpake the≈øe words, did craue aid for his griefe, and fauour for his angui≈øh, ≈øeeing hee did confe≈ø≈øe that his heart vvas not able to beare them, nor his ≈øtrength able to ≈øu≈øtaine them. There are ≈øome men ≈øo ≈øencele≈ø≈øe that they feele no kind of tribulation no more than if their hearts vvere made of ≈øtone‚ñ™ and contrary there are ≈øome of ≈øo tender a nature, that if a man doe but touch their coat, they crie out that they may bee heard vnto heauen, in ≈øo much that the fir≈øt like vnto bea≈øts feele nothing, and the other like impatient men neuer cea≈øe crying. When the holy man ≈øayth, That his heart vvas not like a heart of ≈øtone, hee meant that hee did feele all tribulation and angui≈øh, euen vnto the heart: and vvhen hee ≈øaid that his fle≈øh vvas not made of copper or bra≈ø≈øe, his meaning was, that although he did feele all tribulation, yet hee did neuer complaine of it; in ≈øo much that if hee did feele it as a man, yet hee
did di≈ø≈øemble it like a wi≈øe man. S. Gregory in his Morals ≈øaith, Iob doth very wi≈øely vnder the≈øe vvords ≈øhew vs the manner how bad men and good men doe ≈øuffer their angui≈øh, and hee compareth tho≈øe which feele no tribulation vnto a ≈øtone, and tho≈øe which complaine on them alwaies, vnto ≈øounding copper: for indeed hee who feeleth no griefe at all, is like vnto a ≈øtone, and to feele it and hold his peace is the part of him who is wi≈øe and di≈øcreet. Chri≈øts heart vvas not of ≈øtone, becau≈øe hee ≈øhould not feele, neither was his fle≈øh of copper, to complaine: for hee did feele all paine and angui≈øh more than any man, and did ≈øuffer it better than any; for in all the time of his pa≈øsion he did neuer complaine vpon any when hee ≈øuffered, nor did neuer command a reuenge to bee taken on any when he died.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. How the ≈øon complaineth of his Father, becau≈øe that he had condemned him to die before that Iudas had ≈øold him.
div.p:
QVare me po≈øuisti contrarium tibi, & factus ≈øum mihimet ip≈øi grauis? The≈øe words are vttered by holy Iob, in the per≈øon of the ≈øonne of God, ≈øpeaking vnto his Father vpon the cro≈ø≈øe: & their meaning is this, O my Father, why art thou ≈øo contrary vnto me, as if I were thy enemy? doth it not content thee that for my friends ≈øake I am grieuous vnto my ≈øelfe, and complaine on my ≈øelfe? It is an ordinary thing to ≈øee one man complaine vpon another, and to ≈øee me complaine vpon my ≈øelfe is no new thing, but to complaine on thee and my ≈øelfe at once, is a hard ca≈øe: for although my tongue can count my griefes and tribulations, yet my heart cannot ≈øuffer them. If Chri≈øt did complaine of Herod for mocking him, or of Pilate for giuing ≈øentence on him, it was no maruell; but to complaine on his Father, it ≈øeemeth that there is no patience able to endure it. For ≈øeeing
that hee ≈øhould haue defended him, it ≈øeemeth a very hard part to ≈øuffer him to bee crucified. Chri≈øt ≈øaid preaching that there was no tittle, no point, nor ≈øentence of holy Scripture, vvhich ≈øhould not be fulfilled according vnto the letter. The fir≈øt my≈øtery of the incarnation, Ecce virgo conciptes, was fulfilled litterally, ≈øeeing him≈øelfe vvas a virgine, and borne of a virgine: and al≈øo the la≈øt my≈øtery of his pa≈øsion, was accompli≈øhed litterally, Dederunt in e≈øcam meam fel, & in ≈øiti mea potauerunt me aceto, Seeing that they gaue him vpon the cro≈ø ‚Ä¢ e gaule and vineger to drinke. What did Chri≈øt meane when he ≈øaid, that to fulfill the Scripture hee had ≈øuch great thir≈øt, but that hee might now freely depart and goe out of this vvorld, ≈øeeing that all the redemption was ended, and the Scripture accompli≈øhed? The ≈øimple Reader ought not to imagine, that the ≈øonne of God would not haue come into the world, nor redeemed the world, nor endured this torment and thir≈øt, if it had not been written in the Prophets: for hee mu≈øt learne, that the Scriptures are tied vnto Chri≈øt, and not Chri≈øt vnto the Scriptures; becau≈øe that they ≈øhould not haue been written, if hee ≈øhould not haue been borne and crucified; and yet he ≈øhould haue been borne and crucified, although the ≈øcripture had not ≈øpoken it. Venerable Beed ≈øayth, Seeing that all Chri≈øts actions are great, and tho≈øe of his death and pa≈øsion mo≈øt great, it is much to be noted, and to bewondered at, why it was the plea≈øure of the ≈øonne of God, that his thir≈øt ≈øhould be his la≈øt work, and that he would depart out of this life with great thir≈øt. S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, The la≈øt griefe and paine
which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered was his thir≈øt, the la≈øt complaint which hee made vvas of his thir≈øt, and the la≈øt reque≈øt vvhich hee made vvas for a cup of vvater, and the la≈øt torment vvhich he endured vvas of the gaule, vineger and mire vvhich hee dranke, becau≈øe that immediately after that hee had ta≈øted of that cup he gaue vp his gho≈øt vnto his Father. Seeing therfore that this thir≈øt is the la≈øt torment, the la≈øt reque≈øt, the la≈øt complaint, and the la≈øt vvorke that Chri≈øt did in this vvorld, it is conuenient that vvee tell vvho hee is vvho ≈øuffereth this thir≈øt, vvhere hee dooth ≈øuffer it, for vvhome hee doth ≈øuffer it, and at vvhat time he doth ≈øuffer it. Hee vvho ≈øuffereth is Chri≈øt, the place vvhere is vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, I am hee for vvho≈øe ≈øake hee ≈øuffered it, the time vvas vntill death, in≈øomuch that with the ≈øame great thir≈øt vvhich hee endured, his ≈øoule vvas drawne and pulled out of his body. The high my≈øteries of the cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt may vvell bee compared vnto the eating of Pine-apples, and their kernels, the vvhich the oftener they be ca≈øt into the fire and taken out, the more kernels they yeeld to eat, and more huske to burn. That which happeneth vnto the labourer vvith tho≈øe Pines and kernels, dooth happen vnto vs in the≈øe diuine my≈øteries, in the vvhich the more vvee thinke vpon the pa≈øsion and cro≈ø≈øe, the more ≈øecrets vvee di≈øcouer, and the more my≈øteries vvee find. Cyprian ≈øayth, That vvhich men di≈øpo≈øe of a little before their death, is alwaies of greater importance, than that vvhich vve deale vvith in our life time, becau≈øe it is done vvith greater heed, prouided for with deeper con≈øideration, ordered vvith better di≈øcretion, rated and determined vvith better con≈øcience. No man did euer di≈øpo≈øe better of his life and ≈øoule, than Chri≈øt did of his owne per≈øon and the church, becau≈øe hee di≈øpo≈øed of them vvith more care than Iacob, vvth more pittie than I≈øaac, with more di≈øcretion than Io≈øue, vvith greater wi≈øedome than Dauid, and greater bounty and liberality than Salamon. Mulier da mihi bibere, ≈øaid Chri≈øt to the Samaritane vvoman, As if hee vvould ≈øay, Giue mee a cup of vvater, good
woman, becau≈øe thou ≈øee≈øt that I am weary of the way, and very thir≈øty. When Chri≈øt ≈øaid vnto the woman, Da mihi bibere, and al≈øo when he ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, I am a thir≈øt, it was a ≈øigne that he had been a thir≈øt many daies, and al≈øo many yeares, and very de≈øirous to quench his thir≈øt with water. That which Chri≈øt ≈øayth in the 7 of Saint Iohn, ≈øeemeth to bee very contrary vnto this, If any man bee a thir≈øt, let him come vnto mee. Vpon a ≈øolemne day of Ea≈øter, Chri≈øt cried publikely in the market place. If any man bee a thir≈øt let him come vnto mee. O high my≈øtery and deepe ≈øecret! who is able to vnder≈øtand that which Chri≈øt ≈øayth in this place, ≈øeeing that ≈øometime hee asketh the Samaritane woman for a little water, and on the cro≈ø≈øe hee ≈øayth that he dieth with thir≈øt, and yet on the other ≈øide hee maketh open proclamation, that all vvhich bee thir≈øty ≈øhould come vnto him? How can the≈øe two ≈øpeeches hang together, Woman giue mee ≈øome drinke, and this, If any man bee a thir≈øt, let him come vnto mee? Doe≈øt thou inuite all men to come to drinke at thy Tauerne, and ha≈øt thou not a cup of water for to quench thy owne thir≈øt? For the better vnder≈øtanding of this, it is to bee noted, that God doth take ≈øome things of vs, and yet there are ≈øome things which God doth giue vnto vs; which is ea≈øily perceiued, in that hee tooke fle≈øh of vs when hee would become man, and yet if wee vvill become pure and holy, hee mu≈øt impart his grace vnto vs. This being ≈øo, vvhen Chri≈øt ≈øayth, If any man bee a thir≈øt let him come vnto mee, hee doth giue vs to vnder≈øtand, that hee is the fountaine of grace, of the vvhich vvee ≈øhould all drinke of: and vvhen hee ≈øayih, Woman giue mee ≈øome drinke, he doth let vs al≈øo vnder≈øtand, that there are ≈øome things in vs of the which hee would bee ≈øerued vvithall. When the ≈øonne of God ≈øayth, If any man bee thir≈øty let him come vnto mee, to vvhat vvater, thinke≈øt thou, doth he inuite thee, but vnto the water of his grace and of his glory? And when hee ≈øayth vnto the Samaritane woman, giue me drinke, what water thinke≈øt thou did he ask,
but onely patience and obedience? Chri≈øt doth inuite vs to drinke of his great goodne≈ø≈øe and fauours, and hee craueth of vs of the water of the pooles of our poore ≈øeruice, ≈øaying Da mihi bibere, in ≈øo much that to ≈øhew the great loue which hee doth beare vnto his creatures, hee faineth that hee hath need of their ≈øeruices. S. Barnard vpon tho≈øe wordes of the P≈øalme, Sitiuit anima mea ad deum fontem viuum ≈øayth, O what a great difference there is betwixt the thir≈øt of the good and the bad, becau≈øe the bad thir≈øt after nothing but wickedne≈ø≈øe, and the good after vertues, the bad after temporall things, and the good after ≈øpirituall, the one after ≈øinne, and the other after amendment, ≈øo that all the thir≈øt of the wicked is after ≈øinne, and the thir≈øt of the good after ≈øalnation. Ba≈øil vpon the P≈øalme ≈øayth, The Prophet vvould neuer haue ≈øaid, My ≈øoule hath thir≈øted after God a liuely ≈øpring, if hee could haue found the fountayne of glory in this vvorld, and the vvater of grace in this life. But ala≈ø≈øe of how many vvaters ≈øoeuer wee drinke of, and how many waters ≈øoeuer wee ≈øeeke for, wee ≈øhall neuer meet with the water of life, vntill vvee come to enioy the diuine e≈ø≈øence. Hugo de ≈øancto victore vpon the P≈øalme ≈øayth, All the thinges of this life are drie fountaines, and dead waters; & conrary, all things of glory are fre≈øh fountaines and water of life: for there and not here vvee ≈øhall liue all contented, and not thir≈øt at all.
