All which liue in this vvorld, liue in hunger and thir≈øt, becau≈øe all the vices vvhich wee like of doe hurt and not profite, make vs ≈øorrowfull and not ioifull, vveary and not recreate vs, loath and not fill vs. What vicious man is there in the world, who the more he doth giue him≈øelfe to vice, is not the more thir≈øty after them? Let not the Deuill deceaue thee, my brother, in ≈øaying I vvill now cloy and glut my ≈øelfe vvith vice: for the more thou doe≈øt eat and drinke and bee merry, although thou doe ≈øeeme to bee fully ≈øatisfied, yet thou art not ≈øo, but onely a vveary. Saint Barnard vpon the Pa≈øsion of our
Lord ≈øayth, What dooth it meane that the ≈øonne of God went out of this vvorld dead with thir≈øt, but onely that there is nothing in this world that can quench the thir≈øt of our ≈øoule? An≈øelmus ≈øayth, How is it po≈øsible, O my good Ie≈øus, how is it po≈øsible that I ≈øhould liue in the vvorld contented and fully ≈øatisfied, ≈øeeing that thou didde≈øt depart out of it hungry and thir≈øty? S. Ierome vpon S. Luke ≈øaith, All that the vvorld doth giue vs to quench our thir≈øt withall, is but vineger, and all that hee giueth vs to mittigate our hunger is but gaule, the which thinges being vvell prooued doe take away our life, and not our thir≈øt. Robertus vpon Saint Iohn ≈øayth, That for the ≈øon of God to die vvith thir≈øt, is to let vs vnder≈øtand, that haue we neuer ≈øo many dignities, let vs heap vp neuer ≈øo much riches, and let vs proue neuer ≈øo many vices, and let vs cocker our ≈øelues all we can, yet we ≈øhal depart with as great thir≈øt out of this world, as if we had not liued but one moment in it. In this ≈øorrowful life there is nothing but is thir≈øty: the fle≈øh doth thir≈øt after daintie cheri≈øhing, the ≈øoule doth thir≈øt after longer life, the heart dooth thir≈øt for more ≈øtrength, the Deuill to deceiue vs, and Chri≈øt doth thir≈øt after our ≈øaluation. Which of all the≈øe doe not liue in hunger and thir≈øt? What doth our fle≈øh but complaine in euery part, that we keepe it naked, that we keepe it hungry, weary, di≈øcontented, and dead with thir≈øt? What ≈øinfull ≈øoule did euer depart out of this vvretched life, ≈øo be≈øet vvith griefe, or loaden vvith yeares, vvhich vvould nor haue giuen all that hee had beene worth to haue liued one yeare longer? What humane heart is there on earth, which watcheth not to get more, and breaketh not his ≈øleep to be worth more? Why dooth the Deuill vvatch but to keepe his own, and beguile the good? Why are there ≈øo many ≈øorts of vices in the vvorld, and ≈øo many enti≈øements, but to quench the thir≈øt vvhich it hath, to make vs all vaine, vvordly, and light? Why did the ≈øonne of God come into the world, preach the Go≈øpell, liue in paine, and die vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, but onely for the great thir≈øt
which he had to ≈øaue the world? Loe then, we haue prooued how the fle≈øh, the heart, the ≈øoule, the world, the diuell, and Chri≈øt, are all hungry and de≈øire thee O my ≈øoule: and that which cannot bee ≈øpoken without teares is, that onely Chri≈øt doth thir≈øt after thy ≈øaluation, and all the other after thy perdition. O my ≈øoule, if thou hadde≈øt as great a thir≈øt to amend thy ≈øelfe, as Chri≈øt hath to ≈øaue thee, or if thou hadde≈øt as great a thir≈øt to amend thy ≈øelfe as the≈øe thy enemies haue to deceiue thee, I doe promi≈øe thee that thou woulde≈øt not liue as thou doe≈øt ≈øo carele≈ø≈øy, nor yet behaue thy ≈øelfe ≈øo riotou≈øly. The good doe inherite the thir≈øt of our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and the wicked doe inherite the thir≈øt of the diuell. And what is the thir≈øt which the good doe inherite, but to be peacemakers, humble, cha≈øt, ≈øober, and very charitable? And what is the thir≈øt which the wicked doe inherite of the deuill, but to bee more mighty, and rich, and more vicious? O what great difference there is betwixt the≈øe two thir≈øts! for the thir≈øt of the good and vertuous goeth to bee quenched at the fountaine of life, which is glory; & the thir≈øt of the wicked goeth to bee quenched at the dead waters of paine and puni≈øhment; in ≈øo much that ≈øuch as our thir≈øt is in this world, ≈øuch ≈øhall bee the water which wee ≈øhall drinke of in the other. O how wel the Prophet ≈øaid, My ≈øoule did thir≈øt after the liuing God, becau≈øe that all the water which our Lord doth giue vs to drinke is of the liuely fountaine, which is cleare vnto the eie, and fre≈øh to recreat, ≈øauerous to prouide of, and whole≈øome to ta≈øt of, delicare in di≈øge≈øting, and mo≈øt precious to keepe. The water which the world giueth his followers to drinke of is deep to teach vnto, troubled to ≈øee vnto, vn≈øauery to drinke, puddle in ta≈øt, and ≈øtinking to keepe. Let vs conclude then that the ≈øeruant of God is alwaies thir≈øty and de≈øirous of God, who as hee who is very thir≈øty doth ≈øeeke drinke with all diligence, ≈øo he who is de≈øirous of God doth ≈øeeke all the waies and meanes he can to ≈øerue and obey him.

div.head: CHAP. II. How the Crowes gaue the Prophet Helias meat; and how the Iewes gaue Chri≈øt neither meat nor drinke.
div.p:
REcede hine, & vade contra Orientem, & ab≈øconde te in torrentem Carith, & ibi de torrente viues: nam coruis praecepi vt pa≈øcant te: God ≈øpake the≈øe words vnto H ‚Ä¢
lias Reg. 3. chap. 17, as if he would ≈øay; It is my will and plea≈øure, O Helias, that thou liue no more in this land, but that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt goe out of it, and thou ≈øhalt goe towards the Ea≈øt, and hide thy ≈øelfe in the brook Carith, where thou ≈øhalt haue no need to fear hunger, becau≈øe I wil coÃÑmand the crows to bring thee meat and bread euery day, and there thou ha≈øt water inough for thy drinking. When our Lord did command Helias to goe out of Samaria, there was a great famine ouer all the land, and he was al≈øo per≈øecuted by the wicked queen Iezabel: and yet hauing an intention to ≈øuccour his Prophet, he appointed him a place far off, where he ≈øhould hide him≈øelfe, and prouided him all kind of victuals for him to eat. Helias being gone to the brooke Carith, there hee lay hidden a long time, feeding only vpon that which the crows gaue him, and drinking of the water which ran in the ≈øtream. And after a few months were pa≈øt, and the Queens per≈øecution was ceafed, and the famine amended, Helias returned to the people, and the crowes were ≈øeene no more. Before we doe come vnto the≈øe my≈øteries, it is here to bee noted, what great care our Lord hath ouer his ≈øeruants, and how he is neuer carele≈ø≈øe of his friends, becau≈øe his naturall condition is neuer to bee vnmindfull of tho≈øe which doe not forget to ≈øerue him. Cum ip≈øo ≈øum, eripiam eum, & glorificabo eum, ≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt in the name of our Lord: and his meaning is, I my ≈øelf, and no other,
will bee alwaies with him in his troubles, and I will bring him ≈øafe out of them, and he ≈øhall e≈øcape out of them with honor and glory. If wee doe well vnder≈øtand Chri≈øt, hee promi≈øeth three thinges vnto ≈øuch as ≈øuffer per≈øecution and tribulation for his ≈øeruice: The fir≈øt is, that hee will bee at their ≈øide in all troubles and vexations: the ≈øecond, that they ≈øhall neuer lo≈øe their life, nor endanger their con≈øcience for any trouble, be it neuer ≈øo ≈øtrong: the third, that hee will deliuer them out of that trouble with great fame and glory. If ≈øuch great profite be gotten by per≈øecution, why doth any man follow the plea≈øures and delights of the world? What tribulation is there in this world ≈øo hard and dangerous, which is not ouercomed with the helpe of Chri≈øt? O how happy is that ≈øoule which is tempted for the ≈øeruice of God, and is per≈øecuted for the loue of him! ≈øeeing he hath giuen his word and his credit that he will not ≈øuffer any to fall in his temptation, nor for≈øake any man in his tribulation. Note gentle Reader, that Chri≈øt doth not ≈øay, I am with them In gaudio & exultatione, in mirth and ioy, but In tribulatione, in tribulation: for as in this life he knew nothing but how to ≈øhed tears, ≈øuffer temptations, endure trauaile, ≈øo he hath compa≈øsion of none but of ≈øuch as weep, and are per≈øecuted and tempted; in ≈øo much that as the diuell is the captaine and ring-leader of all which liue in pompe and iolitie, ≈øo Chri≈øt is the head of all that are afflicted and in tribulation. Saint Barnard ≈øayth, If this that is ≈øaid, Cumip≈øo ≈øum in tribulatione, be not performed in thee, thinke with thy ≈øelf that thou doe≈øt not ≈øuffer that tribulation for Chri≈øt, but for thy friend and thy ≈øelfe; and therfore in that ca≈øe let him help and ≈øuccour thee for whome thou doe≈øt ≈øuffer that danger. If thou doe not make reckoning of Chri≈øt, nor thinke on him, nor ≈øuffer for his ≈øake, what hath Chri≈øt to doe with thy paint and trauaile? If thou do ≈øuffer for the fle≈øh, let the fle≈øh help thee, if thou ≈øuffer for the world, let the world deliuer thee, if thou ≈øuffer for thy friend, let thy friend giue thee aid, if thou doe ≈øuffer for Chri≈øt, to Chri≈øt commend thy ≈øelfe: for if thou doe ≈øerue others, what rea≈øon is it that thou ≈øhould≈øt ask
fauour of him. Saint Ba≈øil ≈øayth, What friend had God at any time whom hee forgot, or in what tribulation did hee euer ≈øee him when hee helped him not? Gregory in his Regi≈øter ≈øayth, Hee who did not forget Noe in the floud, nor Abraham in Chaldea, nor Lot in Sodome, nor I≈øaac in Pale≈øtine, nor Iacob in A≈ø≈øyria, nor Daniel in Babilon, doe≈øt thou think that he will forget thee in thy affliction and tribulation? Remigius ≈øayth, If this promi≈øe of Cum ip≈øo ≈øum in tribulatione, bee not kept with thee, thinke that our Lord dooth it, either for thy greater profite, or his owne ≈øeruice: for the greater the tribulation is which thou endure≈øt, the more thou doe≈øt merite for thy ≈øoule: and if it be not for this cau≈øe, it is becau≈øe thou ≈øhalt fall into ≈øome greater danger, from the which our Lord doth keepe his holy hand and diuine ≈øuccour to deliuer thee. And becau≈øe that the curious Reader may not thinke that wee ≈øwarue from our purpo≈øe, it is to bee noted, that the Prophet Helius (who≈øe figure we handled) was be≈øet with three grieuous per≈øecutions, that is, with the warre which was in Iury, with the famine which was ouer all the land, and with Iezabels hatred. He dur≈øt not preach for feare of the Queene, hee dur≈øt not goe abroad for feare of the warre, hee dur≈øt not hide him≈øelfe for feare of famine and hunger; in ≈øo much that this holy Prophet was ≈øo much without hope of remedy, that he knew not whether hee ≈øhould haue his throat cut openly, or whether he ≈øhould die for hunger ≈øecretly. Our Lord therefore to fulfill his promi≈øe, Cum ip≈øo ≈øum in tribulatione, tooke him out of Iury, vnwitting to the ≈øouldiors; and did hide him in Carith, where no man could ≈øee him, and ≈øent him meat by crowes to feed on, and did prouide him a ≈øtreame of water to drinke of. Wee may gather by this example what a good Lord wee haue, and what care hee hath ouer vs if wee ≈øerue him, ≈øeeing that hee doth pay vs for all wee doe, and ≈øuccour vs for all that we ≈øuffer for him. To come now vnto the purpo≈øe, all this figure was fulfilled in Chri≈øt at the foot of the letter: for as Heliac was per≈øecuted by Iezabel, ≈øo was Chri≈øt of the Synagogue, and Chri≈øt found as great a famine of good
men, as Helias did in Samaria of victuals. Hugo de ≈øancto victore, ≈øayth vpon tho≈øe words of Ieremy, Paruuli petierunt panem, The bread which the little ones cried for to ear, and the lamentation which Ieremy made becau≈øe there was no man to giue it him, was not vnder≈øtood of the materiall bread which was woont to bee in the arke, but of ≈øpirituall bread, wherewith the ≈øoules are fed: and to ≈øay that there was no man found to giue it them, was as much as to ≈øay, that there was no good man left to preach vnto them. Chri≈øo≈øtome in an Homily ≈øayth, In Commonwealths well gouerned, the want of a good man is greater than the famine of bread and wine, becau≈øe we haue ≈øeene that God hath ≈øent a famine for the demerits of one man alone, and after abundance for one good mans ≈øake alone. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, Famine, warre, and pe≈øtilence, are much to bee feared in naughty Commonwealths, and where there are no good per≈øons: for although our Lord doth ≈øuffer them to come for a time, yet he doth not con≈øent that they ≈øhould long time endure. What goodne≈ø≈øe haue Commonwealths in them, if they haue no good men in theÃÑ? And what want they, if they doe not want good men? Saint Augu≈øtine in his Confe≈øsions ≈øayth, When I hear a knill rung for the dead, my ≈øoule is pre≈øently driuen into a perplexity, whether I ≈øhould weepe fir≈øt for the good which die, or the bad which liue, becau≈øe there is as great rea≈øon that we ≈øhould weepe for the life of the bad, as for the death of the good. Now that we haue prooued, that the want & famine of good men is more dangerous in a city than a dearth of victuals, who doth doubt but that the ≈øcar≈øene≈ø≈øe which Chri≈øt ≈øound in the Synagogue was greater than that which Helias found in Pale≈øtine? What good thing, or what good man could there be in the Synagogue, where the Viceroy Pilate was a Tyrant, the famous high Prie≈øt Caiphas a Symoniacle, & the mai≈øters the Phari≈øies Hypocrites, and the coun≈øellours the Sadduces Heretikes, and their kings and Prophets all ended? The ≈øonne of God did kill this hunger, when hee gaue the world a church for a Synagogue, Apo≈øtles for Prophets, a
law of loue for a law of feare, a new Te≈øtament for an old, the ≈øpirit for the letter, the truth for the figure, and his holy grace for our old offence. What would haue become of vs, if Chri≈øt had not left ≈øo many good men in his church? Hee left vs many Martyrs, many confe≈ø≈øours, many virgines, many doctors; in ≈øo much that when Chri≈øt died, although hee left not the vvorld many bookes to read in, yet hee left vs many Saints to follow. The figure ≈øayth further, that Helias went to hide him≈øelfe in the water-brooke of Carith, which was a figure, that the ≈øonne of God ≈øhould come to take fle≈øh, and hide him≈øelfe in the entralls of the Virgines wombe: and as it was figured in Helias, ≈øo it was accompli≈øhed in Chri≈øt, becau≈øe that vnder his humanity vvhich hee tooke vpon him, hee did hide his diuinity which hee carried with him. When the Prophet E≈øayas ≈øaid, Ver√® tues deus ab≈øconditus, hee knew well that God would hide him≈øelfe for a time, and remoue him≈øelfe from their eies, ≈øeeing that the catholicke Church did acknowledge him, and the vnhappy Synagogue was vngratefull vnto him. Recede hinc & ab≈øconde te in torrentem Carith: the eternall Father ≈øpake the≈øe words vnto his precious ≈øonne, as if hee had ≈øaid vnto him, Goe my ≈øonne, goe and hide thy ≈øelfe in the world, becau≈øe thou mai≈øt redeeme the world: Where thou ≈øhalt hide thy power becau≈øe thou mai≈øt ≈øuffer, thou ≈øhalt hide thy wi≈øedome, becau≈øe they may mock thee, thou ≈øhalt hide thy prudence, becau≈øe they may take thee to bee vnwi≈øe, thou ≈øhalt hide thy iu≈øtice, becau≈øe they are to iudge thee like a bla≈øphemer, and thou ≈øhalt hide thy ≈øtrength, becau≈øe thou mai≈øt the better die. O how well this was fulfilled in Chri≈øt, hide thy ≈øelfe in the water-brooke of Carith! for if he ≈øhould not haue hidden his great power before Pilate, who would haue been able to take his life from him? If the ≈øon of God ≈øhould not haue hidden his eternal wi≈øedome, dur≈øt the Phari≈øies haue mocked at his doctrine as they did? If Chri≈øt ≈øhould not haue hidden the rigour of his iu≈øtice, who would
haue beene able to doe iu≈øtice vpon him? If Chri≈øt ≈øhould not haue hidden his inexpugnable ≈øtrength, how ≈øhould it haue beene po≈øsible for any man to draw his life out of his body? The Prophet Zachary ≈øpake vnto this purpo≈øe, Ibi ab≈øcondita est potentia eius, As if hee would haue ≈øaid: Thou mai≈øt not looke, O Synagogue, thou mai≈øt not looke for a Me≈øsias which will bee mighty but weake, not rich but poor, not in health but ≈øicke: do not imagine that he ≈øhould be honourable but throwne downe; doe not proclaime him for to bee a great Lord but a ≈øeruant; hee ≈øhall not bee a warriour, but a man of peace; and hee ≈øhall not goe much openly, but for the mo≈øt part in hucker mucker. Seeing that E≈øaias ≈øayth, thou art truly a hidden God, and al≈øo Zacharias that his power is hidden, why dooth the Synagogue looke that the Me≈øsias ≈øhould come openly, con≈øidering that their Prophets ≈øaid that hee was to come ≈øecretly? Origen in his Periarchon ≈øayth, Becau≈øe the ≈øonne of God came not to fight with vi≈øible men, but with inui≈øible ≈øinnes and enemies, there was no nece≈øsity that he ≈øhould come fighting, but preaching, it was not needful that hee ≈øhould wander ouer all the world, but only publi≈øh his Go≈øpell among them all, and if the arrogant Iewes did not reach vnto the knowledge thereof, it was not becau≈øe they could not, but becau≈øe they would not. Theophilus ≈øayth: ≈øpeaking with the church the Prophet Dauid ≈øayth, Deus no≈øter manife≈øte veniet; and ≈øpeaking vvith the Synagogue, the Propht E≈øay ≈øayth, Vere tu es deus ab≈øconditus, and therevpon it happeneth, that the vnhappie I≈øraelites, although they were learned in knowledge, yet of no credite in con≈øcience, and ≈øo they de≈øerued not to know him, becau≈øe they vvould not beleeue him. The figure goeth further and ≈øayth, that the place where Helias went to hide him≈øelfe, vvas at water-brookes of Carith, which is as much to ≈øay as, a thing cut in ≈øunder, or parted in the middle, which had bin once whole. The water-brooke where Chri≈øt did hide him≈øelfe, was the depth and vehemency of his pa≈øsion, where our good Lord entered diuing and
ducking as in a dirty and dangerous riuer, where hee remained drowned and dead in the water of his pa≈øsion: and the ≈øonne of God p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ted him≈øelfe in two, when his ≈øoule went into hell, and his body remained in the graue, and when tho≈øe parts which made him a man were di≈ø≈øolued, although they were neuer ≈øeuered from the Hypo≈øtaticall vnion, ≈øeeing that he was a≈øwell God in hell and in the graue, as hee is this day in heauen. He was ≈øo hidden in the brooke of his pa≈øsion, that there was no part of his diuinity ≈øeene, and the beauty of his humanity ≈øcar≈øely perceiued: and becau≈øe our ble≈ø≈øed Redeemer would ≈øuffer his enemies to be reuenged on him, hee did ≈øu≈øpend for that time, the operation of tho≈øe miracles which might haue hindered his pa≈øsion. The figure ≈øayth further, that the Prophet Helias being in the brooke ≈øecret and clo≈øe, crowes of the fields brought him his dinner in the forenoon, and his ≈øupper at night, ≈øo that the birds gaue him to eat, and the water to drink. If this my≈øtery were not a figure and foretelling of ≈øome other great my≈øtery, it were to bee thought, that as God did ≈øend the Prophet Daniel meat by Abachuch the Prophet, ≈øo hee would haue ≈øent Helias meat by ≈øome other Prophet, or holy man. If by Helias Chri≈øt be figured, by Iezabel the Synagogue, by the per≈øecution his pa≈øsion, and by the brooke the cro≈ø≈øe, and by the water his bloud, and by his hiding him≈øelfe his death, why ≈øhould not the crowes ≈øignifie the Iews? Seeing there were Eagles inowe in the aire, and Pigeons plenty in the world, what great ability did God ≈øee in the crow, that he ≈øhould make him ≈øteward vnto Helias his faithfull friend? What was the meaning that God did commit Helias to the crowes, but that hee ≈øhould al≈øo commit his ≈øonne into the hands of the Iewes? The qualities of a Crow are, to bee in colour blacke, in flying flow, in his fle≈øh hard, in ≈ømelling quicke, in eating rauenous, and in condition vngratefull. And becau≈øe the rauen or crow is an vngratefull bird, the Prouerbe is, that if thou bring vp a Crow, hee will pecke out thy eie. The people of the Iewes were an vngratefull Crow vnto Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing that for a recompence that he tooke fle≈øh
of them, and taught them ≈øo long time, although they did not pecke out his eies, yet they crucified all his members on the cro≈ø≈øe. What bad thing is there in the crow, that is not al≈øo in the Iewes? They are blacke in faith, ≈ølow in iudgement, hard in beliefe, cruell in condition, ready to malice, and mo≈øt couetous. What meaneth this, O my Father, what meaneth this? After that thy ≈øonne had liued thirty three whole years, doe≈øt thou command him to be ca≈øt vnto Crowes? Certainly the Crowes which we ≈øee with our eies, are not ≈øo cruell as the Iewes which wee ≈øpeake off, becau≈øe the Crowes doe eat of nothing vntill it be dead, but the wicked Iewes did venter vpon Chri≈øt when hee was yet aliue. O that Helias did farre better with his Crowes, than the good Ie≈øus with the Iewes, becau≈øe Helias Crowes did giue him bread and fle≈øh to eat, but Chri≈øts crowes gaue him nothing but vineger and gaule to ta≈øt. Let the conclu≈øion of all our ≈øpeech be, that it was better with Helias in his bani≈øhment and water-brooke, thaÃÑ with Chri≈øt on the Mount of Caluary, becau≈øe Helias went out aliue from the water, and Chri≈øt remained dead on the Mount of Caluary, and Helias did neuer know what hunger was, but the ≈øonne of God did neuer kill his hunger, nor quench his thir≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. III. How the hangmen dranke the wine which was brought vnto him, and the other theeues, and did ≈øuffer Chri≈øt to die with thir≈øt.
div.p:
SVper vestimentis pignoratis accubuerunt tuxta altare, & vinum damnatorum bibebant in dome dei ≈øui. O≈øei. 2. God ≈øpake the≈øe words complaining on the I≈øraelits, as if hee would ≈øay, My people of I≈ørael are come to ≈øuch mad and ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe behauiour,
that within the Temple, and hard at the altar they dranke the wine which was prepared for the condemned, and they lay downe and leaned vpon the garments which were laid to pledge. It is an v≈øuall thing and common in tauerns, that drunkards doe ca≈øt them≈øelues downe to ≈øleepe vpon other mens apparrell, and if it bee in hote Summer, to ≈øleepe vpon the benches of the Temple. If there were no greater matter contained vnder this complaint and rebuke, and if the ≈øence were not of greater weight than the letter, and the thing figured worthier than the figure, it was no new thing, nor rare fault, to drinke of another mans wine, or ca≈øt him≈øelfe vpon ≈øome cloke laid to pledge, or to ≈øleepe in the holy Temple. That which God ≈øpeaketh here, and that which our Lord complaineth of, reacheth further than it ≈øeemeth for, and dooth draw vs vnto a deeper my≈øtery than outwardly it appeareth: for if we marke it well, God did neuer ≈øpeake vnto the Synagogue, but it did redound afterward to ≈øome my≈øtery in the church. Fir≈øt the Prophet in this place maketh mention of certain garments: ≈øecondly, that tho≈øe garments were a pawne and pledge: thirdly, that they were laid neere vnto an altar: fourthly, that drunkards lay vpon them: fiftly, that they dranke there much wine: ≈øixtly, that that wine was the wine of condemned per≈øons: and then that they dranke within the holy Temple. What one of the≈øe words dooth want his my≈øtery, or what circum≈øtance is there not worthy of deepe con≈øideration? In the ≈øelfe≈øame ≈øort that this was prophecied by O≈øee, it was fulfilled by Chri≈øt: for wine being brought for Chri≈øt to drinke of, and al≈øo the other theeues, the Iewes did not onely not giue it them, but did them≈øelues drinke it, & then being very dronk, they took Chri≈øts clothes, and ca≈øt them on the ground, and ≈øate vpon them. When the Prophet ≈øayth, that they dranke the wine, & lay down vpon the garments hard by the altar, hee ≈øayth mo≈øt truly: for the fir≈øt church that euer was in the world was the Mount of Caluary, the fir≈øt altar was the cro≈ø≈øe, the fir≈øt ≈øacrifice offered vp for the redemption of man, was his own body to be crucified
on good Friday, vpon the ≈øame altar of the cro≈ø≈øe the fir≈øt faithfull were the Virgine and Saint Iohn, with the other Apo≈øtles and ≈øecret di≈øciples. In that holy Temple, and by that ≈øacred altar, who were they which leaned & were ca≈øt down vpon the garments, but onely the vnhappy and vnfortunate Iewes? Thinke it is a great my≈øtery, that the Prophet did not ≈øee tho≈øe of his Synagogue ≈øitting, but leaning neere vnto the altar, to let vs vnder≈øtand, that they be neither open Chri≈øtians, nor conceiled Iewes: for Chri≈øtians they could not bee, becau≈øe they will not beleeue in Chri≈øt; and if they will bee Iewes they haue no Temple where to Iudaize. Robertus ≈øayth, Vntill this day the Iewes are not pro≈øtrate before the altar, which is Chri≈øt, to beleeue him, nor yet on their knees to wor≈øhip him, nor on foot to defend him, nor embracing him in ≈øigne of loue, but leaning to offend him, becau≈øe their intention is to tread his holy garments vnder feet, and keepe off Ie≈øus Chri≈øt from them with their elbowes. Taking this prophe≈øie in another ≈øence, it is to bee noted, that oftentimes in Scripture by good garments are vnder≈øtood good works, and by torne garments naughty workes; and therevpon it is, that as the body is clad and fo≈øtered with a new garment, ≈øo the ≈øoule is decked and garni≈øhed with holy workes. And becau≈øe that the curious Reader may not thinke that we ≈øpeak at randome, we will proue our ≈øaying by Scripture. What was the meaning that Saint Iohn ≈øaw Chri≈øt Ve≈øtitum ponere, which was to ≈øee him with a long garment, but to ≈øee him loaden with vertues from the head to the foot? Hee that went to the wedding not hauing his nuptiall garment, but becau≈øe hee was vncomely clothed, was carried to pri≈øon: who is repre≈øented vnto vs, but hee, who although he doe lead an euill life, yet dooth dare to enioy Chri≈øtian liberty? When God doth command in the Apocalips, Omni tempore ve≈øtimenta tua ≈øint candida, let thy garments be white alwaies, what doth he ≈øignifie, but that we ≈øhould be all cleane and vertuous? When the Scripture ≈øaith, that Iacob made his ≈øonne Io≈øeph, Tunicam polymitam, that is, an embrodered garment downe to the
ground. What was the meaning that his garment did reach ≈øo low, but that the ≈øonne of God ≈øhould be perfite in all vertues? What did it ≈øignifie that the Iewes did ca≈øt clothes vnder the a≈ø≈øe feet to goe ouer, and the Apo≈øtle put them vpon the a≈ø≈øe which Chri≈øt rode vpon, but that he mi≈øliked all that the Synagogue did, and approoued all that the church did? S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, Becau≈øe in holy writ, by the garments which wee weare are vnder≈øtood the works which wee doe, wee may truly ≈øay, that no man goeth well clothed but the vertuous man, nor no man with a torne coat but the wicked and naughty ≈øinner. Chri≈øt did v≈øe but two garments in this world, the one next his skin, which was without ≈øeame, the other an vpper garment which ≈øerued him for a cloke & coat; in ≈øo much that Chri≈øt did ≈øhew the perfection of his pouerty not only in his diet, but al≈øo in the ≈øimplene≈ø≈øe of his apparell. Barnard ≈øayth, The ≈øonne of God did teach vs not onely to liue, but al≈øo to apparell our≈øelues, becau≈øe his holy garments were few in number, vild in colour, ≈ømall of price, good in profite, but cleane in v≈øe. Hylarius ≈øayth, Although the garments which the ≈øonne of God ware were but few, vild & torne, yet the Scripture dooth much e≈øteeme of them, not for the value vvhich they are vvorth, but for the great my≈øteries which they did ≈øignifie. Origen in an Homily ≈øayth, What vvere the garments vvhich the ≈øonne of God vvent alwaies clad vvith, but his diuine and humane nature, wherof he was made? His coat without ≈øeame, and in which there neuer entred needle nor ≈øci≈ø≈øers, was his diuine nature in great purity glorious from the beginning, in the which there was no beginning, nor ≈øhall bee no end; for that nature is now as it was from the beginning, and ≈øhall be for euer as it is at this in≈øtant. By the other coat vvhich vvas ≈øowne and cur, is vnder≈øtood Chri≈øts ≈øacred humanity, vvhich vvas formed by the Holygho≈øt, and borne of the Virgine Mary, and therefore Chri≈øts vvearing of the≈øe two coats doth ≈øignifie, that hee and no other is God and man, and the ≈øonne vvhich vvas incarnate. Before that Chri≈øt tooke fle≈øh, hee had but one coat to couer
≈øelfe withall, which was his diuinity: but after that hee came into the vvorld, he put on another coat, vvhich vvas his humanity, and by that means he did lend vs his coat to make vs holy, and vvee did lend him ours to make him a man. Saint Chri≈øostome ≈øayth, The one of Chri≈øts coats, to wit, that vvhich vvas vvithout ≈øeame, continued vvhole and vntorne in his pa≈øsion, but his vppermo≈øt garment vvas rent and torne, to giue vs to vnder≈øtand, that although his enemies had power to lay hands vpon his ≈øacred humanity, yet they had none at all to touch his diuinity. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth, One of Chri≈øts coats fell vvhole and entire vnto the knights, and the other torne and ragged vnto the hangmen, and that becau≈øe vvee ≈øhould vnder≈øtand, that to the catholicke church there fell the entire and whole coat, ≈øeeing that ≈øhee dooth fully beleeue that Chri≈øt is both God and man, and vnto the Synagogue there happened his torn coat, ≈øeeing they beleeue that hee is no more than a bare man. Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, By Chri≈øts two garments are vnder≈øtood both his bodies, that is, his true body made and compacted of his holy members, and his my≈øticall body, which are all good Chri≈øtians: and becau≈øe thou maie≈øt perceaue, my brother, how much thou art bound vnto Chri≈øt, know thou, that hee did e≈øteeme better of his my≈øticall body, vvhich are Chri≈øtians, than of his owne true body which vvas made of his owne members. What vvas his meaning that hee ≈øuffered them to take away and teare in pieces the one of his coats, and yet neuer touch the other, but only that hee is more grieued when any man doth ≈øpeake euill of his church, than to haue laid hands vpon his owne proper per≈øon? Remigius ≈øayth, O how whole, and entire hee did leaue vs the vn≈øowne coat of his church! and yet naughty Chri≈øtians and perfideous Heretikes, doe rent his coat into as many pieces, as they doe rai≈øe di≈ø≈øentions, and ≈øtirre vp here≈øies in the church. It was Chri≈øts holy vvill to die not only without a coat, but al≈øo not to haue one thred of a coat vpon him, which hee did ≈øuffer to the
great preiudice of his grauity, and lo≈ø≈øe of his credite. Who was euer, or vvho euer ≈øhall bee ≈øo graue in his doctrine, as the ≈øonne of God vvas, and ≈øo hone≈øt in his per≈øon? And ≈øeeing that E≈øayas ≈øayth, that hee was offered vp becau≈øe hee would, it is to bee beleeued, that ≈øeeing they could not crucifie him, if he him≈øelfe vvould not, ≈øo they could neither haue ≈øtripped him naked vnle≈ø≈øe he had con≈øented vnto it. Wherof it followeth in a good con≈øequence, that if hee would die for our redemption, that hee did let him≈øelfe bee ≈øtripped for our comfort. What did it ≈øignifie that the ≈øonne of God did put off all his garments, but that hee did di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe of all his good workes? I and thou, thou and I, my brother, haue great need to die clothed and clad, to wit, vvith our owne faith and good vvorks, and al≈øo bee helped by others. For as for holy Ie≈øus, as hee came out of the vvombe of his mother vnited vnto the diuine e≈ø≈øence, ≈øo hee had no nece≈ø≈øity of his owne vvorkes, to ≈øaue him≈øelfe, nor of other mens merits to pardon vs. Cyrillus vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, Of as much as the ≈øonne of God did merite praying on the mountaine, preaching among the people, healing the di≈øea≈øed in ho≈øpitals, by ≈øuffering among his enemies, and dying vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, I ≈øay hee did ≈øpoile and make him≈øelfe naked of all that, and put it vpon vs; in≈øomuch that wee are heires of his bloud with which he redeemed vs, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of all the merits which hee heaped together. O glorious inheritance, and happie wealth, which thou good Ie≈øus didde≈øt leaue to the pari≈øhioners of thy church! ≈øeeing that by the meanes thereof, vvee are made ≈øonnes of the Father, brothers of the ≈øonne, puples of the Holy gho≈øt, companions to the Angels, pari≈øhioners of the church, and heires of thy glory. O vvhat great difference there is betwixt the inheritance of heauen, and an inheritance in the world! Worldlings leaue their children ≈øtore of goods and reuenues, and much debate and ≈øtrife to defend them, and many enemies to per≈øecute them: but our good Lord in lieue of great wealth did leaue vs his grace, and in
≈øteed of enemies did leaue vs his merites. What ≈øhould haue become of all the ≈øinners of the world, if as Chri≈øt died ≈øpoiled and depriued of his goods, ≈øo hee would haue died clothed vvith all his merits? What ≈øhould become vnto prowd men, if hee would not haue left them his humilitie, and vvhat of cruell men if hee would not haue left them his charitie? What end ≈øhould angry men come to, if he ≈øhould not haue left them his patience, and vvhat vvere it of all ≈øinners, if hee ≈øhould not haue left them his clemency? Cyprian ≈øayth, If Chri≈øt would haue a≈øcended to heauen vvith all that which hee merited in this world, and not impart it among vs, and as it were vnclothed him≈øelfe of them as of certaine garments, there ≈øhould not haue been in the world at this day a church to preach in, nor Prie≈øt to bee ordained, nor Sacrament to bee admini≈øtred. Cyrillus ≈øayth to this purpo≈øe, If the ≈øonne of God would haue merited for him≈øelfe alone, and died for him≈øelfe alone, wee might haue ≈øaid with rea≈øon, that hee had come into the vvorld, and tooke fle≈øh vpon him for him≈øelfe, and not for vs. But let ≈øuch bla≈øphemy bee farre from our tongues and thoughts, and farre from our heart, becau≈øe our good Lord died not for him≈øelfe, but for vs, nor did not merite for him≈øelfe, but for vs. Hugo de ≈øancto victore ≈øayth, Becau≈øe that the great Redeemer of the world did leaue vs his garments for reliques, and his merites for Trea≈øures, the Church his ≈øpou≈øe hath at this day, Sacraments to giue, ≈øacrifices of a contrite heart to offer, ≈øweet doctrine to preach, and rewards to promi≈øe for amendment of life.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. He followeth the authority of the Prophet O≈øee, and ≈øpeaketh of the garments which Chri≈øt left in pledge.
div.p:
PArtiti ≈øunt vestimenta mea, & ≈øuper ea mi≈øerunt ≈øirtem, ≈øaid Chri≈øt in the 21 P≈øalme, complaining vnto his Father on the cro≈ø≈øe, as if hee would ≈øay, O my good Father, thou wa≈øt not content only, that they ≈øhould ≈øpoile me of my garments, and turne me naked to my great ≈øhame, but al≈øo that the hangmen ≈øhould deuide my coat, and the ≈øouldiours ca≈øt lots vpon him. We mu≈øt ≈øee in this place, how many coats there were, and who≈øe they were, and among whome they were deuided, becau≈øe all our ≈øaluation dooth con≈øi≈øt in being excluded or admitted vnto that deui≈øion. There were but two garments in all, and Chri≈øt was the mai≈øter of them, and they were deuided betwixt hangmen and ≈øouldiours, the place where was by the cro≈ø≈øe, and the manner how was by lots. The≈øe two garments were deuided betwixt the Gentlemen which kept and guarded Chri≈øt, and the hangmeÃÑ which crucified Chri≈øt, in≈øomuch that according vnto the merite or demerite of euery one of them, they receiued their part of the garment. Theophilus ≈øaith, Who are meant by the≈øe gentlemen and knights, but the vertuous and iu≈øt; and who by the hangmen but ≈øinners and naughty men? O infinit goodne≈ø≈øe, O clemency neuer ≈øeene before! ≈øuch as thine was O good Ie≈øus vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, where thou didde≈øt barre no man of the inheritance of thy ≈øweatings, and deuiding of thy merits, depriue no man, exclude no man, nor di≈øinherite no man, but there fell a≈øwel one part to the hangmen which lifted thee vp vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, as to Nichodemus who
tooke thee down from the ≈øame. I≈øichius vpon Leuiticus ≈øaith, As the ≈øonne of God was the Redeemer of all men, ≈øo his plea≈øure was, that his garments ≈øhould be deuided for all, and that none ≈øhould be excluded from the generall redemption; which he did pre≈øently him≈øelfe declare, ≈øeeing that he ≈øaued the theefe who was a Iew, and conuerted the Centurion who was a Gentile. O what great hope wee haue to be ≈øaued, and what great confidence that Chri≈øt will pardon vs! for ≈øeeing that hee hath di≈øtributed part of his merites and garments among butcherly hangmen, it is to be beleeued, that hee will giue with a better will vnto his cho≈øen friends. The difference in deuiding his garments was this, that tho≈øe cruell hangmen did immediately deuide and teare in pieces his garment as it was giuen them, and the Gentlemen kept it whole as it fell vnto them, in ≈øo much that in the handling of the garments, the per≈øons qualities might ea≈øily haue been knowne. That which the Iewes did in tho≈øe daies, the ≈øelfe ≈øame doe Chri≈øtians at this day: for tho≈øe which are good doe keepe all that Chri≈øt commanded them, and tho≈øe which are wicked, keep no more than plea≈øe them: in≈øomuch that the good and vertuous Chri≈øtian doth keepe Chri≈øts garment entire & whole, by endeuouring him≈øelfe to keepe the commandements; and the wicked and peruer≈øe doe keepe it rent and torne, and be content with the bare name of Chri≈øtians. S. Ierome ≈øayth, If thou do ≈øee thy ≈øelf, my brother, prowd in pre≈øumption, enuious in ambition, angry in impaciency, a glutton in eating, & couetous in giuing, tell me I pray thee, what doe≈øt thou hold of a Chri≈øtian, and what doe≈øt thou want of a Pagan? What greater di≈øa≈øter and lo≈ø≈øe could happeÃÑ vnto thy ≈øoule, or what like euill fall vpon thy body, than of all the di≈øtribution and deuiding of Chri≈øts coats and merites, there ≈øhould fall nothing to thy lot but the name of a Chri≈øtian? Doe≈øt thou not know that they call thee a Chri≈øtian in a mockery, if thou do not follow Chri≈øt, as they call him white Iohn, who is all blacke? O how vnhappy they be, vnto whome there fell nothing but a ≈øhred of Chri≈øts garment, that is, to brag that hee
hath heard the Go≈øpell preached, and that hee was bapti≈øed like a Chri≈øtian. For Chri≈øt is not content only with that, but his plea≈øure is, that as he gaue vs all his garments freely, ≈øo he will that wee ≈øerue him with all our might and forces. With the hangmen there fell a ≈øhred of Chri≈øts garment vnto him who keepeth but one commandement onely, and vnto him his whole coat which keepeth all that Chri≈øt commandeth: for Chri≈øt ≈øaid not vnto the young man, who asked him what he ≈øhould doe to goe to heauen, Keep the commandement, but keep, & ob≈øerue the commandements. There fell a ≈øhred or ragge of Chri≈øts garment vnto him, who thinketh to ob≈øerue the Go≈øpell onely by wi≈øhing well; and vnto him it fell whole and entire, who ≈øerueth him with workes and deeds, and not with de≈øires: for as Saint Barnard ≈øayth, The heauens are repleni≈øhed with good workes, and hell is full of good de≈øires. S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, As of children which doe equally inherite their fathers goods, ≈øome doe encrea≈øe their portion, & ≈øome wa≈øt and con≈øume it; ≈øo is it in the church of God: for although all were inheritours of the garments & merits of the ≈øon of God, yet ≈øome doe di≈øsipate and tear them to their own perdition, and ≈øome con≈øerue and keep them to their ≈øaluation. The authority alledged before ≈øayth, Super ve≈øtimentis pignoratis accubuerunt, as if hee would ≈øay, The Gentiles ≈øat down vpon the garments which were laid togage, and the Iews leaned al≈øo vpon them. For the Prophet to lay downe as a great fault and offence, that the Synagogue dur≈øt bee ≈øo bold as to leane vpon certaine garments which were laid to pawne, it mu≈øt be expounded with great diligence, and read with great heed, becau≈øe that in Scripture the newer and more vnu≈øuall a tearme is, the greater my≈øtery it doth contain. It is requi≈øite for vs to declare what the≈øe garments are, and why they were laid to pawne, and when they were laid to pawn, and al≈øo vnto whome, becau≈øe that all the≈øe circum≈øtances doe greatly beautifie the my≈øtery, and lead vs to the ≈øecret. For the better vnder≈øtanding of this new prophe≈øie, Super ve≈øtimentis pignoratis, &c, Wee mu≈øt handle another place which is as new
as this, the newne≈ø≈øe whereof vvil bring vs to the knowledge of the other. The new ≈øpeech is this, Ecce noua facio omnia; Which vvords Saint Iohn in the Apocalips heard Chri≈øt ≈øpeak. Behold & mark vvel all you vvhich be of my Church, how I doe not that which others haue done, nor vndertake that vvhich others haue vndertaken, nor teach that vvhich others haue taught, nor liue as others haue liued, becau≈øe that in my life and family there is no corrupt & rotten thing, but all ≈øound and whole, nor any old thing but all new. This is ≈øuch a new kind of ≈øpeech, that no man euer ≈øpake the like vntill the ≈øonne of God came: and to ≈øay the truth, vnle≈ø≈øe it vvere he who had created all things, who was able to renue all things? For if all the Angels, and all men are not able to make a flie, how ≈øhould they be able to make a new vvorld? Rupertus ≈øayth, O how well Chri≈øt ≈øayth, in ≈øaying, Behold I make all new! for beginning in him≈øelfe, he was a new man, he had a new ≈øoule, tooke new fle≈øh, gaue new light, taught new doctrine, liued a new life, and promi≈øed new glory. Was hee not a new man, ≈øeeing that no man but hee was both God and man? Who but hee had a new ≈øoule, ≈øeeing that his and no others vvas vnited to the diuine per≈øon? took he not new fle≈øh, ≈øeeing that none but he vvas of a mother and a virgine? Who but he gaue the vvorld a new law, ≈øeeing that he vvas the fir≈øt vvhich preached the Go≈øpell? did he not al≈øo promi≈øe a new reward vnto his elect, ≈øeeing none before him promi≈øed the kingdome of heauen? Si volueritis & audieritis me, bona terrae commedetis, ≈øaid God. E≈øay 1. as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, If you vvill beleeue me, & keep my coÃÑmandements, I vvill giue you victory again≈øt your enemies, I vvill giue you health to your bodies, I vvill giue you corne in your fields, and I vvill giue you peace in your kingdomes. This is that theÃÑ that God promi≈øed them, & all the reward vvhich he gaue theÃÑ for their trauails, in≈øomuch that the reward and glory of the Synagogue neuer vvent out of the kingdome of Pale≈øtine. The ≈øonne of God dooth not deale vvith vs vvhich are Chri≈øtians, as his Father did vvith the Iewes, ≈øeeing that he ≈øaith Matthew
10. Qui fecerit & docuerit hic vocabitur in regno caeloruu ‚Ä¢ , As if he would ≈øay, The Chri≈øtian who ≈øhall keepe my commandements, and the preacher which ≈øhall ≈øet forth my law, his name ≈øhall be written among tho≈øe which are prede≈øtinated, and he ≈øhall be placed in the kingdome of heauen. Saint Augustine ≈øaith in a Sermon, As the ≈øonne of God did command vs to keepe new precepts, ≈øo he did promi≈øe vs new rewards for it, and as hee gaue great commandements, ≈øo hee gaue great rewards: wherevpon it is, that vntil hee came into the world, no man commanded that which hee commanded, nor no man promi≈øed that which he promi≈øed. Chri≈øt ≈øaid not in vaine, Ecce noua facio omnia, but becau≈øe hee in≈øtituted the Sacrament, which was a hard thing to reach vnto, and commanded vs to beleeue the ble≈ø≈øed Trinity, which is a high matter to vnder≈øtand, willed vs to beleeue him both God & man, which is a new thing to bee receiued, charged vs to loue our enemies, which is a hard matter to doe, and commanded vs to keepe his law only, which was a new thing in the world to doe. S. Thomas in his book again≈øt the Gentiles ≈øayth, That as the ≈øonne of God did not command tho≈øe of the old law to beleeue great things, ≈øo he did not promi≈øe them but ≈ømall things, and becau≈øe hee commanded his cho≈øen Chri≈øtians to beleeue hard things, and performe things which were not ea≈øily done, he promi≈øed that they ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe and emoy very high rewards. To come then vnto the text of Ve≈øtimentis pignoratis, &c. It is to bee noted, that as the ≈øeruice of the iu≈øt was to bee done here vpon earth, and the reward which they are to receiue to be giuen aboue in heauen; becau≈øe wee ≈øhould not thinke that hee mocked vs, in deferring our paiment to the other world, his plea≈øure was to leaue vs a good gage and pledge in this world, vntill he ≈øhould reward vs for our good life in heauen. The pledges which Chri≈øt left vs in this world were his precious garments, his holy works, and his mo≈øt holy Sacraments. Why did Chri≈øt, thinke≈øt thou, leaue vs ≈øo many pledges in this life, but becau≈øe hee will vnpawne them afterward aboue in his glory? In his glory aboue all
tho≈øe pledges ≈øhall bee taken away and haue an end, becau≈øe that in heauen we ≈øhall need to hope for nothing, becau≈øe we ≈øhall ≈øee that with our eies, which now we de≈øire; nor we ≈øhall haue nothing to beleeue, becau≈øe there ≈øhall be nothing hidden; wee ≈øhall haue no cau≈øe to feare, becau≈øe there ≈øhall bee no death; wee ≈øhall need to aske for nothing, becau≈øe life is there euerla≈øting; neither ≈øhal we de≈øire any thing, ≈øeeing that glory is there perpetuall. O how happie be all Chri≈øtian people, ≈øeeing they haue not only Chri≈øts garments for a pledge and ho≈øtage, but al≈øo Chri≈øt him≈øelfe remaining with vs, vnder the vi≈øible ≈øigns of the Sacrament, vntil he giue him≈øelfe vnto vs in heauen glorified! Let no man maruell to heare vs ≈øay, that we haue Chri≈øt for a pledge & pawne, for that which his Father promi≈øed vs, ≈øeeing that the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith al≈øo that we haue the Holy gho≈øt for a pledge, for that which the ≈øon commanded vs, Ip≈øe est pignus haereditatis meae, as if he would ≈øay, God the eternal Father hath giuen vs the gifts of the holy Gho≈øt, and all the garments and merites of his ≈øonne for a pledge of that which hee hath promi≈øed vs; and this no longer but vntill hee will carry vs to his eternall glory, and giue vs the fruition of his diuine e≈ø≈øence. What Chri≈øtian is there who will bee afraid to loo≈øe him≈øelfe, and not haue a hope to ≈øaue him≈øelfe, hauing as wee haue for an a≈ø≈øurance of our ≈øaluation, as Chri≈øts robes in pawne, and the gifts of the Holy gho≈øt in ho≈øtage? Super ve≈øtimentis pignoratis all holymen doe leane, when they ioine their workes with Chri≈øts workes: for all that we doe is little worth vnle≈ø≈øe we tie it vnto Chri≈øts merits. It is to be weighed, that the Prophet O≈øee did not ≈øee the garments by them≈øelues, and elbowes by them≈øelues, but garments with elbowes, and elbowes with garments, to giue vs to vnder≈øtand, that we cannot merite with our own works, and that Chri≈øt wil not alwaies ≈øaue vs by him≈øelfe; by rea≈øon whereof, it is nece≈ø≈øary, that wee fa≈øten our armes vpon his workes, and that he ≈øticke his workes vpon our elbows armes.

div.head: CHAP. V. Where is brought a ≈øigure of Tobias, and declared to the purpo≈øe.
div.p:
EXentera hunc pi≈øcem, & cor eius & fel & iecur repone tibi, Tobias 6 chap. The Angell Raphael ≈øpake the≈øe words vnto young Tobias, as if hee would ≈øay; Crie not, nor bee not afraid of this fi≈øh, but take him out of the water, flay him, cut him in the middle, and take out his heart, his gaule, and liuer, and keepe it all for thy ≈øelfe, becau≈øe it is all very medicinable to cure a ≈øicke man. The ≈øtory of Tobias is very well knowne to the learned in Scripture. When he ≈øent his young ≈øonne Tobias to Rages a towne of the Medes, for the recouering of tenne markes of ≈øiluer which he had lent his friend Gabelus, when hee was captiue in Babilon, and when yong Tobias came to the riuer Tygris, to wa≈øh his feet, there came foorth a very great fi≈øh to the banck ≈øide toward him, with ≈øuch boldne≈ø≈øe, as if hee would haue eaten and ≈øwallowed him vp, before that hee could flie from him. When the Angell ≈øaw the fiercene≈ø≈øe of this fi≈øh, and the great feare that the youth was ≈øtroke into, hee began to encourage him, ≈øaying: Feare not the fi≈øh, becau≈øe the fi≈øh ought rather to be afraid of thee, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary that thou do by him that which he would haue done to thee, becau≈øe another cannot recouer health before this fi≈øh bee killed. Tobias tooke heart by the encouragement of the Angell, and fa≈øtening on the fi≈øh by the gilles, drew him out of the water, and ≈øtripped him, and tooke out his heart, and his gaule, and his liuer, as the Angell his ma≈øter had commanded him to doe. Now that Tobias fear was pa≈øt, when the fi≈øh was dead and drawne, he ≈øaid vnto his Angell: Tell mee brother Azarias, to what purpo≈øe thou didde≈øt command mee to
keepe the fi≈øhes heart, gaule, and liuer, and didde≈øt not bid me eat at all of him. To this the Angell an≈øwered, Thou mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, my ≈øonne Tobias, that this thy iourney, and this chance which hath befaln vnto thee, wanteth not a great my≈øtery, as hereafter it ≈øhall appeare. But for the pre≈øent, let it ≈øuffice thee to know, that the meat of this fi≈øh is good for trauailers to eat of, and the heart good to ca≈øt out diuels, and the gaule good to heale the blind, and the liuer ≈øoueraine for to cure other externall di≈øea≈øes. There are pre≈øented vnto vs many deepe my≈øteries in this figure, if it may plea≈øe God to giue mee the knowledge to expound them; for in it is ≈øet foorth the wonderfull death which the ≈øonne of God ≈øuffered, and the in≈øpeakeable fruit and benefite vvhich vvee receiue by it. Here is to bee vnder≈øtood, who Tobias is vvhich taketh the iourney, what the fi≈øh is which put him into a fright, what garbi≈øh he tooke from him, what skin he ≈øtripped him of, what is the fle≈øh which hee broiled, what is the heart which hee tooke out of him, what the liuer, and vvhat the gaule which hee kept. Although wee ≈øpeake but a word on euery word, yet this ≈øeemeth to bee a figure full of great ≈øecrets. To come then to the point, who is Tobias who goeth to recouer his fathers goods, but onely all mankind, who goeth euery day a iourney, to recouer the grace which his father Adam lo≈øt? Dum ≈øumus in ≈øeculo, peregrinamur ad dominum, ≈øayth the Apo≈øtle, As long as vvee liue in this mortall vvorld, no man can ≈øay that hee hath a dwelling place, or neighbour, but onely, that hee is a pilgrime and a way-faring man, and the end of our iourney and pilgrimage is, to ≈øeeke for the grace vvhich our fir≈øt father lo≈øt vs, and the glory which our eternall father promi≈øed vs. Then wee ≈øay a man is a pilgrime when he maketh no abode any where, but goeth on, and ≈øtaieth no longer in a place than hee can get nece≈ø≈øaries for his iourney. If vvee aske a man what hee doth, it is an ordinary an≈øwere to ≈øay, that hee either plaieth, or doth his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, or ≈øome ≈øuch like, which in truth is not ≈øo, but his better an≈øwere is to ≈øay, that he wa≈øteth
and con≈øumeth him≈øelfe, and that he is a dying; for a mans life goeth away in playing and labouring. Seneca ≈øayth, Doth not thy life, thinke≈øt thou, goe away, ≈øeeing that euery houre thy life is an houre ≈øhorter, and euery day a day ≈øhorter? Saint Augu≈øtine vpon the Apo≈øtles words ≈øayth, If a man be asked how old he is, or what yeares hee hath, he is wont to an≈øwere either thirty, or fortie, or ≈øuch like; which is cleane contrary vnto that which hee ≈øhould an≈øwere: for hee ≈øhould not ≈øay he hath ≈øo many yeares, but that he wanteth ≈øo many yeares: for if he haue any years at all, it bee tho≈øe which hee looketh for; for as for tho≈øe which are pa≈øt, they are now none of his. The Philo≈øopher ≈øaith, that De tempore non habemus ni≈øi Nunc, Whereby hee meaneth, that wee haue no time but the pre≈øent moment, becau≈øe that the time pa≈øt is already gone, and the time to come is vncertain. Cicero de ≈øenectute ≈øayth, What hath a man that hath liued an hundred yeares, but only time lo≈øt, a grieued heart, a weary body, ≈ømal help, a loathing life, a vading credite, and death at his gates? O how well the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, As long as wee bee in this world, Peregrinamur ad dominum, ≈øeeing that by how much the more wee increa≈øe in age, ≈øo much the more vvee decrea≈øe in life. And to ≈øay the truth, to die young, or to die old, is nothing el≈øe but to come to our Inne betimes or late. Remigius ≈øayth, The Apo≈øtle doth call vs pilgrimes and ≈øtrangers with great rea≈øon, becau≈øe he ≈øeeth, that we haue no goods in this world, which are proper to our ≈øelues: for if euery man would leaue that which were another bodies, for a certaine he ≈øhould be left very naked. For ≈øayth Alchimius the Philo≈øopher, if the ≈øheep ≈øhould take thy garments from thee, the kine thy ≈øhoes, the worms thy ≈øilke, the earth thy linnen, the vines thy wine, the corne thy bread, the trees their fruit, the fountaynes their waters; tell mee I pray thee, of thy ≈øelfe, and by thy ≈øelfe, what ≈øhould≈øt thou haue, what ≈øhoulde≈øt thou be worth or what ≈øhoulde≈øt thou bee able to doe? Horace ≈øayth to this purpo≈øe, Be not prowd like a lion, nor exa≈øperate thy ≈øelfe like an ounce: for if euery one would take from thy hou≈øe & per≈øon
that which is his, there would be no liuing creature more ba≈øe thaÃÑ thou, ≈øeeing that thou ha≈øt neither indu≈øtry to maintaine thy ≈øelfe, nor weapons to defend thy ≈øelfe. Wee haue ≈øaid all this, to proue that if Tobias was a pilgrime, wee are al≈øo pilgrimes. But alas alas, hee is accompanied with the good Angel who keepeth him, and we compa≈ø≈øed with a thou≈øand enemies vvhich be≈øiege vs. Doe not wee, trow you, take our voiage be≈øet with a thou≈øand perils, and hindered with as many troubles, con≈øidering that the deuill doth tempt vs, the fle≈øh mole≈øt and prouoke vs, the world deceiue vs, friends faile vs, our heart ≈øorroweth, our health decaieth, and our life daily ≈øhorteneth? The figure ≈øayth, that as Tobias went on his iourney, the fi≈øh came to the bancke to ≈øwallow him vp, whereof in the end hee receiued more profite than feare, in≈øomuch that by the ≈øame fi≈øh, of vvhich hee thought hee ≈øhould haue beene deuoured, his father receiued remedy. What was that great fi≈øh, of which Tobias thought he ≈øhould haue been deuoured, but only the ≈øonne of the eternall God vvhen he came to redeeme the vvorld? The fi≈øh vvas bred in the bottome of the riuer, and the ≈øonne of God was borne in the bo≈øome of the eternall Father; and how deepe ≈øoeuer the riuer Tygris vvas, yet the ≈øea of the diuine e≈ø≈øence is farre more deeper. Augu≈øtine in his booke of the Trinity ≈øayth, Wilt thou ≈øee how much more deeper the eternity of the Father and of his ≈øonne is, than the ≈øea? For it is po≈øsible to empty the ≈øea for all his greatne≈ø≈øe, but for the ≈øecrets of the holy Trinity, it is impo≈øsible fully to vnder≈øtand. The fi≈øhe comming out of the vvater droue young Tobias into a great feare, but Chri≈øt cau≈øed a greater feare when hee came into the vvorld, ≈øeeing the Angels bowed them≈øelues, the kings adored him, the ≈øtarres vvere changed, the Iewes were mooued, and the deuils vvere a≈øeard. The feare vvhich the fi≈øh put Tobias in, continued but halfe an houre, but the fear which Chri≈øt put the vvorld in, dureth vntill this day: for being afeard and amazed, the Iews and Pagans cannot yet per≈øuade them≈øelues, that Chri≈øt ≈øhould be the God whoÃÑ they ≈øhould
beleeue in, and the Lord which ≈øhall iudge them. When that fi≈øh went out of the riuer to the bancke, of two which were there pre≈øent, the one which was the Angel knew him, & the other, which was Tobias was afeard: and euen ≈øo in like maner when the ≈øonne of God came downe from heauen vnto the earth, the Synagogue was ≈øcandalized, and the church receiued him, in ≈øo much that according vnto old Simeons prophecie, this diuine fi≈øh came to the ≈øhore of the world, for the re≈øurrection of the good, and the ≈øcandale of the wicked. Praeparauit dominus pi≈øcem grandem vt deglutiret Ionam, ≈øayth the holy Scripture, Ionas 2. As if hee would ≈øay, At the very in≈øtant when the cruell Marriners did ca≈øt the Prophet Ionas into the bottome of the ≈øea, immediately our Lord prepared a great fi≈øh, which ≈øwallowed him aliue, and which kept him in his bowels ≈øafe and ≈øound. As before wee met with Tobias and his fi≈øh, ≈øo now wee haue lighte vpon Ionas and his fi≈øh, whereof the one was greatly afeard, and the other ≈øwallowed vp, by rea≈øon whereof wee mu≈øt ≈øeeke out ≈øome ≈øecret in them, and di≈øcouer ≈øome my≈øtery in the expounding of them. Who≈øe figure doth Ionas repre≈øent, but onely the good and godly, and who were the Marriners which threw him into the ≈øea but onely wicked men? Then the Marriners doe ca≈øt Ionas into the ≈øea, when the wicked doe per≈øecute and ca≈øt downe the good, becau≈øe there is no greater torment to a naughty man, than to heare a good man prai≈øed in his pre≈øence. Of all tho≈øe which were in that ≈øhip onely Ionas was a holy and vertuous man, as it doth plainly appeare, becau≈øe there was no one which ≈øpake again≈øt the throwing of him into the ≈øea, but were all of one opinion in that fact: for albeit naughty men bee ≈øometime at variance among them≈øelues, yet in doing of mi≈øchiefe they ea≈øily agree in one. O in what greater danger good mens fame and credite is in, among the wicked, than their liues and goods in the deepe ≈øeas which is plainly ≈øeene in that, that men did ca≈øt the holy Prophet Ionas from them, and the waters did receiue him into them, Origen vpon holy Iob ≈øayth, What ≈øhould become of the good,
if God had no care ouer them? What would not naughty men venter to doe with their ≈ømal ≈øhame & le≈ø≈øe con≈øcience, if their power ≈øhould ≈øtretch as far as their malice? If thou wilt ≈øee, my brother, the care that God hath to keepe thee, if thou haue a care to ≈øerue him, thou ≈øhalt ≈øee it in the holy Prophet Ionas, in that our Lord had prepared long before a fi≈øh to ≈øaue him, than the Marriners had determined to drowne him. The fi≈øh which did ≈øaue the Propher Ionas, did not put him by him, nor on him, nor vnder him, but within him, and ≈øo kept him ≈øo warily in his entrals, that neither the fi≈øh dur≈øt kill him, nor the waters drowne him. O that thy goodne≈ø≈øe is infinit, & thy charity very great, my good Ie≈øus, ≈øeeing that thou doe≈øt acquit all tho≈øe which the world doth condemne, loue tho≈øe which the world hateth, receiue tho≈øe which he ca≈øteth off, fo≈øter tho≈øe which he ≈øuffereth to peri≈øh, and giue≈øt honour vnto all tho≈øe which the world doth di≈øhonour. Aymon vpon Ionas ≈øaith, The Prophet Ionas ≈ølept in the lowe≈øt part of the ≈øhip, & the Marriners did ca≈øt him into the bottome of the ≈øea, & the Whale kept him in the ≈øecrete≈øt part of his bowels; I mean by this, that Chri≈øt dooth put vs in the daintie≈øt part of his bowels: for it is his propertie to keepe tho≈øe in his hart, which loue him from the hart. S. Ierome ≈øaith, If thou doe put Chri≈øt in thy eies to looke vpon him, he doth put thee in his to looke vpon thee; If thou place him in thy eares to heare him, he doth place thee in his to heare thee; if thou haue him in thy tongue to prai≈øe him, he hath thee in his to honour thee; if thou put him in thy heart to loue him, hee doth put thee in his to loue thee; in≈øomuch that where thou doe≈øt put Chri≈øt, Chri≈øt doth al≈øo in the ≈øame place put thee. Vpon tho≈øe words of the P≈øalme, Iacta cogitatuÃÑ tuuÃÑ in domine, S. Ba≈øil ≈øaith. Yeeld thy ≈øelfe, my brother, yeeld thy ≈øelfe to the will of God, goe whither he will direct thee, do that which he commandeth thee, giue him that which he asketh of thee, beleeue him in that which he telleth thee: for as hee pre≈øerued the Prophet Ionas in the Whales belly, ≈øo hee will pre≈øerue thee in the dangers of this life. By this which happened
vnto the Prophet Ionas, it is very euident, that thre is nothing firm & ≈øtable but that which God doth ≈øu≈øtain, nor nothing ≈øure but that which God doth keep, ≈øeeing that that holy Prophet was drie among the waters, found comfort in danger, a remedy again≈øt death, and profite in his enemy. Did he not find a remedy again≈øt death, and profite in his enemy, ≈øeeing the water did not only not drowne him, nor the huge and great fi≈øh kill him, but was in the Whales belly with as great contentment and delight, as a Prince is in his roiall pallace? We haue ≈øpoken all this, becau≈øe no man ≈øhould omit to doe his duty, or goe with the truth, as farre as hee can, for feare of temptation, or ielou≈øie of naughty per≈øons; becau≈øe our Lord who deliuered Tobias that the fi≈øh ≈øhould not deuour him, and Ionas from the ≈øea that it ≈øhould not drowne him, will al≈øo deliuer thee from temptations which follow thee, & from the enemies which per≈øecute thee.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Here the Author followeth the figure which hee touched before, which is declared well to the purpo≈øe: and there is brought al≈øo a prophe≈øie of Ieremy.
div.p:
APprehende branchiam eius, & trahe eum ad te: quod cum feci≈ø≈øet, traxit eum in ≈øiccum, Tobias 6. chapter, The≈øe are the wordes which the Angel Raphael ≈øpake vnto yong Tobias, as if he would ≈øay; I haue told thee already, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt not feare this fi≈øh, but rather as he came vnto thee, ≈øo thou ≈øhoulde≈øt goe and meet him, and apprehend him by the head, and pull out his gilles, all which I would not tell thee, vnle≈ø≈øe I thought it conuenient for thee. Although Tobias did not then know the Angel for to be an Angel, but thought him to bee another man like him≈øelfe, yet notwith≈øtanding he gaue credit vnto his ≈øpeech, and accepted of his coun≈øell, ≈øo that Tobias did immediately kill and panch the fi≈øh vpon the ≈øand, which thought to eat
him in the vvater. We doe in this place aduerti≈øe the curious Reader, that he ≈øhall not be able to vnder≈øtand this chapter, if he doe not read the chapter afore going, becau≈øe this figure of Tobias vvas there begun, and from thence is cited. To continue then this figure, the text ≈øayth, that Tobias did ≈øit vpon the fi≈øh, and tooke him by the ≈øinnes neer vnto the head, and by the gilles in the throat, and drew him to the ≈øand, & there did cut off his head and ≈øtrip him, and tooke out his heart & liuer, and kept his gaule for him≈øelfe, and did eat part of him, and ≈øalted the re≈øt for his iourney. Who is Tobias but the Iudaicall people? What was the fierce ≈øea but the pa≈øsion of Chri≈øt? And vvhat vvas the great fi≈øh but the ≈øame Chri≈øt? And vvhat vvas the ≈øand vvhere the fi≈øh was panched, but the high Mount of Caluary where Chri≈øt vvas put to death? Tobias did greatiu≈øtice vpon that vnhappie fi≈øh, vvhen hee panched him on the ≈øands; but the Synagogue did farre greater cruelties vpon Chri≈øt vvhen they tooke Chri≈øts life away on the Mount of Caluary: for if Tobias did kill the fi≈øh, it vvas becau≈øe the Angell vvhich kept him did ≈øo command him, but if the Synagogue did put Chri≈øt to death, it was done of meere enuy and malice. For the better vnder≈øtanding of this place, it is here to bee noted, that it was done by a continuall miracle, that Chri≈øt did neuer ≈øuffer his mo≈øt holy ≈øoule to communicate and impart her glory vnto his body, becau≈øe that if he had not hindered that, his body had not ben pa≈øsible at all. It was for no other cau≈øe but Propter no≈øtram ≈øalut√´, that our great Redeemer ≈øuffered the death vpon the cro≈ø≈øe as if he had been a ≈øinner. Candolfus ≈øayth, Chri≈øt ≈øometimes gaue place, that the glory of his ≈øoule ≈øhould redound and fall vpon the members of his body, as it happened in the hill Thabor, by rea≈øon vvhereof his precious fle≈øh vvas ≈øo tender in ≈øuffering, and ≈øo pa≈øsing de≈øirous to returne to the fruition of the ≈øame glory, that the ab≈øence and delay of that diuine and heauenly comfort did bring Chri≈øt mo≈øt grieuous torment. Vpon tho≈øe vvords of the P≈øalme, Aby≈ø≈øus aby≈øsum
inuocat. Saint Ba≈øil ≈øayth, for as much as the ≈øoule of the ≈øonne of God vvas full of glory, and his precious body loaden with grieuous paine and angui≈øh, O how oftentimes the depth of his trauailes and griefes did feruently de≈øire and ≈øigh after the depth of his comfort and con≈øolation, the vvhich his eternall Father vvould not impart vnto him vntill hee had ended the redemption of the vvorld. O great goodne≈ø≈øe, O infinite charity! who but thou, O my good Ie≈øus, vvas hungry vvith bread in his hand, thir≈øty vvith vvater in his mouth, naked vvith garments in his che≈øts, ≈øad and afflicted with glory in his ≈øoule? Vpon tho≈øe vvords, Tristis e≈øt anima mea. S. Barnard ≈øayth, It is no maruell if my ≈øoule bee ≈øorrowfull, and full of angui≈øh, becau≈øe the houre of my glory and felicity is not yet come: but in thee O good Ie≈øus, why ≈øhould thy fle≈øh bee ≈øo wearied? And why ≈øhould thy ≈øoule be comfortle≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing that thou carrie≈øt with thee all the glory which is in heauen or in earth. Vbertinus vpon this place ≈øayth, The Redeemer of the world being in the agony of death, and very neere the end of his life, remembring him≈øelfe of that heauenly comfort and diuine influence, vvhich from the glory of his ≈øoule was woont to bee imparted to his precious body, ≈øpake this word Sitio, as if he would ≈øay, O how great the thir≈øt is vvhich I ≈øuffer in this la≈øt houre, and terrible agony, to vvit, of that influence and heauenly comfort, which was woont to bee imparted from my owne ≈øoule vnto my owne fle≈øh, becau≈øe this death and pa≈øsion which my owne Father doth lay vpon this my weake fle≈øh, is not onely grieuous, but doth al≈øo exceed all other humane puni≈øhment. The great thir≈øt that Chri≈øt ≈øuffered vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and the cooling vvater which hee de≈øired, was not the water of the fountain of the hill Lybanus, nor yet that which ran in the riuer Silo, but that heauenly con≈øolation which the glory of his ≈øoule vvas vvont to cau≈øe in him, for that other humane thir≈øt could not ≈øo much grieue him, con≈øidering how neere hee vvas to the end of his life. Wee haue
v≈øed all this di≈øcour≈øe to extoll the word of the figure which ≈øayth, Et traxit pi≈øcem in ≈øiccum, It is to bee vnder≈øtood, that young Tobias did kill the fi≈øh vpon the ≈øand, vvhich would haue killed him in the water. When, thinke≈øt thou, did Tobias draw the fi≈øh vpon drie land, but vvhen the eternall Father did leaue his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øonne vpon the cro≈ø≈øe without any humane con≈øolation? O how drie was that drie tree vpon which the heauenly fi≈øh hanged, vvho hauing been brought vp in the deepe ≈øea of the diuine e≈ø≈øence, had not there ≈øo much as one drop of water to drinke. What can be pitied more in this life, than for a fi≈øh hauing been brought vp in the water, yet afterward to die for vvant of vvater? Tobias fi≈øh was hard by the vvater ≈øide, and yet died vvith thir≈øt, and Chri≈øts fle≈øh vvas coupeled with his holy ≈øoule, and died al≈øo vvith thir≈øt, becau≈øe the eternall Father to giue vs drinke of his water of heauen, killed his owne onely ≈øonne with thir≈øt, and brought him to die vpon the ≈øands of this world. If Tobias ≈øhould not haue drawne the fi≈øh to the land, hee could not haue ma≈øtered him: if Chri≈øt had not become man, neither could he haue died, for how≈øoeuer it be naturall for vs to die, yet it is much more naturall for God alwaies to liue. What meaneth it that the ≈øelfe ≈øame fi≈øh of whome Tobias thought he ≈øhould haue been deuoured, lay dead afterward at his feet, but that, that God which all the powers of heauen did feare and tremble at, we ≈øee now meek & gentle, & hanged vpon the tree? When God was nothing but God, & in his own diuine e≈ø≈øence being, all the world did feare him and tremble, but after that hee came vpon our ≈øandie humanity, & ≈øet foot vpon the drine≈ø≈øe of this world, hee who before made others afeard, was him≈øelfe afraid, and he who before did throw downe others, fell him≈øelfe, and he who before enriched others became poore, and he who gaue all comfort wept him≈øelfe, and hee who killed before died. De≈øertum faciam mare eius & ≈øiccabo venum eius, ≈øaid God by the Prophet Ieremy, chap. 51. as if he would ≈øay. I will make all his ≈øea as drie and without vvater, as
de≈øart and ≈øolitary mountains are woont to bee, and I will cut off all the vaines and ≈øtreames of his depth, becau≈øe there ≈øhal flow no water at any end. The≈øe words mu≈øt curiou≈øly be expounded: for God to ≈øay, that the ≈øea ≈øhall bee as drie as a ≈øolitary mountaine, and that hee will cut off all the vaines of his cour≈øe throughout all the world, ≈øeemeth to bee a new ≈øpeech, and a thing that was neuer ≈øeene to be beleeued. Leauing the letter, & ≈øpeaking according vnto the ≈øence of the≈øe words, the eternal Father doth forewarne his precious ≈øonne, that he wil not onely deale with him like one which will not he are him, nor giue him any comfort, but al≈øo, that he will cut off all occa≈øions, whereby hec may any way receiue comfort; in ≈øo much that to make the ≈øea become a de≈øart, is to make of God a true man, and to cut off the vaines of the ≈øea, is to cut off all heauenly con≈øolation. What other thing was that deepe ≈øea, but onely the diuine e≈ø≈øence? And what el≈øe was it to make a drie de≈øart of the raging ≈øea, but to make him who was the eternal God a true maÃÑ? God ≈øaid by the mouth of his Prophet, De≈øertum faciammare eius, ≈øpeaking of his ≈øon; and as he did prophecie, ≈øo he did accompli≈øh it: for when he hanged vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, he neuer made an≈øwere to any petition which hee made him, nor yet to quench his thir≈øt gaue him ≈øo much as one cup of water. What a ≈øtrange thing is this, O eternall Father, what a ≈øtrange thing is this? For thy ba≈øtard & abortiue childreÃÑ thou did≈øt drawwater out of the liuely rock, & for thy lawful ≈øon ha≈øt thou not ≈øo much as one drop? WheÃÑ Agar & her ≈øon. I≈ømael were ready to peri≈øh with thir≈øt in the mountaines of Ber≈øabee neere vnto the Mount Lybanus, v≈øing thy infinite power thou did≈øt make of the dry de≈øart great abundaÃÑce of water; & why theÃÑ do≈øt thou make vnto thy ≈øon of an abundant ≈øea a dry de≈øart? thou did≈øt ≈øend meat to the Prophet Daniel when he was ca≈øt vnto the Lyons, although no man did demand it at thy hards, & wilt thou not giue thy precious ≈øon a little water at ≈øuch great entreaty? CoÃÑ≈øidering that wheÃÑ the famine was at Samaria, thou did≈øt coÃÑmand the Crowes to carry the Prophet Helias food,
and the riuer Carith to giue him drinke, why doe≈øt thou not helpe thy owne ≈øonne, whom thou ha≈øt ingendred of thy owne ≈øub≈øtance, with a little water, in this his extream thir≈øt? Con≈øidering that thou didde≈øt turn the ≈øower waters of Marath to be ≈øweet, becau≈øe tho≈øe cur≈øed people ≈øhould drinke of them, why wilt thou giue thy precious ≈øonne neither of the ≈øweet nor ≈øowre? O what great encrea≈øing of torments to Chri≈øt are framed in the figure of Tobias, ioined with the prophe≈øie of Ieremy, ≈øeeing the one did draw the fi≈øh to the drie land, and the other made a de≈øart of the ≈øea! for vpon that drie tree of the cro≈ø≈øe, Chri≈øt was exceeding drie, ≈øeeing hee could not obtain a little water to drink of, and hee was al≈øo in a great de≈øart, ≈øeeing that hee found not ≈øo much as one friend to comfort him≈øelfe with. The fourth my≈øtery which the figure containeth is, that Tobias did open the fi≈øh, and took out his gaule and his heart; both which did him & his afterwards great good, the one for his owne marriage, and the other to cure his fathers blindne≈ø≈øe. It is greatly to be noted, that in all that fi≈øh, Tobias found nothing which was not worthy of the keeping, commodious and profitable in curing & ≈øauerous in eating. The be≈øt that euer hath been, or ≈øhall be in the world, was the Creator and Redeemer of the world, who≈øe words were holy, who≈øe doctrine was profitable, who≈øe workes were maruellous, and who≈øe bowels were mo≈øt louing. What did Tobias vnto that fi≈øh, that the Iewes did not vnto Chri≈øt? If the fi≈øh was drawne out of the riuer, ≈øo was Chri≈øt from the people; if the fi≈øh was put vpon drie land, ≈øo was Chri≈øt carried vnto the Mount of Caluary; if the fi≈øh was ≈øtripped, ≈øo was Chri≈øt whipped; if the fi≈øhes throat was cut, Chri≈øt was al≈øo crucified; if the fi≈øh was opened, ≈øo was Chri≈øt pierced with a ≈øpeare; if the fi≈øh was ca≈øt into the fire, ≈øo was Chri≈øt al≈øo ca≈øt into the ≈øepulchre. This which wee haue ≈øaid is but a little in re≈øpect of that which wee will ≈øay, and that is, that the holy catholike Church hath drawne out this ble≈ø≈øed fi≈øhes gaule, with the which hee cureth vs, and heart with the which hee loueth vs, and liuer with the which he pardoneth vs, & bowels
with which hee dooth cheri≈øh vs. O good Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules health, who hath euer had or who euer ≈øhall haue a more louinge heart than thou to loue vs, or ≈øo ≈øound a liuer to pardon vs, or ≈øo profitable a gaule to cure vs, or ≈øuch tender bowels to cheri≈øh vs? What wilt thou denie me now, or what wilt thou not now giue mee, O my good Ie≈øus, ≈øeeing that for to ≈øhew thy clernency and mercy vpon me, thou art hanged vpon a drie tree, made a dead fi≈øh, opened, drawne and bowelled for my ≈øake? What loue can bee compared vnto thy loue, ≈øeeing that for that which touched me, and not for any thing that belonged to thee, thou didde≈øt con≈øent that they ≈øhould open thy heart, and didde≈øt permit them to rend and teare thy bowels? What am I able to giue thee, O good Ie≈øus, what can I giue thee, vnle≈ø≈øe it be my heart which is filthy for thine which is cleane, my rotten liuer for thy vvhole one, my bitter gaule for thy ≈øweet one, and my wicked and hurtful bowels for thy mo≈øt louing ones? Which are the greate≈øt relickes which are this day in heauen or earth, but the heart, liuer, and bowels, which Chri≈øt left vnto his church? O how happy ≈øhould he be who ≈øhould haue ≈øuch relickes in his cu≈øtodie! for hauing thy heart in cu≈øtodie, how coulde≈øt thou chu≈øe but loue me, and hauing thy bowels in keeping, how woulde≈øt thou but pardon me? How is it po≈øsible, O my good Ie≈øus, how is it po≈øsible that there ≈øhould bee any euill thing in thee, vvhen as the church hath thy precious gaule for a relicke? Since the beginning of the vvorld there hath neuer been any ≈øuch thing ≈øeene or heard, that is, that among the relickes vvhich the church dooth account for the be≈øt, the gaule is one of the mo≈øt precious, becau≈øe that vvithout that bitter gaule, neither the world could haue beene redeemed, nor the Prince thereof haue beene ouercome. What is the gaule which the church keepeth in her trea≈øure, but only the bitter pa≈øsion which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered? The riche≈øt iewell which the Synagogue had, was the Manna vvhich came from heauen, & the greate≈øt trea≈øure which the church hath, is the gaule and pa≈øsion of Chri≈øt. Betwixt vvhich two
vvhat great difference there is, it is ea≈øily perceiued, becau≈øe that the profite & coÃÑmodity of our gaule doth continue vntil this day, & will continue for euer; but the memory of that old Manna is already lo≈øt. O glorious gaule, O happy gaul, which thou good Lord didde≈øt leaue vnto thy catholick church! for if it did kill thee, it did make mee whole, if it gaue thee paine it gaue me glory, if it was gaule vnto thee, it was hony to me, & if thou didde≈øt end thy life vvith it, yet my ≈øoule vvas redeemed vvith it. Chri≈øts pa≈øsioÃÑ vvas bitter gaule vnto Chri≈øt, and yet Chri≈øts death vvas a ≈øweet gaule for the redeeming of all the vvorld: for if vnto him there fell trauell & pain, yet vnto vs there fell re≈øt & quietne≈ø≈øe, if it fell to his lot to ≈øuffer, yet it fell to vs to reioice & be glad, if the ≈øoure fell vnto him, the ≈øweet fell vnto vs, in ≈øo much that hee cho≈øe the gaule for him≈øelfe, and left the hony for vs. Iurauit patribus dare terrans fluentem lacte & melle, ≈øaid the Prophet Moi≈øes Exod. 13; As if he vvould ≈øay, You ≈øhall well remember, O yee children of I≈ørael, how you did agree vvith our Lord, & he vvith you, & that both of you by oth, that you ≈øhould neuer ≈øerue any other Lord but him, and that he would giue you a land vvhich ≈øhould flow milke and hony. Notwith≈øtanding this oth, the children of I≈ørael were ≈øuch naughty periures, that our Lord determined not to giue them a land which ≈øhould flow hony, but which ≈øhould bring them forth gaule, ≈øeeing hee made it batten for to ≈øow in, rugged and rough to trauell in, vnhealthfull to dwell in, vveake in defence, drie to drinke in, and very poore to maintaine it ≈øelfe. God did make a farre better agreement vvith his Church, than vvith the Synagogue: for hee did not ≈øend vs a land vvhich ≈øhould bring forth honey but gaule, and therefore hee commanded vs to doe vvorkes vvhich ≈øhould bee very vnplea≈øant and vn≈øauoury vnto ≈øen≈øualitie, although very conformable and very profitable. Chri≈øt did drinke bitter gaules, and gaue vs of the ≈øame to drinke: for vvhen hee vvas poore, he commaunded vs to bee poore al≈øo, hee vvas per≈øecuted, and commanded vs to ≈øuffer per≈øecution, hee pardoned his iniuries,
and commanded vs to pardon ours; he ≈øuffered death being without fault, and charged vs to ≈øuffer it being in fault: all which things are as vn≈øauoury and bitter to accompli≈øh, as hony is ≈øweet in eating. O what bitter gaules our Sauiour dooth command vs to eat, when he ≈øayth, The way is ≈øtreit which leadeth vnto life! but he turneth the≈øe bitter gaules into ≈øweet hony-combes, when hee ≈øayth, My yoke is ≈øweet: for if the way vnto heauen be bitter, yet it is made very ≈øweet, by going in Chri≈øts company. The yoke of the world doth make vs beleeue that he is of hony, and yet he is but of gaule; and contrariwi≈øe the yoke of Chri≈øt dooth threaten vs, that hee is of hony: for immediately as wee bow our heads to carry him, Chri≈øt putteth him≈øelfe on the other ≈øide to helpe vs.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of a new thir≈øt which King Dauid had, which was a thir≈øt not to drinke, but to ≈øaue him≈øelfe.
div.p:
SItiuit anima mea, ad doum fontem viuum. P≈øalme 41. It is nece≈ø≈øary, that wee fir≈øt examine, what thir≈øt Dauid ≈øpeaketh of, and what water he de≈øireth to drink of: for as there are many kinds of waters, and many ≈øorts of ≈øuch as are thir≈øty, ≈øo there is al≈øo many kinds of thir≈øte, and many things wherewith to quench the ≈øame. If Euripides doe not deceiue vs, corporall thir≈øt is cau≈øed of the hear of the liuer, or of the inflaming of choler, or of eating ≈øalt things, ≈øo that indeed true thir≈øt is nothing el≈øe but ouermuch heat, and want of moi≈øture. With this corporall thir≈øt the people of I≈ørael was troubled in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, and Dauid when he de≈øired the water of Bethleem, and the captaine Si≈øara when hee fled from the battaile, and al≈øo Samp≈øon when there gu≈øhed out water vnto him out of an a≈ø≈øes iawe bone. The thir≈øt which the poore I≈øraelites ≈øuffered in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, and the water which they drank out of the ro ‚Ä¢ k, did co≈øt them very deerly; for at the ≈øame time they dranke and wept. Which is ea≈øily perceiued; for if we drinke at dinner, wee drinke better at ≈øupper, and the more a man doth drinke, the more he may, and although we kill our ‚Ä¢ hir≈øt for a time, yet it is not fully taken away. This ≈øhould not bee his thir≈øt, this ≈øhould not be his anxiety, nor yet his complaint, nor that which he ≈øo feruently de≈øired: for being as he was, ≈øo mighty and great a king, hee wanted neither noble wines to drinke of, nor dainty waters to recreate him≈øelf withal.
