O renowned Prince and mighty king, wilt thou not tell what thy thir≈øt was of? If you will know after what I thir≈øted, where my griefe lay, and what the paine was which I endured, I let you vnder≈øtand, Qu√≤d ≈øitiuit anima mea ad deum fontem viuum; and the meaning this, O ≈øorrowfull man that I am and comfortle≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing that the thir≈øt which I endure proceedeth not of a corrupted liuer, for mine is ≈øound & whole, nor of burnt choller, for there is no ≈øuch thing in me: my thir≈øt is then not that which the body ≈øuffereth, but that which my ≈øorrowfull ≈øoule endureth. The thir≈øt which I ≈øuffer, and the drine≈ø≈øe which I abide is ≈øo hard to bee extingui≈øhed, that no liuing creature is able to take it from me, nor any

O happy is the ≈øoule which thir≈øteth after nothing, but after our Lord! for looke what the thir≈øt is which the ≈øoule hath, ≈øuch is the water which ≈øhe ≈øeeketh to mittigate it with. O that this is a diuine ≈øentence which the Prophet doth vtter vnto vs in this place! whereby wee are plainly taught, that the thir≈øt of the ≈øoule is farre different from the thir≈øt of the body, and that the thir≈øt of the ≈øpirit is one, and that of the fle≈øh another, that of the iu≈øt man one, and that of the ≈øinner another, and the heauenly thir≈øt one, and the humane another. And with what is the thir≈øt of the ≈øpirit killed, but by ≈øeruing God? And with what is the thir≈øt of the world ea≈øed, but by following the world? And what doth the iu≈øt thir≈øt after, but grace in this world, and glory in the other? And what thir≈øt hath the wicked, but to procure all meanes hee can the cockering of him≈øelfe? The humane thir≈øt is of humane thinges, and the heauenly thir≈øt is of heauenly things; and therevpon it is, that what our intention is which we haue in our hearts, ≈øuch is the thir≈øt which wee ≈øuffer in this world. div.head: CHAP. VIII. God complaineth that we for≈øake him for vile & ba≈øe things: and doth compare vs vnto old pooles.
div.p:
ME dereliquerunt fontem aquae viuae, & foderunt ≈øibi ei≈øternas di≈øsipatas, quae continere aquas non valent. The≈øe words God ≈øpake by the Prophet Ieremy in the ≈øecond chapter, as if hee would ≈øay, My people of I≈ørael haue run into two great incoÃÑueniences; that is, they haue for≈øaken me, who am the fountaine of the liuely water, and haue made for them≈øelues to drinke in, ce≈øternes and pooles which cannot hold water in them. Although the Apo≈øtle doe ≈øay, that our Lord is profound in his iudgements, yet in tho≈øe thinges which touch the profite of his creatures, he is plaine and ea≈øie: for if hee bee well plea≈øed, he doth pre≈øently ≈øhew it, and if he be angry, he doth immediately complaine. When Abraham had ended the ≈øacrifice of his ≈øonne I≈øaac, our Lord did immediately thanke him for it, and when king Dauid had ended his adultery with Ber≈øabee, he complained out of hand: for our Lord is ≈øo farre without di≈øsimulation and malice, that he doth nether faine him≈øelfe to bee content, nor denie him≈øelfe to bee angry. What more would wee haue God to doe for vs, than like a good Lord, bee thankfull for that which wee doe in his ≈øeruice, and like a good friend admoni≈øh vs of that which we ≈øhould doe for him, and like a pittifull Father correct vs when we doe any thing again≈øt him? Our Lord then doth here complaine, not only for that we doe for≈øake and leaue him, but al≈øo for what vile and ba≈øe things we doe it, whereby we ≈øhew how little we doe account of him, and how greatly wee doe iniury him, ≈øeeing that no man doth v≈øe to change his ma≈øter,
vnle≈ø≈øe it be for his further profite. If it were ≈øo, that as we do leaue one man for another, ≈øo wee ≈øhould leaue one God to dwell vvith a better, it were a thing to be borne vvithall, but ≈øeeing that there is but one true God, how is it po≈øsible to meet vvith a better God, or yet any ≈øo good? What other thing is it to for≈øake God for the creature, but to leaue the kernell for the ≈øhell, the fruit for the rinde, the ro≈øe for the thorne, the floure for the bran, and the fountaine for the ≈øtreame? Therefore like an angry Lord, and a man greatly iniuried, God complaineth and ≈øayth, Me dereliquerunt fontem aquae viuae, for there can be no greater madne≈ø≈øe in the world, than to leaue the Creator for the creature, the Lord for the ≈øeruant, the iu≈øt for the ≈øinner, and the righteous for the vniu≈øt, and that vvhich is euerla≈øting for that vvhich is tran≈øitory. Our Lord in this place as it vvere ie≈øting and mocking vs, doth call all our workes ce≈øternes which cannot hold water, that is, that wee are ce≈øternes or pooles vvhich let out all vvaters, becau≈øe vve be not vvell glewed and fa≈øtened. O how our Lord hath ≈øhamed vs in the≈øe words, and emba≈øed vs in ≈øaying by the Prophet Ieremy, that all our vvorkes are nothing but old broken ce≈øternes, and puddles wherein there is nothing commonly but reeds and duckeweed, dirt & mire, ≈øtinking vvaer, and venomous adders. Our Lord doth compare vs vvith great rea≈øon vnto that vvhich hee dooth name, and doth ≈øcorne and mocke vs fitly by it, becau≈øe the ≈øinnes vvhich are in our ≈øoules, are farre vvor≈øer than tho≈øe filthes which are found in ≈øtanding puddels. What is there in an old puddle, that is not in my ≈øoule? What are all my vvorkes but a little mire, vvho≈øe property is to trouble the water, & hold them fa≈øt vvhich enter into it. O how vnhappie we be, ≈øeeing wee ≈øticke ≈øo fa≈øt in worldly things, that wee cannot get out, and ≈øo bemire our ≈øelues in vaine things, that wee can neuer make our ≈øelues cleane, in≈øomuch that there e≈øcapeth no man vvhich is not either defiled with ≈øinne, or wet vvith infamie. Our workes are al≈øo compared vnto duckweed in ≈øtanding puddles, vvho≈øe propertie is, to fill the vvater, and giue it an

O wretched and vnhappy that I am, ≈øeeing I doe no more good in the catholick church thaÃÑ that weed doth in the water, which is ea≈øily ≈øeene, ≈øeeing I offend and hurt others with my euill example, and that which is wor≈øt of all, I po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the roome of a good one. Doe≈øt not thou eat the bread of the little ones, when as if a Moore or a Pagan had receiued ≈øo many fauors as thou ha≈øt at Gods hands, he would haue ≈øerued him more than thou ha≈øt done, and offended him much le≈ø≈øe? Woe be vnto me, woe be vnto me, what doe I ≈øay that I an≈øwered pre≈øently, when ≈øin called at my doore, ≈øeeing that very oft before it doth call at my doore, I goe vp and downe ≈øeeking it from hou≈øe to hou≈øe? When our Lord ≈øayth by the Prophet E≈øaias, Auferte malum cogitationum ve≈øtrarum ab oculis meis, how ≈øhould he not dete≈øt our workes, ≈øeeing he ≈øaith, that all that we doe thinke of doth ≈øtinke? All my workes are ≈øo vnplea≈øant and corrupt, and my conditions ≈øo ≈øtinking, that it is more tollerable to ≈ømell a dead carka≈ø≈øe with my no≈øe, than vnto thee O my God, to ≈ømell this filthy heart of mine. The quality of the frog is to croake night & day, & it is the condition of a naughty man alwaies to complain, becau≈øe it is one of the infelicities which naughty meÃÑ endure in this life, that they complaine of all things, and liue di≈øcontented with theÃÑ≈øelues. div.head: CHAP. IX. How the ≈øonne of God did not refu≈øe to drinke gaule and vineger, although he knew it would kill him.
div.p:
QVis poterit gustare, quod gustatum adfert mortem? Holy Iob ≈øpake the≈øe words in his ≈øixt chapter, As if he would ≈øay, What man is hee which ≈øo much hateth him≈øelfe, or who hath ≈øo corrupt a ta≈øt, or who is ≈øo weary of his life, that he dare drinke or ta≈øt of any liquor which hee knoweth will pre≈øently make him yeeld vp the gho≈øt? The≈øe words are full of matter, and containe deep my≈øteries in them. For as they were prophecied by holy Iob, ≈øo they were fulfilled by the ≈øonne of God, when as on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe hee ta≈øted a cup of ≈øuch bitter poy≈øon, that in ta≈øting of it his life went pre≈øently out of his body. The Philo≈øopher in his ≈øecond booke De generatione ≈øayth, That the life of a rea≈øonable man dooth con≈øi≈øt in the perfection of the radicall or naturall moi≈øture, and in the con≈øeruation of natural heat; and that is the only rea≈øon why nature
doth de≈øire meat and drinke of vs; for by eating and drinking that humor is alwaies pre≈øerued. Wee ≈øee oftentimes men of ninty or a hundred years die, and yet neuer complaine of any griefe, and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe that that naturall moi≈øture was ended in them, and their naturall heat was extingui≈øhed in them, and therefore we may ≈øay of ≈øuch that their life did rather end, thaÃÑ that they died. Now that we mu≈øt eat & drink of nece≈øsity, which of the≈øe two is mo≈øt agreeable vnto nature, and which le≈ø≈øe grieuous? If Aristotle doe not deceiue vs in his booke De ≈øecretis ≈øecretorum, this que≈øtion was debated before Alexander the great, and in his pre≈øence throughly di≈øputed on, becau≈øe that at the table of that mighty prince no man was admitted to ≈øpeake but his captains which ≈øu≈øtained his warres, or Philo≈øophers which gouerned his hou≈øe. PArum e≈øt mihi vt ≈øu≈øcites faeces I≈ørael: dedi te in lucem gentium, vt ≈øis ≈øalus mea v≈øque ad extremuÃÑ terrae, E≈øay 48. div.head: CHAP. XI. How the Synagogue gaue Chri≈øt that to drinke that ≈øhee her ≈øelfe was, that is gaule, and that which ≈øhe had, that is vineger.
div.p:

The ca≈øe was then this, that when Abraham had brought his ≈øonne I≈øaac from among the people, and being gone vp to the hill with his hands bound, the wood ≈øet on a heap, and the fire kindled, and the ≈øword drawn to ≈øacrifice his ≈øonne, he ≈øaid vnto his Father; behold father, here is the wood and the fire made, where is the bea≈øt which ≈øhall bee ≈øacrificed? What meaneth this, O old Abraham, what meaneth this? ≈øpeake of the ≈øacrifice of I≈øaacs ≈øonne, but of the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øt which was to come, our Lord ≈øaid not, that hee had already prouided a ≈øacrifice, but that he would prouide; neither did he ≈øay that he would prouide it for another, but for him≈øelfe; neither that hee would prouide many, but one; neither that he would indifferently prouide for any, but a killed ≈øacrifice laid whole on the altar. Was it not, think you, an Holocau≈øt, & a great Holocau≈øt which Chri≈øt offered, ≈øeeing there was no ≈øpot in it wherby it ≈øhould be ca≈øt away, nor any meÃÑber in his body which was not tormented? To come then vnto our purpo≈øe, it is to be noted, that we haue made all this di≈øcour≈øe to proue that in the my≈øtery of this word Sitio which
end, becau≈øe that the Iewes did but borrow them vntill our Lord ≈øhould prouide them a ≈øacrifice, which by Abraham he promi≈øed vnto all the world. How was it po≈øsible that the ≈øacrifices of time pa≈øt ≈øhould plea≈øe the Lord, or profit the ≈øinner which did offer them, ≈øeeing their altars did ≈øeeme rather butchers ≈øhambles, than temples of Prie≈øts? Rabanus ≈øayth, Abrahams ≈øacrifice was profitable vnto him≈øelfe, and hurtfull vnto his ≈øonne, ≈øeeing he ≈øhould there haue lo≈øt his life; and becau≈øe we may know that this is true, the Lord did ordaine that Abrahams ≈øword ≈øhould onely threaten his ≈øonne I≈øaac, and afterward kil the ≈øon of God. Our Lord ≈øeeing what ≈ømal benefite ≈øhould be gotten by the death of that child, & what griefe it would cau≈øe vnto this old Father, although hee gaue him licen≈øe to draw his ≈øword, yet hee did not con≈øent that it ≈øhould come neere the child; the which our Lord would neuer haue hindered, if the death of that child could haue ben ≈øufficient to redeeme al the world. God the Father was older than Abraham, and loued his ≈øonne better than Abraham did his: yet notwith≈øtanding all this, ≈øeeing that in that only ≈øacrifice did con≈øi≈øt mans ≈øaluation, he con≈øented that they ≈øhould take his life from him. E≈øichius vpon Leuiticus ≈øayth, That that which Abraham did, was only good vnto him≈øelfe alone, becau≈øe hee did accompli≈øh that which was commanded him; but when he ≈øaid that the Lord would prouide a ≈øacrifice vnto him≈øelfe, that was profitable vnto all the world, con≈øidering that by that prophecie wee were warranted and made ≈øure, that we ≈øhould be redeemed by the ≈øonne of God. Origen ≈øayth, That it is much to be noted, how that all the ≈øacrifices of the old law did proceed from two things only, that is, from the bea≈øts which they did kill, and the fruit which they plucked from trees. Of their bea≈øts they did offer the head
and feet vnto the Lord, the caule, the fle≈øh, and the entralls, and of trees incen≈øe, ≈øtorax, fruit, grapes, aloes, mirrhe, oile, and ≈øweet odours. And God was not content only, that euery maÃÑ ≈øhould offer what plea≈øed him≈øelfe, but onely of that which God in the law commaÃÑded, that is, of bea≈øts that they ≈øhould offer the greate≈øt, of fruits the be≈øt, of perfumes the ≈øweete≈øt, of mettales the riche≈øt, of liquors the mo≈øt excellente. If we beleeue the Philo≈øopher in his book De animalibus, The fir≈øt thing that is engendred is the heart, and the la≈øt the gaule: & when a bea≈øt dieth it is contrary; for the fir≈øt thing that corrupteth is the gaule, and the heart the la≈øt thing that dieth. The Commentator ≈øayth, That as the gaule is the la≈øt thing that is ingendred in man ≈øo it is al≈øo the mo≈øt filthie≈øt and ba≈øe≈øt thing that is in him. Of all liquors the wine is the mo≈øt precious, and contrary no liquor wor≈øer than the dregs of ≈øoure corrupted wine. Doe≈øt thou thinke, my brother, that we haue trauelled in vaine in prouing vnto thee, that the gaule is the wor≈øt part of the bea≈øt, and putrified dregs the wor≈øt of liquors? The end why wee haue ≈øpoken all this is, becau≈øe that when the Redeemer of the world was dead with thir≈øt vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, they gaue him the≈øe two thinges to drinke, that is bitter gaule, which is the la≈øt and wor≈øt part of the bea≈øt, and dregs and vineger which is the wor≈øt of all liquors. S. Augu≈øtine vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, The pure≈øt, cleare≈øt, and cleane≈øt of the Synagogue was already ended and gone, and turned into vineger and lees, by rea≈øon wherof they gaue Chri≈øt nothing to drinke but gaule & vineger, giuing vs therby to vnder≈øtand, that they did not giue him only that which they had in the Synagogue, but al≈øo that which them≈øelues were. For what was all the Synagogue but ≈øoure vineger, and bitter gaule? It was not without a high my≈øtery that they offered that which they did to Chri≈øt vpon the cro≈ø≈øe: for as the gaule is the la≈øt and the vilde≈øt thing that is in the bea≈øt, ≈øo the Synagogue was now at an end, and at the vvor≈øt of all her life, in ≈øo much that ≈øhee was become nothing els but a gaule of malice, and al≈øo vineger of couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe. Saint
Ierome ≈øayth, Euen as vineger hath been good wine, becau≈øe it was gathered of the be≈øt of the vine, ≈øo the people of the Iews were ≈øomtimes good, becau≈øe they had good meÃÑ among them; in ≈øo much that there is no other meaning in that they gaue Chri≈øt wine mingled with mire, and ≈øoure vineger to drinke, but that the people were now corrupted, and ≈øcar≈øe one good man left among them. How came this hap among you, O you Iewes, that all the wine of your ve≈ø≈øels is become ≈øoure vineger, and all the hony of your hiues turned into bitter gaule? Then your wine began to turne into vineger, when you would not receiue Chri≈øt for your Redeemer, and then all your hony turned into gaule, when you did defame his doctrine and bereaue him of his life. The Synagogue ≈øtriketh great pity into my heart, to ≈øee that in time pa≈øt they did offer vnto their God ≈øacrifices, Holocau≈øts, and offerings, and afterward gaule and vineger, and dregs, by which cur≈øed and wicked offering, they took away their makers life, & brought their Commonwealth vnto an end.

div.head: CHAP. XII. How that the thir≈øt that Chri≈øt had vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, was not ≈øo much for drinke, as to de≈øire to ≈øuffer more for vs.
div.p:
EXpergefactus la≈ø≈øus adhuc ≈øitit, & anima eius vacua e≈øt, E≈øay, chap. 29. The Prophet E≈øay vttereth the≈øe words, ≈øpeaking in generall of the great trauails and mo≈øt greiuous thir≈øt which the ≈øonne of God ≈øuffered in particular: and it is as if he would ≈øay, The great Me≈øsias waked out of his ≈øleepe, like vnto a man who had e≈øcaped out of a lithargy, or ≈øome drou≈øie di≈øea≈øe, & wheÃÑ he beheld the ≈øtate of his ≈øoule, he found that ≈øhe was empty. For the Prophet to ≈øay that the ≈øonne of God ≈ølept vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and that after he waked and was weary, and found his heart empty, ≈øeemeth a ≈øtrange and a doubtfull thing vnto
pittifull eares. For if it be true that hee ≈øuffered, how was it po≈øsible that he ≈ølept; and if he ≈ølept, how could it be that he ≈øuffered? What is more ≈øtrange vnto torment than ≈øleepe, and what a greater enemy to ≈øleepe than torment? Con≈øidering that the ≈øonne of God hanged vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, his feet bare, his hands torne, his ≈øide pierced, his ≈øinews wre≈øted, and his bones put out of ioint, how could it bee that he ≈øhould ≈øleepe or take any re≈øt at all? He who ≈øhould hang vpon the cro≈ø≈øe as Chri≈øt did, that is, weary, wa≈øted, bloudy, nailed, and one ioint drawn from another, would he not haue greater ability and inclination to complaine, than de≈øire of ≈øleepe? The Prophet vttereth foure things in this prophecie, the fir≈øt, that Chri≈øt did awake out of a ≈øleepe and dreame which he ≈ølept, the ≈øecond, that he awaked aweary, the third, that hee awaked thir≈øty, the fourth, that hee found his heart empty. Of all the≈øe foure things, the one doth make vs mo≈øt of all to maruell: for to ≈øay that Chri≈øt was aweary I beleeue it, to ≈øay that he was a thir≈øt I agree vnto it, and that he wanted all comfort I do al≈øo admit. But to ≈øay that he ≈ølept, there is that which maketh me to wonder, becau≈øe his eternall Father did not ≈øend him thither to ≈øleepe, but to redeem all the world. It is much to bee noted in this place, that the famous Augu≈øtine ≈øayth again≈øt Manichaeus. Saep√®, imo ≈øaepi≈øsim√® in ≈øacris literis circum≈øtantiae ≈øcripturarum declarant Scripturam, as if he would ≈øay, It happeneth oftentimes, that when the Scripture is darke and ob≈øcure, that the circum≈øtances before going and comming after doe declare and explain the ≈øame Scripture, and one Prophet doth declare another, and one text another. This then being ≈øo, it is conuenient for vs to find out in Scripture ≈øome kind of ≈øleepe, and by that we may coniecture and ge≈ø≈øe at the manner of ≈øleeping which the ≈øon of God ≈ølept vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, and al≈øo wee ≈øhall know, when, how, and wherefore Chri≈øt did awake out of his ≈øleepe. Excitatus e≈øt tanquam dormiens dominus, & tanquam potens crapulatus vino, ≈øayth the Prophet Dauid, P≈øalm 77. as if he would ≈øay, Our Lord did awake out of his dreame like a man that is
≈øleeping, and hee ro≈øe out of that dreame like a man full of power, and like vnto one who had drunke wine. It is a verefied truth in our Chri≈øtian faith, that God is a pure ≈øpirit, and a ≈øub≈øtance not compounded but ≈øimple, which hath no fle≈øh which may putrifie, nor bones which may be brokeÃÑ, nor hunger which may cau≈øe him to eat, nor ≈øtomack to di≈øge≈øt with, nor vapours to a≈øcend and prouoke him to ≈øleepe, nor yeares to make him old. If it bee true that there is no time which can make God old, nor meat which can force him to ≈øleepe, is it not al≈øo true, that his ≈øleepe is otherwi≈øe to be vnder≈øtood than ours, and that he awaketh in another manner than we doe? When the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, That ≈øleep is the image of death, what el≈øe doth he mean, but that a man which ≈øleepeth, is nothing el≈øe but an image of a dead man? Mark well the conditions of a dead man, and thou ≈øhalt find the ≈øame in one which ≈øleepeth: for he who is in his bed a≈øleepe, and hee who is in his graue can neither ≈øpeake, nor heare, nor vnder≈øtand tho≈øe which call vpoÃÑ them, nor feele tho≈øe which touch them, nor offend tho≈øe which abu≈øe them, nor complaine on tho≈øe which bla≈øpheme them, nor reuenge on tho≈øe which hurt them. Who will not ≈øay that our Lord dooth not ≈øleepe this kind of ≈øleep, ≈øeeing we ≈øee that in naughty men he doth di≈ø≈øemble their ambition, the bla≈øphemies which they ≈øpeak, the adulteries which they commit, the ince≈øts they go about, and the malice which they thinke? What is ≈øleepe in a man but to haue all his members at re≈øt? And what el≈øe is ≈øleeping in our Lord, but the ≈øu≈øpending of his vengeance and puni≈øhment? The wicked men thinke, that becau≈øe our Lord doth ≈øuffer them to liue in the world, and not puni≈øh theÃÑ, that therefore he is a≈øleep, & that he hath no care ouer the things of this world; which is an errour without all doubt: for they mu≈øt know, if they know it not, that that which wee call in a man ≈øleeping, is called in God di≈ø≈øembling. Vpon tho≈øe words of the Prophet, Dormitauerunt omnes, S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, Our Lord doth winke at the naughtine≈ø≈øe of wicked men, not becau≈øe he hath a de≈øire that they ≈øhould ≈øinne, but becau≈øe he
hopeth that they ≈øhould amend, which if they doe not, the Lord awaketh for their wickednes, and laieth his heauy hand ouer theÃÑ. WheÃÑ is our Lord ≈øeen to awake out of his ≈øleep but wheÃÑ he laieth his hand ouer the naughty maÃÑ, & doth cha≈øti≈øe him for his errour? Euen as wheÃÑ one will giue another a great blow, the higher he doth lift his hand, the greater ≈øtroke hee doth giue him, in the ≈øelf ≈øame ≈øort, the longer time our Lord doth ≈øtay and wait for the wicked, the more rigorou≈øly and with le≈ø≈øer pity he doth puni≈øh him. Whereof, thinke≈øt thou, doth it proceed, that God doth awake to puni≈øh thy ≈øinne, but becau≈øe he doth ≈øee thee ≈øleepe ≈øo long time in ≈øinne? I≈øidorus ≈øaith, Wilt thou ≈øee curious reader, that our Lords ca≈øting him≈øelfe to ≈øleepe, is nothing el≈øe but to di≈ø≈øemble at our faults, and that to awake is nothing el≈øe in him but to begin to puni≈øh thy ≈øinne; thou maie≈øt perceiue it by that, that as the Prophet had ≈øaid, Excitatus e≈øt tanquam dormiens, hee added immediately, Etpercu≈øsit eos in pectora eorum. What other thing doth the Prophet ≈øay vnto vs by the≈øe words, but that at the ≈øelfe ≈øame time, houre, and moment, that the Lord did awake out of his ≈øleepe, he did put his rigorous hand ouer the Princes of the Gentiles. Looke well vnto it, my brother, looke well vnto it, and be not deceiued, and if thou think that our Lord is a≈øleepe, & hath no regard of thy doings, take thou heed for it is the temptation of the diuell, and that none of the lea≈øt with the which he doth deceiue the world: for thou wilt one day thinke that the Lord is carele≈ø≈øe, and hee will ≈øend ≈øome grieuous puni≈øhment vpon thee. And thou art now to vnder≈øtand, that there are ≈øo many in thy hou≈øe which will awake him, as thou ha≈øt faults and ≈øinnes in thy ≈øoule. In the hou≈øe of our Lord, who is the waker of his clemency, but only our amendment, and who is the waker of his iu≈øtice but only our offence? Vpon tho≈øe words of the P≈øalme, Ecce non dormitabit, S. Barnard ≈øayth, As the enemy which dooth impugn I≈ørael, Non aormitabit neque dormiet, ≈øo the Lord who defendeth I≈ørael, Neque dormitabit neque dormiet, and if it ≈øeeme that his clemency is a≈øleepe, when he doth fauour vs, it is becau≈øe
we ≈øhould liue better, and if it ≈øeemeth that hee dooth defer his iu≈øtice, it is becau≈øe we ≈øhould amend. What ≈øhould I≈øay more vnto thee, but look what workes thou doe≈øt, ≈øuch wakers of God thou ha≈øt. If thou be good, thou doe≈øt awake him to doe thee good, if thou bee naught, thou doe≈øt awake him to doe thee hurt: becau≈øe that in the ≈øight of our Lord the fault crieth for puni≈øhment, and goodne≈ø≈øe asketh reward. Ioining then my≈øtery vnto my≈øtery, and Sacrament vnto Sacrament, now that wee haue declared how God ≈ølept in the old Te≈øtament, it is rea≈øon that wee declare al≈øo how his ≈øon did ≈øleepe and awake vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing that there is no le≈ø≈øe to be wondered at in the ≈øleeping of the ≈øonne, thaÃÑ there was to be ≈øpoken of in the ≈øleeping of the Father. For to think that the ≈øonne of God did ≈øleepe vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, as one that is weary and in health is woont to doe were a vanity, and al≈øo an here≈øie, for giuing him as they did gaule to eat, and vineger to drinke, there were more rea≈øon that his ≈øtomacke ≈øhould be ready to ouerturne, rather than his head haue any inclination to ≈øleepe. When E≈øay ≈øayth, Expergefactus la≈øsus, hee ≈øpeaketh nor of materiall ≈øleepe, but of ≈øpirituall, and if hee ≈øay that Chri≈øt did awake, his powers within him without doubt did not awake, becau≈øe they were broken with tormeÃÑts but tho≈øe powers did awake which lie hidden within him. And although the Apo≈øtle doe ≈øay, Qu√≤d ex ip≈øo, & in ip≈øo, & per ip≈øum ≈øunt omnia, to wit, of him, in him, and by him all things are, yet there are ≈øixe principall things aboue the re≈øt in him. The≈øe ≈øixe are, his e≈ø≈øence, his power, his wi≈øedome, his humane fle≈øh, his patience, and his clemency, and of the≈øe ≈øixe excellences and graces, three of them ≈ølept, when the ≈øonne of God ≈øuffered, and the other three alwaies watched. His pure and diuine e≈ø≈øence ≈ølept vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing hee did not ≈øhew him≈øelfe by it to be an ab≈øolute God, for if hee had ≈øhewed him≈øelfe to haue been onely God and not man, he could neuer haue died vpon the cro≈ø≈øe. His high and eternall wi≈øedome ≈ølept vpon the cro≈ø≈øe in his pa≈øsion, ≈øeeing that hee neuer an≈øwered vnto any iniurious word, were it neuer ≈øo
grieuous again≈øt him. E≈øichius ≈øayth, Chri≈øt did ≈øuffer that to be done by him on the cro≈ø≈øe, that a ≈øheepe doth by him≈øelfe in the butchery, for if the ≈øonne of God ≈øhould haue ≈øhowne before Pilate and Herod any ≈øparke of his wi≈ødome, the Iews had neuer been able to haue put him to death. His in≈øpeakable and incomparable power did al≈øo ≈øleep in his pa≈øsion vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, not reuenging at all on his enemies, for if it would haue plea≈øed him to haue v≈øed it, in le≈ø≈øe than a moment, hell would haue ≈øwallowed theÃÑ all aliue. Now that wee haue told what three powers ≈ølept with Chri≈øt on the cro≈ø≈øe, it is al≈øo conuenient for vs to ≈øhew what three they were which watched with him the ≈øame time. His tender fle≈øh did not ≈øleep at the time of his pa≈øsion vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, which was not one moment at ea≈øe, nor an in≈øtant without torment. How was it po≈øsible that Chri≈øt ≈øhould not bee but awake on the cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing that there was no vaine in his holybody which did not bleed, nor no part of his fle≈øh which was not bru≈øed, and beaten blacke and blew? His incomparable patience did watch and not ≈øleepe vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, the which our ble≈ø≈øed Ie≈øus did neuer lo≈øe, ≈øeeing that he neuer ≈øpake iniurious word vnto his enemies, nor neuer ≈øhewed them an angry countenance? Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, All deuout per≈øons ought to follow Chri≈øt in the vertue of ≈øuffering, for be≈øides that the vertue of patience is meritotious before God, ≈øhee is al≈øo an occa≈øion of great quietne≈ø≈øe in mans life. Chri≈øts diuine and louing clemency did al≈øo watch, and not ≈øleep in his pa≈øsion, the vvhich he did ≈øhew vvhen hee pardoned his enemies, and praied for his malefactors. O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, O in≈øpeakable pitie, O my good Ie≈øus, for if vve ≈øhould grant that all the other vertues ≈øhould haue ≈ølept on the cro≈ø≈øe, yet thy clemency vvould neuer haue giuen ouer vvatching, for it is farre ea≈øier for the ≈øonne to lo≈øe his light, than for thee not to forgiue and pardon. Plutarch in his Apothegms ≈øayth, That the Emperor Titus on a time gaue a great ≈øigh and ≈øaid, Diem ami≈øimus amici, as if he vvould ≈øay, It is not rea≈øon that this day ≈øhould be
reckoned among the daies of my life, ≈øeeing that I haue done no good, nor v≈øed any liberality in it. This ≈øpeech was ≈øpread throughout all the world, & much commended of the Philo≈øophers, and worthy of ≈øo high a Prince. That which the Emperour Titus ≈øpake of his franckne≈ø≈øe, Chri≈øt might farre better haue ≈øpoken of his infinite clemency, for if the Emperour did let no day pa≈ø≈øe in the which he did not ≈øome good, neither did Chri≈øt let ≈ølip any houre or moment wherein hee did not pardon ≈øome offence. And becau≈øe the Prophet ≈øaith that the ≈øonne of God did not onely ≈øleepe, but al≈øo that he did awake, let vs now ≈øee how the≈øe three powers did awake in Chri≈øt, and when, and for what cau≈øe. His incomparable & diuine e≈ø≈øence did ri≈øe and awake when he ≈øpake that terrible word at the time that his ≈øoule was drawne out of him, and therevpon as it were in a traunce and a maze, the great Centurion ≈øaid of Chri≈øt, That this was the ≈øon of the true God. Chri≈øt did al≈øo awake his high wi≈ødome vpon the cro≈ø≈øe wheÃÑ he ≈øpake tho≈øe ≈øeuen wordes in the la≈øt houre of his death, in the which there is contained more profound, and deepe ≈øcience and knowledge, than is in all humane Philo≈øophy or knowledge. Chri≈øt did al≈øo awake his incomparable power, when hee made the ≈øunne to be darkened, the earth to tremble and quake, the graues to open, and the dead to ri≈øe again. Who dooth doubt, but that the ≈øonne of God doth ≈øhew in the≈øe wonderfull meruels, the highne≈ø≈øe of his power, the depth of his e≈ø≈øence, and the greatne≈ø≈øe of his wi≈øedome, and the valour of his per≈øon? O my good Ie≈øus, O the light of my ≈øoule! how vnlike thou art vnto the children of vanity and lightne≈ø≈øe, who doe ≈øhew their e≈ø≈øence, and yet are nothing; ≈øhew their power, and yet can doe nothing; ≈øhew their wi≈øedome, and yet doe know nothing.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Where he goeth forward with the figure mentioned before.
div.p:
ADhue ≈øitit expergifactus, ≈øayth E≈øay in the place before named, as if hee would ≈øay, When the redeemer of the world did awake vpoÃÑ the cro≈ø≈øe, hee did awake very drie and thir≈øty, which was ≈øo great a thir≈øt, that it continueth vntill this day: it is mo≈øt certaine that when a man doth ≈øuffer many griefes at one time, that he ≈øpeaketh of that which grieueth him mo≈øt, and pointeth with his hand where his greate≈øt paine lieth. The angui≈øhes which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered in his mind were innumerable, and the griefes which hee endured in his body were intollerable, and that which is mo≈øt of all to be meruelled at is, that his torments being ≈øo many and ≈øo ≈øharpe as they were, yet he complained of none of them on the cro≈ø≈øe, but only of the thir≈øt which he endured. Saint Barnard ≈øayth, O good Ie≈øus, O redeemer of my ≈øoule, hauing ≈øo many things to complaine on, doe≈øt thou onely complaine of thir≈øt? Thy ≈øhoulders are naked and whipped, thy hands broken, thy head bleeding, thy fle≈øh bru≈øed, and yet doe≈øt thou complaine on nothing, but of the thir≈øt which troubleth thee, and of want of water? Doe≈øt thou complain that thou art thir≈øty, and not that thou art bloudy? ha≈øt thou not greater want of thy bloud, than of water? Seeing the bloud which runneth from thy head, doth bath thy face, & wet thy tongue, why doe≈øt thou aske againe for water? For a quarter of an houre that thou ha≈øt to liue, doe≈øt thou complaine that thou wante≈øt water? O that the thir≈øt which I ≈øuffer ≈øaith Chri≈øt, is not to drinke wine or water, but to ≈øee your amendment, and carry you with mee to my glory, for
≈øeeing that I am now taking my iourney to heauen. I haue a great thir≈øt to take my elect with mee. The thir≈øt which I haue, & the drine≈ø≈øe which I endure, is not ≈øo much to drink any liquor, as to redeem you and ≈øaue you, and reconcile you with my Father, and therefore if thou haue no pitty on mee, yet at the lea≈øt take ≈øome on thy ≈øelfe. O that I had rather, that thou hadde≈øt ≈øome pitty on thy ≈øelfe, than on mee, becau≈øe it is a greater griefe to ≈øee thee lo≈øt, than to ≈øee my ≈øelf ≈øuffer. S. Augustine ≈øayth, Thou didde≈øt adde vnto all thy angui≈øhes, this word Sitio, ≈øhewing thereby ≈øuch a great thir≈øt, and repre≈øenting outwardly the exceeding loue that thou didde≈øt beare me inwardly, and vn≈øpeakable charity, which cau≈øed thee to make but ≈ømall account of all that thou didde≈øt ≈øuffer in re≈øpect of that de≈øire which thou hadde≈øt to ≈øuffer. And he ≈øayth further, O my good Ie≈øus, I know well that thy thir≈øt is not for thy ≈øelfe, but for me, and this thy angui≈øh is for no other cau≈øe, but for the ≈øaluation of my ≈øoule: and when thou ≈øaie≈øt that thou ha≈øt a de≈øire to drinke, that is as much to ≈øay, as to ≈øuffer more for mee, in ≈øo much that the care that thou ha≈øt ouer me is ≈øo great, that by meanes thereof thou doe≈øt wholly forget thy ≈øelfe. What meaneth this O redeemer of my ≈øoule, what meaneth this? Thy ioints being loo≈øed one from another, thy eies broken, thy mother hauing her farewell, and hauing complained on thy Father, doe≈øt thou ≈øay anew I am a thir≈øt? What pitty may be compared vnto this, or what goodne≈ø≈øe equall vnto this Oredeemer of my ≈øoule. Wee ≈øee by this word Sitio, that death was ≈øufficient to take all thy dolors and griefes from thee, and yet that it was not inough to cut off the loue which thou hadde≈øt to redeeme vs. Who is able to ≈øay truly, that thy loue did end vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, con≈øidering that for the loue of thy elect thou didde≈øt yet thir≈øt after more griefes and angui≈øhes? All this Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øpake. Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øayth, When the eternall word ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, I am a thir≈øt, I doe not beleeue that hee did ≈øo much aske for water to drinke, as hee did aske for time of his Father to ≈øuffer more griefe and
torment. For as the candle when it is going out doth ca≈øt the greate≈øt light, ≈øo Chri≈øt the more his death drew neere, the more his loue and charity doth kindle towards vs. Remigius vpon Saint Matthew ≈øayth, Although the diuine prouidence did reduce all the trauailes of his life vnto three yeares, and that al≈øo hee brought all the torments of the cro≈ø≈øe vnto three houres, yet it is not to bee beleeued, that Chri≈øt his infinite charity was contented with this ≈øhort time, and therefore I thinke for my owne part, that the thir≈øt which hee ≈øhewed vpon the tree vvas not ≈øo much to drinke of any water of the riuer, as to declare and make manife≈øt his loue vnto the world. Fulgentius in a Sermon ≈øayth, The ≈øonne of God did thinke, that ≈øeeing his Father had not giuen him charity by waight, ≈øo hee ≈øhould not giue him torment by mea≈øure, by rea≈øon whereof hee cried aloud on the cro≈ø≈øe Sitio, to let vs vnder≈øtand by this thir≈øt, that ≈øeeing the gifts which hee receiued had no end, that the torments likewi≈øe which he receiued ≈øhould not be limitted.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. Of the crueltie and ingratitude that the Iewes v≈øed in giuing Chri≈øt gaule and vineger, and how he ≈øati≈øfied for euery ≈øinne in particular.
div.p:
DEderunt in e≈øcam meam fel, & in ≈øiti mea potauerunt me aceto, ≈øayth Chri≈øt by the Prophet, as if hee would ≈øay, Being vpon the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe full of torments, loaden vvith griefes, compa≈ø≈øed with enemies. I had ≈øcar≈øely ≈øpoken the word Sitio, but they gaue mee gaule to eat, and vineger to drinke. There is much matter to bee ≈øpoken vpon this, that is, what drinke they gaue him when they gaue it him, where they gaue it him, why they gaue it
him, in what they gaue it him, and how quickly they gaue it him. The drinke which they gaue him was gaule and vineger, the place where was vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, the time was when hee was yeelding vp the gho≈øt, the cau≈øe why was to helpe him to die, they gaue it him in a reed and a ≈øpunge, and that pre≈øently when he had thir≈øt; ≈øo that all the≈øe circum≈øtances doe aggrauate the fault in them. Wee find that the diuell made two banquets in this world, the one in the terre≈øtriall paradi≈øe vnto our Father, where he gaue him the fruit of the tree to eat; the other to Chri≈øt in the de≈øert, where he inuited him to ≈øtones of the field, the which might haue ben ground, ≈øifted and ≈øo mingled, that they might haue been eaten. The Iewes gaue Chri≈øt wor≈øer meat, than the diuell offered him in the de≈øart, for they gaue him gaule to eat, and vineger to drinke, which are bitter and ≈øoure, horrible in ta≈øt, and mortal in eating. For as the Philo≈øopher ≈øayth, The true≈øt loue is the loue of children, the ≈ømell of ≈ømels is of bread, the ≈øauor of ≈øauors is of ≈øalt, the ≈øweete≈øt of all ≈øweetes is of hony, and the bittere≈øt of all bitters is of gaule. For what is there vnder heauen ≈øweeter than hony, or more bitter than gaule? For what ≈øtomacke is there in the world ≈øo ≈øtrong, who after a cup of gaule and vineger would not either bur≈øt or die? Rabanus vpon S. Luke ≈øayth, If the Iewes had remembred that his Father gaue them fre≈øh water in the de≈øart to drinke of, and bread from heauen to eat of, and that his ≈øonne likewi≈øe gaue fiue thou≈øand of them fi≈øh their fill, and bread vntill they left off it, they would not haue giuen him gaule to eat and vineger to drinke. Dama≈øcenus ≈øayth, That it is proper to naughty men to be very ≈øparing in matters of vertue, and in matters of vice very laui≈øh, which doth ea≈øily appear in Chri≈øt, for he asking for nothing but drink, they gaue him al≈øo ≈øomewhat to eat. An≈øelmus ≈øayth, That the abundance of malice, and the want of con≈øcience made the Iewes put that bitter gaule to Chri≈øts mouth, which other men do loath to touch. The Iewes did al≈øo ≈øhew the depth of their wicked, naughtine≈ø≈øe in giuing Chri≈øt that horrible drinke, being as hee was
≈øo neere death vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe that all men are wont in that extremity, bee they friends or enemies, to helpe him who is in torment to die well, and no man in that houre dare to trouble or vexe him. Origen ≈øayth, That it is a cu≈øtome among ≈øauage and barbarous men, that ≈øuch as were enemies in their life time, doe reconcile them≈øelues, and pardon one another in death, Becau≈øe as Plato ≈øayth, Death alone doth end all trauaile and all anger. This generall rule failed only in the Iewes, as men which were more barbarous and inhumane than all other, who at the very time that Chri≈øt was yeelding vp his ≈øpirit, did ≈øpet vpon him, bla≈øphemed him with their tongues, hated him with their hearts, & tormented him with gaule and vineger. King Dauid and king Saul were mortal enemies, but when the Phili≈øtims had ≈ølain Saul in the hils of Gelboe, they ≈øaw Dauid weepe bitterly for him, and cau≈øed him to bee buried with great care and diligence. All writers doe affirme, that there were not greater enemies in all Greece than Demo≈øthenes the Philo≈øopher, and E≈øchines the Orator, but when E≈øchines vnder≈øtood in Rhodes that Demo≈øthenes his enemy was dead in Athens, he did not only weepe many teares for him, but did al≈øo be≈øtow ≈øumptuous funerals vpon him. The great hatred and warres which were betwixt Iulius Cae≈øar and Pempeius the great, are knowne vnto all the world, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe when pittifull Ca≈øar had Pompeius head in his hands, hee ≈øpake many pittifull words in his fauour, and ≈øhed many teares ouer his head. Cyrillus vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, That there was neuer read of the like hatred as the Iews bare Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing that although they ≈øaw his breath going out of his body, yet they gaue him gaule to eat, and vineger to drinke, becau≈øe that as they had tormented his outward members with torments, they might al≈øo poy≈øon his inward bowels with griefe and paine. S. Cyprian ≈øayth, It is not credible that the wicked Iews had mens hearts in them, but the hearts of ≈øome madde dogges, ≈øeeing that the more the ≈øonne of God did draw neere vnto death, the more they did waxe cruell, becau≈øe that the end why
they gaue him gaule and vineger, was becau≈øe hee ≈øhould die ≈øooner and al≈øo raging. If as it did plea≈øe Chri≈øt onely to ta≈øt of that drinke, it had been his will to haue drunke it all, con≈øidering how there was no bloud left in his vaines, and al≈øo his weakene≈ø≈øe at that time, it is no doubt but it would haue ≈øhortened his life, and put him to a more painfull death. O that this doctor ≈øaid very well, that they had not mens hearts in them, for otherwi≈øe, con≈øidering the extremity they ≈øaw him in, they could not haue done le≈ø≈øe than haue giuen him ≈øome wine to drinke, or water to refre≈øh him, or v≈øed ≈øome words of comfort. O pittifull ca≈øe, and vn≈øpeakable cruelty, ≈øeeing that at the houre of thy death, thou hadde≈øt no friend to encourage thee, no drop of water to refre≈øh thee, but onely a little gaule for thy breakefa≈øt, and a little vineger to drie thy mouth with. Let not mee v≈øe then any delicate meates, and let all ≈øuperfluous diet bee farre from mee, for ≈øeeing my God and Lord doth neither eat nor drinke but gaule and vineger, from euening to euening, how dare I fare daintely at ≈øet meales? How dare I looke for death, ≈øeeking a thou≈øand dainties euery houre, and change a thou≈øand meats euery day? Seeing that thou, O my good Ie≈øus, hadde≈øt thy mouth poy≈øoned with gaule, and wet with vineger? O ≈øacred mouth, O holy tongue, who is ≈øo wicked, as to dare bath that mouth with gaule and vineger, hauing preached with the ≈øame ≈øo many Sermons, giuen ≈øo many holy le≈ø≈øons, taught ≈øo many people, and done ≈øo many miracles? You ≈øhould put gaule and vineger, O yee cur≈øed Iewes, vpon this my mouth, which is neuer opened but to deceiue, and vpon my tongue which can doe nothing but lie, for as for that of your Creator and our Redeemer, what ≈øinue was there that hee did not tell you of, and what vertue is there that hee did not teach you? Saint Barnard ≈øayth, O what great difference there is betwixt mouth and mouth, tongue and tongue? For mans tongue ≈øaid vnto Pilat, crucifige eum, & Chri≈øts tongue ≈øaid vnto his Father, Ne≈øciunt quid faciunt. In ≈øo much, that the peoples whole drift was to induce Pilate to kill him, and Chri≈øts whole intention was, to
per≈øuade his Father to forgiue them. Vbertinus ≈øayth, Should not Chri≈øt haue had better rea≈øon to haue giuen the people gaule and vineger, ≈øeeing they accu≈øed him openly, thaÃÑ they to Chri≈øt, con≈øidering that with teares hee did excu≈øe them? Quid vltra debui vineae meae quod non feci? Said Chri≈øt to the Prophet E≈øaya ‚Ä¢ , as if hee would ≈øay, O my cho≈øen vine, O my deere Synagogue, what didde≈øt thou aske of mee that I did not giue thee, or what could I doe for thee that I haue not done? The≈øe wordes are deepely to bee con≈øidered of, ≈øeeing that by them our Lord dooth call the Synagogue to a reckoning, like vnto one friend which chideth with another, who with intention not to breake off their friend≈øhip, will trie out where the fault lieth. And to the ≈øame purpo≈øe God ≈øpake by the Prophet Ieremy, when hee ≈øaid, Iudicium contraham tecum, as if hee would ≈øay, I will O I≈øraell, that thou and I, and I and thou, ≈øit down to iudge, and take an arbitrator betwixt vs, to the end, that both parts being hard, he may iudge what ≈ømall rea≈øon thou ha≈øt to offend me, & what great cau≈øe I haue to complaine on thee. O infinit goodne≈ø≈øe, O vn≈øpeakable clemency of thee my great God, what creature can iu≈øtly ≈øay, that thou ha≈øt condemned him without iu≈øtice, ≈øeeing thou doe≈øt fir≈øt ≈øit downe to verifie thy iu≈øtice? O vnto how many may God iu≈øtly ≈øay at this day, what can I doe more for thee than I haue done, and wherein can≈øt thou offend me more than thou ha≈øt offended me? O good Ie≈øus, O light and glory of my ≈øoule, what ≈øhoulde≈øt thou doe more for me than create me, or what coulde≈øt thou doe more for me than redeeme mee? Thy goodne≈ø≈øe and my wickednes do ≈øtriue before thy face, and thy grace and my offence, thy bountie and my vngratefulne≈ø≈øe, thy mercy and mine ob≈øtinacy, thy pardon and my ≈øinne: in ≈øo much, that I neuer cea≈øe to ≈øinne, and thou neuer to di≈ø≈øemble it. But to ≈øpeake more particularly, it is to be coÃÑ≈øidered, that our God was not coÃÑteÃÑted to redeem all of vs in general, but he did al≈øo ≈øatisfie for our ≈øins in particular, laying vpon him≈øelf a particular pain which ≈øhould an≈øwere vnto our particular offence. Chri≈øt ≈øatisfied for the ≈øinne of pride when hee tooke mans fle≈øh vpon him, vnto
which humility there can no vertue of any Saint be compared, becau≈øe he made him≈øelfe of God a man, of eternall temporall, of one that was immortall mortal. Barnard ≈øayth, That of all tho≈øe which were proud, Lucifer was the greate≈øt, of all gluttons Adam, of all Traitors Iudas, of all patient men Iob, and of all humble men Chri≈øt exceeded all. Chri≈øt ≈øatisfied for fornication by his circumci≈øion, and therevpon it is, that becau≈øe the ≈øinne of lechery is that ≈øinne, into which men do ea≈øilie≈øt and mo≈øt oftene≈øt fall into, our Lords plea≈øure was to redeeme it with his precious bloud. Chri≈øt ≈øatisfied for the ≈øinne of enuy with his incomparable pouerty, which hee ≈øo ≈øtreitly kept, that hee had neither hou≈øe to dwell in, nor a penny to ≈øpend, nor wealth to liue by. S. Ierome ≈øayth, That the end of Chri≈øts pouerty was, to withdraw from him≈øelfe things nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe we ≈øhould leaue off things ≈øuperfluous: for if a Chri≈øtian haue any thing in his hou≈øe which is ≈øuperfluous, hee dooth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe it all as ≈øtolne from the poore. Chri≈øt ≈øatisfied for gluttony by his continuall fa≈øting all his life time, and oftentimes ≈øuffering great hunger; which is ea≈øily ≈øeene, becau≈øe that after his fa≈øt in the de≈øart he was greatly a hungred: and al≈øo when he and his di≈øciples did eat eares of corne in the field. S. Barnard ≈øayth, Chri≈øt had ≈øuch a great feruour to preach by day, and did contemplate ≈øo continually by night, that although hee had meat, yet he did ≈øcar≈øe remember to eat it. Chri≈øt ≈øatisfied for the ≈øinne of anger with his continuall patience, which patience of his was ≈øo perfect that hee neuer knew how to reuenge an iniury, nor neuer v≈øe towards any man an iniurious word. In patientia ve≈øtra po≈ø≈øedebilis animaruÃÑ vectrarum, ≈øaid Chri≈øt to his di≈øciples, Luke 25. As if hee would ≈øay, The merit and reward of patience is ≈øo great that it maketh him vvho hath it, lord ouer his owne ≈øoule. Many po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe their eares by not hearing of backbiting, and other po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe their eies, not ≈øeeing of vaine things, and others po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe their hands by keeping them from ≈øtealing, & others their tongues by keeping them from bla≈øphemy, but of all the≈øe which I haue ≈øpoken off, doth Chri≈øt ≈øay that any
of them doth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe his ≈øoule, but only hee who hath patience? What doth it auaile vs to be lords of our feet, hands, and ears, if the diuell do po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe our ≈øoules? What is it to be lord and mai≈øter ouer a mans own ≈øoule, but wholy to ≈øubdue his owne ≈øen≈øuality? Ambro≈øe vpon S. Luke ≈øayth, He onely hath his will in ≈øubiection, who in trauaile and vexation hath great patience. Chri≈øt doth ≈øay very well, that you ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe your ≈øoules in your patience. Seeing that patience is the vertue which dooth confirme friends, reconcile enemies, cut off pa≈øsions, and maketh our he arts mild and gentle. Loe then thou ≈øee≈øt it proued, how the ≈øon of God was not content to redeeme all the world in generall, but that hee did in particular as it were ≈øatisfie for euery ≈øinne, disburdening euery man of a particular fault, and ca≈øting vpon him≈øelfe a generall paine.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Here there is brought a figure of Dauid, and declared to the purpo≈øe.
div.p:
OSi quis mihi daret potum aqua de ci≈øterna, quae e≈øt iuxta portum Bethleem. 2. Reg. 23. king Dauid being in the field of the giants, and fighting with the Phili≈øtims in ≈øummer time, and wearied with the heat of the ≈øunne, and wanting water, gaue a great ≈øigh, and vttered the≈øe wordes: O who would giue me now a cup of water of the ce≈øtern which is neere vnto the gate of Bethleem, where I was wont to recreate my ≈øelfe when I was a young man, and take my fill in drinking of the water. Dauids ≈øigh being heard, and his great de≈øire of drinking perceiued, three young men which were his ≈øeruants, determined to arme them≈øelues, and goe to Bethelem for water, maugre the enemies, with a re≈øolution to
bring ≈øome, or die in the place. And as they had ≈øworne ≈øo they did accompli≈øh it, and going through the enemies camp ≈øtriking and killing, the end was, that they ≈øhed more bloud in going, than they brought water in comming againe. In the letter of this figure, there are two things to be noted, that is, that good king Dauid did not ≈øigh, nor de≈øire ≈øauerous wine to make him drunk with, but for a pot of water to refre≈øh him≈øelf with. Whereof we may take an example, that we may better ouercome our inui≈øible enemies with ab≈øtinence than with abundance and plenty. Yet ≈øo it was, that notwith≈øtanding the great thir≈øt which Dauid had, hee would not drinke one drop of that water, ≈øaying that God forbid that hee ≈øhould drinke of that water which was gotten with the deaths of ≈øo many men, and was bought with ≈øo much bloud. Euery man may take an example to him≈øelfe by this, that no man ≈øhould carry any thing to his hou≈øe gotten with an euill con≈øcience, or by the preiudice of another, for we ≈øee nothing more common than that men for greedine≈ø≈øe of another mans doe not onely lo≈øe that which was their own by inheritance, but that al≈øo which of other mens they had gotten. Leauing the letter, and comming to the ≈øpirituall meaning, it doth well appeare, that Chri≈øt is the ≈øonne of Dauid, and that Dauid is the father of Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing the one was thir≈øty in the field, and the other on the Mount of Caluary, the one ≈øighting, & the other ≈øufiering, the one compa≈ø≈øed with enemies, and the other hanging betweene theeues, the one to drinke a cup of cold water, and the other to redeeme mankind. How farre greater the thir≈øt was which the ≈øonne of God had, than that which Dauid had, it is ea≈øily ≈øeene in that, that Dauid did manife≈øt his thir≈øt with words onely, and the ≈øonne of God with words and teares: wherevpon wee may inferre, that his true thir≈øt was not ≈øo much to drinke water of the ce≈øternes, as to ≈øaue ≈øinfull ≈øoules. O that the thir≈øt which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered was of a farre more higher degree than Dauids thir≈øt, for Dauid did but ≈øigh for water, but the ≈øonne of God did not ≈øigh but did ≈øuffer death to redeeme our ≈øoules, and Dauid did
quench his thir≈øt with the preiudice of other mens bloud, but the ≈øonne of God did not kil his, but with his own bloud. Chri≈øt had not ≈øo good friends on the Mount of Caluary, as Dauid had in his campe, becau≈øe Dauids ≈øeruants brought him water to refre≈øh him withall, and Chri≈øts enemies gaue him gaule & vineger to ta≈øt of. Super vulnera mea addiderunt dolorem, ≈øaid the Prophet Dauid ≈øpeaking in the per≈øon of Chri≈øt, as if hee would ≈øay, The greate≈øt trauaile and griefe which I feele now is, that be≈øides the words & dolours which the Iewes gaue me in crucifieng me, ≈øinners haue now added another dolour vnto my former dolours, which doth grieue me more than all the others did. The dolours which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered in his pa≈øsion, his wounds and thornes cau≈øed them, but the dolour which he now complaineth of, our ≈øinnes doe cau≈øe. And he hath great rea≈øon to complaine more of this than of the others, becau≈øe the wounds which they gaue him and the nailes and thornes which tormented him dured but one day, but the griefe which our offences doe cau≈øe in him doe euery houre offend him. Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, If there were no fault in vs, there ≈øhould be no wounds in Chri≈øt, and therevpon it ri≈øeth, that wee wound him more in his entrails with our offences, than the Iewes did with their nailes. But ≈øome man may ≈øay that Chri≈øt dooth not ≈øo much complaine by the Prophet of his wounds, as of a grief and dolour which they added aboue all dolours, and therefore it is conuenient that we declare what this dolor is, and how farre it reacheth. For the better vnder≈øtanding of this point we mu≈øt note, that ouer and aboue all the ≈øinnes which we commit we doe adde a new one vnto them, which is as it were a counterpei≈øe again≈øt euery ≈øinne, the which cau≈øeth the ≈øinne to bee more grieuous and le≈ø≈øer hope of amendment in vs. What is this new ≈øinne but the plea≈øure which we take to haue ≈øinned, & the de≈øire which we haue to ≈øinne againe? And becau≈øe wee may not ≈øeeme to ≈øpeake at randome, wee will giue of euery one an example. If the prowd man would be content to bee prowd only, it would be but halfe a fault, but ala≈ø≈øe hee ≈øayth
that he is nothing prowd at all, if wee regard his great de≈øart, by rea≈øon whereof he de≈øireth to be of greater power and authority and ability to be≈øtow more than hee doth. What greater wickedne≈ø≈øe, or what greater naughtine≈ø≈øe can there be in the world than not to be content to be naught, but to de≈øire to be more naught. O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, O vn≈øpeakable clemeÃÑcy, who had euer ≈øo great a thir≈øt to enioy our ≈øinnes, as thou my good Ie≈øus hadde≈øt to ≈øuffer torment? Quod facis fac citius, ≈øaid Chri≈øt to Iudas in the night of the la≈øt ≈øupper, Ioh. 13, as if he would ≈øay, Seeing that thou wa≈øt ≈øo ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe as to ≈øell me ye≈øterday, and art determined to deliuer mee this night vnto my enemies, make an end of thy ≈øupper and ri≈øe from thence, and doe that which thou wilt doe quickly, becau≈øe that the end of thy perdition ≈øhall bee the beginning of my redemption. O ≈øorrowfull ≈øpeech, O heauy word which Chri≈øt ≈øpake vnto the vnhappy di≈øciple, becau≈øe that thereby he is permitted to doe what he would, as though he ≈øhould giue him licence vtterly to de≈øtroy him≈øelfe, and that there ≈øhould bee no hope of his amendment. What other meaning had tho≈øe wordes which our holy mai≈øter ≈øpake vnto the reprobate di≈øciple, that is, Do that which thou ha≈øt to doe with ≈øpeed; but to declare by tho≈øe words, that he had for≈øaken him, and that hee will defend him no more with his holy hand? and yet in this lamentable ≈øpeech,
Chri≈øt v≈øed great clemency toward Iudas, for when hee ≈øaid, Doe ≈øpeedily that which thou wilt do; it was to ≈øay, deliuer me quickly, and die thou quickly: for how much the older thou doe≈øt grow in yeares, by ≈øo much the more thou wilt grow in offences. God of his mercy keep vs from this licence or permi≈øsion, for it is a great ≈øigne that this man is already fore≈øeene to be damned, whome our Lord doth permit to beginne to be naught pre≈øently. Our Lord doth neuer giue this licence to a Chri≈øtian religious ≈øoule, but when the fle≈øh doth moue him, or ≈øen≈øuality di≈øquiet him, he taketh away the occa≈øions of falling, and giues him new de≈øires to ≈øtrengthen him with. Woe be vnto him vnto whome our Lord ≈øayth as he did to Iudas, Quod facis fac cito, that is, that hee may doe that which ≈øen≈øuality doth lead him vnto, & accompli≈øh that which the diuell per≈øuadeth, for the greate≈øt malediction that God doth put vpon any man, is, to ≈øuffer to put that in execution which ≈øen≈øuality requireth. Remigius ≈øayth, That the diuell is ≈øo great a friend vnto his friends, and hath ≈øo great care of plea≈øing theÃÑ, that they haue no ≈øooner thought of a ≈øinne, but he doth pre≈øently lay open the way to commit it. Dama≈øcen ≈øayth al≈øo, That when a man de≈øireth to be wor≈øer than he is, the diuell is by and by ≈øo bu≈øie, that he doth agree that which did di≈øagree, and ioine that vvhich was farre a≈øunder, openeth that which vvas ≈øhut, lighteneth that which vvas darke, maketh that ea≈øie vvhich vvas mo≈øt hard, and giueth that, that vvas not to be hoped for. This being true, as true it is, vvhat vvill not a naughty man doe, vvhat vvill hee not venter on, yea and vvhat vvill hee not attaine vnto, hauing ≈øo good a tutor and helpe as the diuell? If a good man vvould doe any good vvorke, hee findeth a thou≈øand ≈øtumbling blockes to hinder him: and contrariwi≈øe, if a naughty man vvill commit any naughty fact, hee ≈øhall find as many helpes for the performance of it, and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe our Lord doth ≈øeeme to forget his, becau≈øe they ≈øhould merit the more, but the diuell doth alwaies fauour his, becau≈øe he vvill incite them to ≈øinne. Wee haue ≈øpoken all this, by rea≈øon of
the gaule and vineger vvhich the Iewes gaue Chri≈øt, for it is a vvonder to thinke vvith vvhat ≈øpeed they ≈øought it out, & vvhat diligence they v≈øed in giuing him it, for ≈øurely if the Scripture did not a≈ø≈øure vs of it, it would ≈øeeme but a dreame to ≈øay that they ≈øhould haue all thinges ≈øo readily & at hand as they gaue him. Is it not a thing much to be vvondered at, that the Iewes being out of the towne, and in open field, as ≈øoone as he had ≈øaid Sitio, that they ≈øhould pre≈øently haue at that place, ≈øoure vineger, bitter mirrhe, poi≈øoned gaule, vn≈øauory i≈øope, and a ≈øpunge to drinke it in, and a reed to reach it him? But vvhen Chri≈øt ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, I am a thir≈øt, they did not ≈øtay ≈øixe houres to ≈øeek the≈øe things, but they did reach them him pre≈øently all at once, kept, and hidden ready for him: for if his ≈øoule vvould not haue for≈øaken him vvith the torment of the nailes, ≈øhee vvould haue for≈øaken him by the force of that drinke.

The ≈øame leaue that Chri≈øt gaue Iudas, it ≈øeemeth that he gaue it al≈øo vnto the Iewes, that is, that they ≈øhould doe by him vvhat they vvould, and how they vvould, and as ≈øpeedily as they vvould, vvhich liberty they v≈øed vvith the aduantage, ≈øeeing that in ≈øhort ≈øpace they vvatched him with their eies, dogged him vvith their feet, laid hold on him with their hands, bla≈øphemed him vvith their tongues, hated him vvith their hearts, and ended his life vvith their drinkes. The naughty Iewes vvent to the Mount of Caluary, and there vvent al≈øo old Io≈øeph and Nichodemus, but their intentions were farre different the one from the other, the holy men carried pin≈øers vvith them to pull out the nailes, ladders to take him downe from the cro≈ø≈øe, ointments to annoint him vvith, a ≈øheet to wind him in, and a ≈øhrowd to bury him in. ≈øtacions on good Friday, and meditate on the Mount of Caluary, they carried vnder their clokes in one pot the vineger, in another bladder the gaule, in a boxe the mirrhe, & in a cloth the I≈øope, in one hand the ≈øpunge, & in another the reed. We mu≈øt aboue al things take heed that we doe not offer vnto our Lord any liquor which is not pure, cleare, and cleane, or mixed, for here vpon earth men refu≈øe mixed liquors, becau≈øe they doe corrupt the ≈øtomacke. Cibus ≈øimplex est vtili≈øsimus homini, compo≈øitus auteÃÑpernicio≈øus, ≈øayth Pliny, as if hee would ≈øay, The body is be≈øt maintained with vncompound meats, becau≈øe that compound meats are dangerous for the body. The like condition is to bee ob≈øerued in the ≈øoule, the which doth dete≈øt di≈ø≈øembled manners, & abhorre doubling in conditions, for being as ≈øhe is a mo≈øt ≈øimple iu≈øtice, ≈øhe cannot endure to bee furred with malice. Hilarius ≈øayth, I will ≈øay that he doth offer vnto Chri≈øt, his vnder≈øtanding mingled with vineger, who occupieth his thought more on another thaÃÑ God: I wil ≈øay that he doth offer his memory mixed with mirrhe, who troubleth his memory with nothing but how he may lead his life without di≈øquietne≈ø≈øe: I will ≈øay that hee doth offer his will mingled with gaule, who forgetteth his creature and ≈øerueth worldly things: hee dooth offer his heart vnto Chri≈øt mingled with bitter I≈øope, who at the ≈øame time will liue at ea≈øe, and yet ≈øerue our Lord: & he doth offer vnto Chri≈øt a good worke put vpon a reed, who dooth it for no other end but for vaineglory: and he offereth Chri≈øt his life ≈øoken with a ≈øpunge, who doth all that he doth of hypocri≈øie. Finally, we ≈øay that tho≈øe do offer vnto Chri≈øt drinks of bitterne≈ø≈øe, who in beliefe are Chri≈øtians, and in workes Pagans.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. That the church of Chri≈øt hath great abundance of ≈øpirituall waters, which are his grace and the gifts of the holygho≈øt: and of the fire which Chri≈øt came to put in the world, which is the loue of God; and of the profit that this loue of God doth in the ≈øoule.
div.p:
HAurietis aquas in gaudio, de fontibus ≈øaluatoris, E≈øay 12. chapter. The Prophet E≈øay ≈øpake the≈øe words, ≈øpeaking vnto good Chri≈øtians of the Catholicke church, and of the great good that Chri≈øt will doe in her: and they are as if hee would ≈øay, When the Me≈øsias promi≈øed in the law, ≈øhall come into the world, all ≈øuch as were drie and thir≈øty ≈øhall receiue great ioy, with great abundance of waters to refre≈øh and recreate their per≈øons. The Prophet dooth promi≈øe foure things in this place, that is, that they ≈øhal not draw water but waters, not out of one well or fountaine, but fountaines, not by force but willingly, not out of euery well, but of the fountaine of our Sauiour. Agar wanted the fountaine, how much more fountains? the children of I≈ørael found water, but ≈øoure: the Patriarke Iac ‚Ä¢ l found ≈øweet water, but he had great ≈øtrife in getting it. They brought king Dauid water, but it was of a ce≈øterne, in≈øomuch that the Synagogue was ≈øo poore, that ≈øhee could not get a cup of cleane water. The catholicke church may hold her ≈øelfe very happie and rich, ≈øeeing that God hath promi≈øed her abundance of waters cleare and cleane, flowing from the fountaine of her Sauior and Redeemer. It is much to bee noted, and al≈øo to bee meruelled at, to ≈øee that our Redeemer Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øaid vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, Siti ‚Ä¢ , and yet ≈øaith that hee hath waters and fountains to refre≈øh and quench the thir≈øt of all the world. What
meaneth this O good Ie≈øus, what meaneth this? Ha≈øt thou not one drop of water for thy ≈øelfe to drinke of, and yet doe≈øt thou inuite all the world to drinke of thy fountaines? It doth wel appeare O my good Ie≈øus, that thou ha≈øt all that good for me, and keepe≈øt all trauailes vnto thy ≈øelfe, ≈øeeing that of thy ≈øweet water thou doe≈øt inuite all men to drinke, but the gaule and vineger thou doe≈øt giue no man to ta≈øt. What are the fountaines that thou woulde≈øt haue vs drinke of, but thy holy wounds with the which we were redeemed? O ≈øacred fountains, O holy wounds, which are ≈øo delectable to behold, and ≈øo ≈øweet to ta≈øt, that the Angels are de≈øirous to drinke of them, and all creatures are willing to bath them≈øelues in theÃÑ. They are fountains which alwaies flow, they are waters which alwaies run, & what do they flow but bloud & water, & whither do they flow but to the Catholick church? Holy Ie≈øus did giue vs much more than E≈øay did promi≈øe vs, for E≈øay did promi≈øe vs nothing but waters, but he gaue vs afterwards waters of his bowels, & blond of his vains. O good Ie≈øus, O holy fountaine, from whence but from the fountaine of thy bowels did the water flow to wa≈øh our ≈øpots, and from whence but from thy precious vaines did the bloud runne to redeeme our offences? It is gathered in ≈øcripture, that the waters of Ra≈øim were mo≈øt ≈øwift, the waters of Iorda. troubled, the waters of Bethleem were pooles and ≈øtanding, the waters of Marath were bitter, the waters of Siloe were ≈øoure: The waters of thy wounds O my Redeemer, are not of the≈øe qualities, for they are ≈øafe to ≈øaile in, cleane to behold, ≈øweet to ta≈øt, and profitable to keepe. What meaneth hee to ≈øay that you ≈øhall draw waters In gaudio, but that as we were redeemed with his great loue and will, ≈øo we ≈øhould ≈øerue him with great ioy and mirth? Hee doth draw waters of the fountaines of Chri≈øt with ioy and mi ‚Ä¢ th, who doth ≈øerue him with good will; and hee doth draw bloud out of Chri≈øts wounds with ≈øorrow and griefe, who doth ≈øerue him with an evill will, who≈øe ≈øeruice is neither acceptable to God, nor profitable vnto him which doth it: for as our Lord
doth giue nothing which hee doth giue, but with ioy and mirth, ≈øo he will not that any man ≈øerue him, but with pure affection and entire good will. With what great loue the ≈øonne of God hath redeemed vs, and with what a liuely will he wil be ≈øerued, wee may gather by his owne doctrine, and ≈øee it in his owne louing words. Ignem veni mittere in terram & quid v ‚Ä¢ lo ni≈øi vt accendatur, Luke. 12. This high word no man could ≈øay, but hee only who was the word of the eternall Father, and the meaning is this, If thou wilt know why I came downe from heauen, vnder≈øtand thou that it was for no other cau≈øe, but to burne and ≈øet all the world on fire, and therfore I bring this light with me, becau≈øe it may burne day & night, and that thou maie≈øt blow it that it goe not out. Chri≈øt ≈øpeaketh to the ≈øame purpo≈øe in another place, when hee ≈øayth, Non venipacem mittere ≈øed gladium, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, Let no man thinke that I came into the world, to giue it peace and quietne≈ø≈øe, but to put a gallowes and a≈øword in it: the gallowes to doe iu≈øtice on the wicked, and the ≈øword to martirize the good. The≈øe words are worthy of the noting, and al≈øo to be feared of all mortall men, for hauing created the world, what meaneth he to ≈øay that hee came into the world but to put it all to fire and bloud? What man is there this day in the world ≈øo noble in birth, or ≈øo rich in wealth, but if he proclaime publickely, that hee will burne both man and woman, but they wil pre≈øently lay hands on him, & bind him hand & foot, or coÃÑdemn him for want of di≈øcretioÃÑ? What can be more ≈øtraÃÑger, or what inueÃÑtioÃÑ may be like vnto that, for our Lord to tel vs. & al≈øo warne vs, that he hath brought nothing el≈øe with him but a firebrand to burne, and a ≈øharpe ≈øword to cut our throats? Vpon tho≈øe wordes, Non veni mittere pacem ≈øed gladium, S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, If wee will well vnder≈øtand, that which Chri≈øt ≈øayth in this place, we ≈øhould not only not bee ≈øcandalized at it, but al≈øo highly thanke him for it: for to ≈øay the truth, with that fire he doth ≈øeare our dead fle≈øh, and with that knife he doth let out our corrupt bloud. Beda vpon the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth. What is the ≈øire which Chri≈øt brought from heauen into the world but his exceeding great loue?
The quality of this high fire is, to heat and not burne, to giue light and not hurt, to burne and not con≈øume, to putrifie and not wa≈øt, to warme and not to grieue. O good Ie≈øus, and light of my ≈øoule, what ≈øen≈øuality can ouercome mee, or what tentation can throw mee downe, if at the coales of thy fire I warme my ≈øelfe, and giue my ≈øelfe light with the flame of thy loue? What can hee doe, what is in him, or what regard is there of him in this life, who doth not warme him≈øelfe at the fire of thy loue? What made S. Andrew goe cheerfully and ≈øinging to be crucified, but the fire of the loue which burned in him? What made S. Agnes goe more ioifully to martyrdome than a new married ≈øpou≈øe to bed, but the fire of thy diuine loue which ≈øhined in her? What made tho≈øe ≈øtones ≈øeeme vnto S. Steuen hony comoes, but that holy loue which burned in his ≈øoule? Iguis erat & calefaciebat ≈øe. O vvhat a difference there is betwixt the fire which Chri≈øt brought downe from heauen, and the fire which Cayphas hath in his pallace. For S. Peter warming him≈øelfe at it, of a Chri≈øtian became a Pagan, & S. Paule warming him≈øelf at Chri≈øts fire, of a Pagan became a Chri≈øtian. God ≈øend me of Chri≈øts fire, ≈øeeing it doth make me know him, and God keep Cayphas fire from me, ≈øeeing it doth make me denie him. For if S. Peter had not warmed him≈øelfe at Cayphas fire, the wench would not haue importuned him, nor he denied Chri≈øt, not haue lo≈øt the confe≈øsion of the catholicke faith. The Euangeli≈øt ≈øayth that, Petrus calefaciebat ≈øe, that is, That Peter did warm him≈øelfe at the fire, but he ≈øayth not that the fire was able to take his cold from him, and therefore the fire which the world hath for her worldlings is ≈øuch, that they are but few vvhich warme them≈øelues at it, but many which waxe cold by it. S. Peter being from the fire ≈øaid vnto Chri≈øt, Tecum paraui iam in mortem me, and by the fire he ≈øaid, Non noui heminem, in ≈øo much that being at ≈øupper with Chri≈øt he did burne, and being at Cayphas fire he was a cold. The ≈øonne of God then ≈øeeing that there was not below in the world heat which could recreate, nor fire which could burne, nor light vvhich could
comfort, nor flame which could giue light, nor any thing which might content, he brought from heauen with him the fire of his holy loue, with the which wee ≈øhould all be enflamed, all lightened, and all contented. The ≈øon of God would neuer haue ≈øaid, I came to put fire on earth, if hee had ≈øeene that there had been the true fire of his loue vpon the earth, but ≈øeeing that the fire of the world doth burn and not heat, hurt and giue no light, wa≈øt and not burne, grieue and not cheere, burn and not purifie, ≈ømoke and not ≈øhine, he remembred to bring a fire which ≈øhould heat all the world. Woe be vnto him which will not warme him≈øelfe at this fire, and woe be to him who will not receiue light at the flames of his loue, becau≈øe that the only perfection of our ≈øaluation dooth con≈øi≈øt in offering our ≈øelues to God, and in louing him with all our heart. It is much to be noted, that Chri≈øt brought at one time fire to burn, & a ≈øword to cut meÃÑs throats, ≈øeeing he ≈øaith, Ignem veni mittere in terram, and al≈øo, Non veni pacem mittere ≈øed gladium, to let vs vnder≈øtand, that hee brought fire with him, with the which his elect ≈øhould ≈øerue him with loue, & a ≈øword of the which the imperfect ≈øhould haue feare. Hee burneth with liuely flames who ≈øerueth God with loue: and his throat is cut who ≈øerueth God with feare, and not vvith loue. Whereupon it is, that in the arke of Noe there were many little roomes, and in the hou≈øe of God many dwelling places, ≈øo al≈øo in the Catholicke church there are diuers maners of ≈øeruing of God, he doth ≈øerue God much better who ≈øerueth him with loue, than he who followeth him for feare: but in fine ≈øo as we doe not offend our Lord, be it with loue, or be it with feare, let vs alwaies ≈øerue him. He is happy who ≈øuffereth his throat to be cut with the knife of feare, but he is very happy who goeth to warme him≈øelfe at the fire of his loue: for the feare may be ≈øo great, that he may erre in that which he taketh in hand, but he who loueth him much cannot erre in that which he doth. According vnto Ouid, he cannot erre who loueth a good thing, nor there can bee no errour where there is perfect loue. Cyrillus ≈øayth, If the Synagogue did

This is the ≈øixt word which the Redeemer of the world ≈øpake at the houre of his death on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, and it is as if he would ≈øay, As hee ended to take and ta≈øt of the gaule and vineger which they had giuen him in the ≈øpunge, and offered him vpon a reed, he ≈øaid Con≈øummatumest, that is. Being a rule of the Philo≈øopher, Quod omnia quae fiunt fiunt propter finem. If Chri≈øt had not ≈øpoken the≈øe

Septuaginta hebdomedae abbreuiatae ≈øunt ≈øuper populum tuum & ≈øuper vrbem ≈øanctam tuam vt con≈øummatur preuaricatio, &c, The Angell Gabriell ≈øpake the≈øe words to the Prophet Daniel, chap. 9. as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, Seuenty weekes hence, which ≈øhall bee accompli≈øhed foure hundred and ≈øeuen and twenty yeares hence, the holy of all holies ≈øhall be annointed, iu≈øtice ≈øhall bee perfect, noughtine≈ø≈øe ≈øhall bee blotted out, and ≈øinne ended. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth. Who was able to ≈øay that ≈øinne is at an end, but only hee who died to end ≈øinne? It is here to bee noted what is ≈øaid, who ≈øpeaketh it, where hee ≈øpeaketh it, and in what meeting he ≈øpake it, and for what my≈øtery hee ≈øpake it. In the fir≈øt word which was. Father forgiue theÃÑ, what intere≈øt had the church in it, ≈øeeing that Chri≈øt ≈øpake it onely for the pardon of the

In the third which was, Behold thy mother; what part hath the church therein, ≈øeeing hee ≈øpake it onely vnto the di≈øciple which was there pre≈øent, and to his mother which wept by him? O profound my≈øtery, O vn≈øpeakable ≈øecret, and neuer heard of before, in Con≈øummatum est, ≈øeeing that it is nothing el≈øe to ≈øay Con≈øummatum e≈øt, but to giue notice vnto all the vvorld, that the church is novv begun, and the Synagogue ca≈øt dovvne, the Scripture fulfilled, & his life ended. His precious bloud is ended, the vvhich is ≈øo dravvne out, that there remained no one drop in his vaines, for hee came vvith a determination into the vvorld, fully to accompli≈øh all the loue vvhich hee bare vs, and to ≈øhed for vs all the bloud vvhich hee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. When Chri≈øt went to Ieru≈øalem to ≈øuffer, he ≈øaid vnto his di≈øciples. div.head: CHAP. II. Against di≈øordered eaters and drinkers, and how Chri≈øt was a greater martir than any other, and there is declared a prophe≈øie of E≈øayas.
div.p:
QVando hora vo≈øcendi fuerit, veni huc & intinge buccellam tuam in aceto. Ruth. 2. chapter, Honourable old Booz ≈øpake the≈øe wordes vnto the honourable and vertuous woman Ruth, when ≈øhe went with her workmen to gather the eares of corne for to maintaine her ≈øelfe and her mother in law, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, When the houre of dinner is come, thou ≈øhalt come where my people lay the table, where thou mai≈øt eat of that that there is, with a peece of bread wet in vineger. This labourer Booz, and this woman Ruth were great grandfathers to king Dauid, becau≈øe they begat Obed, and Obed begat Ie≈ø≈øe, & Ie≈ø≈øe begat Dauid, in ≈øo much that although they were ≈øimple country people, yet they de≈øerued to bee counted in Chri≈øts line, and be great grandfathers vnto King Dauid. If we looke curiou≈øly vnto this letter of the text Booz toucheth foure things in it, that he doth inuite Ruth, that he doth inuite her at dinner time, and that to bread alone, and to wet it in vineger. This is another kind of banquet than that which the Emperour Vitellius made to certaine Emba≈ø≈øadors of Per≈øia, of which Plutarch ≈øayth,
That if they had bound them≈øelues to giue them another dinner like vnto their ≈øupper, hee doubteth whether all the trea≈øure of Rome would haue ≈øufficed to haue done it. This is another banquet than that of Marcus Antonius and Cleopatra, wherein he and ≈øhee did ≈øpend ≈øo many precious ≈øtones beaten into pouder, and ≈øuch a great ≈øumme of riches, that in the opinion of writers, another A≈øia might haue ben bought with it. This was another kind of banquet than that which king A≈ø≈øuerus made to the nobles of his kingdome, in the which for the ≈øpace of an hundred and four≈øcore daies, there was neither ≈øtint in eating, nor mea≈øure in drinking. By the≈øe examples it is manife≈øt that prophane men doe inuite like vnto prophane men, and vertuous & good men like vnto vertuous men. Such a one ≈øeemeth to bee this good man Booz, who going in the field, and reaping in ≈øummer time, doth not entreat any to breakfa≈øt but to dinner, and hath nothing to eat but a ≈ølice of bread dipped in vineger. And this good labourer Booz the better to ≈øhew his temperancy, and his great ab≈øtinency, did not ≈øay vnto Ruth that ≈øhe ≈øhould wet all the bread in the vineger, but a ≈ølice only, the which being hard, he bid her rather wet it to make it ≈øoft, than that ≈øhee ≈øhould haue any great dainty of it. The holy Scripture reciteth this ≈øtory for the prai≈øe of tho≈øe which are pa≈øt, and confu≈øion of tho≈øe which are pre≈øent, I meane of tho≈øe which the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh of, who≈øe God is their belly, who rather follow Epicure in eating, than Chri≈øt in liuing. Of all the vices which mans nature is ≈øubiect vnto, there is none that groweth ≈øo fa≈øt as gluttony, becau≈øe that in times pa≈øt all men did keepe ≈øuch a meane in eating, and ≈øobriety in drinking, that there was ouermuch meat, and ≈øear≈øity of eaters, but ala≈ø≈øe now a daies there are ≈øtore of eaters, and want of meats. Vidi mon≈øtrum a natura, hominem bis ≈øaturum in die, ≈øaid Plato when hee returned from Scicilie vnto A≈øia, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, The thing which maketh me mo≈øt of all to wonder at in Scicilia, is that I ≈øaw a man a mon≈øter in nature, becau≈øe hee filled his belly twi≈øe euery day in eating. O if Plato ≈øhould come in this our

Omnia fecit
deus in numero pondere, & men≈øura, ≈øayth the wi≈øe man, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, Our Lord is ≈øo certaine in all that he doth, and ≈øo wary in all that hee taketh in hand, that bee they neuer ≈øo many he numbreth theÃÑ all, be they neuer ≈øo great hee weigheth them, and be they neuer ≈øo broad he mea≈øureth them, ≈øo that in the hou≈øe of God there is number, weight, and mea≈øure. Touching the ≈øecond, the humanity of the word wanteth weight, & he cannot be weighed, for all the Saints being put in one balance, and the ≈øonne of God in another, it would bee that, that a drop of water is in re≈øpect of all the water which is in the world. Su≈øcepit de manu domini duplicia, ≈øeeing it was giueÃÑ vnto him alone to be the end of the vnhappy Synagogue, and the beginning of the catholicke church, and to be him who doth inflict puni≈øhment vpon the bad, and giueth glory vnto the good. Behold then how Chri≈øts humanity is a perfect image & a high re≈øemblance, ≈øuch as is not to be found neither in heauen nor vpon earth, becau≈øe it is made to the liuely likene≈ø≈øe of God, and becau≈øe it is alwaies like his mould and type which is the Word.
