And becau≈øe wee may the better ≈øee what conformity there is betwixt the humanity and the diuinity, we wil ≈øpeak one word vpon euery word of that which S. Iohn did put in the beginning of his holy Go≈øpell, ≈øpeaking of the eternall Word. In the beginning was the Word, ≈øayth S. Iohn, ≈øpeaking of the eternal generatioÃÑ of the ≈øon of God. Wherein he giueth vs to vnder≈øtand, that that eternall word hath his being by the fir≈øt internall emanation of the Father, ≈øeeing that hee proceedeth of him by the way of vnder≈øtanding, which is the fir≈øt emanation, and before the will, ≈øeeing it is pre≈øuppo≈øed. That which we ≈øay of the diuinity, we may al≈øo ≈øay of the humanity, ≈øeeing that it was in the beginning
of God, by an Hypo≈øtaticall vnion in the word, and by an excellency of perfection aboue all that which God created. And the word was with God, ≈øaith al≈øo S. Iohn, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, Becau≈øe thou maie≈øt ≈øee that the per≈øon of the Father is not the per≈øon of the ≈øonne, nor the per≈øon of the ≈øonne the per≈øon of the Father, if I haue ≈øaid, that In the beginning was the word, I ≈øay now that neere vnto God was the ≈øame word, in ≈øo much that that which is neere vnto mee is without all doubt di≈øtingui≈øhed from me. The humanity is ≈øo neere vnto the diuinity, that it is one per≈øon with it, and thereupon it is, that as in the Father and in the ≈øonne there is but one e≈ø≈øence although they be two per≈øons, ≈øo in the word of God, and in the humanity of Chri≈øt, although there bee two natures, there is but one per≈øon; and this diuine, and not humane. S. Iohn ≈øaith further, And God was the Word, which may al≈øo be ≈øaid of the humanity well vnder≈øtood, as of the diuinity, by the high communication of diuine and humane qualities which are in Chri≈øt, becau≈øe there are many things in Chri≈øt by grace, which are in God by nature. Vpon tho≈øe words. In quo habitat omnis plenitudo diuinitatis, S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, The diuinity of the word doth dwell ≈øo perfectly in the humanity of Chri≈øt, that becau≈øe that is ≈øo neerely vnited and deified which is contained, it taketh the name of that which containeth it: and hee ≈øayth further, Quod factum e≈øt in ip≈ø ‚Ä¢ vita erat. The which hee ≈øpeaketh, becau≈øe that being (as he is God) the fountaine of all life, and that of his onely will dooth proceed all life, it is certaine that all that ≈øhould be in him ≈øhould be life. S. Augu≈øtine vpon S. Iohn ≈øayth, As all things in God ≈øhall be called life, becau≈øe they are accompanied and ioined in him, ≈øo in his holy humanity, all things are life, becau≈øe there are vnited in him all the goodne≈ø≈øe of glory and grace. As all that which is made in the word is life, & al that which is out of it is death, ≈øo all that which is wrought in Chri≈øt for his honour and glory is life, and all that which is not done in him and by him is all death. S. Iohn goeth forward and ≈øayth, And the life was the light of men, which he ≈øpeaketh for the
light of rea≈øon, which hee did imprint in the ≈øoules, which were blind by ≈øinne, the which blindne≈ø≈øe was remedied with the light of the humanity of Chri≈øt, the which although it do not ≈øhine like vnto the mo≈øt ≈øimple diuine light, yet it was ≈øufficient to lighten all humane nature: and hee addeth further, That the light doth ≈øhine in darkene≈ø≈øe, Et tenebrae eum non comprehenderunt, which words may be no le≈ø≈øe verified of the humanity of Chri≈øt than of the diuinity of the word. Hilarius vpon tho≈øe words ≈øayth, In re≈øpect of the diuine clearne≈ø≈øe all other creatures may bee called darkene≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe it is impo≈øsible that the diuine ≈øhould not alwaies ≈øhine, but the humane hath euery houre need of light. God doth ≈øhine in the darkene≈ø≈øe of our ≈øinnes, ≈øeeing that none but hee can forgiue them: and in this point it is no other thing to ≈øay, Tenebrae eum non comprehenderunt, but that his mo≈øt great mercy cannot be made empty. S. Barnard in a Sermon ≈øayth, God is mighty in forgiuing ≈øinnes, but he is mo≈øt mighty in forgiuing tho≈øe which are often committed, wherein is ≈øhewed his infinite mercy, ≈øeeing that he is not comprehended by them, nor limited in pardoning them, but hee doth pardon them when he will, how he will, and vnto whom he will. In that that hee is man, Chri≈øt hath al≈øo darkene≈ø≈øe where he may ≈øhine, that is to wit, all pure creatures be they neuer ≈øo holy and cho≈øen, ≈øeeing that of them≈øelues they haue no light at all, if they doe not receiue it of the ≈øonne of God. S. Ierome ≈øayth, The perfection and light of Chri≈øt is ≈øo great, that being compared vnto that which other Saints haue, it ≈øeemeth that it maketh them ≈øomewhat vnperfect, which is to bee vnder≈øtood, not becau≈øe there is any want in them, but becau≈øe there is a great abundance of excellency. Irenaus in a Sermon ≈øayth, Although God tooke from the ≈øpirit of Moy≈øes to giue vnto tho≈øe elders which ≈øhould be iudges with him, yet notwith≈øtanding Moy≈øes continued wi≈øer than they: ≈øo it is in Chri≈øt, from whom how much grace ≈øo euer the holy men doe take, or haue taken, yet they did neuer draw his grace drie, nor at any time compared them≈øelues with him. We haue v≈øed all
this long di≈øcour≈øe to prooue how well the Apo≈øtle ≈øaid of Chri≈øt, Quod CoÃÑ≈øummatus factus e≈øt, ≈øeeing that by the≈øe words it doth appeare, that he had all perfections in him, and by his Con≈øummatus e≈øt, which he ≈øpake vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, that all our wickedne≈ø≈øe is now fini≈øhed and at an end.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Herein is entreated of the greatne≈ø≈øe and wealth of Salomons temple, and how that in the ≈øacred and holy temple of Chri≈øts humanity, the holygho≈øt hath be≈øtowed greater workman≈øhip, riches, and ≈øpirituall gifts, then were in the temple which Salomon did build.
div.p:
EDificauit Salomon domum domini, & con≈øummauit eam. 3. Reg. chap. 6. that is, King Salomon builded a hou≈øe for our Lord, & hee made ≈øuch ≈øpeed in the building of it, that he neuer cea≈ø≈øed vntill he had fini≈øhed it. Origen vpon this place ≈øayth, The loue which God beareth mankind is ≈øo great, that it plea≈øed him to make him≈øelfe a neighbor and an inhabitant of this world, and therfore he would haue Salomon build an hou≈øe here vpon earth, where he might with ea≈øe communicate with euery per≈øon. And becau≈øe that this materiall temple was a figure of the true temple which was Chri≈øt, and becau≈øe the Scripture ≈øayth of the one, Quod con≈øummauit eam, and Chri≈øt al≈øo ≈øayth of his Con≈øummatum e≈øt, we will fir≈øt tell you how magnificent Salomon was in building of his, and then wee will declare vnto you how liberall the holy Gho≈øt was in framing that of Chri≈øt. The ca≈øe thn ‚Ä¢ e≈øtandeth thus, that in the yeare foure hundred and foure≈øcore after that the Iewes went our of Aegypt, and in the fourth yeare after that Salomon inherited the kingdome, in the ≈øecond month of that yeare, which was in Aprill, the building of the Temple began, and was
fini≈øhed in all perfection in the ≈øeuenth yeare. There were alwaies bu≈øied in the working of that temple a hundred fiftie and three thou≈øand and ≈øixe hundred workmen, and all this in time of peace, for otherwi≈øe in time of warre, it might haue been that ≈øome ≈øhould haue builded, and others defended. Of this great number of workmen, foure≈øcore thou≈øand brought ≈øtones out of the mountaines, and ≈øeuen ‚Ä¢ y thou≈øand carried burdens on their ≈øhoulders, and the three thou≈øand and ≈øixe hundred were as it were ouer≈øeers and commanders: The va≈ø≈øales of the king of Tyrus are not compreheÃÑded vnder this number, who did cut wood on the Mount Lybanus, and yet they were many in number, as it may appeare in that Salomon did ≈øend them at one time twenty thou≈øand load of corne, and twenty thou≈øand of barley, and twenty thou≈øand quintales of oile, and forty thou≈øand mea≈øures of wine. Neither are there included in this number the Marriners which brought timber, nor the engrauers which engraued images, nor the gold≈ømithes which wrought in ≈øiluer, which were a great number, ≈øeeing that the metall which they wrought was much. The Scripture maketh no mention of the ≈øiluer that was ≈øpent there, but he ≈øayth only that there was ≈øuch abundance of it in Salomone hou≈øe, as there are ≈øtones on the earth. What ≈øhall wee ≈øay of the gold that was ≈øpent there, which would ≈øeeme incredible to all the world? Before that king Dauid died, he left three thou≈øand mea≈øures of gold for the building of the Temple, which hee offered of his owne, and not of that which he had taken in warre. All the nobles of the Realme did offer al≈øo for the building of that holy edifice fiue thou≈øand mea≈øures of gold, be≈øides others mettals of lattin, copper, and tinne, whereof there is no waight laid downe, becau≈øe the quantity of it exceedeth number. What riches was ≈øpent there may bee ea≈øily gathered in that, that the Temple was all couered with gold from the top vnto the bottome, & that not of plain gold like a painted table, but curiou≈øly cut & kerned. In this prowd building, this word gilding is ≈øildome v≈øed, but this word clad with gold, and enterlaced
with gold, and couered with gold is oft ≈øpoken, and therefore that which Salomon did of pure gold, is more theÃÑ now adaies is wont to bee gilded. The Glo≈ø≈øe ≈øayth, That the floore of the greate≈øt place, which they called Sancta, and the floore of the le≈ø≈øer, which they called Sancta ≈øanctorum, were both paued with fine gold, and all this for the reuerence of the arke, whereby ≈øo much the more euery thing was more precious, by how much the neerer it was vnto it. For the ≈øeruice of this Temple there were appointed twenty and foure thou≈øand Prie≈øts, of the great tribe of Leui, who≈øe charge was to panch the bea≈øts, offer ≈øacrifice, light the lampes, and kindle the fire. For to keepe the gates of the Temple, there were appointed foure thou≈øand porters, and for to ≈øing the P≈øalmes which Dauid made, and tho≈øe which Salomon made, there were cho≈øen other foure thou≈øand, who≈øe office was al≈øo to play on in≈øtruments of mu≈øicke. If the building which Salomon made was prowd and ≈øtately, ≈øo was al≈øo the fir≈øt ≈øacrifice which he offered, for he killed and offered vnto our Lord on one day twenty and two thou≈øand beefes, and a hundred and twenty thou≈øand ≈øheepe. Now that wee haue ≈øpoken of the pompe, glory, and riches of that famous temple, wee will tell you in what all this great trea≈øure did end, and thereby it may be perceiued how vaine and brittle all worldly glory is, and e≈øpecially that which is founded vpon riches. It is a thing much to be wondred at, and worthely to be noted, that wheÃÑ the Sancta was not rich, and when the great citie of Ieru≈øalem was poore, with their pouerty they did ouercome all their enemies, and afterward with their wealth they were ouercome by them. Dauid was poorer than Salomon, and Saul was poorer than Dauid, and yet for all their pouerty they had more victories ouer their enemies then Salomon and Roboam his ≈øonne in their times, who≈øe riches & trea≈øures did exceed the trea≈øures of their predece≈ø≈øors. Men thinke that the remedy again≈øt mi≈øery & pouerty, doth con≈øi≈øt in getting much wealth and riches, and in hauing abundance of all things; the which thing to thinke is a great vanity, and a dangerous thing
to get, for we ≈øee many, who thinking to bring wealth and riches to their hou≈øe, bring death, war, and di≈ø≈øention to it: and becau≈øe we may not ≈øeeke far for examples, let vs looke vpon the Iewes with their trea≈øures, and if wee weigh the matter well, we ≈øhall find for a truth that mi≈øery & pouerty is not remedied with riches, and that the captain of mi≈øery is peace, and the companion of riches is mi≈øery. No longer after the death of Salomon but fiue yeares, Se≈øach king of Aegypt did ≈øend to Ieru≈øalem ≈øeuenty thou≈øand hor≈øemen, and twi≈øe as many footmen, and a thou≈øand two hundred Wagons for cariages, and took Ieru≈øalem and robbed the Temple, and ≈øpoiled king Roboams pallace: in≈øomuch that the Temple was not ≈øo long a ≈øacking as it was a building. The king of Babilon did ≈øend his army to Iudea, who v≈øed the matter ≈øo well, that hee tooke the city, and robbed the Temple, and led the king of Iudea pri≈øoner to Babilonia, and no man was able to re≈øi≈øt him or hurt him. After this great mi≈øchiefe came the king of the Chaldeans, who killed the yong men, tooke the women captiue, ≈øet fire on their towres, burnt the ≈øanctuary, & tooke the people pri≈øoners, and robbed the trea≈øure. The warres which the Aegyptians, Chaldeans, and Babilonians had with the Hebrews, were not becau≈øe they did hold them for their enemies, but only to rob their trea≈øures: n≈øomuch that again≈øt the poore I≈øraelites made greater warres their owne riches, than all other barbarous nations. Let the litterall conclu≈øion be, that wee may ≈øay truly of the Temple of Salomon, Quod Con≈øummatum e≈øt, ≈øeeing that the Temple is at an end, Salomon which made it, the people where it was made, the riches with the which it was made, and the ≈øacrifices for the which it was made. Of all this we may gather, that God dooth not giue vs riches, becau≈øe we ≈øhould loue them, but becau≈øe wee ≈øhould benefite our ≈øelues by them, & ≈øerue him with them: but ala≈ø≈øe that which God doth giue vs to ≈øerue him withal, we doe turne to our owne plea≈øures and delights. Dominus in templo ≈øancto ≈øuo, dominus in caelo ≈øedes eius, ≈øayth the P≈øal. 10. as if he would ≈øay, The places where our Lord doth mo≈øt of
all abide are in the heauens vvhere he hath his ≈øeat, and in the holy Temple where he hath his dwelling place. Becau≈øe we ≈øhould not thinke that the Temple vvhich he here ≈øpeaketh of is the Temple of Salomon in Ieru≈øalem, or of Dian. in Antiochia, or of Pantheus in Rome. God ≈øaid not that hee dwelled in euery Temple, but he added holy, and al≈øo his For in the Temple where God mu≈øt dwell there mu≈øt be no ≈øinne, nor any el≈øe with him. The Temple which Salomon made vvas very rich, and although it vvas a Temple, it followeth not that it vvas holy, for if it had been, and tho≈øe al≈øo which made it, they would not haue killed within it the great Prophet Zachary hard by the altar, nor they would not haue placed the Idoll As ‚Ä¢ aroth in it vpon the altar, nor they vvould not haue con≈øented that Pompeius ≈øhould haue made a ≈øtable for his hor≈øes hard by the altar which vvas dedicated vnto diuine ≈øacrifices. Neither was that Temple holy in re≈øpect of the Prie≈øts and mini≈øters which were in it, for if it had beene holy they would not haue had birds at the gate to ≈øell, nor bankes for V≈øurers, nor Chri≈øt would not haue rebuked them, nor they put Chri≈øt to death. Neither was that Temple holy in re≈øpect of the ≈øacrifices, ≈øeeing that they were not ≈øufficient to take away ≈øinnes: and if there was any profit in them, it was not by rea≈øon of the ≈øacrifice which was there offered, but in re≈øpect of the merits of tho≈øe which did offer them. Neither vvill vve ≈øay that Salomons Temple vvas holy by rea≈øon of the matter whereof it was made, becau≈øe that true and ≈øincere holine≈ø≈øe is not in gold, ≈øiluer, timber, & ≈øtone, whereof it was made, but in the Chri≈øtian and glorious Temple which is there a≈ø≈øembled and gathered together. It followeth then of that which is ≈øpoken, that God doth not abide euery where, & where euery man lu≈øteth, but where our Lord wil make his dwelling place mu≈øt be a Temple, and that a holy Temple, and his owne Temple, or els hee will dwell vvith none. Where or vvho is the true Temple vvhere God dwelleth, but the mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity of the ≈øon of God?
Wee ≈øhall call his deified body a Temple, and a holy Temple, and his owne Temple: becau≈øe of him and of no other, God ≈øaid at the riuer of Iordan, This is my welbeloued ≈øon. This holy Temple was builded not by the hands of Salomon the peaceable, but by the hands and indu≈øtry of the Holy-gho≈øt, in who≈øe framing and fa≈øhioning as Salomon ≈øpent ≈øeuen yeares, ≈øo the Holy-gho≈øt did endue his with his ≈øeuen gifts. This our Temple is farre more richer than Salomons was, for if his was couered with gold, ≈øo ours is couered with diuine loue: and the difference betwixt tho≈øe two may ea≈øily bee knowne, by the difference that is betwixt a ≈øimple gilter, and a great louer. In Salomons Temple, the things of gold were ≈øo mea≈øured, & tho≈øe of wood ≈øo leuelled, that when they were laid downe, there was no Ax nor hamber heard: When the Holy-gho≈øt did frame the Temple of the mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity of Chri≈øt in the wombe of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgine Mary, hee framed it ≈øo iu≈øt, and made it in all perfection ≈øo exqui≈øite, that there was there no axe of ≈øinne, nor hamber of the diuell. The windowes of that temple were broader within than vvithout, to ≈øignifie vnto vs that the loue which Chri≈øt had ≈øecretly in his entrails was farre greater and broder than the wounds were which hee ≈øuffered for vs: and although that at the beginning he doth lead his a ≈øtraight and narrow way, yet after that they doe ta≈øt of his heauenly loue he maketh all things broad and large vnto them. In this holy Temple of Chri≈øt, we mu≈øt offer pure gold and excellent ≈øiluer, which wee doe then, when in heart we beleeue him, and with our mouth confe≈ø≈øe him. There mu≈øt al≈øo be offered latten, copper, and bra≈ø≈øe, by which we may vnder≈øtand the vertue of patience, for as tho≈øe mettals doe ≈øuffer many blowes, and ≈øerue to many v≈øes, ≈øo the vertue of patience doth ≈øuffer many iniuries, and maketh many men vertuous. It is fit for vs to offer there a ‚Ä¢ acinth ≈øtone, which is of the colour of heaueÃÑ to ≈øignifie therby vnto vs, that al our works & de≈øires ≈øhold be directed to attain heaueÃÑ, becau≈øe that is in heauen which we do beleeue on earth; there he dwelleth whoÃÑ we preach here;
and that is recompenced there which wee ≈øuffer here. Wee ≈øhould offer al≈øo in the liuely Temple of that ble≈ø≈øed humility, ≈øcarlet wel coloured and fine: whereby is vnder≈øtood the memory which wee ought to haue of his holy pa≈øsion, the which if it was trouble≈øome for him to ≈øuffer, is mo≈øt profitable for vs to contemplate. O how happy ≈øhould he be of whoÃÑ it might be ≈øaid, thy hears are like vnto the ≈øcarlet of the king died in the gutters. What are the heares but my thoughts? and what are the gutters but his precious wounds? and what is the coloured ≈øcarlet but his mo≈øt precious fle≈øh, died in his owne precious bloud? O who could be worthy to wa≈øh in this bloud the heares of his thoughts, euery day a little time, for ≈øeeing them of that colour, they would pre≈øently be acceptable to Chri≈øt. Thou ≈øhoulde≈øt offer al≈øo in this mo≈øt holy TeÃÑple ≈øcarlet twi≈øe died, that is, loue doubled: & if thou wilt know what loue doubled is, we tell thee that it is the loue of God, and the loue of thy neighbor. He offereth ≈øcarlet twi≈øe died, who doth the works of charity vnto his neighbour, and giueth no euill ≈øpeech vnto any man: and hee doth al≈øo offer ≈øcarlet twi≈øe died who offereth his ≈øoule vnto God, and part of his goods vnto his neighbour in nece≈øsity. God did al≈øo command fine white linnen to be offered vnto him, whereby a cha≈øt and a clean conuer≈øation is vnder≈øtood, becau≈øe there is nothing in this world in greater danger than the fame of a vertuous per≈øon. Flie then my brother, flie the occa≈øions of the world, and tru≈øt not ≈øo much as thy ≈øelfe, for how much the finer the thrid of thy fame is, the ≈øooner it will be broken & ≈øpotted, if thou haue not a viligant care ouer it. God commaunded likewi≈øe that they ≈øhould offer him in his Temple timber of the wood Cethin, becau≈øe it was incorruptible, whereby are vnder≈øtood all perfect works and well fini≈øhed, and this hee noteth, that if in vertuous workes wee haue not great con≈øtancy and pe≈øeuerance, the worme dooth con≈øume them like as they doe timber. God doth al≈øo command that they ≈øhould offer in his Temple goats heare, if they had nothing el≈øe, nor no other riches, and therevpon the Lord may
offer what he will, and man what hee can. What other thing are the goats heare which thou art to offer vnto him, but only our ≈øharpe and au≈øtere workes with the which wee are to ≈øerue him? With a vile and ba≈øe and rough couering, cloath of gold and fine ≈øilke is kept, and with a ≈øeuere life fame is con≈øerued and a clean con≈øcience, becau≈øe that dainty meats and curious apparell are not to bee v≈øed among perfect men. O how happy hee ≈øhould bee who might ≈øay with Chri≈øt, Con≈øummatum e≈øt, that is, that he followed our Lord vntil the la≈øt houre as hee might, and offered vnto him that which he had.

div.head: CHAP. V. How that all the my≈øteries and prophe≈øies which God had prophe≈øied of him were mo≈øt highly fulfilled in Chri≈øt in Ieru≈øalem.
div.p:
ECce a≈øcendimus Hiero≈øolimam, & con≈øummabuntur omnia quae ≈øcripta ≈øunt de filio hominis, Luke 18. Chri≈øt ≈øpake the≈øe wordes vnto his di≈øciples in the la≈øt iourney that hee made with them in this life, and it as if hee would ≈øay, Behold we goe vp into the great city of Ieru≈øalem, where all the prophe≈øies ≈øhall bee fulfilled which are written of mee, and where the ≈øonne of the virgine ≈øhall bee deliuered vnto the Gentiles, ≈øhal be ≈øcorned, and ≈øpet vpon, whipped and put to death, and after three daies they ≈øhall ≈øee him ri≈øen again. Before all things it is principally to be noted, that wher≈øoeuer this aduerb (Ecce) is put, there is alwaies ≈øignified ≈øome great my≈øtery as in E≈øayas, Ecce, Behold a virgine ≈øhall bring forth: in the incarnation, Ecce, Behold the handmaid of the Lord: in the tran≈øfiguration, Ecce, Behold a white cloud: in the temptation, Ecce, Behold the Angels ≈øhall mini≈øter vnto him: and in his re≈øurrection, Ecce,
behold an earthquake. The things which Chri≈øt ≈øpake vnto them in this place were ≈øo high, and the my≈øtery ≈øo great which hee di≈øcouereth vnto them, that they could not onely not vnder≈øtand it, but they were al≈øo afeared and began to tremble to heare it: for they thought it a violent thing that they ≈øhould martyr a holy man, and they thought it a very ≈øtrange thing that any man ≈øhould ri≈øe againe. Theophilus vpon S. div.p:
PAter ≈øancte claritatem quam tu dedi≈øti mihi dedi eis, vt ≈øint Con≈øummati in vnum, I ‚Ä¢ h. 17. The≈øe words are ≈øpoken by the mouth of the ≈øon of God, praying vnto his Father, after he had made a ≈øermon before ≈øupper, the highe≈øt and longe≈øt that euer hee preached in all his life time, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, O my holy, eternall, mighty and ble≈ø≈øed Father,
that which I entreat and reque≈øt of thee in this la≈øt houre is, that ≈øeeing I haue giuen to my Di≈øciples part of the light and ≈øcience which thou ha≈øt giuen mee, thou woulde≈øt al≈øo giue them grace to bee perfect in that kind of perfection as thou are wont to make perfect the elect. By occa≈øion of tho≈øe words which Chri≈øt ≈øpake vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, that is, Con≈øummatum est, and by rea≈øon of that other which he ≈øpake, praying vnto his Father, Con≈øummati ≈øunt, it ≈øhall bee nece≈ø≈øary for vs to declare in this place what that is which the redeemer of the world ≈øpake in his praier, and what the Scripture ≈øayth of it. It is here to be noted, who hee is which praieth, where hee praieth, when he praieth, and how he praieth, and for whome he praieth, & what he praieth: for oftentimes in Scripture the circum≈øtances how a thing is done, makes it either weighty or very weighty. Hee who praieth is Chri≈øt; the place where, is the p ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ or; the time, is at ≈øupper; how, is with lifting vp his eies; the things which hee praieth, are very high; they for whom, are his di≈øciples. In this high praier Chri≈øt ≈øpake dainty words, mo≈øt graue ≈øentences, very ≈øecret my≈øteries, very nece≈ø≈øary adui≈øes, and very profitable coun≈øels; by rea≈øon whereof, it is conuenient to read them with attention, and note them with deuotion. Chri≈øt then ≈øayth in the beginning of his praier, Pater ≈øancte ≈øerua eos in nomine tuo qui tui ≈øunt, & pro eis rogo & non pro mundo, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, My holy and ble≈ø≈øed father, that which I ask of thee for the≈øe thy children and my di≈øciples, is, that thou deliuer them from ≈øin, & keep them in thy ≈øeruice, ≈øeeing that they bee my brothers by nature, and thy children by grace: and if I aske any thing of thee it is not for tho≈øe which are of the world, but for tho≈øe which thou doe≈øt keepe vnder thy ≈øafegard. O ≈øweet words for the good, and ≈øorrowfull for the bad, ≈øeeing that by them are diuided and ≈øeperated the perfect from the fore≈øeene, the elect from the reprobate, Gods friends from the children of perdition, and al≈øo the neighbours of heauen from the louers of the world. How≈øoeuer Chri≈øt our redeemer praied from the hart for tho≈øe which he loued from the heart, yet he ≈øet this word
Sancte Pater before his praier, becau≈øe it is a very naturall thing, that this word Pater, maketh a father attentiue to here the child, and maketh his eies tender to behold him, and his heart gentle to loue him, and openeth his entrails that hee can deny him nothing. What ≈øweeter words can come to a fathers eares, than to heare his ≈øonne call him father? As a ≈øonne welbeloued and tendered, once Chri≈øt calleth his father my father, another time iu≈øt father, & another time Lord and father, ≈øometimes holy father, and ≈øometimes father and nothing el≈øe, ≈øo that ≈øuch as his praier was, ≈øuch was the name which hee gaue him. It is not then here without a my≈øtery, that hee calleth him Pater ≈øancte, becau≈øe hee who praied in this praier was mo≈øt holy, hee to whom hee praied was holy, that which hee praied were holy things, the place where hee praied was a holy place, and hee for whom he praied was his holy colledge. Peter, whom although Chri≈øt ≈øuffered to fall, yet hee did not abandon him and put him out of his ≈øight, for as ≈øoone as hee had committed the fault Chri≈øt pre≈øently looked him in the face. What ≈øhould become of ≈øinners and naughty per≈øons, if our Lord ≈øhould take away all good men from among≈øt them? God ≈øpake the≈øe words to holy Moy≈øes, giuing him order how the Prie≈øts ≈øhould be appointed, and how the ≈øacrifices ≈øhould be offered, as if he would ≈øay, If any Hebrew will offer vnto God any fruit to bee fried in a frying pan, the floure mu≈øt bee kned with oile, and without leauen, and after it is well fried, and oile ≈øprinkled vpon it, and cut into very ≈ømal peeces, ≈øo offered vnto Aaron, to bee offered vpon the altar. Before wee come to expound the≈øe my≈øteries, we mu≈øt ≈øhew the cau≈øe why our Lord would bu≈øie and occupy the people of the Iewes, in ≈øuch ≈øtrange rites, in ≈øuch new ≈øacrifices, and in ≈øo many ceremonies, being as hee was, ≈øo graue a Lord, and ≈øo mighty a God. Stapulen≈øis in the fir≈øt of Leuiticus ≈øayth, That for three cau≈øes God commanded the Iewes, to offer ≈øo many ≈ømall ≈øacrifices, and made with ≈øo many ceremonies. The fir≈øt is, that becau≈øe the Iews had beene brought vp in Aegypt, where all were idolatours, and they giuen to Idolatry, the Lord would that they ≈øhould offer tho≈øe ≈øacrifices vnto him, and not to the gods of the Gentiles. The ≈øecond rea≈øon is, that becau≈øe vnder tho≈øe ≈øacrifices
hee would declare and figure the true ≈øacrifice which ≈øhould come into the world which was his precious ≈øonne. The third rea≈øon is, that being occupied in that multitude of ≈øacrifices they ≈øhould haue no time to be≈øtow in committing of other ≈øinnes, becau≈øe the foundation of all wickedne≈ø≈øe is accur≈øed idlene≈ø≈øe. It is al≈øo to be noted, that there was ≈øeuen kinds of ≈øacrifices in the old law, vnto the which all other were reduced, although they ≈øeemed to be infinite. The fir≈øt ≈øacrifice was called Holocau≈øtum, which was the greate≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øumptuou≈øt of all, becau≈øe it was offered vnto our Lord without any other re≈øpect: the ≈øecond was called Pacificum becau≈øe it was offered in time of warre, partly becau≈øe our Lord ≈øhould giue them peace in their times, and partly becau≈øe he ≈øhould giue theÃÑ victory again≈øt their enemies. The third was called Propiciatory which was offered in time of great dearth or pe≈øtilence, and the end of it was becau≈øe our Lord ≈øhould withdraw his hand from ouer them, and take that plague from them. The fourth was called Pontificat, which was offered for the ≈øinnes of the prie≈øt of the Temple, and the end of it was, becau≈øe they did hold it certaine, that if the Prie≈øt were loaden with ≈øinnes, that the Lord at his handes would not accept the ≈øacrifices. The ≈øixt was called Common, which was offered for the ≈øins of all the people of I≈ørael, & the end of it was, that the Lord ≈øhould take them vnder his protection, & look vpon that people. The ≈øeuenth was called Particular, & this was offered for euery particular per≈øon, and the end of it was, that God ≈øhould pardon him for that which was pa≈øt, & giue him grace to amend hereafter. All the≈øe ≈øacrifices differed in the bea≈øts which were offered in them, & in the ceremonies with the which they were offered: and in one thing they all agreed, that is, that there could no ≈øacrifice be made for the remi≈øsion of any ≈øin, vnle≈ø≈øe the bloud of one

The Apo≈øtle ≈øaid not without great cau≈øe, Non fit ≈øanguinis effu≈øio ≈øed remi≈øsio, becau≈øe no maÃÑ could bee made cleane of a fault in the old law but by the death of ≈øome bea≈øt. Origen ≈øayth, It is certain that euery bea≈øt doth rather liue by his bloud, than by his fle≈øh, or members, or bones which he goeth with, for when he leaueth bleeding, hee leaueth breathing. Although it bee true, that in recompence of the lea≈øt fault, we are bound to offer our life for it, yet God in the old law was content with the life of a dead bea≈øt, in recompence of the life which that Iew did owe him. O how happie we be which fight vnder the name of Chri≈øt, becau≈øe the pari≈øhioners of the ≈øynagogue did offer the bloud of dead bea≈øts, but the faithful Chri≈øtians offer nothing but the bloud of the ≈øonne of the liuing God; in≈øomuch that we haue no nece≈øsity to offer our liues in recompence of our offences, becau≈øe the life of one was ≈øufficient to make cleane all the faults of the world. S. Paule could not prai≈øe Chri≈øts buying of vs better, than to ≈øay, Emptiestis pretio magno, giuing vs thereby to vnder≈øtand, that with the bloud of his vaines hee had bought our liues, and al≈øo taken away our offences. For to haue pardoned a Iew of his fault, it was nece≈ø≈øary euery time that hee had ≈øinned, to kill a bea≈øt: but in Chri≈øts holy law one death tooke away all deaths, one life did buy all liues, and one paine tooke away all paines and offences. When the Apo≈øtle calleth Chri≈øt, Hostiam viuentem, he wanteth not a deepe ≈øecret and a profound my≈øtery, becau≈øe that in the old law they called HostiaÃÑ, the ≈øacrifice which was offered again≈øt tho≈øe which were enemies, & they offered nothing but dead ≈øacrifices, becau≈øe the bea≈øt which they did offer was neither called ≈øacrifice, nor Hostia, vntill his life had been taken from him. The ≈øonne of God gaue the name of Ho≈øtia a ≈øacrifice when he died, and the name of life when he ro≈øe againe, and therefore wee may very well call him a liuely ≈øacrifice, a holy ≈øacrifice, a pure ≈øacrifice, and holy bread, ≈øeeing that hee is the ≈øacrifice and Hostie which giueth life vnto all,
and is the holie≈øt ≈øacrifice of all other, and the pure≈øt, and the cleane≈øt bread of all others. Anima cum obtulerit oblationem ≈øacrificij domino ≈øimilae erit eius oblatio & fundet ≈øuper eam oleum, & ponet thus, Leuit. 2. God ≈øpake the≈øe words vnto Moy≈øes, becau≈øe he ≈øhould tel them the people of I≈ørael, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, If any will offer any ≈øacrifice which ≈øhall bee acceptable vnto mee, offer mee it of the pure≈øt floure mingled with oile, and therewithall he ≈øhal adde a little frankincen≈øe. If wee doe curiou≈øly looke vnto it, of three things onely our Lord requireth an offering of vs, that is pure floure, good oile, and ≈øweet incen≈øe; the which things are ea≈øiy to bee found, light to offer, and not co≈øtly to buy. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, In this wee may ≈øee what a great de≈øire our Lord hath to pardon the ≈øinnes which we commit again≈øt him, in that he him≈øelfe doth teach vs what ≈øacrifices we ≈øhould offer vnto him. What is vnder≈øtood by that fine ≈øifted floure, but that mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity of the ≈øonne of God? This holy floure was ≈øo ≈øifted and putrified, that all the Angels which ≈øhall come to ≈øee it, and all the men in the world which ≈øhall come to clen≈øe it, ≈øhall not find in that ≈øacred humanity one ≈ømal grite of originall ≈øinne, nor on ≈øpot of mortall ≈øinne, nor one little du≈øt of any other ≈ømall ≈øinne. Of this mo≈øt pure floure Chri≈øt did knead the ≈øacramentall bread in his la≈øt ≈øupper, which he left vs in the church, which doth differ farre from that which mother Eue did leaue her children, becau≈øe that in eating of that we doe ≈øinne, and receiuing of this we doe liue. What is the incen≈øe which God commaunded vs to offer with the floure in his Temple, but the diuinity which is ioined with the humanity in Chri≈øt? Vntill the gate of the Temple the floure was carried by it ≈øelfe, and the incen≈øe by it≈øelfe, but being brought to the gate of the Temple, the one was incorporated with the other: which my≈øtery was mo≈øt notably accompli≈øhed in the comming of Chri≈øt, becau≈øe that ≈øo farre a≈øunder was mankind which was here vpon earth, from the diuinity which was in heauen, but the ≈øon of God comming into the world, immediately God with man, and man with
God became one. What is the oile with the which God commanded the floure and incen≈øe to be tempered, but that which in the ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie wee call the holy-gho≈øt? The coniunction & bond of loue betwixt the Father and the ≈øon, and hee who did incorporate the floure with the incen≈øe, was no other but the holy-gho≈øt, for ≈øo ≈øaid the prophe≈øie, Vnxit te deus, deus tuus eleo letetia, and ≈øo ≈øaid the Angell vnto the virgine when he ≈øaid, Spiritus ≈øanctus ≈øuperueniet in te. That which the Prophet called oile, the Angell afterward did cal the holy-gho≈øt: in≈øomuch that the cake which God demanded of floure, oile, and incen≈øe, was nothing el≈øe but the humanity of him which was made by the father, and by the ≈øon, and by the holy-gho≈øt. A cake ≈øo well ≈øea≈øoned, a ≈øacrifice ≈øo highly well made, which of the ≈øaints would not offer, and which of the Angels would not adore? The ≈øacrifice which God did demand in times pa≈øt, was not that which the Synagogue did offer, but that which the catholike church doth now offer, for they did offer him dow wet in vineger, and fou≈øtie oile, and mo≈øt ≈øharpe incen≈øe, but the ≈øacrifice which wee doe now offer him is the humanity and diuinity of Chri≈øt, vnited and put together by the handes of the holy-gho≈øt. It is no rea≈øon that the Chri≈øtian and deuour reader ≈øhould be ignorant why God commanded but a part of the floure to bee offered, but all the incen≈øe. To put a mea≈øure in the floure was to ≈øay, that the humanity of it ≈øelfe was limitted and had an end, and to put no mea≈øure in the frankincen≈øe was to ≈øay, that in the diuinity there is neither beginning nor end, which is mo≈øt true, becau≈øe the workes which the ≈øonne of God did were limmitted and circum≈øcribed in that, that he was man, but being kneaded with the oile of the holy-gho≈øt, he made them infinite in value and weight. To come then to our fir≈øt purpo≈øe, the text ≈øayth, si oblatio tua fuerit de ≈øartagine ≈øimile con≈øper≈øa oleo, & ab≈øque fermento, diuides eam minutatim, & fundas ≈øuper cam oleum, as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, The fritter which thou ≈øhalt offer vnto me, ≈øhall bee made of the floure of the meale, without leauen, kned with very good oile, and then
being well pricked, thou ≈øhalt ≈øprinckle it ouer with new oile. If there ≈øhould bee no my≈øtery hidden vnder this Iudaicall ≈øacrifice, wee might haue occa≈øion to thinke that our Lord were a glutton, and giuen to variety of meats, ≈øeeing that in the beginning of this chapter he asked of theÃÑ fritters or cake dre≈ø≈øed with good oile, and now againe a cake made of the floure of wheat, and that without leauen, ≈ømall broken, and fried in a frying pan in very whote oile. Of this high and new ≈øacrifice, what is the floure but the humanity which ≈øuffered, what the oile but the loue with the vvhich hee died, and what the frying pan but the cro≈ø≈øe where hee died? To ≈øay that God the Father did aske for a cake made in a frying pan, and to ≈øay that the cro≈ø≈øe of his ≈øonne was the frying pan, and that the fine floure of his precious fle≈øh was fried in that fryingpan, and that the oile with the which it was fried was the loue with the which he redeemed vs, is no vnreuerent ≈øpeech to v≈øe; neither is there any errorin affirming it, ≈øeeing wee he certain that there is no word writteÃÑ in holy Scripture which is not full of high my≈øtery. The property of the fryingpan is, being put vpon the fire the fire dooth not wa≈øt him nor melt him as hee doth many other thinges, and be≈øide: hee maketh tho≈øe meats which are cold, hard, and not to be eaten; whote, ≈øoft, and very ≈øauourous. What was the death and pa≈øsion of our redeemer Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, but a frying pan put to the fire? The ≈øacred humanity of Chri≈øt being put in the fryingpan of the cro≈ø≈øe, notwith≈øtanding all the torments which they gaue him, and all the iniuries and reproches which they ≈øpake again≈øt him they neuer dimini≈øhed any part of his vertue, for although for the ≈øpace of three daies his ≈øoule was ≈øeperated from his body, yet they deuide not his Diety from his ≈øoule, nor from his body. I≈øichius vpon Leuiticus ≈øayth, Before that the ≈øonne of God was fried in the frying pan of the cro≈ø≈øe, his fle≈øh was ≈øo raw that it could not bee eaten, but after that the fire of his pa≈øsion did ≈øea≈øon it vs and frie it, there is nothing in heauen more ≈øauerous, nor nothing on the earth more profitable. Cyrillus in another ≈øence ≈øaith, There were four things
in this ≈øacrifice, fire, the pan, oile, and flour: The≈øe four things were found in the pa≈øsion of Chri≈øt, that is, the fire which the Iewes kindled to the end hee ≈øhould dieithe frying pan, vvas the cro≈ø≈øe which they ≈øought out where hee ≈øhould die: and the oile, the loue and charity with the vvhich hee died there for to redeeme the world: and the floure, his mo≈øt ≈øacred fle≈øh vvhich there was fried. O glorious ≈øacrifice, O eternall meat, that thou art O ≈øonne of the liuing God, ≈øeeing that fried and whote, and ≈øea≈øoned, thou didde≈øt giue thy ≈øelfe in the frieng pan of the cro≈ø≈øe, to the end that all men might eat thee, and none excu≈øed from ≈øeruing thee. When the ≈øonne of God ≈øaid, Ni≈øi manducaueritis carnem filij hominis, his Di≈øciples being ≈øcandalized, Abierunt retror≈øum & dixerunt, durus est hic ≈øermo. But after that, that mo≈øt ≈øacred fle≈øh was ≈øea≈øoned & fried in the frying pan of the cro≈ø≈øe, it was ≈øoft & ≈øweer to ta≈øt of, ≈øauerous to eat, and profitable to be taken. Sume tibi ≈øartaginem ferream, & ponas eam murum ferreum, inter te & eiuitatem, ≈øaid God by the Prophet Ezechiel, chap. 4, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, Goe thy way out of the city, and thou ≈øhalt put a frieng pan of iron betweene thee and the city, becau≈øe thou maie≈øt neither ≈øee her, nor ≈øhee hurt thee. Who euer ≈øaw or heard the like, that the Lord ≈øhould command the Prophet to fight with a frying pan, and defend him≈øelfe behind the ≈øame? Tell me O Ezechiel, what hurt coulde≈øt thou do with a frying pan, ≈øeeing it hath no point, or how coulde≈øt thou defend thy ≈øelfe vnder it, con≈øidering that it will ≈øcar≈øe couer thy head? If thou wilt goe to fight take a launce with thee, and if thou wilt go to defend thy ≈øelfe from thy enemies take thy Target, becau≈øe the frying pan is fitter for the kitcheÃÑ thaÃÑ the warre, and better to dre≈ø≈øe meat with than to fight. O glorious cro≈ø≈øe, O holy frying pan, where the fle≈øh of my God was fried, where his bloud was ≈øhed, where his charitie vvas enflamed, where our fault was melted, and where his life was ended. The frying pan of the Synagogue was neither good for warres nor profitable for peace: But thou holy cro≈ø≈øe and happy frying pan wa≈øt hee, with the which the diuell was
ouercome, God pacified, the world redeemed, and the heauen opened. What thing can I put betwixt thee and mee O good Ie≈øus, but this precious cro≈ø≈øe & frying pan where thou didde≈øt end thy life, that my ≈øin might not come vnto thee, nor thy puni≈øhment pa≈ø≈øe to me. Doe thou not think my brother, doe thou not think, that God commanded the Prophet to put betweene him and the city a frying pan, for any good that it would doe him, but for that which the frying pan ≈øignified: for thereby was ≈øignified the cro≈ø≈øe and the crucified, which ≈øhould be a mediator betweene God and the world. O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, O my ≈øoules delight, where but in the frying pan of thy dolors and griefes, and where but in the oile of thy charity and loue, didde≈øt thou end con≈øume and fry my enormious ≈øinnes? Where but in the frying pan of the cro≈ø≈øe, where thou ≈øaied≈øt, Con≈øummatum e≈øt, giuing vs to vnder≈øtand by that la≈øt ≈øpeech, that there thou hadde≈øt ended and made a full account of our ≈øinne and thy anger, of our perdition and thy pa≈øsion, of our ignorance and thy life?

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Wherein is declared a figure when Moy≈øes did annoint the altar ≈øeuen times with one finger, and how that vnction was a figure of Chri≈øt, and fully accompli≈øhed in his mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity.
div.p:
DIgito ≈øuo vnxit Moy≈øes altare ≈øepties oleo vnctionis, this is written in the 40 chapter of Exodus, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, In the ≈øame day that Moy≈øes did in≈øtitute his brother Aaron bi≈øhop, and ordained al≈øo his children Prie≈øts, hee did annoint the great altar ≈øeuen times, and that with one finger, and did con≈øecrate it with oile. Cyrillus vpon this place ≈øayth, That although all the holy Scripture be full of my≈øteries,
yet there is greate≈øt attention to bee giuen when it ≈øpeaketh of the altar, or of a Prie≈øt, becau≈øe that, that my≈øtery cannot be handeled, and not talk of the my≈øteries of Chri≈øt. If we doe looke into the words of the text, we ≈øhall find that that which is annointed is the altar, that with the which it is ointed is holy oile, and the manner how is with one finger only, and that ≈øeuen times; and that which was further ointed were all the ornaments of the altar. The≈øe were the qualities of the altar, neere vnto it were the holy breads, before it burned lampes, on the ≈øide of it they did put the candle≈øtickes, on the top of it the offered ≈øacrifices, at the foot of it they ≈øhed the bloud, behind it were the people, ouer again≈øt it was the vaile, vpon it was the Cherubin, about it were the curtaines. This altar was made of wood which would not rot, there could come none to it but the Prie≈øts, they could not goe vp to it by ≈øteps nor ≈øtaires, night and day lampes burned there, & other fire which ≈øhould not be put out. Although the altar of the Synagogue had many priuiledges, and great freedomes, yet it had a counterpei≈øe with it, which was, that vpoÃÑ it they ≈ølew all the bea≈øts which they did offer vnto God, & therefore it was ≈øometimes ≈øo bloudy & ≈øo loaden with flies, that it ≈øeemed rather a bord in the butchery to cut fle≈øh on, then an altar of the church. Who is the true altar, & the holy altar, and the cleane altar, but only the ≈øonne of the liuing God? Origen ≈øayth, In the Temple of the Synagogue the altar was one thing, and the Prie≈øt another, & another thing that which they offered; but in the altar of the church, the altar where they offer, and the Prie≈øt which doth offer, and the ≈øacrifice which is offered, and he vnto whom it is offered is one and the ≈øame thing. Leo in a Sermon of our Lords Supper ≈øayth, In this high ≈øupper and in this holy altar, the ≈øonne of God is the ultar, and the meat, and he who inuiteth, and he who is inuited, he who eateth, and is eaten, hee who annointeth, and is annointed, he who offereth and is offered. What preheminences had the altar of the old Synagogue, which are not greater in the Catholicke church? Their altar was of
the wood of the Mount Lybanus, & ours of the mo≈øt ≈øacred humanity of Chri≈øt; theirs was of wood which would not corrupt, and ours of fle≈øh which cannot ≈øinne; theirs was made bloody with other bloud than their owne, and ours is wa≈øhed with his own bloud; vpon theirs they did kil bea≈øts, vpon ours they forgiue vs our offences; to theirs there could none go vp but the Prie≈øts of the teÃÑple, but vnto ours al the ≈øinners of the world may come vnto; in theirs there burned a fire of light which mu≈øt euery houre be kindled and put together, but in ours there burneth the fire of his loue and charity which can neuer be extingui≈øhed. O holy altar, O glorious altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, in which there is offered not dead bea≈øts, but mens ≈øins, not to proue theÃÑ but to pardon them, where our weake ≈øeruices are offered, not becau≈øe thou woulde≈øt prai≈øe theÃÑ O Lord, but becau≈øe thou woulde≈øt accept them, and where al≈øo the merits of thy holy ≈øonne are offered, not for his own ≈øake who was without ≈øin, but for ours who can doe nothing but ≈øinne. The altar of the Synagogue had no ≈øtep nor ≈øtaire, becau≈øe the common ≈øort did beleeue nothing in God but his e≈ø≈øence, but to the altar of our catholick church, which is a congregation of the faithful, they go vp by three ≈øteps, becau≈øe we beleeue in one e≈ø≈øence & three per≈øons. The text al≈øo ≈øaith, that the altar of the ≈øynagogue was annointed with one finger only: who ≈øhal we ≈øay that this finger is but the ≈øelfe≈øame holygho≈øt? Hilarius de Trinitate ≈øaith, In al the Trinity there is but one arm, & that is the Father, of whom the Prophet ≈øaith, Et brachiuÃÑ meuÃÑ coÃÑfortauit eum, neither is there any more but one hand which is the ≈øon, of whom al≈øo the Prophet ≈øaith, Filius meuses tuego hodie genui te, nor there is in all the Trinity but one finger of whoÃÑ the ≈øcripture ≈øaith, Digitus dei hic e≈øt. In the vnctions & creations of vs there are many fingers occupied, that is, my great grandfather begat my grandfather, and my grandfather my father, & my father begat me, & I begat my ≈øon, and my ≈øonne begat my nephew: but in the generation of Chri≈øt there was applied one only finger, which was the per≈øon of the holy-gho≈øt. Augu≈øt in a ≈øermon ≈øayth, Seeing that
he which doth beget is one, and hee who is begotten is one, and ≈øhe who doth bring forth is one, and he for whom hee is borne is one, which is the world; why ≈øhould there haue been more then one finger, which was the Holy-gho≈øt? The text ≈øayth further, that the altar was not annointed once only, but ≈øeuen times a row. What is meant that Chri≈øt was annointed ≈øeuen times a row, but only that all the ≈øeuen gifts of the holy-gho≈øt were be≈øtowed vpon him? It is to bee noted, that in all the ≈øacrifices which they made of kine, ≈øheepe, and goats, and pigeons, the altar was alwaies annointed with bloud, ≈øauing when they ordained Aaron a prie≈øt, at what time they did annoint it with oile alone, the which was not done without a my≈øtery. The rea≈øon theÃÑ is this, that becau≈øe al their ≈øacrifices were done to take away the Iews ≈øins, the which were to bee taken away with ≈øhedding of bloud, Quia ≈øine ≈øanguinis effu≈øione non fit remi≈øsio, ≈øayth the Apo≈øtle, there was no need of effu≈øion of bloud in the ≈øacrifice which did only repre≈øent Chri≈øt, becau≈øe in him there was no ≈øinne at all. Why ≈øhould they haue annointed with bloud the altar of the humanity of Chri≈øt, con≈øidering that not onely there was no ≈øin in him, but in him all the ≈øins of the world were to be taken away? If the curious Reader would deeply vnder≈øtand this high figure let him turn Moy≈øes name into the Father, and Aarons name into Chri≈øt, and the altar into humanity, and the name of annointing into gift, and bloud into the water of bapti≈øm, & the finger into the holy-gho≈øt, and then hee ≈øhall truly find, how well the truth doth an≈øwere vnto the figure, and the letter to the ≈øpirit. The text ≈øayth further in the ≈øame chapter. Vnxit altare cum omni≈øuppellectili, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, After that Moy≈øes had made an end of annointing the altar with holy oile, hee did al≈øo annoint all things that did belong to the altar, that is, ewars, ba≈øins, candle≈øtickes, towels, hookes, chafindi≈øhes. Let no man thinke it to bee a ie≈øt, that God commanded to annoint with holy oile, not only the altar, but al≈øo all things which did appettaine to the altar, becau≈øe that by this is di≈øcouered one of the greate≈øt priuiledges that Chri≈øt had,
which no man did euer but hee enioy in the world. What ≈øhould it meane that at the altar of the Synagogue there remained nothing which was not annointed with oile, but that there was nothing in the humanity of the word which was not fully repleni≈øhed with the holy-gho≈øt? Why is Chri≈øt called Sanctus ≈øanctoruÃÑ, but becau≈øe his holy vnction was more holy thaÃÑ that of all the other ≈øaints? When the church doth wa≈øh her creatures in bapti≈øm, ≈øhee doth with water wa≈øh, and as it were only there annoint ≈øoules which were defiled with original ≈øin, the which ≈øoules are made ≈øo clean & pure with that vnction, that if they ≈øhould depart pre≈øently out of this life, they ≈øhould imediately by Gods fauor go to glory. O vnhappy that we be, for although they wa≈øh & annoint our ≈øoule in bapti≈øm, yet there remaineth our memory to be annointed, ≈øeeing that wee forget God; there remaineth our vnder≈øtanding to be annointed, ≈øeeing we think of other things thaÃÑ of God; there remaineth our will to be annointed, ≈øeeing that wee put our loue on other things be≈øides God; & al≈øo our hart remaineth to be annointed, ≈øeeing we giue it to another thaÃÑ to god. What ≈øhall we ≈øay of our poore body, ≈øeeing there is no part or meÃÑber of it which is annointed? ≈øeeing my eies can ≈øee nothing but vanity, my ears hear nothing but lightnes, my toung nothing but lie, my meÃÑbers coÃÑmit ≈øin, & my hands theft? what ≈øhal I ≈øay of ≈øuch a body, is he not rather rotteÃÑ theÃÑ annointed? wheÃÑ the Apo≈øtle S. Paul ≈øaid with weeping tears, alas & woe be vnto me vnhappy & vnfortunate man, who wil deliuer me froÃÑ the ≈øeruitude of this body? would he haue ≈øpoken ≈øuch pitiful words if the powers of his body had been annointed with holy oile of loue & charity? the church like a pittiful mother doth annoint vs with the whol≈øome water of bapti≈øme when we be born, & afterward ≈øhe doth wa≈øh and annoint vs vvith loue & charity wheÃÑ ≈øhe doth giue vs grace to loue god & forgiue our neighbors: the fir≈øt vnctioÃÑ is to help vs that we do not ≈øin, & the ≈øecoÃÑd to make vs clean of al that which we haue already ≈øinned. O what ≈ømall need Chri≈øt hath to bee ≈øo many times annointed, nor by the church helped; for from the fir≈øt in≈øtant of his incarnation was annointed, not only the altar of
his mo≈øt holy humanity, to enioy pre≈øeÃÑtly the diuine e≈ø≈øence, but al≈øo all the members of his holy body were annointed, becau≈øe they might neuer ≈øinne, nor neuer be ≈øeperated from God. The figure of annointing the altar with all the furniture was ≈øpoke of none but of Chri≈øt, nor fulfilled in none but in Chri≈øt alone, becau≈øe it doth ea≈øily appeare, that as the holygho≈øt left no part in his ≈øoule nor body, which he did not ≈øanctifie and make holy, ≈øo there was no power in his ≈øoule nor body, which to our benefite hee did not imploy. Wee may better ≈øay of Chri≈øt than of Moy≈øes, hee dooth annoint the altar, Cum omni ≈øuppellectile, ≈øeeing that with his feet hee vi≈øited the altars of the Temples, with his hands cured the ≈øick, with his tongue preached to the people, and with his heart forgaue ≈øinners.

div.head: The≈øe foure chapters are all which the Author left, made vpon the ≈øeuenth word which Chri≈øt ≈øpake vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, that is, In manus tuus, &c. For while≈øt that he was a making it, it plea≈øed our Lord to take him out of this life.
CHAP. I. How God is the only and true comforter, and how hee was Deus vltionum to the Synagogue, and is to the church Pater mi≈øericordiarum.
div.p:
BEnedictus deus & pater domini no≈øtri Ie≈øu Christi, pater mi≈øericordiarum, & deus totius con≈øolationis, qui con≈øolatur nos in omni tribulatione nostra. The≈øe are the words of the Apo≈øtle, ≈øpeaking of the goodnes and mercy of our Lord God, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, Ble≈ø≈øed and prai≈øed bee the Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who is the father of all mercies and God of all comfort, and who is the true con≈øolation of all our tribulations. With a high ≈øtile and lofty wordes the Apo≈øtle doth extoll the greatne≈ø≈øe and power of God in calling him Father, and Father of mercies; and God, and the God of con≈øolations: and aboue all that, he keepeth them
not for him≈øelf only, but doth ≈øuccour vs with them in all our tribulations. O how happy is the Apo≈øtle who vttereth the≈øe words, and how ble≈ø≈øed wee Chri≈øtians for whom hee ≈øpake them, and how ble≈ø≈øed is Chri≈øt, by who≈øe merits they were ≈øpoken? What grauer ≈øentences, or ≈øweeter words could bee ≈øpoken, ≈øeeing that by them he maketh him≈øelfe, of God, our Father; of a iudge, our aduocate; of a Lord, our brother; of a reuenger, mercifull; of him which was cruell, gentle & meek; of him which could not be ≈øpoken with, mo≈øt affable; and of one which was inui≈øible, treatable. Thou mai≈øt haue pitty on me, and I haue pitty on thee, and I can comfort thee, & thou can≈øt comfort me, but to haue pitty on all, who can doe it but only the father of mercies? and comfort all men, who is able to doe it but only the father of all con≈øolations? If I be ≈øicke one may cure me, if I be naked another can cloth me, if I be ≈øad a freind can ≈øomewhat comfort mee, but tell mee I pray thee, who is able to helpe mee in all tribulation and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, but only our Lord who doth coÃÑfort vs in all our tribulations? Who ≈øayth by the P≈øalme, Cum ip≈øo ≈øum in tribulatione, & of whom ≈øpeaketh the Apo≈øtle, Quod con≈øolatur nos in omni tribulatione: of who was he euer called whom he did not helpe? The father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt is he, who in calling vpon him, doth open; in ≈øpeaking to him, doth an≈øwer; who being demanded any iu≈øt thing, doth graunt it. By peeces & by patches, and by crownes men can giue vs of their plea≈øures, and the world his delights: onely hee who is the God of all comfort can comfort vs in our di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and ≈øuccour vs in our nece≈øsities. It is much to be noted, that the Apo≈øtle doth not ≈øay the God of con≈øolation, but the Lord of all con≈øolation: whereof wee may inferre, that all comfort which dooth not come of him is di≈ø≈øolute or fained, or imperfect. Wee ≈øhould haue great pitty on tho≈øe men which ≈øay, Let vs go ≈øport our ≈øelues at the water, let vs goe walke in a garden, who ≈øeeme rather to play the Idolaters then to recreate them≈øelues, ≈øeeing they put all their felicity and ca≈øe in ≈øeeing a greene meddow in the running of the riuer, in flouri≈øhing trees, and to ≈øit
in a banketting hou≈øe. Seneca in an Epi≈øtle ≈øayth, Let no man thinke that con≈øolation dooth con≈øi≈øt in that which wee ≈øee with our eies, or heare with our eares, or touch with our hands, or ≈ømel with our no≈øe, but only in that which the heart de≈øireth: for no man can bee at re≈øt, if his heart haue not contentment. With variety of meats the ta≈øt is recreated, the ≈øight reioiceth in faire ≈øights, the hearing is delighted with ≈øweet mu≈øick, the ≈ømell is plea≈øed with aromaticall perfumes, and the feeling ioieth in ≈øoft thinges; but what ≈øhall the poole heart doe, which neither taketh ta≈øt in meats, nor plea≈øure in mu≈øicke, nor delight in that which it ≈øeeth, nor contentment in that which it ≈ømelleth? what other thing ≈øaith the church when ≈øhe ≈øayth, Sur≈øum corde, but that we ≈øhould lift vp our hearts vnto God, ≈øeeing that there is no perfect con≈øolation for them below in the world. Al wicked men would bid God much good doe it him with his glory, if they could find any perfect ca≈øe vpon earth for their hearts, but becau≈øe they cannot find it, bee he neuer ≈øo bad hee ≈øighteth to goe to heauen. We ≈øay all this, becau≈øe the Apo≈øtle ≈øaying, that hee is the God of all con≈øolation, how can any man haue any con≈øolation in this life, vnle≈ø≈øe hee giue it him who is the God of all con≈øolation? How great ≈øoeuer a lord Hector was in Troy, & how great ≈øoeuer Alexander was in A≈øia, and how mighty ≈øoeuer Cae≈øar was in Rome; notwith≈øtanding Chri≈øt was greater in his church: becau≈øe all tho≈øe Princes were ≈øuch ouer their cities only, but the ≈øonne of God is the God of all con≈øolations. What greater plea≈øure then to giue plea≈øure to whom thou loue≈øt, what greater contentment then to giue contentment to whome thou like≈øt? Our Lord kept this trea≈øure for him≈øelfe alone, and re≈øerued this ≈øegniory for him≈øelf, that is, Quod ≈øit deus totius con≈øolationis, and therevpon it is, that if he will not ≈øhew that which hee can doe, and impart among vs that which he hath, no iu≈øt maÃÑ ≈øhould liue coÃÑteÃÑtedly, nor any Angell happily. If as one is lord of many po≈ø≈øe≈øsions and inheritances, he were al≈øo of many plea≈øures and con≈øolations, what would wee not giue for them, what would wee not be≈øtow
to attaine vnto them, and vnto what would we not put our ≈øelues to take them? All mortal men go after their plea≈øures, and hunt for delight, but ala≈ø≈øe they ≈øeeke them in the hou≈øe of the God of trauels which is the world, and for≈øake the Lord of con≈øolations which is God, and therefore they goe a≈øtray in that which they ≈øeeke, and goe di≈øcomforted in that which they de≈øire. Barnard in a ≈øermon ≈øayth, O what a great comfort it is to the good, that they haue him for their God and Lord who is the God and Lord of all con≈øolations: for it is not to be beleeued, that being the God of al comforts, that he doth not impart ≈øome of them vnto his; and e≈øpecially, ≈øeeing that hee doth not di≈øcomfort tho≈øe which offend him, who will not beleeue but hee will comfort tho≈øe which ≈øerue him? When the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth that our God is the God of all con≈øolations, and not onely that, but al≈øo the father of mercies, we haue great cau≈øe to loue him, and to be thankfull vnto him, ≈øeeing that not long before hee called him≈øelfe the God of reuenge, as now he dooth call him≈øelfe the Father of mercies. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, What greater news could we hear, or what could he giue vs for a greater reward, then for our Lord to giue him≈øelfe vnto vs for our father, his ≈øonne for our brother, the holy-gho≈øt for our mai≈øter, his church for our mother, the Sacraments for a medicine, his death for a pardon, & his bloud for our redemption? I≈øichius vpon Leuiticus ≈øayth, Marke the depth of the Scripture, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee that when he ≈øpeaketh of mercies, it doth not call God, Deus mi≈øericordiarum, The God of mercy, but Pater mi≈øericordiarum, the Father of mercies; and when it talketh of iu≈øtice, it doth not call him Pater vltionum, but Deus vltionum, The God of reuenge, becau≈øe it is the office of God to puni≈øh, and the duty of the father to pardon. The Prophets did oft v≈øe this word Deus, God, and helped them≈øelues little with this word Pater, Father; and Chri≈øt contrariwi≈øe, did oft benefite him≈øelfe with this word Pater, Father, and ≈øildome with this name Deus, God: giuing vs thereby to vnder≈øtand, that the time of iu≈øtice was now ended, and that
the time of mercy was come.

I≈øidorus De ≈øummo bono, ≈øayth, O eternall goodne≈ø≈øe, and depth of all vvi≈øedome, vvhy ≈øhould I di≈øtru≈øt in thy great clemency, being that thou art my Father, and Father of all mercy? Let the Pagans di≈øtru≈øt in thee who beleeue thee not, let the vvicked di≈øtru≈øt in thee vvho ≈øerue thee not, for I vvill hope in thee vvith tho≈øe vvhich ≈øerue thee and loue thee: For although I cannot wholly ≈øerue thee, I labour as much as I can not to offend thee.

An≈øelmus vpon the Apo≈øtle ≈øayth, After I heard thee ≈øay, O my good Ie≈øus, Pater igno≈øce illis; and the Apo≈øtle ≈øay, Pater mi≈øericordiarum, Although my naughty life make mee afraid, yet thy great mercy commeth immediately to my mind, for the ≈øame day that thou didde≈øt make thy ≈øelfe man, thou didde≈øt change thy name, from the God of Reuenge, into the Father of Mercies. O glorious and happy chaunge, that is, the changing the name of God into the name of Father, and the name of a Reuenger into the name of a Defender, the name of Iu≈øtice into the name of Mercy, the name of a Creator into the name of a Redeemer, all which thou didde≈øt chaunge vvhen thou wa≈øt made man, and didde≈øt ≈øuffer on the cro≈ø≈øe for mee.

Saint Augustine vpon the Apo≈øtles vvordes ≈øayth, Tell mee O good Ie≈øus, tell mee O great Redeemer, after thou hadde≈øt chaunged the name of Deus vltionum into the name of Pater mi≈øericordiarum, what didde≈øt thou ≈øee ≈øo hard that thou didde≈øt not bring to pa≈ø≈øe, or vvhat ≈øinne didde≈øt thou ≈øee ≈øo enormious that thou didde≈øt not pardon? In calling thy ≈øelfe the Father of mercies thou didde≈øt forgiue Matthew his exchanges, Mary Magdalene her vanities, the Samaritane
her Adulteries, the good theefe his theft, and the fi≈øher-man Peter his denying of thee, the Apo≈øtles for≈øaking of thee, and thy enemies putting thee to death. Irenaeus ≈øayth, Seeing that the time of Deus vltionum is pa≈øt, and that the time of Pater mi≈øericordiarum is come, haue mercy on mee, O great God of I≈ørael, haue mercy on mee: and when ≈øhall this bee, but vvhen thou vvilt giue me ≈øtrength to ≈øerue and prai≈øe thee, and endue mee vvith grace to ≈øaue mee? O Father of mercies, O the God of all con≈øolation, vvhen ≈øhall my ≈øoule heare for her ≈øelfe, Pater igno≈øce illi, as the vvicked Synagogue did heare thee ≈øay, Father forgiue them? What doth it auaile mee, that thou ha≈øt pardoned tho≈øe vvhich did then put thee to death, if thou doe not al≈øo now forgiue vs vvhich mo≈øt vvickedly offend thee? Children for children, ≈øinners for ≈øinners, there is as great rea≈øon that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt pardon tho≈øe of thy holy church as tho≈øe of the Synagogue, for if they vvere children of the God of reuenge vvho did put thee to death then, they are al≈øo children of the Father of mercies, who do offend thee now.

Saint Augustine in his Confe≈øsions ≈øayth: O Father of mercies and God of all comfort, if it bee true that I vvas vvith tho≈øe vvhich tooke thy life from thee vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, vvhy ≈øhoulde≈øt thou not as well forgiue mee my fault, as thou didde≈øt then theirs?

Vnto thee O eternall Father, I ≈øay Mea culpa, and vnto thee O holy ≈øonne I confe≈ø≈øe my offence, in that, that if I vvas not vvith Iudas vvhen hee ≈øold thee, yet I vvas vvith the vvicked and vngratefull Iewes vvhen they did crucifie thee: for if they did fa≈øten thee on the cro≈ø≈øe vvith nailes, I did there crucifie thee vvith my ≈øinnes. An≈øelmus in his Meditations ≈øayth, O good Ie≈øus, O the bli≈ø≈øe of my ≈øoule, vvho
carried thee to the cro≈ø≈øe, but the loue which thou hadde≈øt to redeeme vs? And what tormented thee but thy dolours? And what tooke thy life from thee but my ≈øinnes? And by whom haue I life but by thy merits? O Father of mercies, if it be true, that for my demerits thou didde≈øt lo≈øe thy life, and that by thy great merits I recouered my ≈øoule, do≈øt thou not thinke that thou ha≈øt much in my faults to pardon, & in my ≈øoule to redre≈ø≈øe and amend? Barnard ≈øayth, O creator of all things, O redeemer of all ≈øinnes, vnto thee O my God I offer my ≈øelfe, and before thee O my Lord I pre≈øent my ≈øelfe, not ≈øuch a one as thou didde≈øt leaue mee when thou didde≈øt create mee, but ≈øuch as one as thou founde≈øt mee when thou redeemed≈øt mee. What a one didde≈øt thou leaue mee but made to thy image and ≈øemblance? and what a one didde≈øt thou find mee but with my innocency lo≈øt, and loaden with ≈øinne? O father of mercies pardon mee, ≈øeeing that I am a worke of thy owne hands, pardon me ≈øeeing that I am one of thy children, and ≈øeeing I ≈øay vnto thee vpon my knees, Tibi ≈øoli peccaui, it is rea≈øon that thou an≈øwer me (O my God) with Mi≈øcriatur tui.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the difference that is betwixt Dauids te≈øtament, and Chri≈øts te≈øtament, ≈øeeing the one commandeth to reuenge other mens iniuries, and the other pardoneth his owne death.
div.p:
NOn deduces canicies eius pacifice ad inferos, 3. Reg. chap. 2. King Dauid being in the la≈øt point of his life, commanded his ≈øonne and heire apparent, Salomon, to be called vnto him vnto whome hee ≈øpake the≈øe words, Thou remembere≈øt my ≈øonne Salomon, when my ≈øeruant and capraine Ioab did ≈ølay captaine
Abner and Ama≈øias who were ≈øcruants vnto king Saul, the which offence becau≈øe I cannot reueÃÑge in my life, the charge ≈øhll be laid vpon thee, to ≈øee that hee goe not quietly to his graue: and Dauid ≈øaid further vnto him, Thou ≈øhalt al≈øo remember, that when I fled from thy brother and my ≈øon Ab≈øolon, my enemy Simei came again≈øt me, and followed mee all the field ouer, cur≈øing me and ca≈øting ≈øtones at me; Look vnto it like a wi≈øe and a di≈øcreet man, and that hee depart not in peace out of this world. That which Dauid commanded his ≈øonne Salomon to doe, was not commanded to one who was deaffe, for if hee did command him to kill two, hee did kill three or foure, that is, the infant Abdonias, the captaine Ioab, Simei, and the Prie≈øt Abiathar. In al his kingdome Dauid had no captaine which had done him ≈øo great ≈øeruice, nor no ≈øeruant which had loued him better than old Ioab, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe, he had more re≈øpect to reuenge the iniuries done to others, than vnto their ≈øeruices pa≈øt. If Dauid had not been welbeloued, and by Scripture commended, his Te≈øtament ≈øhould much haue ≈øcandalized vs, ≈øeeing that at the time of his death when men forbid iniuries, hee commandeth by his Te≈øtament to take away mens liues. It is to be beleeued, that he being ≈øo acceptable to God as he was, that he had con≈øulted with God, for otherwi≈øe being in ≈øo narrow a ≈øtraight as he was in, it was more than time for him to prepare him≈øelfe to confe≈ø≈øe his ≈øins, than to command the death of his enemies. O how vnlike Dauids Te≈øtament is vnto Chri≈øts, for Dauid commaunded in his to reuenge other mens deaths, but Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Redeemer commanded his owne proper death to be pardoned. How happy we be which be the inheritours of Chri≈øt, and how vnhappy they be which bee the ≈øucce≈ø≈øours of Dauid, which is ea≈øily ≈øeene by their Te≈øtaments, for Dauids ≈øoule goeth out of his body, ≈øaying, Filine igno≈øcas illis, and Chri≈øt yeeldeth his la≈øt breath, ≈øaying, Pater igno≈øce illis, What ≈øimilitude is in this, when the one commaundeth to ≈ølay Ioab, who neuer once touched ≈øo much as his garment, and the ≈øonne of God willeth to forgiue tho≈øe which
tooke away his life? How would Dauid forgiue his owne death, ≈øeeing he commandeth to reuenge another mans? wilt thou ≈øee the difference betwixt the charity of the one, and the goodne≈ø≈øe of the other? Thou maie≈øt ≈øee it in that, that king Dauid would not pardon Ioab and Simei, who≈øe ≈øinnes were ≈øo old that they were forgotten: and meeke Ie≈øus did pardon the Iewes, who≈øe wickednes was new and fre≈øh. How woulde≈øt thou haue the wounds of him vvho pardoneth, more fre≈øher, and the wickedne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe which are pardoned more newer, but to haue them at the ≈øame time crucifieng as he is pardoning. Aymon ≈øayth, Much good may Dauids Te≈øtament doe him, which hee made being annointed, for I will hold with that which Chri≈øt made when he was crucified, for the one ≈øeeketh out tho≈øe which are culpable to kill, and the other ≈øeeketh out faults to pardon. Saint Augustine vpon our Lords wordes ≈øaith, O how much better it is to fall into the hands of God then into the hands of men, which is ea≈øily ≈øeene in the death of king Dauid, and in the death of the ≈øonne of God, where the one commandeth to ≈ølay his owne ≈øeruants, and the other willeth pardon to his cruel enemies. Hugo de ≈øancte victore ≈øayth, I do not enuy king Salomon for the kingdome which king Dauid his father left him, nor for his will which he commaÃÑded him to accompli≈øh, becau≈øe he left him the heire of his kingdome with ≈øuch a condition, that wheÃÑ he ≈øhould giue the la≈øt ga≈øpe, the other ≈øhould pre≈øently begin to murder and kill. In the ≈øame day and in the ≈øame houre that good king Dauid died, as the captaine Ioab was in the Temple a praying, kind Salomon ≈øent immediately to ≈øley him, in≈øomuch that before they could put Dauid in his graue, they tooke away poor Ioabs life. O my good Ie≈øus, the conditions of thy Te≈øtament be not like vnto the≈øe, ≈øeeing that in the la≈øt farwell on the altar of the cro≈ø≈øe, thou didde≈øt not command thy ≈øucce≈ø≈øors to reuenge, but to forgiue, nor to take away mens liues, but to pardon iniuries, ≈øo that as the Synagogue was a hou≈øe of buying and ≈øelling, ≈øo thou made≈øt thy church a hou≈øe of pardon. Chri≈øt him≈øelfe did whip tho≈øe
who bought and ≈øold in the Temple, and the ≈øelfe≈øame ≈øon of God did pardon tho≈øe whom he found in his hou≈øe of pardon: whereof wee may inferre, that he is no inhabitant of his hou≈øe, who dareth reuenge an iniury. Chri≈øt did ≈øhew him≈øelfe to be the ≈øonne of Dauid, in being meeke as hee was, but he ≈øhewed it not in being vindicatiue as he was, for when he died vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, he did not leaue in al the world any one ≈øinne to forgiue, nor any iniury for his heires to reuenge. If as Dauid did command to reueÃÑge the mi≈ødemeanour which his ≈øeruants did him, Chri≈øt ≈øhould haue commanded to reuenge the ≈øinnes which the Iewes committed again≈øt him, it had not been po≈øsible to haue been done, becau≈øe the ≈øinners had too many ≈øinnes, and the tormentors wanted torments.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the difference betwixt the bloud of Abel and the bloud of Chri≈øt, and how vnlike their cries vnto God are.
div.p:
ACce≈øsi≈øtis ad ≈øanguinis a≈øper≈øionem, melius loquentem quam Abel, ≈øayth the Apo≈øtle writing vnto the Hebrewes, chap. 9, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, We are very happy which beleeue in Chri≈øt, and receiue his go≈øpel, ≈øeeing wee bee redeemed by his death, and bought with his precious bloud. And becau≈øe thou maie≈øt the better e≈øteeme of the price of this bloud, know thou that it crieth before the eternal father better than the bloud of Abel, becau≈øe that cried Iu≈øtice, Iu≈øtice, and the bloud of the ≈øonne of God crieth Mercy, Mercy. S. Ierome ≈øayth, The Apo≈øtle dooth highly ≈øet forth the bloud of Chri≈øt, who≈øe ≈øoueraine price and high merit hee would not compare with the other blouds of the old Te≈øtament, but with the bloud of the fir≈øt iu≈øt man that euer was in
the world, the bloud of the holie≈øt ≈øaint that is in heauen. Origen ≈øaith, The Apo≈øtle ≈øhould haue done Chri≈øt great iniury, if hee ≈øhould haue compared his bloud with the bloud of calues and goats of the old Te≈øtament, becau≈øe the bloud of tho≈øe bea≈øtes did ≈øerue to no other purpo≈øe but to defile the ≈øtaires, and to take away their liues: but the bloud of the ≈øon of God dooth wa≈øh and make cleane offences, and ≈øaue our ≈øouls. The fir≈øt bloud with the which God was offended, was the bloud of Abel; and the fir≈øt bloud with which God was plea≈øed, was the bloud of Chri≈øt; and that which is mo≈øt to be wondered at is, that the bloud of Abel did benefite but him≈øelfe alone, but the bloud of Chri≈øt did profite all the world. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øayth, What bloud can be compared vnto the bloud of Chri≈øt? for the bloud of Abel did ≈øtirre vp, and not appea≈øe, ≈øeeing that thereby hee lo≈øt his life, and his brother his ≈øoule: The bloud which thou did≈øt ≈øhed for mee O ≈øweet Ie≈øus, did not ≈øtirre vp, but appea≈øe, becau≈øe it did pacifie the fathers anger, tooke away thy owne life, and redeemed my ≈øoule.
